column2: A picture caption on Monday with an article about first-round games in the N.C.A.A. women's basketball tournament carried an erroneous credit. The photograph of the game between Florida and Ohio State was by J. D. Pooley of The Associated Press; it was not a ''pool photo by J. D. Ey.'' The error was repeated in some editions on Wednesday in credits for pictures of Baylor's Brittney Griner playing against Florida.
Images from campaign stops and polling places in Illinois and Louisiana.
How the parties have used or tried to use an invented word to shape public opinion.
Kentucky reached the Final Four with a dominant win over Baylor, 82-70. Kansas defeated North Carolina, 80-67, to earn its second berth in five years.
Performers at the Chocolate Factory, in a sea of tennis balls, animate David Foster Wallace’s brilliant, funny, self-conscious writer’s voice.
A revival of “Lost in Yonkers” at the Beckett Theater is warmly satisfying, with a depth of character, humanity and personal investment.
An investor who expects a stock to fall in price may execute a short sale. If the price of the stock does fall, he can make a profit.

Politicians and analysts in Massachusetts explain the nuances of a relationship that brought together the Republican candidate and the iconic Democratic senator.

A look back at some of the film and television adaptations of fairy tales.
The Ethicist asks readers to make an ethical case for eating meat.
Why do some New York nannies earn more than doctors? Faulty economics (for starters), but also because they can groom horses and speak Mandarin.
The historian Elaine Pagels has been a popular, though polarizing, figure ever since she introduced readers to early competing views of Christianity in her 1979 book “The Gnostic Gospels.”

FOR Henry Evans, a self-taught artist who began making linoleum-block prints in 1958, nature was his subject matter. (His wife, Marsha, did the actual printing.) Mr. Evans favored bright colors, capturing the essence of plants like California poppies, roses, daffodils and tulips. The persimmons he illustrated were the first fruit from a tree that he planted himself. Mr. Evans died in 1990, but his wife continues the business in St. Helena, Calif., producing calendars and note card sets of her husband's prints and selling the prints themselves, all of which are available at henryevans.com. An exhibition of Mr. Evans's prints will be on view at the Thacher Gallery and the Donohue Rare Book Room at the University of San Francisco through April 22. BROOKE HODGE

An entry on the paperback advice best-seller list on March 11 for ''Act Like a Lady, Think Like a Man'' omitted the name of the co-author with whom Steve Harvey wrote the book. She is Denene Millner. The error was repeated last Sunday.
Suggestions for what you'd like Jason to see and draw may be sent to thingsisaw @nytimes.com

The award for the week's best dressed goes not to any pedestrian, as stylish as the ones here were, but to Mother Nature, decked resplendently throughout town: magnolias at the Frick Collection and Central Park, forsythia along the park's transverses, fruit trees on the streets and hyacinths in Bryant Park.

In a continuing effort to distance himself from News Corporation's embattled British newspaper unit, James Murdoch has stepped down from the board of Times Newspapers Holdings. The group, established by Rupert Murdoch, chief executive of News Corporation and James's father, was created to safeguard the editorial independence of The Times of London and The Sunday Times after the media conglomerate bought the British newspapers in 1981, according to public filings with the British government.

ROSEN--Anna (nee Clapman), beloved wife of Nathan for 63 years; devoted father of Karen and Ross, Philip and Lois; cherished grandfather of Jessica, Catie, Allison and Rachel. Chapel Services will be held at 11:15am on March 26, 2012 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St., New York, NY. (212) 362-6600.

IT wasn't your traditional sample sale. On a recent lunch hour, a stream of well-coiffed professional women descended upon a salon in the Flatiron district of Manhattan. They weren't tearing through boxes of designer shoes or ripping through racks of clothing. These women came looking for something more personal: wigs. These were no ordinary wigs, however. These were custom creations by Hadiiya Barbel, a stylist and wig maker to the stars. And as Ms. Barbel zipped about the salon in a black jumpsuit and leopard flats, she made it abundantly clear that she'd prefer her customers not use the W-word.

TRUBOWITZ--Dr. Sidney. 8/25/1911-3/19/2010 Your memory will always be as a blessing. Your loving family, Ethel, Eugene, Rachel, Ella, Jascha, Simon, Charlotte

ASK Dutch or Danish riders about the bicycling subculture back home, and they are likely to give you a quizzical look: ''Subculture?'' Because bicycles are so entrenched in the daily lives there, both the Netherlands and Denmark have official cycling embassies. It should be no surprise that Amsterdam and Copenhagen have obsessive types who catalog their city's parade of two-wheel street style. Marc van Woudenberg, of the blog Amsterdamize.com, and Mikael Colville-Andersen, of CopenhagenCycleChic.com, agree that their respective cycling cultures are more alike than different. ''It's as normal as running water,'' Mr. Van Woudenberg said. Mr. Colville-Andersen added, ''We don't fetishize it.'' A slide show of street-style shots from both blogs establishes that in both Amsterdam and Copenhagen, women on bikes rule the roads. ABBY AGUIRRE
Manhattan Union Square Area $355,000

LEVY--Barbara H. Barbara H. Levy, passed away on March 10, 2012. She was born Barbara Jane Henly on April 6, 1927 in Minneapolis, MN, and grew up in St. Paul. The daughter of a pianist, she began cello studies as a child. She continued to pursue her music career in New York while she attended Barnard College. Shortly after graduation in 1948, she met S Jay Levy who she married a few months later. Early in her music career she won the distinguished Piatigorsky prize at Tanglewood. She studied with Diran Alexanian, Zara Nelsova and Ernst Rosenberg. She performed as a soloist and with chamber music groups in broadcasts on WNYC and WQXR and at Carnegie Recital Hall. In Westchester she was a member of the Afternoon Chamber Players. A longtime member of Temple Beth El in Chappaqua, NY, she is fondly remembered for her annual performance of the Kol Nidre at the Yom Kippur service. She shared her joy of music with many students as a private cello teacher. She was active as a volunteer and supporter of numerous causes including Barnard College scholarships, Planned Parenthood, and English as a Second Language. She is survived by her loving husband of 63 years, S Jay Levy and her children, Ann Levy, David A. Levy, and Joshua R. Levy as well as her grandchildren Claire Levy, Hannah Levy, Noah Simms-Levy, and Alice Levy. A private service was held at her home. Donations in lieu of flowers can be sent to Barnard College or a cause she would have valued.

A FAMILY reunion of sorts is taking place at the Vineyard Theater, where the new musical ''NOW. HERE. THIS.'' opens this week. The gang that brought the world ''[title of show],'' the infectious and seriously self-referential musical with a similarly eccentric title, has reunited to create a show that promises to be just as idiosyncratic and as personal as their first. Hunter Bell and Susan Blackwell have written the book, while the songs are by Jeff Bowen. Mr. Bowen and Mr. Bell were the authors of ''[title of show],'' which began life at the Vineyard before moving to Broadway.
The Gray Matter column on bilingualism last Sunday misspelled the name of a university in Spain. It is Pompeu Fabra, not Pompea Fabra.

FRIEDMANN--David, Beloved husband of Edith West and uncle to Gene, Dan and Robynne, passed away peacefully on March 23. Funeral Services at Schwartz Bros, Forest Hills, Sunday, March 25th at 10am. Graveside service at Beth Moses Cemetery to follow. Shiva at the home of Edith West in Forest Hills. Dave will be missed for his bountiful heart, his big smile and his sense of humor.

ROBARDS--Lois O'Connor, 75, died peacefully at home in New York City on March 17. Before her marriage in 1970 to actor Jason Robards, she was one of the first women hired in television production at both Talent Associates and Filmways Productions, and worked on shows including Playhouse 90, The Patty Duke Show, Get Smart, The Steve Allen Show, The David Susskind Show, and Good Company with F. Lee Bailey, where the last featured such notable guests as Ernest Hemingway, J. Paul Getty, and Rev. Martin Luther King, Jr. In Hollywood she worked with director Sam Peckinpah on films including Noon Wine, where she first met her future husband. Behind the scenes, she was a foundation for Mr. Robards' personal and professional success, which included his iconic roles in Moon for the Misbegotten and All the President's Men. Lois will be remembered for her elegance, intelligence, and above all, generosity. She was devoted to her children, Shannon and Jake, and her large extended family. She was an active supporter of the Westport Country Playhouse, the Brain Tumor Foundation, the American Classical Orchestra, and the Roundabout Theater Company, which gives an award in her husband's name each year. Lois lived in Southport, CT, for 30 years and subsequently in New York City. In addition to her two children, she is survived by four grandchildren and four stepchildren. A funeral mass will be held on Monday, March 26, at 3:00pm at St. Ignatius Loyola, 980 Park Avenue New York City. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made in her name to the American Classical Orchestra or the Inner-City Foundation of Bridgeport, CT.

An article on March 11 about Rob Will, a death row inmate in Texas, misstated the circumstances surrounding the removal of Leslie Ribnik, Mr. Will's state-appointed habeas lawyer, from the list of approved death-penalty-defense lawyers. Mr. Ribnik asked to be removed from the list; he was not removed because of his performance.

Robert Griffin III rescheduled his pro day workout at Baylor University to Wednesday from Thursday so he could have the day all to himself. He would perform passing drills one day before Andrew Luck, another top prospect, and with no N.C.A.A. basketball or other diversions on the schedule, Griffin's workout could command the undivided attention of the sports news media. That plan did not work out.

VOLK--Kenneth Hohne. Admiralty lawyer Kenneth Hohne Volk died in his home in Portsmouth, NH, on March 19. He was 89 years old, and the cause of death was cancer. He was born in 1922, the son of Henry and Constance Brady Volk, and spent his early years in West Englewood, NJ. His college education at Cornell was interupted by World War II, when he joined the Navy and from there was appointed to the US Naval Academy. He graduated in 1946. After serving on a destroyer with the Sixth Fleet, he resigned his commission to study law. He graduated from Yale Law School with honors (Order of the Coif) in 1953. Volk joined the law firm Shearman, Sterling and Wright in New York City the year he graduated. In 1954, he married Joyce Geary, whose father was a prominent admiralty lawyer in San Francisco. Through his wife, he met several young maritime attorneys in the city, and envied their stories about their careers in a new and fascinating field to him. In 1956, he joined the firm of Burlingham, Hupper and Kennedy in the city, a firm specializing in the practice of maritime law. He spent the rest of his working life in admiralty law, participating in many of the most notable cases of the era. These included representing the Italian Line in connection with the Andrea Doria-Stockholm collision off Nantucket in July 1956, the Santa Rosa-Valchem collision off New Jersey in January 1957, and the Torrey Canyon grounding off England in 1967. Other cases were the Seawitch-Esso Brussels collison in New York harbor in 1973, and the Salem sinking off the west coast of Africa in 1980, one of the largest maritime fraud cases in history. He was a frequent contributor to legal periodicals, writing and lecturing on many area of maritime law. He was elected President of the Maritime Law Association of the United States from1990 to 1992. He was also a member of the Tulane University Maritime Law Advisory Board, and belonged to many other professional organizations including the America College of Trial Lawyers, and a Titulary Member of the Comite Maritime Internationale. He was a life member of the American Bar Association. When he retired from the Burlingham firm in 1992, he and his wife moved to Portsmouth, NH, where he continued his practice of law as counsel to the firm of McLane, Graf, Raulerson & Middleton. One of the most interesting of the matters in which he was involved while there was the 1989 Exxon Valdez oil spill in Alaska. He was appointed by Lloyd's of London as one of three arbitrators in their dispute with Exxon over the extent of insurance coverage. He resigned as counsel to the McLane firm at the end of 2010. He is survived by his wife, Joyce; their son, Christopher and his wife Hollis and their two children, Emma and Chambers; and their daughter, Cynthia, and her three children, Charles, Clementine, and Della Sainty. A memorial service will be held April 28 at 4:00pm at the South Church in Portsmouth. In lieu of flowers, gifts in his memory may be made to The Seaman's Church Institute, 241 Water Street, New York, NY 10038, or to the charity of your choice.

TISDALE--Stuart. August 15, 1928, died March 21, 2012, at his Milwaukee home. Beloved husband of Ann Howard Tisdale and father of five loving sons and two stepsons. Stu graduated from Yale University in 1951. Donations appreciated to a vocational rehabilitation program he supported, Grand Avenue Club, 210 E. Michigan Ave., Milwaukee, WI, 53202, or to a school of your choice.

WITH Snooki pregnant and a sixth season in limbo, ''Jersey Shore'' as we know it may have come to an end. But for Paul DelVecchio, the peacockish housemate otherwise known as Pauly D, the party is just getting started. ''THE PAULY D PROJECT,'' a spinoff to have its premiere Thursday at 10:30 p.m. on MTV, follows Mr. DelVecchio as he resurrects, with a little help from some childhood pals, the D.J. career that flagged when he joined the reality show. It's ''Entourage,'' Rhode Island style, with a cast featuring Ryan Labbe, Mr. DelVecchio's best friend and wingman; Gerard Gialanella, known as Big Jerry, his security force; and Michael Morgan (Biggie), his mentor, and the only man with a girlfriend. ''No strip clubs, no whores,'' that girlfriend advises the posse as it departs for Las Vegas, where Mr. DelVecchio will man the turntables at the Palms Casino Resort and conquer the town under the guidance of Jason Craig (JROC), before opening for Britney Spears's ''Femme Fatale Tour.'' And along with Mr. DelVecchio's ubiquitous wind-tunnel blowout there's the requisite fresh ink -- this time in the form of his signature on a contract with G-Note Records, the a label of the rapper 50 Cent.

GITTLEMAN--Arne G.,87. On March 21, 2012, the world lost an original and a giant in the car and Ad world. Arne G. Gittleman of Wilton, CT., Lake Forest, IL., and New York City, died of complications from Parkinson's Disease. Born in Brooklyn, NY., and married to "Stevie" Gittleman for 56 years, Arne leaves behind daughters Jane Gittleman-Poole of Los Angeles, and Polly E. Wing of Miami, his son-in-law Doug Poole, and grandchildren, Christopher, Sarah, Chelsey, and Emma. Arne was a decorated First Lieutenant, and Navigator in WWII, and earned four Battle Stars, and a Distinguished Unit Badge. He graduated from Michigan University with a BA, and went on to be in the first MBA graduating class at Michigan. After working at several newspapers and magazines, he was part of the start-up of Car & Driver Magazine. He achieved his lifelong dream and worked at the New Yorker Magazine for over 36 years as Automotive Advertising Manager. He was an icon in the industry in Detroit, Chicago, and on both coasts. A dedicated husband, father, friend, and jazz afficianado he will be missed by all. Memorial service to be announced.

YATSU--Dr. Frank M.,79, died unexpectedly but peacefully March 9, 2012 at home, leaving devoted wife of 56 years, Michiko; loving daughter Libby (Ben); grandchildren Katie, Sophia. Born 1932 Los Angeles. Graduated Phillips Academy, Brown University, CWRU, Neurological Institute of New York. Career at UCSF, Chairs of Neurology at Oregon HSC and UTHSC, Houston. World renowned Neurologist, leader in stroke awareness. Memorial services: Rothko Chapel, Houston, Sunday, March 25, 1pm. Visit Frank's website: www.earthmanbellaire.com

For weeks now, something resembling spring has hung awkwardly in the air. January was oddly balmy, February disquietingly snowless. Even with the calendar still declaring winter, forsythias, phlox and magnolias were already abloom. But at 1:14 a.m. Tuesday, the calendar caught up with the weather. Spring has officially arrived, and with it this chronicle. Two seasons ago on City Room, I traced autumn's unfolding on a boulder-strewn ridge in Upper Manhattan. Beginning today, I will offer weekly dispatches from a low patch of Staten Island woodland bisected by a trickling brook.

SHIPPEE--Nathan Mathewson, 92, of Old Lyme, CT, died peacefully at his home March 20, 2012. He was born May 1, 1919 in Providence, Rhode Island to Harold Robinson and Beatrice Wright Shippee. He is survived by his adoring wife of 45 years, Patricia Morel Shippee. A graduate of Rhode Island State College, Mr. Shippee served in the US Army from 1941 to 1945, and was promoted to major and awarded the Bronze Star for his role in re-opening the port of Port du Bouc in Southern France, following previous landings in Casablanca and Anzio. In 1969, on the 25th anniversary of the liberation of Port du Bouc, Mr. Shippee was decorated by the French government with the L'Ordre du Merite Maritime. In 1946 Mr. Shippee joined Chase National Bank and moved to Shanghai, China where he worked to help re-open the bank's office there. On his return in 1948, Mr. Shippee began his 65-year career in business, founding Inpak Systems and Prudential Oil Corporation, later called Prudential Funds. Working closely with his wife, Patricia, they opened Old Lyme Art Works Gallery and Shippee Gallery on Madison Avenue in New York City. Patricia Shippee continues as an accredited senior fine art appraiser. Mr. Shippee's survival of the crash of Mohawk Airways flight 121 in 1963 changed his outlook and philosophy of life, and led to publication of three books: Becoming, Coming Into Being (1979); The Human Being (2001); and BEING, The Radiant Force Within, the Autobiography of My Soul (2008). In addition to his wife, Patricia, he is survived by his four children from his first marriage: Dr. Elizabeth Shippee Boylan of Larchmont, NY; Robert Wright Shippee of Greenwich, CT; Richard Robinson Shippee of New York City; Rev. Arthur Bradford Shippee of Hamden, CT; and their spouses. He is also leaves five grandchildren, one great-grandchild and his former wife, Elizabeth, of Greenwich, CT. In lieu of contributions, the family reminds friends of his encouragement to always show kindness and respect to every Human Being, and to "keep a curve in your cheek." A memorial celebration of Nathan Shippee's life as an exceptional Human Being will be held at a later date. Additional details about his life may be found at www.neilanfuneralhome.com.

MacGUIGAN--Duncan, 1950-2012. We at Acquavella Galleries are deeply saddened by the death of our esteemed former Director, Duncan MacGuigan. During his thirty years at Acquavella Galleries, Duncan was a great friend and a knowledgeable and influential art dealer with a great eye for quality. We are proud of his many years of loyal service and will miss him dearly. Duncan had a variety of interests which encompassed all manner of musical idioms, running the marathon (more than once), and his beloved Boston Red Sox. The Acquavella Family and Acquavella Galleries

A TALL man with a cloud of white hair and pants with suspenders, Charles Bello is the sort of guy whose choices were not the obvious ones. Though he had the résumé for a successful career in architecture -- he was an intern for Richard Neutra in the 1950s, and also worked for the architect Henry Hill and the landscape architect Robert Royston -- Mr. Bello chose to become a steward of the land. It happened after meeting the Italian engineer Pier Luigi Nervi. Mr. Bello asked Mr. Nervi if he thought his ferroconcrete curvilinear forms could be done in wood, and Mr. Nervi said: ''There is no wood in Italy. Go home and do it in California.'' So he did. In 1968, on 400 acres in the redwoods of Northern California, Mr. Bello and his wife, Vanna Rae, began to build what has become a handcrafted compound of structures, bridges, trails and houses. The newest building is the art gallery (right), which showcases Mr. Bello's wood sculptures, including one carved from a massive piece of redwood that was struck by lightning, and has a roof made of lattice and a translucent material that makes the light inside it glow. For more about Mr. Bello and his organization, the Redwood Forest Institute, go to savetrees.org. LESLIE WILLIAMSON

BACK in 2008 the Swedish sister folk duo FIRST AID KIT first made a name for itself by retreating to the woods. In a forest near their home Johanna and Klara Soderberg recorded an intoxicating cover of Fleet Foxes' ''Tiger Mountain Peasant Song'' that became a YouTube hit, getting the attention of the Foxes themselves. A few years later First Aid Kit retreated again, this time to Omaha to work with Mike Mogis. He's a producer, studio owner and musician who was central to the rise of the influential Omaha indie-rock label Saddle Creek Records, home to Bright Eyes, Cursive and more. The Soderbergs met Mr. Mogis on tour -- they played alongside Bright Eyes, which Mr. Mogis had joined -- and he agreed to produce their second full-length album, ''The Lion's Roar'' (Wichita), which was released in January. Vigorous Saddle Creek pastoralism is the mood of the new album. The Soderbergs' vocals sound robust, and the music is more urgent and fuller bodied than the duo's previous work, which was winningly naïve. Now the songs are sturdy; they announce themselves loudly, hiding from nothing. Wednesday at 8 p.m., Webster Hall, 125 East 11th Street, East Village, (212) 353-1600, websterhall.com; $20.

AT church, where the celebration begins, there is deferential silence. The girls -- they are called quinceañeras, or the ones who are turning 15 -- sit before the altar, like offerings adorned in ruffles and sequins. Then they change from flats to high heels, from gowns to dresses that hug their bodies in a tight, tight embrace. At the party hall, the music is too loud for conversation, but not loud enough to keep exhausted children awake.

THE Toyota Prius C, with a combined E.P.A. fuel-economy rating of 50 miles per gallon, is in such demand that a dealer in Florida reportedly levied a $7,000 premium on the $19,710 vehicle, a scaled-down version of the class-leading hybrid. Toyota, which began sales of the C on March 12, sold more units in its first three days than either Chevrolet, with its plug-in-hybrid Volt, or Nissan, with its purely electric Leaf, managed in all of February.

TWEED--Reverend John Gregory, died March 20th from complications of heart disease in Santa Fe, NM. Greg had an impact on everyone he met-as a chaplain, an early pioneer in AIDS outreach, an author, and later as a painter. A graduate of Yale Divinity School, he became Senior Pastor of the Middle Collegiate Church in Manhattan. He was involved with the first efforts in Manhattan to provide hospice care to AIDS patients. Greg left his mark on the world in countless ways, including his forgiveness, intelligence, wit, humor, love, and abiding good cheer.

A RELATIVELY new field, called interpersonal neurobiology, draws its vigor from one of the great discoveries of our era: that the brain is constantly rewiring itself based on daily life. In the end, what we pay the most attention to defines us. How you choose to spend the irreplaceable hours of your life literally transforms you. All relationships change the brain -- but most important are the intimate bonds that foster or fail us, altering the delicate circuits that shape memories, emotions and that ultimate souvenir, the self.

New York University's latest proposal to expand its Greenwich Village campus seeks to add some 2.5 million square feet of new construction to the two superblocks the university owns below Washington Square Park. Somewhere between the school's grand plans, which imagine giant crescent-shaped towers in the open space between the two 1950s apartment slabs of the Washington Square Village housing complex, and the neighborhood's need for open space and porous streets, is a middle ground preferred by Michael Kimmelman.
FISHMAN--Julius. March, 26, 1980-We miss and love you. Please take care of Mommy and Susie.

Once during a disagreement with my husband, I complained that he wasn't helping enough with our daughter, and I gave him a long list of the parenting chores I was shouldering on my own. ''But you like doing all that stuff,'' he blurted in his defense. I don't recall how the conversation ended (probably badly), but I thought of it while reading a new study about the more mundane responsibilities of parenting. Researchers asked 181 heterosexual college professors who had children 2 or younger to rate, on a scale of 1 to 5, the pleasure they experienced from child care. On 16 out of 25 child-care tasks -- like changing diapers, taking a child to the doctor or getting up in the middle of a night to attend to a child -- women reported statistically significant higher levels of enjoyment than men. The only parenting issue that gave women less pleasure than it gave men was having to manage who does what for the child. Over all, women's scores were 10 percent higher than men's.

The curious and energetic 15-year-old actress plays Clove in ''The Hunger Games,'' which opened Friday. Here, she shares her makeup tips with T. Q. Your makeup bag is full of goodies. What's in there?

SUTNER--Robert F. May 16, 1930-March 22, 2012. Robert Sutner, 81, of Irvington, died peacefully on Thursday night in White Plains Hospital surrounded by his children. He was an Army veteran of the Korean War era. He earned an MBA from Baruch College and attended the London School of Economics. He later lived in and worked in the financial services industry in Europe, Mexico, Canada and in Manhattan. His wife, Charlotte, died in 1995. He leaves his beloved partner of 15 years, Karen Ganz, of Irvington; four children, Adam, of Vail, CO, Arianne, of Portland, OR, Joshua, of Vail, and Shaun, of Worcester, MA; four grandchildren; and Karen's children, David, of Montclair, NJ, and Beth, of Denver. The funeral service is Sunday, March 25 at 9:45am, at Riverside Chapel, 21 Broad Street West, Mount Vernon, NY. Burial is at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pine Lawn, NY. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Breast Cancer Research Foundation or other charities.

An article on March 11 about the transformation of the young-adult novel ''The Hunger Games'' into a movie misstated the title of another novel that has caught Hollywood's attention and described its theme incorrectly. The novel, ''The Fault in Our Stars'' -- not ''A Fault in Our Stars'' -- takes place in present-day Indianapolis and does not have a dystopian theme. A correction in this space last Sunday about the title repeated the error about the theme.
An article last Sunday about the effect Andy Pettitte's return to the Yankees will have on the pitching rotation misstated the number of his career regular-season victories. He has 240, not 230.

In honor of the long-awaited return of ''Mad Men,'' the Big City Book Club is getting in the spirit of 1960s Manhattan. Our next selection is James Baldwin's 1962 novel, ''Another Country,'' which chronicles the descent of the jazz drummer Rufus Scott. Baldwin recreates the world of Greenwich Village bohemians for an examination of race, emotional denial, professional rivalry, tortured marriages and other subjects that the AMC series has mined so well. The online conversation takes place April 4 at a new time, from 7 to 10 p.m. To join the Book Club and receive updates about book selections and chats, send an e-mail to bigcity@nytimes.com with the subject line ''Join.''

Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the Knicks' 102-88 victory over the Indiana Pacers gave an outdated name in some editions for the Pacers' home arena. It is Bankers Life Fieldhouse, no longer Conseco Fieldhouse. (That was its name from 1999 until December 2011.)

HABER--Franklin R. Died unexpectedly at age 72 on March 19, 2012, of complications following open-heart surgery. A noted motion picture sound mixer and engineer for over 30 years, Frank was the beloved husband of Molly Nelson-Haber, the cherished brother-in-law of Thomas Nelson and Eileen Brady Nelson, and the adored uncle of T. Podcast Scheduled to appear this week: Jeanette Winterson on her new memoir, ''Why Be Happy When You Could Be Normal?''; Charles McGrath on James Dodson's ''American Triumvirate: Sam Snead, Byron Nelson, Ben Hogan, and the Modern Age of Golf''; Julie Bosman with notes from the field; and Gregory Cowles with best-/seller news. Former Vice President Dick Cheney had a heart transplant on Saturday after 20 months on a waiting list, and was recovering in a Virginia hospital, a statement from his office said. Mr. Cheney, 71, who has suffered five heart attacks and was in end-stage heart failure, was recovering in the intensive care unit of Inova Fairfax Hospital in Falls Church, Va.

An article last Sunday about open office designs misstated the height of a building in Tacoma, Wash., that was occupied by Russell Investments before it moved to a less traditional space in Seattle. It is 12 stories high, not 16.

New York University's latest proposal to expand its Greenwich Village campus seeks to add some 2.5 million square feet of new construction to the two superblocks the university owns below Washington Square Park. Somewhere between the school's grand plans, which imagine giant crescent-shaped towers in the open space between the two 1950s apartment slabs of the Washington Square Village housing complex, and the neighborhood's need for open space and porous streets, is a middle ground preferred by Michael Kimmelman.

PINKAS--Robert Paul. 58, beloved husband, devoted father and caring brother, passed away March 18, 2012 from complications following a double transplant in January. Bob, the first of his family to be born in the United States, was born in Cleveland on November 11, 1953. He is predeceased by his parents, Ludvik and Esther Pinkas, who lived in the former Czechoslovakia and immigrated to Cleveland following World War II. Bob's entrepreneurial spirit was evident early on as his clever reorganization of the local paper route landed him an esteemed scholarship to The Hotchkiss School. Continuing on scholarship, he then attended Harvard University as a George F. Baker Scholar. He rowed lightweight on the Varsity Crew team, walked onto the cross-country team, and received both his AB in Government and AM in Intellectual History in four years. After graduating, he was awarded a scholarship to the University of Pennsylvania Law School where he received his JD before beginning his career as a lawyer at Simpson Thacher & Bartlett in New York, where he worked for two years. Transitioning away from law, Bob moved back to Cleveland with McKinsey & Co. in 1980, and in 1984 founded his own firm, Brantley Partners, above the garage of his home on Brantley Road in Shaker Heights. Focusing on venture capital and private equity investments, Bob built a successful portfolio of business over the following 25 years. He served on dozens of corporate boards nationwide, as well as the boards of The Cleveland Playhouse and Hathaway Brown School, and was a member of the Visiting Committee to the College of Harvard University. Bob had a strong commitment to education, which stemmed from his deep belief in giving back. At Harvard he established a professorship in Engineering and Applied Sciences, as well as a scholarship program for financial aid students. Bob's passions and pride revolved around his family, which was always his priority. Bob lived a full and loving life. He was a devoted husband to Jane and a remarkable father to his five children, Robbie, Callie, Benny, Lissa and Katie. He is also survived by his older brother Morton A. Pierce, and nephews Matthew (Silvia) and Nicholas. The Pinkas family would like to sincerely acknowledge and thank The Cleveland Clinic's entire kidney and liver teams for their support these past two years, and especially recognize the unconditional guidance they received from Dr. Titte Srinivas. His burial was private, and a memorial service will be held Saturday, April 7, 2012 at 4:00pm at The Shaker Heights Country Club, 3300 Courtland Blvd, Shaker Heights, OH. For those who wish to honor his memory with a gift, his family would request donations to either the Robert Pinkas Scholarship Fund at Harvard University, c/o Harvard Recording Secretary, 124 Mount Auburn St., Cambridge, MA 02138, or The Cleveland Clinic, 9500 Euclid Avenue Cleveland, OH 44195. For additional information, directions, complete obituary and guestbook, please log online to: www.Brown-Forward.com Brown-Forward Service 216-752-1200

KREUTZER--Ethel, peacefully at 94. Mother of Jeffrey Gorney, Vicki and Jack Lang. Grandmother of Michelle and Daren Levis and great-grandmother of Charlie and Henry. Widow of Mike Kreutzer. Our condolences to her children and grandchildren. May their shared memories bring comfort and solace at this sorrowful time. Patrick J. Kelly, MD, FACS, Founding President Michael Schreiber, Chairman Zeesy Schnur, Executive Director

THE Brooklyn Heights mansion where Truman Capote once lived and worked has sold for $12.5 million, making it the biggest sale of the week and the most ever paid for a Brooklyn home, according to city records. Even though the seller, Nicholas Callaway, came down from his original asking price of $18 million, the deal still eclipsed the next-highest sale ever in Brooklyn, earlier this year, by $1.5 million. That town house was also in Brooklyn Heights. The Capote house, at 70 Willow Street, is one of the oldest in the neighborhood. Built in 1839, it features many of the elegant design elements of a bygone era, including 11 fireplaces, 38 windows, and ''Jeffersonian floor-to-ceiling pocket windows and French doors leading to the Federal style columned veranda,'' according to the listing. The 9,000-square-foot five-story house also has two eat-in chef's kitchens, a spacious garden and a private, gated driveway.

He responded ''No, no, no'' when asked if it would be acceptable -- not unacceptable -- to cut a ballad and the choruses from his musical ''Sweeney Todd.''

MAYERSON--Manuel D.,died in his Cincinnati home on March 22nd at the age of 90. In business he was known as a pioneer in the original development of malls and shopping centers. He was a Founder and Trustee of the International Council of Shopping Centers. Along with the Simon and Buxbaum families he helped build the shopping center industry. Today, the ICSC has more than 60,000 members world-wide and facilitates the development and leasing of tens of millions of square feet of retail space annually. Mr. Mayerson has been a major financial supporter of the Hebrew Union College. As a long-time member of the Board of the college, he helped lead the initiative and formation of HUC's Manhattan Campus and created the Hebrew Union College Mayerson Ethics Center. In honor of his lifetime of service he was given the American Judiasm Award from Hebrew Union College. The family foundation he formed is a national leader in accessibility and rights of the disabled. In addition to numerous disability rights initiatives in the U.S., Mayerson established the Mayerson Inclusive Parks Project in Israel in partnership with the Jewish National Fund. He gave his time and talent to numerous Israeli and American Jewish causes including the Jewish Funds for Justice in which he established the Drip Irrigation Agricultural program, used in Israel, for the Navajo Nation. Mr. Mayerson with his wife Rhoda established The Mayerson Family Foundation. Their tremendous generosity has touched the lives of thousands of people from all walks of life. In addition to supporting key community institutions and smaller non-profit agencies, the foundation has been a major supporter of: Hebrew Union College, Mayerson Academy, created for the professional development of K-12 teachers, The INclusion Network, aimed at full inclusion of people with disabilities in community life, Mayerson Freestore Foodbank Distribution Center, Via Institute on Character, The Mayerson Center for Safe and Healthy Children at Cincinnati's Children's Hospital, and Numerous civic and cultural projects in Israel Manuel and Rhoda spent a lifetime collecting art. As a result of their renowned collection, they have been active supporters and Board members of The Cincinnati Art Museum, The Contemporary Arts Center, and The National Foundation of Jewish Culture. Equally interested in the performing arts, their support and involvement extended to Music Hall, The Cincinnati Symphony, Cincinnati Playhouse in the Park, and SCPA - School for Creative and Performing Arts. Manuel and his wife Rhoda are the parents of Frederic and his wife Dawna, Arlene and her husband Alan, Neal and his wife, Donna, and the grandparents of Amanda, Adam and Emma.

THE composer David Del Tredici has spun out a large part of his output around the works of Lewis Carroll's ''Alice in Wonderland'' and ''Through the Looking Glass.'' He's not the only one inspired by Alice and her adventures. OPERA ON TAP, born as a barroom presenter of arias, and AMERICAN OPERA PROJECTS, a champion of new music-theater works, are offering two evenings of Alician performances, on Sunday and Monday. The major work on the programs is ''Haddock's Eyes,'' a 1986 piece for soprano and large chamber ensemble by Mr. Del Tredici. It is named after the title of a poem sung by the White Knight in ''Looking Glass.'' The programs veer off into very different territory with ''Through the Peeping Glass,'' described as a ''burlesque/cirque'' performance by the burlesque artist Rita MenWeep. Sunday's show includes excerpts from the opera ''Dreaming of Wonderland'' by Manly Romero and on Monday with portions of Susan Botti's opera ''Wonderglass.''

He was a wonderful father to his sons, G. Lawrence, III, of Englewood, CO, Christopher of Bellingham, WA, and Andrew of New York, and to his daughter Lauren Ready of Richardson, TX. His daughter Kelly predeceased him. He was also the adoring grandfather of Christopher and Caitlyn Pepe of Richardson and Ben and Liana Phillips of Bellingham. Gil lived a long and successful life and he will be lovingly remembered and sorely missed by his family and many friends.

Who speaks for the Republican Party? The answer is that everyone does -- and therefore, no one does. What accounts for the division, rancor and lethargy that have beset the party's nominating campaign? It's no great mystery. Republicans have fallen prey to one of the favorite tactics of the heedless, improvident, 21st-century-style capitalism they revere. Their party has been outsourced.

IT'S hard to conceive of a time when electricity was a tough sell, but in the early 20th century the light we now take for granted required its own promotional campaign. The Museum of Modern Art has ELECTRIC CURRENTS, 1900-1940, a collection of the posters that were designed for this purpose and a dozen of them will be on view in the museum's third-floor Architecture and Design Galleries, starting Wednesday. Following the first arc lamps and incandescent filament bulbs of the mid-19th century, electricity transformed every aspect of life, from living rooms to streetscapes. Although it offered myriad possibilities for progress, the innovation was not universally welcomed.

An article last Sunday about the Indian village of Nrityagram, which is completely dedicated to the pursuit of dance, misidentified the theater where the village's troupe, the Nrityagram Dance Ensemble, made its New York debut in 1996. It was the Kaye Playhouse at Hunter College, not the Joyce Theater. The article also misspelled the given name of a Sri Lankan dancer who was observed practicing with the troupe. She is Mithilani Munasingha, not Mithirani.

An article in some editions last Sunday about the New York connections of the Norfolk State men's basketball team misstated the year that Coach Anthony Evans arrived at the university. He was hired as an assistant coach in 2003 -- not in 2007, which was the year he became head coach.

DALY--Owen, II, died March 22, 2012 at home in Lutherville, MD. He was eighty-seven. Born September 4, 1924 in Denver, Colorado where his mother's family had lived since 1879, Owen was the only son of Dorotita O'Donnell and O. Gordon Daly. He had a sister Kathleen who died in 1936. In many ways, Owen's life would mirror that of the man he admired most, his father, who also graduated from Gilman, before rowing crew and captaining the soccer team at Harvard. Owen graduated from The Gilman School in 1943, where he played Varsity football, basketball, baseball, tennis, and lacrosse, while also serving as vice-president of his class junior and senior year. He then attended the Navy V-12 program at the University of Pennsylvania, before serving honorably as an Assistant Gunnery Officer in the Pacific Theater. After the war, he enrolled in Princeton where he majored in politics, played Varsity football, and was a member of The Ivy Club. Graduating from Princeton in the summer of 1948, Owen began a life of banking, first at the Mercantile-Safe Deposit and Trust, and later at the Equitable Trust and Equitable Bancorporation. At the Equitable, he was president and chairman from 1967 to 1982 and was a founding member of VISA International. Owen married Marian Riggs Bailliere on November 17, 1950 in Baltimore, Maryland. In addition to being the longest serving trustee of Gilman School, he was president of the Board from 1969 to 1975. He was a member of the Elkridge, Maryland, and Center Clubs. A devoted Catholic, he was a Knight in the Federal Order of Malta and a parishioner at the Cathedral of Mary Our Queen. He was a founding director of the National Aquarium and AIM and a board member of Goucher College, St. Mary's Seminary, Provident Bank of Philadelphia mutual fund board, Cortland Trust Inc., CFI Steel Corp., Monumental Life Insurance Company, and the Monumental General Insurance Company. He is survived by his wife, Marian Riggs Bailliere, his sons, Owen Daly III, Gordon Bailliere, Clinton Riggs, Thomas O'Donnell, 11 grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. Mr. Daly has requested that any donations made in his name should go to the two institutions he loved most, The Gilman School and St. Mary's Seminary.For more information on services, please visit: www.evansfuneralchapel.com

Kareem Abdul-Jabbar is the only athlete to be voted the most outstanding player of the N.C.A.A. tournament three times - he was known as Lew Alcindor as his U.C.L.A. teams won three championships. He received the first Naismith Award as the college player of the year in 1969 and went on to a 20-year record-setting N.B.A. career. More recently, Abdul-Jabbar became a columnist for ESPN.com and, through his Skyhook Foundation, he produced a documentary focusing on the Harlem Rens, ''On the Shoulders of Giants,'' now on Showtime. In January, he was named a global cultural ambassador for the State Department.

KINGSBURY--Peggy, Died March 21st in Greenport, NY. Right from the start, there was something special about Peggy. She was born on July 4, 1938, in German-occupied Vienna, and grew up all over the world. She and her adoring husband Jim, who were married for 50 years, had three children, Anne, Heather and James, Jr. After they were born, she got a masters in Urban Affairs and Policy Analysis from the New School and worked as deputy director of the city's Office of Management and Budget under Mayor Ed Koch. She later ran her own conference-planning firm, then earned her MSW from Smith College. She was a natural at being in charge. She loved the beach at Point O'Woods where she and Jim built a house, and she took great pleasure and pride in their five grandchildren. The service is Sunday, March 25, 2pm at Holy Trinity Church in Greenport. In lieu of flowers, please donate to The Church at Point O' Woods, Fire Island, NY or CAST, Inc., Southold, NY.

McDERMID--Helen. The lovely Helen Grace Spencer-McDermid. (nee Helen Miller Grace), b. August 28, 1935 passed away peacefully on March 9, 2012, 12:02 pm. She is the daughter of the late Oliver Russell Grace and Anne Inman and stepmother Lorraine Grace. She grew-up in Manhattan, East Hampton and Oyster Bay, New York. She attended the Brearley School in Manhattan, Westover School in Middlebury, CT and Swarthmore College in Pennsylvania. She was married to her first husband, Mr. Oliver Spencer, in 1956 until his untimely passing in 1958. On November 17, 1961 Helen Miller Grace Spencer married Ralph Manewal McDermid, Jr. at Saint Barnabus Church in Greenwich, CT with whom she had four children. She was a longtime resident of Greenwich and a member of the Greenwich Junior League. In the mid 1980's she found peaceful comfort and a spiritual connection with the Community of Jesus in Orleans, MA. She visited the community as often as she could, where members of the Community of Jesus seek to be instruments of the transforming love of Christ, that all may be brought to healing and wholeness in his name. She taught her family everything we know of compassion, generosity and kindness; her love was boundless and her heart would encompass the world. She was stylish, beautiful and elegant, and always surrounded by people who loved her dearly. Family was, hands-down, the most important thing in the world for her. She travelled constantly, visiting with her children and grandchildren, taking them on family trips all over the world, that over the years have kept her family together. She had a sense of humor that was sidesplitting, even when she didn't mean to be. She loved and wrote eloquent poetry and was fluent in French. There are no words to express our deepest sorrow at losing the warmest light in our lives. She created new memories for us everyday, and we found guidance in her unique views on every way to live in this world. She gained strength through faith and knows that her journey into the light of our Lord is a greatness to celebrate! Helen taught unconditional love everyday to her four children Ralph Grace and his wife Margaret, Alice Chilton (Jill) and her husband Erik, Mark Grace, Helen Frances (Fran) and her partner Sylvia. She loved very deeply her five grandchildren Gray, William, Maisie, Noah, and Sorijah. Her mother, Anne Inman, her stepmother Lorraine Grace and her siblings Anne Kelly, Ruth Jervis, Oliver Grace, John Grace, Lori Grace, Wendy Grace, Dr. Edward Kendall, Donna Kendall and cousin Natalie Dejoux, survive her. She enjoyed spoiling her dogs, adorable teacup Maltese, Roger, and the sweet and loyal Irish Wolfhound, Atlanta. Memorial contributions can be made to: Gloriae Dei Artes Foundation, Inc. PO Box 2831, Orleans, MA 02653 .

SPRING weather usually tosses a lot of bad fashion trends onto the city's sidewalks. But this year, with our strangely early spring, the journey between my house and Bergdorf's is absolutely perilous. I worry -- I do! -- about those late-middle-aged women in super-high platforms and skinny J Brand jeans. A ballerina in toe shoes would have more contact with the pavement than these babes do. Women love platform shoes, for their sense of superiority and comfort (relative to other high heels); I love platforms. For 20 years I had a favorite pair of Lagerfeld black suede platforms -- from the era of Karl Lagerfeld's high-fashion label, with crisscross ankle straps -- that almost every year I left at Shoe Service on West 55th Street for a perk-up. As men know, good shoes can be repaired and worn for a long time, and the Lagerfeld platforms, aside from being well made, were a classic sin trap style -- sexy and shapely but rather modest in height.

A picture last Sunday with an article about artist neighborhoods springing up around New York City misidentified a diner pictured in a timeline about Williamsburg, Brooklyn, and its arc as an artist colony. The diner was Relish, not the Miss Williamsburg Diner. (The photograph, captioned incorrectly in The Times's archive, was also published on Feb. 6, 2000.)

CARTER--Matthew G. Matthew G. Carter, the first African-American Mayor and Commissioner of Public Works in Montclair, New Jersey, died from complications of Alzheimer's disease on March 14, at the age of 98 years old. His was a true American story of struggle and accomplishment becoming a prominent religious, civil rights and political leader. Beloved husband of Frances Hill Carter; loving father to Bettye C. Freeman and Nanette Carter; and devoted grandfather to Eva Freeman, Nina Hanlon and Leah Haskin, Matthew Carter's success as a public official stemmed from his strong faith in humanity and in Christianity. He believed overall in man's connection to his fellow man and that these bonds would ultimately bring meaning to our lives. A Memorial Service is planned for April 28, 11:00am at Grace Presbyterian Church, 153 Grove Street, Montclair, New Jersey.

DESPITE its charming look -- rows of ornate, prewar Chinese shophouses in punchy pastels fronted by palm trees -- the Duxton Hill neighborhood in Singapore has a sordid past peppered with hostess bars, gambling dens and police raids. Now, after being deemed a conservation area by city authorities, the area, on the outskirts of Chinatown, has been reborn as a hip enclave better known for its indie culture and fine dining than raucous bachelor parties. Duxton Hill's tranquil, pedestrian-friendly streets make for an easy afternoon stroll among independent shops and cafes or an evening choosing from Singapore's latest culinary experiments, with options ranging from Spanish tapas to Russian delicacies to modern Singaporean, or Mod Sin, cuisine. NAOMI LINDT

It's a happening neighborhood! ... RoughAcres, New York

Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about Gloria Steinem misattributed the statement ''If men could get pregnant, abortion would be a sacrament.'' It was by Florynce Kennedy, a lawyer for Ms. Steinem in the 1970s, not by Ms. Steinem. The article also misidentified Courtney E. Martin's affiliation with the blog Feministing. She is an editor emeritus, not a founder.

A shining era is captured in ''ORDINARY MIRACLES: THE PHOTO LEAGUE'S NEW YORK,'' a documentary account of the Photo League, a cooperative that in the 1930s and '40s exerted a pivotal influence on American photography. Its prevailing aesthetic, a byproduct of the Great Depression, combined ambitious composition with a social-minded agenda. Created by two City College dropouts, Sol Libsohn and the passionate, imposing Sid Grossman, the league attracted luminaries like Dorothea Lange, Weegee and Lisette Model. Its school and exhibitions drew guests like Margaret Bourke-White, Henri Cartier Bresson and Ansel Adams. The league encouraged its members to roam the city and direct an intimate eye at urban subjects, and its newsletter addressed the role of photography in the political climate. But its progressive sensibility made it a victim of the cold war: in 1949 a government informer accused Grossman of being a Communist, and by 1951 the league collapsed. But its spirit endures in this record, narrated by the actor Campbell Scott and featuring 350 wondrous images spanning 15 years. A conversation with the directors, Nina Rosenblum and Daniel Allentuck, follows. Thursday at 8 p.m., IFC Center, 23 Avenue of the Americas, at Third Street, Greenwich Village; (212) 924-7771, ifccenter.com.

Luxury hotels like the Oberoi and the Taj Mahal have long been part of the fabric of Indian hospitality industry, but several high-end hoteliers are starting new outposts in the country. The French hospitality brand Sofitel recently opened its first hotel in India in Mumbai's business district: the Sofitel Mumbai BKC (bathroom, above), named for its location in the Bandra Kurla Complex. The Franco-Spanish designer Isabelle Miaja is the creative mind behind the 302-room property, with contemporary design infused with Indian touches like the metal elephant adorning the North Indian restaurant Jyran. Other restaurants and bars include a French-Indian spot and a Paris-style cafe.

YANNELLA--Donald Joseph, a noted scholar and professor of American Literature, born in New York City, died peacefully on March 3, 2012. He was 77. He is survived by his wife, Kathleen (nee Malone), to whom he was married for more than fifty years, and his five children, Susan Harrigan, Katherine Jennings, and Donald, Christopher, and Clare Yannella, eight grandchildren, and his brother, Philip. The sound of his voice and his humor will be missed.

A cover article this weekend about the Argentine actress Elena Roger, who is starring in a Broadway revival of ''Evita,'' misstates her age and misquotes her when she refers to a song from the show ''What's New, Buenos Aires?'' She is 37, not 39. In quoting the lyrics during an interview, Ms. Roger correctly said, ''Rio de la Plata, Florida, Corrientes, Nueve de Julio.'' -- not ''Rio de la Plata, Florida, Nuevo de Corrientes.'' And because of an editing error, the article misidentifies the actress who originated the role of Fantine in the Broadway production of ''Les Misérables.'' She is Randy Graff, not Patti LuPone.

IN 1987 a program called ''Parallels in Black'' went to Europe, showcasing the work of a group of little-known African-American choreographers. Blondell Cummings, Ralph Lemon, Bebe Miller, Fred Holland and Jawole Willa Jo Zollar were all part of that tour, as was Ishmael Houston-Jones, who organized the first series of Parallels concerts in 1982. Danspace Project has been celebrating the 30th anniversary of Parallels with a series of performances, and on Tuesday it hosts a number of events under the rubric ''THIS & THAT: A DAY OF WALKING, TALKING AND WATCHING.'' At 5.30 p.m. Thomas F. DeFrantz, a professor of dance and African-American studies at Duke University, presents ''Performance Black,'' a lecture of sorts about histories of black dance in the United States. It won't be dull; Mr. DeFrantz is charisma incarnate. It also won't be long: at 6 p.m., Mr. Houston-Jones and Mr. Cummings will talk to Henry Pillsbury and Barbara Watson, the director and assistant director of the American Center in Paris at the time of the group's 1987 performances there. And at 8 p.m. Will Rawls offers ''Coining,'' a screening of works made for film and video that investigate sexuality, politics, gender and black culture -- this and that. St. Mark's Church, 131 East 10th Street, East Village, (866) 811-4111, danspaceproject.org; free.

JetBlue and Korean Air recently announced a partnership allowing fliers to book trips that combine legs on both airlines on a single ticket. The arrangement makes reservations more seamless, has bags forwarded from one carrier to the other without fliers reclaiming them in between and ensures that fliers delayed by one carrier will be helped in reaching their final destination by the other.

The cover story on March 11, about Eva Duarte de Perón's legacy in Buenos Aires, omitted one of the creators of the 1978 musical ''Evita'' and misspelled the surname of the composer who wrote the score. The storyline and lyrics were by Tim Rice; Andrew Lloyd Webber (not ''Weber'') wrote the score. The musical was not solely the creation of Mr. Webber.

ROSA--Ercole, 88, of Bronxville, NY, formerly of Great Neck, on March 21, 2012. Preceded in death by Joyce, his beloved wife and dearest friend for 62 years. Wonderful father to Stephen (Rachel), Karen (Jim King), and Luke. Adoring grandfather of Thea, Lily (Simon Liebel), Claudia, and Angela. Career IBM executive; proud WWII Navy Veteran; adjunct professor; member, American Society of Mechanical Engineers; founder, Eastchester Arts Council. Dad was a visionary man, deeply committed to the common good. He will be sorely missed. Memorial service at a later date.

DAVID FOXLEY introduced the prep company Jack Foxley to service those well-worn men's sweaters and jackets that are in need of some love. Offering sew-on-yourself leather, suede and wax cotton elbow patches in rich colors ($12 a set, plus $3 for shipping), Mr. Foxley makes mending one's favorite blazer or cardigan easier, chic and more affordable. No more bad pleather patches. ''I've received orders from college professors in New England and military colonels in North Carolina,'' Mr. Foxley said. ''The list of characters is long and their correspondence is strikingly colorful.'' Send him a garment, and for a tailoring fee of about $50, Mr. Foxley and his crew will fit, sew and ship it back within two weeks. A hand-written note is included. EDWARD BARSAMIAN

OKADA--Barbra Teri, Dr. Japanese art specialist in Netsuke and Lacquer. Barbra Teri Okada passed away on March 22nd. Barbra Teri Okada was born on August 30, 1935 in New York City to Cecil Reich and William Kantrowitz. She had a MFA degree from Yale University and has written many books and articles on Japanese Art. She is survived by her husband David Okada and daughter Carrie Ann Stern.

MORRIS--Richard S. Richard S. Morris, retired President and CEO of El Paso Natural Gas Co, died March 9th in Santa Fe, NM. Born in Oklahoma City, OK, he grew up in Tyler, TX, and attended McCallie School in Chattanooga, TN, which awarded him an Outstanding Career Achievement Recognition in 1999. At Rice University, he studied engineering and geology. He received his JD at the University of New Mexico in 1960. Richard enlisted in the US Air Force, serving from 1951-1956. He completed his aviation cadet training at Ellington and Mather USAF bases; was commissioned as a first lieutenant; and served as a navigator-bombardier on B-26s in France, Germany, and N. Africa. At EPNG, Richard served on the board, in the legal department, and in project development, including its Algerian LNG and Alaska projects, and in the merger with Burlington Northern, Inc. He was Chairman of the Interstate Natural Gas Assn of America and on the boards of the American Gas Assn, the Pacific Coast Gas Assn, and the Gas Research Institute. While serving as Chairman of the board of the UNM Foundation, he established the Richard and Patricia Morris Presidential Scholarship. UNM awarded him a Regents' Recognition Medal. Retiring to Santa Fe, he served on the Board of Visitors and Governors of St. John's College; the Board of Trustees of the Santa Fe Opera Foundation; and the Board of Managers of the School of Advanced Research. Survivors include his wife, Patricia, a former Nebraska State Senator; four children from his previous marriage: Daniel (Betsy), Edward (Jessica), Joseph, and Maria Stewart (Roger); his two grandchildren, Cole Morris and Sarah Severin; his sisters, Mary Ann Ulan (Michael) and Jan Clark (Craig) and their families; and his wife's daughter, Kem Morehead (Rev. Kim Crawford Harvie). Berardinelli Family Funeral Service 1399 Luisa Street Santa Fe, NM 87505 (505)984-8600. Please sign our guestbook online at berardinellifuneralhome.com.

Singapore is opening a cruise terminal by midyear to accommodate a growing number of cruise passengers and larger ships like Royal Caribbean's Oasis of the Seas, its tourism board announced recently. The $400 million terminal, shown in a rendering, above, will allow for two berths, and will include a large arrivals and departures hall as well as an area for ground transportation. The cable channel TNT will bring a new meaning to April showers to promote the return of a familiar series known for the most celebrated shower scene since ''Psycho.'' Beginning on Monday, billboards in Times Square, above 723 Seventh Avenue at 48th Street, are to depict a silhouette of a man in a cowboy hat behind a simulated, 46-foot-tall shower curtain. ''They're back,'' the signs will tease.

The exchange operator BATS Global Markets styled itself as the future of stock trading - faster, more efficient - when it began in 2005. Its name stood for Better Alternative Trading System. Despite a very public setback for BATS on Friday, the future of stock trading still looks to be one dominated by rapid-fire computerized trading and a panoply of trading platforms like BATS.

Apps, games and e-books may look great on the new iPad's high-resolution ''retina'' display, but it's unclear whether Web sites will get the same treatment. Pick up a new iPad and load a Web site, and you'll often see crisp, clear text next to not-so-sharp photos. That's because most Web developers are still considering whether they want to upgrade their sites to deliver higher-resolution images and videos for the new iPad, which has a 2,048-by-1,536-pixel display. This may involve more bandwidth and storage costs, and the programming work required to keep track of different image sizes and deliver them to the right screens.

An article on Friday about the dismissal of a lawsuit by nine graduates of New York Law School, who accused the school of misleading them about their postgraduate job prospects, misstated the location of Thomas M. Cooley Law School, which is facing a similar complaint. It is based in Lansing, Mich., not in Detroit. (One of the school's satellite campuses is in Auburn Hills, in the Detroit metropolitan area.)

Funeral 11am, Tuesday, at Temple Emanuel, Westfield, NJ, In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to American Parkinson Disease Foundation, 135 Parkinson Avenue, Staten Island, NY 10305 or National Parkinson Foundation, 1501 N.W. 9th Avenue, Bob Hope Road, Miami, FL 33136. MAYERSON--Manuel D.,died in his Cincinnati home on March 22nd at the age of 90. In business he was known as a pioneer in the original development of malls and shopping centers. He was a Founder and Trustee of the International Council of Shopping Centers. Along with the Simon and Buxbaum families he helped build the shopping center industry. Today, the ICSC has more than 60,000 members world-wide and facilitates the development and leasing of tens of millions of square feet of retail space annually. Mr. Mayerson has been a major financial supporter of the Hebrew Union College. As a long-time member of the Board of the college, he helped lead the initiative and formation of HUC's Manhattan Campus and created the Hebrew Union College Mayerson Ethics Center. In honor of his lifetime of service he was given the American Judiasm Award from Hebrew Union College. The family foundation he formed is a national leader in accessibility and rights of the disabled. In addition to numerous disability rights initiatives in the U.S., Mayerson established the Mayerson Inclusive Parks Project in Israel in partnership with the Jewish National Fund. He gave his time and talent to numerous Israeli and American Jewish causes including the Jewish Funds for Justice in which he established the Drip Irrigation Agricultural program, used in Israel, for the Navajo Nation. Mr. Mayerson with his wife Rhoda established The Mayerson Family Foundation. Their tremendous generosity has touched the lives of thousands of people from all walks of life. In addition to supporting key community institutions and smaller non-profit agencies, the foundation has been a major supporter of: Hebrew Union College, Mayerson Academy, created for the professional development of K-12 teachers, The INclusion Network, aimed at full inclusion of people with disabilities in community life, Mayerson Freestore Foodbank Distribution Center, Via Institute on Character, The Mayerson Center for Safe and Healthy Children at Cincinnati's Children's Hospital, and Numerous civic and cultural projects in Israel Manuel and Rhoda spent a lifetime collecting art. As a result of their renowned collection, they have been active supporters and Board members of The Cincinnati Art Museum, The Contemporary Arts Center, and The National Foundation of Jewish Culture. Equally interested in the performing arts, their support and involvement extended to Music Hall, The Cincinnati Symphony, Cincinnati Playhouse in the Park, and SCPA - School for Creative and Performing Arts. Manuel and his wife Rhoda are the parents of Frederic and his wife Dawna, Arlene and her husband Alan, Neal and his wife, Donna, and the grandparents of Amanda, Adam and Emma.

SAS Institute, the world's largest private software company, has built its lucrative business by being the pioneer of sophisticated data-analysis tools. SAS software, down to its own programming language, is used by most large corporations for things like detecting credit card fraud for banks and fine-tuning pricing for retailers. But the data-analysis game is democratizing. New kinds of data are part of the trend, as Web and social-networking messages join all the information in corporate databases as grist of decision making. But so are new tools, opening data-analysis to a wider audience of corporate users, not just elite teams of Ph.D. quants in Fortune 500 companies.
The neighborhood watch volunteer who shot Trayvon Martin told police Trayvon had punched him and slammed his head into the sidewalk in the moments before the shooting.

March means millions of viewers for the N.C.A.A. The 1983 women's title game, which pitted Lori Scott, left, against Cheryl Miller, drew one-third as much as the men's 1979 Michigan-Indiana game. Last year, 48 million people watched the men's Elite Eight round, and 39 million saw the championship. For the women, the numbers were 10 million and 9 million, respectively. Lower viewership translates into less advertising revenue. Last year, a 30-second spot for the men's final cost $473 million compared with $49 million for the women. SHELLY FREIERMAN

Jon S. Corzine, the former chief executive of MF Global, was told during the brokerage firm's final day of business that a crucial transfer of $175 million came from the firm's own money - not from a customer account, according to an internal e-mail. The e-mail, sent by an executive in MF Global's Chicago office, showed that the company had transferred $175 million to replenish an overdrawn account at JPMorgan Chase in London. The transfer, the e-mail said, was a ''House Wire,'' meaning that it came from the firm's own money. The e-mail, sent at 2:20 p.m. on Oct. 28 to Mr. Corzine and two of his assistants in New York, says the transfer came from a ''nonseg'' account, industry speak for a noncustomer account.

7:12 p.m. | Updated Variety, the trade publication that has chronicled the entertainment industry for more than a century but has struggled financially in recent years, will be put up for sale, its parent company, Reed Business Information, said Friday. In a news article posted on Variety's Web site, Reed Business said it was beginning the process of selling Variety. For many years Variety was widely considered the bible of show business, but in recent years it has declined in influence amid competition from the Internet, where entertainment news is often freely available.

Wagner has promoted assistant Bashir Mason to be its head basketball coach, replacing Dan Hurley, who left for the Rhode Island coaching job. Mason, 28, will become the youngest head coach in Division I basketball. A news conference will be held on Tuesday.

Lincoln Hall, an Australian mountaineer who in May 2006 was rescued on Mount Everest after being left for dead and surviving a night alone at more than 28,000 feet, died on Tuesday in Sydney. He was 56. His death was announced on the Web site of the Australian Himalayan Foundation, which supports improvements in education, health care and conservation in the Himalayan region. Mr. Hall had helped found it. Australian newspapers said he died of mesothelioma, which was attributed to childhood exposure to asbestos.

Maria Flores and her husband, Marco Muñoz, finished work one recent afternoon and embarked on a short drive to pick up their son, Sebastian, at a nearby day care center in the Elmont section of Nassau County. Along the way, the couple passed an exercise track and rows of barns where their co-workers, mostly Hispanic men and women working in a steady rain, were feeding, bathing and walking thoroughbred horses through thick clumps of mud.

Meg Whitman, the chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, wants to make it clear to shareholders: Hewlett-Packard is about the money. More than anything, Wednesday's big reorganization is about that. ''The intent behind all these changes is to remove complexity, make it easier to buy, easier to sell, easier to get things done,'' Ms. Whitman, the company's chief executive, said in an interview. ''We have to deliver more to the bottom line.''

Amid concerns from parents, Notre Dame High School in Lawrenceville, N.J., has canceled its production of ''The Laramie Project,'' Moises Kaufman's play based on the 1998 murder of a gay college student in Wyoming. According to The Times of Trenton, administrators at that Roman Catholic school received calls arguing that the play's content, which depicts a gay man being beaten and left tied to a fence, was inappropriate for high school students, and the administrators concluded that the production had become too distracting. That decision has led to even more controversy among some of the students, staff members and alumni, who said the play's message of tolerance should be considered over its other elements. Since its premiere in 2000 in Denver ''The Laramie Project'' has been performed in a number of high schools without incident, including the Catholic-run Xavier High School in Manhattan, in 2010.

Executives at NBC are confirming reports that the playwright Theresa Rebeck, who is listed as the creator of the network's Broadway-based drama ''Smash,'' has stepped down as the lead producer on the series. In television that job is called a showrunner, and Ms. Rebeck, whose play ''Seminar'' is in the middle of a successful run on Broadway, has carried that title for every episode of ''Smash'' this season. A showrunner essentially leads the creative direction of a series, including overseeing the writing of episodes.

Last week Amazon, the online retailer, announced it was buying a robot maker called Kiva Systems for $775 million in cash. Before you get excited that Amazon may offer a robot that can tuck you into bed at night and read Kindle books to you, this isn't that kind of robot company. Instead, Kiva Systems' orange robots are designed to move around warehouses and stock shelves. Or, as the company says on its Web site, using ''hundreds of autonomous mobile robots,'' Kiva Systems ''enables extremely fast cycle times with reduced labor requirements.''

For those consumers who did not go to Yale but wish they could have, a new shirt may be all that is needed to fill the void. On Monday, Gant, the clothing retailer known for its preppy fashions, will announce a new advertising campaign to promote its ties to Yale with a focus on its Yale Co-op shirt collection. The cotton oxford-cloth shirts, which were created in the 1960s and sold at the Yale Co-op campus store, were reissued last year in the United States and will now be available globally for the first time.

On Monday, the Supreme Court will begin three days of arguments over the constitutionality of the Affordable Care Act. The act is often called ''Obamacare,'' primarily by Republicans, as a term of disdain. Democrats have tried to limit the term's use to reshape perceptions, but that has been a tough sell. Grant Barrett, a vice president for the American Dialect Society, says it is almost impossible to persuade people to discontinue the use of a political word. ''It's an invitation to have your heart broken. You forbid it, and they start writing it on the bathroom stalls.'' Now Democrats seem to be embracing the term, launching a Twitter campaign that seeks to build positive associations for it.

Lady Gaga and the producers of ''Smash'' on NBC were among those honored at the 23rd annual Glaad Media Awards presented on Saturday in New York by the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation. Lady Gaga, above right, received the award for outstanding music artist for her album ''Born This Way,'' while the executive producers Neil Meron and Craig Zadan of ''Smash'' received the Vito Russo Award for promoting equal rights. Other honorees included ABC's ''Dancing With the Stars,'' which was named outstanding reality program, and ''World News With Diane Sawyer'' for its coverage of bullying; DC Comics for its ''Batwoman'' comic series by J. H. Williams III and W. Haden Blackman; and Katy Butler, a 17-year-old high school student, for her work in gathering more than 450,000 online signatures to petition the Motion Picture Association of America to overturn its R rating for the documentary ''Bully.'' More awards will be announced this year at ceremonies in Los Angeles and San Francisco.

PHOENIX - When Rick Pitino coached Louisville, the fourth seed in the West Region, past seventh-seeded Florida on Saturday, he ascended higher into the realm of history's most successful college basketball coaches. In victory, this Cardinals team became the sixth Pitino team to reach the national semifinals. Only five coaches have led more teams to the Final Four, and Denny Crum (also of Louisville) and Adolph Rupp (Kentucky) also took six teams there. Rare air, indeed. Pitino, making his second trip to the Final Four with Louisville, is the first coach to guide three schools that deep into the tournament.

FRIEDMAN--Lois J. Died on March 22, 2012 at age 64 in Beth Israel's Hospice with her adoring and loving partner of 29 years, Barbara J. Miller, by her side. An article in some editions on Thursday about State Senator James S. Alesi, who voted in favor of same-sex marriage and is unlikely to receive the nomination of the main Republican committee in his district, described incorrectly the role the Monroe County Republican Committee plays in putting a candidate on the ballot. While the county party can endorse a candidate, candidates get on the ballot by submitting a petition with the required number of signatures from party voters in the district. It is not the case that the likely outcome of the Monroe County nominating convention is that ''the towns will not vote to put Mr. Alesi on the ballot.''

(Sundance) STILL WALKING (2009) Ryota (Hiroshi Abe) returns home for the 15th anniversary of a brother's death, but resentments emerge when he realizes that his parents have not moved past the loss in this film from Hirokazu Kore-eda. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis described a story about ''what it means to return to a home that you helped create, animating it with spirit and love (or rage or fear or despair), and then left behind.'' She credited Mr. Kore-eda with the understated ambiance. ''They rarely express themselves with blunt force and never with perfectly scripted paragraphs detailing every slight,'' she wrote. ''It's this restraint rather than any change in volume that makes their brief displays of florid emotion so effective.''
