CATCHPOOL--Carol May, 77, on March 24, 2012 in Palm Beach, FL. Cherished mother of Gail May Engelberg and mother-in-law of Alfred B. Engelberg. One of 1700 children sent to the United States via convoy across the Atlantic to escape the blitz of London, Carol started life in America as an orphan. A devoted mother, elegant and considerate of all, her beauty, wit and British fortitude were an inspiration to her family and all who knew and loved her

10 P.M. (13, 49) FRONTLINE The phone hacking and police bribery investigations enveloping British tabloids owned by News Corporation have placed Rupert Murdoch, right, the company's 81-year-old chief executive, under increased scrutiny. He testified before a parliamentary panel in the matter and shuttered one disgraced property, the 168-year-old News of the World. In this edition of ''Frontline'' Lowell Bergman examines the scandal that has rocked Mr. Murdoch's media empire. 5:20 P.M. (Showtime 2) THE PERFECT HOST (2011) While putting the finishing touches on dinner party preparations, Warwick Wilson (David Hyde Pierce) answers his door to find a man named John Taylor (Clayne Crawford), who is not a guest but rather a bank robber, looking for a place to hide. This man talks his way inside but becomes a threat once his cover is blown. Warwick plies the thief with strong wine to knock him out, and once he has taken back control of the situation, he reveals his own dark side. ''Like Warwick himself, the movie begins to run amok after a taut and tantalizing first act,'' Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. ''Not even Mr. Hyde Pierce's best efforts can make sense of a character who by the end of the film seems to be a completely different person with the same name.''

In a senior citizen circuit battle over Medicare, Republicans have Pat Boone, while Democrats have President Bartlett. Last week, the conservative 60Plus Association began running an advertisement against vulnerable Democratic senators featuring Mr. Boone, the aging crooner, with the somewhat convoluted message that President Obama and Democrats are cutting Medicare spending and rationing care, while ignoring the problem of the program going bankrupt.

Michaels Stores, the arts and crafts retailer owned by the Blackstone Group and Bain Capital, plans to file to go public as soon as next week, according to people briefed on the matter. The initial public offering could be one of the biggest of the year. Blackstone and Bain have hired JPMorgan Chase and Goldman Sachs to lead the company's initial public offering, said these people, who requested anonymity to talk about private discussions. The timing of the actual stock sale has not yet been determined.

Because of an editing error, a Sports of The Times column on Monday about star quarterbacks who changed football teams late in their careers, as Peyton Manning recently did, referred incorrectly to a late interception thrown by Brett Favre of the Minnesota Vikings in the N.F.C. championship game in January 2010. It came near the end of regulation, not in overtime.

SPENCER--Edson White, age 85, passed away peacefully at home in Wayzata, MN on March 25, 2012 after a valiant battle with PSP. He was surrounded by his wife of 62 years Harriet, and their four children, Linda Spencer Murchison, Edson W. Spencer Jr., Douglas Stuart Spencer and James McClure Spencer. Born June 4, 1926, and raised in Chicago, Illinois, Spencer served in the U.S. Navy and was honorably discharged in 1946. A graduate of Williams College, he went on to Oxford University as a Rhodes Scholar, earning an M.A. in 1950. He and Harriet McClure Stuart married in August 1950. He worked for Sears Roebuck in Sioux City, IA, La Crosse, WI, and in Venezuela before settling in Minneapolis in 1954. Ed began his 32 year career at Honeywell as an aeronautical engineer, then as Regional Manager for Honeywell Asia based in Tokyo, Japan from 1959 to 1964. He ultimately served as Chairman and CEO of Honeywell from 1973-1987. During that time he served on the boards of Norwest Corporation, CBS, and American Express Mutual Funds Group, and the international advisory boards of NEC, Chase Manhattan Bank, and Robert Bosch, Gmbh. Ed's personal interests were many and varied and he brought passion, insight and intellectual curiosity to everything he took on. He was most proud of his service on the boards of the Ford Foundation, Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, the Mayo Foundation and the Minneapolis Foundation. Throughout his career he pursued his interest in US Japan relations with membership on the U.S. Japan Business Council and the Trilateral Commission. Additionally, he served on Governor Perpich's Blue Ribbon Commission on the University of Minnesota, Governor Carlson's Roundtable on Higher Education, and the Board of Carleton College. Ed was actively engaged in the Humphrey Institute at the University of Minnesota and a dedicated advisor to the Center for Victims of Torture. Between many a trip to interesting places around the world you could find Ed (and Harriet) casting a line in the Clarks Fork of the Yellowstone in Northwestern Wyoming. Deeply committed to the national treasure that is Yellowstone National Park, he and Harriet were founders of the Yellowstone Park Foundation, and served on the Advisory Board of the National Parks and Conservation Association. Spencer was accomplished athlete who enjoyed competition throughout his life. He was an excellent college hockey and tennis player; later in life he enjoyed skiing, tennis, fly fishing and hiking. These many professional accomplishments never masked what was most important to him, which was spending time with family and friends. He is survived by his wife Harriet; children Linda (Reid) Murchison, Ed (Val) Spencer, Doug (Kathleen Parrish) Spencer and Jim (Polly) Spencer, and nine wonderful grandchildren, Sarah (Andy), Clare, Emily, Julia, Katie, Alison, Teddy, James, and Michael. The family would like to express special appreciation to Becky Fredericks and her team of nurses for their gracious and wonderful care, and to Allina Hospice Care. A memorial service will be held at the Wayzata Community Church on Tuesday, April 3rd at 3pm. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts can be made to Cure PSP, 30 E. Padonia Road, Suite 201, Timonium, MD 21093; www.curepsp.org; The Center for Victims of Torture, 649 Dayton Avenue St. Paul, MN 55104; www.cvt.org; or The Mayo Foundation: www.mayoclinic.org.

BEIJING - At a time when many airlines are filing for bankruptcy or consolidating routes, George Weinmann is jumping into the industry with a start-up. Mr. Weinmann, the chief executive of Mega Maldives Airlines, is going after a growing niche, linking increasingly affluent China with the Maldives, a tiny island nation. The American entrepreneur says he has the right ingredients to make it a success: lucrative landing rights in an expanding market, an international network of contacts and crucial government approvals.

2:49 p.m. | Updated Julie Otsuka is the winner of the 2012 PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction for her novel ''The Buddha in the Attic'' (Alfred A. Knopf), the directors of the award announced on Monday. The book, which traces the lives of six Japanese mail-order brides who sail to San Francisco in the early 20th century, was chosen from more than 350 novels and short-story collections, all by American authors and all published in 2011. Marita Golden, one of three judges, said in a statement that in ''The Buddha in the Attic,'' Ms. Otsuka ''creates a voice that is hypnotic and irresistible, and renders her story with the power of the most ancient, timeless myths, the legends that crowd our dreams, and the truths we cannot bear.'' She went on to say, ''Her skill is awesome and utterly inspiring.''

''Mad Men'' rode a flood of publicity - and praise from critics overcome with longing for the series after an extended absence - to reach its largest audience on Sunday night. The first episode after a year-and-a-half hiatus attracted 3.5 million viewers, the most for any episode of the drama about the advertising business in the 1960s, which is beginning its fifth season.

An article on Saturday about the arrival of Pope Benedict XVI in Mexico included several errors. The trip was the pope's first visit to Spanish-speaking Latin America, not to Latin America. (He visited Brazil, whose national language is Portuguese, in 2007.) The Mexican War of Independence, not the Mexican revolution, started in 1810 in the mining area of Guanajuato, the heart of Catholic Mexico where the pope spoke at an outdoor Mass on Sunday. The group at the center of a sexual abuse scandal that has angered Mexican Catholics is the Legionaries of Christ or the Legion of Christ, but not the Legions of Christ. And it was Benedict who removed the Legionaries's founder, the Rev. Marcial Maciel Degollado, in 2006 after Father Maciel was accused of being a drug addict who abused teenage seminarians and fathered several children. He did not remove Father Maciel when he was Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger. (He became pope in 2005.)

-Aretha Franklin says she has resurrected her partnership with Clive Davis, the record executive who engineered her comeback in the 1980s, and will record a new album, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Franklin made the announcement during a short interview at her 70th birthday party on Saturday night in the Helmsley Park Lane Hotel in Manhattan. Mr. Davis, the chief creative officer for Sony Music Entertainment, sat next to Ms. Franklin for most of the night. ''I have re-signed with Clive Davis, so I'm recording with Clive again,'' Ms. Franklin said. She added that next month ''we're going to sit together and decide what it is we're going to record.''
When the Supreme Court grants six hours of oral arguments over three days, I don't have to win that case to know that my challenge is serious. RANDY E. BARNETT,
Well Anahad O'Connor posted at nytimes.com/well:

After previously pitching its lavishly decorated tent at the South Street Seaport, the traveling troupe Spiegelworld will be moving uptown for a 15-week summer engagement with a new work, ''Empire.'' The show will display Spiegelworld's circus, cabaret and burlesque acts in a 440-seat tent, which will be erected on West 45th Street, near Eighth Avenue. Previews are set to begin May 22, with opening night scheduled for May 31. Tickets can be purchased at (212) 239-6200 or telecharge.com. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

FLORHAM PARK, N.J. -- Missing from the spectacle at Jets headquarters Monday was a Goodyear blimp circling overhead, transmitting panoramic images of this woodsy suburban pocket that was overtaken by something no organization had ever done. The wide-angle views could have captured the scope -- lines of cars at the security booth seeking entry; drive-through credential stations; satellite truck after satellite truck, a dozen in all -- without intruding into the event itself. And it was an event, disguised as an introductory news conference. Tim Tebow said he was excited and thankful and humbled and grateful and excited, as he did on a late-night conference call last Wednesday. Only this time, he was standing on a podium before more than 200 members of the news media in the team's field house -- the only area large enough to accommodate such interest in a backup quarterback.

ARNBERG--Henry of Melville, NY and Jupiter, FL passed away after a lengthy battle with a brain tumor yesterday, March 26th, at the age of 69. Beloved husband of Lynda, loving father of Robyn and Richard, Howard and Amy, Marc and Melina and Dana and David. Cherished grandfather of Benny, Lucas, Ethan, Harrison, Jackson, Mason, Dylan, Lola, Evan, Samantha and Daniel. Dear brother of Ellen. Special friend to Dwaine. And best friend to Hava. Loving uncle to many nephews and nieces. An amazing leader both at home and in the business world. An active participant in the community and a long-time member of Temple Beth Torah. Memorial donations to be made to the Preston Tisch Brain Tumor Center at Duke University, c/o Dr. Henry Friedman, Duke University Medical Center, DUMC Box 3624, Durham, NC 27710 or Temple Beth Torah, 35 Bagatelle Road, Melville, NY 11746. For more information: jewish-funeral-home.com

The number of elementary school students in classes of 30 or more has tripled in the last three years because of teacher attrition and budget cuts to public schools, according to a report released on Monday by a city councilman. Using data from the city's Department of Education, the report found that 31,079 students in first through fifth grade were now in large classes, compared with 9,756 in the 2008-9 school year. Fourth graders and fifth graders are most likely to be in large classes, according to the report, released by Councilman Brad Lander of Brooklyn.

An article on Saturday about the resurgence of boy bands, including the British group One Direction, which has been signed by Columbia Records, misspelled the surname of a Columbia executive who commented on the group and misstated his title. He is Steve Barnett, not Barnet, and he is co-chairman, with Rob Stringer, not chairman.

THE FACTS Poor diet, a lack of exercise, excess weight and genetics are the usual risk factors for Type 2 diabetes. But a new line of research suggests that in some cases, there may be a surprising contributor: the stomach bacterium known as Helicobacter pylori.

The jury deliberating the charges against a police officer accused of raping a woman at gunpoint in Upper Manhattan last August indicated on Monday that it had reached a verdict on several of the charges, but was stuck on others. In a note sent to the judge, the jurors said they had reached a unanimous verdict on three counts of criminal sexual assault and three counts of predatory sexual assault, which carries a maximum sentence of life in prison. But they were at an impasse on two rape counts, and did not believe further deliberations would be fruitful.

PANOFF--Jack Edward. Age 91. Predeceased by his wives Ruth and Gloria and his daughter-in-law Laurie. Survived by his sons Roy, Randy (Eliska) and Neil, his grandsons Nick and Zack, his nephew Chuck, niece Lenore and good friend Anita. He is also survived by all single women in America. Graveside service Tuesday, 12:30pm at Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

An article on Friday about black and Hispanic lawmakers who see a racial divide over the New York City Police Department's stop-and-frisk practice misstated, in some editions, a result of some police stops last year. About 10 percent, according to the Center for Constitutional Rights, led to arrests or summonses, not just to arrests.

More than 40 million American adults already take an aspirin a day to prevent heart disease. Now many more are weighing the pros and cons of daily aspirin use in light of new studies finding that it also may reduce the risk of many cancers and stop the spread of tumors. Six months ago Vanessa Brannan, a 31-year-old Seattle mother of two, learned she had colon cancer and Lynch syndrome, an inherited condition that increases risk of the disease and other cancers. Some of the best data on aspirin's effectiveness against cancer has been found in patients like Mrs. Brannan. In one British study, patients with Lynch syndrome who took aspirin for two years cut their risk of colon cancer in half.

MF Global's top lawyer will break her five-month silence on Wednesday to tell Congress that she was unaware of a gaping shortfall in customer money until hours before the brokerage firm filed for bankruptcy on Oct. 31. Laurie Ferber, MF Global's general counsel, was expected to tell a House panel that she ''had no reason to believe'' that the firm had raided customer accounts to meet its own obligations, according to a copy of her prepared testimony. While Ms. Ferber learned of a shortfall in customer money in the afternoon of Oct. 30, she said she believed it to be an accounting error.

MILLER--Charlotte, 97 years old, died on March 25, 2012. Beloved wife of the late Theodore Miller. Devoted mother of Dr. Bernard Miller and his wife Marilyn, and Allen G. Miller. Cherished grandmother of Ray Miller, Elissa Whiteman and her husband Adam, and Adam Miller. Loving great-grandmother of Nathan, Noah, Abigail, and Tamara. Funeral services were held on Monday at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels of Great Neck, New York. Interment followed at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, New York. Shiva will be observed Tuesday through Friday at the home of Allen G. Miller, Old Brookville, NY.

An obituary on Saturday about Al Ross, a cartoonist whose work appeared in The New Yorker for more than 60 years, misstated the years Lee Lorenz, who discussed Mr. Ross's working method, was the art editor there. He held that position from 1973 to 1993, not ''from the 1950s into the '70s.''

NEWMAN--Carole K. March 26, surrounded by loving family. Her passion for modern dance found form as a student of Martha Graham at Bennington College; as a dancer and choreographer for the Westchester Dance Players; as a dance therapist; and for many years as a member of the Board of the Paul Taylor Dance Company. She leaves her brother, William C. Kobin, of Boston; daughter Cynthia and son-in-law Arnaldo Diaz of NYC; her sons, Jeffrey, of NYC, and William and daughter-in-law Dale Melcher, of Northampton, MA; and grandchildren Jo, Dawn, Leah, Brian and Gina. She gave us style, grace and love, and will be sorely missed. Memorial service announced later.
FOSTER--Michael Scott. Beloved son of Hal and Essie, brother of Stacy, Tamar, and Jody, loving husband of Beth, dear father of Eden, died on March 20. He has flown away to paradise.

The Emmy Awards, to be televised on ABC in September, will be hosted by Jimmy Kimmel, the network's late-night comedian. ABC announced the booking on Monday morning, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Kimmel has never hosted the Emmys before. The awards -- considered the most prestigious in all of television -- are put on each year by the Academy of Television Arts and Sciences. This year's prime-time awards will be presented on Sept. 23 at the Nokia Theater in Los Angeles. Don Mischer, the veteran director and producer, will oversee the producing of the television broadcast.
LIPMAN--Sandy. Missed, loved and remembered. You are always in our hearts. Larry, Beth, Reed, Samara, Paige, Donna, Matthew, Ian and Nathaniel

Rick Santorum tried on Monday to turn a tense and profane exchange with a New York Times reporter to his benefit, using the encounter as a rallying cry and a fund-raising plea. In an appearance on Fox News and in front of reporters on the Supreme Court steps, Mr. Santorum boasted about his eruption at Jeff Zeleny, the Times reporter who had pressed him on remarks he made Sunday that Mitt Romney was ''the worst Republican in the country'' to run against President Obama.

''Fifty Shades of Grey,'' the erotic novel that went from X-rated underground sensation to mainstream literary phenomenon, is poised to become a Hollywood movie. Universal Pictures has acquired the film rights to the entire ''Fifty Shades'' trilogy, the studio announced on Monday. Focus Features will distribute and market the film. Written by the British author E L James, the trilogy includes two more novels, ''Fifty Shades Darker'' and ''Fifty Shades Freed.''

The French rock star Johnny Hallyday will perform a concert at the Beacon Theater in October, and it will be one of only a few New York appearances of his 50-year career. Heavily influenced by Elvis Presley, Mr. Hallyday is famous in France as one of that country's best rock 'n' roll singers, known for his deep, raspy voice, his energetic shows and his wild lifestyle. (He has 21 platinum albums.) Although he shot a music video in New York in the late 1990s and sang at a charity concert in the early 1960s, Mr. Hallyday says the show at the Beacon on Oct. 7 will be his first real concert here. ''I've never given an entire show in New York City but I have an unforgettable memory,'' he said in a statement, adding, ''in 1962, when I sang on the celebrated ship, the France, docked at the New York Harbor, for a charity concert in the presence of Jacqueline Kennedy.'' Mr. Hallyday, 68, will also perform in Los Angeles on April 24.

A Political Memo article last Tuesday about the Republican race for the presidency quoted incorrectly from comments by a senior aide to Newt Gingrich regarding the release of his financial report from February. The senior aide said the campaign was expecting to show a ''nice chunk of debt'' from the month. He did not say it was expecting to show a ''huge chunk of debt.''

FOSTER--Michael Scott. We mourn the loss of our beloved Michael, who died suddenly March 20 at age 59 due to complications following surgery. Our Michael was a charismatic paradox: loving and aloof, sardonic and silly, passionate and reserved. He was elegant of form and mind and a talented craftsman. He had embracing interests that he loved to share, discuss, and debate. He seemed to know, or be able to master, anything. Michael was filled with optimism, excited by the possibilities of life, and open to new experiences. His own path had taken him around the world and on unconventional turns that gave him a broad and tolerant perspective. Michael, we love you dearly and will miss you always. This inexplicable loss has left a void in our lives and in our hearts that can never be filled. Michael is survived by his devoted wife, Elizabeth, and daughter, Eden; his parents, Israel and Estelle; his sisters, Stacy, Tamar, and Jody; and his niece and nephews.

For the past few years, proponents of barefoot running have argued that modern athletic shoes compromise natural running form. But now a first-of-its-kind study suggests that, in the right circumstances, running shoes make running physiologically easier than going barefoot. The study, conducted by researchers at the University of Colorado in Boulder, began by recruiting 12 well-trained male runners with extensive barefoot running experience. ''It was important to find people who are used to running barefoot,'' says Rodger Kram, a professor of integrative physiology, who oversaw the study, which was published online in the journal Medicine & Science in Sports & Exercise.

After several days at the center of a storm of controversy and often heated debate about the boundaries between journalism and theater, the performer Mike Daisey has offered an apology for the exaggerations and falsehoods in his show ''The Agony and the Ecstasy of Steve Jobs,''writing on his blog that he had ''failed to honor the contract I'd established with my audiences over many years and many shows.'' A version of that monologue by Mr. Daisey, in which he chronicles his travels to the Foxconn factory in China where Apple products are manufactured, was retracted by the public radio show ''This American Life'' earlier this month. Journalists at that radio program said they were unable to confirm details from Mr. Daisey's monologue, and a translator who had traveled with him disputed key elements of his narrative, including supposed encounters with young teenage workers outside the plant and a meeting with a man who had been injured at the factory.

NEWMAN--Carole. Paul Taylor and The Paul Taylor Dance Company mourn the loss of Carole K. Newman. Supporter and friend to all in the Taylor organization, Carole's love of the dancers and dances was second to none. We dance this week in celebration of her life.

The About New York column on Friday, about Senate hearings in the immediate aftermath of the Titanic disaster, misspelled the surname of a victim of the tragedy who refused to stay in a lifeboat without her husband. She was Ida Straus, not Strauss.

FREUND--Barbro H.,of Greenwich, CT, died on Tuesday March 20, 2012 of natural causes at age 74. Born in Tasjo, Sweden her father Johannes Hellstrom and mother Lydia Hagstrom moved to Ostersund where she grew up with her sister Siv Bengstsson and brothers Alan and Rolf. She moved to the US in the early 1960s while working as a stewardess for Pan Am airlines. She was married to James C. Freund of Manhattan for 18 years. Earned a master's degree in Art History from Columbia University and spent much of her life buying and selling antiques. She was a nurturing mother and a smart and beautiful woman with a passion for art and language. Bo (as was her nickname) loved to play and watch tennis and was a regular in the local Greenwich area. She had many cats in her life, most notable of late, her companion Phoebe. She is survived by her two loving sons Erik and Thomas, her daughters-in-law Wendelyn Waters and Frances Wong and her grandchildren, Delilah and Paige Freund, all of whom will miss her greatly. The family is having a private service for her in Old Greenwich, CT.

MacGUIGAN--Duncan, 1950-2012. We at Acquavella Galleries are deeply saddened by the death of our esteemed former Director, Duncan MacGuigan. During his thirty years at Acquavella Galleries, Duncan was a great friend and a knowledgeable and influential art dealer with a great eye for quality. We are proud of his many years of loyal service and will miss him dearly. Duncan had a variety of interests which encompassed all manner of musical idioms, running the marathon (more than once), and his beloved Boston Red Sox. The Acquavella Family and Acquavella Galleries

QUEEN'S BANKER FINED British regulators on Monday fined the private bank Coutts £8.75 million ($13.9 million) for failing to follow standards intended to fight money laundering. The fine is the largest ever for a British firm for issues connected to financial crime. The Financial Services Authority of Britain said Coutts, which is part of the nationalized Royal Bank of Scotland and provides banking services to Queen Elizabeth II, had not applied rigorous controls when dealing with so-called high-risk customers. In November, British authorities fined Coutts £6.3 million for improperly selling bonds issued by the American International Group. MARK SCOTT

-Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg signed a bill on Monday that extended the city's participation in rent regulation for another three years by redeclaring a state of housing emergency, even as a challenge to rent regulation laws looms in the United States Supreme Court. - ''The Department of Housing Preservation and Development reports the vacancy rate in rental apartments to be at 3.12 percent,'' Mr. Bloomberg said at the bill-signing ceremony. That, he continued, is ''well below the 5 percent rate at which the law requires that rent regulation be discontinued.''

MOSCOW -- Marina Salye, a Russian politician and former Soviet dissident who in the early 1990s led a thwarted inquiry into corruption in the office of Vladimir V. Putin, then a little-known deputy to the mayor of St. Petersburg, died on Wednesday in Ozero, Russia. She was 77. The cause was a heart attack, said a friend and colleague, Tatyana S. Dorutino.

Visitors to the High Line, the elevated park on a formerly derelict rail line, might someday be greeted by a vision even more improbable than the park itself, which has become one of Manhattan's top tourist draws: A massive locomotive dangling from a crane. The sculpture, by Jeff Koons, would be a full-size replica of a 1943 Baldwin 2900 steam locomotive. Called simply ''Train,'' it has not yet been fabricated. The Los Angeles County Museum of Art has conducted its own feasibility studies for the project and is still exploring the possibility of acquiring the artwork, which is estimated to cost at least $25 million to create and install.

To the Editor: Re ''Getting Doctors to Think About Costs'' (Doctor and Patient, March 15): It is almost impossible for most doctors to reconcile cost and benefits. When treating patients, their only concern is how to make the diagnosis quickly and safely and how to begin the best treatment.

An article on March 15 about Russia's willingness to allow NATO to use an airfield in European Russia as a transit center for moving troops and ''nonlethal'' cargo into Afghanistan quoted incorrectly from testimony last month by Gen. William Fraser III, the commander of the United States Transportation Command, before the Senate Armed Services Committee. In listing countries through which the United States now has approval to move equipment out of Afghanistan, the general included Kyrgyzstan -- not Kurdistan, an autonomous region in the north of Iraq.

EPEL--Beatrice. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) mourn the loss of Beatrice (Bea) Epel of Detroit and Highland Beach, FL. A warm and encouraging presence at national and local meetings, for many years in Detroit and later in South Florida, Mrs. Epel was a devoted supporter for more than six decades. A Technion Guardian who had reached the highest level of support, she and her late husband, Dr. Joseph Epel initiated and supported many projects. These included the Beatrice and Joseph N. Epel Michigan Dormitory, the Salman and Evelyn Grand Dormitory, and the South Palm Beach Chapter Endowed Doctoral Fellowship Fund. To their five children Naomi Epel, Julia Epel Sherry, Dena Epel Korda, Joshua Epel and Daniel Epel and the entire Epel family, we offer our heartfelt condolences. American Technion Society Joel Rothman, President Joan Seidel, Chairman of the Board Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President

It is now two years since I lost Richard, the man I lived with and loved for 44 years, and I have to admit, the second year was harder than the first. At first I was busy navigating a seemingly unending number of legal and financial issues, foreign territory to me. I figured out how to undertake the many household duties that had long been my husband's, and I learned to ask for or hire help when tasks were more than I could handle.

A New York school administrator was forced to resign on Tuesday after a city investigation found that he had arranged for his wife to be hired for an Education Department job paying $52,000 a year. The administrator, Angel Namnum, arranged for his wife, Rosa Castillo, to be hired in May by the department's Extended Use Office in the Bronx as a community coordinator, according to a report released by the special commissioner of investigation, Richard J. Condon. Ms. Castillo had worked for the department as a paraprofessional from 1990 to 1996.

A new German bakery, unlike any other in New York City, has its roots in Swabia, a region of Bavaria. Its name, Landbrot (which means country or farm bread), is that of its signature loaf, a round dark rye that is briefly baked a second time to bestow a distinctive heavy crust. The bread is one of about two dozen varieties baked on the second floor of the marble-sheathed shop, cafe and bar, which opens on April 1 in Greenwich Village. Pretzels, rolls and classic German pastries like Berliner jelly doughnuts and Black Forest cakes, along with more American treats like blueberry muffins, are available. German cheeses and condiments, cured meats and some groceries will be sold, too. For eating in at cafe tables, there are Bavarian beers (some on draft) and wines, to accompany bratwurst, hot dogs, ''flaming pies'' (like the Alsatian open-face bacon tart), quiches, sandwiches, salads and soups. A clever little banquette on the balcony is made from used flour sacks.

Florida, which is expected to be a vital swing state once again in this year's presidential election, is enrolling fewer new voters than it did four years ago as prominent civic organizations have suspended registration drives because of what they describe as onerous restrictions imposed last year by Republican state officials. The state's new elections law -- which requires groups that register voters to turn in completed forms within 48 hours or risk fines, among other things -- has led the state's League of Women Voters to halt its efforts this year. Rock the Vote, a national organization that encourages young people to vote, began an effort last week to register high school students around the nation -- but not in Florida, over fears that teachers could face fines. And on college campuses, the once-ubiquitous folding tables piled high with voter registration forms are now a rarer sight.

Plans for the expansion, first reported by Politico and later obtained by The New York Times from a rival campaign, include a split-level, four-car garage with a ''car lift,'' an outdoor shower, and a 3,600-square-foot basement.

FERBER--Samuel, in Thousand Oaks, CA, 91. Beloved husband of Beatrice, devoted father of Bruce and Joel, father-in-law of Lyn and Jenise (d), cherished grandfather of Aaron, Sarah, Joey and Rebecca. Loved by all who knew him. Born in New York, the son of Austrian immigrants built a successful career in the advertising and magazine businesses, becoming the publisher of Esquire in 1974. He was an active member of his community, both in his New York home of Searingtown, and his adopted Thousand Oaks. He will be sorely missed. Donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, or the charity of your choice.

The National Archives announced Tuesday that two new leather-bound volumes of an infamous catalog of looted art compiled for Hitler during World War II had been discovered among the possessions of former American soldiers. The albums were compiled by a special Nazi task force, the Einsatzstab Reichsleiter Rosenberg, to document the plundering of French museums and private collections undertaken in part for a museum Hitler planned to build in his hometown, Linz, Austria. The two newly discovered volumes, Albums 7 and 15, were among the possessions of the families of Albert Lorenzetti, who served as a corporal in the 989th Field Artillery Battalion, and Yerke Zane Larson, a private first class in the 501st Battalion of the 101st Airborne Division. Both men, now dead, are thought to have taken the albums from the Berghof, Hitler's home in the Bavarian Alps, in the waning days of the war.

A music review on Tuesday about a performance of Bach's ''St. John Passion'' by Les Violons du Roy and La Chapelle de Québec, at Carnegie Hall, misidentified the site of an ''improvised Passion'' to be presented by the Trinty Choir on Sunday morning in Manhattan. While the choir will perform the ''St. John Passion'' at St. Paul's Chapel on Sunday afternoon, the ''improvised'' performance that morning will be at Trinity Church, not at St. Paul's Chapel.

A defect in wires that connect hearts to defibrillators caused at least 22 deaths, possibly as a result of a short circuit that is difficult to detect during routine monitoring, according to a study in the journal Heart Rhythm. The manufacturer of the wires, St. Jude Medical, estimated that about 79,000 patients in the United States and about 49,000 patients elsewhere have had the wires implanted. Removing the wires is considered dangerous.

Newt Gingrich, who has encouraged donations of as little as $2.50, has turned to an unusual tactic for his financially troubled campaign: charging $50 for a photograph with him. On Monday evening after an appearance in Delaware, people posing were asked to fill out a form with credit card information and directed to a Web site to download the images, according to news accounts.

9 P.M. (13) NOVA In this episode, ''Cracking Your Genetic Code,'' scientists consider the possible impact of a genetic code sequencing revolution. The technology to read and analyze an individual's DNA exists, but high costs have kept it out of reach for many people. But within the next five years, according to this program, sequencing an individual's complete genome could cost less than $1,000, making the procedure more accessible. Scientists believe the sequencing could help predict a person's genetic vulnerability to particular illnesses. That, in turn, could mean more personalized preventive medical treatment. 10:45 A.M. (IFC) CHE: PART ONE (2008) Steven Soderbergh's film about the international revolutionary Ernesto Guevara (Benicio Del Toro), known as Che, is an ''epic hagiography,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. The film, he said, ''not only participates in the worship of its subject but also spares no effort to insulate him from skepticism.'' This part chronicles Guevara's participation in the Cuban Revolution and his 1964 address to the United Nations, a bombastic speech that raised his profile.

Joining a sizable roster of museums around the country, the Bronx Museum of the Arts has decided to go free. As a way of marking its 40th anniversary, the museum, on the Grand Concourse not far from Yankee Stadium, will eliminate its suggested admission fee of $5 beginning March 29. ''At a time when other New York City museums are raising their admission fees, we have chosen to focus on increasing access to the museum as a resource for our community,'' said Holly Block, the museum's executive director, citing the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs and the New York Community Trust for financial support that will help make free admission possible.

MAKING CONCESSIONS A group of investors led by Sony has submitted concessions to win European regulatory approval for its $2.2 billion purchase of EMI's publishing unit. The news comes a few days after the European Union opened an in-depth investigation into the proposed $1.9 billion acquisition of EMI's recorded music business by Vivendi, the French media and telecommunications company.

It has been a shipping magnate's country residence, has housed public restrooms and classes for immigrants and has even done a stint as an ice cream shop. But for the past 70 years, Gracie Mansion has been home to nine New York City mayors, from Fiorello H. La Guardia to Rudolph W. Giuliani. On Tuesday, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said he thought that the tradition should end and that future mayors should pay for their own housing - somewhere else.

DOMANSKY--Sophie, 87, passed away on March 27, 2012. Sophie was born in Lodz, Poland in 1925. Sophie is a Holocaust survivor. In 1949 they moved to New York where she devoted her time to Jewish causes such as UJA Federation, The Lodzer Young Men's Benevolent Society and was often a guest speaker at Holocaust lectures and classes. Sophie is preceded in death by her husband of 64 years, Harry Domansky. Sophie was a member of Shelter Rock Jewish Center, Aventura Jewish Center and Hadassah. Her greatest achievements are seen in her family. She is survived by her son Martin and daughter-in-law Paula. Her grandchildren Elissa and Scott and their spouses Alan and Elisabeth. She was blessed to have four great-grandchildren Olivia, David, Remy and Jordan.

Is a check for $412 really worth $412? That's a question that has comic book fans intrigued this week. The check in question is the one endorsed by Jerome Siegel and Joe Shuster when they signed over their rights for creating Superman, whose adventures are published by DC Comics. Now the auction site Comicconnect.com is putting the check up for sale. The auction began on Monday and ends on April 16. The 12 bids have already pushed the price to $25,500. The check includes an accounting: $130 for the rights to Superman, $210 for stories in Detective Comics and two $36 payments for stories in More Fun and Adventure Comics. The back of the check includes a stamp from a United States District Court from 1939, when it was used as evidence by DC Comics in its successful copyright infringement lawsuit against Victor Fox, a publisher who unveiled Wonder Man, a champion created by Will Eisner. That wondrous hero, DC Comics said, was too similar to the Man of Steel.

A picture credit on Monday with The Books of The Times review of the novel ''The Master Blaster,'' using information from a publicist, misidentified the photographer. The picture of P. F. Kluge, the novel's author, was taken by Ruth Smilan, not by Rick Smillan.

In today's ramped-up bar culture, the sweetness of Curaçao or Triple Sec, the orange liqueurs used in many classic cocktails, did not satisfy David Wondrich, the drinks historian and expert. So he worked with Alexandre Gabriel, the president of Cognac Ferrand in France, to develop a drier bitter orange Curaçao, like the kind made back in the 1800s. They researched 19th-century recipes, and the result is Pierre Ferrand Dry Curaçao Ancienne Méthod, made with an infusion of the dried skins of Seville oranges in unaged, clear brandy. The spirit is redistilled and blended with Cognac, seasonings like anise and grilled sugar, and more orange peels. It is then barrel-aged and emerges smooth, veiled with orange, kissed with sweetness and hinting of juniper, almonds and vanilla. Mr. Wondrich wrote the tasting and historic notes on the label.

Goodness only knows what was rattling around F. Scott Fitzgerald's brain when he said there were no second acts in American lives. As often as that line is quoted, that's about how often it has been proved wrong. Now, the flaw in Fitzgerald's train of thought is being demonstrated yet again. Poetry in Motion, the underground dabble in verse that made a subway ride to work more bearable, is getting a second act. The return of the program, discarded in 2008 and sorely missed by many, is being announced on Tuesday by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

After years of painful cuts and threats of teacher layoffs, New York officials laid out on Tuesday a decidedly more optimistic portrait of financing for city schools next year, saying they expected that principals would have enough money in their budgets to retain most of their teachers and other school employees. In testimony before the City Council Education Committee, the schools chancellor, Dennis M. Walcott, said the Education Department's goal was to provide principals with a stable source of revenue next year so they could maintain the current level of instruction and other services.

LOS ANGELES - After weeks of storm, stress and no small amount of pressure - online and otherwise - over the R rating assigned to the antibullying documentary ''Bully,'' the Weinstein Company said late Monday that it would release the film without a rating. That decision appears to mark something of a draw between the Weinstein operation and the Classification and Rating Administration, which is overseen by both theater owners and the Motion Picture Association of America.

The seven books of the Harry Potter series are now available as e-book editions, the author J.K. Rowling announced on Tuesday. The e-books are for sale only through Ms. Rowling's Pottermore Web site, ArtsBeat reported, the books will first be sold in English, with editions in French, Spanish, German and Italian coming later. The first books in the series are priced at $7.99 each, while the last four will cost $9.99 each. Read more at ArtsBeat This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Some MF Global employees were aware of a shortfall in the firm's customer accounts days before filing for bankruptcy on Oct. 31, according to people involved in the case, a revelation that raises questions about why the firm failed to safeguard client money and whether it withheld information from authorities. One such indication came from an internal document suggesting that the firm was putting customer funds at risk on Oct. 27, an MF Global executive, Christine Serwinski, is expected to tell a Congressional panel on Wednesday. Specifically, the firm had burned through a buffer of its own money and was using the cash of customers who were trading overseas, according to one of the people involved in the case.

Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about a debate among members of the Park Slope Food Co-op over whether to boycott products from Israel misstated an affiliation of a co-op member who supports a boycott and also misstated the given name of a visitor to the co-op. The member, Liz Roberts, is part of a group known as the Park Slope Food Co-op Members for B.D.S. (Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions) group; there is no co-op ''B.D.S. board.'' And it was Nechama Marcus, not Mechama, who visited the co-op.

LONDON - American private equity firms are playing a waiting game in Europe. These firms, the Carlyle Group, Apollo Global Management and Oaktree Capital Management among them, have been raising billions of dollars during Europe's sovereign debt crisis to buy loan portfolios, corporate bonds and other holdings from troubled financial institutions on the Continent. The firms are betting that they can snap up cheap assets for as little as 10 cents on the dollar.

The Obama administration's proposed rule to control greenhouse gas emissions from new power plants -- the first ever -- could go far toward closing out the era of old-fashioned coal-burning power generation. The draft rule, unveiled on Tuesday by Lisa P. Jackson, the Environmental Protection Agency administrator, would limit carbon dioxide emissions from new power plants to 1,000 pounds per megawatt-hour.

The troubled New York law firm Dewey & LeBoeuf has overhauled its leadership amid questions about its financial condition and a stream of partner defections. Dewey's chairman, Steven H. PALM BEACH, Fla. - The Giants will host the Dallas Cowboys in the N.F.L.'s season opener Sept. 5 at MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J. Since 2004, the Super Bowl champion has hosted the opener, with the home team going 8-0 in those games. The game will be played at 8:30 p.m. on a Wednesday night, so it does not conflict with President Obama's speech at the Democratic National Convention the next night.

9:05 p.m. | Updated An internal memorandum from one of the country's leading organizations against same-sex marriage outlined a plan to help its cause by exploiting unease among blacks over the issue. The undated memo was one of several documents unsealed by a federal judge on Monday in a case in Maine, where the group, the National Organization for Marriage, helped finance a successful ballot initiative in 2009 overturning the state's legalization of same-sex marriage.

An obituary on Monday about the sociologist Irving Louis Horowitz referred incorrectly to Kathryn Mills, the author of a letter to The New York Times in 1984 criticizing Mr. Horowitz's biography of the sociologist C. Wright Mills. She is Mills's daughter, not his widow.

Florida, which is expected to be a vital swing state once again in this year's presidential election, is enrolling fewer new voters than it did four years ago as prominent civic organizations have suspended registration drives because of what they describe as onerous restrictions imposed last year by Republican state officials. The state's new elections law -- which requires groups that register voters to turn in completed forms within 48 hours or risk fines, among other things -- has led the state's League of Women Voters to halt its efforts this year. Rock the Vote, a national organization that encourages young people to vote, began an effort last week to register high school students around the nation -- but not in Florida, over fears that teachers could face fines. And on college campuses, the once-ubiquitous folding tables piled high with voter registration forms are now a rarer sight.

The fight between two branches of performing arts - voice and dance - tipped decidedly to the singers Monday night in the area that counts most in television, younger adult viewers. But ''The Voice'' on NBC and ''Dancing With the Stars'' on ABC are doing enough damage to each other to ensure that Fox's ''American Idol'' will regain its status as the top-rated weekly show with its Wednesday edition.

FINERMAN--Jane, born April 23, 1937, passed away on Sunday, March 25, 2012. She was the daughter of Dr. Irvin and Dorothy Stein of Philadelphia. She attended the Friends' Select School in Philadelphia and cherished her summers spent at Tripp Lake Camp in Poland, Maine. In 1959, she graduated from the University of Pennsylvania where she met her first husband, Dr. Gerald Finerman. The Finermans raised their children in Beverly Hills, California. Jane taught elementary school, specializing in bilingual education, in the Los Angeles Unified School District for many years. While teaching, she also earned a Master's Degree in Education from California State University, Northridge. After raising her children, Jane relocated to Boca Raton, Florida, where she continued to teach and eventually remarried Carl Hutman, to whom she was married for the last 14 years of her life. In recent years, Jane and Carl divided their time between Boca Raton and New York City, to be closer to their children and grandchildren. Beloved by her large family and legions of friends, Jane was, by all accounts, a force of nature opinionated and strong-willed, never afraid to speak her mind. She was deeply compassionate and concerned for others. She possessed a sharp mind and was known for her quick wit. Above all else, Jane had a passion for early childhood education and children's literacy. She was dedicated to her children's and grandchildren's educations and was immensely proud of their successes in life. A devoted wife, mother, grandmother, and sister, Jane is survived by her husband, Carl Hutman; her daughter, Wendy (David); son, Mark (Lisa); daughter, Karen (Lawrence); daughter, Leslie (Sean); and daughter, Stacey, as well as two step-daughters, Debbie Meisenzahl (Bill) and Susan Arndt (Daniel). She was predeceased by her son, Scott. Jane leaves behind thirteen grandchildren, whom she adored: Dorothy, Henry, James, Grace, Lucy, Jack, Alex, Drew, Kate, William, Tess, Lars, and Ellis. She is also survived by her sisters, Kathy Sachs and Margery Schab. Services Wednesday, March 28, 3pm at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65 Street. Donations may be made to Dr. Moldwin's Interstitial Cystitis Research Fund at The Smith Institute for Urology.

Now that the new iPad supports so-called ''retina'' resolution - namely the uber-HD 2048x1536 pixels that delivers crisp text and and great 3-D gaming - most of the video media you're probably viewing on your older devices will probably look like an unmitigated mess. What to do? Upscale, young users. If you're trying to drag your own content onto the iPad, you're probably used to converting it to Apple's specific format and resolution. Now, however, that resolution is considerably higher. The solution? Up the resolution.

While the Tribeca Film Festival has never been shy in scheduling Hollywood studio movies for its opening or closing nights (like ''The Interpreter'' with Nicole Kidman or ''Baby Mama'' with Tina Fey and Amy Poehler), blockbuster action pictures are not typically part of its usual fare. But this year, Marvel's superhero team ''The Avengers'' will be the final act of the annual gathering, on April 28. ''The Avengers,'' starring Robert Downey Jr., Chris Evans, Mark Ruffalo, Scarlett Johansson and Samuel L. Jackson, was directed by Joss Whedon, best known for the television series ''Buffy the Vampire Slayer.'' The comic, first published in 1963, unites Iron Man, the Incredible Hulk, Thor, Hawkeye, Black Widow and Captain America to battle evildoers. The movie, which will be released nationally on May 4, is expected to be one of the biggest box-office draws this summer. As part of the publicity extravaganza, the festival is inviting what it calls ''everyday heroes'' from uniformed agencies and the military to attend the screening and meet the cast. ''Marvel's 'The Avengers' is an exciting ride that absolutely transports audiences,'' Jane Rosenthal, one of the founders of the festival, said in a statement. ''It is the perfect way to end our 11th Festival.'' More information can be found on the festival Web site.

-The owner of a Brooklyn tortilla factory where a worker died after falling into a mixing machine has been arrested on charges of underpaying employees, falsifying business records and violating workers' compensation and unemployment insurance laws, the authorities said on Wednesday. -The owner, Erasmo Ponce, faces 26 felony counts and 23 misdemeanor counts, according to a complaint filed in Brooklyn Criminal Court by Eric T. Schneiderman, the state's attorney general. Mr. Ponce surrendered to the authorities on Tuesday and was arraigned and released without bail, his lawyer said.

WILSON--Isabel Brown. The staff and Board of Trustees of the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston, acknowledge with great sorrow the death, on March 27, of MFAH Life Trustee and former Chairman Isabel Brown Wilson, at 80. Mrs. Wilson's philanthropy had a transformative impact not only on the MFAH but also on the arts, culture and civic life of Houston. She was extraordinarily generous with her time, energy, opinion and resources. Following the tradition of leadership of her legendary family, and in particular that of her mother, Alice Pratt Brown, Mrs. Wilson became an MFAH Trustee in 1979 and was elected Chairman of the Board in 2001. She was the second woman to hold this position; her mother was the first, in 1973, having spearheaded the building of the museum's Brown Pavilion, which was designed by Ludwig Mies van der Rohe and opened in 1974. During Mrs. Wilson's six-year tenure as Chairman, the MFAH collections and programs grew dramatically, with nearly 16,000 works of art acquired and more than 200 exhibitions presented. Over the course of 30 years, she and her husband, Wallace Wilson; and The Brown Foundation, Inc., made possible the acquisition of major works of art by Rembrandt, Jean-Simeon Chardin, J.M.W. Turner, Georgia O'Keeffe and James Turrell, as well as significant antiquities. In the 1980s and 1990s, the museum's endowment grew at an unprecedented rate, largely as the result of a Brown Foundation challenge grant that Mrs. Wilson initiated. The Museum of Fine Arts, Houston, has lost a treasured family member and extends deepest condolences to Mrs. Wilson's husband, Wallace Wilson; and to her family.

The question came from a 20-something son sitting next to his 50-something father, who I hope was proud because the question was thoughtful and, I'm sure, on the minds of many. Also, it took some guts. I had just given a speech to a group of family-business owners who were interested in professional development and succession planning. This was a very engaged group that was dedicated to improving their businesses and preparing them for the next generation. For me, it was the perfect audience because I was able to interact with several generations of owners with different experiences, perspectives and attitudes. I always look forward to taking questions, and this session was particularly rich.

Breaching House decorum, Representative Bobby L. Rush donned a hooded sweatshirt and sunglasses on the House floor on Wednesday in honor of Trayvon Martin, the teenager fatally shot in Florida in a case that has gained national attention. During the short morning speeches granted lawmakers each day, Mr. Rush, an Illinois Democrat, condemned what he said was the role of racial profiling in the death of Trayvon, who was unarmed when he was shot by a neighborhood watch volunteer in February. Trayvon's parents attended a House forum on racial profiling on Tuesday.

The business jet maker Hawker Beechcraft is readying a bankruptcy filing, people briefed on the matter said on Wednesday, dealing a blow to its private equity owners, Goldman Sachs and Onex Partners. Hawker, which is based in Wichita, Kan., said on Tuesday that it had obtained $120 million in additional loans to buy it time to fix its balance sheet. In exchange, a majority of the company's debt holders agreed to defer some interest payments and grant relief from loan covenants.

An article on Wednesday about a defect in defibrillator wires that may have led to some patient deaths misstated details of a 2011 recall of the wires, manufactured by St. Jude Medical. St. Jude stopped making the wires in 2010 and in 2011 sent a letter to physicians warning of problems with the wires; it says it did not issue a recall. (The Food and Drug Administration later classified the letter as a recall.) The article also misstated the number of deaths caused by the wire rubbing against the defibrillator, according to the company's data. It was seven, not 13.

Earl Scruggs, the bluegrass banjo player whose hard-driving picking style influenced generations of musicians and helped shape the sound of 20th-century country music with his guitar-strumming partner, Lester Flatt, died on Wednesday in a Nashville hospital. He was 88. His son Gary confirmed the death.

A civil rights group filed a federal lawsuit on Wednesday accusing the New York Police Department of illegally stopping tens of thousands of people in privately owned buildings across the city where officers had been given permission to enter by landlords. Police officers routinely arrest people on criminal-trespass charges with no justification, the suit says, creating what some residents describe as a police state in which they feel compelled to carry identification while performing mundane tasks like picking up mail or doing laundry.

It has been nine years since a rather futile protest brought the issue of Augusta National's lack of female members to the fore, but this year it has risen again -- in a much thornier form for the club that hosts the Masters. In 2003, it was Martha Burk, then the chairwoman of the National Council of Women's Organizations, who decided to press the issue of Augusta's all-male membership, but now, it stems from I.B.M.'s decision last year to name Virginia M. Rometty as its chief executive. Traditionally, I.B.M. chief executives are invited to join Augusta, which isn't a tradition that would get shoved aside lightly because I.B.M. remains one of only three main sponsors of the Masters. But Augusta has not only never had a female member, its former chairman Hootie Johnson famously responded to Burk's challenge with his declaration that he wouldn't be forced ''at the point of a bayonet'' to admit women.

Ernest Hemingway first met Gianfranco Ivancich in 1949 at a bar in Venice, where the two struck up a conversation about their war experiences. It was the beginning of a epistolary friendship. Hemingway remained close to Mr. Ivancich, a member of a noble Venetian family, and his sister, Adriana, whom Hemingway credited with inspiring his 1952 Pulitzer Prize-winning novel ''The Old Man and the Sea'' during her visit to Cuba in 1950. Now the John F. Kennedy Library Foundation is making available 15 letters it bought from Mr. Ivancich, now in his early 80s, that Hemingway wrote between 1953 and 1960 as he wandered through Cuba; Ketchum, Idaho; Kilimanjaro; Nairobi; Paris; and Madrid. The library also acquired a manuscript of ''The Faithful Bull,'' a tale that Hemingway wrote for Mr. Ivancich's nephew. The letters -- at turns chatty, amusing and touching -- offer a glimpse into Hemingway's more private self. In one, above, dated Feb. 22, 1953, from Cuba, he describes having to shoot his beloved cat Willie after he was hit by a car. Someone else offered to do the job, but Hemingway writes that he could not risk ''a chance of Will knowing anybody was killing him.'' He goes on to say that a group of tourists unexpectedly drove up: ''I still had the rifle, and I explained to them they had come at a bad time and to please understand and go away. But the rich Cadillac psycho said: 'We have come at a most interesting time. Just in time to see the great Hemingway cry because he has to kill a cat.' '' In response, he writes, ''I humiliated him as he should be humiliated, omit details.''

BOSTON -- Every other Monday, right before class ends, Muhammad Zaman, a Boston University biomedical engineering professor, hands out a one-page form asking students to anonymously rate him and the course on a scale of one to five. It asks more, too: ''How can the professor improve your learning of the material?'' ''Has he improved his teaching since the last evaluation? In particular, has he incorporated your suggestions?'' ''How can the material be altered to improve your understanding of the material?'' ''Anything else you would like to convey to the professor?''

Much has changed since Karen Mills, the administrator for the Small Business Administration, first sat down with us back in the fall of 2009. The economy is improving, unemployment is falling, and S.B.A. lending is back to pre-recession levels. Ms. Mills's agency, however, still faces pressing challenges. Fewer S.B.A. loans are reaching the smallest, underserved businesses. And both the agency and the Obama administration are under intense pressure to show that they are creating jobs, even as the White House proposes new cuts to the S.B.A. budget. Last week, The Agenda sat down with Ms. Mills once more to discuss some of these issues - and to ask her questions submitted by You're the Boss readers. What follows is a condensed version of that conversation. Special thanks to the readers who submitted questions.

(NBC) COMMUNITY In the first half of a two-part episode Shirley (Yvette Nicole Brown) and Pierce (Chevy Chase) lose their appetites when a Subway shop opens in the college cafeteria, so they team up with Britta (Gillian Jacobs) to try to shut it down. Though he encounters problems with the language barrier and hasn't negotiated with factory owners before, he remains committed to what he calls his ''humorous domestic hygiene product.''

RONSON--Kay. Beloved wife of Harold for 57 years, devoted and cherished mother of Norma (James) and Joanne, loving grandmother of Lauren and Jonathan, died on March 26th after a long journey with Alzheimer's. Born in Postenkill, NY, she received an R.N. from Samaritan Hospital and a BS and MS in nursing from Russell Sage College. She served on the nursing faculty of Russell Sage for many years where she taught medical-surgical and psychiatric nursing. Her family later moved to New York City and also resided in Longboat Key, FL. In New York City she became involved in Central Synagogue and at the age of 63 became a Bat Mitzvah. She was a strong supporter of the Sarasota Opera and Temple Beth Israel of Longboat Key. Kay is also survived by her brother Ben (Gail) and nieces Julie and Cathy. Kay was an independent spirit whose focos was always on her family first and her goals kept her moving forward. She is deeply and sorely missed by all who loved her as she loved them. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Weill Cornell Medical College, Relkin Research, 1300 York Avenue, Box 123, NY NY, 10065, Attn: Adrienne Rose or Central Synagogue, 123 East 55th Street, NY, NY 10022.

The Windows Start menu lists programs in alphabetical order by default, but if you would prefer to arrange things in your own way, you can override the alphabet. Just right-click on the Start button, choose Properties from the contextual menu and click on the Start menu tab in the Properties box. Click the Customize button, scroll down and remove the checkmark from the box next to ''Sort All Programs menu by name.'' Click O.K. to close the Properties box and apply the new settings. You can now drag programs into your preferred order on the Start menu. Personal Tech invites questions about computer-based technology to QandA @nytimes.com. This column will answer questions of general interest, but letters cannot be answered individually.nThis is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

PARIS - When London's National Gallery mounted its blockbuster Leonardo da Vinci exhibition late last year, advance tickets sold out the first week, online scalpers pocketed up to $400 per ticket and crowds lined up around the block at dawn for the paltry number of tickets still for sale. Now it may be Paris's turn. On Thursday, the Louvre unveils a newly restored Leonardo masterpiece, ''The Virgin and Child With St. Anne,'' the centerpiece of a major exhibition running through June 25 of more than 130 works exploring the painting's genesis, execution and legacy, as well as the cult of St. Anne in the late 15th century.

A picture caption on Wednesday with the continuation of an article about voter registration groups that have curbed their efforts in Florida because of new restrictions in elections laws there misidentified one of the women shown at a luncheon, second from the right. She is Jean Walker, a board member for the League of Women Voters of Seminole County -- not Deirdre Macnab, the president of the League of Women Voters of Florida.

Police surveillance video obtained by ABC News shows George Zimmerman, the Florida man who has set off a national outrage over his killing of an unarmed teenager in February, as he arrived at the Sanford, Fla., police station on the night of the shooting. Mr. Zimmerman, 28, said he shot the 17-year-old student, Trayvon Martin, in self-defense after an altercation in which Trayvon punched him in the nose, knocked him over and slammed his head into the sidewalk. His lawyer, Craig Sonner, has said that Mr. Zimmerman's nose was broken. He has not been arrested or charged.

Yes, it's really catchy. And it's pretty funny, especially the ''drunk girl roll call.'' (''Becky -- the drunkest one.'' ''Theresa -- someone's cousin.'') And yes, I have observed the phenomenon it satirizes, though in my experience such groups tend to be less huge, both collectively and individually. ''It'' is ''Huge Group of Girls,'' a comedy-music video posted in January by Last Call Cleveland, which bills itself as a sketch comedy group. The mostly PG-13 production (with some explicit language), featuring a large group of women dancing, texting, stomping, drinking, glaring and looking for Stacy (she's missing), has accumulated about 690,000 views in not quite three months.

FISH--Charles H.,died March 27, 2012 of natural causes. He was born May 11, 1928, the only son of Morris and Bess (nee Kraus) Fish and the half brother of Jack and Sylvia Fish. Mr. Fish was a graduate of Boys High School, Brooklyn, and received his BS in Accounting from St Johns University in 1948. He was a licensed CPA and a retired tax partner from Arthur Andersen & Co., where he had a long and successful career. Mr. Fish lived his entire life in New York, mostly in Brooklyn and for the last 10 years, in Manhattan. He loved the city and everything it had to offer, especially the performing and visual arts, the variety of great cuisine and the ability to walk almost anywhere. He was a keen patron of the theater, and various opera and symphony houses. He was predeceased by his wife of 48 years, Seena Israel Fish. He is survived by his children, daughters Melissa Fish Darrow of Atlanta, GA, Nora Fish of Brooklyn, NY, son, Jason Fish, and daughter-in-law, Courtney Benoist, of San Francisco, CA. He was the proud grandfather of five grandchildren, Susannah and Sarah Darrow, and Genevieve, Grace and Alexander Fish. He also is survived and missed by many friends and family members, especially his close companion Patricia Peck. There will be a service at Green-Wood Cemetery, Brooklyn, Sunday at 12:30. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that you make a donation to the opera house of your choice in honor of Charles Fish.

FEUER--Alan Zachary, died March 26, 2012. A memorial service will be held Saturday, March 31 at 4pm at The Church of the Incarnation, 209 Madison Avenue, New York, NY. In lieu of flowers, please send donations in Alan's memory to the Soliders', Sailors', Marines' & Airmen's Club, 283 Lexington Avenue, New York, NY 10016 made out to SSMAC.

Senator Marco Rubio of Florida endorsed Mitt Romney on Wednesday night on Fox News's ''Hannity'' show, calling Mr. Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts, ''a stark contrast to the president's record.'' ''I am going to endorse Mitt Romney and the reason why is not only because he is going to be the Republican nominee but he offers, at this point, such a stark contrast to the president's record,'' Mr. Rubio told the show's host, Sean Hannity. ''In Mitt Romney, we have a candidate, an alternative, that in addition to being successful as a governor, running an important state in this country, has also been successful in the private sector and offers a very clear alternative to the direction this president is going to take our country.''

FIRST-DAY GAIN Annie's, the organic food maker, soared on its stock market debut on Wednesday, rising 63.7 percent, to $31.11 a share, at its open. Shares closed close at $35.92. The company, best known for its organic macaroni and cheese and its smiling rabbit mascot, priced its initial public offering at $19 a share on Tuesday night, above the expected range of $16 to $18 a share. EVELYN M. RUSLI

A standalone highlight on Monday headlined ''Three Times a Charm,'' with coverage of the N.C.A.A. men's basketball tournament, misstated the year that Louisville Coach Rick Pitino became the first coach to advance to the Final Four with teams from three universities (Providence, Kentucky and Louisville). He accomplished that in 2005, not at this tournament when Louisville advanced to the Final Four.

Last week, we published a case study that looked at a team of four toy designers - Chris Dahlberg, H. Eric Mayse, Jim Preziosi and Eric Treadaway - faced with a quandary: how to expand their business so that they are not so dependent on their one big client, Mattel. Their company, the Four Horsemen Toy Design Studio, has revenue of more than $500,000 a year, most of it from its contract work for Mattel. They have a staff of three to help with sculpting, painting and shipping in their workshop in Butler, N.J. They want to design and sell their own collectible action figures, but their work for Mattel leaves them with little time to focus on their own toy lines. They have created four lines so far, but to be successful, they believe the lines need a back story supported by content from movies, TV or comic books.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba -- Brian Boyle, a fresh gap adorning his grin, scored a strange goal 3 minutes 7 seconds into the third period Wednesday night, sparking the Rangers to a 4-2 victory over the Winnipeg Jets. It was the Rangers' third straight win and it widened their lead atop the Eastern Conference to 5 points over the Pittsburgh Penguins with a week and a half left in the regular season.

It's been three years since TiVo promised that a high-definition version of its DirecTV-compatible digital videorecorder would be available shortly. And now, it finally is. DirecTV's original standard-definition recorders were manufactured by TiVo. Seven years ago, the companies ended their exclusive relationship.

The Whitney isn't the only museum to involve dance artists in its programming. The Museum of Modern Art has commissioned the artist and choreographer Ralph Lemon to create a three-week program of dance performances entitled ''Some Sweet Day'' to be presented in the Donald B. and Catherine C. Marron Atrium Oct. 15 to Nov. 4. Organized by Mr. Lemon and Jenny Schlenzka, the associate curator at MoMA PS1, the series will showcase three pairings of six choreographers intended to demonstrate, according to a statement from the museum, how dance engages with ''aesthetics, gender, race and history as well the potential of the museum space.'' The program includes two Steve Paxton works, ''Satisfying Lover'' (1967) and ''State''(1968), juxtaposed with ''The Show Must Go On'' (2001) by the French choreographer Jérôme Bel. The second and third weeks will feature new commissioned works created specifically for the atrium space by the Congolese dancer and choreographer Faustin Linyekula, with the American experimentalist Dean Moss. It will also include a two-day interstitial performance by the artist Kevin Beasley. The final week will present the pairing of Deborah Hay and Sarah Michelson.
TORCHON-BELMOUR--Gislene on March 24, 2012. Funeral Service, 11am, Saturday March 31, 2012, Andrett Funeral Home 353 Second Avenue NY, NY 10010 Visitation will be from 9am-11am before the services.

The opening scenes of the Season 5 premiere of ''Mad Men,'' set in 1966, depicted a sort of knucklehead-racism at work, when young men from the advertising agency Young & Rubicam dropped bags filled with water on protesters picketing on the Madison Avenue sidewalk below. Wet and angry, several protesters came upstairs to demand to know who at the firm had dropped the water bombs. One protester said in disgust, ''And they call us savages.''

An article on Tuesday about a rule proposed by the Environmental Protection Agency that would limit carbon dioxide emissions from power plants misstated the amount they would be allowed to emit. The limit would be 1,000 pounds per megawatt-hour of energy produced, not 1,000 tons.

FX is adding a new late-night show from Chris Rock featuring the comedian W. Kamau Bell to its lineup of original comedy series. During the weekly half-hour, of which the network has ordered six installments, Mr. Bell will take on provocative issues including politics, race, religion, media and sex, said Nick Grad, the executive vice president of original programming at FX. Mr. Bell is a founding member of the comedy group Laughter Against the Machine. ''I think Kamau is one of the funniest guys out there,'' said Mr. Rock, who is also the show's executive producer. Mr. Rock's track record includes a raft of successful film, television and comedy projects that have won him four Emmy awards and three Grammys, and he made a well-received debut on Broadway last year in Stephen Adly Guirgis's ''The ---------------------- With the Hat.''

TAFFEL--Mendy, 82, died on March 27 after a courageous battle with cancer. He leaves behind "the best thing that ever happened to him", his wife, Ruth, children, Valerie Tarrow, Shelley and Joe Won and Kim Silverstein, grandchildren, David, Michael and Leslie, Marc, Jason, Jordyn and Dani, great-grandson, Camden and brother Sam. Mendy was born in Brooklyn, the youngest of seven siblings. His life was spent taking care of his family and his work. He started his business, Mendon Leasing Corporation in 1958, was a great contributor to many charities, and was the first President of the Men's Club of Shore Parkway Jewish Center in Brooklyn. Services will held on Thursday March 29 at 1pm at Riverside Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.
Update: Addresses new features added today. The new free iPhone app from photo storage and sharing site SmugMug has something to be smug about.

Hilton Kramer, who died on Tuesday at 84, arrived at The New York Times in 1965 and became the paper's chief art critic in 1973. He founded the conservative literary journal The New Criterion in 1982, and he was no stranger to politicized culture wars, even if his most common tactic was to rail against the very idea of art as an ideological battleground. Perhaps the most provocative work Mr. Kramer wrote for The Times was ''The Blacklist and the Cold War,'' a 1976 article for the Arts & Leisure section. In it he bemoaned what he saw as the historical revisionism fueling popular culture that was ''assiduously turning the terrors and controversies of the late 1940s into the entertainments and best sellers of the 1970s.''

An annual report from a regional Federal Reserve bank is typically a collection of banalities and clichés with some pictures of local worthies who serve on the board. And so it is with this year's annual report from the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas, whose pages are graced by the smiling, stolid portraits of board members who run local companies like Whataburger Restaurants.

While other sports photographers head to Florida for spring training, Sol Neelman drives through the mountains of Idaho looking for K-9 keg pulls and a skijoring event (skiers, pulled by horses). His itineraries are not shaped by the N.F.L. season or the P.G.A. tour, but by the schedules of weekend warriors pursuing oddball pastimes. ''If I can fit the mini-park wiffle ball tournament into the same weekend as the mud football championship, that's a trip I have to take,'' Mr. Neelman said.

PALM BEACH, Fla. - Tom Benson, the owner of the New Orleans Saints, headed home from the N.F.L. meetings Wednesday with the immediate future of his franchise still in flux. One thing seems clear, though: Bill Parcells is strongly considering the chance to coach, or at least consult for, the Saints while his friend Sean Payton is suspended for his role in the team's bounty program. Parcells, 70, played golf with Payton and Saints General Manager Mickey Loomis on Tuesday. In a text message Wednesday, Parcells said that he had not been offered the job. He added: ''Several things have to happen that are unclear. Even then still not sure. Long way off.''

Airplane cockpits are meant to be the last line of defense from outside aggressors. But what if the threat comes from the cockpit itself? On Tuesday, a JetBlue pilot who was behaving erratically was physically restrained by passengers after his co-pilot locked him out of the cockpit. With chaos in the cabin, the plane, flying from New York to Las Vegas, was forced to make an emergency landing in Amarillo, Tex.

SINCE its introduction in 1984, advertising for Depend, the adult incontinence brand by Kimberly-Clark, has tended to feature elderly actors golfing, gardening or fawning over grandchildren. The message, naturally, was that the products enabled them to be active without fear of embarrassment. But a new Depend campaign aimed at baby boomers takes a decidedly different approach, featuring younger celebrities who are not incontinent but agree to model the products as a stunt to benefit charity. The campaign is to introduce brieflike products, Silhouette for Women and Real Fit for Men.

KORNBLUH--Bettina Nisselson, 93, of Queens died March 26. First generation daughter of Jewish immigrants, grew up in Brooklyn. Attended Thomas Jefferson High and Kings County Hospital School of Nursing; earned R.N. 1940, and B.S. in Elementary Ed, Hofstra, 1967. Survived by Sol, husband of 69 years, sons Martin, John, daughters-in-law Judy, Andrea, grandchildren Anna, Gregory. Clear-eyed matriarch, generations appreciate her generous support. Accomplished Scrabbler, crossworder, needlepointer, Mah Jongg player. Critical appraiser, harboring no illusions. Active member of Ethical Culture Society of Long Island; advocate of reproductive rights and public education. Foodie before we knew that word; remembered for hosting parties, discerning taste, and luscious pumpkin chiffon pie.
International MILITIAS IN THE CONGO
