An article on Tuesday about Britain's request that China open an investigation into the death of a British citizen, Neil Heywood, who has been linked to the family of Bo Xilai, who was dismissed this month as the Communist Party secretary of Chongquing, misstated the given name of Mr. Heywood's widow in some editions. It is LuLu, not Leonie. And because of an editing error, the article referred incorrectly to an account of accusations of poisoning lodged by a Chongqing crimefighter, Wang Lijun. He reportedly claimed that Mr. Heywood had been the target of the poisoning -- not Mr. Wang's boss, Bo Xilai.

In this week's Dashboard, we quoted from a guide to using Pinterest prepared by Jay Ehret, a marketing specialist. As you may have heard, Pinterest is a fast-growing new Web site where users can create sites of photos ''pinned'' from other parts of the Web. We went back to Mr. Ehret with a few questions about how small businesses can use Pinterest. Q: Why do you think Pinterest has become so popular? A: It's brilliant in its simplicity. Users just collect things they like. Simple. Their Pinboards are passively shared with their Pinterest friends, and they can peek in on anyone else's Pinboards. Another big reason is that Pinterest is visual. People are attracted to pictures more than they are words.

RONSON--Kay. We note with sorrow the passing of our longtime member Kay Ronson and extend sincerest condolences to her bereaved family. Rabbi Peter Rubinstein and President Kenneth Heitner, Central Synagogue of New York City

ELIAS--Albert Louis, author of the book "A Life With More Ups Than Downs," died on Tuesday, March 27 at 1:00pm. He was 65 years old. Elias was born in New York City on November 9th, 1946 with cerebral palsy. He was educated at the American School in London and at Greenwich High School (class of 1965). He went on to earn a BA in Philosophy and Government from Boston University. After graduation in 1969, he returned to London, where he worked in the Marketing department for Norman, Craig, and Kummel, until he returned to the United States in 1977. While in London, he was active in Shelter: the National Campaign for the Homeless, the Camden Council for International Relations, the United Nations Association, and the Unitarian Church. Elias returned to New York and lived in Scarsdale from 1977-1997, working in the Purchasing department of United Cerebral Palsy. During those years he was active in the Greenville Community Theater, the Scarsdale Audubon Society, the Unitarian Church, and the United Nations Association. In 1997 he retired to Florida, and lived in West Palm Beach until his death. Albert was predeceased by his father Albert J and his brother William. He is survived by his mother Rea, his niece Vanessa, his two nephews Jon and Ben, and his three great-nieces Stella, Ava, and Sophie. Donations can be made in Albert's name to United Cerebral Palsy of New York City, or Habitat for Humanity International.

2:19 p.m. | Updated BERLIN - Bertelsmann, the biggest media company in Europe, said Wednesday that it was considering a public share offering to raise money for expansion. The move is a striking change of heart by the controlling Mohn family, which previously resisted such efforts.

Three of the four executives at MF Global called to testify before a House panel on Wednesday said that they were cooperating with federal authorities. Christine Serwinski, the chief financial officer for the firm's North America operations, has spoken to regulators on two occasions. Laurie Ferber, the firm's general counsel, is also cooperating with authorities. She said she was expecting to be interviewed on April 6. Lawyers for Henri Steenkamp, MF Global's chief financial officer, have also been in contact with authorities.

“Scenes of a Crime,” a documentary, explores modern police interrogation methods, specifically the Reid Technique, whose goal is to extract a confession using sophisticated psychological manipulation.

The American Museum of Natural History is opening an exhibition, “Creatures of Light,” that looks at the strange world of bioluminesence.
The exhibition “Colorful Realm” at the National Gallery of Art in Washington focuses on some 30 scrolls painted by a 17th-century Japanese monk that depict flora and fauna in exacting detail.
Ryan McDonagh says the Rangers’ coaches do not let anything slide, a major reason the young players have developed and the team has won 49 games entering Friday.
Responding to a critical investigation of its factories, Foxconn, a top electronics supplier for Apple and other companies, pledged to curtail working hours and increase wages.

The German power firms RWE and E.On backed out of a venture to build nuclear plants in the south, a plan that would have provided cleaner burning energy in compliance with European laws.

To compete in the increasingly rugged American League, the Royals need high-impact players at low cost. Their shining example is Eric Hosmer, 22, who hit .293 last season.

After the release of unemployment reports, investors took a wait-and-see approach ahead of earnings season.

Aerosmith has teamed up again with Jack Douglas, who produced the band's blockbuster albums of the 1970s, and plans to release a long-delayed collection of new songs this summer to coincide with a North American tour. The veteran Boston hard-rock band made the announcement on Wednesday at a mall in Los Angeles, The Associated Press reported. Steven Tyler, the frontman, said he was finishing two final songs for the as-yet-unnamed album, which he said would come out in about three months.

8:59 p.m. | Updated Sheldon Adelson, the Las Vegas billionaire who has been the biggest backer to a group supporting Newt Gingrich, said this week that Mr. Gingrich had reached ''the end of his line'' in his bid for the presidency. Mr. Adelson, whose family has contributed more than $15 million to a ''super PAC'' supporting Mr. Gingrich, made the comments in a brief interview with The Jewish Journal at the Venetian resort in Las Vegas.

GRANT--Gardner Lewis of Purchase, NY and Jupiter, FL died on March 28, 2012, after a long battle with cancer. He was 85 years old. Raised in Providence, RI, Gardner was a graduate of Yale and Harvard Business School, and was the inventor of automatic toll machines. A life-long, passionate fly fisherman, Gardner served as president of New York's Theodore Gordon Fly Fishers, the Federation of Fly Fishers and the American Museum of Fly Fishing; and a board member of Trout Unlimited, the Atlantic Salmon Federation, the Hudson River Foundation for Science and Environmental Research and Yale's Peabody Museum of Natural History. Gardner also served as president of Sunningdale Country Club in Scarsdale, NY. Gardner is survived by his wife of over 60 years, Ellen, his daughter Laurie Zimmerman, son Gardner L. Grant, Jr, son-in-law Dr. Franklin H. Zimmerman, daughter-in-law Sulu Hegde Grant, and grandchildren Stacey, Ricky, Sean and Shakira. The family requests that any donations in Gardner's memory be made to the American Museum of Fly Fishing in Manchester, VT.

The Trinity Choir, which had announced a performance of an ''improvised Passion'' based on a text of the ''St. John Passion'' created by the National Conference of Christians and Jews (now the National Conference for Community and Justice) at Trinity Wall Street on Sunday morning, has changed its plans. On Thursday it reported through a publicist that it had not left enough time to get clearance from the church hierarchy to use the text. As a result, it said it would instead present an improvised version of the Passion According to St. Mark. That will be followed by its performance of Bach's ''St. John Passion'' at St. Paul's Chapel on Sunday afternoon.

A critic's notebook article on March 22 about the comedian Todd Barry referred incorrectly to his album ''Medium Energy.'' It was his first album, not his second. The article also misidentified the setting where he told a joke about people telling him that he is a genius and adorable. It was on ''Medium Energy,'' not at the New York club the Comedy Cellar.

DOMANSKY--Sophie. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Sophie Domansky. Sophie and her late husband, Harry, were dedicated donors, committed to helping Holocaust survivors, like themselves - as well as the entire Jewish community. The couple's son, Martin, and his wife, Paula, carry on a special legacy of charitable giving. We extend our condolences to Martin and Paula, and the entire family. Jerry W. Levin, President Alisa R. Doctoroff, Chair of the Board, John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

The Advertising column on Thursday, about a campaign for Depend incontinence products, using outdated information from the company, misstated the brand's charitable contributions to Dress for Success and the V Foundation. Dress for Success has been given $225,000, not $150,000; the V Foundation has been given $150,000, not $75,000.

LONDON - A review of 15 investment banks released on Thursday by Britain's financial regulator showed that a majority lacked adequate anticorruption and bribery checks. The Financial Services Authority said its review of the banks, including eight major global investment banks, had found that about half had an inadequate bribery risk assessment. The review, conducted during the second half of 2011, also found that managers were not sufficiently knowledgeable about anticorruption and bribery laws.

A report and a headline in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Thursday about plans for a new late-night show on FX misstated the comedian Chris Rock's role. While he is an executive producer of the show, as the report noted, the announcement from FX said that the comedian W. Kamau Bell would be the star -- not both Mr. Bell and Mr. Rock.

The DealBook column on Tuesday, about a tax dispute between the NetJets unit of Berkshire Hathaway and the Internal Revenue Service, referred incorrectly to Warren Buffett's aircraft ownership. He does not own a plane; he is a fractional owner through NetJets. (Berkshire sold the plane he called ''the Indispensable'' years ago.)

The maker of Etch A Sketch is trying to put a positive spin on its status as a political insult with a new advertisement campaign. ''Etch A Sketch is a lot like politics,'' reads one ad. ''There's a lot of gray area.''

BACON--Edward M.,Jr., on March 27th at his home in Greenwich, CT. Ed is survived by Isabelle, his wife of 55 years, his brother, Jack and his sister, Missy Ahrens, sons, E. Michael III and Thomas H. of Greenwich, daughters, Cary Winslow of Far Hills, NJ, and Beth Bacon-Blaber of Brooklyn, NY, and 12 grandchildren. Ed was a former partner at Kidder, Peabody and longtime volunteer at Covenant House. He graduated from the College of the Holy Cross in 1952. Most recently Ed resided in Vero Beach, FL. Funeral services will take place at St. Michael's in Greenwich on April 3rd at 11am. A memorial service will be held in Vero Beach at a later date. For more details visit www.leopgallagher.com

Because of an editing error, the Personal Health column on Tuesday, about the relationship between strong social ties and longer life, gave an outdated academic affiliation for Lisa F. Berkman, the lead author of a 1979 study that found evidence of such a relationship. Dr. Berkman, an epidemiologist, is at Harvard University -- not at Yale, where she worked at the time the study was published.

6:37 p.m. | Updated A woman sleeping inside a Brooklyn apartment was grazed by a bullet or small debris on Thursday after a plainclothes New York City police officer's gun discharged during a drug raid in an apartment a floor above her, the police said. -The woman, who was visiting from Japan, was struck on the inside of her left arm but did not even need stitches when she was checked at a nearby hospital, the police said.

XIDI, China -- In the spring, as rapeseed flowers bloom, this fertile swath of central China is transformed into a sea of yellow. In the summer, when rainstorms descend, the fields pulsate emerald green and canals brim with brown water. But through all the seasons here in the Huizhou region of Anhui Province, the weathered white-walled homes endure, rising like pottery shards from the earth, each one a testimony to the commercial acumen and prosperity of earlier generations.

Some of Wall Street's biggest banks are bracing for fallout from a possible cut in their credit ratings. Moody's Investors Service, one of the two big ratings agencies, has said it will decide in mid-May whether to lower its ratings for 17 global financial companies. Morgan Stanley, which was hit hard in the financial crisis, appears to be the most vulnerable. Moody's is threatening to cut the bank's ratings by three notches, to a level that would be well below the rating of a rival like JPMorgan Chase.

A museum review on Saturday about the Natural History Museum of Utah, in Salt Lake City, whose chief architect was Todd Schliemann of Ennead Architects, referred incompletely to an earlier project Mr. Schliemann took part in, the design of the Rose Center at the American Museum of Natural History in New York. He designed it with James Stewart Polshek as part of the firm Polshek Partnership Architects (which has changed its name to Ennead Architects); Mr. Schliemann was not the sole designer. Because of an editing error, a picture caption with the review misidentified the mountain range visible through windows shown in a picture of the Utah museum. While the museum is in the foothills of the Wasatch Range, the Oquirrh Mountains are seen in the picture, not the Wasatch.

The playwright Rajiv Joseph, a Pulitzer Prize finalist for ''Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo,'' and the Tony Award-winning musician Bill Sherman are collaborating on the new musical ''Fly,'' a darker re-telling of the Peter Pan story, which will have its world premiere in July 2013 at Dallas Theater Center, executives at the theater plan to announce on Thursday. The show will be part of a 2012-13 season that will also include a new play by Roberto Aguirre-Sacasa (''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark''), based on Bram Stoker's ''Dracula,'' and a new musical conceived by Kim Rosenstock (''Tigers Be Still'') about the New York City blackout of 1965.
With lawmakers unable to agree on a broader transportation measure, a 90-day extension averted a halt in financing for road and infrastructure projects.

I really don't think Justice Kennedy has any idea at the moment how he's going to vote in these cases. HELEN J. KNOWLES, author of a book about the justice, who is seen as the deciding vote in the health care law case. [A19]

Karam Nachar wants to topple President Bashar al-Assad of Syria. Every day, he wakes before dawn and begins working with other activists - planning opposition strategies, honing their message to the world media, and coordinating the smuggling of goods into the country to aid the revolution. They chat online or in the back rooms of cafes.

KALLAS--Judith Carroll. Judith Carroll Kallas passed away on March 24, 2012 of cardiac arrest. The beloved wife of John L. Kallas for the last 35 years, she pursued her busy and fulfilling life with undiminished energy. Born on July 24, 1937 in Trenton, NJ, she moved to New York City and became co-owner of Cornelia St. Cafe. Judith loved music and was a singer with the Greek Choral. She will be remembered as a deeply caring person by those who survive her her husband, John L. Kallas, her sister, Gail Orr, her brother-in-law, Thomas Orr, and her niece, Emily Orr. A memorial will be held at the Friends Meeting House on 15th Street in Manhattan on Saturday, April 14, 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Alzheimer's Foundation of America.

BURGER-LIVINGSTON--Mattie, 104. Phenomenal mother of Bonnie (Bob) Cooperman and Howard (Judy) Burger, died peacefully on March 27. Her heart overflowed with her love for her five grandchildren and 11 great-grandchildren, all of whom adored her. Mattie touched many lives in myriad wonderful ways. Her charismatic personality and upbeat spirit inspired us all. Always loved, never to be forgotten. Services private.

PARIS -- Paris Charles de Gaulle is the second-largest European airport in terms of passengers -- 61 million last year -- and the seventh-largest worldwide. Yet it doesn't get much love. According to Skytrax, a consulting firm based in London that publishes one of the world's leading passenger surveys of airports, Charles de Gaulle ranked No.34 last year out of the 73 European airports it covers and 89th out of 208 worldwide.

A picture caption on March 15 with photographs from the South by Southwest festival in Austin, Tex., misidentified a member of the band the Union Suits who was shown with his bass guitar. He is Zach Cotant, not Max Markin, the band's leader.

The market for initial public stock offerings is riding high as another company has soared in its first day of trading. On Thursday, shares of Millennial Media, a mobile advertising company, closed at $25, nearly double its initial offering price of $13.

The Town Hall on West 43rd Street, whose stage has featured speakers from Eleanor Roosevelt to President Obama and performers like Billie Holiday and Bob Dylan, has been designated a National Historic Landmark. The announcement, made by the secretary of the Interior, Ken Salazar, makes the Town Hall the only new entry to the list of National Historic Landmarks in New York City. Designed by McKim, Mead & White, the hall was built in 1921 by the League for Political Education, a suffragist group whose fight for passage of the 19th Amendment led to the commissioning of the building as a meeting space. The hall, which became a New York City landmark in 1987, continues its spring season in the coming weeks with performances by the likes of Judy Collins and Jane Krakowski.

BATH--William H.,Roslyn, NY, 82, passed March 25th at home after a brave battle with cancer. Born August 21, 1929 in Brighton UK to Harry and Elizabeth (McQueen) Bath, Bill lived a life intertwined with the history of aviation. His lifelong passion for aircraft and the business of flight was sparked as a young Air Engineer with the Royal Air Force and continued upon his emigration to America in 1957. He worked through his illness, within the industry he loved, until January 2012. Bill served the industry trade society ISTAT as an Appraiser Fellow and Administrative Director of their International Appraisers' Program (Chairman 1994-97.) He was also a historian for the Wing's Club in Manhattan. In addition to his parents, Bill was predeceased by his first wife Lucie Leonne Maisonneuve. He is survived by his second wife Marie Bath and two adoring stepdaughters Jacquelyn and Coraline Dahlin who lived consistently enthralled by his storied passion for life and his life's work. Bill will remain forever in our hearts. Services will be held on March 31st from 2 until 4pm at Knowles Funeral Home in Port Washington.

An article on Saturday about efforts by some companies to collect and recycle their own packaging misidentified the state in which one such company, the yogurt maker Stonyfield Farm, is based. It is New Hampshire, not Vermont.

WEINFLASH--Ruth Stupell, 80, of Cresskill, NJ died on March 27, at home with her husband and children at her side. Born on August 5, 1931, to Edward and Leah Stupell in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn; graduated from Connecticut College in 1952. Ruth was an actress, both by nature as well as by training having received accolades in her productions of Tennessee Williams' plays, until she became involved in a production of her own - her marriage to her beloved Bernie of 55 years. Cherishedmother of Jody (Steve) Konstadt, Jeff (Elahna) Weinflash and Carol (Michael) Kopelman; Adored Granmum of Michelle, Debbie, Sarah, Eden, Noah, Emily and Naomi. She was a woman of valor and integrity, vibrant and poetic, and always - a lovelylady. She was adored and treasured by all who knew and loved her - and always will be. Donations can be made to Shirah Choir at the Kaplen JCC or to James F. Holland Research Foundation at Mount Sinai Hospital. Services will take place at 12:30pm on Friday at Temple Emanu-el in Closter, NJ.

An article on Thursday about medical and psychological screening of airline pilots, using information from the Federal Aviation Administration, misstated the percentage of pilots with a first-class medical certificate who have been granted a waiver to fly while taking certain psychiatric medications. It is 0.016 percent, not 0.00016 percent.

Hedge funds have endured a rough year. Tumultuous markets. Tighter regulations. An insider trading crackdown. But despite the lackluster environment, the top managers still took home $14.4 billion in 2011.

YOUNG-BRUEHL--Elisabeth. The New York Memorial for Elisabeth Young-Bruehl will be held Sunday, April 1, 2012, 2pm, New York University School of Law, Greenberg Lounge at Vanderbilt Hall, 40 Washington Square South, NYC.

KORNBLUH--Bettina Nisselson, 93, of Queens died March 26. First generation daughter of Jewish immigrants, grew up in Brooklyn. Attended Thomas Jefferson High and Kings County Hospital School of Nursing; earned R.N. 1940, and B.S. in Elementary Ed, Hofstra, 1967. Survived by Sol, husband of 69 years, sons Martin, John, daughters-in-law Judy, Andrea, grandchildren Anna, Gregory. Clear-eyed matriarch, generations appreciate her generous support. Accomplished Scrabbler, crossworder, needlepointer, Mah Jongg player. Critical appraiser, harboring no illusions. Active member of Ethical Culture Society of Long Island; advocate of reproductive rights and public education. Foodie before we knew that word; remembered for hosting parties, discerning taste, and luscious pumpkin chiffon pie.

An Associated Press report in the N.B.A. roundup in some editions on Thursday described incorrectly the injury that has kept Chicago Bulls point guard Derrick Rose from playing recently. It is an injury to his groin, not a shoulder.

10 P.M. (Science) TED TALKS In this collection of the best TED conference talks, the producer and director J. J. Abrams tells of a ''mystery box'' he received as a child that he never opened, explaining that his fascination with the unknown drives his work. Bonnie Bassler, above, a molecular biologist, discusses a chemical language that allows bacteria to communicate. Robin Ince, a comedian, riffs on the relationship between science and wonder. And the inventor Skylar Tibbits speaks about the future of building and the nascent science of self-assembly. 8 P.M. (CBS) UNDERCOVER BOSS The chief executive of Yankee Candle learns how his company works at the store level when he dons a disguise (a curly wig and a soul patch) and pretends to be a new hire. But his go-getter attitude raises eyebrows when he expends considerable effort on customer service, and he almost blows his cover when he speaks up testily about a store's sloppy appearance.

GOMEZ--Alexander, beloved son of Mariette Himes Gomez and Raymond Gomez and cherished brother of Brooke Gomez, died on Wednesday, March 28, 2012 at age 42. Alex graduated from the Trinity School in NYC and Vassar College where he majored in Political Science. After graduation, he lived in Los Angeles for ten years and had a successful career with Court TV and The Fox Family Channel. His passion for music led him back to New York where he composed and produced. his music. He also performed at various clubs in NYC; among them, CBGB, Maxwells and The Bitter End. He will always be remembered by his family and many, many friends. In lieu of flowers, a donation may be made to: New York Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical Center for GI Oncology Research. Friends may call Sunday, April 1, 2012, 3-6pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, NY 10028. Mass of Christian Burial, Monday, April 2, 10am, St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue at 84th St. Interment private.

EVANS--David M.,of Hackettsown, NJ, formerly of Glen Ridge, NJ, died on March 26th. at age 82. He graduated from Williams College in 1952, and served in the U.S. Air Force in Germany. His subsequent career was in international insurance brokerage, first with the American Foreign Insurance Association, where he spent many years overseas and in New York City in charge of European, Middle Eastern and African operations. He later was a senior vice president with Marsh and McLennan, Inc., and president and CEO of Resolute Reinsurance Company. He is survived by his wife Deborah, children Charles and Katherine, grandchildren Chas and Emily and brothers Jack and Dean. He will be deeply missed by those who knew him.

WINOGRAD--Morris, of Clifton, NJ, beloved husband of Ruth (nee Erlichman) devoted father of Steven (Damon), Barry (Ann) and Lynne (Lorraine). For over 60 years he was President of Morris Winograd Insurance Co. Jersey City and allied businesses. Services Sunday 11:15am at Robert Schoem Menorah Chapel, W 150 Rt. 4 East Paramus. (201) 843 9090.

The blooms may be off the branches, but there is still plenty left of the monthlong National Cherry Blossom Festival, including a kite-flying extravaganza on Saturday on the grounds of the Washington Monument. Where to eat when you are taking it all in? For those who do not mind more walking, or an inexpensive taxi ride, here are suggestions for meals, snacks or cocktails in the National Mall neighborhood: Several of the Smithsonian Institution museums facing the Mall have reasonable options, though they generally close by 5 p.m. There's the Castle Café at the Smithsonian Castle. Across the Mall is the National Museum of Natural History (10th Street and Constitution Avenue), which has the Atrium Café, Fossil Café and ice cream and espresso bars. On the Mall closer to the Capitol is the National Museum of the American Indian, where the Mitsitam Café serves food inspired by Indian fare.
KRAMER--Hilton. The New York Studio School of Drawing, Painting and Sculpture regrets the passing of Hilton Kramer, longtime friend, trustee, and supporter of the School.

WEINFLASH--Ruth. We deeply mourn the loss of our beloved lifelong friend, Ruth Weinflash. She was kind, loving, caring, talented, vivacious and witty. We send our sincere condolences to Bernie, her beloved husband and life partner of over 55 years. Also, our condolences go to her children Jody, Jeffrey and Carol, and all of their children. May all of the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Arnold and Siema

LANE--Mark Wiley, age 44, Managing Director in Fixed Income at Lazard Capital Markets of Brooklyn, NY died suddenly in an accident on March 24, 2012 on the island of Providenciales, Turks and Caicos while on vacation with his family. Mr. Lane is survived by his wife, Lisa, and four sons: Wiley, 13; Peyton, 12; Grant, 9, and Trevor, 8. Mr. Lane is also survived by his parents, Margo and Andrew Lane of Newton, MA, his brother Drew of Ridgewood, NJ and his sisters Sara of NYC and Julie of Newton, MA. Visiting hours on Saturday, March 31st from Noon to 2pm at Eaton & Mackay Funeral Home, 465 Centre Street, Newton Corner, MA. Private interment to follow. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, April 7, at 10am at 156 Sterling Place in Park Slope, Brooklyn, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in memory of Mark Lane in honor of his friend, Sam Brown, to The Lustgarten Foundation: (www.lustgarten.org).

GROSSMAN--Will, M.D. The Beth Israel Medical Center community joins with the leadership of its parent company, Continuum Health Partners, in acknowledging with deep sadness the passing of our dear friend and devoted colleague, Will Grossman, MD, attending in the department of medicine specializing in internal medicine and cardiology for 42 years. He will be greatly missed by all who knew him and worked with him, but most especially by those who looked up to him as a mentor. To his beloved wife Soony, and all of his family and loved ones, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Harris M. Nagler, MD, FACS President Beth Israel Medical Center Steven R. Bergmann, MD, PhD Chief, Thomas Killip Division of Cardiology, Vice-Chair, Department of Medicine, Beth Israel Medical Center Henry C. Bodenheimer, MD Chairman, Department of Medicine Beth Israel Medical Center

The War of 1812 is finally getting some respect. For years, budget woes have led New York State officials to reject calls to commemorate the bicentennial of the war - a footnote to many people, but a revered piece of American history to residents of upstate communities where battles were waged.

''The Hunger Games'' cleaned up at the box office over the weekend, and its soundtrack has been a hit too. The album, featuring songs by Taylor Swift, Arcade Fire and Maroon 5, sold 175,000 copies in its first week, Nielsen SoundScan reported. That does not translate into anything close to the $155 million in tickets the film sold last weekend. But it was enough to send the soundtrack, released by Universal Republic, to No. 1 on Billboard's album chart, the first soundtrack to open in the top spot since ''Michael Jackson's This Is It'' in late 2009.

Investors may soon get a keyhole view into the cloistered world of hedge funds and private equity firms, thanks to a little-known provision in a new bill that would relax rules on how investment firms can market themselves to the public. The bill, called the Jump-start Our Business Start-ups Act, or JOBS Act, would reverse parts of a nearly 80-year-old regulation preventing these funds from discussing even the most basic items, like performance or investment strategy, with outsiders. The rule, part of the Securities Act of 1933, gave an already secretive industry the regulatory cover to remain silent.

This summer's 79th edition of the American Dance Festival, the first under its new director, Jodee Nimerichter, will feature world premieres from Jodi Melnick, Helen Simoneau and Reggie Wilson along with performances from festival regulars including the Paul Taylor Dance Company and the Mark Morris Dance Group. Ms. Nimerichter took over the modern dance festival set in Durham, N.C., earlier this year, replacing Charles L. Reinhart, who retired at the end of 2011 after 43 years as director. This year's festival runs from June 14- July 28, and features seven commissions, seven company debuts, six world premieres and two United States premieres. Regulars like Keigwin + Company and Hubbard Street Dance Chicago are slated to perform and new works will be presented by Pilobolus in collaboration with Michael Moschen and Sidi LarbiCherkaoui. Companies appearing for the first time at the festival include Stephen Petronio Company, Vertigo Dance Company, Ragamala Dance, and Kyle Abraham/Abraham. In.Motion. The festival and the North Carolina Museum of Art will also co-present the choreographer Shen Wei's newest work among the galleries of the Museum's West Building. More information about the festival will be available at Americandancefestival.org on April 1.

A Rikers Island correction officer looked confused on Wednesday morning when a group of Chinese immigrants - trailed by a crush of reporters from local Chinese news outlets - arrived to pick up an inmate who had been in the jail for four years. ''Four years, really?'' the guard said, leaning back and wiping his hand over his face skeptically, perhaps because Rikers Island is primarily intended for short stays, with most inmates typically staying no more than three months.
International OUTRAGED BY FATAL ASSAULT,

Next week, Katie Couric will co-host the news on ABC's ''Good Morning America.'' It's a one-week role for the former co-host of ''Today,'' the main rival to ''Good Morning America'' in morning television. Ms. Couric will be filling in for Robin Roberts, who has the week off.

For the second straight day, I.B.M. has taken the no-comment route on whether its new chief executive, Virginia M. Rometty, should be extended an invitation to join Augusta National as I.B.M. chief executives traditionally have been. This is, of course, an issue because Augusta National has rather vehemently defended its male-only membership over the years and now that tradition clashes with an important corporate sponsor. Neither Augusta National nor I.B.M. is willing to say anything about the topic, with both saying Augusta membership is a private matter for the club. NAGLER--Stewart Gordon, died March 29, 2012 after a long illness. He was 69 years old. Beloved wife of Ronnie. Devoted father of Ellen, David and Amy and grandfather of Brooke and Emily and cherished stepfather of Lauren and David, Dana and Steven and grandfather of Adam, Evan, Emma and Alex. Loving brother to Lenore and David. He was predeceased by his first wife Bonnie and his parents Mary and Henry Nagler. Born in Brooklyn, New York, he was a summa cum laude graduate in mathematics of the Polytechnic University of New York, and later served as Chairman of the Board of Trustees of Polytechnic. He spent his entire working career of 43 years at the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and Metlife, Inc., retiring in 2004 as Vice Chairman, Chief Financial Officer and a member of the Board of Directors. He was a long-time leader in the insurance industry, responsible for numerous innovations in the life insurance and pension business, and was a former Chairman of the Life Insurance Council of New York and a board member of the American Academy of Actuaries. In recent years he was active as a director of the Nassau County AHRC Foundation. He had previously served as a Chairman of the Reinsurance Group of America, a board member of Tesoro Petroleum Corp., a Trustee of the Boys & Girls Clubs of America and a Trustee of Barnard College. A memorial service will be held on Monday, April 2 at 11:45am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York, New York. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to either the Nassau County AHRC Foundation, 189 Wheatley Road, #

Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His book, ''The Behavior Gap,'' was published earlier this year. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog. We live relatively short lives. Most of us last less than 100 years, so it's no surprise that we often get caught in the trap of small sample sizes. Imagine, for instance, if you go to Seattle for two days, and it's sunny both days. You may start to think all these stories of rain are just a trick by the locals to keep you from moving there. But it's only two days. What about the other 363 (or 364) days?

An article on Page 22 this weekend about the debt-deal negotiations last summer between President Obama and Congress misstates the difference in the revenues suggested by the so-called Gang of Six committee and the initial figure proposed by the president. The larger figure, $1.2 trillion, proposed by the committee, is 50 percent more than the president's initial figure of $800 billion -- not one-third more.

To the consternation of tabloid editors everywhere, a judge on Thursday ended Lindsay Lohan's long-running probation for a 2007 drunk driving case after a string of violations, jail sentences and rehab stints, wire services reported. Ms. Lohan, 25, remains on informal probation for taking a necklace without permission last year, but she no longer must report to a probation officer, limit her travel or show up for weekly cleaning shifts at a morgue. Judge Stephanie Saunter of the Los Angeles Superior Court told Ms. Lohan last time to straighten up her act. ''You need to live your life in a more mature way, stop the nightclubbing and focus on your work,'' the judge said.

The Metropolitan Opera has announced that concurrent with its final live presentation of the Robert Lepage production of Wagner's ''Ring des Nibelungen'' this spring (May 5-12), it will begin broadcasting the complete ''Ring'' cycle to movie theaters around the world, recycling the HD transmissions of the individual operas as they appeared over the last two seasons. On May 7, in the United States, Canada and some other countries, the Met will present ''Wagner's Dream,'' a documentary on the production by Susan Froemke. The opera screenings will take place in the United States on May 9 (''Das Rheingold''), May 14 (''Die Walküre''), May 16 (''Siegfried'') and May 19 (''Götterdämmerung''). Screenings abroad will take place at various times, extending in some cases into summer and, in Japan, through August. This is said by the Met to be the first time a ''Ring'' cycle has been presented on a big screen, though the production will not be entirely unified, since the first two operas were recorded with James Levine conducting, the last two with Fabio Luisi. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Groupon revised its financial results on Friday, an unexpected restatement that deepened losses for the daily deals site and once again raised questions about the accounting practices of the newly public company. As part of the revision, Groupon disclosed a ''material weakness'' in its internal controls, saying it failed to set aside enough money to cover customer refunds. The accounting issue increased the company's losses in the fourth quarter to $64.9 million, from $42.3 million.

Just five months before he died, Louis Armstrong gave a performance at the National Press Club in Washington, singing and playing the trumpet for nearly a half-hour at a party for the club's newly elected president. That concert was recorded by CBS newsmen who attended the event, and the press club later pressed about 300 vinyl copies and distributed them to journalists who had attended. It was never released as a commercial album, even though it was one of the last times the jazz trumpeter performed before his death in July 1971. Now Smithsonian Folkways Recordings has gotten permission from the Armstrong estate to release the recordings on a new album, ''Satchmo at the National Press Club: Red Beans and Rice-ly Yours,'' which will come out April 24 as part of the Smithsonian's annual Jazz Appreciation Month, the label and the press club announced on Thursday.

Services at Riverside Memorial West 76th Street, Sunday April 1, 11:45am. Gifts to Murray Braunstein Leadership Award, LaGuardia Arts http://www.alumniandfriends.org/give/murray-braunstein-leadership-award or Alumni and Friends, 100 Amsterdam Ave., Rm. 853, New York, NY 10023.

When a German art conservator recently sought to authenticate an early painting by Robert Motherwell that she had inherited, the director of the artist's New York foundation told her there was both good news and bad news. The work, ''Figuration,'' a charming 1947 oil on masonite, was real. But, the art conservator was told, the painting was stolen. On Friday the Motherwell, along with three other paintings that were stolen from a Madison Avenue gallery in 1988 and now valued at $1 million, were recovered by police in Cologne, Germany, and turned over to the Art Loss Register, a private database of lost and stolen art. The works were part of a batch of a half dozen contemporary paintings that were swiped from the now-defunct Solomon Gallery during a weekend theft. One, a painting by Karel Appel, was recovered in 2003 when the owner, a German dealer, tried to get it authenticated. According to Christopher A. Marinello, executive director and general counsel of the register, the dealer said he had bought the painting during a trip to New York City but refused to reveal the seller's identity. A lawyer handled all the negotiations, so the German dealer's name was never disclosed to law enforcement.

HIRSCHBERG--Erich, 90, of Hillsboro Beach, FL, formerly of Greenwich, CT, passed away peacefully after a short illness at Hospice of Palm Beach County in Delray Beach. Born October 24, 1921 in Munich, Germany. Fled Germany in 1934 after his father's politically motivated arrest. Resided in Milan, Italy with his parents for 5 years before emigrating to the U.S. in 1939. Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Queens College in 1943. Awarded Masters from New York University and PhD from University of Wisconsin, fellow at McArdle Laboratory for Cancer Research. Worked at Columbia Presbyterian for 18 years in cancer research. Professor of Biochemistry and Associate Dean for Research at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey for 22 years. Retired in 1990 to enjoy time with his beloved wife and family. He is survived by his wife of 67 years, Ruth; his son Michael and daughter-in-law Chrissy; his daughter Judy Atwood; his son Robert; grandchildren Robyn, Scott, Lauren and his wife Sydney, Kimberly, Michelle, Carly, Laura and Josh. Wonderful and nurturing husband, father and grandfather. Volunteer at Meals on Wheels and Jewish Family Service of Greenwich. Avid reader and intellectual. Lover of classical music. Passionate liberal Democrat, civil rights and anti-war activist and humanist. Master of Boggle, Scrabble and Backgammon. Lover of desserts and sweets, especially those baked by his wife. Will be greatly missed and mourned by all who knew him. Funeral with burial to follow at noon on Sunday, April 1 at the WJC Cemetery on Memory Lane in the Glenville section of Greenwich, CT.

Greg Smith, the former Goldman Sachs executive whose book proposal about his 12 years at the firm set off a fierce bidding war among New York publishers, has made a deal with Grand Central Publishing, part of the Hachette Book Group, a person with knowledge of the negotiations said Friday. The deal wrapped up a lengthy auction that involved some of the biggest publishing houses in New York, all of whom were vying for the rights to a book they hoped would provide a compelling inside look at a powerful Wall Street firm.

In its never-ending quest to reach young viewers, MTV is going back to the past, and to a generation weaned on its early videos. The network announced Friday that it is reviving ''Art Breaks,'' a pioneering 1985 series that broadcast TV spots created by a vanguard of downtown artists. In its original incarnation, the series included work by Doug Aitken, Jean-Michel Basquiat, and Richard Prince. The new ''Art Breaks,'' to begin on April 2, will feature videos by emerging artists like Mickalene Thomas, Rashaad Newsome, Tala Madani, Jani Ruscica, and Mads Lynnerup. In a first, the artists, most of whom are in their 30s, were selected and commissioned through a partnership with MoMA PS1 and the arts organization Creative Time. The program will debut on MTV and MTV.com and have a dedicated Tumblr site at Artbreaks.MTV.com. Ms. Thomas's video, titled ''Ain't I a Woman Portraits,'' will begin the series on Monday; a preview is above.

GRANT--Gardner Lewis of Purchase, NY and Jupiter, FL died on March 28, 2012, after a long battle with cancer. He was 85 years old. Raised in Providence, RI, Gardner was a graduate of Yale and Harvard Business School, and was the inventor of automatic toll machines. A life-long, passionate fly fisherman, Gardner served as president of New York's Theodore Gordon Fly Fishers, the Federation of Fly Fishers and the American Museum of Fly Fishing; and a board member of Trout Unlimited, the Atlantic Salmon Federation, the Hudson River Foundation for Science and Environmental Research and Yale's Peabody Museum of Natural History. Gardner also served as president of Sunningdale Country Club in Scarsdale, NY. Gardner is survived by his wife of over 60 years, Ellen, his daughter Laurie Zimmerman, son Gardner L. Grant, Jr, son-in-law Dr. Franklin H. Zimmerman, daughter-in-law Sulu Hegde Grant, and grandchildren Stacey, Ricky, Sean and Shakira. The family requests that any donations in Gardner's memory be made to the American Museum of Fly Fishing in Manchester, VT.

NEW ORLEANS - This year, the Final Four is about the big men. There has been too much talk of rivalries instead of post moves and famous coaches instead of box-outs. The best player on the three best teams remaining is a big man; Kentucky's Anthony Davis, Kansas' Thomas Robinson and Ohio State's Jared Sullinger all expect to be N.B.A. lottery draft picks. Louisville's post stalwart is no slouch. Gorgui Dieng has excelled in tournament play and anchors the country's stingiest defense. The key to understanding the teams starts inside, and the key to advancing to the championship is to attack each big man's weakness.

The last five years have been tough on Americans' financial confidence, particularly among baby boomers thought of as upbeat and affluent, a new survey has found. Roughly half of people born from 1946 to 1964, known as baby boomers, say they are optimistic about the country's financial future, down from about two-thirds in 2007, a survey from the financial services firm Ameriprise found. And just 17 percent say they are ''very optimistic'' about their personal financial future, down from 39 percent five years ago.

A classical music entry in the Listings pages on Friday about a concert by the viol consort Teares of the Muses, at St. Michael's Church on West 99th Street in Manhattan, misstated the date. The concert, as noted in a separate listing of performances of sacred music for the holiday season, was Friday night; there is no performance scheduled for tonight.

Michaels Stores, the Texas-based purveyor of knitting needles and pipe cleaners, is planning to raise as much as $500 million in its public debut, according to a filing made with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday. The initial public offering for the arts and crafts giant, which was reported earlier this week, is expected to be one of the most hotly anticipated offerings of the year. Michaels plans to list itself on the New York Stock Exchange under the ticker symbol ''MIK.'' The company said it plans to use the proceeds from the offering to pay down debt and for ''general corporate purposes.''

10:06 p.m. | Updated For nearly a year now, Al Gore and Joel Hyatt have been building their liberal cable news channel, Current TV, with the mercurial television anchorman Keith Olbermann at its center. This week, the center collapsed.
A map on Page 9 this weekend with the 36 Hours column, about Cologne, Germany, omits labels for several locations the writer visited. The complete map can be found at nytimes.com/travel.

An article in some editions on Thursday about the Rangers' 4-2 victory over the Winnipeg Jets the previous night in the N.H.L. misstated the number of power plays the Rangers had and which ones were converted into goals. They had the last five power plays in the game, not the last four, and scored on their second and fifth power plays, not on their third and fourth.

WARSHAW--Richard S.,born to Louis and Ida on March 4, 1928. Long-time owner of Warshaw Hardware founded in 1925 in Gramercy Park, NY, and a long-time Mason passed away on March 29, 2012. Beloved husband of Marie for 60 years. Loving father to his three sons and their wives, John (Rachel), Carl (Mindy) and Edward (Caroline). Devoted grandfather to Daniel, Benjamin, Megan, Sarah, Margot, Max and Madeline. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, April 1st at 10:15am at Sinai Chapels, Fresh Meadows, NY. Burial services to follow at King David Cemetery in Putnam Valley, NY.

At the Metropolitan Pavilion on West 18th Street, divorce is following marriage, just as it does in life. On Wednesday the Pavilion, which describes itself as one of New York's premier special events locations, played host to a wedding expo, New York magazine's ''New York Weddings Event.'' About 850 people paid $40 a ticket. Couples got in for $60. On hand were wedding planners, cake designers and representatives of bands that couples could hire. On Friday, a different expo set up displays and booths, a $75-a-person-and-up divorce expo called Start Over Smart. It begins at 9 a.m. Saturday and continues on Sunday.

WOLLNER--Paul, in Hartsdale, NY, 81. Beloved husband of Monica, devoted father of Wendy and David, father-in-law of Will and Susan, devoted grandfather of Daniel, Lauren, Brian, Michael, Sam, Andrew, stepchildren Matt and Eric. Loved and respected by all. World traveler and avid hiker. Built a very successful career in employee benefits at Professional Group Marketing. He will be sorely missed. A memorial service will be held at Hawthorne Funeral Home, 21 W. Stevens Ave. in Hawthorne on Sunday, April 1, 2012 at 11:00am. Donations may be made to The Mary Lea Johnson Richards Research Institute Inc. 232 East 30th Street New York, New York, 10016.

A classical music entry in the Listings pages on Friday about the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center misstated the time of the concert it is presenting Sunday at Alice Tully Hall. It is at 5 p.m., not at 5:30.

WEINFLASH--Ruth. We deeply mourn the loss of our beloved lifelong friend, Ruth Weinflash. She was kind, loving, caring, talented, vivacious and witty. We send our sincere condolences to Bernie, her beloved husband and life partner of over 55 years. Also, our condolences go to her children Jody, Jeffrey and Carol, and all of their children. May all of the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Arnold and Siema

A picture caption on Thursday with an article about educators who regularly solicit feedback from students misspelled the given name of a biomedical engineering professor at Boston University. As the article correctly noted, he is Muhammad Zaman, not Mohammad.

Fresh from his gripping performance as Gustavo Fring in the television drama ''Breaking Bad,'' Giancarlo Esposito has been cast as the lead in John Patrick Shanley's new play, ''Storefront Church,'' which the Atlantic Theater Company will produce this spring, the company said Friday. Mr. Esposito will play a fictional Bronx Borough President who is forced by the mortgage crisis into a confrontation with a local minister, to be played by Ron Cephas Jones (''The Overwhelming,'' ''Hurt Village''). The play is the final part of what Mr. Shanley calls his ''Church and State'' trilogy. ''Doubt,'' about allegations of sexual abuse in the Catholic church, won the 2005 Pulitzer Prize and several Tony awards, including best play, after its Off Broadway run. ''Defiance,'' from 2006, was about a criminal investigation on a military base.

9 P.M. (Starz) MIDNIGHT IN PARIS (2011) In Paris with his fiancée and her parents, Gil (Owen Wilson, above with Marion Cotillard), an aspiring novelist with a nostalgic bent, goes for long walks each night and is magically transported to the 1920s. Though he wakes up each morning in the present, he spends his nights consorting with Picasso (Marcial Di Fonzo Bo), F. Scott Fitzgerald (Tom Hiddleston), Salvador Dalí (Adrien Brody) and other notables, delighting in the glamour of the Paris described as a ''Moveable Feast'' by Hemingway (Corey Stoll). A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times that the film ''is marvelously romantic, even though -- or precisely because -- it acknowledges the disappointment that shadows every genuine expression of romanticism.'' Woody Allen, who wrote and directed the movie, won an Academy Award for best original screenplay. Noon (13) RICHARD HEFFNER'S OPEN MINDDavid Segal, a reporter for The Times, discusses the quality of education at law schools in the United States and why graduates are not necessarily prepared to practice law.

FEUER--Alan Zachary, died March 26, 2012. A memorial service will be held Saturday, March 31 at 4pm at The Church of the Incarnation, 209 Madison Avenue, New York, NY. In lieu of flowers, please send donations in Alan's memory to the Soliders', Sailors', Marines' & Airmen's Club, 283 Lexington Avenue, New York, NY 10016 made out to SSMAC.

MUNITZ--Lenore Bloom, 90, of Scarborough, NY, on March 29. Mother of Charles and Andrew, grandmother of four. Her husband, Milton Munitz, predeceased her. Retired Professor of Philosophy and Dean of Students at Briarcliff College and a talented mediator. Beloved by many, and a force of nature.

In the battle for Thursday ratings supremacy, Fox and CBS split the spoils, as the former finished first in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic loved by advertisers and the latter reached the highest overall viewership. Fox's ''American Idol'' averaged 15.3 million total viewers and at least temporarily ended its slide in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic after a month of drops. NBC was also able to claim a small victory as ''Community'' held steady in the 18-to-49 category when compared to last week despite direct competition from a new episode of ''The Big Bang Theory'' on CBS at 8 p.m. ''Big Bang Theory'' on CBS was the No. 1 Thursday program with adults 18-to-49, but the show was down 12 percent in that category and dropped in total viewers (from 15 million to 13.6 million) when compared to the last new episode three weeks ago.

STEIN--Jane B. The staff and trustees of the North Shore-Long Island Jewish (LIJ) Health System are greatly saddened by the death of Trustee Jane B. Stein. Jane was a valued, long-time benefactor of North Shore University Hospital, the Katz Women's Hospital and the Philip Stein Center for Human Reproduction, located at the Alvin and Dorothy Schwartz Ambulatory Surgery Center in Manhasset, NY. Her experience as a volunteer emergency medical technician and strong interest in all things medical inspired her generous philanthropy that helped ensure that North Shore-LIJ provides quality healthcare in the communities it serves. She is survived by her daughter, Associate Trustee Frances Stein. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to Frannie and her family. Michael J. Dowling, President and CEO Richard D. Goldstein, Chair, Board of Trustees North Shore-LIJ Health System

This week's Your Money column examines the best approach to rebalancing your investment portfolio -- in other words, reshuffling your investments back to their original mix to reduce your risks in the market. While most investors should periodically re-evaluate their portfolios to make sure they don't require any major changes, most of the time all investors need to do is a little maintenance. Perhaps you just need to sell a portion of your stock funds and buy some bonds so that you're not becoming too bloated in any one investment.

LANE--Mark. Lazard Capital Markets' employees mourn the passing of our colleague Mark Lane. We had the honor and pleasure of working with Mark over the past few months, and many of us have known him as a friend and colleague for many years. Our thoughts and prayers are with his wife, children, parents, and family. In Mark's memory, we have established the Mark Lane Memorial Fund. Donations, either by check or wire, can be sent to: Mark Lane Memorial Fund, Lazard Capital Markets, c/o Cashiers Department, 30 Rockefeller Plaza, New York, NY 10021.

It's a strangely moving experience to flip through ''Woodcut'' (Princeton Architectural Press, $30), a book of Bryan Nash Gill's relief prints of tree-trunk cross sections, which the artist harvests from felled trees, cedar telephone poles and discarded fence posts in his native Connecticut. One is struck by how Gill's method - cutting blocks with a chain saw, sanding them down, burning them and sealing them with shellac - amplifies the events in the life of a tree: lightning strikes, burgeoning burls, insect holes and, of course, the aging process, evidence of which radiates out in transfixing patterns. Verlyn Klinkenborg, who also writes for The New York Times, describes these cross sections in the book's preface as ''the death mask of a plant, the sustained rigor mortis'' of maple, spruce and locust. They remind us, he says, that every biological form ''possesses a unique footprint.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

THE new boutique in SoHo called American Two Shot not only caters to but is also curated by New York City 20-somethings. Here, the artist Olivia Wolfe and the former Theory wholesale planner Stephanie Krasnoff, both 27, offer a carefully edited selection of men's and women's clothing, serving up a clever mix of things -- from designer pieces by Timo Weiland and Jonathan Simkhai to rare vintage finds, like pairs of Winnie the Pooh Vans. A shot (or two) is served on site at Café Integral, which is run by the Nicaraguan coffee enthusiast César Vega. ''New Yorkers know what they like, but they love something new,'' Ms. Wolfe said of A.T.S. and its relaxed, chillin'-out aesthetic. Playing host to art exhibitions, the first of which will feature the artists Christi Birchfield and Erik Foss, and guest D.J.'s (a pair of rotating wooden stages support accessory displays during the day and turntables at night), A.T.S. is set up for hot-spot-ness. Ms. Krasnoff said, ''We're just happy to be able to have a place that will continue to inspire our friends.'' American Two Shot, 135 Grand Street. Go to americantwoshot.com. MACKENZIE WAGONER

In ''Operation Paws,'' on the cover of last Sunday's Metropolitan section, Robin Finn chronicled the efforts of Christina Beckles and her organization, the Sato Project, to bring rescue dogs from Puerto Rico to the continental United States. A selection of reader comments from NYTimes.com is below. So nice to hear about people doing good things in this world for a change. Thanks to people like Christina, maybe we can change the way of life for dogs in Puerto Rico. I visit there often, and we have a loooong way to go. But with exposure to the problem in newspapers like this, maybe we can get more people onboard to help this terrible situation. Adopt a rescue dog; they are forever grateful and make the best companions.

See a larger version of the forest from this week. Compare with the enlarged version of last week's image. I had a Snow White moment as I stood in our wooded area on Staten Island last Friday morning with wildlife all around me. In nearly 70-degree heat, fat, furry bumblebees lolled about while cabbage-white butterflies skimmed and soared. I half expected the northern flicker, a woodpecker, that swept and bobbed among the trees to circle back and land on my shoulder.

THANKS in large part to Alexa Chung, the tomboy look has been enjoying unprecedented appeal of late. But Ms. Chung was preceded by a long line of women who made stealing from the boys seem like the most stylish thing in the world, notably Katharine Hepburn, Françoise Hardy, Patti Smith, Jane Birkin and Ms. Birkin's two younger daughters, Charlotte Gainsbourg and Lou Doillon. ''Tomboy Style: Beyond the Boundaries of Fashion'' (Rizzoli, $32.50), a compact coffee-table tome, celebrates these style icons and their countless lesser-known sisters via dozens of vintage and contemporary photographs. ''It's become acceptable, even fashionable, to describe yourself as a tomboy,'' said Lizzie Garrett Mettler, the book's author and the creator of the Tomboy Style blog from which it sprang. ''It doesn't have butch connotations anymore.'' Her favorite image is one of Steve McQueen and his first wife, Neile Adams, shooting pistols in the desert. McQueen is something of a unifying thread in the book and a man with an evident weakness for tomboys: His second wife, Ali MacGraw, is pictured just a few pages later in a photo by William Claxton. It's one that is especially meaningful to Ms. Mettler. When they married, she said, McQueen ''bought her a house in Beachwood Canyon in L.A.,'' she said. ''Neighborhood legend has it that it's the house across the street from mine. I like to think the photo was taken there.'' NANCY MacDONELL

After Franco, the deluge! Or so it would seem from Anthology Film Archives' fascinating series, SPANISH CINEMA OF THE EARLY POST-FRANCO ERA (1975-83), which considers the flowering of film after his death in 1975. This was something of a coming-out party for all things underground and repressed: drugs, raucous experimentation and, of course, sex. A gay sensibility flourished, not only in the films of Pedro Almodóvar, represented here by ''Pepi, Luci, Bom y Otras Chicas del Montón'' and ''Laberinto de Pasiones,'' but also in movies like Ventura Pons's ''Ocaña,'' a 1978 documentary portrait of José Pérez Ocaña, an artist who walked around Barcelona in a peek-a-boo dress. The series, beginning Friday, features 10 films, most rarely seen in America, including Iván Zulueta's ''Arrebato'' (''Rapture''), a genre bender that is itself giddily enraptured by cinema. As one of its two filmmaker heroes says, ''It isn't me who loves film, but film who loves me.'' And beware an enthusiastic lover. Cinema, it seems, eats its young -- or at least its acolytes. 32 Second Avenue, at Second Street, East Village; (212) 505-5181, anthologyfilmarchives.org.

Notre Dame vs. Connecticut Connecticut (33-4) makes its 13th N.C.A.A. Final Four appearance since 1991 against the only program that has had its number in the semifinals. Geno Auriemma's Huskies are 7-5 in the semifinals, but 0-2 against its Big East rival Notre Dame (34-3), including the Fighting Irish's 72-63 victory last Aprilo in Indianapolis. Until that game, the Huskies had won 28 of 32 against Notre Dame; in the last 12 months, the Irish, led by point guard Skylar Diggins, have claimed three of four.

There's one house in Bentonville, Ark., that looks nothing like the others. It was designed in 1954 by Cecil Stanfield, a Modernist architect who helped give Oral Roberts University in Tulsa, Okla., (two hours west) its ''Jetsons''-esque appearance. The house's large windows are the kind that people in small towns tend to associate with storefronts. That meant the lives of its owners would be displayed as surely as the merchandise in Sam Walton's first five-and-dime, just a few blocks away. Which made it, paradoxically, the right house for Don Bacigalupi, Dan Feder and their 6-year-old son, Guston. ''We live our lives very openly,'' says Feder, a graphic designer and stay-at-home dad, who has been with Bacigalupi, a respected museum director, since the early 1990s. Still, even Alice Walton, the Walmart scion who grew up in Bentonville, wasn't sure the couple would be happy raising their child there. After offering Bacigalupi the job of director of her Crystal Bridges Museum, in 2009, Walton insisted he get to know people in the Ozarks town before deciding. She even went ahead and found potential friends for the two men, via a gay employees group at Walmart. ''After knowing that Don was the right fit for us,'' Walton wrote in an e-mail, ''I wanted to be certain the community was the right fit for him and his family. That was my No. 1 priority.''

An article last Sunday about a heart transplant for former Vice President Dick Cheney misspelled the given name of the noted surgeon who performed the first successful heart transplant in 1967. He was Dr. Christiaan Barnard, not Christiian.

In a photo essay on March 25 by Lise Sarfati called ''On Hollywood,'' the photographer provided titles that gave incorrect locations for where some of the photographs were made. The photograph titled ''Elisabeth, Northwest Corner Sunset and Poinsettia, 2010'' should read, ''Elisabeth, Sunset and North Poinsettia, 2010.'' And the photograph ''Malaika #13, North Sunset Boulevard, 2010'' should read, ''Malaika #13, Sunset Boulevard, 2010.''

The interior designer Marco Pasanella is now enjoying a robust second act as a vintner, but first he had to triple his mortgage, max out his credit cards and risk his marriage. He details his metamorphosis in a new memoir, ''Uncorked'' (Clarkson Potter, $24). File this under perfect pairings: The psychedelic dot enthusiast Yayoi Kusama illustrates a new edition of ''Alice's Adventures in Wonderland'' (Penguin Global, $35). It appears at the same time as her big Tate Modern museum show, which moves to the Whitney in June. Mona Talbott's ''Zuppe'' (The Little Book Room, $19) is as much a collection of inspiring Italian soup recipes - like puréed pea with mint - as it is a window into the eco-conscious, seasonal kitchen of the American Academy in Rome. And ''The Uninvited Guests'' (Harper, $25), a devilish comic novel by Sadie Jones, is set inside ''a strange, shallow red-brick manor house'' in ''Downton Abbey''-era England. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Tebow May Play Various Roles, Ryan Suggests,'' March 26: Jets Coach Rex Ryan won't say it, but he realizes that Tim Tebow may have the worst quarterbacking fundamentals in the N.F.L. The only way Tebow can be effective is if the Jets run the Wildcat and have Tebow take the snaps, a position usually taken by a running back, and no coach knows how to run the Wildcat more efficiently than Tony Sparano.

When Coach enlisted the talents of James Nares, it didn't ask the artist to riff on the brand's logo - it literally gave him a blank canvas. A double-layered Italian canvas, that is. Five of Nares's dynamic single brush-stroke paintings provide the motif for a collection of striking limited-edition totes, 175 each in black, green, blue, orange and fuchsia (above). $798 at coach.com. In an exclusive video, Meredith Danluck visits Nares in his studio and discovers that his process is as mesmerizing as the work itself.

The New York designer is known for effortless-looking rooms in which comfy upholstered pieces cohabitate happily with classical 18th- and 19th-century furniture and art and design from the 1960s and '70s. For Delavan, who is the creative director of the online shopping site Gilt Home and the former editor-at-large of Domino magazine, it's important that a house reflects the history of its inhabitants. His own home -- an Anglo-Italianate town house in downtown Manhattan -- showcases his aesthetic roots (''I grew up in Connecticut in the '70s, with that WASPy 'Ice Storm' sort of décor,'' he says) and contains works by his favorite artists and furniture designers (Joe Colombo and Vico Magistretti, to name two). Most precious, though, are pieces made by his friends -- a vase by Hugo Guinness, a box by John Derian. ''These are the things that make a house a home.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Relais & Châteaux, a network of more than 500 luxury hotels and restaurants around the world, will host its second annual Grands Chefs Dinner on April 16 at Gotham Hall in New York City. More than 40 chefs will gather, including Mark Ladner and Mario Batali from Del Posto in New York; Gary Danko (above) of Gary Danko restaurant in San Francisco; Joseph Lenn from Blackberry Farm in Walland, Tenn.; and Patrick Henriroux from La Pyramide in Vienne, France. The chefs will be divided into teams of three and cook for a group of 30. One will be responsible for the appetizer while the other two are in charge of the fish and meat courses. The dinner is meant to showcase American producers and growers, and the chefs will work with the same ingredients, though they can interpret them any way they like.

A few miles up Highway 1, just north of Santa Cruz, an unmarked single-lane road winds steeply into the California coastal range, climbing from the misty salt zone of a first marine terrace, through the agricultural flats of a second and on up to a third, whose archipelago of gently sloping open spaces is creased at irregular intervals by redwood-choked ravines. Wild boar roam free up here, rattlesnakes are routine, and the soil, what there is of it, soaks in high-perching water in the winter, dries out in the summer and rests on layers of oil-impregnated asphalt rock and chalky mudstone. It's a land where poison oak, burr clover and thistles thrive. All in all, not the most obvious spot for a garden, but that's what Stephanie Mills saw when she and her husband, David, bought this 372-acre ocean-view aerie, which they named Laguna Ranch, in 1991. From 1993 to 1995, Mills worked with the grass guru John Greenlee to help tame the invasive weeds that had taken hold after a failed brussels sprouts farm and years of ranching created optimum conditions for these opportunistic pests. ''The idea was to control the thistles and poison oak with grasses,'' she recalls. ''If you plant something, a thistle can't grow in its place.''
