''I'm hopelessly opinionated,'' says the designer Harriet Anstruther as she walks through the rooms of the mid-19th-century house in London that she shares with her husband, the photographer Henry Bourne, and her teenage daughter from a previous marriage. Indeed, this is not the home of someone who's wishy-washy on design and decorating. Anstruther - who has designed everything from scarves (two of which are in the collection of the Victoria and Albert Museum) to hotel rooms, and who consults for fashion and lifestyle companies, and for British institutions like the Design Museum - restored the elegant late-Georgian architecture of the house (which had been divided into three apartments) while making sure that the rooms weren't slaves to it. Wherever you look, traditional is engaged in conversation with modern, old furniture and art with new, and bold colors with white walls. The white walls, needless to say, aren't the product of indecision. ''Clarity keeps me calm,'' Anstruther explains. ''I like the architecture to be the story,'' she says, adding that white allows you to ''see the silhouette.'' On the main floor of the house, white emphasizes the modernity of the skylit, open kitchen-dining area, which is a new addition. (A glass insert in the dining-area floor sends light down to Bourne's basement-level studio, which opens onto a garden courtyard.) The kitchen's white marble counters, Anstruther acknowledges, are highly impractical, but she doesn't care. ''I dreamt about unlacquered brass and white marble,'' she recalls.

MUNITZ--Lenore Bloom, 90, of Scarborough, NY, on March 29. Mother of Charles and Andrew, grandmother of four. Her husband, Milton Munitz, predeceased her. Retired Professor of Philosophy and Dean of Students at Briarcliff College and a talented mediator. Beloved by many, and a force of nature.

BRAUNSTEIN--Murray. Died peacefully at home on March 29. Unparalleled educator, proud veteran of WWII, active member of UFT, involved citizen, unwavering Giants fan, steadfast friend, indomitable spirit, uncle to many, teacher to more, the great and only love of the late Pixie Braunstein. Services at Riverside Memorial West 76th Street, Sunday April 1, 11:45am. Gifts to Murray Braunstein Leadership Award, LaGuardia Arts http://www.alumniandfriends.org/give/murray-braunstein-leadership-award or Alumni and Friends, 100 Amsterdam Ave., Rm. 853, New York, NY 10023.

Ward Bennett (1917-2003) was one of design's great American success stories. He left home at 13, created dresses and window displays, met Brancusi and studied painting with Hans Hofmann - before he was 30. When he turned to design, his clients included David Rockefeller, Gianni Agnelli and Jann and Jane Wenner. Bennett used industrial materials before they were chic and insisted that his furniture be comfortable. Many of his designs went out of production, leaving aficionados to hunt the secondhand market. But now Herman Miller is adding several Bennett pieces (including the Scissor chair and I-Beam table shown here) to its Herman Miller Collection, a portfolio of products for home and office that also includes classics by the Eameses, Nelson and Noguchi; contemporary designers like Sam Hecht, Leon Ransmeier and Ayse Birsel; and the Italian brands Magis and Mattiazzi. (The collection will make its debut this month; go to hermanmiller.com) As Ben Watson, the company's executive creative director, says, ''We are celebrating our design heritage, but we're not just looking backward.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

10 P.M. (AMC) MAD MEN In last week's Season 5 premiere, Don Draper (Jon Hamm) was the man of the hour at a surprise birthday party engineered by his new wife, Megan (Jessica Paré, above), but he was embarrassed by her sexy performance of the French song ''Zou Bisou Bisou'' in front of his colleagues. In this week's episode, Don and Harry (Rich Sommer) try to make a client happy. Peggy Olson (Elisabeth Moss), fresh off the disappointment of having her Heinz pitch rejected, takes on new duties at the office. 10:30 A.M. (CBS) FACE THE NATION The program broadcasts an interview with Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. in which he expresses confidence that the Supreme Court will uphold the constitutionality of the health care law. Bob Schieffer speaks with Newt Gingrich and Ron Paul, both Republican presidential candidates, about the 2012 election. Other guests are Jan Crawford and John Dickerson, both of CBS News; Kevin Madden, a campaign adviser for Mitt Romney; and Gwen Ifill of PBS NewsHour.
A map on Page 9 this weekend with the 36 Hours column, about Cologne, Germany, omits several labels for locations the writer visited. The complete map can be found at nytimes.com/travel.
The Designer After working with the Bouroullec brothers for five years, Ionna Vautrin opened her Paris studio in 2011.

BARBER--Fred Lee. Died at home on March 29th, 2012. (Born December 15, 1927, in Perth Amboy, New Jersey) For a man who demanded impeccable quality and taste, he was surprisingly domestic in his enthusiasms; he believed in family as passionately as he believed in food, savored fresh air and photo-copying, and could leave a conversation about Churchill's views on the Dardanelles to talk with the same avidity with a Punjab cab driver about the most authentic curry place in town. He was the master of the High-Low (poker) and the high-low (life), an American original, which he didn't get from his voracious intelligence or savvy, but rather from his eye and ear and heart. His motto was B.E. -- "Benefit from your Experiences" -- and all those who came in contact with him certainly benefited from the experience of him, most especially Fanny Barber, Joan Malawista, Phyllis Barber, David and Laureen Barber, Daniel Barber and Aria Sloss, Carolyn Levine and Richard Preiss, Stephanie and James Preiss, and Jacob and Aidan Barber, and Steve and Tobe Malawista. We will never have a more alert ear, a more attractive eye, or a more ardent heart than his.

WEISS--Miroslava, 86, Czech Republic National Figure Skating Champion, wife of late Max Weiss, Vice President of Helmsley Spears, died peacefully on March 27, 2012 at her home in Quogue Long Island NY.

WITH the citywide American Mavericks celebration of home-grown artistic modernity behind us now, music lovers will most likely fall into two camps: some who wish the party never had to end, and others ready to soak up sounds of an earlier vintage. Anyone still hungry for fresh sounds can look to CUTTING EDGE CONCERTS, an annual new-music series hosted by the composer Victoria Bond. That's not to say that what you will hear during the first program lacks historical resonances. Rufus Müller, a tenor widely admired for his interpretations of Bach's music, joins the pianist Jenny Lin in Ms. Bond's ''Leopold Bloom's Homecoming.'' And N. Lincoln Hanks, whose piano work ''Monstre Sacré'' receives its premiere, has extensive experience in early-music vocal groups. Also appearing is the Danjam Orchestra, a jazz ensemble; the festival continues through April 30 . 7:30 p.m. Monday, Leonard Nimoy Thalia Theater at Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, (212) 864-5400, symphonyspace.org; $20, students and 65+ $15.

The cover of Mark Dion's Phaidon monograph describes him as a ''celebrated artist/explorer/archeologist.'' Not three vocations that ordinarily inhere in one man (though some improbable combination of Audubon and Indiana Jones might cover it) and not the full tally of Dion's occupations, either. To them can be added: teacher, naturalist, advocate, author, designer, collector (that is to say, hoarder), curator and probably six or seven other things I don't have room for here. Dion is one of those curious characters the world produces every so often; men and women who combine making things with intervening in the institutions that show them - in museums and schools, in cities and far-flung sites, disrupting the flow and structure of our picture of the world just enough to make us wonder why we give it that structure and flow in the first place. Dion's a collector of collections, especially the hundreds or thousands (or more - who knows how many?) hidden in forgotten buildings in small cities around the world: Cabinets of Wonder, specimen museums, obscure archives, as well as the complex and uncataloged collections of things, both manufactured and natural, one might find in, say, a patch of the rain forest or a bank of the Thames. In February, he was in New York working on ''Phantoms of the Clark Expedition,'' an exhibition that explores, among other things, the Explorers Club - the venerable members-only institution. The installation, which runs from May 9 to Aug. 3, is part critical, part fond, and is intended to show, through artist-made objects, what such endeavors don't reveal about themselves. Dion is an owlish man with an Encyclopedia Brown air about him, who lives in an apartment in Washington Heights with his wife, their dog and a kind of controlled clutter of books, knickknacks, souvenirs and the like. When I visited him there, a fishbowl on the living room table seemed to be filled with matchbooks and old receipts; a few minutes later, it stirred, alarmingly. ''That's the mouse,'' he said casually, and then we went back to our conversation, which roamed all over the world, back millenniums and up to the present again. Endangered species, Renaissance customs, a periscope contraption that Freud had installed in his office in Vienna (whence Dion had just returned) so that he could spy on patients sitting in his waiting room. A very good artist can do a lot; surprisingly few of them know a lot, at least outside of their immediate concerns. Dion is one of the exceptions, perhaps because his immediate concern is . . . everything.

REDMOND--John Jack Richard, 81, of Harding Township, loving husband of Norma Redmond, died of complications after a courageous battle with pancreatic cancer at his home on March 28th, with his loving family at his side. A son of Daniel Redmond and the former Mildred Phelan, Jack was born in Berwyn, PA on December 1st, 1930. After graduation from Villanova University with a BS in Civil Engineering in 1953, he was commissioned as an Ensign in the United States Navy as a Chief Engineer on the USS Robert L. Wilson (DDE847), retiring as a Lieutenant in 1958. Upon discharge from the Navy, Jack joined the Wilbur B. Driver Company, a family owned manufacturer of alloys, and earned his M.S. in Metallurgy at Stevens Institute of Technology in 1960. After the subsequent sale of the Wilbur B. Driver Co. to GTE in 1967, Jack left the manufacturing business and became a Member of the New York Stock Exchange, joining the brokerage firm Carlisle DeCoppet & Company. In 1970, he became a general partner of Fowler, Rosenau & Company, the NYSE Specialist firm. He retired in 1995 as the firm's senior partner. Mr Redmond lived in Llewellyn Park, West Orange for many years where, with his former wife Claire Driver Redmond, who passed away in 2003, he raised six children, John Jr. (Nancy), Robert (Elise), Suzanne Anderson (Robert), Richard (Jane), Paul (Donna), and Ruth Bloom (William). He also maintained former residences in Longboat Key, Florida; Bondville, Vermont; and Convent Station, New Jersey. He was an important Benefactor to his beloved Villanova University, and was recognized as a Distinguished Alumni in 1988 and became a member of the President's Forum in 1995. He was also a member of the Presidents Council at St. Elizabeth's College, and served for many years on the Boards of Newark Academy and the Montclair Community Hospital. He was a former member and trustee of the Essex County Country Club and at the time of his death was a Member Emeritus of the Baltusrol Golf Club where he was an avid golfer. In addition, he was an enthusiastic member of the choir at Notre Dame of Mt. Carmel Church. Among many things, he will be remembered as a beloved patriarch, true friend, mentor to many, great partner, story and joke teller extraordinaire, and not the least, a distinguished gentleman. He is pre-deceased by his brother, William and a grandchild, William John, and is survived by his six children, three Khandalavala stepchildren, Dorab (Gitte), Dina, and Rustom (Maartje), seventeen grandchildren, six step-grandchildren, two great-grandchildren and three siblings. A funeral Mass will be held at Notre Dame of Mt. Carmel Church, Cedar Knolls, New Jersey, Wednesday, April 4th at 10:00am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Pancreatic Support Fund, 100 Madison Ave., Morristown, NJ 07962.

GOMEZ--Alexander, beloved son of Mariette Himes Gomez and Raymond Gomez and cherished brother of Brooke Gomez, died on Wednesday, March 28, 2012 at age 42. Alex graduated from the Trinity School in NYC and Vassar College where he majored in Political Science. After graduation, he lived in Los Angeles for ten years and had a successful career with Court TV and The Fox Family Channel. His passion for music led him back to New York where he composed and produced. his music. He also performed at various clubs in NYC; among them, CBGB, Maxwells and The Bitter End. He will always be remembered by his family and many, many friends. In lieu of flowers, a donation may be made to: New York Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical Center for GI Oncology Research. Friends may call Sunday, April 1, 2012, 3-6pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, NY 10028. Mass of Christian Burial, Monday, April 2, 10am, St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue at 84th St. Interment private.

For many Bostonians, the beauty of spring means the installation of the 20-foot-long scarlet nasturtium vines in the flower-filled courtyard of the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum. The process suggests a ballet, much like the dancing figures on the sarcophagus above, as workers carry the vines through the 50-foot glass tunnel connecting the new wing to the original Venetian-palace-style museum. Stan Kozak, who grows the vines and directs the process, hung the vines over balustrades. Elsewhere, women seem to be taking cues from the museum's Renaissance portraits, experimenting with elaborate hairstyles decorated with jewels. Not since the '30s have we seen such imaginative, intricate styling, a departure from ironed flat hair.

An obituary last Sunday about the civil rights lawyer John Payton misstated his role in defending the affirmative-action policies of the University of Michigan. He argued Grutter v. Bollinger, a case involving the university's law school, before a district court, which ruled against the university, and before an appeals court, which reversed that decision; he also argued Gratz v. Bollinger, a separate case involving the university's College of Literature, Science and the Arts, before the Supreme Court, which ruled against the university. He did not argue the Grutter case before the Supreme Court, which ruled in the university's favor.

In the vibrant hothouse that is Chris Garofalo's Chicago studio, nearly every surface holds carefully composed displays - natural specimens, souvenir postcards, family photos and random objects, like a petrified frog or lurid blue ceramic eggplants. A framed, somewhat faded dinosaur mural reigns over the space; herds of small plastic animals roam the shelf above her worktable. Sometimes it's hard to tell the found objects from the art. The question of what is real and what is not is at the heart of Garofalo's work. Her spiky, surreal porcelain pieces are neither plant nor animal. She is most drawn, she says, to things that look familiar but are sui generis: ''The idea of species intermingling intrigues me, and it's boring to make something that already exists.''
An article on Page 6 this weekend about the making of the musical ''Ghost Brothers of Darkland County'' misstates the name of one of the characters. It is the Shape, not the Shade.

MILLER--Dr. Arthur Dr. Arthur Miller, 93, a practicing physician in New York for 70 years, passed away from natural causes surrounded by family and friends on Monday evening, March 19th. After attending NYU and NYU Medical School, he and his brother, Dr. Julius Miller joined the US Navy as medical officers. He served with distinction in the Pacific Theater during WWII and, was present during the battles of Iwo Jima (witnessed the raising of the flag), Okinawa and Guam in the Philippines. After 4++ years of service to his country, Dr. Miller recommitted himself to the profession of medicine specializing in Obstetrics/Gynecology and ultimately Fertility/Sterility and Cancer. In collaboration with fellow physicians from the Soviet Union, in the early 1960's he was responsible for introducing into the US the 'cervical sling', allowing for successful outcomes to very difficult pregnancies. In private practice he became one of New York City's most highly respected fertility and cancer specialists. Dr. Miller's attending privileges included: New York Infirmary Hospital, Bellevue Hospital, Beth Israel Medical Center, New York University Langone Hospital, and the Jewish Hospital of Brooklyn Medical Center. Starting in 1952, Dr. Miller's passion for medicine and teaching led him to establish a post-graduate relationship with NYU Medical School as a Clinical Assistant Professor of Obstetrics and Gynecology. A pioneer in the advocacy of women's access to health care and reproductive rights, in 1953 Dr. Miller began donating part of his time to what became a life-long commitment to providing health care to members' families of the Mens' Clothing Workers Union at the Hillman Center in Manhattan. In the late 1960's Dr. Miller opened his 3rd office in New York across the hall from the joint practice of his father and brother (Dr. I. William Miller and Dr. Julius Miller). In 1972, following the US Supreme Court's Decision 'Roe v Wade', in partnership with Dr. Mansoor Day and Dr. Roy Gold, Dr Miller founded VIP Medical Associates in association with Beth Israel Medical Center, the first clinical practice to open in New York State devoted to providing abortion services to women of limited financial means. Continuing in private practice though his 90th birthday, his many honors and recognition included: Diplomate, American Board of Obstetrics and Gynecology; Fellow, American College of Surgeons; Fellow, International College of Surgeons; Fellow, American College of Obstetrics and Gynecology; Chairman, Committee on Admissions, NY Academy of Medicine; Fellow, Pan American Medical Association; Fellow, American Fertility Society. In a statement made shortly after Dr. Miller's death, Dr. Anthony Greco, Associate Dean of the NYU School of Medicine, said of Dr. Miller he set the bar. His was a large life defined by more than his career. He was Arthur in his private life and found equal joy in his roles as a devoted husband, father, grandfather, father-in-law, and friend. He loved traveling with his family, ocean swimming, winning rounds of golf, telling (and retelling!) bawdy jokes, attending the symphony and the opera in a tuxedo and cape with red lining, wearing a finely cut suit set off by the perfectly selected tie, and sharing good meals and fine wine with those he loved. More than anything, he loved seeing the transformation of his lovely granddaughter Ruth into a fine young woman A well lived life cannot help but leave a large absence when it ends. Dr. Arthur Miller will long be remembered and missed deeply by all who knew and loved him. A member of the Town and Village Synagogue, he is survived by his wife of 63 years Hope Simon, sons Lane (of Seattle, WA) and Lloyd (of Anchorage, Alaska), daughters-in-law Anne and Heather, and granddaughter Ruth. He was preceded in death by his son Scott.
THE BIG PROFILE

NESSEL--Jack H.,of New York, NY and Canaan, CT, on March 27, 2012 at the age of 73. Born and raised in Long Beach, California, he graduated from Stanford University in 1959. He did graduate studies at Harvard Law School and at UC Berkeley, and worked at KPFA Pacifica radio. Jack was the first managing editor of New York Magazine from 1968 to 1972 and its editorial director from 1974 to 1977. He was the editor-in-chief of Psychology Today from 1977 to 1982, and a senior consulting editor on the start-up of Conde Nast Traveler. In 1973 he was an Alicia Patterson Foundation fellow in Paris. He was also a guest lecturer at NYU, Yale, the Stanford Publishing Program, and the Aspen Institute. In a second career, he became an antiquarian bookseller and was a member of the ABAA. Jack did crossword puzzles rapidly and in ink. He loved carnivals, mysteries, old radio, and old movies, especially The Thief of Bagdad, and as an infant he appeared in the movie Another Thin Man. Jack will be missed immensely by his wife, Ginger Curwen; daughter, Jen, her partner, Matt, and their son, Oscar; Ginger's family; and a group of very dear friends. The family requests that any donations be made to the American Cancer Society.

The corner of McGuinness and Kent, in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, has undergone a minor face-lift in the seven years since my aunt Liz was struck and killed there. The Budget Rental Center that occupied the east corner is now an Enterprise Rent-A-Car, and there's a new BP service station across the street from it, in what used to be a vacant lot. You can no longer park on the east side of McGuinness, because the gas station's driveway flows out into the street there. Seven years ago, before the gas station, a row of parked trucks lined the curb, and it is for that reason that the driver of the Budget rental van, turning left onto Kent, was unable to see Liz as she rode her bike from the sidewalk to the street. A few months later, a group of activists chained a white-painted bicycle to a signpost across the street from the site of the accident. Above it, a plaque states her name and the day she died, and how: ''killed by truck.'' You can see these ''ghost bikes'' all around the city, wherever cyclists lost their lives.

An article on Page 22 this weekend about the debt-deal negotiations last summer between President Obama and Congress misstates the difference in the revenues suggested by the so-called Gang of Six committee and the initial figure proposed by the president. The larger figure, $1.2 trillion, proposed by the committee, is 50 percent more than the president's initial figure of $800 billion -- not one-third more.

BATH--William H.,Roslyn, NY, 82, passed March 25th at home after a brave battle with cancer. Born August 21, 1929 in Brighton UK to Harry and Elizabeth (McQueen) Bath, Bill lived a life intertwined with the history of aviation. His lifelong passion for aircraft and the business of flight was sparked as a young Air Engineer with the Royal Air Force and continued upon his emigration to America in 1957. He worked through his illness, within the industry he loved, until January 2012. Bill served the industry trade society ISTAT as an Appraiser Fellow and Administrative Director of their International Appraisers' Program (Chairman 1994-97.) He was also a historian for the Wing's Club in Manhattan. In addition to his parents, Bill was predeceased by his first wife Lucie Leonne Maisonneuve. He is survived by his second wife Marie Bath and two adoring stepdaughters Jacquelyn and Coraline Dahlin who lived consistently enthralled by his storied passion for life and his life's work. Bill will remain forever in our hearts. Services will be held on March 31st from 2 until 4pm at Knowles Funeral Home in Port Washington.

Sophie Aschauer has been fascinated by puzzles since she was a child. But it wasn't until she picked up a book of sailor's knots last year on a trip to Nantucket, Mass., that she put this interest to any practical use. ''I was mesmerized,'' says Aschauer, a New York-based, Austrian-born graduate of Central Saint Martins, who designs under the label SerpentSea. ''Right away, I knew I was going to make them into mats.'' Each of her small but weighty rugs incorporates about 150 feet of repurposed nautical and mountaineering rope, which she coaxes into intricate patterns that loop and twine like baroque infinity symbols. The hands-on process takes about four hours per rug; devising the patterns can take considerably longer. She has three models available, all named for famous pirates - Drake, Bonny and Morgan - and a larger area rug is in the works. ''People love them as bathmats,'' Aschauer says. ''They feel very nice under bare feet.''

WEINSCHENK--Fritz. An American hero is no longer with us. The members of the board of directors of the Otto and Fran Walter Foundation mourn the passing on March 23, 2012, of their esteemed fellow director and treasurer of the Foundation, our dear friend Dr. jur. Fritz Weinschenk. Driven from his German homeland by Nazi hatred, he made a new life for himself in the United States. He volunteered for the U.S. Army immediately after Pearl Harbor and underwent training in South and North Carolina, in the course of which he was naturalized as a citizen. He liked to say that he considered himself a Rebel, since he became an American citizen in the South. He came ashore under Eisenhower at Omaha Beach on D-Day, where he incurred a leg wound that would plague him the rest of his life; he refused being sent to a field hospital, because that would have separated him from his unit. That unit was trained in beachhead communications, so after two months in France it was transferred to the Pacific. There, after participating in landings at Port Moresby, Hollandia (now Jayapura) and Sansapor in New Guinea, Fritz came ashore with MacArthur in the Philippines, first at Lingayen Gulf and later at Malapascua Island/Mt. Mayon. His unit was preparing for the invasion of Japan when the war ended. "The atomic bomb," he later said, "saved my life." His military honors include the American Campaign Medal, European--African--Middle Eastern Campaign Medal with one battle star and an arrowhead, Presidential Unit Citation (for the Normandy invasion), Asiatic-Pacific Campaign Medal with two battle stars and an arrowhead, World War II Victory Medal, Army of Occupation Medal and Good Conduct Medal; and foreign honors, the Philippine Liberation Medal and the Medaille de la Debarquement (French Liberation Medal). After his discharge he served as a civilian in the Army Counter Intelligence Corps in Germany, in the course of which he worked with the U.S. prosecution team in the trial of German war criminals at Nuremberg. Returning to the U.S., he took up the study of law, graduating from New York University School of Law in 1953, and then devoted the greater part of his long professional career to the pursuit of justice on behalf of those who, like himself, had suffered under Hitler's brutal regime. He interviewed hundreds of witnesses whose testimony was critical for the prosecution of war criminals in German courts, and served as counsel for Nazi victims in hundreds of restitution and indemnification claims. For his humanitarian service the German government bestowed upon him the Bundesverdienstkreuz am Bande (Knight's Cross of the Order of Merit) and the Bundesverdienstkreuz erster Klasse (Officer's Cross of the Order of Merit). Late in life he again took up the study of law and earned the degree of Doktor juris, summa cum laude, from the University of Mainz the city from which he had been ostracized half a century earlier. He served in many capacities in numerous philanthropic and professional organizations, but the one that means the most to us is our own. We will miss his insight and wise counsel, as well as his unfailing courtesy and sly humor, at our board meetings. Otto and Fran Walter Foundation, Inc Frank G. Helman, President Martha H. Peak, Vice President and Grants Director

ONE of Park Avenue's oldest surviving town houses, once the home of the abstract painter and philanthropist Judith Rothschild, has sold for $16.5 million, making it the biggest sale of the week, according to city records. Although the property was bought anonymously by a limited liability company, papers filed with the city indicate that the buyer was the development company Toll Brothers of Horsham, Pa.

KLEIN--Joseph, beloved husband, father, grandfather and great-grandfather, died on Friday, March 30. Born on August 1, 1928, Joe built the Phoenix Candy Company in Brooklyn, NY alongside his father, Harry, into a huge success. When he wasn't churning out Now & Later candy bars, Joe was a devoted family man, home with his wife and three children in East Meadow, New York. In 2001, Joe and Zina left their home in Manhasset, New York to live permanently in Delray Beach, Florida where Joe enjoyed playing golf, cards, seeing movies, spending time with his Florida family and hosting his New York family during visits. Joe will be remembered as a strong, selfless and loving person by those who survive him -his wife of 63 years, Zina, his sister, Millie Nixon, his children Wendy Smith and Nadine, Howard and Jeannie Klein, Shari and Steven Nemiroff, his grandchildren Brian Klein (Marne), Lee Klein (Ali), Lexi Fried (Matthew), Peter Smith, Perri and Lonnie Nemiroff, his great-grandchildren Emma and Spencer Fried. He will be missed and loved always.

An article last Sunday about Factual, a company that is aiming to gather all of the world's facts, misspelled the given name of a co-founder and general partner of Andreessen Horowitz, a firm that invested in the company. He is Marc Andreessen, not Mark.

WINTERS--Mark, passed away on March 16, 2012. Mark was born in Manhattan and lived most of his life there, first working in the hospitality industry and then working in personnel placement, helping many find gainful employment. Mark was a very kind, generous, and compassionate individual. He reveled in the kaleidoscope of New York life, and also nurtured his deep interest in the human family with his personal study of world culture, history, and politics. His joy of life was a gift to all who were fortunate to have known him. Mark is survived by his brother Warren, as well as Sabine and Ariane of New York, and many aunts, cousins, nieces, and nephews. He will be lovingly remembered by us forever. We will celebrate Mark's life on Sunday, April 22, 2012 at 10am at Gutterman's Chapel, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY.

Feb. 26, 2012, Blue Lagoon, Iceland My daughters and I usually go on a ski or beach vacation at this time of year, but as the winter was shaping up to be a mild one, and with my youngest daughter taking earth science, it was a great time to take them on an adventure. The Blue Lagoon is near the capital on the Reykjanes Peninsula. The Svartsengi thermal power station nearby heats the sea water in ''hot pots'' underground. By the time it reaches the lagoon, it cools to 38 degrees Celsius. It is surrounded by rough lava fields covered with a delicate moss. The contrast between the landscape and the baths was spectacular. We had no idea that it would be so strange. SUSAN STAVA, New City, N.Y.
People and pets in Plexiglas boxes
International IN RIO DE JANEIRO,

Most of us don't think of craft as holy. But it certainly was for cloistered nuns of the 17th through 19th centuries, who made reliquaries of rolled or ''quilled'' paper that was adorned with beads, shells, coral, fabric and other materials. Nearly 150 of these pieces will be on view in ''Quilling: Devotional Creations From Cloistered Orders'' at the Pinacoteca Giovanni e Marella Agnelli in Turin, Italy, from April 5 through Sept. 2. A number of works in the show are owned by the photographer Nan Goldin, who shot some of the pieces in the exhibition. In addition to the reliquaries, the exhibition also includes miniature 19th-century reconstructions of nuns' cells, like the one at right, which are as spare as the reliquaries are ornate. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

BEFORE brands were brands, they were just companies with stories and nice carpeting. I remember going into the Mark Cross store on Fifth Avenue with my parents. (This was in the late '60s.) There was an unfussy elegance to that store, just as there was to the main floor of Tiffany up the street, and it's not hard to picture guys in sack suits and skinny ties, maybe a rumpled khaki raincoat, going to check out the desk blotters. I was looking at the photo in The New Yorker this week that accompanies Robert A. Caro's article about Lyndon B. Johnson on the day of the Kennedy assassination -- it shows the president and a group of men, including reporters, leaving a Fort Worth hotel. Their uniformity (''Johnson hastily snatched off his hat,'' Mr. Caro noted), their desire for uniformity, is something that ''Mad Men'' fails to capture. But, of course, it is interested in entertainment, not in subtle differences of taste and body types.

HOW much do you know about Philadelphia's contemporary performance scene? I'm embarrassed to admit that I know very little, despite how close the city is to New York and how regularly I hear reports of cross-pollination. Here is the latest one, right here in New York, as luck would have it; you can educate yourself without getting on a BoltBus. The THIRDBIRD organization of Philadelphia, run by Dustin Hurt and Anna Drozdowski, is coming to Abrons Arts Center for its New York debut, presenting two evenings as part of the Seen & Heard series.

WEINFLASH--Ruth Stupell, 80, of Cresskill, NJ died on March 27, at home with her husband and children at her side. Born on August 5, 1931, to Edward and Leah Stupell in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn; graduated from Connecticut College in 1952. Ruth was an actress, both by nature as well as by training having received accolades in her productions of Tennessee Williams' plays, until she became involved in a production of her own - her marriage to her beloved Bernie of 55 years. Cherishedmother of Jody (Steve) Konstadt, Jeff (Elahna) Weinflash and Carol (Michael) Kopelman; Adored Granmum of Michelle, Debbie, Sarah, Eden, Noah, Emily and Naomi. She was a woman of valor and integrity, vibrant and poetic, and always - a lovelylady. She was adored and treasured by all who knew and loved her - and always will be. Donations can be made to Shirah Choir at the Kaplen JCC or to James F. Holland Research Foundation at Mount Sinai Hospital. Services will take place at 12:30pm on Friday at Temple Emanu-el in Closter, NJ.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''The End of an Era in Indiana,'' March 25: To one who holds the fondest memories of playing and watching numerous basketball games in the Anderson Wigwam, its demise illuminates the tectonic shifts in the socioeconomic life of Indiana.

In the stripped-down interiors at the Brooklyn restaurant Isa -- exposed tree branches, piles of firewood -- there is a hint of the menu to come. All the tapas-size dishes and entrees at the woodsy eatery are studiously simple: raw scallops with apple and celery; sardines roasted with olives; beef tartare with smoked oil and juniper berries. It's the newest (and much buzzed-about) vision from Taavo Somer, the architect behind the downtown New York institution Freemans, and Ignacio Mattos, the former chef of Il Buco, both of whom use the word ''primitive'' to describe the space and the food. ''It's nothing that a home cook couldn't do,'' Mattos says. ''You can do it with two hands, a knife and a little bit of fire.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

An article last Sunday about a Brooklyn woman's effort to save abandoned and abused dogs from a Puerto Rican beach called Dead Dog Beach described incorrectly part of the woman's return to New York this month. When she returned to New York on a flight from San Juan, P.R., she was on a domestic flight; she did not go through customs. And because of an editing error, the article referred imprecisely to the destination of 60 dogs for which she was trying to find adoptive homes. She brought the dogs to the continental United States from Puerto Rico -- not to ''the United States,'' of which Puerto Rico is a part, of course.

In a green twist on multitasking, Element Hotels (elementhotels.com) has introduced a power-generating stationary bike at its Miami location, offering guests the opportunity to plug in and recharge their cellphones, laptops, MP3 players or other electronic devices while burning calories. A generator linked to one bike in the gym converts pedal to electrical power. The system was introduced in mid-March in Miami and will be expanded to include the Element in Lexington, Mass., one of 10 branches of the chain, which is aimed at extended-stay guests. Hotel representatives say they plan to expand the power-pedal plan with one bike at each location within the year.

Almost immediately after the so-called grand bargain between President Obama and the Republican speaker of the house, John Boehner, unraveled last July, the two sides quickly settled into dueling, self-serving narratives of what transpired behind closed doors. In the months that followed, some of Washington's most connected Democrats and Republicans told me in casual conversations that they didn't know whose story to believe, or even what, exactly, had been on the table during the negotiations. A few mentioned, independently of one another, that the entire affair reminded them of ''Rashomon,'' the classic Kurosawa film in which four characters filter the same murder plot through their different perspectives. Over time, the whole debacle became the perfect metaphor for a city in which the two parties seem more and more to occupy not just opposing places on the political spectrum, but distinct realities altogether. There is a practical reason for this. Both sides knew that if the most crucial and contested details of their deliberations became public, it would complicate relationships with some of their most important constituencies in Washington -- or worse. It's one thing for a Democratic president to embrace painful cuts in Medicare and Social Security benefits, or for a Republican speaker to contemplate raising taxes, if they can ultimately claim that they've joined together to make the hard decisions necessary for the country; it's quite another thing to shatter the trust of your most ideological allies and come away with nothing to show for it. Obama and Boehner have clung to their separate realities not just because it's useful to blame each other for the political dysfunction in Washington, but because neither wants to talk about just how far he was willing to go.

Democrats in New York State outnumber Republicans two to one. Yet Republicans hold a narrow majority in the State Senate. One key reason is the Legislature's approval of gerrymandered political districts -- like this one, Buffalo's 60th District -- in the redistricting process, which takes place every 10 years to reflect population shifts identified by the census. This year is no different: The Legislature has approved, and Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has signed, a new map of Senate districts designed by the Republicans, as well as a map of Assembly districts designed by the Assembly Democratic majority. Government reform groups say the Senate map is particularly flawed; legal challenges are pending. A graphic is on Page 4. THOMAS KAPLAN

In honor of the long-awaited return of ''Mad Men,'' the Big City Book Club is getting in the spirit of 1960s Manhattan. Our next selection is James Baldwin's 1962 novel, ''Another Country,'' which chronicles the descent of the jazz drummer Rufus Scott. Baldwin recreates the world of Greenwich Village bohemians for an examination of race, emotional denial, professional rivalry, tortured marriages and other subjects that the AMC series has mined so well. Ginia Bellafante, the Big City columnist, will lead the online conversation on April 4 at a new time, from 7 to 10 p.m. To join the Book Club and receive updates about book selections and chats, send an e-mail with the subject line ''Join'' to bigcity@nytimes.com.

THE ancient communities of southern Mexico called themselves Children of the Plumed Serpent, after the deity Quetzalcoatl. Part bird, part snake, Quetzalcoatl was the region's founding father and benefactor. A new exhibition at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art argues that he was also a lasting political and economic phenomenon, allowing the southern kingdoms to resist conquest by the Aztecs and, later, the Spanish. Some indigenous Mexicans still call themselves descendants of Quetzalcoatl. Opening Sunday, ''CHILDREN OF THE PLUMED SERPENT: THE LEGACY OF QUETZALCOATL IN ANCIENT MEXICO'' connects Quetzalcoatl to the development of vast trade routes that reached from central Mexico out to the Yucatán Peninsula and the American Southeast. It also credits him with inspiring the simplified International Style in art, which helped to knit together a group of ethnically diverse and multilingual communities. The show's more than 200 art objects date from the postclassic to the early colonial periods (roughly 900 to 1521), and include gold, textiles, turquoise mosaics, fresco fragments, painted codices and feather work. Through July 1, (323) 857-6000, lacma.org.

Fans of ''The Hunger Games'' books whose thirst for the trilogy wasn't slaked by the opening of the blockbuster film last weekend can still visit the country of Panem, where teenagers are pitted against one another in deadly fights. It takes only a vivid imagination and transportation to North Carolina, where the movie was shot. The North Carolina Division of Tourism has published a four-day self-guided tour as well as a list of spots of interest. Included on the list is the abandoned Henry River Mill Village (above), outside Hildebran, which was the site of District 12, where the main characters live. The village, which held Katniss's house and Peeta's family's bakery, is not open to the public but can be seen from the road.

A picture caption on March 4 with an article about a new book on Winston Churchill, ''Churchill Style,'' by Barry Singer, using information from his publisher, misidentified one of the items shown among Churchill's personal effects. It is a baby rattle, not a gilded trench whistle.

GRANT--Gardner Lewis of Purchase, NY and Jupiter, FL died on March 28, 2012, after a long battle with cancer. He was 85 years old. Raised in Providence, RI, Gardner was a graduate of Yale and Harvard Business School, and was the inventor of automatic toll machines. A life-long, passionate fly fisherman, Gardner served as president of New York's Theodore Gordon Fly Fishers, the Federation of Fly Fishers and the American Museum of Fly Fishing; and a board member of Trout Unlimited, the Atlantic Salmon Federation, the Hudson River Foundation for Science and Environmental Research and Yale's Peabody Museum of Natural History. Gardner also served as president of Sunningdale Country Club in Scarsdale, NY. Gardner is survived by his wife of over 60 years, Ellen, his daughter Laurie Zimmerman, son Gardner L. Grant, Jr, son-in-law Dr. Franklin H. Zimmerman, daughter-in-law Sulu Hegde Grant, and grandchildren Stacey, Ricky, Sean and Shakira. The family requests that any donations in Gardner's memory be made to the American Museum of Fly Fishing in Manchester, VT.

IT'S not true that David Auburn vanished after the blockbuster success of ''Proof'' around a dozen years ago. But to some theater people waiting for another Pulitzer Prize-winning play it can feel that way. He's actually been very busy, working on screenplays, adaptations, one-acts and an HBO pilot about a surgeon starring Kevin Kline. But in terms of completely original new drama -- a scarce resource on Broadway this spring -- ''THE COLUMNIST,'' which begins previews this week, represents a major return for Mr. Auburn and a good sign for audiences. This play features John Lithgow as Joseph Alsop, the powerful columnist and critic of Communism, who in the 1950s discovered that the K.G.B. had photos of him having sex with a Russian man in a Moscow hotel room. With political events like the Kennedy assassination as the backdrop, Mr. Auburn tracks Alsop's life in the '50s and '60s. In interviews the playwright said he wanted to give a complicated portrait of this fascinating figure who has been largely forgotten. The prolific Daniel Sullivan, who earned (surprisingly) his only Tony Award for ''Proof,'' is directing. Performances begin Wednesday at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater, 261 West 47th Street, Manhattan; (212) 239-6200, telecharge.com.

SCHNITZER--Ben, M.D. passed away peacefully on Thursday, March 29, 2012. He was born on August 13, 1934 to the late Pearl and Morris Schnitzer and was a lifetime resident of Dallas, TX. Ben Schnitzer graduated from Forest Avenue High School in 1950 at the age of 16 and was awarded an A. Harris & Company academic scholarship to Southern Methodist University, where he received his B.S. degree in 1953. At SMU, he was elected to Phi Eta Sigma, the Freshman Scholarship Society. He received his M.D. degree from The University of Texas Southwestern Medical School in 1957. Ben served his medical internship and residency at Parkland Hospital, where he was present in the Emergency Room when President Kennedy was admitted on November 22, 1963. Ben also served in the U.S. Navy as a lieutenant in the Medical Corp. Ben practiced Urology at Baylor University Medical Center in Dallas for 47 years and was beloved by so many of his patients who were grateful for his clinical expertise and deep sense of compassion. He served on the Board of Directors of Baylor and as Chief of Urology from 1986 - 1996. He introduced prostate screening in the City of Dallas, and over the years he was the primary investigator of a number of innovative urological technologies. He was a clinical Professor of Urology at Southwestern Medical School and was a Fellow of the American College of Surgeons. Ben loved to play golf and had a joke for every occasion. He is survived by his loving wife of 54 years, Marilyn Schnitzer, his adoring children, Mark and Denise Schnitzer of Honolulu, HI, Judy and Robert Perl of New York, NY and Alan and Anne Schnitzer of New York, NY, his sister, Eva Kaplan of Dallas, TX, his brother-in-law, Robert Pyon of Conifer, CO, and his sister-in-law, Shirley Schnitzer of Dallas, TX. He dearly loved his seven grandchildren: Harrison, Hannah and Ava Perl of New York, NY, Emily and Tara Schnitzer of Honolulu, HI and Matthew and Natalie Schnitzer of New York, NY. He is also survived by many other devoted and loving family members and friends. Ben was preceded in death by his dear brother Bernard Schnitzer. Services will be held at Temple Emanu-El, Dallas, TX, on Sunday, April 1, 2012 at 2:30 pm with interment following at Hillcrest Memorial Park, Rabbi David Stern officiating. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Baylor Health Care System Foundation, Fund for Pancreatic Cancer Research, 3600 Gaston Avenue, Suite 100, Dallas, TX 75246, https://give.baylorhealth.com/schnitzer, 214-820-3136.

IN the spirit of Valextra's original 24h travel bag, a prizewinning attaché created in the 1950s by the founder Giovanni Fontana for quick overnight trips, the steel-frame Avietta 48h, introduced in 1964, accommodates a two-night stay in an equally elegant way. The compact carrier, which is about the size of a pillow and nearly as light, features a proper briefcase handle (no lazy elbow-hooking here), buttery soft leather and the company's signature rhodium-brushed zippers and pulls (so discreet and smooth to use). Inside, buckled straps secure things in place. Luxury, meet efficiency at its finest. Valextra case; $4,810. Go to barneys.com. JANE HERMAN

IN recent years, discount clothing shops and dingy dining spots have pretty much been the extent of consumer options on Rua do Rosário, in Porto. But with the emergence of nearby Rua Miguel Bombarda as the premier art-gallery strip in Portugal's second-largest city, the Rua do Rosário is benefiting from a spillover effect. As faded town houses fill with upstart designers and upscale food shops, Rua do Retail might be a more fitting moniker these days. SETH SHERWOOD

Children and pets, exercise caution: if you are a small creature in the presence of Tierney Gearon, it is quite likely you will be lowered into a Plexiglas box and asked to hang out for a while. But Gearon, who is working on a photo book about shapes, says her subjects seem to enjoy their captivity. ''The funny thing is no one tries to get out,'' she says. ''That's what's so crazy. They just stay in there looking around.'' For the past two years, Gearon has shipped her materials -- sheets of magenta, turquoise, vivid yellow Plexiglas -- to picturesque locales like St. Barts and Telluride, where she assembles them and corrals her own four children (ages 5 to 18), along with friends and various pets, for the pictures. Even the family's Bengal cat, Striker, consented to a few minutes in a cube, where he luxuriated in the Malibu sun. ''Once they're in the box,'' Gearon says, ''they start doing their own thing.'' total Cost of Plexiglas: $20,000

An article last Sunday about the European Fine Art Fair in the Netherlands misspelled the term coined by Emily Post for a group of well-polished characters (which the author used to describe some of those who attended the fair). It is the Worldlys, not Worldys.

BOGART--Vincent L. Vincent L. Bogart was born on the family farm near Kirwin, KS, on June 8, 1922. Vince died on Monday, March 26, in his home surrounded by loved ones. After high school and one year of college, he traveled to Washington, D.C., and became a Federal Reserve Board page. He attended George Washington University at night, joined Sigma Nu, and enlisted in the Army Air Force Cadets in August 1942. Vince was commissioned as a 1st Lieutenant fighter pilot, was assigned to the Aleutians and later trained combat pilots before his inactivation. With the GI Bill running out, he began at Kansas State University and met his future wife, Julia R. Henry, in April 1951, on a blind date. They both loved acting and appeared in plays together and each received a best actor Oscar. After marriage in August 1952, he entered Washburn Law School. Graduated in 1955 with a LLB, he was hired by a large Wichita law firm, served one term in the Kansas state legislature, was elected president of the West Side Democratic Club and Chairman for Sedgwick County Democratic Committee. In 1960, John Kennedy appealed to Vince for support with the Kansas delegation to win the nomination in July and the election in November. Vince hosted Kennedy's first visit to Wichita and drove Ted Sorensen and Larry O'Brien to campaign speeches. Sorensen and O'Brien joked in the car that Kennedy was such a speech deviant. Ted Kennedy also came to Wichita to promote his brother's candidacy. Vince started his own law firm and was elected to the Wichita City Commission in 1963-67 and as Mayor in 1964-65. He represented Wichita at Orleans Joan d' Arc festival and gave a speech in perfect French. Judy and Vince were invited with other Mayors to meet President Johnson at the White House. The mayors discussed the Vietnam War with the President. Afterwards, the couple dined and joined others dancing in the foyer. President Johnson cut-in to dance with Judy and drawled "Are you having a good time?" During Vince's tenure, he supported Johnson's war on poverty, passed a fair housing law, and signed a contract to construct Century II. He became Chairman State Democratic Platform Committee in 1966-67, was appointed WSU Board trustee, and then Governor Docking chose him as legislative representative. He was later appointed to the State Board of Regents. In 1968 Vince served on National Democratic Platform Committee and attended the Chicago National Convention as delegate. The Chicago convention was interrupted with a show of force between demonstrators and Mayor Daley's police. The joke among the delegates was to nominate Hubert Humphrey as President and Vince as Vice-President so the ticket would read Humphrey Bogart. In 1972-74 and 1976-77, he was special assistant to the Attorney General, State of Kansas. Vince served on the local, state and national Bar Associations, was a member of the state and local Trial Lawyers Association and was recognized in Who's Who in American Politics and Who's Who in American Lawyers. Vince served under Governor Sebelius as Judge of the Workmen's Compensation Court and ended his career as of counsel with a local law firm. Survivors include his much loved wife of nearly 60 years, Judy, their lovely children Candace Miller, Lee Bogart, Celeste Racette, and Cynthia Sandin, and their spouses. "Oompa" was the name affectionately given to him by his grandchildren; Renee, Matthew and Robert Racette, Janelle and Andrea Bogart, and Caitlin and Anders Miller. Private services held at the Bogart cemetery in Kirwin, KS, on Wednesday, March 28, 2012.

NOW'S the time to make plans to pile into the Jazz Gallery and hear ORRIN EVANS'S CAPTAIN BLACK BIG BAND, in town for two nights next weekend. Mr. Evans, the pianist, a bandleader and teacher, is a hero of the Philadelphia jazz scene, and though all of his groups have a certain kind of energy, the Captain Black band really dominates a room. It connotes the 1980s and '90s in style and language, but maybe the '60s in energy, which is to say it plays with urgency, beyond the coding that makes jazz a small-audience special interest. The lineup looks different depending on where and when he's playing; this 14-piece one is full of first-call New Yorkers. Watch for the trumpeter Tatum Greenblatt, the saxophonists Stacy Dillard and Marcus Strickland, and the trombonist David Gibson; Mr. Evans, with the bassist Luques Curtis and drummer Anwar Marshall, tie it together. 290 Hudson Street, at Spring Street, South Village, (212) 242-1063, jazzgallery.org; 9 and 10:30 p.m. Friday and Saturday; $20, $10 for members.

An article on March 18 about privately owned, family-run restaurants in Havana misstated the principal ingredient in the Cuban stew called ropa vieja. While ropa vieja is made with lamb at the restaurant Doña Eutimia, and at other restaurants in Cuba, the dish is traditionally made with beef.

Steve Kerr, one of the busiest men in basketball this time of year, does not play or coach. He is a TNT game analyst for the N.C.A.A. men's tournament and the N.B.A. Kerr, 46, played 15 N.B.A. seasons. He won three championships with the Chicago Bulls and two with the San Antonio Spurs before retiring in 2003, then moved to the Phoenix Suns' front office from 2007 to '10. This season, Kerr crisscrossed the country to watch his son Nick, a freshman guard at the University of San Diego. ''He's a lot like his old man,'' Kerr said. ''He can really shoot and he's slow.''

Just because the artist Jason Hackenwerth can create almost anything - including a frighteningly tentacled cyclops - out of balloons, doesn't mean he'll work your child's birthday party. A graduate of the Savannah College of Art and Design, Hackenwerth formed a 13-foot-tall ''T'' out of thousands of inflated latex balloons. Like all of Hackenwerth's creations, his ''T'' will deflate in a matter of months. Such impermanence is a big part of the artist's practice. ''We need to learn how to let go,'' he says, ''because everything in life is temporary.'' View the making of Hackenwerth's ''T,'' in all its impermanent glory, in our video:

An article in some editions last Sunday about the third round of the Arnold Palmer Invitational golf tournament in Orlando, Fla., described incorrectly the penalty Tiger Woods incurred by driving the ball out of bounds on the 15th hole on his way to a double-bogey 6. It was a one-stroke penalty, not a two-stroke.

LINDEN--Fred, born July 24, 1913. Formerly of New York, Wading River and Los Angeles, passed away March 13, 2012 in Santa Barbara, CA. Survived by his loving wife Pauline, daughter Ruth Rubin (Dr. Lewis Rubin), four granddaughters and nine great-grandchildren. He was predeceased by his daughter Martha Lois Linden. He is in our hearts always.

MORTON--William Scott, missionary, minister, professor and author, died on March 29 at the age of 103 in New York Born in Edinburgh Scotland, he received his bachelor's degree from Clare College Cambridge and his divinity and doctoral degrees from Edinburgh University. He went out to China as a missionary in the 1930s, escaped in 1941 on the last British boat out of Japan, to land in the U.S. a month before Pearl Harbor. During the war he served as a chaplain in the Royal Air Force. Returning to Scotland, he was called to minister to a church that been destroyed during the war. Later, called to a church in the US, he began lecturing at NYU, eventually becoming a professor of Asian history at Seton Hall University. During this period he produced articles and books on China and Japan, some of which are still in use by universities. He is survived by children of his first wife, Alice Gleysteen Morton: Michael, Alistair and Keith Scott Morton and Margaret Gail Scott Morton Hampson; seven grandchildren and nine great-great-grandchildren; and his wife, Phyllis Stock-Morton.

''YOU know that feeling when you get home and lay in bed and your whole body just hurts? I feel like that all the time.'' That's how Raquel Beckford, 18, described the grind of holding a demanding job while studying to graduate from high school. It is a juggling act that young New Yorkers have struggled with for generations, scribbling homework assignments in the predawn light and reading books on late-night subway rides.

STEIN--Jane B. The staff and trustees of the North Shore-Long Island Jewish (LIJ) Health System are greatly saddened by the death of Trustee Jane B. Stein. Jane was a valued, long-time benefactor of North Shore University Hospital, the Katz Women's Hospital and the Philip Stein Center for Human Reproduction, located at the Alvin and Dorothy Schwartz Ambulatory Surgery Center in Manhasset, NY. Her experience as a volunteer emergency medical technician and strong interest in all things medical inspired her generous philanthropy that helped ensure that North Shore-LIJ provides quality healthcare in the communities it serves. KALLAS--Judith Carroll. Judith Carroll Kallas passed away on March 24, 2012 of cardiac arrest. The beloved wife of John L. Born on July 24, 1937 in Trenton, NJ, she moved to New York City and became co-owner of Cornelia St. Cafe. Judith loved music and was a singer with the Greek Choral. An ''In the Region'' article in some copies last Sunday, about properties bequeathed to nonprofit organizations, misstated the title of Alexandra Wolfe of the Society for the Preservation of Long Island Antiquities. She is its director of preservation services, not its executive director. The article also referred incorrectly to the status of two houses bequeathed by Sonja Stein of Manhasset. Edith Minturn Stokes and Isaac Newton Phelps Stokes are best known today as the patrician subjects of this 1897 portrait by John Singer Sargent, which hangs in the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Banking and shipping heirs, Newton and Edith were at once wealthy globe-trotters and reform-minded New York liberals whose good deeds have endured even as the couple themselves drifted into obscurity. In a brisk, admiring dual biography, ''Love, Fiercely'' (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $26), Jean Zimmerman argues that theirs was perhaps ''the greatest love story never told.'' Sargent painted Edith in street clothes as the so-called New Woman who represented ''hot-button developments such as bloomers and bicycles.'' The straw boater hat Edith holds in the painting, Zimmerman says, could be interpreted as ''obscuring if not downright obliterating her husband's manhood.'' In life, Edith was, if not emasculating, at least tough. Nicknamed ''Fiercely,'' she flouted upper-crust norms: not marrying until an overripe 28, adopting a child openly and bringing kindergarten, then a radical concept, to the United States.

A group of masked individuals gave subterranean vandalism an activist tinge this week: They tampered with subway entrance equipment with the aim of letting commuters in Manhattan and Brooklyn ride free, the police said on Saturday. At eight different subway stations before the morning rush on Wednesday, the unidentified suspects chained open emergency gates and posted signs on which they had scrawled: ''Customers ride for free.''

He is survived by his wife, Janet, and his children Donna Hodgdon and his son-in-law Stephen Hodgdon of Raleigh, NC, Brenda Earl of New York City, John Earl and his daughter-in-law Morgan Earl of Ridgewood, NJ. Van Emburgh Funeral Home, Ridgewood. www.vanemburgh.com

NAGLER--Stewart Gordon, died March 29, 2012 after a long illness. He was 69 years old. Beloved wife of Ronnie. Devoted father of Ellen, David and Amy and grandfather of Brooke and Emily and cherished stepfather of Lauren and David, Dana and Steven and grandfather of Adam, Evan, Emma and Alex. Loving brother to Lenore and David. He was predeceased by his first wife Bonnie and his parents Mary and Henry Nagler. Born in Brooklyn, New York, he was a summa cum laude graduate in mathematics of the Polytechnic University of New York, and later served as Chairman of the Board of Trustees of Polytechnic. He spent his entire working career of 43 years at the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and Metlife, Inc., retiring in 2004 as Vice Chairman, Chief Financial Officer and a member of the Board of Directors. He was a long-time leader in the insurance industry, responsible for numerous innovations in the life insurance and pension business, and was a former Chairman of the Life Insurance Council of New York and a board member of the American Academy of Actuaries. In recent years he was active as a director of the Nassau County AHRC Foundation. He had previously served as a Chairman of the Reinsurance Group of America, a board member of Tesoro Petroleum Corp., a Trustee of the Boys & Girls Clubs of America and a Trustee of Barnard College. A memorial service will be held on Monday, April 2 at 11:45am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York, New York. To the Sports Editor: Re ''Golfer Confronts Toughest Foe: Her Stutter,'' March 28: It is important for young people who stutter to know that famous people share their problem and that it has not held these people back. I wish there could be a measure of the number of lives Sophie Gustafson has changed for the better with her total openness about her stuttering.

With one foot in Modernist cool and the other in vibrant Pop Art, Jonas Wood gives breathing room to densely patterned paintings of domestic interiors that celebrate the logic of incongruity. ''I think painting's fun,'' Wood says in ''Interiors,'' the catalog accompanying his exhibition, on view from Mar. 31 through May 12 at the David Kordansky Gallery in Los Angeles, where Wood lives. Austere his work is not. The bold parrot-and-leaf print on a bedspread that nearly consumes a guest room fairly shrieks at the unperturbed Bertoia wire chairs that face it. The Keith Haring figures on a bathroom shower curtain dance to the visual music of intersecting, overlapping grids of colored tile. As the son of art-inclined parents, Wood grew up in such environments, exaggerating them in paintings that pack multiple viewpoints, labyrinthine spaces and iconic images by Picasso, Matisse, Calder, Warhol and others into kicky cabinets of curiosities that feel just like home. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

CHILDHOOD memories and revisiting the characters and works of Beatrix Potter (Peter Rabbit), Jean de Brunhoff (Babar) and Ernest Shepard (Winnie the Pooh and ''The Wind in the Willows'') with her son, Gustavo, 6, are what inspire the artist Sarah Nicholas Williams's collection of fantastical paintings for children, called ''Radish Moon.'' Done in India ink and watercolor, her work depicts creatures in fanciful scenarios: a goat rides his bicycle by lunar light; a tutu-wearing bird skips rope on the back of a ballet-slippered goat. Prints come in frames made of driftwood by a man who gathers the wood by canoe in Key West, Fla. With each vignette, ''the child has an opportunity to make his or her own story,'' Ms. Nicholas Williams said. Her own son ''lets it be known what I should add or take away. I was working on a picture of a rabbit sleeping underground beneath a garden, and Tavo told me: 'You really need a door. How else will she get in?' '' ''Radish Moon'' limited-edition prints; $250. Go to radishmoon.com. FLORENCE KANE

After blockbusters like the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Alexander McQueen exhibition, visitors to ''Fashioning the Object,'' which opens April 14 at the Art Institute of Chicago, might be inspired to ask, ''Um, so where's the fashion?'' But that would no doubt come as a compliment to Bless, Boudicca and Sandra Backlund, the unconventional and fiercely independent designers who were selected by the show's curator, Zoë Ryan, because their work ''challenges the fashion system and speaks to the time in which it is made.'' Three immersive environments highlight behind-the-scenes aspects of the creative process. The Boudicca designers Zowie Broach and Brian Kirkby have provided 25 to 30 of their conceptual short films. The Bless component will feature Desiree Heiss and Ines Kaag's signature look books - using friends as models and distributed in publications like Monthly Vampire Magazine - and surreal hybrid objects like the ''Hairbrush.'' And Backlund will be represented by light-infused abstractions of her sculptural, handmade knits printed on 11-foot scrims, which underscore her emotional connection to her work. Says Ryan: ''I'm curious to see what people will make of it.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

IN the photographer Cass Bird's new book ''Rewilding'' (Damiani, $35), she recasts the artist haven of Sassafrass, Tenn., as a naturalistic oasis where women are not only unafraid to roughhouse, climb trees and dress in breast-baring overalls, but are also allowed to reclaim tokens of femininity (tutulike skirts, pigtails and rollers among them) for fun. ''It is really about letting go, being wild and creating a space that someone can be free in,'' said Ms. Bird, pictured above with some of the women who model in the book (from left, Diane Russo, Cherlyn Russo, Julia Res, Ms. Bird and Khara Gilvey). ''That experience of confronting how society wants women to conform, even within the queer community, was life-changing.'' SARAH SCIRE

The tax-filing deadline for 2012 is April 17. While there is no app that can cure procrastination, some allow you to file the ''EZ'' form using your phone; help track and organize expenses and receipts; offer refund estimates; and track your refund as it wends its way from the I.R.S. to your bank account. The top developers in the app market are the two companies that have dominated the software category for years: H&R Block and Intuit, which makes the TurboTax line of products.

Nina Levy is putting mothers everywhere to shame with what she makes for her sons' lunches: their napkins. With waterproof art markers and using generic white paper luncheon napkins as her canvas, Ms. Levy, a Brooklyn sculptor by day, designs a flat fantasy world at night where dragons breathe fire, teddy bears battle knights, Batman and Luke Skywalker make cameos, and popular cartoon animals wish 9-year-old Archer and 5-year-old Ansel a good lunch.

JOVANOVIC--Danica, On March 20, 2012. Beloved wife of Petar. Devoted mother of Rozalia and Aleksandar and his wife Janine. Adoring grandmother of Roman and Maxim. Danica was married in Trieste, Italy and moved to New York in 1966 where she began her career as a lingerie designer, winning numerous awards and working for a time for Christian Dior. Danica was admired for her iconic style, her warm generous and positive spirit, her support of the arts and her love of entertaining. Family will receive visitors at Frank E. Paul S. Boyer, an intellectual historian who wrote groundbreaking studies of the Salem witch trials, the history of apocalyptic movements and the response of the American public to the nuclear annihilation of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, Japan, died on March 17 in Madison, Wis. He was 78. The cause was cancer, said his wife, Ann.

MTV2 plans to resurrect the game show ''Hollywood Squares'' with a twist: producers will fill many of the nine spots in the giant tic-tac-toe grid with figures from the hip-hop world, the network announced on Friday. The new show will be called ''Hip Hop Squares'' and will be hosted by Peter Rosenberg, a D.J. from the radio station Hot 97 (WQHT-FM) in New York. As in the old game show, the stars will be asked trivia questions and contestants will judge the veracity of their answers. The network has lined up well-known rappers for the show, including Fat Joe, Biz Markie, Ghostface Killah, Mac Miller and Machine Gun Kelly. The comedian Nick Cannon and the professional skateboarder Bam Margera (perhaps best known for his appearances in the ''Jackass'' movies) will also appear. ''The show will refresh an iconic format,'' said Paul Ricci, the head of programming for MTV2, adding the program is ''more party than game show.'' The show, which will have its premiere on May 22 at 11 p.m., will be part of the network's Tuesday night programming block intended to lure male viewers. No word yet on who will fill Paul Lynde's spot in the center square.

George Zimmerman, 28, a neighborhood watch coordinator, says that he shot Trayvon Martin, 17, in a gated community in Florida in self-defense after a life-or- death struggle. Official accounts and interviews with those involved in the case offer a glimpse into what may have happened on the night of Feb. 26. 1. A TRIP TO 7-ELEVEN Trayvon walks back toward the home of his father's girlfriend after a trip to 7-Eleven, carrying a bag of Skittles and a can of iced tea.

NAGLER--Stewart Gordon, died March 29, 2012 after a long illness. He was 69 years old. Beloved wife of Ronnie. Devoted father of Ellen, David and Amy and grandfather of Brooke and Emily and cherished stepfather of Lauren and David, Dana and Steven and grandfather of Adam, Evan, Emma and Alex. Loving brother to Lenore and David. He was predeceased by his first wife Bonnie and his parents Mary and Henry Nagler. Born in Brooklyn, New York, he was a summa cum laude graduate in mathematics of the Polytechnic University of New York, and later served as Chairman of the Board of Trustees of Polytechnic. He spent his entire working career of 43 years at the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and Metlife, Inc., retiring in 2004 as Vice Chairman, Chief Financial Officer and a member of the Board of Directors. He was a long-time leader in the insurance industry, responsible for numerous innovations in the life insurance and pension business, and was a former Chairman of the Life Insurance Council of New York and a board member of the American Academy of Actuaries. In recent years he was active as a director of the Nassau County AHRC Foundation. He had previously served as a Chairman of the Reinsurance Group of America, a board member of Tesoro Petroleum Corp., a Trustee of the Boys & Girls Clubs of America and a Trustee of Barnard College. A memorial service will be held on Monday, April 2 at 11:45am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York, New York. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to either the Nassau County AHRC Foundation, 189 Wheatley Road, #

Searching for higher returns to bridge looming shortfalls, public workers' pension funds across the country are increasingly turning to riskier investments in private equity, real estate and hedge funds. But while their fees have soared, their returns have not. In fact, a number of retirement systems that have stuck with more traditional investments in stocks and bonds have performed better in recent years, for a fraction of the fees.

An article on Thursday about how Skittles, the candy Trayvon Martin was carrying when he was killed, has become a symbol of protest rendered incorrectly the name of a powdered drink that also became a symbol of protest after the cult leader Jim Jones laced it with cyanide to kill more than 900 people in Guyana in 1978. It is Flavor Aid, not Flavor-Aid.

LOS ANGELES - You don't want an Israeli Air Force pilot on your tail, especially not the kind who has turned documentary filmmaker. But Arnon Milchan, a Hollywood film producer who spent years moonlighting for Lakam, Israel's now-disbanded top-secret intelligence agency, has just such a pursuer, in the person of Elan Frank.

AT&T is going all in with the upcoming release of the Nokia Lumia 900 smartphone. The carrier claims that the release, set for April 8, will be its biggest product introduction ever - surpassing even the release of the iPhone. That's a remarkable statement to make about a smartphone featuring Windows Phone 7, Microsoft's new mobile software, which hasn't gained much traction in the United States. But AT&T will be trying hard to get people to want this phone. The wireless company told CNET that it was working with Nokia on a big television campaign to advertise the Lumia 900, and in AT&T stores, the phone will be put in the spotlight with signs and posters promoting it.

She was a gentle soul who always had a smile and kind word for everyone. She was beautiful inside and out and was a "lady" to the very end. She will greatly missed. Private service will be held Monday, April 2nd.

When Encyclopaedia Britannica announced last month that it was discontinuing its print editions after 244 years, company executives noted that there were 4,000 sets of the final 32-volume 2010 edition left in a warehouse, the remnants of an old tradition. Less than three weeks later, the bulk of them are gone.

BICKMAN--Marion. May 1, 1918, passed away March 28 at home. Sister to Bea, Elaine and Morty; mother to Andi and Barbara; grandmother to Gary, Lisa, Marc and Sam; great-grandmother to six. Marion's beauty, humor and dancing will be missed.

COPENHAGEN -- European Union finance ministers agreed on Saturday to increase competition among credit ratings agencies and to continue difficult discussions on taxing certain financial transactions. At the end of a two-day gathering here, Margrethe Vestager, Denmark's economics minister, announced that the ministers had reached an agreement to require companies to rotate ratings agencies to prevent conflicts of interest and encourage more competition.

CHIBNIK--Mara, passed away on March 26, 2012 of cancer at home. Survived by loving husband Martin J. Smith, parents Joseph and Rosa Chibnik, brother Paul, sister and brother-in-law Lisa and Stephen Kawolsky and their children Sharon, Neil and Erin.

Some DirecTV customers woke up on Sunday without Fox or the CW networks on their television sets, the result of a failed negotiation with Tribune Broadcasting, which owns or operates 23 television stations across the United States. The blackout effects stations in 19 markets, including New York, where Tribune owns the CW network affiliate WPIX; Philadelphia, where it owns MyNetworkTV affiliate WPHL; Chicago, where it owns CW affiliate WGN-TV; Los Angeles, where it owns CW affiliate KTLA; and Seattle, where it owns Fox affiliate KCPQ. It also effects WGN America, a version of WGN-TV that is available on cable and satellite systems in many parts of the country.

All the different computers and mobile devices that are used in today's offices are a headache for information technology managers, but they could turn into a strategic advantage for some companies. Just not, perhaps, Microsoft. The online data storage company Box.net has announced plans for a product that will work with 30 different business applications across a range of mobile devices. Box says the product, OneCloud, works now with Apple's iPhone and iPad, and will soon work with Android phones and tablets.

Comcast said recently that a video-streaming service it will provide to Xbox consoles would not count toward its customers' monthly data limits. The cable company's move is raising concerns about net neutrality, the idea that Internet providers should treat all services equally to keep competition fair.

One of the most prolific art forgers in America is getting a show this weekend at the University of Cincinnati. Curators say they are putting on display more than 90 forgeries by Mark A. Landis, an eccentric painter who donated dozens of phony works to museums around the country for more than 25 years before being found out in 2008. The tongue-in-cheek show, ''Faux Real,'' opens, appropriately enough, on April Fool's Day, and includes copies of paintings ostensibly by masters, including a fake Picasso that fooled the Cummer Museum of Arts and Gardens in Jacksonville, Florida.

Penn and Teller, meet Wayne and Garth. And another guy.
