PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. -- The Mets on Sunday made the announcement they had been itching to make since the middle of February: Johan Santana will be their starter on opening day. At the beginning of spring training, the club circled April 5 as the date it hoped Santana, who missed last season with a shoulder injury, could make his triumphant return. But the ever-present possibility for setbacks in his recovery forced Manager Terry Collins to hold off on making a decision.

An article on the Itineraries page on Tuesday about the effect of business policies like airline baggage fees on the income of people who rely on tips misstated the surname of a skycap at George Bush Intercontinental Airport in Houston who commented on the issue. He is Calvin Miller, not Harris.

An article on Thursday about Rick Santorum's shifting the tone of his remarks about Mitt Romney misstated the location of the town of Onalaska, Wis., where Mr. Santorum campaigned on Wednesday. It is north of La Crosse, Wis., not southeast.

ZASLOWER--Philip M.,March 31, 2012. Survived by his wife Sheila; children Leslie and Jay Zaslower, David Meyer and Jennifer Krauss; and four grandchildren Max, Ben, Nate and Ella. Residence of Sag Harbor and Florida, Phil and Sheila were co-owners of The PML Furniture Group. A gifted and comedic storyteller, Phil was passionate about family, friends, golf, tennis and retiring to Florida. Services to be held at "The Riverside", 76th and Amsterdam, Tuesday at 10am.

''The Hunger Games'' continued to dominate movie theaters over the weekend, leaving the big-budget sequel ''Wrath of the Titans'' and ''Mirror Mirror'' with Julia Roberts to make do with box-office scraps. Propelled by strong word of mouth, ''The Hunger Games'' (Lionsgate) repeated as the No. 1 movie in North America, taking in an estimated $61.1 million for a two-week total of over $251 million, according to Hollywood.com, which complies box-office data. ''Wrath of the Titans,'' which cost Warner Brothers and Legendary Pictures about $150 million to make, finished second, with about $34.2 million in ticket sales -- or 44 percent less than ''Clash of the Titans'' took in over its first three days in 2010. The continued strength of ''The Hunger Games'' hurt ''Wrath.'' But audiences -- perhaps proving the adage that you can fool ticket buyers once but not twice -- may have stayed away because of dissatisfaction with ''Clash,'' which drew criticism for shoddy 3-D effects. Warner and Legendary hope that ''Wrath'' will play well overseas, where the first installment generated 67 percent of its total ticket revenue. It dominated the international box office over the weekend with sales of $78 million in 60 markets, according to Warner Brothers.

LEIGHTON--Cy, (aka Samuel C. Levine) died on March 31st, 2012. Mr. Leighton was born in the Bronx NY on November 14, 1920. He graduated from NY University. He was a United States Army Staff Sergeant, serving in the 3rd Army, Member of the Greatest Generation and the Band of Brothers--from Normandy through to the Battle of the Bulge where he received a Purple Heart. Owner of Danleigh Insulation & Supply Corp. for 40 years, past President of The Builders Institute of Westchester County. He was married more than 65 years to Bernice Levine. Survived by three daughters, Linda Greenfield, Barbara Levine and Sandra Levine; three sons-in-law, Dr. Andrew Greenfield, Attorney Frederick S. Gold, and Henry Nelson; three granddaughters, Dani Greenfield, Samantha Reiff and Alexandra Gold, and Grandson-in-law Howard Reiff. Services will be held 11:00am on Tuesday April 3rd, 2012 at The Congregation Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Avenue, White Plains, NY with interment to follow at the Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, New York.

MF Global customers who closed their accounts in the brokerage firm's final days have been fuming for months about how the firm mailed checks to them, instead of promptly transferring the money electronically as usual. Many of those checks arrived after the bankruptcy filing, and subsequently bounced. Now customers are taking action, trying to show that MF Global delayed the return of their money to cover the firm's own bills and stay afloat. They are amassing client documents and submitting them to federal investigators in hopes of building a criminal case against MF Global executives.

BURR--Benjamin Munroe, 89, St. Augustine, died February 28, 2012 at the Glenmoor Health Center at World Golf Village. He was born May 20, 1922 in New York City, son of the late George and Priscilla Burr. He had resided in St. Augustine since 2005, moving from Stuart, FL. He was a member of San Sebastian Catholic Church. Ben was a devoted husband, father, and friend, and he is missed by all who had the good fortune to know him. He attended Milton Academy and graduated from Harvard University, Class of 1945. Ben served in the U.S. Marines in World War II, and fought in the Pacific theater. He was later recalled to service at Paris Island, S.C. to train Marines for combat in Korea. Ben worked as a marketing executive for DuPont and Hercules Chemical Company. He enjoyed boating, travel, and spending time with his family. A memorial service is planned at the Glenmoor Chapel at a later date. Ben and his recently departed wife Ginny will be interred together May 5 at Sleepy Hollow Cemetery in Tarrytown, NY. He is survived two daughters, Pam Smith, Brunswick, Maine, Sarah Burr (Timothy Lewis), Brooklyn, NY; son, John E. Burr (Karen Koster Burr), Jacksonville; and two grandchildren, Emily Burr, Princeton, NJ, and Ian Burr, Jacksonville. A second son, Benjamin Jr., died in 2004. St. Johns Family Funeral Home and Crematory is in charge of services.

(13, 49) MARGARET MITCHELL: AMERICAN REBEL Mitchell, above, the author of ''Gone With the Wind,'' won a Pulitzer Prize for her novel and used royalties from it to pay for the education of some the first black doctors in the South. (IFC) THE TAVERN (2000) A bartender hears the knock of opportunity when offered the chance to own a tavern, only to learn that he is unprepared for the pressure and responsibility of running a small business. Ronnie (Cameron Dye), the man with the plan, doesn't have enough money, so he borrows some from his family and joins with his friend Dave (Kevin Geer), who ponies up the rest. But the competition in Manhattan is tough, and the bar's former owner opens a new establishment that attracts the old customers.

Brian L. Fisher, an entomologist at the California Academy of Sciences, has been studying the ants of Madagascar for more than 15 years. The plan sounded so simple. We would drive from this capital city to Kandreho and then boat down the Mahahavy River until we reached one of the last remaining large forests in northwestern Madagascar. We would carry all our food and gear, including a full lab with a microscope, to a beach camp adjacent to the forest itself.

Was that all there was? The art world was braced for another attack from Morley Safer and his ''60 Minutes'' crew on Sunday night. It had been nearly two decades since the 1993 segment in which he derisively lumped together the work ofJeff Koons,Cy Twombly, Robert Ryman,Robert Gober, Christopher Wool, Felix Gonzalez-Torres andJean-Michel Basquiat while inviting conservative art critics likeHilton Kramer, who died last week, to confirm that it was all indeed overpriced tripe - ''the emperor's new clothes,'' as he put it. The first time around Mr. Safer did little except talk about money. There being much more money in the art world these days, a reprise must have been irresistible.

Rarely does reality intersect with role playing the way it did two Sundays ago in Bob Woodward's living room. Meeting him there were Carl Bernstein, his writing partner at The Washington Post during the Watergate scandal in the 1970s; Ben Bradlee, their top editor at the time; and Robert Redford, the actor who played Mr. Woodward in ''All the President's Men,'' the 1976 film that dramatized The Post's presidential detective work.

I was so excited for what lay ahead, I nearly forgot to wave goodbye to my parents. Armed with a college diploma, my first job offer, a one-way ticket to Paris and a new pair of heels, I was ready to take on anything. Little did I know, I would be back in New York seven short months later. But my parents would not be taking pictures at the airport or chatting about my future plans. I would be in a wheelchair, too weak to walk. In Paris, the doctors had struggled to make sense of my symptoms - anemia, fatigue and persistent infections. They ran test after test - I was even hospitalized for a week - but the results were inconclusive. I was just 22, but the doctors released me with a diagnosis of ''burnout syndrome'' and orders to rest for a month.

8 P.M. (NBC) THE BIGGEST LOSER One of the many reasons to lose weight is the excuse to buy new clothes. Or, if you're a contestant on this show, to receive a free new wardrobe. The six remaining contestants get clothes to fit their slimmer waistlines when the fashion professional Jeannie Mai and the stylist Ken Paves join the show in this makeover episode. All dressed up, the contestants just need somewhere to go. That problem is solved when they receive an invitation to visit the White House and meet with the first lady, Michelle Obama. The contestants travel to Washington, where they reunite with their families and show the payoff from their hard work. In the second part of the episode, appearing next week, Mrs. Obama works out with them and discusses the benefits of an active lifestyle. Above, a scene from the show. 10:15 A.M. (Showtime 2) OUTSOURCED (2007) After Todd Anderson (Josh Hamilton) loses his job as a call-center manager, he is sent to India to train his replacement in this film from John Jeffcoat. Todd is initially grumpy about the change in his fortunes and has trouble adjusting to the food, the crowds and the language. But then he falls for one of his colleagues at work, the bright and self-possessed Asha (Ayesha Dharker), and he learns to embrace India and recognize the benefits of change. Reviewing this movie for The New York Times, Matt Zoller Seitz called it ''a wonderful surprise'' and said ''the filmmakers treat Todd's story as a springboard for a smart look at the effect of cultural difference on work, friendship and love, and the global economy's impact on national and personal identity.''

FORT--Pavel, MD. The Steven and Alexandra Cohen Children's Medical Center of New York mourns the untimely passing of our esteemed colleague, Pavel Fort, MD on Saturday, March 31, 2012. Dr. Fort graduated from the Faculty of Pediatrics of Charles University School of Medicine, Prague, and emigrated to the United States in 1971. After completing his residency, he specialized in Pediatric Endocrinology under Dr. Fima Lifshitz, and remained on the staff of NSLIJHS for the past nearly 40 years. Named among the best doctors in New York, Dr. Fort was widely respected by colleagues and patients alike. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Suzana, three children, Andrea, Paul and Phillip, and three granddaughters.

TESSER--Dr. Sheldon, of Roslyn Heights, died at home on April 1st at the age of 76. A practicing psychoanalyst, he was devoted to his wife, Joan, daughters Mimi and Julie, sons-in-law Ned Rumpeltin and Ivan Okun and grandchildren Abigail, Max and Daphne. After attending NYU he received a Medical degree from the University of Lausanne, Switzerland. Subsequent to practicing internal medicine, he served as a radiologist during the Vietnam War from 1966-1967. Upon his discharge, Dr. Tesser attended the Psychoanalytic Division of New York Medical College, ultimately becoming a Fellow of The Society of Medical Psychoanalysts and Dynamic Psychiatry in 1979. He then went on to practice psychoanalysis for over thirty years and served on the faculty of the State University of New York at Stonybrook and the Long Island Institute of Psychoanalysis. He will be remembered for his love of dahlias, jazz and classical history. His wit and ability to find humor when least expected will always be part of his legacy. An extraordinary husband and dedicated father, he will live on in the memories of Joan, Mimi, Julie and his brother Richard.

Regulators on Monday accused the Royal Bank of Canada of orchestrating an elaborate trading scheme and booking bogus trades to generate lucrative tax benefits. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission claims that Canada's biggest, and arguably most powerful, financial institution concealed a plot involving hundreds of millions of dollars in trades for years, according to a civil lawsuit. The action is the agency's most significant enforcement case in recent memory.

Wall Street, which buys and sells all types of exotic securities, has found a limit to its financial innovation. It can't trade derivatives tied to the 2012 election. On Monday, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission rejected a plan for so-called political event contracts, wary that mixing politics and trading would create a dangerous cocktail. The agency ruled, in part, that such trading amounts to gambling - and that it could unduly influence election results.

An article on Monday about relations between the Oakland A's and the San Francisco Giants, who are battling over territorial baseball rights to San Jose, misstated the number of years the teams have shared the Bay Area market. They have done so for 44 years, not 42. The article and, in some copies, a picture caption also erroneously attributed a distinction to the A's stadium. It is one of a couple of major league parks that host another team in another sport -- not the only one to do so. (The A's share the Coliseum with the Raiders of the N.F.L., while the Blue Jays share Rogers Centre in Toronto with the Argonauts of the Canadian Football League.)

AMSTERDAM -- It was 1989, and Dr. Petra de Jong, a Dutch pulmonologist, was asked for help by a terminally ill patient, a man in great pain with a large cancerous tumor in his trachea. He wanted to end his life. She gave the man pentobarbital, a powerful barbiturate -- but not enough. It took him nine hours to die.

In his best-known roles, Ashton Kutcher has played a young man who came of age in the 1970s and a self-made technology gazillionaire, so why shouldn't his latest gig combine them both? Mr. Kutcher, the sitcom star of ''That '70s Show'' and ''Two and a Half Men,'' is set to portray Steve Jobs in an independent film about that Apple co-founder, Variety reported. The film, called ''Jobs,'' is to be directed by Joshua Michael Stern (''Swing Vote'') and written by Matt Whiteley, and is expected to chronicle Jobs's life from his relatively wayward youth to his involvement in the creation of Apple. Variety said the film is expected to start production in May while Mr. Kutcher is on a hiatus from ''Two and a Half Men,'' on which he plays Walden Schmidt, a wealthy Internet entrepreneur. This ''Jobs'' film is unrelated to a film adaptation of Walter Isaacson's best-selling biography ''Steve Jobs'' that Sony Pictures Entertainment is preparing. (As is often the case with Apple, there's always a new product or upgrade to contend with every few months.)

Every year millions of children from all walks of life become victims of, or witnesses to, abusive or violent events that can result in long-lasting symptoms of distress. The events can range from sexual and physical abuse to involvement in a natural disaster, fire or serious motor vehicle accident. In many cases, the trauma is unknown to parents and caregivers or never dealt with effectively. The consequences can be devastating for the children and families involved and for society at large. These children are at much greater risk of developing behavioral problems, failing at school, abusing drugs or alcohol and becoming violent themselves.

Spending time on a bicycle seat, which has been linked to erectile dysfunction in men, may also be a hazard to a woman's sexual health, a new study shows. Many women who cycle or take spin classes are familiar with the numbness that sometimes can occur from sitting on a traditional bike seat. Bike seats are designed in such a way that body weight typically rests on the nose of the seat, which can compress nerves and blood vessels in the genital area. In men, this raises the risk of erectile dysfunction, something that has been documented in studies of male police officers on bicycle patrol.
An obituary and a headline on Sunday about the historian Paul S. Boyer misstated his age. As the obituary correctly noted, he was born on Aug. 2, 1935, and therefore he was 76, not 78.

''I know where this is going,'' Mr. Romney said as the voter, Bret Hatch 28, stood and - speaking haltingly and reading from a sheet of paper - tried to ask Mr. Romney a highly specific and provocative question about his religion.

Five legally married same-sex couples filed a lawsuit on Monday to challenge the 1996 law that bars the federal government from recognizing same-sex marriages, arguing that its impact is particularly harsh on couples that include an American citizen and a foreigner. The lawsuit, filed in United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York, was brought by Immigration Equality, a gay rights legal organization that focuses on immigration issues. Same-sex marriage advocates said it was likely to become the most prominent suit seeking to overturn the law, known as the Defense of Marriage Act, based on its effect on gay or lesbian immigrants who want to gain legal residence through marriage to American citizens.

''Tweet, tweet, tweet!'' chirped the kindergartners in Jennifer Aaron's class last week, as they settled onto the multicolored carpet and began to consider what they would like to send out into the Twitter universe that day. Three days a week, as the school day draws to a close, the children in Ms. Aaron's class sit down to compose a message about what they have been doing all day. They then send it out to their parents and relatives through Twitter, the stamping grounds of celebrities and politicians, where few kindergartners have been known to venture.

ELLMANN--Erwin B.,of New York City, formerly of Birmingham, MI, died on March 28th at age 97. For sixty years he was a lawyer in Michigan, a well-known specialist in labor issues. His distinguished career extended back to the early 1940s in the FDR administration, when he contributed significantly to the Department of the Interior "Portal-to-Portal" case, which improved working conditions for coal miners. Later he represented the ACLU in First Amendment cases and the Michigan Education Association in cases affecting the rights of teachers. He argued cases before the United States Supreme Court, and in later years he was much in demand as a labor arbitrator. His legal briefs were known for their strength and eloquence. He often served as a primary editorial helper for his brother, the biographer, Richard Ellmann, on the manuscripts of books about William Butler Yeats and James Joyce. When his wife of 60 years, Steffani Ellmann, died in 2006, he moved to New York from Michigan to be close to his family. He earned a B.A. from the University of Michigan and graduated from the University of Michigan Law School. He is survived by a daughter, Barbara Ellmann, of New York; a son, Michael Ellmann, of Boston; and two grandsons, Christopher Ellmann and James Boone McElroy. Friends wishing to honor Erwin's memory are encouraged to contribute to University of Michigan Law School or University of Michigan Comprehensive Cancer Center.

Adding to the recent wave of artists suing record companies over online royalties, ''Weird Al'' Yankovic has sued Sony Music Entertainment, saying he is owed more than $5 million. In the suit, filed Friday at United States District Court in Manhattan, Mr. Yankovic says the company underpaid him for videos and other expenses, and also incorrectly counted downloads of his music as ''sales'' rather than as ''licenses,'' which pay a higher royalty rate. He also asks for money from industry settlements with Napster, Kazaa, Grokster and other file-sharing services, and says he is owed $2.5 million from Sony's share of the sale of YouTube in 2006. Sony, Universal and the Warner Music Group had owned a stake in YouTube, and when that company was sold to Google for $1.65 billion, the labels made a reported $50 million.

GODWIN--Howard Gibson, Jr.,67, passed away peacefully at his home in Tarrytown, NY on April 1, 2012. The son of the late Howard Gibson and Nettie Mae Motes Godwin, he was born on April 28, 1944, in Harnett County, NC. A graduate of Dunn High School, he earned his Bachelor of Arts degree from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, where he was a Morehead Scholar and a member of Phi Beta Kappa and Chi Psi Fraternities. He also served on the Board of Visitors for the University. Howard attended Duke University School of Law, where he earned his Juris Doctorate in 1969. At the time of his death, he had worked for 42 years as a corporate lawyer, and partner since 1978, at Sidley Austin LLP in New York City. He was also a member of the New York State Bar Association. An avid sports fan, particularly of high school athletics, Howard was the sole sponsor of the Sleepy Hollow High School Annual Holiday Basketball Tournament for the past 20 years and played a major role in the Sleepy Hollow High School Sports Association. He is survived by his wife of 42 years, Mimi McDonough Godwin, children Elizabeth Godwin and Anne Godwin Cauthren, his son- in-law, Benjamin Cauthren, and his sister, Virginia Anne Godwin Carboy. He was predeceased by his son, William Godwin. Visitation will be held Tuesday from 7-9pm and Wednesday from 2-4pm and 7-9pm at Dwyer & Vanderbilt Funeral Home, 90 North Broadway, Tarrytown. Liturgy of the Word and Commendation will be at 10:30am on Thursday, April 5 at the Church of the Magdelene 525 Bedford Road Pocantico Hills, NY. Interment will follow at Sleepy Hollow Cemetery in Sleepy Hollow. In lieu of flowers, the family has asked that donations may be sent to either the Foundation for the Public Schools of the Tarrytowns with notation in support of the Howard Godwin Athletics Fund, 210 North Broadway, Sleepy Hollow, NY 10591 or in memory of Howard Godwin to the University of North Carolina's School of Journalism and Mass Communication, Office of Development, Campus Box 3365, Chapel Hill, NC 27599.

QUINN--Edward G.,80, died April 2, 2012. A US Army Veteran and Bronze Star recipient, Edward grew up in Brooklyn, NY, where he graduated from St. Michael's High School and Brooklyn College. After beginning a successful teaching career at JHS 51 (NYC Department of Education), Edward completed an MA and PhD at New York University and then taught English at St. Francis College (Brooklyn). Edward continued his career as an English professor at The City College of New York, where he served as English Department Chair and co-founder of the CCNY Center for Worker Education. He retired after a 20+ year career as professor emeritus. An imaginative, lively critic and productive scholar, Edward authored/co-authored numerous books and journal articles, including "The Reader's Encyclopedia of Shakespeare" and "The Sense of the Sixties." Son of the late Edward and Margaret Quinn, Edward was the beloved husband of Barbara Gleason. He was the devoted father of Deirdre, Colin, Dave and Jennifer, father-in-law of Helene Quinn, and grandfather of Liam, Caitlin, Adam, Kieran, Declan, Maya, Shannon, and Summer, and is also survived by his former wife, Gail (Murphy) Quinn. Dear brother of Kathleen Hackett, Patricia Phelan, Mary Lilja, Margaret Quinn, Maureen Quinn, and of the late Dorothy Quinn, Helen Keeler and James Quinn, Edward will be also be sorely missed by a multitude of nieces, nephews, and godchildren, and by a large circle of very close friends. Visiting Tuesday 2-5 and 6-9pm at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Ave., Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday 9:45am at St. Anselm's Church, 356 82nd St., Brooklyn. A scholarship/ merit-based award will be established in memory of Edward G. Quinn at the City College of New York (to be announced). Donations will be appreciated.

9:49 p.m. | Updated The Obama campaign released a new commercial on Monday that tries to link Mitt Romney to the oil industry, painting them both as hostile to the president's efforts to raise automobile mileage standards and produce more renewable energy. With gasoline prices approaching $4 a gallon and expected to increase further in the weeks ahead, the ad is an acknowledgment of the political difficulties the president faces over his energy policies.

The government of Turkey appears to be joining the list of countries making more concerted demands of the United States for the return of antiquities believed to have been looted and exported illegally, The Los Angeles Times reported. Paul Getty Museum, the Cleveland Museum of Art and the Dumbarton Oaks Research Library and Collection at Harvard University are among the institutions in which Turkish officials have identified objects they believe should be returned.

An article on Friday about places in the National Mall neighborhood in Washington to get meals, snacks or cocktails during the National Cherry Blossom Festival referred imprecisely to the Willard InterContinental hotel. While it is on the site of the earlier Willard Hotel, the current building was erected in 1901 (and extensively renovated in 1986) and thus has not ''welcomed presidents since before the Civil War.''

4:53 p.m. | Updated It's no easy feat for a show set in the 1960s to comment on an election taking shape in 2012. And while the writers of ''Mad Men,'' the popular AMC period drama, haven't officially endorsed any candidate in this year's presidential contest, they did find a way to take a sly dig at the Republican front-runner - or at least a progenitor who shares his name. In a brief scene from Sunday's latest installment of ''Mad Men,'' written by Erin Levy and the series creator Matthew Weiner, the character Henry Francis (played by Christopher Stanley) is shown in a telephone call with an unseen colleague. Francis, a fictional character who is the public relations director for Mayor John Lindsay of New York City, tells the off-screen figure: ''Well, tell Jim his Honor's not going to Michigan.''

One hundred years ago, the architect Ernest Flagg designed what might be thought of as the Apple store of its day: a sumptuous Beaux-Arts showcase for the retail business of Charles Scribner's Sons, book publishers. The Scribner's bookstore at 597 Fifth Avenue, between 48th and 49th Streets, presented a generous glass front, enough to intrigue passersby but not enough to reveal all the treasures within. One had to go inside. A sense of unfolding discovery was heightened by stairways leading to a variety of levels. The volume was far more ample and the finishes far more refined than they had to be. This space was as much about establishing a brand as it was about moving inventory. Sound familiar?

The Federal Highway Administration has removed a major obstacle to the Bloomberg administration's plan to turn a waterlogged enclave of crumbling shops and sheds near Citi Field into a major development site. -In a decision long awaited by both supporters and opponents of the project, which is to cost about $3 billion, federal officials found that it would have ''no significant effect on the human environment.''

Maybe President Obama should have bought shares in Groupon's I.P.O. If he had, he would understand what some Groupon investors may be feeling as he prepares this week to sign a new piece of legislation to help start-ups get financing. Had he purchased $10,000 worth of shares on the open market on the first day of public trading for Groupon, the online coupon company based in his hometown Chicago, he would have lost a good chunk of his investment, putting him in the red by almost $4,100 today.

Schiro, the former chief of Zurich Financial Services Group, as its new lead director and head of its corporate governance and nominating committee on Monday. Shareholders recently pressured Goldman into appointing a lead director. Mr. Schiro will succeed John H. Bryan, the former chief executive of the Sara Lee Corporation, who had served since 1999.

Taylor Swift, Miranda Lambert and Jason Aldean were the big winners at the 47th annual Academy of Country Music Awards in Las Vegas on Sunday night in a show that provided few surprises. Ms. Swift, who at 22 has become one of the highest-earning singers in any genre, was named entertainer of the year for the second year in a row, beating out Mr. Aldean, Kenny Chesney and Brad Paisley. The award was not unexpected. Her last album, ''Speak Now,'' was the second-best-selling LP of 2011, and Billboard recently named her its top moneymaker last year with an estimated $35 million earned. She also won two Grammys earlier this year. Ms. Lambert won her third consecutive female vocalist of the year award and her third album of the year trophy for her ''Four the Record.''

KLEIN--Joseph. The staff and trustees of the North Shore-Long Island Jewish (LIJ) Health System mourn the loss of Trustee Emeritus Joseph Klein. Along with his wife Zina, Joe was a long-time benefactor of North Shore University Hospital (NSUH). Their generosity supported NSUH's programs and services, and enabled the hospital to develop state-of-the-art cardiology services which gained nationwide recognition. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Zina; his sister, Millie Nixon; his children Wendy Smith and Nadine, Howard and Jeannie Klein, and Shari and Steven Nemiroff; his grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Michael J. Dowling, President and CEO, North Shore- LIJ Health System Richard D. Goldstein, Chairman, Board of Trustees, North Shore-LIJ Health System

GOLICK--Morrie. The Board of Directors and staff of the S.L.E. Lupus Foundation and the lupus patient and scientific communities across the nation mourn the death of our Foundation's beloved founder Morrie Golick (1911-2012) at the age of 101. Born of a father's love, the S.L.E. Lupus Foundation was forged by his devotion to his daughter Susan and his determination to find answers when she was diagnosed at 24 with the devastating autoimmune disease lupus. Celebrating the Foundation's 40th anniversary and his 100th birthday in 2010, Morrie reflected, "I wanted to find a way others could benefit from our family's difficult experience with lupus." Morrie Golick made the difference for lupus patients, families, researchers and physicians, launching the lupus movement in New York City and leading its evolution across America. He and Susan worked tirelessly to create much-needed patient services, awareness and advocacy, while always supporting lupus research. Their leadership in nurturing promising scientists and building the laboratories of New York helped their city become the world's foremost center for lupus care and research. Convinced that a cure is within reach, Morrie worked to create the Lupus Research Institute in 2000, now the world's leading supporter of innovative research in lupus. Because of that steadfast conviction, Morrie saw many pivotal scientific discoveries, including the first lupus treatment in 50 years, come to fruition during his lifetime. Morrie Golick has given us a lasting legacy - generosity of spirit, a loving heart that went out to all who struggle with this disease every day, and the unflagging determination to pursue a cure for lupus. We honor and remember Morrie with love and will miss him very much.

BOASBERG--Sarah Szold, known as Sally, died peacefully at home surrounded by her family, her garden and the flowers of spring on March 29, 2012. She is survived by her husband, Tersh, four children, Jeb, Tom, Margaret and Melissa, and 12 grandchildren. There will be a memorial service to celebrate her life in a few weeks. She was active in the Washington area as a landscape designer, teacher, lecturer, and civic leader. Her own shade garden on Newark Street was nationally recognized. She served on many local and national horticultural, garden, landscape, education and opera boards and committees. In lieu of flowers, donations in the name of Sally Boasberg may be made either to: (1) "The Sally Boasberg Founder's Fellowship" at The Cultural Landscape Foundation, 1909 Que St. NW, 2d Floor, Washington, DC 20009; or (2) "Friends of the National Arboretum", 3501 New York Ave. NE, Washington DC 20002 for the "Flowering Tree Walk".

With news conferences in Chicago and Paris on Tuesday, Google announced the start of its expanded, technologically refined Google Art Project. This new program, the company said, ''goes global.'' The numbers alone speak for themselves. The project -- which began in January 2011 and gave users access to artworks and views of galleries in 17 participating museums -- now includes 151 institutions. Initially the museums were in the United States and in eight European nations; 40 countries around the world are now represented. Museums in Australia, Japan, India, the Philippines, Israel and Qatar have entered the Google art universe. And while the initial project gave access to 1,000 paintings, visitors may now look at more than 32,000 works in all art media, from aboriginal rock art to textiles, glass and ceramics.

An article on Friday about Canada's decision to stop production of pennies erroneously included two countries as having preceded Canada in abandoning one-cent coins. While Australia did so, neither Britain nor Norway had one-cent coins to abandon. Britain has, however, eliminated the half-pence (worth about 1 cent American and Canadian), and Norway has removed all coins valued at 25 öre (about 4 cents) or less. (Among other nations whose residents cannot buy a penny candy, if such a thing still existed, without getting change back are Sweden, Finland, the Netherlands, Switzerland, Israel, Brazil, Australia and New Zealand.)

A picture caption on Saturday with an article about the early years of Tim Tebow's football career in the Jacksonville, Fla., area misidentified the city in which Nease High School, for whom Tebow played, is located. It is in Ponte Vedra, not Jacksonville Beach.

HERRMANN--Edmund. Edmund Herrmann passed away on Thursday, March 29, 2012, at Mease Continuing Care in Dunedin, Florida. He was 94. Ed was born in Brooklyn, NY and lived in Mount Vernon, NY for many years where he raised his family with his first wife, the former Beatrice Wertheim. He married Janis G. Thomas in 1976. They retired to Dunedin, FL in 1992. Janis died in 2003. Ed worked as a compositor for The New York Times at its Times Square, New York facility and retired in 1983, just as computers were starting to make his profession obsolete. Besides being a member of The New York Times Credit Union Board, when not at work, he volunteered his time and energies to local organizations. As a member of the Ethical Culture Society of Westchester (NY), Ed provided administrative and leadership support to the Society's outreach programs. After working with Boy Scout groups for many years, Ed became the Scoutmaster for a troop that was organized in a local orphanage in Mount Vernon. As a volunteer with the Visiting Nurse Services in Westchester, Inc., Ed began what would be many years of Hospice service in both Westchester County, NY and then Pinellas County, FL with Suncoast Hospice. Ed's fifteen plus years of volunteer work with the City of Dunedin Library system resulted in a public citation and Certificate of Appreciation presented by the mayor. As a life insurance salesman in the 1950's, Ed saw a lot of the country by car and train. He also had worked in New York City as a counselor with the Jewish War Veterans. Ed was a 1st Lieutenant in U.S. Army during WWII. Before suffering from a series of debilitating strokes that restricted his mobility, Ed attended weekly services with the Unitarian Universalists of Clearwater; enjoyed traveling by cruise ship with Janis; and hosted weekly meetings in Dunedin's Hale Senior Activity Center where current affairs would be discussed. As an avid reader, he would always have a book within reach as well as the daily New York Times. Survivors include a daughter Judy; sons Barry, Jeffrey and Walter; stepdaughter Susan Thomas and stepson Peter Thomas; and grandchildren Mico Hassert, Beth Herrmann, Joshua Herrmann, Jason Thomas and Ryan Thomas. A Memorial Service is not planned. Contributions, if desired, may be made in Ed's memory to a favorite charity.

In a move likely to alter treatment standards in hospitals and doctors' offices nationwide, a group of nine medical specialty boards plans to recommend on Wednesday that doctors perform 45 common tests and procedures less often, and to urge patients to question these services if they are offered. Eight other specialty boards are preparing to follow suit with additional lists of procedures their members should perform far less often. The recommendations represent an unusually frank acknowledgment by physicians that many profitable tests and procedures are performed unnecessarily and may harm patients. By some estimates, unnecessary treatment constitutes one-third of medical spending in the United States.

A dance review on Saturday about the Paul Taylor Dance Company, which was at Lincoln Center from March 13 through this past Sunday, misstated the number of works the company performed in its first two weeks there and misstated the date of the first performance of ''Esplanade'' during the run. The company performed 22 works in the first two weeks (and in the entire run), not 21, and ''Esplanade'' was first performed on March 24, not on March 28.

An article on Tuesday about a movement in the Netherlands to make voluntary euthanasia widely available described incorrectly the powerful muscle relaxant curare, which is typically administered in euthanasia. Curare causes respiratory paralysis; it does not stop the heart.

CBS, closing the lid on any speculation that change might be coming for its late-night lineup, announced Tuesday that both David Letterman and Craig Ferguson have agreed to continue in their shows for at least two more years. The ''at least'' may be the biggest news because Mr. Letterman -- whose tenure at night would now reach 32 years, passing the 30-year mark of his idol Johnny Carson and making him the longest-serving late-night host in TV history -- has been the subject of frequent speculation about when he might choose to step down. Mr. Letterman will turn 65 on April 12.

In Hollywood you're always at risk of being replaced by someone younger and newer to the scene. But why should Los Angeles get to have all the fun? For the first time the director Jason Reitman will bring his popular ''Live Read'' series, in which famous movie scripts are performed by contemporary actors, to New York with a reading of ''The Apartment'' to be presented on April 27 at the TimesCenter in Manhattan, it was announced on Tuesday. ''I'd done table reads for my own screenplays, and I always thought they were so much fun,'' said Mr. Reitman, whose films include ''Young Adult,'' ''Juno'' and ''Up in the Air.'' ''Why couldn't we do these for other classic screenplays and bring them to life? You can experience live theater, where you get to see plays produced by different directors and different casts, but there's really nothing like that for movie scripts. The great words in these screenplays were really only heard one way, the way they existed in that one film.''

AUGUSTA, Ga. - This is Tiger Woods's 18th Masters, which means he has been playing at Augusta National for half his life. That exposure is priceless, as are the countless tips he has picked up from others during practice rounds over the years. Woods, a four-time Masters champion, said: ''I've gotten just umpteen amount of advice from guys who have played here way more than I have. That's really helped.''

The judicial authorities will indict 13 Muslim radicals suspected of plotting terrorist acts in France, a state prosecutor said Tuesday, though he acknowledged that the plots remained at an ''intellectual'' stage. The 13, members of the Islamist group Forsane Alizza, or Knights of Pride, were arrested in raids across the country on Friday. The group, which had been disbanded by the government, had hailed the deaths of Western soldiers in Afghanistan but denied any plans to commit violence. Investigators recovered three Kalashnikov assault rifles in the suspects' possession, along with several handguns, the prosecutor said. President Nicolas Sarkozy has renewed an emphasis on combating Islamic extremism since a series of killings in southern France last month committed by a young Frenchman claiming ties to Al Qaeda. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

WEINSCHENK--Fritz. Sons Walter and Carl, their wives Terri and Lori and grandchildren Sam, Rose, Emily and Daniel regret to announce the passing of Fritz Weinschenk on March 23. Fritz was a beloved father, father-in-law and grandfather. Fritz's exploits at Omaha Beach on D-Day and the Philippines during World War II, his activities after the war in Europe and his long legal career that largely consisted of helping the victims of the Nazis are well known. Those who knew him were equally struck by his humility, dignity and sense of humor. He will be missed.

''Potted Potter,'' the 70-minute unauthorized parody of the seven Harry Potter books, will make its United States debut with an Off Broadway production starting preview performances on May 19 at the Little Shubert Theater, a group of Canadian and British producers announced on Tuesday. As previously reported, the producers plan to hold 10 performances a week at the 499-seat Little Shubert - more than the typical New York performance schedule of eight a week - in hopes of making more money off the relatively brief running time of ''Potted Potter'' and the popularity of the Potter characters and stories. The two-man show starring Daniel Clarkson and Jefferson Turner, who play multiple characters amid many costume changes, has proved popular in productions in Edinburgh, London, Toronto and elsewhere and was recently nominated for an Olivier Award (Britain's equivalent of the Tony Awards) in the category of best entertainment.

An article on Tuesday about a lawsuit by same-sex married couples challenging the Defense of Marriage Act -- arguing that the law is harsh on couples with an American citizen and a foreigner -- described incorrectly the action gay advocates sought from the federal government before filing the suit. While advocates asked the federal government to halt deportations of immigrants in those couples, they did not do so in connection with the lawsuit. The advocates asked officials to postpone consideration of applications for permanent residency, also known as a green card, for immigrants married to American citizens of the same sex.

An assistant principal at a Bronx elementary school was arrested on Tuesday on charges of sexually abusing two girls, the police said. New York police and the Education Department said the man, Joseph Ponzo, 59, touched the chests of a 10-year-old and an 11-year-old last Tuesday inside Public School 106, where he has been assistant principal since 2008.

KAELIN--Patricia M. The Board of Directors, staff and volunteers of the American Heart Association's Founders Affiliate mourn the loss of their beloved friend and colleague Pat Kaelin. During her 27 years with Heart, she distinguished herself as a passionate advocate for improving the heart health of all in the community. She will be greatly missed. We extend our deepest condolences to her family, Ray, Shannon, Matthew and Jason. Nicholas H. Racanelli, Chairman Gerald R. Marx, MD, President Michael L. Weamer, CAE, Executive Vice President

Amy Adams, who has had a string of Academy Award nominations in recent years for ''The Fighter,'' ''Doubt,'' and ''Junebug,'' got her start performing in dinner theater in the 1990s - but the movies made her famous before theater companies could. This summer, however, Ms. Adams will have a shot at a star turn on stage when she makes her New York debut playing the baker's wife in the musical ''Into the Woods,'' which will run July 23 to Aug. 25 at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, the show's producers at the Public Theater announced on Tuesday. The baker's wife, a central character in a re-imagined fairytale land created by Stephen Sondheim and James Lapine, was played by Joanna Gleason in the original Broadway production in 1987; Ms. Gleason won the Tony Award for best actress in a musical for the performance. Kerry O'Malley played the role in the Broadway revival in 2002.

WILK--Dr. Stephen D.,68, of Old Westbury, passed away on April 2, 2012. He served as a captain in the US Army and in 1969, he joined Dr. Edward Kornbluh's dental practice in Midtown Manhattan where he had a thriving practice for 40 years. Dr. Wilk is survived by Margaret, his loving wife of 26 years; his son Bradley; his daughter Jodie, her husband Andrew Nevas, and their children Chloe and Zachary; his sister Iris Jacobs, and her husband Alan and their two daughters Alison and Courtney. Services Thursday 7pm at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Tpke., Woodbury, LI. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in the memory of Dr. Stephen Wilk to the Veterans of Foreign Wars Foundation.

New York's highest court ruled on Tuesday that a man who had lost his settlement proceeds in Bernard L. Madoff's Ponzi scheme would not get a do-over on his divorce agreement. The unanimous decision from the New York Court of Appeals overturned a lower court ruling that had allowed Steven Simkin, a real estate lawyer at a powerful Manhattan firm, to sue his ex-wife, Laura Blank, also a lawyer, to alter the terms of their divorce pact.

The hard-core fans of Gaelic football were already there by noon on Saturday, hoisting pints and watching Crossmaglen play Garrycastle in the All-Ireland club final on multiple screens at the Irish Pub. ''This game is on network TV in Ireland now, and we're getting the signal on a 90-second delay,'' said Eugene Rooney, 64, who has been an owner of the bar, on West 54th Street in Manhattan, since 1980.

GOLICK--Morrie. Morrie Golick in his 102nd year. As was his wish, he peacefully passed on at home, without pain, surrounded by loved ones. Last surviving brother of Rae Koster, Albert and Nathan Golick. He had unwaivering dedication to family and friends. Treasured by his daughter Susan, her husband Alan Wasserman, "second family" Penny and Steven Goldberg, and loving grandchildren Lauren and Matthew. Adored uncle to Howard, Toby, Roberta, Stephen, Robert and Ann Beth and devoted Great Uncle. Distinguished career: Member of Massachusetts and Illinois Bar; Assistant Naval Attache to American Embassy in Union of South Africa; founded Golick Brothers and later Golick Martins, Inc, confectionary brokers. In 1970, founded SLE Lupus Foundation. He was selflessly philanthropic and had a strong sense of ethics. An avid bridge player, always sharp and with gentle elegance. He will be greatly missed and always loved. Funeral Thursday 11:15, Riverside Memorial, NYC. Contributions may be made in his honor to The SLE Lupus Foundation, 330 Seventh Avenue, New York, NY 10001. www.lupusny.org

April 3, 2012 | Updated The world's only luxury Chinese restaurant chain, Hakkasan, landed in New York on Tuesday, making its long-awaited debut with a $10 million installation on a gritty block just steps from Times Square. And not wasting time to recoup that investment, it offers a few dishes with three-figure prices.

A poll of American Jewish voters shows that they overwhelmingly support Barack Obama for president, just as they did four years ago, and that Israel and Iran rank low on their list of priority issues in the presidential election. The results cast doubt on the claim that Mr. Obama has alienated a significant swath of Jewish voters because of his rocky relationship with Israel's prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu. -

BTG PACTULA PLANS OFFERING The Brazilian investment banking powerhouse BTG Pactual, led by André Esteves, below, said on Tuesday that it was planning to raise as much as $2.24 billion in an I.P.O. BTG Pactual's offering is to be priced at 28.75 to 33.75 reais a share ($15.71 to $18.44), with 90 million units being offered simultaneously in Amsterdam and São Paulo, Brazil, a prospectus said. DAN HORCH DEPARTURE AT JPMORGAN CHASE Ian Hannam, JPMorgan's global chairman of equity capital markets and a top banker at JPMorgan Chase in London, resigned on Tuesday. He left the bank after British financial regulators fined him $721,000 for disclosing inside information, a decision Mr. Hannam said he would appeal. The fine relates to e-mails sent in 2008 to a prospective client that had information on Heritage Oil. MARK SCOTT

A construction worker died on Tuesday in Brooklyn when part of a house collapsed, the authorities said. The man, Santos Garcia, 25, of the Borough Park section, was pronounced dead at Lutheran Medical Center, the police said.

LOBEL--Lili, died peacefully at home on March 31, 2012. She was born in Vienna on March 6, 1920 and came to New York as a refugee in 1940. She was predeceased by her husband John and is lovingly remembered by her sons John and Peter and their wives, grandsons Joseph and Samuel, and companion Raymond. She will be missed.

Whether the Jump-start Our Business Start-ups Act will create jobs or only encourage fraud is open to debate, but one thing is clear: this piece of legislation is a reminder that Congress, both Democrats and Republicans, are completely inept at regulating our financial system. The JOBS Act is an annoyingly named piece of legislation that purports to create jobs partly by seeking to increase the number of initial public offerings. Companies with up to $1 billion in revenue are labeled emerging growth companies and relieved of disclosure and other securities law requirements for their first five years after going public.

5:05 p.m. | Updated President Obama will deliver a special introduction to the first presentation of a restored print of the classic 1962 movie ''To Kill a Mockingbird'' on the USA cable network Saturday night. The inclusion of the president came at the request of the American Film Institute. The institute collaborated with the film's owner, Universal Pictures, on the restoration of the film, which is timed to the 50th anniversary of its release.

The Killers, the Black Keys and Jack White will headline a new music festival in Dover, Del., this summer. The three-day event, the Firefly Music Festival, is scheduled for July 20 to 22 at the Woodlands of Dover International Speedway. Organizers say more than 40 bands and solo artists will play, ranging from the R&B singer John Legend to the indie band Death Cab for Cutie. The rappers Tinie Tempah and Lupe Fiasco are also expected to perform. The festival is being produced by Red Frog Events, a five-year-old Chicago company that has had success promoting extreme foot races under the name Warrior Dash, as well as pub crawls, but has never put together a large music event. Meghan Roman, a spokeswoman for the company, said the vision of the owners -- Joe Reynolds and Ryan Kunkel -- was an open-air festival on the East Coast with plenty of outdoor camping, much like the Bonnaroo music festival in Tennessee. A three-day pass costs $178. Attractions will include an air-conditioned brewery, a wine garden and hot-air balloon rides above the speedway, she said.

(USA) THE INTERPRETER (2005) Nicole Kidman portrays an idealistic United Nations interpreter who believes she has overheard a plot to assassinate a dictator (Earl Cameron). Sean Penn is a federal agent sent to protect her and investigate. ''This kind of movie, stuffed with intimations of faraway strife and people in suits talking frantically on cellphones and walkie-talkies, is conventionally described as a political thriller, but 'The Interpreter' is as apolitical as it is unthrilling,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this film from Sydney Pollack. Still, he said, the United Nations building in Manhattan ''is beautifully shot, both from without and within.''

Those who fear that Nike will turn N.F.L. uniforms into highlighter-hued, reflective-surfaced, overengineered showcases for fashion-forward football apparel have no cause for concern. Yet. Nike unveiled the new uniforms Tuesday at Steiner Studios in Brooklyn, and with the exception of the Seattle Seahawks, every team escaped the event sartorially unscathed.

The state court system put changes in its hiring practices into effect on Tuesday, a day after the State Commission on Judicial Conduct reported that the protocol at an appellate court promoted a culture of nepotism. Beginning immediately, the state's chief administrative judge, A. Gail Prudenti,, said, job openings in the state's four appellate divisions will be publicly advertised. Judge Prudenti also said that applicants for all vacancies will be vetted by hiring panels, court employees will be required to disqualify themselves from the hiring process when relatives apply for jobs, and court employees will not be allowed to supervise relatives or their spouses' relatives.

Exactly a year after the police in China locked him up for 81 days, the artist Ai Weiwei has installed four live webcams in his Beijing home. The cameras, whose feed can be viewed by anyone on a Web site day and night, weiweicam.commake symbolic reference to the 24-hour police surveillance he has been subjected to since his detention, he told Agence France Presse.

When Lehman Brothers collapsed at the height of the financial crisis, JPMorgan Chase was at the center of the storm. The bank was a major lender to the firm, which filed the biggest bankruptcy in United States history. Now, more than three years later, regulators are set to penalize JPMorgan for actions tied to Lehman's demise, according to people briefed on the matter. It will be the first federal enforcement case to stem from Lehman's downfall.

HBO's knights and dragons fantasy series ''Game of Thrones'' took a big leap in the ratings Sunday night as its second season returned with the most-watched scripted show on cable television last week. The series is riding growing word of mouth and is fed by viewers catching up with the drama's first season, as well as readers who have continued to buy, in large numbers, the novels the series is based on. The ''Game of Thrones'' second-season premiere averaged 3.9 million viewers for its first play on Sunday night at 9 p.m.

ALBANY - The Republican presidential campaign is coming to New York. The state Republican Party announced on Wednesday that Rick Santorum and Newt Gingrich, who are struggling to stay afloat in the race, had accepted invitations to the party's annual gala dinner in Midtown Manhattan on April 19. New York's presidential primary will take place the following week, on April 24.

Wall Street is examining whether it will benefit from a little-known section of a broad new law that President Obama is expected to sign on Thursday. Provisions tucked into the so-called JOBS Act, or the Jumpstart Our Business Startups, will roll back some major securities regulations and parts of a landmark legal settlement struck almost a decade ago. That 2003 settlement built a Chinese wall between Wall Street research analysts and investment bankers, an effort to prevent analysts from improperly promoting stocks to help their firms drum up business from corporate clients.

Bill Jenkins, an influential and revered figure in drag racing who helped lift the sport from the streets to the professional track while introducing a host of technical innovations, died on Thursday in Paoli, Pa. He was 81. The cause was heart failure, his daughter Susan Jenkins said.

AUGUSTA, Ga. - The thunderstorms that ripped through the area late Tuesday night returned Wednesday afternoon, suspending the annual Masters Par 3 tournament with a slew of players yet to finish. After a short delay, Padraig Harrington and Jonathan Byrd were declared co-champions of the event with scores of five-under-par 22. Before the extreme weather arrived, there was the typical assortment of charming moments on the 1,060-yard course located just down the road from the practice putting green at Augusta National Golf Club. Several players played with wives or children caddying for them, and fans lined the gallery ropes with yellow flags for players to autograph.

Buyout shops have developed a reputation for taking companies private and then quickly selling them to the public again. But a hedge fund manager is behind the fast flip of Burger King. While the owners of the fast food chain planned to take the company public early next year, William A. Ackman, the founder of the hedge fund Pershing Square Capital Management, persuaded them to move up the timetable. Late Tuesday, Burger King announced that it planned to return to the New York Stock Exchange through a merger with Justice Holdings, a publicly traded shell company.

CHARLESTON, S.C. - In the time since Melanie Oudin's fairy-tale run at the 2009 United States Open, her career has been without a ''happily ever after.'' Since she beat four formidable Russians (Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova, No. 4 Elena Dementieva, No. 29 Maria Sharapova, No. 13 Nadia Petrova) to reach the quarterfinals in New York as a 17-year-old two and a half years ago, Oudin has struggled to beat players outside the top 100. Although improbable and thus far unrepeated, Oudin's United States Open run could hardly be called a fluke because it was preceded by an appearance in the fourth round of Wimbledon two months earlier, a prequel that included a win over Jelena Jankovic, who was ranked No. 6 at the time.

The Mets made their most significant financial commitment to a player in two years Wednesday by agreeing to five-year, $25.5 million contract extension with the left-hander Jon Niese, according to a person in baseball with knowledge of the deal. The agreement includes two team option years, for $10 million and $10.5 million, which could eventually bring the total value of the contract to $46 million. The deal is pending a physical on Friday.

Although he and the guitarist Lester Flatt were co-leaders of the Foggy Mountain Boys at the time, Mr. Scruggs performed with a different group, Hylo Brown and the Timberliners, at that year's festival.

Over the last few decades, a handful of deal makers have reigned over the private equity industry, wielding vast influence over Wall Street and, more broadly, the world economy. Now in their 60s and billionaires several times over, these men - Stephen A. Schwarzman of the Blackstone Group, Henry R. Kravis of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, David M. Rubenstein of the Carlyle Group and Leon D. Black of the Apollo Management Group, chief among them - are surely ready to pass the baton to the next generation.

Ai Weiwei, the rebellious Chinese artist, said on Wednesday that the authorities had shut down a Web site on which he was streaming video from four live surveillance cameras in his home. Mr. Ai, one of the Chinese government's harshest critics, was detained without charge for 81 days last year; he started his camera-surveillance project earlier this week to commemorate the one-year anniversary of the start of his detention. Putting up the cameras was Mr. Ai's way of commenting on the fact that he has been under constant surveillance since he was released from detention. Mr. Ai is not allowed to leave Beijing, and plainclothes security officers are stationed on his street around the clock. A security camera is trained on the main entrance of his studio and home in the Caochangdi district of Beijing. On Wednesday, Mr. Ai said over Twitter that his web camera project had been operating for 46 hours before being shut down. ''Byebye to all the voyeurs,'' Mr. Ai wrote in English on Twitter four hours after the camera Web site, weiweicam.com, ended operations. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

RATTNER--Miriam, nee Weinstock, 89, of Forest Hills and Ocean Beach died unexpectedly on April 3. She leaves behind her devoted children, Judith (Michael Di Bari) and Kenneth (Patricia) and adoring grandchildren Rebecca, Sofia, Casey and Samantha, as well as her sister, Evelyn Virshup and extended family and friends. She was predeceased by her loving husband of 56 years, Nathaniel. A retired New York City elementary school teacher, she was a 30-year-member of Community Planning Board 6 and always involved in civic affairs. Active until the end, she was an avid bridge and scrabble player, crossword aficionado, former tennis player, dedicated reader of the New York Times and lover of the arts. She will be sorely missed. Memorial service is set for April 9th, at 11am at Gutterman's in Rockville Centre.

CATLETT--Elizabeth. The Board of Trustees and staff of The Studio Museum in Harlem salute the life and legacy of Elizabeth Catlett, one of the most exceptional artists of our time. Her incomparable commitment to art, education and activism will influence and inspire generations to come, and she will be deeply missed. Our sincere condolences to her family. Raymond J. McGuire, Chairman Thelma Golden, Director

Ángel Corella, a star principal dancer with American Ballet Theater, has announced that he will retire from the company at the end of its 2012 season at the Metropolitan Opera House. Mr. Corella, whom Alastair Macaulay has described in The Times as ''brilliantly charming,'' will give his farewell performance on June 28 in the role of Prince Siegfried in ''Swan Lake,'' dancing opposite Paloma Herrera. Mr. Corella, 36, was born in Madrid and joined the company as a soloist in 1995. He has danced leading roles throughout his career from the company's stable of story ballet classics, including ''Romeo and Juliet,'' ''Le Corsaire,'' ''La Bayadère,'' ''Don Quixote'' and others. In 2008 Mr. Corella founded the Barcelona Ballet, (previously Corella Ballet Castilla y León) where he is now the artistic director and principal dancer. He will continue to lead and dance with that company. In a statement he said: ''It is difficult to balance being principal dancer with ABT while directing and dancing with my own company. It was not an easy decision but I want to dedicate myself 100 percent to Barcelona Ballet, and I feel now is the time.''

The House Proud column last Thursday, about the Utah home Ivo Zdarsky built out of an airplane hangar, misspelled the name of the car whose engine Mr. Zdarsky used in his own plane. It is the Trabant, not Treblant.

On a Thursday evening in January the David Rubenstein Atrium at Lincoln Center was packed -- many were turned away at the door -- for a rare performance of Kate Bush's music. It was a big deal for fans of that reclusive British art-rock singer. Despite releasing records more or less steadily over the years, Ms. Bush has never performed a concert in the United States. And she hasn't toured anywhere, singing in public only rarely since a one-month string of European shows in 1979.

LEE--Herbert C. The Trustees, National Committee and Staff of the Whitney Museum of American Art express with great sadness the passing of Herbert C. Lee, devoted father of longtime Trustee, Thomas H. Lee and National Committee Chair, Jonathan O. Lee. Together with his wife, the late Mildred Schiff Lee, he was a friend and advocate of the arts. His dedication has forever enriched the arts community and he will be deeply missed. We extend our most heartfelt sympathy to Tom Lee and Ann Tenenbaum, Jon and Barbara Lee, Robert Lee and Elizabeth Berardi and to his many grandchildren and loved ones. Flora Miller Biddle, Honorary Chairman Leonard A. Lauder, Chairman Emeritus Robert J. Hurst, Co-Chair Brooke Garber Neidich, Co-Chair Neil G. Bluhm, President Joanne Leonhart Cassullo, Trustee National Committee Liaison Adam D. Weinberg, Alice Pratt Brown, Director

If you want to make billions of dollars from deal-making, don't head to Wall Street. Government offers the quickest path for riches these days - if you are a deal maker with close ties to those in power in a number of emerging markets.

Like many young scions, Mark Ghermezian joined the family business, an empire started by his grandfather that now includes banks, manufacturing companies and the largest mall in America. He spent two years leading an energy group, managing dozens of oil and gas drilling sites across Texas. But last year, Mr. Ghermezian, 29, traded his plush Houston office and job security for a cramped work space in the meatpacking district of Manhattan and the uncertainty of a fledgling technology venture. Using his connections, he raised $3 million from his family and other investors to start Appboy, a service that helps businesses manage their mobile applications.

8 P.M. (HBO) GOD IS THE BIGGER ELVIS (2011) In 1957, 19-year-old Dolores Hart made her film debut opposite Elvis Presley in ''Loving You.'' She went on to appear in many more movies, including ''Wild in the Wind,'' ''Where the Boys Are,'' ''King Creole'' and ''Come Fly With Me,'' her final film. In 1963 this Hollywood starlet -- then engaged to a handsome architect -- shocked her family, friends and fans by deciding to become a Benedictine nun. ''I never felt I was leaving Hollywood,'' Ms. Hart, now mother prioress of the Abbey of Regina Laudis in Bethlehem, Conn., said of her decision to join the order after spending time on its 400-acre working farm following an exhausting stint on Broadway in ''The Pleasure of His Company.'' ''God was the vehicle, the bigger Elvis,'' she added. Her former fiancé, Don Robinson (above, with Mother Dolores), speaks about his heartbreak and his annual visits to her in this Oscar-nominated documentary short from Rebecca Cammisa, whose own mother was once a nun. 7 P.M. (HBO Signature) LE DIVORCE (2003) Kate Hudson (below, with Romain Duris) plays Isabel Walker, an American who arrives in Paris to visit her pregnant half sister (Naomi Watts), whose marriage to a French artist (Melvil Poupaud) is in shambles. And after a style and sensibility makeover, lust and romance ensue. Writing in The New York Times about this Merchant-Ivory adaptation of Diane Johnson's novel, A. O. Scott said that despite a cast of very fine actors -- among them, Stephen Fry, Sam Waterston, Stockard Channing, Glenn Close, Leslie Caron and Thierry Lhermitte -- the film ''is pretty weak tea, a thin and unsatisfying concoction that somehow manages to make one of the richest and most durable sources of culture-clash comedy into an occasion for dullness.'' He added, ''What's French for annulment?''

As tablets become more ubiquitous, toy companies are seeking ways to keep the tradition of family game night alive by combining physical board games with digital apps. Discovery Bay Games, a maker of games and puzzles as well as a few iPad apps and accessories, has created an analog iPad add-on called Duo Pop, which sells for about $40 at Apple, Target and Amazon.com.

If you are shopping for a device to stream the Internet to your TV, and If you believe in the wisdom of crowds, your choice is pretty simple. FixYa, a site best described as volunteer technical assistance, combed through more than 23,000 support requests for the most popular streaming-TV devices, Apple TV, Google TV, Boxee and Roku, and gleaned some recommendations.

GOLICK--Morrie. The Board of Directors and staff of the S.L.E. Lupus Foundation and the lupus patient and scientific communities across the nation mourn the death of our Foundation's beloved founder Morrie Golick (1910-2012) at the age of nearly 102. Born of a father's love, the S.L.E. Lupus Foundation was forged by his devotion to his daughter Susan and his determination to find answers when she was diagnosed at 24 with the devastating autoimmune disease lupus. Celebrating the Foundation's 40th anniversary and his 100th birthday in 2010, Morrie reflected, "I wanted to find a way others could benefit from our family's difficult experience with lupus." Morrie Golick made the difference for lupus patients, families, researchers and physicians, launching the lupus movement in New York City and leading its evolution across America. He and Susan worked tirelessly to create much-needed patient services, awareness and advocacy, while always supporting lupus research. Their leadership in nurturing promising scientists and building the laboratories of New York helped their city become the world's foremost center for lupus care and research. Convinced that a cure is within reach, Morrie worked to create the Lupus Research Institute in 2000, now the world's leading supporter of innovative research in lupus. Because of that steadfast conviction, Morrie saw many pivotal scientific discoveries, including the first lupus treatment in 50 years, come to fruition during his lifetime. Morrie Golick has given us a lasting legacy - generosity of spirit, a loving heart that went out to all who struggle with this disease every day, and the unflagging determination to pursue a cure for lupus. We honor and remember Morrie with love and will miss him very much.

IN this print-happy season, odds are that a novel pattern rather than, say, an on-trend floral will still look appealing a year from now. This desert-hue print from Gretchen Jones, the fairly innocuous ''Project Runway'' winner from Season 8, mashes up a medley of inspirations: Patti Smith's ''Horses'' album; Castaneda's ''Teachings of Don Juan: A Yaqui Way of Knowledge''; and Buckminster Fuller's geodesic dome. ''The result was this kaleidoscopic horse stampede,'' Ms. Jones said. However she got there, the print is eye-catching, and this silk shirt or skirt, worn with denim, would put a new spin on country chic. Gretchen Jones silk shirt, $365, and skirt, $375, at Condor, 259 Elizabeth Street; (212) 966-4280; shopcondor.com.

AUGUSTA, Ga. -- The mysteries that make Augusta National hard for the uninitiated golfer to solve are less puzzling when the greens are spongy from rain, as they were in this week's practice rounds. ''As soft as the golf course is, you can fire at a lot of the pins,'' Phil Mickelson, a three-time champion, said. ''The greens are soft. I don't want to say they are slow, but it's just not the same Augusta. It's wet around the greens, and there's no fear of the course. You've got to attack it this week. Unless something changes, and I know they have SubAir and hopefully they will be able to use it, but unless they change it, it's going to be a birdie-fest.''

ADELSON--Dr. Richard, 56, a former long term Orangeburg resident succumbed Tuesday, April 3rd 2012 to ALS after a long illness. Dr. Adelson, a graduate of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine and Fellow of the American College of Cardiologists was honored by the Orangetown Jewish Center which named the Dr. Richard and Jana Adelson Campus after him and his wife Jana. Born in New York, Dr. Adelson resided in Allenhurst, NJ. Dr. Adelson was a 1978 honors graduate of the State University of New York at Binghamton and received his Medical Degree from Albert Einstein College of Medicine, NY in 1978. He completed his Medical Internship and Residency at Montefiore Hospital in 1986. His Cardiology Fellowship was completed at Montefiore Hospital in 1988 and his Fellowship in Cardiac Catheterization was completed at Loma Linda University Medical Center in California in 1989. Dr. Adelson founded Shore Heart Group, PA in 1993 and presided as the Medical Director and Managing Partner until he retired in 2007. Shore Heart Group is a comprehensive, multi-location cardiology practice with eleven physicians. Dr. Adelson is survived by his wife, Jana, sons, Daniel, Roger and Gordon, his parents Fred and Bertha and their sons Howard and Mark.

SEATTLE -- In early March, Boeing's biggest jet, the 747-8 Intercontinental, took off from Paine Field near here, its gleaming white livery shrouded in secrecy. But the newest version of the airliner, which can carry 460 passengers, was not destined for a commercial airline. This particular model, the 747-V.I.P., was headed for a private customer in the Middle East believed to be the emir of Qatar.

POWELL--Claire Lewis. September 18, 1927, died April 3, 2012. She was beloved wife of George, mother to Charles, Susan, and Ellen and beloved grandmother. Services 11am Thursday Hellmann Memorial Chapels, Spring Valley, NY.

LUNZER--Francis George. Died peacefully at home on Monday, April 2, 2012, succumbing to lung cancer. Francis was born September 16, 1938 in Paris, France. He lived in Neuilly initially and then in Manhattan for the rest of his life. He was the son of the late Frederic and Julia Goldschmidt Lunzer of Vienna, both noted artists who regarded their brilliant son as the most talented of their family of three. He is survived by the love of his life, his wife of 27 years, Lynn Torgerson of Manhattan. He also leaves behind his dearly beloved cats, Buddy and Slinky. Francis was impeccably educated formally at Horace Mann Prep School followed by Columbia College, but was an autodidact of astonishing scope. His musical ability, both as a drummer from which he made a living, and the piano was innate. He was supremely musical, possessing a keen ear and solid sense of rhythm. He was deeply erudite on a broad range of subjects with deep wells of knowledge of jazz, automobiles, fine art, literature, superior cuisine, in addition to being a scholar of the Second World War and the Holocaust. He amassed an immense and rare group of collections of African art, books, classic scale model cars, and all manner of notable objets d'art. His collection of true friends was equally as impressive. Francis was a polymath of the highest order. One's initial impression upon meeting Francis was the realization that one was in the presence of a man of fierce wit and an easy, wicked sense of humor. He was fully engaged with his life, savoring every moment. His memory will live long in the hearts of all who knew and loved him. A service will be held on Friday, April 6, 2012 at 1:30pm at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, corner of 91st Street. Downtown reception to follow.
COLE--Charles J. - Happy Birthday Dad. Missing you as much today as 19 years ago. Love, Abbie and Brad

The thing that's missing from paper shredders? Celebrity endorsements. Take Fellowes's new 79Ci shredder, which costs $240. For starters, Fellowes could get guitar heroes like Eddie Van Halen or Yngwie Malmsteen to vouch for its superior shredding ability. The 79Ci is also, Fellowes claims, jam proof. Well, I'd like to see Paul Weller or Jimmy Jam put that to the test. Advertising aside, Fellowes's newest consumer model does address some practical issues. Start with that jam-proof technology: What the 79Ci does is try to head off a jam before it happens. It accomplishes this by measuring how much paper is being inserted before it cranks up its jaws of death. If you try to pull a Full Enron (that's shredder-speak for overloading the machine), a green-to-yellow-to-red indicator will tell you if you've exceeded the shredder's capacity, requiring you to reload in more moderate amounts.

Thanks to integration with Microsoft's Messenger program, Windows Live Hotmail users just need to link their Windows Live profiles to Facebook to chat with online friends right from the mail window. To connect the two services, log into Hotmail, and under your name on the right side of the screen, click on the Profile link. On the Profile screen, click Connect on the left side of the window. On the Connect screen, select Facebook, choose the settings you want to use and click the ''Connect with Facebook'' button. If you are not already logged into Facebook, you will be prompted to enter your name and password. Hotmail users can also connect their accounts to profiles on LinkedIn, YouTube, Blogger Flickr, Pandora and other social media sites.

Regardless of who wins the 2012 presidential election, billionaires will come out on top. This campaign cycle, the richest Americans, a disparate group that crosses party lines and spans political beliefs, are using their wealth to support a wide cast of presidential contenders. Their growing influence has coincided with the rise of the so-called super PACs, fund-raising efforts that are aligned with specific candidates but shielded from the traditional donation limits.

The question seems to arise time and again: why would the rich jeopardize their wealth by committing an illegal act like insider trading? Some of the most prominent cases of illegal insider dealings have involved very wealthy people who made very little in profit from such trades when compared with their overall net worth.

Rometty, as it did her four male predecessors.

GOLICK--Morrie. Morrie Golick in his 102nd year. As was his wish, he peacefully passed on at home, without pain, surrounded by loved ones. Last surviving brother of Rae Koster, Albert and Nathan Golick. He had unwaivering dedication to family and friends. Treasured by his daughter Susan, her husband Alan Wasserman, "second family" Penny and Steven Goldberg, and loving grandchildren Lauren and Matthew. Adored uncle to Howard, Toby, Roberta, Stephen, Robert and Ann Beth and devoted Great Uncle. Distinguished career: Member of Massachusetts and Illinois Bar; Assistant Naval Attache to American Embassy in Union of South Africa; founded Golick Brothers and later Golick Martins, Inc, confectionary brokers. In 1970, founded SLE Lupus Foundation. He was selflessly philanthropic and had a strong sense of ethics. An avid bridge player, always sharp and with gentle elegance. He will be greatly missed and always loved. Funeral Thursday 11:15, Riverside Memorial, NYC. Contributions may be made in his honor to The SLE Lupus Foundation, 330 Seventh Avenue, New York, NY 10001. www.lupusny.org
