Tribune Broadcasting and DirecTV announced an agreement Wednesday night to end a dispute over retransmission fees, returning programming to subscribers after a blackout that began early Sunday. The deal will allow DirecTV, the second-largest TV distributor in the United States, to continue carrying local Tribune stations and WGN America for the next five years, DirecTV said in a statement. The financial terms of the agreement were not disclosed.

3:04 p.m. | Updated The German novelist and Nobel laureate Günter Grass has come under intense criticism after publishing a poem saying that Israel, not Iran, was the Mideast's greatest threat to world peace, Der Spiegel Online reported on Wednesday.

THERE'S an easy way to make things expensive: slap some diamonds on them or slather them with platinum. But such items often betray the owner to be gauche, an arriviste or, to use a term more suited to our technophilic times, a newbie. Better to announce your Croesus-like wealth quietly. A low-key camera with an ultra-lightweight body. A bespoke briefcase. A pair of headphones not from a multi-acre plant in Shenzen, but from a Brooklyn workshop. The products below say big money with subtle clues obvious only to those in the know.

WINNIE BEATTIE and Rob Magnotta, a couple who met in the surf, have realized their urban-hippie passion for travel and family with a beachy new boutique in NoLIta. At Warm, customers can walk out with pastel shorts and pretty white lace dresses from the French label Roseanna, '70s surf-inspired sweats from Aviator Nation, print boho dresses by Yvonne Sporre or dangling feather earrings from the model-turned-designer Manon von Gerkan. There are also Locals flip-flops from Hawaii, children's clothes and art books chosen by Mr. Magnotta, a photography agent. ''Everything was done in the spirit of holiday,'' said Ms. Beattie, above. Everything will also look good with sand between your toes. Warm, 181 Mott Street; (212) 925-1200; warmny.com.

An article on Tuesday about the Dutch government's plan to restrict the sale of marijuana to residents of the Netherlands misstated the number of seats in the lower house of Parliament that are held by People's Party for Freedom and Democracy and the Christian Democrats, along with their ally, the Freedom Party. It is 75 of the 150 seats -- not 83, which includes three smaller parties.

-There may be no bigger New York Mets fan than Miriam Stone, and she has never even seen them play. ''For me, hearing is what seeing is,'' said Ms. Stone, 60, on Wednesday, as she sat on her bed in her small studio apartment in Forest Hills, Queens, listening to the WFAN radio broadcast of the Mets-Yankees preseason game from Florida. ''You've got to be able to hear everything going.''

President Obama on Wednesday signed an ethics bill that bans insider trading by members of Congress and requires thousands of federal employees to disclose information about their personal finances. The signing came 10 weeks after Mr. Obama called for such legislation in his State of the Union address.

An article on the Itineraries pages on Tuesday, about a campaign to promote foreign tourism in the United States, erroneously attributed a distinction to the effort. The marketing project is the first undertaken under the Travel Promotion Act, enacted in 2010, but it is not the nation's ''first coordinated effort to market itself overseas.'' (The United States Travel and Tourism Administration, a Commerce Department agency, did similar marketing work until it was eliminated in 1996.)

Bobby Valentine will not leave New York behind, nearly 10 years after the Mets fired him as their manager. Although he is now the Boston Red Sox' manager, he will appear weekly in New York on ESPN Radio, giving him a platform to tease the Yankees or, perhaps, his former team. Dave Roberts, the station's general manager said, ''Any opportunity we have to serve fans with dynamic personalities who are willing to speak their mind and not provide the type of typical say-nothing sound bites is simply a benefit.'' He added: ''People do not tune into personalities who don't evoke an emotion. He is a distinctive, unique personality in one of the most high-profile managerial jobs in baseball.''

Some recent back-and-forths between the Obama and Romney camps regarding the House Republican budget plan and other fiscal issues: ''If Mitt Romney is the nominee, then this really is going to be the Romney-Ryan plan ... So the American people have to understand, if Mitt Romney's elected president, he'll rubber-stamp that budget ... It showers huge additional tax cuts on the wealthy ... that are paid for by veterans and seniors and the middle class, so it's not a balanced approach.'' -- David Plouffe, senior White House adviser, of Paul D. Ryan's proposed budget plan, March 25

The Showtime counterterrorism drama ''Homeland,'' the Comedy Central satire ''The Colbert Report'' and the cable news channels CNN and Al Jazeera English were among the recipients of George Foster Peabody Awards on Wednesday. The awards, presented by the University of Georgia's Grady College of journalism and mass communication, are considered to be the most prestigious of their kind in electronic media. HBO picked up three: one each for ''Game of Thrones,'' ''Treme'' and a documentary it showed about Rwanda, ''Earth Made of Glass.'' Its rival Showtime picked up two, one for ''Homeland'' and another for a documentary it ran about survivors of 9/11 called ''Rebirth.'' CNN also won three awards, for its worldwide coverage of the Arab Spring, commentary by the weekend host Fareed Zakaria, and its annual awards telecast, ''CNN Heroes.''

William K. Marimow, who served as the top editor at The Philadelphia Inquirer from 2006-10, will rejoin the paper in the same role, the company said on Wednesday. His appointment, effective May 1, comes two days after the Philadelphia Media Network, publisher of The Inquirer, The Daily News and Philly.com, was sold to a group of local investors.

An article on March 28 about the requirement that most Massachusetts residents have health insurance gave an incomplete account of the options that Wayde Lodor, an independent consultant from Leominster, had for buying health coverage. While Mr. Lodor, after researching several plans, estimated he would have to spend at least $1,200 a month to insure himself and his daughter, he could in fact have bought coverage through the state's insurance exchange for significantly less.

An article on Wednesday about a move to recommend that doctors curb the use of 45 common and often unnecessary medical tests and procedures misidentified the organization that was issuing the advisory. It is the American Board of Internal Medicine Foundation, an organization that promotes physician professionalism -- not the American Board of Internal Medicine, the specialty board with which it is affiliated.

An article on Monday about Washington State's enacting a law that targets escort advertising misstated the American Civil Liberties Union's stance on the bill. The group took no position; it did not join some newspaper groups in supporting the bill. (The A.C.L.U. did work to ensure that the bill did not infringe on civil liberties.) The article also misspelled the surname of the general counsel for Village Voice Media Holdings. She is Elizabeth L. McDougall, not McDougal.

An article last Thursday about the re-emergence of Augusta National Golf Club's men-only membership as an issue misidentified the organization Martha Burk headed when she tried to pressure the club to admit women in 2003. She was chairwoman of the National Council of Women's Organizations, not the National Organization for Women.

This week on the pop charts, new albums by Madonna and Lionel Richie are hits, and a newfangled chart rule keeps Justin Bieber's new single from reaching No. 1. Madonna's latest, ''MDNA'' (Interscope) sold 359,000 copies in its first week out, according to Nielsen SoundScan, sending her to No. 1 for the eighth time -- among female performers, that puts Madonna second only to Barbra Streisand, who has had nine No. 1's. Madonna benefited from early promotion by performing at the Super Bowl halftime show, but her numbers this week were also helped by a promotion bundling the album with sales of Madonna's concert tickets.

Representative Timothy V. Johnson of Illinois will not continue his re-election bid, despite winning the Republican Party nomination in a primary last month. Mr. Johnson, a six-term congressman who was running in Illinois's newly drawn 13th District, made the surprise announcement at a news conference on Thursday that he would instead retire at the end of his current term.

AUGUSTA, Ga. - At 7:40 a.m. Thursday, golf's Big Three - Jack Nicklaus, Arnold Palmer and Gary Player - teed off together for the first time as honorary starters at the Masters. All three of their drives found the center of the fairway, although they had to take everyone else's word for it. ''I don't think any of us can see that far,'' Nicklaus said with a laugh at a press conference afterward. ''We can hear them all land, though.''

A caption on Thursday with one of several pictures showing ultraexpensive versions of some common business items misspelled the title held by Princess Margaret, mother of David Linley, a furniture maker whose custom desks retail for around $100,000. She was the Countess of Snowdon, not Snowden.

Tossing a gauntlet as he delivered an Easter sermon in 1841 to the people of New York, Charles Auguste Marie Joseph, the bishop of Nancy and Toul in France, demanded: ''In this great city, where the Irish and German Catholics have recoiled from no sacrifice to have their own churches and priests, how is it that the French, so famous for the faith of their fathers, alone remain indifferent?'' he asked. ''How, in fact, can this nationality be long preserved in a foreign land without the powerful bond of religion?''

AUGUSTA, Ga. - As clusters of fans waited to cross Berckmans Road on their way to the main entrance at August National Thursday morning, they could not avoid hearing the booming shouts of Larry Craft, a middle-aged man wearing a bright orange shirt with bubbles on it that proclaimed things like ''You need Jesus'' and ''Trust Jesus.'' Craft, who was also holding a large billboard with similar messages, preached loudly as one of his daughters offered pamphlets to the passerby. Every few moments, Craft's audience changed as the officers directing traffic allowed the fans to cross the street.

It is two, not one. The error was repeated in an accompanying picture caption.

AUGUSTA, Ga. - For a moment, early on Thursday, Randal Lewis was on the Masters leader board. Lewis, a 54-year-old amateur from Alma, Mich., who is believed to be the oldest Masters rookie in tournament history, was in the second group to tee off, so when he made par on No. 1 his name went among the leaders. Unfortunately for Lewis, it did not last. Lewis, who won the United States Mid-Amateur Championship to earn his spot, struggled with his driving all day and shot 81.

Sotheby's asked a federal judge in Manhattan on Thursday to bar the government from seizing a 1,000-year-old Cambodian statue that Sotheby's sought to auction last year for as much as $3 million. -Federal prosecutors and the Cambodian government say the statue was stolen from a Cambodian temple and should be returned to Cambodia. But a lawyer for Sotheby's, Peter G. Neiman, said in court papers that the company's bid to sell the antiquity on behalf of an anonymous Belgian collector was legal under its interpretation of American and Cambodian cultural property laws.

The Books of The Times review on Wednesday, about ''Dreaming in French: The Paris Years of Jacqueline Bouvier Kennedy, Susan Sontag, and Angela Davis,'' by Alice Kaplan, misstated the name of the newspaper in which Ms. Davis sought information after the Birmingham church bombings in 1963. At that time, it was The Paris Herald Tribune -- not The International Herald Tribune, the name it began operating under in May 1967. (The paper has been owned by The New York Times since 2003.)

RICH--Katherine Russell, age 56 of New York on April 3, 2012. Katherine was a graduate of Syracuse University and she was the author of two novels. Survived by her brother Stuart P. Rich, Jr. (Nancy) and her sister Lucy Harrison (Leonard Lollis). Relatives and friends are invited to her Visitation Tuesday 10-10:45am followed by her Funeral Service 11am at St. David Church, 763 South Valley Forge Road Wayne, PA 19087. Interment St. David Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory to the American Cancer Society 1626 Locust St. Philadelphia, PA 19103 would be appreciated. www.danjolell.com

GODWIN--Howard Gibson, Jr. Howard Gibson Godwin, Jr., a respected partner of Sidley Austin LLP and a highly valued leader of the firm's securities practice, passed away on April 1 at his home in Tarrytown, NY. He was 67. Mr. Godwin joined the firm, then named Brown & Wood, in 1969 after graduating from Duke University Law School. He became a partner in 1978 and served as senior counsel from 2011 until his untimely passing. Mr. Godwin specialized in the representation of issuers and underwriters of securities, with an emphasis on transactions involving companies in the energy and real estate industries, particularly real estate investment trusts. Mr. Godwin is survived by his wife of 42 years, Mimi McDonough Godwin, children Elizabeth Godwin and Anne Godwin Cauthren, his son-in-law, Benjamin Cauthren, and his sister, Virginia Anne Godwin Carboy. He was predeceased by his son, William Godwin. He was warmly regarded at Sidley for his gentlemanly demeanor and genial personality, and greatly admired for his dedication and talent. Mr. Godwin shared freely his impressive knowledge of the law with both clients and colleagues. Our firm and the many lawyers he helped to train have greatly benefited from the example he set. We will miss his friendship, integrity and humanity, and we extend our condolences to his family. With deepest sympathies, his colleagues at Sidley Austin LLP.

KAPLAN--Cynthia. The Center for Modern Psychoanalytic Studies' Board of Trustees, administration, faculty, alumnae, and students mourn the passing of Cynthia Kaplan, devoted wife of Phil Kaplan, mother to Andrew, Libby, Robin, Troy, Mark and Andrea, and grandmother to many. To them, we extend our deepest sympathies. May the love and experiences you shared comfort you during this difficult time. Cynthia was an extraordinary woman, dedicated to her family, loyal to her friends, and committed to the principle of knowing oneself. She will be missed.

PAROLE IS DENIED FOR KOZLOWSKI L. Dennis Kozlowski, below, the former chief executive of the conglomerate Tyco International, was denied early release from prison this week by a New York State parole board. The decision by the three-member parole board will keep Mr. Kozlowski behind bars for now. He will next be eligible for early release in September of next year, according to the New York State depatment of corrections. MICHAEL J. de la MERCEDTALKS OVER MF GLOBAL FUNDS JPMorgan Chase is talking with the authorities about turning over customer money that disappeared from MF Global when the firm went bankrupt last year. The discussions, announced this week by the trustee assigned to return money to MF Global customers, suggest that a substantial sum of client funds is still sitting at JPMorgan. The trustee's announcement came after an investigation of JPMorgan ''in connection with MF Global.'' BEN PROTESSTHEME PARK BATTLE Apollo Global Management may find itself once again in a battle to acquire an amusement park company, according to the Deal Professor. On Wednesday, Great Wolf Resorts, the lodging and water park operator, announced that KSL Capital Partners had submitted a proposal to acquire Great Wolf for $6.25 a share in cash. The question now is whether Apollo will lose out on a coveted deal one more time. STEVEN M. DAVID OF FANTITRUST APPOINTMENT Joseph F. Wayland was appointed as the acting head of the antitrust division of the Justice Department on Thursday. Mr. Wayland, 55, will serve as the government's top antitrust lawyer while the White House awaits Senate approval of William J. Baer, of Arnold & Porter, to head the unit. ''Joe's leadership and litigation expertise has made him a significant asset to the antitrust division and to the department,'' Eric H. Holder Jr., the United States attorney general, said in a statement. PETER LATTMAN dealbook/nytimes.com

The Metropolitan Museum announced its 2012-13 season of concerts, lectures and other presentations on Thursday, the first entirely programmed by Limor Tomer, who became concerts and lectures general manager last July. Renamed Met Museum Presents, the series reflects a heightened emphasis on programs tied to Met exhibitions and collections. The season opens with a Patti Smith salute to Andy Warhol, to coincide with the exhibition ''Regarding Warhol: Fifty Artists, Fifty Years.'' Tan Dun's 70-minute condensation of Tang Xianzu's classic 19-hour opera, ''The Peony Pavilion,'' conceived for presentation in a garden in Shanghai, will be staged in the Astor Court in connection with an exhibition of Chinese garden imagery in painting and the decorative arts. The Salomé Chamber Orchestra will play concerts on instruments from the Sau Wing Lam Collection of rare instruments, also on display. The Endellion String Quartet will perform Beethoven's 16 string quartets over two weekends as curators discuss Beethoven's role in the dawning of Romanticism.
MANSON--Bunny. A treasured friend, whose gentleness, caring and loyalty truly touched our lives. Our heartfelt sympathy to Barry and the family. Rina and Edward Gladstone

A super-fly lineup is taking shape for the 70th-birthday tribute to Curtis Mayfield at the Lincoln Center Festival this summer. So far Lincoln Center has signed up Kyp Malone and Tunde Adebimpe of TV on the Radio; the gospel and soul star Mavis Staples; Dr. Lonnie Smith, the jazz organist; and the young rapper and singer Aloe Blacc. They -- and others to be announced, Lincoln Center said -- will perform with the current version of the Impressions, Mayfield's classic vocal group of the 1960s, and a 14-piece band under the direction of the Dap-Kings guitarist Binky Griptite. (The current Impressions include Sam Gooden, who has been with the group since 1958; Fred Cash, a member since 1960; and Reggie Torian, who joined in 1973.) Mayfield died in 1999 at age 57.

TEAMKIN--Rosalind "nee Labenbaum." 78 years old, died on April 5, 2012. Beloved wife of the late Jerome. Devoted mother of Stephen, Kevin (Patti) and Jeffrey Teamkin. Cherished grandmother of Rachel, Hayley, Joshua and Nicolas. Loving daughter of the late Benjamin and Molly Labenbaum. Services 10am Friday at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

Déjà vu, anyone? A sixth performer from the Broadway musical ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark'' is said to have been injured during the show's run last winter - and he has become the first to take legal action against the ''Spider-Man'' producers. The stuntman, Richard Kobak, who played Spider-Man in some of the musical's flying sequences, says that he sustained two herniated discs, a concussion, whiplash and holes in both knees as a result of errors by crew members in charge of programming the aerial rigging computer.

HELD--Dirk tom Dieck, Of Westerly RI, was the Elizabeth S. Kruidenier '48 Professor of Classics at Connecticut College in New London, CT. He took his A.B. and Ph.D in Classics at Brown University. In 1971, he joined the faculty of Connecticut College, where he served until his death from a cerebral hemorrhage on March 19, 2012. He held the Chair of the Classics Department for thirty-two years. Professor Held presented and/or published over one hundred learned papers on a wide variety of topics. He was widely known and respected for the quality of his scholarship and his dedication to the field. Colleague Robert Proctor, Professor of Italian, remarked, "Dirk Held lived the liberal arts ideal. His scholarship was both profound and wide-ranging, from Plato's understanding of love to Nietzsche and the reception of classical antiquity in the modern world. He was a modern exemplar of ancient Roman humanitas: culture, kindness, generosity, and wit." In 2007 he was awarded the Helen B. Regan Faculty Leadership Award. He was a superb teacher whose students often became his lifelong friends. Dirk was secretary and presiding officer of the Ariston Club, a society of prominent professionals founded in 1900 to foster literary culture in the New London area, where he was his black tie, witty, raconteur best. Born on March 24, 1939, he was the son of the late Oskar Edouard Held and Ethel Crofton Hunt. He grew up in Rumson, NJ. He is survived by his wife of 50 years, Elizabeth Candace Allen; daughters Elizabeth Jensen and Kristin Held; grandsons Nicholas Thomson and Martin Jensen; and his brother Robert Crofton Held. He was descended from Pierre S. DuPont and was buried in the family cemetery, DuPont de Nemours, in Wilmington, DE. A Memorial Service will be held in Harkness Chapel, Connecticut College, on Friday, April 27th at 4pm, followed by a reception.

THE scene of the crime, Riverside Park at the foot of West 115th Street, is in full spring bloom, carpeted in the butter-colored flowers of lesser celandine. It was here 68 years ago, on a slope descending to the moonlit Hudson River, that Lucien Carr, 19, the Beat Generation's charismatic, callow swami, buried a knife in the heart of David Kammerer, 33, his besotted, dauntless hometown stalker. Carr is often characterized as muse to the Beats, but he was more than that. Jack Kerouac and Allen Ginsberg were acolytes, captivated by Carr's profane rants about bourgeois culture and the path to transcendence through pure creative expression -- his ''New Vision,'' after ''A Vision'' by Yeats.
ROSENFELD--Anne. Mom, another year without you. So much to share. Love, Debbie and Alison

Google said on Thursday it would abolish a program through which independent bookstores have been selling e-books, a blow to small booksellers that have benefited from the large and recognizable platform Google provides. In a blog post, Scott Dougall, Google's director for product management for digital publishing, said that the so-called reseller program, which allowed bookstores to offer e-books for sale through their Web sites, was not a success.
GOLD--Sidney. April 6, 1972. Dad, you are always in our hearts and thoughts. Your loving daughter & family.

The biggest theater in the new Pershing Square Signature Center has a name: It will be called the Irene Diamond Stage, thanks to a $10 million donation from a fund created by Mrs. Diamond, a philanthropist who died in 2003. Signature Theater Company on Thursday announced the gift from the Irene Diamond Fund, one of the largest yet to the new three-theater center on West 42nd Street. The 299-seat house, where ''Edward Albee's The Lady from Dubuque'' is playing, had been called the End Stage. The other two theaters in the center are named after the playwright Romulus Linney and the educator Alice Griffin.

''The Hunter,'' filmed in Tasmania, has the faintly surreal look peculiar to Australian movies in which nature pulses with a mysterious, primordial shimmer. Adapted from Julia Leigh's novel and directed by Daniel Nettheim from a screenplay by Alice Addison, the film tells the story of a lone hunter from another continent searching for a creature that may not exist in an old-growth forest largely untouched by humans. There are moments, as the hunter wanders through the wilderness, when you wonder if a dinosaur might appear.

MAYER--Helen Waren, 96, on April 4, 2012. Her first passion was the theatre. She was a member of Clifford Odets' Theatre Union and had five featured roles on Broadway. During WWII she served in the USO and became a member of the Jewish underground. She dedicated the next 10 years to the establishment of the State of Israel. Later, as a consummate New Yorker, Helen served as President of Lincoln Square Community Center, founded and directed The Double Image Theatre and the Seasoned Citizens Theatre Workshop. Her life was dedicated to shattering stereotypes, serving her community and breaking down social barriers. Cherished wife of the late Jules Mayer, survived by her brother Stanley Waren, her son Max Mayer and granddaughter Jude Mayer. Service Sunday, 4pm at "The Riverside", 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

ROWE--Fanny B.,on April 4, 2012. Beloved mother of Charles (Phyllis) Rowe and Toby (Patrick) Rewick. Loving grandmother of Katherine, Kevin, Jacob, Patricia, and Gary Rewick. Great-grandmother of Jenna, Elizabeth, and Kaylei. Memorial Service, Sunday April 8 at 1pm at Horne-Dannecker Funeral Home, 445 W. 43rd Street, New York City. A great mother, grandmother and friend.

Because of Holy Thursday, Good Friday and Passover, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City through Sunday. Other regulations will remain in effect. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

An article last Friday about the decision of the Berkeley police chief, Michael Meehan, to send a sergeant to the house of an Oakland Tribune reporter in the middle of the night to press for changes to an article about Chief Meehan's department's response to a crime misstated the year that Mayor Tom Bates pleaded guilty and paid a fine for stealing copies of The Daily Californian, as well as his status at the time. He pleaded guilty in 2003, not 2002, which was after he had been elected mayor, not when he was running for re-election.

An article on Tuesday about the effects of clothing on cognitive processes misstated the name of the journal that published a recent study showing that wearing a doctor's white coat led subjects to pay sharper attention. It is The Journal of Experimental Social Psychology, not The Journal of Experimental Social Cognition. The article also described the findings of an earlier study incorrectly. In that experiment, people who held a hot drink in their hands rated others personally warmer; it is not the case that people were rated personally warmer if they held a hot drink.

KUNSTLER--Lotte Rosenberger, March 27, 1925 - April 5, 2012. Extraordinarily wonderful mother of Karin (Neal) and Jane (George), sister of Ernst (Judith), grandmother of Daniel and Pristine, Jessica and Michael, Andrew and Christopher, great grandmother of Rose, Hannah, Jesse and Sadie, aunt of Stephanie, Carol, Susan, John and Annie, stepmother of Robby, best friend of Joan, horticulturalist, champion of the underdog, good friend, role model and mentor to many. In lieu of flowers, please make a contribution to Visiting Nurses of New York City Hospice and Palliative Care Program - VNSNY.org. Memorial service Sunday, April 15, 2012, 12:30pm (Not this Sunday) at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., Manhattan. Following the service there will a reception nearby.

GUTTENBERG--Elliott, on April 5, 2012. Beloved husband of Sondra, loving father of Jonathan and Randi Guttenberg, Jane Guttenberg and Max Kozower. Dear brother of Fran Collier. Cherished grandfather of Katie, Maddy, Hannah and Ethan. Services today, 11:30am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

GUTTENBERG--Elliott. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of our devoted member Elliott Guttenberg beloved husband of Sandra. Deepest sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Herman Hochberg, President

CYBUL--David Nathan, age 87, of Fort Lee formerly of Tarrytown, NY, on April 4, 2012. He was born in Israel and came to the United States in 1929, where he was an Architect and Structural Engineer for Cybul, Cybul and Wilhelm, Edgewater. Beloved husband of Norma nee; Trugerman. Devoted father of Laurie Edelstein and her husband Jeffrey, Martin Cybul and his wife Miriam. Cherished grandfather of Brandt, Mathew, Katie and Brett. Dear sister of Edith Whitman and George Cybul. Chapel Service Friday in Eden Memorial Chapels, Inc. at 10:45am. For information www.edenmemorial.com or call (201) 947-EDEN.

POWELL--Claire Lewis. September 18, 1927, died April 3, 2012. She was beloved wife of George, mother to Charles, Susan, and Ellen and beloved grandmother. Services 11am Thursday Hellmann Memorial Chapels, Spring Valley, NY.

A federal appeals court on Thursday reversed a lower court's decision to throw out a $1 billion lawsuit filed against YouTube by Viacom and other media companies five years ago. The copyright infringement suit, which has become a symbol of the clash between entrenched media companies and the upstarts that compete with them, sought damages for unauthorized video clips from shows like ''The Daily Show With Jon Stewart'' that had been uploaded by users to YouTube.

MANSON--Beverly Beverly (Bunny) Manson. She lost her four year battle with breast cancer on April 5, 2012 at the age of 71. Survived by her beloved husband Barry of 47 years, cherished mother and mother-in-law of Sheri and Brian Callahan and Adam Manson, loving grandmother of twins Sarah and Grant, dear sister and sister-in-law of Donna and Stewart Senter and Laura and David Loventhal, adored aunt of five. A 30 year resident of Old Westbury, NY. She earned a bachelors degree in speech therapy from Adelphi University and a master's degree from New York University. She was a founding member of Partners Council for Women's Health and an officer of ABM Management, a real property management co. She left behind many broken hearts and her warmth touched everyone she met. Services Friday, April 6, 10am at the Old Westbury Hebrew Congregation, 21 Old Westbury Road, Old Westbury, NY 11568. 516-333-7977. www.owhcong.org

BORN--Esther. It is with a deep sense of sorrow that we send our condolences to the family of Esther Born. Our families have been together for more than 50 years through both joy and sorrow. Esther was a woman that was loved by everyone who came into her presence. She always had a kind word or a warm smile available. We will miss her greatly. May her family be comforted by their memories of her. Our hearts go out to Rita and Fred, Debbie and Richard, Harry and Barbara and their children and grandchildren. Gale and Ira Drukier

BORN--Esther. Our deepest condolences to our cousins and dearest friends, Rita and Fred Distenfeld, Debbie and Richard Born and to their children and grandchild on the loss of their beautiful mother, Esther Born. Also, to Harry Wittlin, Esther's dear brother and friend. We will miss our dear Esther, she was like an aunt to us, she was my parent's best friend and treated my grandparents as if they were her own. Esther, we will forever miss you. Ruth, Fred, Jason, Evan, Karen, Ella and Chloe

The poet Percy Dovetonsils, disc jockey Wolfgang von Sauerbraten, magician Matzoh Hepplewhite and storyteller Auntie Gruesome are getting a retrospective at the Museum of the Moving Image - and so, too, are Ernie Kovacs, who portrayed these characters, and Edie Adams, his wife and frequent co-star, who appeared with him in several pioneering television series of the 1950s and 60s. The museum said on Wednesday that it will host a month-long program, running from April 27 through May 27, honoring Kovacs and Adams, whose innovative character skits and comedy pieces influenced any number of self-aware, self-referential performers and shows, including David Letterman, ''Sesame Street'' and Pee-wee Herman.

NBC News has signed Matt Lauer to a new multiyear contract to remain as the co-host of the ''Today'' show, addressing one of the division's most pressing issues. The news will be announced formally on the air during the show Friday morning. But Steve Capus, the president of NBC News, confirmed Thursday evening that Mr. Lauer had signed what he called ''a long-term deal'' to continue as the leading figure on the most profitable show on NBC.
Liberman--Rob, 35. Haines, Alaska heli-ski guide. Died in avalanche on March 12. Rob will be missed.

Can you make an Alaskan Polar Bear Heater in Tennessee? A musical version of ''The Nutty Professor,'' the Jerry Lewis comedy that introduced that stiff alcoholic concoction - along with the Jekyll-and-Hyde-like characters of Julius Kelp and Buddy Love - will have its world premiere in Nashville before a planned Broadway run later this year, the Tennessee Performing Arts Center said on Wednesday. The ''Nutty Professor'' musical will be performed at the center's James K. Polk Theater from July 24 through August 19, the organization said. The production, which is adapted from Mr. Lewis's hit 1963 film of the same title, is to star Michael Andrew as Kelp, and will feature music by Marvin Hamlisch (''A Chorus Line'') and a book and lyrics by Rupert Holmes (''Curtains,'' ''The Mystery of Edwin Drood''). Mr. Lewis - who didn't need a fat suit to play his ''Nutty Professor,'' thank you very much - is directing.

An article in some editions on Tuesday about races for Congressional seats to represent New York that have been reshaped by redistricting misspelled the surname of a candidate in the 19th District. He is Julian Schreibman, not Schriebman.

Lauren Oliver, the 29-year-old author of best-selling teenage novels, will write her first novel for an adult audience, her publisher said on Thursday. Ecco, part of HarperCollins, has acquired ''Rooms,'' which will be released in fall 2014. Lee Boudreaux, who will edit the book, said it was ''as instantly gripping as it was elegantly written, filled with characters and predicaments I still can't get out of my head a week later.'' Ms. Oliver is the author of three young-adult novels, ''Before I Fall,'' ''Delirium'' and ''Pandemonium,'' and a middle-grade novel, ''Liesl and Po.''

CATLETT--Elizabeth. The Board of Trustees and staff of The Studio Museum in Harlem salute the life and legacy of Elizabeth Catlett, one of the most exceptional artists of our time. Her incomparable commitment to art, education and activism will influence and inspire generations to come, and she will be deeply missed. Our sincere condolences to her family. Raymond J. McGuire, Chairman Thelma Golden, Director

An article on March 29 about the varied opinions among Americans about the individual mandate -- the central provision of the Affordable Care Act that requires most Americans to obtain health insurance -- referred incorrectly to a medical student in San Diego who commented on the possibility that the Supreme Court might strike down the law. The student, Rohan Vilms, is a man.
International BILLIONAIRE IN GEORGIA

AUGUSTA, Ga. - On the silver anniversary of his Masters victory, Larry Mize returned to Augusta National on Thursday and made some good shots in his opening round of four-over-par 76, but none that would qualify as miraculous. Playing in the third grouping of the day, Mize birdied No. 2 to make an early appearance on the leader board. He went bogey-birdie-bogey-birdie on the next four holes, then dropped from the leader board after a double-bogey 7 at No. 15, which was set up by a bad chip on his third shot.

An article on March 17 about appeals for a Department of Justice investigation into the shooting of Trayvon Martin by George Zimmerman misstated the time period in which Mr. Zimmerman made 46 calls to 911. The calls were made over the course of about eight years, not over 14 months. The error was repeated in a front-page article on March 21 about Florida's self-defense law known as Stand Your Ground.

Facebook, which is preparing for its highly anticipated initial public offering, has picked a home. The social network will list its shares under the ticker symbol FB on Nasdaq, according to people with knowledge of the matter, who requested anonymity because the discussions were private.

An article on March 19 about an American teaching in Yemen who was shot and killed by two men on a motorcycle in the city of Taiz gave an outdated name for the organization with which the teacher was affiliated. It is the International Trade and Development Center, no longer the Swedish Free Mission.

Letters written by George Washington, Henry David Thoreau's pencil-drawn map of Walden Pond and Mark Twain's manuscript of ''A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court'' are among the items from the New York Public Library's American collections that will soon be digitized and made available to the public online, the library announced on Thursday. The library, aided by a $500,000 grant from the Polonsky Foundation, has already begun digitizing the Thomas Addis Emmet Collection, which covers the early years of the United States and includes a copy of the Declaration of Independence written in Thomas Jefferson's hand and manuscript minutes of the Annapolis Convention, the 1786 meeting at which delegates unanimously called for a constitutional convention.

Keith Olbermann, fired last week from his show on Current TV, has followed through on his threat to file suit against his former employers. The suit, filed Thursday in Los Angeles Superior Court, seeks damages of $50 million to $70 million. Mr. Olbermann, who hired the prominent Hollywood lawyer Patty Glaser to represent him, charged in the suit that his employers at Current have failed to come through on promises made in his contract. The suit, which was posted on the Web site of The Hollywood Reporter, cites the technical failures that plagued his show and other examples of unprofessional work.
As the Rangers’ last man between opposing players’ shots and the back net, Henrik Lundqvist has led the team to the playoffs with stellar goaltending.
In one of the most remote spots on earth, looking for clues to the origins of the universe.
The Chicago Blackhawks won the Stanley cup in 2010 and suddenly the city had hockey fever. Even adult novices started taking classes to learn to play the fast sport.
Gov. Jerry Brown on Friday commuted the sentence of a woman convicted in 1997 of shaking her baby grandson to death, saying significant doubts surrounded her conviction.
The founder of the Christian university where a gunman killed seven people this week says the suspect, a former nursing student, came to campus that day to discuss a tuition dispute.
The Department of Defense has identified 1,912 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
A Brutalist building faces demolition in Goshen, N.Y., raising questions about the future of unfashionably Modern midcentury structures.
Gov. Rick Scott signed a bill Friday inspired by 2-year-old Caylee Anthony’s death.
Good Friday was an official holiday in Cuba for the first time in a half century, but few Roman Catholics on the island seemed to use the day off to attend Mass.
The founder of a medical marijuana training school said Friday that he was giving up his marijuana businesses in downtown Oakland after a federal raid this week.
A man who battled deportation from Canada for a decade after being accused of running China’s largest-ever smuggling ring went on trial on Friday.
President Abdu Rabbu Mansour Hadi replaced nearly 20 top military officers on Friday, including a half brother of former President Ali Abdullah Saleh, the official Saba news agency reported.
Iranian naval forces freed a Chinese freighter hijacked by Somali pirates off southern Iran on Friday and arrested all the attackers, the semiofficial Iranian news agency Fars reported.
Abdulhadi al-Khawaja, a jailed activist who has been on a hunger strike for 58 days, was moved to a hospital and fed intravenously after his health deteriorated sharply, his lawyer said.
An audit of and recommendations for the United States Immigration and Customs Enforcement’s Secure Communities program.
Victoria Pendleton of the United Kingdom won her sixth world sprint title after Simona Krupeckaite of Lithuania was disqualified at the Melbourne velodrome.
The Olympic 2000 and 2004 canoe slalom champion, Tony Estanguet of France, qualified for the London Games at the French selection competition in Pau.
Jeremy Welsh is expected to play for the Carolina Hurricanes at Florida on Saturday night, less than 48 hours after playing for Union College in its loss to Ferris State in the N.C.A.A. semifinals.
A man who once said he wanted to wage jihad against the United States renounced terrorism on Friday as he was sentenced to 25 years in prison in a bombing plot.
Omar Suleiman, a former deputy of the ousted President Hosni Mubarak, announced his presidential candidacy, shaking up an already heated race.
Mike Smith made 31 saves, helping the Phoenix Coyotes take the Pacific Division lead with a 4-1 road victory over the St. Louis Blues.
Shaul Mofaz, the new opposition leader once regarded as a hawk who would try to join the governing Likud coalition, has an agenda more typically associated with the left.
John Isner defeated Gilles Simon, 6-3, 6-2, 7-5, pulling the United States even with France on Friday in the Davis Cup quarterfinals in Roquebrune, France.
Howard University’s spring sports teams have resumed competition after a temporary halt because of possible N.C.A.A. rules violations.
Florida International fired Isiah Thomas as its men’s basketball coach, after a record of 26-65 over three seasons.
State Senator Pam Roach had been removed from the Republican caucus in 2010 after repeated clashes with fellow lawmakers and staff members.
Almost two months after a victory at the Withers Stakes, Alpha will finally make his reappearance in Saturday’s $1 million Wood Memorial at Aqueduct.
A veiled apology was offered after the Turkish prime minister, a crucial mediator, chastised Iran’s leaders for seeking to move talks from Turkey to Iraq or Syria.
Memphis put seven players in double figures to end Miami’s 17-game home winning streak on Friday night.
The controversy over a poem by Günter Grass showed no signs of subsiding, even after he said that he meant to criticize the government and not Israel as a whole.
Beset by injuries, Islanders goalie Rick DiPietro has played in only 47 games in the past four years, winning 14.
Andreas Georgiou, who was recruited in 2010 to help get Greece’s famously unreliable public accounting in order, has become the target of a criminal investigation.
An effort to identify illegal immigrants who committed crimes led to confusion among authorities before it started to yield results, according to two reports from the inspector general.
Some of the more controversial sections of the law may be altered or eliminated.
City representatives met with league officials and asked questions about the size of a proposed stadium, how often it would be used and what facilities would be available for the public.
With the general election campaign about to start, President Obama is set to emphasize an issue that few Democratic candidates have made such a focus.
Work-life conflicts are standard for fathers everywhere, and dads who happen to be playing in the Masters are no exception.
The Obama administration would prevent federal workers from attending seminars, receptions and social gatherings for free, which lobbyists have denounced as excessive.
Commissioner Roger Goodell’s soon-to-be-announced decision on the discipline appeals by the New Orleans Saints offers a chance to send a message about the primacy of player safety.
Carlos Pena hit a grand slam against C. C. Sabathia in the first inning, and his game-ending hit against Mariano Rivera in the ninth led the Rays past the Yankees.
An illegal immigrant whose quest for a kidney was chronicled in The New York Times received one from his brother.
Mr. Steinberg brought what he called a new, “American style” assertiveness to the World Jewish Congress as its top executive.
Garrett Jackson spends more time with the candidate than even Mr. Romney’s wife, Ann, does.
Isiah Thomas was fired by Florida International University as its basketball coach on Friday, and Donnie Walsh, Thomas’s successor as the Knicks’ president, began seeking work with another franchise.
Avezzano coached the kicking and kick-return units for Dallas teams that won Super Bowls in the 1992, 1993 and 1995 seasons.
In his defense, an educator in Washington Heights showed a picture of the schools chancellor at the time in a similarly affectionate pose with students.
G.M.’s innovative hybrid has become quite the political lightning rod.
Corrections appearing in print on April 7, 2012
The Interior Department should broker a compromise with a Denver-based gas company, so as not to drill in Desolation Canyon, a wild and fragile landscape.
Fred Couples, 52, shot the lowest score of the day, a five-under 67, to move into the lead with Jason Dufner after two rounds at the Masters.
A businessman with a passion for Bruce Springsteen found a way to hold a Seder and still attend a concert at Madison Square Garden.
The ouster of Bo Xilai, the party chief in Chongqing, points to possibly the most serious division in the party elite since the leadership upheavals during the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests.
The winning lottery numbers for April 6, 2012, for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
The currency fell against the euro and the yen after data showed nonfarm payrolls rose by 120,000 in March, well below expectations.
An appeals panel struck down a judge’s order that New York State transfer thousands of mentally ill adults in New York City from institutional group homes into their own homes and apartments.
After two years in a maze of conflicting health care and immigration policies, an illegal immigrant receives a kidney from his brother.
A new vision of how we farm and how we eat, and of how to take better care of this planet’s biological resources, will be needed to provide food for a growing population.
The government ordered three companies that received bailout money and have not paid it back — the American International Group, Ally Financial and General Motors — to cut executives’ pay.
New York courts may be reforming hiring practices so that jobs are not given to favored friends and relatives, but one justice has been given a pass for doing so.
A problem with wires in a defibrillator is the industry’s third highly visible safety episode in seven years, inviting discussion of a greater role for the F.D.A.
Winning has never been a problem for Bobby Petrino, but the Arkansas coach’s disclosure of a relationship with a young employee after a motorcycle crash has put new focus on his character.
One reason the United States has a low voter-participation rate is that most states are using 19th-century registration methods in the 21st century.
The case of the shooting death of a black teenager in Florida is producing another O.J. Simpson moment for America.
The last of the big toy stores struggles to revamp its business as sales decline, management defects, and debt and competition mount.
Daytop Village, one of the oldest and largest drug rehabilitation agencies in New York State, owes more than $33 million to two banks.
Ryan Braun, who avoided a suspension after a positive drug test, was 0 for 5 as the Milwaukee Brewers lost to St. Louis in their home opener.
In “On the Beach” at the Baryshnikov Arts Center, teams of artists and performers play around with Philip Glass’s “Einstein on the Beach.”
Garrett Jackson is Mitt Romney’s “body man,” seeing to his every need and helping to keep him on time.
Investors are buying up homes to turn into rentals, Google gave a preview of its Internet-connected glasses and the government released a disappointing jobs report for March.
November is fast approaching, people! The Republicans have much to do to stay on top of things. Here is a checklist.
For the first time in the history of the Frozen Four, college hockey’s championship is being contested in the South.
Ms. Rich wrote a memoir about the daily trials encountered in a place she called Cancerland, and ended up living there far longer than the year or two she had expected.
Santa Monica College met with vigorous student objections, and some people at a recent protest were hurt by pepper spray from the campus police.
The proportion of Americans in their mid-teens claiming sexual experience has decreased, and for boys the decline has been especially steep.
Papiss Demba Cissé collected both goals in Newcastle’s 2-0 win over host Swansea in the Premier League, lifting his team above Chelsea and into fifth place.
Samantha Stosur beat Venus Williams, 6-3, 4-6, 6-3, ending the chance at an all-Williams-sister semifinal at the Family Circle Cup in Charleston, S.C.
A stray bullet hit a 10-year-old boy from Norway in a shooting in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, that otherwise seemed to have caused no panic.
A group of economists called permabears offer what they say are more realistic assessments of the economy and the tepid pace of the recovery.
Harvey Weinstein succeeded in getting the rating changed for the documentary “Bully,” but he stands accused of making a fuss purely for publicity, which he denies.
Rebel fighters in the ancient crossroads of Timbuktu, Mali, announced the birth of a country called Azawad. But the declaration is unlikely to be embraced by anyone.
Mariano Rivera blew the save, and the Yankees lost their season opener to Tampa Bay in the bottom of the ninth, echoing a less important game at the end of last year’s regular season.
In a long-running feud, a jury awarded Fresh Del Monte $13.15 million, saying Del Monte Foods violated licensing agreements by selling cut, refrigerated fruit products.
The Council for Opportunity in Education discusses how colleges can increase diversity.
A reader comments on rulings on the insurance mandate and strip searches.
Former Mayor Edward I. Koch says rock throwing is definitely not “nonviolent.”
The Center for Progressive Reform says the F.D.A. has the legal power to prevail and should resist pressure from the White House.
President Obama and Senate Democrats will kick off a coordinated push for a requirement that the rich pay at least 30 percent of their income in taxes.
“A Crack in Everything,” by the choreographer Zoe Scofield and the video artist Juniper Shuey, is at New York Live Arts.
Royal Ballet’s triple bill of 21st-century ballets by young British choreographers includes Christopher Wheeldon’s “Polyphonia” and two premieres, by Liam Scarlett and Wayne McGregor.
Readers’ thoughts about the Supreme Court after the health care arguments.
Midway through a three-week residency at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, Dr. John performed at a concert that highlighted songs from his new album, “Locked Down.”
Borrowing on credit cards fell by $2 billion, after a $3 billion decline in January.
There are many deals in which declarer would make his contract if he could peek at an opponent’s hand.
For the latest version of Michael Clark’s “Who’s Zoo?” at the Whitney Biennial, live music is provided by Pulp’s frontman, Jarvis Cocker.
AutoSlash, a car rental site that searches for the best rates, has earned the enmity of Hertz, Enterprise and other rental giants. Airlines haven’t been much warmer to services that help passengers.
If the Rangers win the regular-season finale Saturday night against Washington, they will be awarded the Presidents’ Trophy for the best record in the league.
Chano Domínguez reimagines Miles Davis’s “Kind of Blue” in his show at the Jazz Standard.
The German cabaret artist Ute Lemper sang in six languages in a performance at Zankel Hall.
The experimental musician Theo Bleckmann has released an album of Kate Bush’s songs, one of a series of projects that could raise awareness of this German-born singer.
Turkey’s foreign minister reported increased Syrian military attacks near the border and a relentless influx of refugees from Syria on Friday.
While the rest of Spain’s economy struggles, prostitution — almost all of it involving the ruthless trafficking of foreign women — is exploding into public view.
Some international investors are delaying investments in India, a sign of concern over a raft of new taxes proposed by the government.
Virginia M. Rometty is expected to attend the Masters to entertain clients while a debate continues about Augusta National Golf Club’s men-only membership policy.
Alison Smale, executive editor of the International Herald Tribune, narrates a look back at news coverage of the Titanic disaster.
President Obama on Friday emphasized the last three months of job creation while Mitt Romney argued that Mr. Obama has been a failed economic steward.
Since 1986, more than 12,000 runners have competed in the Marathon des Sables, a six-day ultramarathon through the desert in Morocco.
Representative Paul D. Ryan’s much-vilified budget proposal is clearly an opening gambit, leaving plenty of room for further hearings and negotiations.
Two men behind Proposition 7, a tough death penalty initiative passed in California in 1978, now see it as one of the biggest mistakes they ever made.
The market for rare and finely made vintage timepieces is booming but, as with all collectibles, there are risks.
In Indianapolis, black Christians and Sephardic Jews who once shared a neighborhood are brought together in the spirit of harmony they once shared.
Chinese security officials have issued a wanted list of six suspected members of a militant group that they said is using a number of Asian nations as staging grounds for terror attacks.
The United States economy added a disappointing 120,000 jobs in March, the Labor Department reported on Friday, about half the gains posted in each of the preceding three months.
Russia’s foreign ministry lashed out on Friday over the sentencing of a Russian arms trafficker, Viktor Bout, to 25 years in prison, warning that it could harm relations with Washington.
The United States expressed concern about the future of the impoverished African nation of Malawi on Friday after a swirl of reports that its president, stricken by a heart attack, had died.
Tuareg rebels who overran much of northern Mali after disaffected soldiers toppled the government in the south declared an independent state called Azawad on Friday.

FENHAGEN--The Reverend James Corner Fenhagen, 82, former President and Dean of the General Theological Seminary in New York City, died April 5, 2012 in Georgetown, SC. Services 3pm Monday, April 9, 2012, at Holy Cross Faith Memorial Episcopal Church, Pawleys Island, SC with committal service at St. John's Georgetown Parish, Washington D.C., at a later date.

Imagine a canvas at the so-called Crossroads of the World: Artists are being invited to take over the giant screens of Times Square. Chashama, an organization that supports artists, has teamed up with Artists Wanted and the Times Square Alliance to create ''Art Takes Times Square,'' which starts with a day of events on June 18. The selected artworks will be shown on Nasdaq, Thomson Reuters, Clear Channel and Spectacolor signs, among others, as well as A2aMedia's Port Authority display. Artists can submit their work for consideration here through May 25.

A picture caption on Wednesday with an article about the testing of satellite technology to help streamline airplane landings described incorrectly some equipment shown. The heads-up display in front of the pilot in the photograph is used for landing under conditions of limited visibility; it is not related to the GPS used in the satellite-guided landings.
SAVAGE--Evelyn H. April 7, 2009. She loved her family, her friends and Life.

MURPHY--Rev. Edward J.,S.J., on April 4, 2012. Loving brother of Sr. Margaret Mary Murphy S.C. and Dennis Murphy. Predeceased by his brother Timothy Murphy. Reposing at the Murray-Weigel Hall Chapel, 515 E. Fordham Rd., Bronx, NY on Sunday from 7-9pm and on Monday from 3-5 and 7-9pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at the Fordham University Church on Tuesday at 10:30am. Interment will take place at the Jesuit Martyrs' Shrine, Auriesville, NY. For information contact Farenga Bros. Inc., Directors (718) 654-0500.
Because of Passover, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Saturday and Sunday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

An article on Feb. 16 about the efforts by advocates for same-sex marriage to win over blacks in Maryland misidentified the home state of Michael Kenneth Williams, an actor from the Baltimore-based television series ''The Wire.'' He was born and raised in New York, not in Maryland.
WALERSTEIN--Jeffrey David. Our love for you is Eternal. You are forever in our hearts. Mom, Dad and Mark

Ozier Muhammad has lived in Harlem for the last 22 years, exploring the area and hunting for stories during long walks in the neighborhood. ''It is an intriguing place that is a laboratory for artistic expression,'' said Mr. Muhammad, a staff photographer for The Times. ''A cultural cauldron for Latino and African-American expression and, of course, with all the historical benchmarks like the Harlem Renaissance.''
BORN--Esther. The Erlich and Pruzansky families extend their heartfelt condolences to the families of Esther Born, a lifelong connection.

GUTTENBERG--Elliott. It is with deep sorrow that we mark the loss of our Member, Elliott Guttenberg. The Counselors, clients, and friends of Elliott at SCORENYC will surely miss his sage advice. ScoreNYC Harry Dannenberg, Chairman
MONTE--Pat C.,1928-2009. It is three years today that we are without you. You're terribly missed and forever in our hearts. Maryann and Family.

BORN--Esther. Our deep condolences to our father, Harry Wittlin, upon the loss of his cherished sister, and to our cousins, Debbie and Richard Born, Rita and Fred Distenfeld, and their families, on the loss of their beautiful and adoring mother. Our Aunt Esther was an exceptional role model -- kind, elegant, brilliant and humble. She will live on in our memories. Abby and Gabriel Tolchinsky, Lisa and Tommy Nadler.

A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Friday about the Metropolitan Museum of Art's 2012-13 season of concerts, lectures and other events, which includes performances of all of Beethoven's string quartets by the Endellion String Quartet, misstated the number of string quartets Beethoven composed. It is 16 -- not 32, which is the number of piano sonatas he composed.

NAPLES -- After years of criticism that Italy was not sufficiently caring for one of its most famous, and fragile, archeological sites, the Italian government came out on Thursday with a long-term plan for the protection of Pompeii. A team of government ministers presented the plan at a news conference in Naples that came on the heels of the approval last week of a 105 million, or $137 million, contribution for the site from the European Commission.

An article on Friday about the 1944 killing of David Kammerer by the Beat Generation figure Lucien Carr misidentified the source of a screenplay based on the killing. The screenplay, ''Kill Your Darlings,'' now in production, was written by John Krokidis and Austin Bunn. They did not adapt it from ''And the Hippos Were Boiled in Their Tanks,'' a roman à clef written in 1945 by Jack Kerouac and William S. Burroughs that tells a similar version of the killing.

A start-up that had a test-run at Stanford University's business school last year aims to tap alumni as a source of funding for student loans at colleges across the country. SoFi - short for Social Finance Inc. - is branching out and expects to begin taking applications for consolidation loans in April from recent graduates of five business schools, using funds raised from alumni of those schools (Harvard, M.I.T., Northwestern and the University of Pennsylvania, in addition to Stanford).

An article last Saturday about the fight to change prison policies on solitary confinement rendered incorrectly the name of a correctional department whose gang management program has been a model for other states. It is the Connecticut Department of Correction, not the Connecticut Department of Corrections.

Six Chinese citizens have had their assets frozen in connection with an insider trading case involving a Chinese pork processing company, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced Friday. The S.E.C.'s complaint, which was filed in a United States District Court in Chicago on Wednesday, alleges that six Chinese citizens - Siming Yang, Caiyin Fan, Shui Chong Chang, Biao Cang, Jia Wu, and Ming Ni - made more than $9 million by trading in the shares of Zhongpin Inc. ahead of the announcement of a management-led buyout offer last month. A British Virgin Islands-based entity formed by Mr. Yang, Prestige Trade Investments, was also named in the complaint.

SPINNER--Marion, beloved widow of Herman, loving mother of Annie Borofsky and Jan Spinner, cherished sister of Paul and William Fried, died on March 31, 2012 at the age of 89. The matriarch of a large and adoring family, she overcame adversity with strength, grace, joy, and a marvelously acerbic wit. She will be deeply missed.

Louis Oosthuizen was in the fifth group on the course, and when he arrived at the first tee he could have been forgiven for thinking he was back at St. Andrews, the site of his 2010 British Open victory. Fans were buying green stocking caps from the merchandise stores to ward off the chill. The sky was pewter and it was 53 degrees, but a raw wind made it feel 10 degrees colder. More frigid than the conditions were Oosthuizen's clubs. He made a double bogey on the second hole and was three over par for the round when he made the turn. He played the back nine in three under, without a bogey, to finish with an even-par 72 and a 36-hole total of four-under 140.
Alison Smale, executive editor of the International Herald Tribune, narrates a look back at news coverage of the Titanic disaster.

Globe-trotting admirers of Charles Dickens can celebrate this year's bicentennial of his birth by brushing shoulders with chimney sweeps at a Dickens World theme park in England, taking in lectures and amateur theatricals at a scholarly ''Dickens camp'' in California, or attending any of the festivities being held from Bologna, Italy, to Colorado Springs. But those stuck at home with gout or other quasi-Victorian ailments are not entirely out of luck. They can now enjoy unlimited virtual access to Dr. De Jongh's Light Brown Cod Liver Oil, Kaye Wordsell's Vegetal Tablets and other medicinal concoctions available in Dickens's day, thanks to a new Web site introduced on Thursday by the Dickens Project, a research consortium based at the University of California, Santa Cruz.

WEIDMAN--Lucy, on April 5, 2012. Lucy died peacefully from cancer, discovered shortly after she suffered a stroke in January. She graduated Tilden High School, attended Vassar College, and graduated Sarah Lawrence College in 1979. Lucy was a gifted painter and designer, and was beloved by family and friends. Daughter of the late Henrietta (Queenie) and Hyman (Kitty) Katz, she is survived by husband Edwin; brothers Henry and Richard; children James, Peter, David and Jennifer; children-in-law Marsha, Debbi, Debbie and Barry; and grandchildren Amanda, Samuel, Hilary, Rachel, Katie, Lauren, Julia, Isabel and Benjamin. In Lucy's memory, please consider a donation to your favorite art museum. Service Monday, April 9, 11:45am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

An entry in the ''What's on Today'' television highlights on Thursday about a documentary short on HBO, ''God Is the Bigger Elvis,'' about the former movie star Dolores Hart, misstated the title of a film in which she appeared. It is ''Wild Is the Wind,'' not ''Wild in the Wind.''

After following his opening-round 71 with a six-over-par 78, Patrick Cantlay talked about his first Masters experience in the past tense. ''Just the whole experience I'll remember, for sure, nothing in particular,'' he said. ''Staying in the Crow's Nest was fun.'' At five-over-par 149 for the tournament, Cantlay, a sophomore at U.C.L.A., made the 36-hole cut on the number, affording him a weekend's stay in the Crow's Nest, the residence for the amateurs in the tournament.

An article on March 28 about voter registration groups that have curbed their efforts in Florida because of a new law that imposes restrictions on them misstated the date that the new law took effect. It was May 2011, not July. (After the bill was signed in May, groups that were already registered with the state were given 90 days to comply with some of its provisions.)
SHACTER--Charles Banks March 23, 1910 - April 7, 1992. Treasured Hero and Papa, Missed and Loved Always.

LEVIN--Behna M.,the widow of the late I. Victor Levin, a past member of the New York Stock Exchange, died peacefully in her 91st year. A native New Yorker, Mrs. Levin was the daughter of the late Eva B. Marks and the late Henry C. Marks, a founder of Howard Clothes, who resided in Palm Beach, Florida at the time of her death. She is survived by her children, Eileen Robert of NYC and Steven Levin of Arlington, MA., her granddaughters, Elisabeth Amory Robert of NYC and Alexandra Robert Gordon of San Francisco and two great-grandsons, Eli and Zach Gordon. After a private funeral and interment, the family will be receiving on Sunday, April 8th from 4-8 at the home of Eileen Robert. Behna certainly will be missed by all those who loved her dearly!

The Alamo Drafthouse Cinema chain, which got its start in Austin, Tex., and became known nationally for its strict no-talking, no-texting policy, has plans to expand to Manhattan next year. The new theater will be at the site of the former Metro theater on Broadway, between 99th and 100th Streets, the chain said in a statement. Its plans call for five screens, with food and drink service at patrons' seats during the movie.

Admit it. You've sometimes grumbled after buying a nice wedding gift, only to see the couple split up a year or two later. Well, now you can hedge your bets, at a new Web site called -- what else -- WeddingGiftRefund.com.

KLIEGER--Edith W. The congregation of Westchester Reform Temple mourns the death of its longtime, devoted member and extends sympathy to her bereaved family. Lisa Messinger, President Jonathan Blake, Rabbi Jill Abramson, Cantor

While a fast group of golfers playing through a slower group is a regular occurrence on public courses, it is unusual - if not downright rare - to see it take place in a professional event. Yet, early Friday at Augusta National, it happened. Martin Laird and Chez Reavie were the second group off No. 1, but by the fifth hole they were the lead group. Sean O'Hair, who was playing in the threesome in front of them, suggested to a rules official that they let the twosome through. When another official brought it up to Laird, ''I waited about a half-second before I said yes,'' he said.

Two former executives of the Franklin Bank Corporation, a now-defunct lender started by the mortgage bond pioneer Lewis Ranieri, have been accused of hiding losses during the final days of the company. In a complaint filed on Thursday in United States District Court in Texas, the Securities and Exchange Commission accused Anthony J. Nocella, Franklin's former chief executive, and J. Russell McCann, the bank's former chief financial officer, of misstating the health of their company during the financial crisis, when a series of mortgage loans on the bank's books went sour and it struggled to stay afloat.

Updated 2:10 p.m. | To add more details There is still time to make a contribution to an individual retirement account for 2011. But most Americans aren't contributing to an I.R.A. for their retirement, and those who do aren't maximizing their potential contributions, a recent survey finds.

GREEN--Hubert D.,of West Hempstead, NY, died April 5 peacefully at his home at the age of 95. He was the loving husband of the late Esther Mayer Green, devoted father of Robert Green and Nancy Green, loving father-in-law of Jerome Katz and Jane Heitman Green, adored grandfather of Jonathan, Elizabeth, Andrew and Adam, and loving companion of Rita Pollack. As a U.S. Army radio operator on an unarmed transport plane during World War II, he helped deliver Allied paratroopers at the beginning of the June 1944 D-Day invasion. Hubie will always be remembered for his integrity, wonderful sense of humor, zest for life, devotion to friends and family, and the love he inspired in his caregivers during his final years. Hubie loved tennis, the occasional Southern Comfort Manhattan, and the New York Mets, in good times and bad. Hubie was also a tireless and loyal worker, employed as an engineer until the age of 87. A funeral will be held at the Riverside Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY, on April 8 at 11am.

When restaurant customers learned that the waiter they called Angel was in the hospital with kidney failure, they stuffed bills into a collection jar to help support his family. His brother offered something more precious: a healthy kidney to restore his life. But for two years, the obstacles to the transplant seemed insuperable. Angel, the father of two American-born children, is an illegal immigrant. And a maze of conflicting health care and immigration policies meant that while the government would pay for a lifetime of dialysis, costing $75,000 yearly, it would not pay for a $100,000 transplant that would make dialysis unnecessary.

10 P.M. (Ovation) HOLY FLYING CIRCUS (2011) Darren Boyd channels John Cleese, and Charles Edwards is Michael Palin in this reimagining of the Monty Python members' 1979 debate against the journalist Malcolm Muggeridge (Michael Cochrane) and the Bishop of Southwark (Roy Marsden) on the talk show ''Friday Night, Saturday Morning,'' following the release of the comedy troupe's farce ''Life of Brian.'' That comedy tells the story of Brian Cohen, a young Jewish man born on the same day and in the next stable as Jesus who spends his life being mistaken for the Messiah. A dramatization of the debate, ''Circus,'' directed by Owen Harris and written by Tony Roche, chronicles the build-up to the face-off and the controversy surrounding ''Brian,'' which resulted in nuns and rabbis picketing movie theaters and some British authorities, as well as countries like Ireland and Norway, banning it outright. The cast is rounded out by Rufus Jones as Terry Jones, Tom Fisher as Graham Chapman, Phil Nichol as Terry Gilliam, Ben Crispin as Jesus and Stephen Fry as God. ''Circus,'' a scene from which is above, is the first entry in ''The Best You've Never Seen,'' a new Saturday-night block of original programming. 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Judy Valente visits with young singers of the Boston Boys Choir, a Roman Catholic all-boys choir and school founded nearly 50 years ago to help preserve and promote sacred classical music in the United States. Deborah Potter reports on the nearly 15,000 parish nurses who provide health counseling and home and hospital visits to faith communities around the country.

Ruling against the immediate seizure of a 1,000-year-old Cambodian statue the United States and Cambodian governments say was looted from its temple site, a federal judge in Manhattan on Thursday gave Sotheby's continued custody of the antiquity and called a conference on the case for April 12. The judge, George B. Daniels, signed a restraining order directing Sotheby's not to dispose of the sandstone statue, which the auction house had planned to sell for an unidentified Belgian client for up to $3 million last year, and to make it available for inspection by the Department of Homeland Security, which had sought its forfeiture as stolen property.

The young used to go to discos. But now they go to brothels. It's just another form of entertainment to them. FRANCINA VILA I VALLS, Barcelona's councilor for women and civil rights, on the explosive increase of prostitution in Spain. [A6]

Growing up in Williamsburg in the 1980s, Dennis Farr dreamed of a life that was mythical. His fascination with the murals slathered on the walls of the abandoned buildings on the neighborhood's post-industrial waterfront satisfied his longing for adventure, looking like tags written by phantom giants. But he also envisioned a life that was biblical. He got that soon enough when he started writing and warning against the influx of artists and other trendsetters who were slowly colonizing the area in the early 1990s. Where others saw a brick and mortar change for the better, Mr. Farr was alarmed that these newcomers would push out members of the area's long-established Puerto Rican community.

In what turned out to be a very rough night for the broadcast networks, almost all of Thursday's programming fell sharply no matter what category or time period is used for comparison. According to Nielsen, Fox's ''American Idol'' had another drop in total viewers, to 13.8 million this week from 15.9 million last week, and in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic its new drama ''Touch'' fell to 7.5 million total viewers from 8.9 million. On CBS ''The Big Bang Theory'' hit a season low in the 18-to-49 category, and ''Person of Interest'' tumbled to its lowest viewership since February, at 13.5 million. ''Grey's Anatomy'' on ABC and ''Community'' and ''30 Rock'' on NBC dropped to season lows in adults 18-to-49 as well.

BORN--Esther. Beloved wife of Robert Born a blessed memory. Devoted mother to Rita and Fred Distenfeld and Debbie and Richard Born. Adoring grandmother to Mikey and Erica, Caroline and Zac, Jenny and Benjy, Claire, and Max. Number one fan of her great-grand- daughter Julia, loving sister to Harry Wittlin. Our beautiful, wise and adored mother has found her peace. She maintained her poise and dignity throughout her life. She will be sorely missed and always in our thoughts.

The parent company of the Outback Steakhouse chain of restaurants, Bloomin' Brands, filed to go public on Friday, becoming the latest company owned by private equity firms to seek a stock market listing. The prospectus listed a preliminary fund-raising goal of $300 million in its prospectus to calculate registration fees.

''Enlightened hospitality,'' the restaurateur Danny Meyer's catchphrase for success, takes on new meaning during National Poetry Month. All April long, before each lunch and dinner shift at Gramercy Tavern, his three-star Flatiron district restaurant, the employees take turns reciting poems for one another before they hit the floor. The audience can number up to 50, a mingling of managers, kitchen workers in white and servers and runners dressed in identical blue shirts, tangerine ties and charcoal vests.

The Riff column on Page 52 this weekend, about musical obscurity and how it is no longer an honor, misspells the surname of a singer about whom everybody knows something (or at least something other than her name). She is Lana Del Rey, not Ray.

STEINBERG--Elan. The American Gathering of Jewish Holocaust Survivors and Their Descendants mourn the tragic death of our beloved vice president Elan Steinberg, a great Jewish leader and a wonderful friend. A son of Holocaust survivors, he defended the memory of the victims of the Shoah and fought for the rights and dignity of survivors throughout his all too short life. As Executive Director of the World Jewish Congress, he exposed Kurt Waldheim's Nazi past and was a critical moving force behind the successful efforts to obtain a measure of justice for victims of Nazism from Swiss banks and European governments and insurance companies. Our love, thoughts and prayers are with his devoted wife Sharon, their children Max, Harry and Lena, and his brother Alex. Sam Bloch, President Roman Kent, Chairman Max Liebmann, Senior Vice President Menachem Rosensaft, Vice President Jean Bloch Rosensaft, Vice President Joyce Levine, Secretary

The Mets' coveted clean bill of health lasted through one game of the regular season. The Mets announced Friday that center fielder Andres Torres, who left their opening game Thursday with a strained left calf, would be placed on the 15-day disabled list before their game Saturday afternoon. Kirk Nieuwenhuis, the club's most advanced outfield prospect, will be recalled from the minors to replace him.

“Cocktail Culture: The Glamorous Gold Coast Years From Prohibition to 1960,” at the Coe Hall mansion, highlights the fashions and other accoutrements of the decades “when the house was in its heyday.”
The director of the Princeton University Art Museum said the current show featuring oil sketches by John Constable is an attempt to “re-radicalize” Constable for 21st-century viewers.
“100 Years: Titanic Survivors and Their Stories” will be staged on April 15, the anniversary of the disaster, at the Arts and Community Center on the campus of Ocean County College.

K. Pacho, a casual Mexican restaurant, opened less than two months after its predecessor, the expensive Two Steak and Sushi Den, closed in January.

This year’s auto show is notably light on fantasies and flashy niche models, and heavy on mass-market appeal. Here is a look at some of the show’s highlights.

The FX is a strange beast, a crossover that shares its rear-wheel-drive platform with Nissan and Infiniti sports cars. That helps to distinguish the FX from all the quasi-S.U.V.’s that ride on stretched front-drive-sedan platforms.
The Fiat 500 gets a performance upgrade that turns the mild-mannered car into a little beast with a burbling growl and a welcome jolt of horsepower from the Abarth engineers.

PATI HERTLING occupies a position in the art world that is both organic and anomalous. She is webbed among family, friends and lovers who populate a rising bicontinental scene: her twin brother, Alexander, is an owner of the upstart Parisian gallery Balice Hertling, which in 2011 opened a branch in New York called Balice Hertling & Lewis; her girlfriend is K8 Hardy, the chameleon performance artist whose photographs are in the current Whitney Biennial. Born in Berlin, Ms. Hertling exudes reserve and discretion (though usually not in the eye makeup department), perhaps exaggerated by the fact that she is a practicing restitution lawyer. What ties it all together, loosely enough, is that she moonlights as a curator. ''Heart to Hand,'' a group show she organized around the idea of ''art being received in connection to a political progress of thought,'' is on view at the Swiss Institute in SoHo until April 15. Go to swissinstitute.net. KEVIN McGARRY

To navigate New York's mass transit is to experience all of this competitive city's struggles, pleasures and pains, only transposed underground, into the subterranean arena otherwise known as a train station. Faced with sprints, crowded staircases and down-to-the-minute departure times, the successful urban traveler must display an agility and athleticism akin to a gladiator's. And in an environment where seconds count, there are glorious triumphs and heartbreaking defeats.

WITH straps that form sparkly starfish, the latest glitterific Miu Miu shoes are beach sandals at their best. Conical crystals mimic the ocean creatures' rough, pumice texture; a thick layer of gold glitter beneath them reads like pyrite sand; the leather piping is the ideal seaside color: coral. Every detail has been applied and assembled by hand (so walk away from the salt water). Miu Miu sandals, $695, (212) 641-2980. JANE HERMAN
