RATTNER--Miriam, nee Weinstock, 89, of Forest Hills and Ocean Beach died unexpectedly on April 3. She leaves behind her devoted children, Judith (Michael Di Bari) and Kenneth (Patricia) and adoring grandchildren Rebecca, Sofia, Casey and Samantha, as well as her sister, Evelyn Virshup and extended family and friends. She was predeceased by her loving husband of 56 years, Nathaniel. A retired New York City elementary school teacher, she was a 30-year-member of Community Planning Board 6 and always involved in civic affairs. Active until the end, she was an avid bridge and scrabble player, crossword aficionado, former tennis player, dedicated reader of the New York Times and lover of the arts. She will be sorely missed. Memorial service is set for April 9th, at 11am at Gutterman's in Rockville Centre.

BUTTENHEIM--Curtis R.,93, died March 12 at home in Dennis, MA after a brief illness. Born in Hastings-on-Hudson, NY on October 10, 1918, son of Edgar J. and Marian Voorhees Buttenheim, he was a 1936 graduate of The Taft School in Watertown, CT and a 1940 graduate of Yale University. In World War II Buttenheim was stationed in Calcutta, India where he attained the rank of Captain in the US Army. He taught at the Russell Ranch School in Tucson, AZ before joining the family business, Buttenheim Publishing Corporation, from which he retired as Vice President in 1975. During his career he resided in Lookout Mountain, TN; Ossining, NY; and Stockbridge, MA before moving to Dennis. A supporter of the arts wherever he lived, Buttenheim twice served as Co-Chair of the Council of Friends of Tanglewood in Lenox, MA, and was a member of the Board of Overseers of the Boston Symphony Orchestra. He was an early supporter of Shakespeare and Company and served as a Trustee of the Berkshire Country Day School, both in Lenox, and served as a Trustee of the Norman Rockwell Museum in Stockbridge. He was an early board member of the Cape Cod Museum of Art in Dennis. In 1953 Buttenheim married Patricia L. Johnson of Pittsburgh, PA, who survives him, as do their children, Lisa M. Buttenheim of Nicosia, Cyprus; Edgar J. Buttenheim II of Franklin, MA; Curtis R. Jr. of Los Angeles, CA; and Patricia M. Buttenheim of New York, NY. He is also survived by two grandchildren, James Curtis and Mary Catherine Buttenheim; a sister, Constance Swain of Sarasota, FL and brother Edgar M. of Princeton, NJ. A private funeral was held on March 17 in Barnstable, MA. Donations may be sent to the Taft School/Buttenheim Family Scholarship, 110 Woodbury Road, Watertown, CT 06795.

''I think it's part of our job as public fund managers to do our best to drive a better bargain.'' Joseph A. Dear, the chief investment officer for Calpers, California's giant state pension system, which is pushing managers of hedge funds to lower fees.

An article on March 25 about the actress Elena Roger, who is starring in ''Evita'' on Broadway, referred imprecisely to Ms. Roger's experience in dance. While she once toured Europe with a tango company for three months, she is not a considered a professional tango dancer. The article also misstated the current plans for Ms. Roger's understudy, Christina DeCicco. She is scheduled to take over the role of Eva Perón during Wednesday night performances, not during matinees.

WILLIAMS-SONOMA, the company that has lured every amateur Alice Waters into the kitchen with the promise of gleaming, chef-grade pots and pans and all manner of specialized countertop appliances, not only wants you to prepare your own food but also to grow it. It has introduced Agrarian, a collection of just about everything one might possibly need to make the leap from seed to table, including cedar garden beds, organic soil, heirloom seeds, copper gardening tools, even a chic dark denim gardening apron. For the more adventurous, there are portable chicken coops (above). Or for those who don't want to get their hands dirty there all the accouterments for ''putting up'' the fruits and vegetables you ''picked'' at your local farmers' market. In keeping with the locavore spirit, the emphasis is on small producers like Brooklyn Slate, which makes garden markers, and Fire Escape Farms, a company in Northern California whose leafy greens and seed packets are also part of the mix. ''It's about building community through food,'' said Daron Joffe (affectionately known as Farmer D), an organic farmer and advocate who produces the raised beds from sustainably harvested cedar in Atlanta. ''There is a lot of opportunity for growth.'' ALIX BROWNE
KELLNER--Zoe. Impossible to believe it has been 5 years. We think of you and miss you every day. Your legacy of loving and being loved by so many will live forever. Love, Mom and John

KARL BRADL and Robert Gerstner established Aedes de Venustas, their jewel-box store on Christopher Street, as a premier source for elegant and avant-garde fragrances years ago. So it comes as no surprise that the aroma experts have now created a namesake Signature Eau de Parfum ($225). Enlisting the help of the master perfumer Bertrand Duchaufour, the duo decided against a traditional perfume pyramid structure, which features top, base and bottom notes, in favor of a more even equation: hints of rhubarb and Madagascar vetiver meld in unison with rich incense of wood and leaf. Go to aedes.com. EDWARD BARSAMIAN

MAYER--Helen Waren, 96, on April 4, 2012. Her first passion was the theatre. She was a member of Clifford Odets' Theatre Union and had five featured roles on Broadway. During WWII she served in the USO and became a member of the Jewish underground. She dedicated the next 10 years to the establishment of the State of Israel. Later, as a consummate New Yorker, Helen served as President of Lincoln Square Community Center, founded and directed The Double Image Theatre and the Seasoned Citizens Theatre Workshop. Her life was dedicated to shattering stereotypes, serving her community and breaking down social barriers. Cherished wife of the late Jules Mayer, survived by her brother Stanley Waren, her son Max Mayer and granddaughter Jude Mayer. Service Sunday, 4pm at "The Riverside", 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.
REARDON--Dr. Ruth C. August 13, 1933, died April 6, 2012. Daughter of the late James and Ruth Reardon. Mass of Resurrection, 10am, Tuesday, St. Vincent Ferrer Church, 869 Lexington Ave.

GREEN--Hubert D.,of West Hempstead, NY, died April 5 peacefully at his home at the age of 95. He was the loving husband of the late Esther Mayer Green, devoted father of Robert Green and Nancy Green, loving father-in-law of Jerome Katz and Jane Heitman Green, adored grandfather of Jonathan, Elizabeth, Andrew and Adam, and loving companion of Rita Pollack. As a U.S. Army radio operator on an unarmed transport plane during World War II, he helped deliver Allied paratroopers at the beginning of the June 1944 D-Day invasion. Hubie will always be remembered for his integrity, wonderful sense of humor, zest for life, devotion to friends and family, and the love he inspired in his caregivers during his final years. Hubie loved tennis, the occasional Southern Comfort Manhattan, and the New York Mets, in good times and bad. Hubie was also a tireless and loyal worker, employed as an engineer until the age of 87. A funeral will be held at the Riverside Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY, on April 8 at 11am.
BATTERBERRY--Michael. Remembering my beloved Michael on what would be his 80th birthday. Terribly missed by all. Ariane.

The Titanic exhibition in Belfast opened late last month, promising the world's largest display of materials on the ship built and launched from the city 100 years ago. But for Titanic buffs who can't make the trip to Ireland, a few exhibitions on our shores promise a look at the now mythic voyage. The Mystic Aquarium in Connecticut focuses on the ship's eventual recovery with a show called ''Titanic -- 12,450 Feet Below,'' which opens on Thursday. The display, organized with the explorer Robert Ballard, who discovered the shipwreck in 1985, includes images, recreated relics, rare videos and interviews with the crew that found it.

Thomas Kinkade, the prolific painter of bucolic and idealized scenes who estimated that his mass-produced works hung in one out of 20 American homes, died on Friday at his home in Los Gatos, Calif. He was 54. He appeared to have died of natural causes, according to a statement that his family issued to The San Jose Mercury News.

8 P.M. (13, 49) FINDING YOUR ROOTS WITH HENRY LOUIS GATES JR. The married actors Kevin Bacon and Kyra Sedgwick, above, are both descended from prominent American families that have been in this country since its inception. But this episode reveals other similarities, including ancestors who were early abolitionists. Mr. Bacon's Quaker clan repudiated slavery in 1780. And in 1781 Theodore Sedgwick argued the case of Elizabeth Freeman, known as Mumbet, which helped end slavery in Massachusetts. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS In a special Easter broadcast with Jake Tapper filling in for Mr. Stephanopoulos, Pastor Rick Warren of the Saddleback Church in Lake Forest, Calif., talks about the spiritual climate of the nation, culture wars, the intersection of church and state, and keeping faith in difficult times. Mr. Tapper also speaks with Mr. Warren's wife, Kay Warren, about her new book, ''Choose Joy: Because Happiness Isn't Enough.''

WEIDMAN--Lucy, on April 5, 2012. Lucy died peacefully from cancer, discovered shortly after she suffered a stroke in January. She graduated Tilden High School, attended Vassar College, and graduated Sarah Lawrence College in 1979. Lucy was a gifted painter and designer, and was beloved by family and friends. Daughter of the late Henrietta (Queenie) and Hyman (Kitty) Katz, she is survived by husband Edwin; brothers Henry and Richard; children James, Peter, David and Jennifer; children-in-law Marsha, Debbi, Debbie and Barry; and grandchildren Amanda, Samuel, Hilary, Rachel, Katie, Lauren, Julia, Isabel and Benjamin. In Lucy's memory, please consider a donation to your favorite art museum. Service Monday, April 9, 11:45am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

An article on March 25 about the Lower Ninth Ward of New Orleans since Hurricane Katrina misspelled the given name of a geographer who called New Orleans ''the inevitable city on the an impossible site.'' He is Peirce Lewis, not Pierce.

Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about documentaries on animals referred incorrectly to John Berger's 1977 essay ''Why Look at Animals?'' Mr. Berger wrote that the emergence of zoos, pet keeping and animal toys was part of early modernization; he did not say that the birth of cinema was a signal achievement of that period of modernization. (That point was made by the writer of the article.)

CUTOLO--Louis, Sr.,MD. The SUNY Downstate Medical Center community mourns the passing of Louis Cutolo, Sr., MD, clinical associate professor of surgery. A graduate of Long Island College of Medicine, Downstate's predecessor institution, he served on the attending staff faculty at Long Island College Hospital for 48 years, chaired the Tumor Board, directed the Tumor Registry, and was primarily responsible for maintenance of LICH's continuing successful accreditation. We offer our deepest sympathies to his wife, Virginia, daughter, Dorothy, and son, Louis Jr. John C. LaRosa, MD President Marwan William Atallah, MD, President, Medical Staff Antonio Alfonso, MD Chair, Department of Surgery

A French-cuffed shirt requires cuff links; it seems pretty obvious to me now. However, 10 years ago, when I first removed the pins and packaging from a dress shirt and threaded my arms through the sleeves, I was that most hapless class of human being -- a college intern. It was my first morning in New York; I had just woken up on my friend Dan's couch in Murray Hill; and I had one hour to go before the scheduled start of my professional life. I was to be an investment banker, if I could just get dressed. The bank's dress code was business casual. I figured that meant something sharp, like a pair of Dockers. Or since I didn't own any khakis, how about my tan, five-pocket corduroys? One of the belt loops had come loose, and yes, the cuffs had begun to fray. But these were not jeans and thus were dress pants, perfectly acceptable for Sunday church back in Iowa and therefore equally appropriate for one of Manhattan's revered financial institutions. Dan had already left for work, or else, presumably, he would have questioned some aspects of this logic.

I know there are some people who abuse the system. But I was willing to do anything they asked me to. If I could, I'd still be working for those two dollars an hour. TAMIKA SHELBY, whose welfare benefits have been cut as restrictions have grown. [18]

HECKER--William J.,Sr., on April 4, 2012. Beloved husband of Elizabeth Ann. Loving father of William J. and the late Denise Hecker Pereira. Devoted grandfather of Meg, Thomas and Kate. Memorial service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Monday 11:30am.

David Cone pitched for six major league teams from 1986 to 2003, posting a 194-126 record, with a 3.46 earned run average and 2,668 strikeouts. A member of five World Series championship teams, he pitched a perfect game for the Yankees in 1999.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Touchy Day at Augusta National Men's Club,'' April 5: I got where I am today because of public golf courses and because of the people and facilities that support young women playing the game. I first became attached to golf when I saw a major championship, the 2001 United States Open; these major events have that power. Does Augusta National not realize the implications of a policy or a statement?

WEINER--Arnold. Beloved husband, father and grandfather, passed away on March 24, 2012 after a long illness. A chemist and chemical engineer, he helped form Macrosonics and then worked for Pall Corporation for 36 years. In retirement, he became a financial planner. He will be missed by all who knew him.

To the Sports Editor: ''After Title Run, the Starting 5 Rush the Exit'' (April 4) barely nibbles at the edge of the travesty known as N.C.A.A. basketball. The players are exploited to generate billions of dollars in profits. They ought to be paid for their efforts. David Lussier

To the Sports Editor: Re ''After Howls of Protest, WTA Will Address Shrieks,'' March 31: What would the WTA and the television networks say if they heard nobody would purchase anything advertised on a station where a screamer was playing? I watch on mute, and do not buy anything advertised during those matches. Liz Neumann

SEROY--Sandra, fashion industry veteran, dies at 67 on March 24th. Sandra Seroy died at the Mount Sinai Medical Center in Miami. The cause of death was chronic heart failure. Sandra is survived by her son, Gerald Seroy, her grandchildren Jack and Lila Seroy and her husband Frank Crivello. Over the span of a forty-six year career in the fashion industry, Sandra worked together with her late husband Michael, to build the Michael Seroy label. Then starting in the early nineties she went on to become a top U.S. senior executive for a number of leading European fashion brands such as Max Mara, Genny, Gianfranco Ferre and Brioni. She was highly recruited by European fashion houses for her incredible knowledge of the U.S. market and her relationships with the top executives at the largest retailers. Her accomplishments are matched by the wonderful friends, family and business colleagues that she leaves behind and will never forget her. A private memorial service will be held in June in Southampton. (fcrivello@gmail.com). In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to WIN-Women In Need (www.women-in-need.org/)

In ''Putting In Their 2 Cents,'' on the cover of last Sunday's Metropolitan section, Soni Sangha wrote about an experiment that gives New Yorkers in four City Council districts control of a slice of their council members' discretionary budgets. (An update is on Page 2.) On Facebook, readers shared their thoughts on participatory budgeting; a selection of their comments is below. On nytimes.com, readers responded to an article about a downloadable audio guide to East Village literary history. A sop to the public. I'd rather they voted sensibly on the larger portion of their budget and not based on corporate and union interests.Lee Drake

Mr. Tress has taken many photographs of children, frequently showing them sleeping or in states of reverie, a common subject for artists with a Surrealist bent. The untitled documentary shot from 1964, left, shows a little girl from behind, sitting alone, as she watches the crowd on Van Ness Avenue in San Francisco. ''The shadows of the adult world are passing before her, but she's quite calm,'' Mr. Tress said.
THE BIG PROFILE MICHELLE YEOH

One reason the San Francisco Giants sell out every game, said their chief executive, Larry Baer, is that fans relate to the different personalities on the roster. The eccentric ones stand out most: Brian Wilson is the raging, bearded closer; Pablo Sandoval is the jovial panda of a third baseman; Tim Lincecum is the little, long-haired ace. Matt Cain, meanwhile, is the ''nose-to-the-grindstone guy,'' Baer said. Cain is the unassuming right-hander from Tennessee - bright enough to be the team's union representative at 24, loyal enough to sign a contract extension before free agency.

Depending on whether you read this online or on paper, via home delivery or in your shrink's waiting room, today may be your last chance to contribute to the Ethicist's once-in-a-lifetime, globe-spanning, paradigm-upending reader contest, on the subject of meat. Specifically, why it's ethical for human beings to eat other animals, at least when their own survival is not on the line -- an area of inquiry that meat-eaters have until now largely ceded to vegetarians and vegans. Entries have poured in by the hundreds, but the doors are open only until 9 p.m., April 8. To review: Entries must be no longer than 600 words, and must be sent to ethicist@nytimes.com. Check out the full details -- and our panel of hard-to-impress judges -- at nytimes.com/magazine. But do it fast! e-mail queries to ethicist@nytimes.com and include a daytime phone number.

Cholera is on the rise around the world. Last year, according to Unicef, West and Central Africa had ''one of the worst ever'' cholera outbreaks. An outbreak in Haiti sickened 1 in 20 Haitians and killed more than 7,000 people. The World Health Organization estimates that there are between three million and five million cases of cholera each year, and between 100,000 and 120,000 deaths. New and more virulent strains are emerging in Asia and Africa, and the W.H.O. says that global warming creates even more hospitable conditions for the disease. In most parts of the world, the last few months have brought a respite. But April is the start of the rainy season, which is also the cholera season.

FISCHBACH--Stella, died peacefully in her home with family by her side on the morning of April 2, 2012 at the age of 102. She is survived by her daughter Judith Berke of Miami Beach and many devoted nieces and nephews. Mrs. Fischbach, along with her husband Harry, was a founding member of the Israel Museum, Jerusalem, whose modern art department bears her name. For 45 years she was an active member of the executive committee of the American Friends of the Israel Museum and was a committed and generous patron of the arts and education. She was an aesthete and a woman of great style and integrity. She will be profoundly missed by all who knew and loved her.

SPINNER--Marion, beloved widow of Herman, loving mother of Annie Borofsky and Jan Spinner, cherished sister of Paul and William Fried, died on March 31, 2012 at the age of 89. The matriarch of a large and adoring family, she overcame adversity with strength, grace, joy, and a marvelously acerbic wit. She will be deeply missed.

See a larger version of the forest from this week. Compare with the enlarged version of last week's image. It was kite-flying weather last Friday morning. When the wind kicks up at our site, tender tree branches arc and bow. At my feet, the leaves of wild leeks undulate like a tempestuous sea.

WEIDMAN--Lucy. Always in our hearts. We love and will miss you. The Crames Family

The Riff column on Page 52 this weekend, about musical obscurity and how it is no longer an honor, misspells the surname of a singer about whom everybody knows something (or at least something other than her name). She is Lana Del Rey, not Ray.

Couchsurfing.org and Airbnb.com offer home stays to travelers seeking an alternative to hotels. Now your dog can get a similar service: a home instead of a kennel. DogVacay.com, introduced March 1, compiles dog boarders across the United States and Canada who will house, feed and water your pup in their homes for a fee. Hosts are vetted through interviews and reference checks, and some claim professional credentials like pet CPR. Dog owners can schedule a meet-and-greet session beforehand, which in some cases includes meeting the dogs that live with the host full time. The site also sells insurance and offers GPS-enabled dog collars for those seeking extra assurance.

Point Clear, Ala. The Battle of Shiloh began at sunrise on April 6, 1862 -- the Sabbath -- as 44,000 Confederate soldiers swooped down on an unsuspecting Union Army encampment near Pittsburg Landing, a nondescript hog-and-cotton steamboat dock on the Tennessee River. What followed were two of the bloodiest days of the Civil War, leaving nearly 24,000 men on both sides dead, dying or wounded.
'I was told it was true by people in our management. ' STAN VAN GUNDY,

DRACHMAN--Sally Ann, died peacefully at home in Auburndale, Mass. Formerly of Scarsdale and Mamaroneck, NY, she was born in New York City on December 15, 1920 to Solomon S. and Helen Goldsmith Rudolph. She was a graduate of the Fieldston School and Cornell University. She was the beloved wife of the late Dr. Stanley R. Drachman and the late Charles Brand; loving mother of Virginia of Newton, Mass., Susan of Saratoga Springs, NY, Josh, of Seattle, Wash., and Dori of Peterborough, NH; grandmother of Wendy and Andrew Van Raalte, and Abigail and Eliza Drachman-Jones. She was the sister of the late Alan G. Rudolph of Clinton Corners, NY, and niece of the late Reuben, Isaac, and Benjamin Goldsmith of Goldsmith Brothers Stationers, New York City. She was an avid reader, an adventurous traveler, and an eternal optimist. Contributions may be made in Sally's memory to the Ethical Culture Fieldston School or WGBH Boston.

It has been said that if you cut off the head, the body will die. At this point, most Eastern Conference teams are probably wondering just what part of the Chicago Bulls qualifies as the head. The obvious answer is Derrick Rose, the N.B.A.'s reigning most valuable player. Rose is leading the team with a player efficiency rating of 24.8, which qualifies for sixth in the league. He is also leading the team in points (22.8 a game) and assists (8).

BERLIN--Dr. Irwin. The Trustees, Staff and Artists of Signature Theatre all mourn the loss of former Trustee and one of our earliest advocates, Dr. Irwin Berlin. He was a wonderful guy with a tremendous wit and big heart. We send our deepest sympathies to his family, friends and all those he touched.

I was on assignment for Sports Illustrated for a story on Muhammad Ali, who was known as Cassius Clay at the time, so I went to visit his parents' house in Louisville, Ky. I took a lot of photos of Ali playing with the neighborhood kids, romping around in front of his parents' house. The kids loved him. Lonnie Ali: That was May of 1963. I was 61/2 then. I was just starting to lose my teeth. I was scared to death. I was scared of boys anyways and especially scared of this man I didn't know. Muhammad had just turned 21 in January.

THIS is a confusing time of year at the greenmarkets in New York. While the sunny afternoons have the feel of early summer, the farmland in the Northeast is only just easing into spring: you might crave asparagus and shell peas, but all you'll find at the markets in Union Square or Grand Army Plaza are root vegetables left over from the fall and spring's first lettuces. Which are exactly the ingredients you need for the Patates Douces, Oignons Rouges and Pickled Walnut served at Le Bal Café, a Paris restaurant and café on the ground floor of a dance hall turned photography center and bookstore (below). The dish is a comforting composition, still-warm roasted sweet potatoes and red onions tossed with pickled walnuts, capers and whatever flavorful greens look good that day. It's what you want to eat on these brisk afternoons. Le Bal Café, 6 Impasse de la Défense, Paris, le-bal.fr. OLIVER STRAND

An article last Sunday about the Shelby Cobra sports car misidentified the source of the financing that supported the racing career of Lance Reventlow. He was an heir to the Woolworth fortune, not Revlon.

MURPHY--Rev. Edward J.,S.J., on April 4, 2012. Loving brother of Sr. Margaret Mary Murphy S.C. and Dennis Murphy. Predeceased by his brother Timothy Murphy. Reposing at the Murray-Weigel Hall Chapel, 515 E. Fordham Rd., Bronx, NY on Sunday from 7-9pm and on Monday from 3-5 and 7-9pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at the Fordham University Church on Tuesday at 10:30am. Interment will take place at the Jesuit Martyrs' Shrine, Auriesville, NY. For information contact Farenga Bros. Inc., Directors (718) 654-0500.

ARE alarm bells going off at the 59E59 Theaters? They should be, since the playwright David Harrower has left a man and a woman alone on a stage there. The last time Mr. Harrower did this, in his Olivier Award-winning ''Blackbird'' (staged by the Manhattan Theater Club in 2007), the chemistry between his characters was so toxic that many of us who saw it still feel the burn. His current offering, opening on Thursday, has the ominous title ''A SLOW AIR.'' It is ostensibly a portrait of a relationship between a long-estranged brother and sister, played by Lewis Howden and Susan Vidler. But the play's scope turns out to range far beyond matters domestic. (The 2007 terrorist attack on the Glasgow Airport is a fulcrum of the plot.) Mr. Harrower has referred to ''A Slow Air'' as ''a Scotland play,'' which considers ''how the certainties with which people grew up have been challenged.'' The production is part of 59E59 Theaters' Scotland Week celebration, which also includes Gerda Stevenson's ''Federer Versus Murray.'' (And it is not, for the record, exclusively about tennis.) 59 East 59th Street, Manhattan, (212) 279-4200, 59e59.org; $35 (''A Slow Air'') and $25 (''Federer versus Murray'').

An article on March 30 about the independent Texas power grid, which occasionally leans heavily on its few links to the outside, incorrectly stated the plan for a transmission line in College Station in case of emergencies. The linkup is intended to allow the Electric Reliability Council of Texas to feed power to the eastern grid when problems arise there, rather than shifting College Station's electrical load out of Ercot during emergencies.

MIAO--Mouchi Sha, at 93, beloved mother of four, grandmother of nine, great-grandmother of five, died March 11, 2012. Born in Jiangyin, Jiangsu, China, she came to the US in 1948, lived in Bayside, Westbury, Melville, NY, and Monroe, NJ. Service: Kingston Presbyterian Church, Kingston, NJ, April 14, 2012 at 11:30am. Beatrice, Evelyn, Tremont, Walter

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Pay for Women's Basketball Coaches Lags Far Behind That of Men's Coaches,'' April 3: How come no comparison is made to the highest-paid professor and the men's and women's coaches? No Division I coach makes less than the professors at the college. In fact, most of these coaches make more than the university president.

AUGUSTA, Ga. -- Luke Donald knows the exact moment he wrote off his chances of winning the Masters: When his second shot at the par-5 13th looked to have plenty of carry but hit the top edge of the bank in front of the green and rolled back into the water. ''I have a chance to make a 4 or 3 there and get back to 2-over or 1-over, maybe pick up a couple more and get into red numbers, and I end up making a 7,'' Donald said. ''That was it probably.''

Music snobbery has, like a lot of subcultures, a jingo-laden, elitist downside, but for some reason music snobbery tends to anger people more than, say, comic-book collecting or film snobbery. I think people are doubly hostile to pop-music snobbery because there's something elemental to our lives about music that makes it easier to be defensive if someone knows more about it than you do, particularly if it's something you like. I've definitely felt the anguish of looking like a rube next to someone more knowledgeable about something I like, and the initial reaction can be anger and rejection. But learning new information about pop music is generally worth sucking a little humble pie.

December 2011, Luang Prabang, Laos Since we both have French ancestry, my husband, Paul, and I like to go to countries that once had a connection with France. We wanted to go to Vientiane in Laos to get the feel of the city, to see what French colonial buildings remain and to see the genocide museum and the killing fields. What we hoped for was to find out if the old French influence was still visible, if the French language was still spoken by some people, how Laotian people view their past as a French colony and how they view Americans since the end of the Vietnam War. This picture of a young Buddhist novice was taken on the bamboo bridge, which has to be rebuilt annually after it is swept away by rising waters on the Nam Khan River. The bridge links the city of Luang Prabang to picturesque villages like Ban Phong Pheng, on the other side of the river. It was taken around 4 p.m., when the Buddhist novices come back home from their studies. DENIS KOHLMULLER, Brooklyn

PETERSON--Marcia Helen, 65, of New York City, died March 29, 2012, at New York Downtown Hospital. Ms. Peterson was the daughter of architect Ralph Delos Peterson, Jr., and Virginia (Cole) Peterson. Born June 22, 1946, in Brooklyn, NY, she grew up in Englewood, CO. She graduated with honors from Cherry Creek High School in 1964. She also attended the University of Chicago, St. John's College in Santa Fe, NM, and the University of Illinois, Chicago campus. Her entire professional career was devoted to publishing. She was a fact checker for the final edition of the Encyclopedia Britannica and later worked as a copyeditor at The University of Chicago Press and Northwestern University Press, where she edited books in both English and French. In 1972 she moved to New York City where she joined Simon and Schuster Publishing as a copyeditor in their Trade Books Department, rising to the position of vice president. She is survived by her loving sister Constance Ellen Peterson of New York City, her aunt Helen Wildermuth of East Lyme, CT, and many cousins. An avid reader, music lover, traveler, and craftsperson, she was a great lover of animals. Contributions in her name may be sent to the Humane Society of the United States: www.humanesociety.org or to Defenders of Wildlife www.defenders.org. A private memorial service will be held at a later date.

BORN--Esther. Beloved wife of Robert Born a blessed memory. Devoted mother to Rita and Fred Distenfeld and Debbie and Richard Born. Adoring grandmother to Mikey and Erica, Caroline and Zac, Jenny and Benjy, Claire, and Max. Number one fan of her great-grand- daughter Julia, loving sister to Harry Wittlin. Our beautiful, wise and adored mother has found her peace. She maintained her poise and dignity throughout her life. She will be sorely missed and always in our thoughts.
To the Sports Editor: Re ''Backup to Starter to Phenomenon. Repeat.'' March 31: Tim Tebow was pictured praying on the football field. Again.

Here is a sign of how dominant Detroit's Justin Verlander was last season: throwing only one no-hitter left him disappointed. ''I feel like I should have done it two more times,'' Verlander said, mentioning two bids he lost in the eighth inning.

MOMENTUM has always been a core principle for the VIJAY IYER TRIO, one of jazz's sharpest small groups, and one of its most rhythm obsessed. ''Accelerando'' (ACT), released last month, takes that preoccupation to its logical extreme: the album is about how music articulates human motion. That might sound like an academic premise -- and it has been, for the band's namesake pianist. But this isn't chin-stroking music; its aim and effect are visceral. Mr. Iyer has a percussive attack at the piano, along with a habit of digging in, kneading the keys. Stephan Crump lays a strong undertow on bass, his notes ringing purposefully plump. And Marcus Gilmore uses his drums and cymbals ingeniously, swarming the beat while laying back. He's one of the most excitingly kinetic drummers in jazz, and this is his best outlet so far. ''Accelerando'' came about after extensive touring in support of ''Historicity,'' the trio's previous album on the same label.

STEINBERG--Elan. The World Jewish Congress mourns the tragic and untimely death of Elan Steinberg, the WJC's long-time Executive Director and a pivotal figure in our fight for Jewish rights throughout the world. He played a critical role in the fight to obtain restitution for Holocaust survivors from Swiss banks and other European countries and corporations, and was the strategist behind the campaign to expose Kurt Waldheim's Nazi past. He was a tireless advocate for Israel and Jewish rights everywhere. Our deepest condolences go to his devoted wife Sharon, their children Max, Harry and Lena, and their entire family. Ronald S Lauder, President Dan Diker, Secretary General

A credit on March 25 with an article about the post-graduation experience of the Class of 2011 from Drew University in Madison, N.J., misspelled the surname of one member who wrote about the three jobs she is working now. She is Eri Rosshirt, not Rosshart. The credit for another member, Benjamin Lynch, misidentified his employer and misstated his current academic status. He works for Fairfield Advisors L.L.C.,not Fairfield Financial Advisors, and he is taking pre-master's financial engineering courses at Baruch; he is not a master's candidate in financial-engineering there. The article also misstated a category of liberal-arts colleges in an annual ranking by U.S.News & World Report; it is national, not private.

WHO doesn't love seeing the word ''free'' attached to the words ''film festival''? The annual DISAPPEARING ACT festival of European films begins on Wednesday, and except for the opening-night screening of ''The System,'' admission to all films is free, on a first come basis. The festival, sponsored by various European cultural institutes and continuing through April 22, will showcase 25 recent movies. ''The System,'' a German film by Marc Bauder receiving its United States premiere, involves a young dropout who encounters former East German secret service agents, among others. Mr. Bauder will be at the Wednesday showing, which is at 7 p.m. at the IFC Center (323 Avenue of the Americas, at Third Street, Greenwich Village; $13). One of the movie's screenwriters, Dörte Franke, is also scheduled to appear.

GROSSMAN--Will, MD, A prominent New York internist and cardiologist, died peacefully in his home of metastatic melanoma. He was tended lovingly throughout his illness by his beloved wife Soony. He is survived by his brother Howard and his family. A memorial service will be held at 3:30pm on Sunday, April 22, 2012 at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue (81st Street). Born in the Bronx, NY on October 18, 1932, he graduated from the prestigious Bronx High School of Science in 1948, the University of Pennsylvania in 1953, and the New York University School of Medicine in 1957. He was certified by the American Board of Internal Medicine and the American Board of Cardiovascular Disease. From 1959 to 1961, he served as a captain in the U.S. Air Force in Evreux France, where he honed a taste for gourmet food and fine wines. After leaving the Air Force, he was closely associated with Beth Israel Medical Center in New York, initially as director of geriatric medicine at the Gouverneur Clinic from 1966 to 1972. Gouverneur, on the Lower East Side, where Beth Israel had its origins, was a renowned and innovative clinic. He mentored scores of health professionals in that setting, providing a unique and humane practice of health care delivery to the poor and underserved. In 1978, he initiated a private practice of internal medicine and cardiology at Madison Avenue and 72nd Street. Participating fully in the cultural life of New York's theater, music and arts, the Grossmans also traveled extensively in the United States, Asia, Europe and Africa. Will was an accomplished photographer and birder, and he often made these activities the center of their travels. Over the years, he acquired a notable collection of U.S. duck decoy and shore bird carvings and was well recognized at Eastern shore auctions as a knowledgeable and perceptive collector. The gentle art of good listening made him a beloved friend and companion and enhanced his skills as a physician. He was a devoted husband and loving friend, a man with a great zest for life, a gift for friendship and a compassionate and caring nature. Beloved by colleagues and friends, his true genius showed in his relationship with his patients. He instilled in them a remarkable level of confidence and trust inspired by his warmth, compassion, attentiveness and wisdom. Scores of colleagues, friends, and patients made their way to the Grossman home over the course of his illness to pay him tribute. People of widely diverse backgrounds including notables like Ban Ki-moon, Secretary-General of the United Nations, Milton Glaser, the celebrated and pre-eminent graphics designer, and Dr. Howard Gray, renowned immunologist and president of the Scripps Institute of La Jolla came to praise a good man. In this day of hyperbole, Will Grossman was the essence of goodness. He will be sorely missed by the multitude of friends, patients and colleagues whose lives he touched deeply. May his name be a blessing for us all.

An article on March 25 about World Wrestling Entertainment's movie operation misidentified which Muppets movie was promoted on the cable television show ''Monday Night Raw'' last Halloween. It was ''The Muppets'' -- not ''The Muppet Movie,'' which came out in 1979.

Travelers who want to shave time off a four-hour car drive don't have many options. Amtrak's Acela Express has just a single route. And given airport procedures, flying isn't such a shortcut. Surf Air (surfair.com), an airline starting this summer, has designs on that short-haul sweet spot. Its concept: eight-seater, first-class planes fly daily loops through uncongested regional airports (inaugural route: Van Nuys-Palo Alto-Monterey/Pebble Beach-Santa Barbara). For a $3,000 membership fee during the initial three-month trial -- and for up to $1,500 each month thereafter -- members can fly as many times as they wish along that route, subject to availability. They can drive to the airport, hand their car keys to a valet, wheel their bags up to the pilot, and board.

LINDNER--Victor, 95, of Randolph, New Jersey died on March 20. Associate Technical Director for Systems Development and Engineering at Picatinny Arsenal, he was an internationally- known authority in the research and development of armaments. During his 57-year career, his leadership was instrumental in the Arsenal's development of innovative high-tech ordnance. Before his 1998 retirement Mr. Lindner received many awards, including two from Presidents Ronald Reagan and George Bush, and an honorary doctorate from Inha University in Korea. In 1990 he was inducted into the Ordnance Hall of Fame. He was a visiting professor at Stevens Institute of Technology until age 90. Mr. Lindner established six scholarships and research grants, including at his alma maters, City College of New York and New Jersey Institute of Technology. He donated his home to The Nature Conservancy and founded the Mary A. Lindner and Clarice Olinger gardens at Frelinghuysen Arboretum. Born in Manhattan to Sam and Clara Lindner, he was preceded in death by his first wife Mary Lindner and a brother Murray. He is survived by his beloved second wife, Clarice Olinger, two children, Vicki Lindner of Denver, David of Albuquerque, brother Raymond, and nephews Richard, Gary, and Lawrence Lindner. Contributions go to Planned Parenthood of New Jersey.

An interview on March 25 with Sandra Lee, the cookbook author and girlfriend of Gov. Andrew Cuomo, referred imprecisely to the presidency of Chester A. Arthur, in relation to a potential run by Cuomo for the office. While Arthur was single for the entirety of his term, he did not serve a full one; he became president after James Garfield died in office, serving from September 1881 until March 1885.

KROLL--Douglas 7/67 4/8/02 Ten years later/m, your life is proof that a great, loving soul always lives on. You are in our hearts and in our thoughts every day. Your love keeps us warm; your strength keeps us strong. Your love, compassion and courage continue to inspire and sustain us. Love Mom, Pamela, close friends and family

The Video column on March 25 about the John Ford western ''Fort Apache'' referred incorrectly to a painting that is mentioned in the film. ''Thursday's Last Stand,'' named after one of the characters in the movie, is only described in the film; it is not shown. And a picture caption with the article, using information from a publicist, misidentified the actor shown standing with John Wayne behind an overturned covered wagon. He was Ray Hyke, not John Agar.

Things that might have happened long ago and far away come back to happen here and now in ''LAST TOUCH FIRST,'' by Jiri Kylian, the Czech-born former director of Nederlands Dans Theater, and Michael Schumacher, an American dancer based in Europe. They might even have called it ''Remembrance of Things Past,'' except for the stumbling block of Proust. Even so, this hourlong 2008 creation does evoke a sense of vanished times. The setting is a manor-house drawing room with furniture shrouded by immense dust covers; the lighting is sepia toned, as if to evoke old photographs; and the performers might well be ghosts, dancing to a score by the German composer Dirk P. Haubrich that includes sounds of a seemingly far-off piano. Everyone moves with unusual slowness, when they move at all. But this near motionlessness is occasionally broken by sudden acts suggesting that emotions still survive in these specters, passions that can haunt the present. 7:30 p.m. Tuesday and Wednesday, 8 p.m. Thursday and Friday, 2 and 8 p.m. Saturday, 2 p.m. on April 15, Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, Chelsea, (212) 242-0800, joyce.org; $10 to $39.

When last we saw Showtime's blond bombshells of a certain age -- Jackie Peyton, the self-medicating emergency room nurse portrayed by Edie Falco in ''NURSE JACKIE,'' and Cathy Jamison, the cancer patient played by Laura Linney in ''THE BIG C'' -- they were discovering that what goes around comes around. As the seasons wrapped, Cathy confronted not her own mortality but rather that of her husband, Paul (Oliver Platt); she crossed the finish line of a marathon just as he succumbed to a heart attack. And the philandering, pill-popping Jackie sent her spouse, Kevin (Dominic Fumusa), packing after he confessed to having an affair. On Sunday at 9 ''Nurse Jackie'' will admit its tart-tongued protagonist into rehab when a drug-fueled encounter with a stranger results in his death. And at 9:30 ''The Big C'' will begin a new round of gallows humor, as Cathy downs her third martini at a bar and christens the drink a Thirsty Widow. The plot twists could lead to another Emmy Award face-off this year between the consistently stellar Ms. Falco and Ms. Linney -- and prove to women everywhere that 40-something doesn't have to be the new anything. When embodied by these actresses the number is pretty terrific on its own merits.

ROBERTS--Jeanne Addison. October 18, 1924-April 3, 2012. Died at her home. A noted feminist scholar, Dr. Roberts was a Professor of Literature at American University for 30 years. Jeanne also taught at the Folger Shakespeare Library and founded the Folger's Teaching Shakespeare Institute, where she presided as Head Scholar for two years and was a visiting scholar in later years. Her many academic achievements include serving as President of the Shakespeare Association of America, and as President of the Southeast Renaissance Society. She is also a recipient of the South Atlantic Modern Language Association Lifetime Achievement Award. A lifelong patron of the arts, Jeanne was passionate about theatre and the literary arts. She was an active member at the Cosmos Club and in the community, giving lectures at the Osher Lifelong Learning Institute in her retirement. Offering an alternative perspective in a world of male dominated criticisms, Jeanne, provided a feminist analyst of gender in Shakespeare plays. Jeanne has written three books on Shakespeare and other major authors. Her many articles on Swift, Johnson, Milton, Margaret Cavendish and Elizabeth Cary have been published widely in scholarly journals. She has served on the editorial boards of Shakespeare Quarterly, Shakespeare Survey, Shakespeare Studies and the Upstart Crow. Born in Washington, DC, Jeanne is a Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Agnes Scott College and holds a MA from the University of Pennsylvania and a Ph.D from the University of Virginia. She spent four years in Bangkok, Thailand and four years in Beirut Lebanon while teaching and raising her two children. Jeanne is survived by her loving and devoted husband, Markley Roberts; her two children Ellen Coster and Addison Masengill; her brother John West Addison and four grandchildren, Stephanie, Jennifer, Misha and Robert. Jeanne died of complications from breast cancer. A Memorial Service will be held at St. Columba's Episcopal Church, 4201 Albermarle St. NW, Washington, DC on Thursday, April 12 at 11:30am with a reception at the Church to follow. Memorial donations may be made to, Folger Shakespeare Library or the American University Library. For more information, Jeanne Roberts is also listed in Who's Who.

LEVIN--Behna M.,the widow of the late I. Victor Levin, a past member of the New York Stock Exchange, died peacefully in her 91st year. A native New Yorker, Mrs. Levin was the daughter of the late Eva B. Marks and the late Henry C. Marks, a founder of Howard Clothes, who resided in Palm Beach, Florida at the time of her death. She is survived by her children, Eileen Robert of NYC and Steven Levin of Arlington, MA., her granddaughters, Elisabeth Amory Robert of NYC and Alexandra Robert Gordon of San Francisco and two great-grandsons, Eli and Zach Gordon. After a private funeral and interment, the family will be receiving on Monday, April 9th from 4-8 at the home of Eileen Robert. Behna certainly will be missed by all those who loved her dearly!

FANT--Mark E. Died March 5, 2012. Born May 29, 1959 in Bronx, NY. Reared and educated in Great Neck, NY. Graduated from NYU and NYU School of Law; member of the NYU Law Review of Social Justice. Held offices in 100 Black Men, Brooklyn Guardsmen, and was Sire Archon of Zeta Boule Chapter of Sigma Pi Phi Fraternity at his death. He is mourned by his mother, Winnie L. Fant of Great Neck; sisters, Verenice Sicuro (Salvatore), New York City and Lisa Fant of Raleigh, NC, nephews Mattia Sicuro and Ruben Allen. His father, Thomas L. Fant predeceased him. He will be sorely missed. Mark will be memorialized on Saturday, April 14, 2012 at 10:00AM at The Abyssinian Baptist Church, 132 Odell Clark Place, NY 10030. The Reverend Dr. Calvin O. Butts, III, Pastor. The Fant Family

SOMETIMES, though not often, there is immediate chemistry between a conductor and the players of a major orchestra. This happened when the wiry, kinetic Dutch conductor JAAP VAN ZWEDEN first conducted the Dallas Symphony Orchestra in 2006. Soon afterward the organization courted him as music director, and Mr. van Zweden began his tenure there in 2008. He was impressive, if not a knockout, in a 2009 program I heard in Dallas that season. From all reports the musicians and the community are fully behind him. It will be interesting to see if chemistry ignites when Mr. van Zweden makes his debut with the NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC this week. The unadventurous program offers familiar pieces, with the Mahler First as the main work. Prokofiev's exciting Piano Concerto No. 3 features the dazzling young Chinese pianist Yuja Wang. (See article, Page 15.) 7:30 p.m. Thursday, 8 p.m. Friday and Saturday, Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 875-5656, nyphil.org; $41 to $121.

EARLY on a chilly March morning, my iPhone alarm clock sounded. I extracted myself from deep within a navy blue comforter, sat up and opened the door. I had momentarily forgotten where I was. Oh, right. I gazed out at Lake Taupo, a sprawling lake on New Zealand's North Island. Ducks gliding along just offshore were an invigorating sight. So were the mountains that rose behind them, and the predawn periwinkle and orange sky beyond.

GALANT--Lionel. This 'Free Spirit,' was born in San Francisco, born July 11, 1943, died in New York City on March 20, 2012. After high school he traveled extensively as an actor, attending the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art in London. He was a member of SAG and AFTRA and more recently a travel agent. He graduated the CUNY Baccalaureate Cum Laude. Lionel touched many lives with his beautiful soul. He is survived by his wife, Jody Heller Galant, mother, brother, sister, nephews and niece.

AFTER the success of its one-night-only presentation of the singer-artist Antony Hegarty at Radio City Music Hall, the Museum of Modern Art offers an eight-day-only retrospective of the German group KRAFTWERK, starting Tuesday. Kraftwerk -- ''powers station'' in German -- began as a two-man project in Düsseldorf in 1970. Its creators, Ralf Hütter and Florian Schneider, working with multitrack tapes, synthesizers and, increasingly, with digital technology, composed scores that sounded at once spacey and robotic, and had a big impact on early electronic dance music and hip-hop. In the past decade the group has complemented its act with extravagant sets and videos, making it a natural candidate for the museum's current performance art initiative. Over the eight nights, inside the museum itself, the group will cover what is advertised as its complete repertory, from 1974 through 2003. Could it be that the Modern's relentlessly maligned atrium will finally have found its proper use, as a kind of intergalactic sound-and-light machine? Tuesday through April 17, (212) 708-9400, moma.org; sold out. (An exhibition of Kraftwerk audio and visual material is on view at MoMA PS1 in Long Island City, Queens, April 12 to May 14.)

Dashes of color, an eclectic mix of styles, silk scarves catching a spring breeze: vivid harbingers on Fifth Avenue last week for the Easter Parade (which by now, it seems, has become a reminder of an Irving Berlin tune). Top prize among the holiday window displays easily went to children's clothing retailers (parents still love those new spring outfits). For others, spring was signaled by a flower-print skirt (bottom right). Many times, the color mix echoed a bunch of balloons. The farmers' markets stocked branches of cherry blossoms and crab apples. And the few spring coats that were seen resembled an artist's smock, with the collar becoming a bow. Peter J. Rabbit was everywhere, in chocolate or as a carousel ride.
The Possessed column last Sunday, about a dermatologist and his yoga mat, misspelled his given name. He is Fredric Brandt, not Frederic.

NAUGHTON--James, P.,on April 2, 2012 aged 92 years. Adored husband of the late Josephine. Cherished father of James J., Delia, Grace and father-in-law of Jeanette. Loving grandfather of Matthew and Brian. James was a devoted brother, uncle and friend to many. Visitation: Monday from 2-4pm and 7-9pm at John Krtil Funeral Home, Inc. Funeral Mass: Tuesday 9:30am at Mary Manning Walsh. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

Mr. Tress has frequently worked in black and white, and this pair of portraits extends the idea of opposing colors to a metaphorical level. The 1964 image, right, caught on the fly, shows a man in front of a car dealership during a protest of racial discrimination in car sales. ''I think I caught a feeling of anger,'' Mr. Tress said. The repeated reflection of the brand name is striking, but, he added: ''I don't think I ever noticed the three 'Cadillacs' until now. Photographers see the whole moment.''

As White House aides and Congressional leaders flood the media with dueling leaks about just how far President Obama was willing to go last summer to meet the budget-cutting demands of House Speaker John A. Boehner, many liberals have reacted with shock and horror at how much of their historic achievement the president appears to have been ready to bargain away. If a Democratic president could consider cutting America's shredded safety net further when unemployment remained stiffly high and the country was undergoing an explosion of inequality, was the ''liberal moment'' of American politics finally over? Yet Maryland recently became the eighth state to join the same-sex marriage club (which includes the District of Columbia). Rush Limbaugh was force-fed a triple helping of crow for his failed attempt at ''slut shaming,'' after opening up the gender gap again. Women, young people, college graduates and mixed-race Americans, surveys indicate, are spurning conservative arguments about contraception, same-sex marriage and sexual freedom.

LAHARDANE, Ireland -- For decades, abandoned stone cottages were the only mark of the Addergoole Fourteen, young emigrants who had fled the dark bogs of County Mayo with dreams of fortune in America and steerage tickets aboard the Titanic steamer setting sail from its last port of call: Queenstown, Ireland. The devastated people of tiny Addergoole in western Ireland chose to silently mourn their loss in one of the most famous tragedies of the 20th century. The ache was too much for townspeople, who already had lost so many relatives to the Irish exodus brought on by desperate poverty.
Camper vans are everywhere in New Zealand. Why so popular? They are smaller, cooler and more fuel-efficient than your grandparents' RV.
Liberman--Rob, 35. Haines, Alaska heli-ski guide. Died in avalanche on March 12. Rob will be missed.

Over time, a player who struggles to reach base does not help his team. Too many years with a .282 on-base percentage, as Toronto Blue Jays catcher J. P. Arencibia posted as a rookie last season, and the player will not last long. But on opening day, Arencibia showed with one swing why on-base percentage is not the only important measure of a player's value. In the 16th inning in Cleveland, Arencibia failed in an attempt to bunt over two runners. Forced to swing away, he showed off his power, clubbing a home run that propelled Toronto to a 7-4 victory in the longest opening-day game in major league history.

Mr. Tress came upon the window display of a mom-and-pop shop in his wanderings in 1964, and he liked the mannequin, near right, which reminded him of the work of the Italian painter Giorgio de Chirico. ''He always had an eye for juxtapositions, and San Francisco was a rich environment for an ironic sensibility,'' Mr. Ganz said. ''He loved these shop scenes, with their odd arrangements of objects, which prefigured the arrangements he did himself.''

IN the age of epic security lines and endless fees, traveling anywhere can seem daunting, even if the trip is to Dubuque. But when one is headed to more dangerous places, those concerns can go from annoying to alarming. Take Egypt, a popular draw for pyramid and pharaoh fans. More recently the nation has been the scene of anti-government demonstrations and other unsettling developments, including the kidnapping of several foreign tourists. More daunting are places like Iraq, where, despite the allure of hiking and rafting in the northern part of the country, threats to Americans remain acute. ''No region should be considered safe,'' the State Department reports on its Web site.

The Video column last Sunday, about the 1958 Titanic movie ''A Night to Remember,'' which was directed by Roy Ward Baker, misidentified the director of the 1967 movie ''Guess Who's Coming to Dinner,'' which was compared to Baker's 1961 working-class drama of race, ''Flame in the Streets.'' The director was Stanley Kramer, not Stanley Kubrick.

A penthouse apartment at 34 Greene Street in SoHo that has a 2,200-squarefoot terrace and was bought with two adjoining apartments for $19.2 million was the biggest sale of the week, according to city records. ''It has ridiculous outdoor space,'' said Frances Katzen of Prudential Douglas Elliman who brokered the deal with her colleague Melanie Lazenby. Potential buyers were told that they had the option to put a reflecting pool or hot tub on the terrace so they could soak while gazing up at the Empire State Building.

AUGUSTA, Ga. - As far as final rounds as an amateur go, Kelly Kraft could certainly do worse: The 23-year-old U.S. Amateur champion will play Augusta National in the fourth round of the Masters on Sunday before officially beginning his professional career on Monday. Kraft, who played college golf at Southern Methodist, said it was ''pretty cool'' to conclude his amateur career here but was disappointed not to be in the hunt for the silver medal, which is awarded each year at the Masters to the amateur with the lowest score.

Even if she hadn't been a prominent war correspondent, Martha Gellhorn's place in our cultural lore would be secure because she was the one Hemingway wife who told dear Ernest what he could do with his macho posturing. The HBO film ''Hemingway & Gellhorn,'' exploring their tempestuous waltz, has its premiere May 28, starring Nicole Kidman and Clive Owen.

THE corridor of Telegraph Avenue in Oakland known as the Temescal District used to be the go-to for an unlikely trio: Ethiopian food, paint and stamps. But since the late 1990s, an influx of young families and hipsters fleeing San Francisco's unaffordable real estate prices has transformed the vibe from utility to upscale. Crowds wait curbside for tables at top restaurants, while couples of all stripes snack on organic sorbet. Along a string of '20s alleyways, garages and stables (right) were recently converted by a developer into charming shops offering midcentury furniture, indie fashions and specialty foods. Many are now under renovation by a cohort of young proprietors. Coming soon: organic doughnuts from Doughnut Dolly. LOUISE RAFKIN
