Bubba Watson won his first major championship by making a tournament-saving par to top Louis Oosthuizen’s bogey on the second hole of a sudden-death playoff.
Bank of America and Citigroup have plenty in common, and when bank earnings are revealed in the coming weeks, investors will be watching to see how the two match up.
While bond purchases pushed down borrowing costs and helped Spain and Italy avoid a Greek-style bailout from the euro zone, they once again have enmeshed the banks in their debt woes.
A spokesman for the Seoul government said satellite images of a growing pile of earth outside a tunnel might signal plans for an underground blast.
After brandishing a gun in a sidewalk dispute in Sheepshead Bay, a man held a woman and baby hostage and shot four responding officers, including a captain.
A reporter with the presence of a performer, Mr. Wallace went head-to-head with chiefs of state, celebrities and con artists for more than 50 years.
India’s prime minister, the host, said he would visit Pakistan, a trip that many analysts regard as instrumental to any major diplomatic breakthroughs between the countries.
The government requested “written guarantees” that rebels would stop fighting before it pulled back its troops.
Jacob C. England and Alvin Watts are accused of shooting five African-Americans in north Tulsa on Friday. Three black people were killed, and two others were wounded in the attacks.
An agreement on raids that are deeply unpopular in Afghanistan would give legal oversight to Afghan forces, putting American troops in a supporting role.

Rick Santorum said in a statement issued late Saturday that he will not campaign on Monday so he can stay with his daughter Bella, who was hospitalized on Friday. ''Senator Santorum will not hold any campaign-related events on Monday so that he and Karen can remain in the hospital with their daughter Bella,'' said the statement, which was issued by Hogan Gidley, Mr. Santorum's campaign spokesman.

It is rare to see private equity firms lock horns in a public bidding war. But a heated auction appears to be brewing for Great Wolf Resorts, the big indoor water park operator. The company announced on Sunday that it had received a new takeover bid of $7 a share in cash, or $234 million total, from KSL Capital Partners, topping a $225.7 million offer by Apollo Global Management, the publicly traded buyout giant.

Patients sitting in waiting rooms are often relegated to watching television or reading well-worn magazines to pass the time. But in many doctor's offices these days, the standard television offerings like daytime talk shows are giving way to a more focused kind of programming: health content. A company called AccentHealth has been providing programming to 12,300 doctor's offices in the United States, on subjects like mental health, allergies and diabetes.

An article on Wednesday about Russians who spend billions of dollars on real estate in the United States misstated the year that Donald J. Trump bought an oceanfront home in Palm Beach, Fla., which he subsequently sold to a Russian buyer. It was 2005, not 2006.

MADOW--Michael P. The Brooklyn Law School community mourns the loss of a beloved colleague, fabulous teacher and cherished friend, Professor Michael P. Madow. Over the course of twenty-five years of service on the Law School faculty, teaching and writing in the areas of First Amendment and Mass Media Law and Criminal Law, he touched the lives of thousands of students. His gentle and unassuming manner could not completely mask a brilliant intellect that his colleagues respected and his students revered. He served on the Due Process Committee of the ACLU and the Communications and Media Law Committee of the New York City Bar. Although his presence will be missed, it will always be felt by the colleagues and students who knew and cherished him. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Dr. Karen Brudney, his children Benjamin and Hannah, and to his entire family. Stuart Subotnick, Chairman of the Board Joan G. Wexler, President Michael A. Gerber, Interim Dean

Designing and building things for the United States military is a notoriously slow-moving and costly endeavor. The time from idea to manufacturing for a new armored personnel carrier or a tank is typically 10 to 20 years. The Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency wants to change that, and drastically so. It seeks to cut the design-to-production cycle to two to four years.

Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan weighed in on the role of religion in politics in an Easter Sunday appearance on ''Face the Nation,'' pledging to fight President Obama's contraception policy and defending Rick Santorum over a comment that reading John F. Kennedy's 1960 speech about the separation of church and state almost made him throw up. Speaking at a Catholic college in New Hampshire last fall, Mr. Santorum said that when he had read Kennedy's speech, ''I almost threw up.'' He added: ''In my opinion it was the beginning of the secular movement of politicians to separate their faith from the public square, and he threw faith under the bus in that speech.''

An obituary on Tuesday about the British playwright John Arden misspelled the name of the country where English soldiers killed five innocent people in 1958, an incident that inspired Mr. Arden's play ''Serjeant Musgrave's Dance.'' It is Cyprus, not Cypress.

FANT--Mark E. Died March 5, 2012. Born May 29, 1959 in Bronx, NY. Reared and educated in Great Neck, NY. Graduated from NYU and NYU School of Law; member of the NYU Law Review of Social Justice. Held offices in 100 Black Men, Brooklyn Guardsmen, and was Sire Archon of Zeta Boule Chapter of Sigma Pi Phi Fraternity at his death. He is mourned by his mother, Winnie L. Fant of Great Neck; sisters, Verenice Sicuro (Salvatore), New York City and Lisa Fant of Raleigh, NC, nephews Mattia Sicuro and Ruben Allen. His father, Thomas L. Fant predeceased him. He will be sorely missed. Mark will be memorialized on Saturday, April 14, 2012 at 10:00AM at The Abyssinian Baptist Church, 132 Odell Clark Place, NY 10030. The Reverend Dr. Calvin O. Butts, III, Pastor. The Fant Family

All the shootings have a disgraceful fact in common: all were committed with illegal guns that came from out of state. And that is the case with nearly every shooting in our city. MAYOR MICHAEL R. BLOOMBERG,on the wounding of four police officers in Brooklyn on Sunday morning, bringing to eight the number of New York City police officers shot in the last four months. [A16]

1:22 p.m. | Updated Adding comment from ARM executive at end. ARM, the London-based company that designs the chips in most of the world's smartphones, announced a partnership on Tuesday with two other companies to improve security for mobile services. This would lay the groundwork for companies to more easily build secure mobile payment services into smartphones and other devices.

The newest phone from HTC on the Sprint network will have the words ''4G LTE'' in its name - even though Sprint hasn't finished building a network that uses 4G LTE technology. This underscores a problem for Sprint: If it doesn't build out that network in a hurry, it risks falling behind AT&T and Verizon. The HTC Evo 4G LTE smartphone will be available for preordering on May 7 and in stores soon after, Sprint said on Wednesday. Sprint has said its 4G LTE network would be deployed by midyear in six markets: Atlanta, Dallas, San Antonio, Houston, Kansas City and Baltimore.

WALLACE--Mike. The Board of Directors of the Sonja Matos Foundation for Biophysical Study notes with sadness the loss of our colleague, friend and fellow director, Mike Wallace. We extend our condolences to his family. Michael Bulkin Fred Marcusa Jeffrey Matos Marshall Matos Daniel Pekarsky Martin Perl Robert Schoenthal Board of Directors, Sonja Matos Foundation for Biophysical Study

STEINBERG--Elan. The World Jewish Congress mourns the tragic and untimely death of Elan Steinberg, the WJC's long-time Executive Director and a pivotal figure in our fight for Jewish rights throughout the world. He played a critical role in the fight to obtain restitution for Holocaust survivors from Swiss banks and other European countries and corporations, and was the strategist behind the campaign to expose Kurt Waldheim's Nazi past. He was a tireless advocate for Israel and Jewish rights everywhere. Our deepest condolences go to his devoted wife Sharon, their children Max, Harry and Lena, and their entire family. Ronald S Lauder, President Dan Diker, Secretary General

WIENER--Gabe. Not a day goes by, when I don't think of you, miss you and yearn to have you here with your family. I hope you are well my sweet son. I will see you one day soon. Your music continues to play. All my love, Mom

AUGUSTA, Ga. -- Bubba Watson is an iconoclast in a sport of conformists, in possession of a swing that defies duplication and a mind so overactive that he has a hard time focusing for more than a few seconds. Somehow, his long hitting and short attention span carried him to victory Sunday at the most buttoned-down of majors, on a course that requires the mental concentration of an illusionist. Extricating himself from more tight spots than David Blaine, Watson overcame a four-stroke deficit in the final 16 holes of the 76th Masters to force a playoff with his final-round partner, Louis Oosthuizen.

BUTTENHEIM--Curtis R.,93, died March 12 at home in Dennis, MA after a brief illness. Born in Hastings-on-Hudson, NY on October 10, 1918, son of Edgar J. and Marian Voorhees Buttenheim, he was a 1936 graduate of The Taft School in Watertown, CT and a 1940 graduate of Yale University. In World War II Buttenheim was stationed in Calcutta, India where he attained the rank of Captain in the US Army. He taught at the Russell Ranch School in Tucson, AZ before joining the family business, Buttenheim Publishing Corporation, from which he retired as Vice President in 1975. During his career he resided in Lookout Mountain, TN; Ossining, NY; and Stockbridge, MA before moving to Dennis. A supporter of the arts wherever he lived, Buttenheim twice served as Co-Chair of the Council of Friends of Tanglewood in Lenox, MA, and was a member of the Board of Overseers of the Boston Symphony Orchestra. He was an early supporter of Shakespeare and Company and served as a Trustee of the Berkshire Country Day School, both in Lenox, and served as a Trustee of the Norman Rockwell Museum in Stockbridge. He was an early board member of the Cape Cod Museum of Art in Dennis. In 1953 Buttenheim married Patricia L. Johnson of Pittsburgh, PA, who survives him, as do their children, Lisa M. Buttenheim of Nicosia, Cyprus; Edgar J. Buttenheim II of Franklin, MA; Curtis R. Jr. of Los Angeles, CA; and Patricia M. Buttenheim of New York, NY. He is also survived by two grandchildren, James Curtis and Mary Catherine Buttenheim; a sister, Constance Swain of Sarasota, FL and brother Edgar M. of Princeton, NJ. A private funeral was held on March 17 in Barnstable, MA. Donations may be sent to the Taft School/Buttenheim Family Scholarship, 110 Woodbury Road, Watertown, CT 06795.

Mike Wallace, the CBS reporter who became one of America's best-known broadcast journalists as an interrogator of the famous and infamous on ''60 Minutes,'' died on Saturday. He was 93. On its Web site, CBS said Mr. Wallace died at a care facility in New Canaan, Conn., where he had lived in recent years. Mr. Wallace, who received a pacemaker more than 20 years ago, had a long history of cardiac care and underwent triple bypass heart surgery in January 2008.

New York, the city, knew all about the Titanic before the problem with New York, the ship. The Titanic - the largest passenger ship the world had seen, and the most unbelievably and unapologetically opulent - was an event before it was an event, and New York had read all about it in progress reports on the positioning of the stern frame, in accounts of its launching and in short paragraphs about brief test runs. And then, as it left Southampton, England, on its maiden voyage, it yanked the New York, which was alongside it at the pier, from its moorings.

Roger Furst, one of two fishing buddies who founded the Eastern Mountain Sports retail chain, which has equipped thousands of people to trek deep into the mountains, ski in the backcountry or scale a peak, died on March 16 in Sherman, Tex., a day after his 78th birthday. His death was confirmed by his son Jason, who did not specify a cause.

An article on Thursday about five former police officers sentenced to prison in the shooting of six unarmed civilians in the days after Hurricane Katrina, and the cover-up afterward, misstated the reason for the sentence of at least 35 years for those convicted of taking part in the shooting. It was based on mandatory minimum sentencing statutes, not on sentencing guidelines.

CHICAGO -- Dinner theater, that derided and mostly moribund genre, is making an unlikely comeback at the Lookingglass Theater here, where one of this city's most renowned chefs, Rick Bayless, is preparing a savory meal onstage, and doing a modest bit of acting in a modest little comedy too. Called ''Cascabel,'' the show is a sliver of romantic hokum that is mostly used as a platform for a series of Cirque du Soleil-style diversions. While these are being performed the audience is served a three-course dinner conceived by Mr. Bayless, whose Chicago restaurants, Topolobampo and Frontera Grill, serve some of the best Mexican food in the country.

WEIDMAN--Lucy, on April 5, 2012. Lucy died peacefully from cancer, discovered shortly after she suffered a stroke in January. She graduated Tilden High School, attended Vassar College, and graduated Sarah Lawrence College in 1979. Lucy was a gifted painter and designer, and was beloved by family and friends. Daughter of the late Henrietta (Queenie) and Hyman (Kitty) Katz, she is survived by husband Edwin; brothers Henry and Richard; children James, Peter, David and Jennifer; children-in-law Marsha, Debbi, Debbie and Barry; and grandchildren Amanda, Samuel, Hilary, Rachel, Katie, Lauren, Julia, Isabel and Benjamin. In Lucy's memory, please consider a donation to your favorite art museum. Service Monday, April 9, 11:45am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.
An obituary on Thursday about the drag racer Bill Jenkins misstated the name of the city in Pennsylvania where he began racing. It is Downingtown, not Downington.

JERUSALEM -- Israel's interior minister declared Günter Grass, one of Germany's best-known authors, unwelcome in Israel on Sunday, barring him from entering the country for a poem that accused Israel of being a threat to world peace. ''Grass's poems fan the flames of hatred against Israel and the Israeli people, thus promoting the idea he was part of when he donned an SS uniform,'' said the minister, Eli Yishai, referring to Mr. Grass's admission that he had been a Nazi soldier as a 17-year-old. ''His distorted poems are not welcome in Israel. I suggest he try them in Iran where he will find a sympathetic audience.''

BORN--Esther. Our deepest condolences to brother, Harry Wittlin; children, Rita and Fred Distenfeld, Debbie and Richard Born; grandchildren and great-granddaughter upon the loss of their gracious and beautiful matriarch. Hammerman, Weiss and Ainsberg families

LESH--Irving, father of Lillian Heidenberg and Joyce Krawiecki, died on April 7th. He will be missed dearly by three generations of family to whom he dedicated utter devotion and love throughout his life. Funeral services at Riverside Chapel on April 9th at 9:45am.

Since the fate of humanity is often hanging in the balance, science fiction rarely has a problem with dramatic stakes. That's part of its appeal, and why the genre lends itself to urgent -- if sometimes woolly -- philosophical reflection. Crackling exchanges are at the core of ''Blast Radius,'' the suspenseful second part of an alien invasion trilogy by Mac Rogers (''Advance Man'' was first), whose confident writing displays deep affection for the genre. He clearly loves spaceships and extraterrestrials, but understands that for his story to work as theater, he must focus on a clash of worldviews, not worlds.

WEISER--Ruth Fox, nee Bressler, 76, died peacefully at home in Boynton Beach, FL, April 8th, after four years of living with pancreatic cancer. Formerly of Oceanside, NY, she was pre-deceased by her loving husband Alan. She leaves her devoted children Debra of Manhattan, David and his husband Tim Robblee of Fort Lauderdale, Diane and her husband Dave Kidd of San Francisco, as well as Sammy, Jenn, Lucy, Lake, Bruno and Butch, and the families of Robyn, Brad and Cheryl Mintz. She loved reading, theater, travel, the Times crossword, was a co-founder of the Long Island Symphony, and is surely now walking five miles a day in heaven. Graveside service Tuesday, April 10, 11am, at United Hebrew Cemetery, Staten Island. Shiva to begin at Debra's home in New York, to conclude at Ruth's home in Florida. If so moved, donations to GMHC or Oceanside Library.

LOS ANGELES - The annual White House Correspondents' Association dinner is Hollywood's big night in Washington. Movie and television stars arrive by the private jet load. Cable channels like MSNBC spend lavishly on parties. Moguls like Rupert Murdoch and Robert A. Iger endure banquet food in hopes of rubbing an important political elbow or two.
WEIDMAN--Lucy. Always in our hearts. We love and will miss you. The Crames Family

9 P.M. (13, 49) BEING ELMO: A PUPPETEER'S JOURNEY (2011) As a teenager in Baltimore in the 1970s Kevin Clash had a singular wish: to be a puppeteer on the team of Jim Henson, the creative force behind ''Sesame Street'' and the Muppets. Mr. Clash's dream eventually came true when he attracted the attention of the Muppet designer Kermit Love. And then one day the veteran puppeteer Richard Hunt tossed a furry red monster at him in a fit of frustration, unable to find the character's voice. Mr. Clash eventually did, and Elmo (above, with Mr. Clash), one of the world's most beloved characters, was born. ''Independent Lens'' presents this documentary, directed by Constance Marks and narrated by Whoopi Goldberg, which Neil Genzlinger, writing in The New York Times, called ''a winning tale of the persistence and creativity behind one of the most famous and fuzziest faces in the world.'' 8 P.M. (CBS) HOW I MET YOUR MOTHER Ted (Josh Radnor), Marshall (Jason Segel) and Barney (Neil Patrick Harris) watch the original ''Star Wars'' trilogy and imagine what their lives will be like in three years. In ''2 Broke Girls,'' at 8:30, Max (Kat Dennings) persuades Caroline (Beth Behrs) to take part in a clinical drug trial to raise money for her father. In ''Two and a Half Men,'' at 9, Walden (Ashton Kutcher) tells Zoey (Sophie Winkleman) that he's going into business with his ex-wife (Judy Greer). And in ''Mike & Molly,'' at 9:30, the outspokenness of Molly (Melissa McCarthy) costs her and Mike (Billy Gardell) a wedding chapel.

GLASGOW--Lloyd, devoted husband to the late Dorothy, loving father to Jenny and Donna, adoring grandfather to Byron, and irreplaceable friend to many died peacefully at his home on April 7 at the age of 91. A veteran of World War II, he served as a Lieutenant in the U.S. Coast Guard. He earned two battle stars and was awarded three medals for distinguished service in the Atlantic Theater antisubmarine patrol. As President and Chairman of Jacques Jugeat, Inc. (Lalique North America), he modeled integrity, honesty and loyalty to two generations of retailer buyers and wholesale sales representatives in the luxury giftware and tabletop industry. Generous to a fault, beloved for his loyalty, admired for his consistency, solicited for his wisdom, celebrated for his wit and charm, and loved for so much more, he is greatly missed. In lieu of flowers, donations to Doctors Without Borders in his memory would be welcomed.

The actress Amy Brenneman will star in the premiere production of Gina Gionfriddo's new play ''Rapture, Blister, Burn'' at Playwrights Horizons this spring, the theater announced on Monday. Ms. Brenneman, a five-time Emmy Award nominee known for her television roles in ''Private Practice,'' ''Judging Amy'' and ''NYPD Blue,'' will be joined in the cast by Kellie Overbey, Lee Tergesen, Beth Dixon and Virginia Kull. Ms. Gionfriddo's comedy, to be directed by Peter DuBois, is about two women, Catherine (Ms. Brenneman) and Gwen (Ms. Overbey), who, after taking different paths, begin to covet the other's life. Ms. Gionfriddo was a Pulitzer Prize finalist for the play ''Becky Shaw,'' which ran Off Broadway at Second Stage in 2009. Her other plays include ''After Ashley,'' ''U.S. Drag'' and ''Guinevere.''

It was a dark Sunday evening in early October when Mark Vincent reluctantly set off on a city chore shared by some and lamented by many: moving his car to abide by alternate-side parking rules. Mr. Vincent lives in Park Slope, Brooklyn; his car is a maroon 1992 Honda that he and his wife inherited from her father after her father could no longer drive. Not that the couple drives it much.

An article last Monday about Apple's steps to address concerns about labor conditions at plants that manufacture its products misstated the timing of Timothy D. Cook's appointment as the company's chief executive. It occurred in August, not last fall.

STRANG--John Perry died on March 25, 2012. Born April 15, 1926 in Chicago; Jack served in WWII. He was awarded three battle stars in the European Theater of Operations and the Bronze Star. He was entitled to wear the Distinguished Unit Citation. He received a degree in Fine Arts from Wesleyan University and studied at the University of Tulsa, The University of Houston and New York University. Pursuing an interest in photography Jack freelanced for national magazines including LIFE. In the 1950's Jack was a member of The Independent Filmmakers in New York. His short film "A Poem of Life" of a sculpture by Aristede Maillot is in the Permanent Collection of the Library of Congress. Working in film and television in New York and California he photographed and directed documentaries and television films. For his work in the field he received several industry awards including the Sylvania Award for Creative Television Technique. Subsequently he founded a private company to explore for oil and natural gas in the US. A descendant of Huguenot refugees who settled in New Rochelle in 1687, Jack established a nonprofit organization Huguenot Heritage to research and to inform the public about cultural, scientific, technical and artistic contributions of the descendents of the Huguenots. He was most pleased with a project to preserve the beautiful but neglected Chateau Chamerolles in Loiret, France, a place of unique Huguenot history. An early marriage ended in divorce. He is survived by a daughter, Suzanne Lightbourn, and two granddaughters. He was member of numerous societies dedicated to history, the fine arts and film. Jack was man of great intelligence, intellectual curiosity and integrity and his wry wit will be missed. A memorial gathering is being planned.
BORN--Esther. Our heartfelt condolences to the family of Ester Born. Our families were joined under the wedding canopy and we shall remain family forever. Lorelei and Ben

An obituary on Friday about Gil Noble, a television journalist who hosted ''Like It Is,'' an award-winning Sunday morning public affairs program in New York, referred incorrectly to Milton Allimadi, who was an occasional guest on the program. He is the publisher of The Black Star News, not the former publisher.
KELLNER--Zoe. Impossible to believe it has been 5 years. We think of you and miss you every day. Your legacy of loving and being loved by so many will live forever. Love, Mom and John

Car sales were up in March, with gains from a year ago of more than 30 percent for Chrysler and Volkswagen, a 15 percent increase for Toyota and 12 percent for Chevrolet. Three carmakers -- Nissan, Hyundai and Kia -- had record sales. Ford, which gained 5 percent over 2011, sold more small cars as well as more F-Series trucks. The Focus, above, moved up 24 places on the AutoTrader ranking, which tracked 370 new cars in March. Other models that showed increased interest: the Toyota Camry, to No. 19 from No. 60, and the BMW 3 Series, to No. 18 from No. 50. SHELLY FREIERMAN
International NEW EGYPT CANDIDATE

NAGORSKI--Ingrid, 87, died April 8. Wife of the late George Nagorski, mother of Tom, mother-in-law to Anne, and adoring grandmother to Natalie and Billy. Born Ingrid Young in Oslo, her teenage years were lived under the German occupation of Norway. After the war she worked for the United Nations in Geneva, then met George Nagorski on a vacation in Spain. For two years they wrote letters to each other; they were married in Oslo in 1956. They settled in New York, where she resumed her career at U.N. headquarters. She was most proud of her work on international peacekeeping, for Sir Brian Urquhart and the late Nobel Peace laureate Ralph Bunche. To her last days Ingrid Nagorski was grateful for an interesting and rewarding life grateful especially for having met George, and for Natalie and Billy, who she considered the finest grandchildren imaginable. Burial will be private. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Donations in Ingrid Nagorski's name may be made to The Center For Arts Education.

OWENS--Fritzi Weitzmann, died on Friday afternoon, just before sundown on Passover. She was a true Aishet Chayil, the Biblical woman of valor. Adored wife of Herbert Owens for more than 68 years, beloved mother of Bob [Evie], Ruth, Mark [Mindy] and sister of Ilse. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother. Raised in Vienna, Austria from her birth in 1924 until the Nazi occupation in 1938, she and her immediate family fled to safety in Albania with the help of its righteous Muslim ruler, King Zog I. After a year in Tirana, Fritzi and her family arrived in New York to start her new life as an American high school student the only woman in her class at the School of Industrial Arts. After graduation, she joined her parents at Weitzmann Photo Studio which they had re-established in New York. Later, Fritzi was the first female volunteer in the Photography Department at the Metropolitan Museum of Art for 25 year. She also served as a volunteer for more than 10 years at the International Foundation of Art Research. She loved attending operas, concerts, and the theater; and spending time with her family. For the past 16 years, she had courageously fought cancer, not allowing her illnesses to slow her down. Her amazingly rich life and marriage have now come to an end. We are heartbroken to be observing Passover without her and her renowned gefilte fish. The private graveside service was held on Sunday morning. Because of the Passover holiday, Shiva will be observed on Sunday, April 15, from 2 to 5pm, at the home of Bob Owens and Evie Klein, 241 Central Park West. Contributions in her memory can be made to Hadassah NY, Sharon Chapter, at 50 West 58th Street, New York, NY 10019.

The kids of ''The Hunger Games,'' even in their third weekend in theaters, ran laps around the rested adults of ''American Reunion,'' selling an estimated $33.5 million in tickets to repeat as the No. 1 movie in North America. ''The Hunger Games'' (Lionsgate) has now taken in $302.8 million at the domestic box office, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles ticketing data. ''American Reunion,'' the R-rated continuation of the 13-year-old ''American Pie'' franchise, was second with ticket sales of about $21.5 million. Universal Pictures and its financing partner spent about $50 million to make ''American Reunion,'' which brought back the original cast and was directed by Jon Hurwitz and Hayden Schlossberg of ''Harold & Kumar'' fame.

SKARIMBAS--Elias. On your birthday 4/9/26. There's a love song floating on the air. When you spoke, you left it there. From now on I walk with music, and your voice will follow me everywhere. Unavoidably yours

The photographer Barton Silverman, who has worked for The New York Times for 50 years, also worked for the Rangers in the 1960s, when he was trying to establish himself as a photographer. With the team's cooperation, he was among the first to station a camera inside the net, a tactic that allowed photographs like the image at right, showing Bernie Geoffrion's shot past a sprawling Johnny Bower of the Toronto Maple Leafs in November 1966 at Madison Square Garden. As the Rangers begin the Stanley Cup playoffs as the top seed in the Eastern Conference, Silverman will be there again, armed with the experience and recollections of hockey in days when the N.H.L. did not require players to wear helmets.

Because of an editing error, the Advertising column on Thursday, about New Balance's issuance of a 30th anniversary model of its 990 running shoe, gave an outdated name for a nonprofit organization that is joining with the company in a promotion, and rendered part of its former name incorrectly. It is now the USO; it was formerly the United Service Organizations, not the United Service Organization.
The Miami Marlins suspend manager Ozzie Guillen for five games over his comments in praise of Fidel Castro.
Pablo Larraín’s “Post Mortem” observes the political turmoil in Chile, from the perspective of a morgue worker, after the 1973 military coup that overthrew the Allende government.
“The Lady” by Luc Besson is a biopic about Daw Aung San Suu Kyi of Myanmar.
The new ABC comedy “Don’t Trust the B–––– in Apartment 23” purports to be a modern, female “Odd Couple,” but without the realism.
An agitated city woman and a hokey outdoorsman find love in Drew Larimore’s romantic comedy “Out of Iceland.”
The trajectory of Mr. Santorum’s campaign, illustrated with charts of primaries and caucuses, delegates, polls and other recent Republican candidates.
Bank issuance of credit cards to subprime borrowers has grown in recent months.
The autobiographical play “From the Same Cloth” finds Megan Auster-Rosen setting out a journey, as her father did in the 1970s.
Krysten Ritter is the titular character in the new ABC comedy.
Russell Harvard plays a deaf young man and Susan Pourfar his girlfriend in Nina Raine’s play at the Barrow Street Theater.
April 10, 2012 — A European court rules that Britain can extradite five terror suspects to the United States.
China’s exports outstripped imports last month
Jeff Zeleny reports on Mr. Santorum's withdrawal from the race and the turn to the general election for his former rival Mitt Romney.
The day in sports included bodybuilding in Mumbai, the first round of the Danish Open tennis tournament in Denmark and opening day at Dodger Stadium.
After 444 days in captivity, the Americans held hostage in Tehran were released.
April 10, 2012 - Sizing up Google's Internet-connected glasses.
Rick Santorum suspended his presidential campaign on Tuesday, ending his improbable, come-from-behind quest to become the party’s conservative standard-bearer in the fall.
The Department of Defense has identified 1,913 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently.
The Miami Marlins suspend Manager Ozzie Guillen over comments praising Fidel Castro | A European court rules that Britain can extradite five terror suspects to the United States.
Michael Olajide Jr., a former boxing champ, and Leila Fazel, a ballerina turned spa designer, discuss their gym, the “machine-free” Aerospace High Performance Center in downtown New York.
The first of two eggs hatches in the Hawk Cam nest high above Washington Square Park.
Why Facebook paid $1 billion for Instagram; sizing up Google's Internet-connected glasses; and the frenzied market for tech patents.
The author of more than a dozen novels, as well as short stories, essays and criticism, Ms. Brooke-Rose was one of relatively few Britons to maintain a long association with experimental fiction.
The surplus is likely to bring renewed calls in the United States and elsewhere for China to allow further appreciation of its currency, the renminbi.
A new federal report says Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey exaggerated the projected cost of a new train tunnel, the nation’s largest public works project, when he scrapped it in 2010.
Mr. Lenzi won a gold medal in diving at the 1992 Summer Olympics in Barcelona, Spain, and four years later came out of a brief retirement to win the bronze medal at the Atlanta Olympics.
Mr. Strickler was a Washington lawyer who represented two of President Richard M. Nixon’s top aides in the aftermath of the 1972 Watergate break-in and subsequent cover-up.
Hundreds of South Sudanese were stranded at the Khartoum airport after Sudan denied them permission to board, escalating tension between the two countries.
After falling behind by three runs early, the Mets used a walk, a bunt, an error and a single in the ninth to improve to 4-0.
A bill in the General Assembly would prohibit motorists from driving with dogs in their laps. A first offense would draw a fine of $85, and a second $100.

Tammy Kwarciak, a 44-year-old nurse whose weight had been creeping up for years, was determined to lose 50 pounds. So in February, she drove from her home in Port Huron, Mich., across the border into Canada and had a small balloonlike device inserted into her stomach. The intragastric balloon, filled with liquid and left in the stomach for up to six months, is not approved for use in the United States, though it's available in Europe, South America and other parts of the world. Clinical trials required to win federal Food and Drug Administration approval are being initiated, but many Americans aren't waiting.

AT&T said on Monday that it had agreed to sell a majority stake in its yellow pages business to Cerberus Capital Management for about $950 million, giving the private equity firm an opportunity to resuscitate a declining operation. Under the terms of the deal, which had been expected for months, AT&T will receive $750 million in cash and a $200 million note. It will keep a 47 percent stake in the business, which is composed of AT&T Advertising Solutions and AT&T Interactive.

About 28 million Americans have sleep apnea, which causes repeated awakenings and pauses in breathing during the night, sometimes resulting in loud snoring and gasps for air. For decades, the standard treatment has been ''continuous positive airway pressure.'' A mask worn at night pushes air into the nasal passages, enabling easier breathing. C.P.A.P. reduces and in some cases completely prevents episodes of apnea. But the mask is like something from a bad science fiction movie: big, bulky and obtrusive. Many patients simply refuse to wear it or rip it off while asleep. Studies show that about half of all people prescribed C.P.A.P. machines stop using them in one to three weeks. ''For a lot of people out there, the C.P.A.P. machine turns into a doorstop,'' said Dr. Joseph Golish, the former chief of sleep medicine at the Cleveland Clinic. ''C.P.A.P. is very effective in the sleep lab. But when people go home, there's a good chance they won't use it, and the success rate of an unused C.P.A.P. machine is absolutely zero.''

The start of April school vacations led some Broadway producers to charge high premium prices for more seats last week because of family and tourist demand, and as a result several of the shows - ''Wicked,'' ''The Lion King,'' ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark'' and ''The Book of Mormon'' - brought in huge sums per person on average, according to weekly box office data published on Monday. For instance ''The Lion King'' had an average paid admission of $155.09 even though its regular top ticket price was $133. This was possible because Disney Theatrical Productions charged as much as $197.50 for the best seats in the theater. ''The Book of Mormon'' was even more aggressive in its ticket pricing: The musical had an average paid admission of $181.70 last week. Its regular top price was $155, but the ''Mormon'' producers charged as much as $477 for some of the best seats. As a result ''Mormon'' set a new box office record at the Eugene O'Neill Theater of $1,590,235.

(HBO Signature) CRIMES AND MISDEMEANORS (1989) When the mistress (Anjelica Huston) of Judah Rosenthal (Martin Landau, in an Oscar-nominated performance), a Manhattan ophthalmologist, threatens to go public with their affair and his unethical financial dealings, he hires his mobster brother (Jerry Orbach) to kill her. In this movie from Woody Allen, who received best director and best screenplay nominations, Mr. Allen plays Cliff Stern, a married documentarian infatuated with another woman (Mia Farrow). Sam Waterston is Judah's best friend, a rabbi; Alan Alda is a successful television producer and Cliff's brother-in-law. ''The wonder of 'Crimes and Misdemeanors' is the facility with which Mr. Allen deals with so many interlocking stories of so many differing tones and voices,'' Vincent Canby wrote in The New York Times. ''The film cuts back and forth between parallel incidents and between present and past with the effortlessness of a hip, contemporary Aesop.''

A large new study has ruled out concerns that children over 4 are at greater risk of seizures after getting a common measles-containing vaccine called MMRV. The vaccine -- which combines the shot for measles, mumps and rubella, or MMR, with the vaccine for varicella, or chickenpox -- is given to children in two steps, first as toddlers and then again between ages 4 and 6. Concerns were raised several years ago after scientists found that 1-year-old children who were given the MMRV vaccine had double the risk of a febrile seizure, a brief convulsion triggered by a fever, compared with those who were given the MMR and chickenpox shots separately but on the same day. Febrile seizures, which can also be set off by ear infections, colds and other viral illnesses, strike about 5 percent of children younger than 5 and are particularly common in toddlers. Although they are alarming to parents, they do not cause any long-term problems.

During the triumphant New York recital debut of the Italian soprano Anna Caterina Antonacci on Sunday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall, it was hard to keep from being a little upset with her. Here was a remarkable artist in her prime at 51, a musically intelligent and vocally splendid singer with a significant career in Europe who has been embraced by discerning maestros like Riccardo Muti. Yet she has given few performances in the United States. This recital, with the American pianist Donald Sulzen, was her first appearance in New York since her debut here in an early-music program at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in 1999. At the end, along with all the ''bravas'' from the audience, I wanted to shout, ''Where have you been?''

To newspaper readers, and to the anxious crowds that jammed the streets around newspaper offices, hoping to see giant-letter bulletins be posted on the walls, it was the unforgettable story of the unsinkable ship. Behind the scenes, in the fiercely competitive newsrooms of a city with more than a dozen daily papers, it was the equally unforgettable story of two larger-than-life editors, one brilliantly analytical, the other brilliantly theatrical. Years later one would end up in the headlines, and in jail, for murder. But on April 15, 1912, the two editors - Carr V. Van Anda, the managing editor of The New York Times, and Charles E. Chapin, the city editor of The New York Evening World - just wanted the facts.

More than 40 million women are the primary caregivers for a sick person, very often the man they are married to. Caregiving, after all, is a wife's expected role, and most accept it perforce as a duty that offers precious time to express love and wishes, settle financial and legal matters, and right past wrongs. When a caregiving wife runs into a friend, acquaintance or even a relative, the most frequently asked question is, ''How is he doing?'' Far less often is an inquiry made about the wife, who may be struggling to juggle a job and child care as well as patient care.

Taking antidepressants during pregnancy raises the risk of high blood pressure in expectant mothers, a new study shows. Antidepressants are one of the most commonly used medications in pregnancy, and hypertension can cause problems for both mother and child. About one in five women suffer from depression during pregnancy, and up to 14 percent of those women end up using an antidepressant medication to treat it.

LAZAR--Gerald "Jerry" Alan, beloved husband, father, brother and friend, died suddenly on Friday, April 6, 2012, of complications following surgery. Jerry Lazar lived in Tenafly, NJ, with his wife, Risa Rosenberg, and his two children, Alexander Lazar and Katherine Lazar. Jerry was born on April 18, 1960, in New York, New York, to the late Irving Lazar, a physicist, and Florence Halpert Lazar, a writer and editor. He grew up in Great Neck, New York, and graduated from Cornell University in 1981. He married his best friend, Risa, on October 2, 1983. Jerry was a freelance writer, editor, director, playwright and performer, and was a founding member and assistant director of the Lunatic Fringe Improv Comedy Troupe. He was known for his wonderfully resonant bass singing voice, and his irrepressible sense of humor. Over the past 30 years, Jerry performed widely around the NY/NJ area, from regional theater, community theater, to off-Broadway, including Medicine Show Theater Ensemble, 12 Miles West, Shadowland Theater, The Theater Project, Playwrights Theater of New Jersey, and The Garage Theater. In addition to adapting numerous literary works for the stage, he created the original comedy, "Two Big Guys from Jersey," with his long-time friend, Paul Murphy. During his writing career, he produced over a million words on information technology, and in his spare time he amused readers with his comedy blog, "The Awkward Silence." Jerry taught improv comedy to children in the Tenafly community and public schools for many years. He volunteered at the Malcolm S. MacKay Elementary School in Tenafly, advising the student produced newspaper, "The MacKay Times". He loved being around children and teaching them the joys of laughter. Jerry is survived by beloved wife, Risa, and children, Alexander and Katherine; and by his sisters, Janet Lazar and Karen Lazar. He will be missed by his sisters-in-law, Ellen Portnoy and Miriam Rosenberg; by his brothers-in-law, Steven Rosenberg, Jay Portnoy and Jan Kamil; and by his nieces and nephews, Lara, Michelle, Joshua and Michael. He will be missed by his many loving friends and by his appreciative audiences. Funeral from Gutterman and Musicant Jewish Funeral Directors, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ. Interment will take place at Beth-El Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. Please call 1-800-522-0588 or visit GuttermanMusicantWien.com for service information. In lieu of flowers, donations should be made to the Tenafly Nature Center, 313 Hudson Avenue, Tenafly, NJ 07670, or charity of your choice.

JACOBS--Phoebe. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family is saddened by the passing of our dear friend, devoted benefactress and a great lady of jazz, Phoebe Jacobs. As Executive Vice President of the Louis Armstrong Educational Foundation, Phoebe was a tireless supporter of the work of Beth Israel's Louis and Lucille Armstrong Music Therapy Program, which eventually grew to become The Louis Armstrong Center for Music and Medicine. She had an incredible passion for music, and gave unstinting support and encouragement to Beth Israel's embracement of music as a process for treatment and healing, our outreach efforts and, most especially our music therapy staff. We will forever be grateful for all of her many contributions. To her family, friends and loved ones, we extend heartfelt condolences. Harris M. Nagler, MD President Joanne Loewy, DA LCAT, MT-BC Director Stephan Quentzel, MD Medical Director Armstrong Ctr. for Music & Medicine John Mondanaro, MA, LCAT Clinical Director Armstrong Music Therapy Program

PARDO--Stanley Thomas, of Montclair, New Jersey, passed away after a long illness on Saturday, April 7, 2012 at 3:40pm. He was 76 years old and had lived life with gusto and enthusiasm. He was born on November 22, 1935 in Jersey City, New Jersey. Stanley graduated as valedictorian of his class from St. Peter's Preparatory School in Jersey City in 1953. He then went on to Holy Cross College in Worcester, Mass., on a Navy scholarship as part of the US Navy ROTC program, earning an A.B. with Honors in History & Philosophy in the Honors Course in 1957. Born with a gift for language and expression, Stan effortlessly won debating competitions while at Holy Cross and continued to be through later life an adept writer and public speaker. In 1958, he entered active duty as an ensign with the US Navy. He served on the USS Canberra, one of the first guided missile cruisers, as a member of the staff of the Commander Cruiser Force of the Atlantic Fleet, circumnavigating the globe and twice crossing the Equator at the international dateline. He was released from active service in 1961 with the rank of Lieutenant and joined the Naval Reserve. He ultimately retired from the Reserve in 1995 with the rank of Commander. He married Mary Alyce in June of 1962, and earned his L.L.B. from the Columbia University School of Law in 1963. He practiced law from 1963 to 1971 as an associate attorney in the corporate department of Breed, Abbott & Morgan, a major New York City law firm. In 1971, he left the practice of law and spent the remainder of his professional career in investment banking, initially joining Eastman Dillon, Union Securities & Co. as Vice President of Public Finance. Four years later, he was appointed Executive Vice President of the Municipal Bond division of the merged Blyth Eastman Dillon & Co. in charge of public finance, municipal bond underwriting, trading and sales. He also served as a Director of that firm and converted Eastman Dillon from a niche player in industrial revenue bond financing to top rankings in all important areas of public finance at that time: public power, housing, healthcare, pollution control, transportation and corporate-related issuances. In 1980, he was named Managing Director in charge of the Public Finance Department of Blyth Eastman PaineWebber, and in 1983 Chairman of the Municipal Securities Group management Committee at PaineWebber. In 1985, he joined Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. as Managing Director of the Public Finance Department. Stanley pioneered many of what later became standard state housing revenue bond programs in the single-family, multifamily, and home improvement areas. He served on the Public Securities Association as a member of the Public Finance, Membership and Tax Reform committees. He was a member of the Municipal committee of the Securities Industry Association, also serving as that association's chairman for a term during the 1980s. From 1991, during semi-retirement, he worked as a consultant to Ring, McAfee & Company Inc. in the areas of project finance and merchant banking. Stan and Mary Alyce owned a summer home in Nantucket, Mass., and with their children enjoyed the beauty and serenity of summers there. Stan loved to travel and took every opportunity to do so. He was a devoted Catholic and gave much of his time to active participation in his parish at Immaculate Conception Church, including teaching in the CCD program for many years. Stan loved to have a good time, and shared many late night revelries with friends. He was a maverick who nonetheless succeeded in the system. He was opinionated but also a peacemaker. He bore the burdens of his long illness without complaints or self-pity. He appreciated music and loved to dance. He leaves behind his wife of 50 years, Mary Alyce, and four devoted children: Georgiana M. Pardo of Charles Town, West Virginia, Helaine G. Utzinger and her spouse Henry of Wayne, New Jersey, Thomas S. Pardo, his spouse Johanna, their child, Nicholas S. Pardo, all of Maplewood, New Jersey, and Alyson A. Pardo of Montclair, New Jersey. He also leaves behind his brother Joseph A. Pardo of Philomont, Virginia, his sister Mary Ann Pardo of Holly Spring, North Carolina, and his sister Patricia Walker of Middleburg, Virginia. A wake will be held on Wednesday, April 11 at 2:00 to 4:00pm and 7:00 to 9:00pm at the Moriarty Funeral Home, 76 Park Street, Montclair, NJ, and a funeral mass will be celebrated on Thursday, April 12 at 9:40am at Immaculate Conception Church, 30 North Fullerton Ave., Montclair, NJ. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be made in his memory to St. Peter's Preparatory School, 144 Grand St., Jersey City, NJ 07302 or www.stpetersprep.org, or to the Resurrection School, 189 Brunswick St., Jersey City, NJ 07302 or www.resurrectionschooljcnj.org

A film review on Friday about ''The Hunter,'' in which the prey is the animal known as the Tasmanian tiger, referred imprecisely to its relationship to the wolf. While all life forms are related in the broadest sense, the Tasmanian tiger, which is believed to be extinct, was a marsupial and thus not ''a relative of the wolf.''

OWENS--Fritzi Weitzmann, died on Friday afternoon, just before sundown on Passover. She was a true Aishet Chayil, the Biblical woman of valor. Adored wife of Herbert Owens for more than 68 years, beloved mother of Bob [Evie], Ruth, Mark [Mindy] and sister of Ilse. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother. Raised in Vienna, Austria from her birth in 1924 until the Nazi occupation in 1938, she and her immediate family fled to safety in Albania with the help of its righteous Muslim ruler, King Zog I. After a year in Tirana, Fritzi and her family arrived in New York to start her new life as an American high school student the only woman in her class at the School of Industrial Arts. After graduation, she joined her parents at Weitzmann Photo Studio which they had re-established in New York. Later, Fritzi was the first female volunteer in the Photography Department at the Metropolitan Museum of Art for 25 year. She also served as a volunteer for more than 10 years at the International Foundation of Art Research. She loved attending operas, concerts, and the theater; and spending time with her family. For the past 16 years, she had courageously fought cancer, not allowing her illnesses to slow her down. Her amazingly rich life and marriage have now come to an end. We are heartbroken to be observing Passover without her and her renowned gefilte fish. The private graveside service was held on Sunday morning. Because of the Passover holiday, Shiva will be observed on Sunday, April 15, from 2 to 5pm, at the home of Bob Owens and Evie Klein, 241 Central Park West. Contributions in her memory can be made to Hadassah NY, Sharon Chapter, at 50 West 58th Street, New York, NY 10019.

STRANG--John Perry died on March 25, 2012. Born April 15, 1926 in Chicago; Jack served in WWII. He was awarded three battle stars in the European Theater of Operations and the Bronze Star. He was entitled to wear the Distinguished Unit Citation. He received a degree in Fine Arts from Wesleyan University and studied at the University of Tulsa, The University of Houston and New York University. Pursuing an interest in photography Jack freelanced for national magazines including LIFE. In the 1950's Jack was a member of The Independent Filmmakers in New York. His short film "A Poem of Life" of a sculpture by Aristede Maillot is in the Permanent Collection of the Library of Congress. Working in film and television in New York and California he photographed and directed documentaries and television films. For his work in the field he received several industry awards including the Sylvania Award for Creative Television Technique. Subsequently he founded a private company to explore for oil and natural gas in the US. A descendant of Huguenot refugees who settled in New Rochelle in 1687, Jack established a nonprofit organization Huguenot Heritage to research and to inform the public about cultural, scientific, technical and artistic contributions of the descendents of the Huguenots. He was most pleased with a project to preserve the beautiful but neglected Chateau Chamerolles in Loiret, France, a place of unique Huguenot history. An early marriage ended in divorce. He is survived by a daughter, Suzanne Lightbourn, and two granddaughters. He was member of numerous societies dedicated to history, the fine arts and film. Jack was man of great intelligence, intellectual curiosity and integrity and his wry wit will be missed. A memorial gathering is being planned.

A premiere screening of ''Tiger Eyes,'' a film adaptation of the novel by the New Jersey native Judy Blume that was directed by her son, Lawrence Blume, is among the Garden State-centric events planned for the first Montclair Film Festival, its organizers announced on Monday. The festival, which will run in Montclair, N.J., from May 1 through 6 (and bills itself with the cheeky slogan ''It's Sundance. Only Jersier''), will open with a gala screening of ''The Oranges,'' the Julian Farino comedy set in suburban New Jersey and starring Hugh Laurie, Leighton Meester and Oliver Platt. Other events include a tribute to Kathleen Turner on May 2, which will feature a live interview with that actress; a May 3 screening of ''Cloudburst'' that will be attended by its star, Olympia Dukakis; a comedy event called ''The What-Is-It?,'' featuring commentary on esoteric film clips by the ''Daily Show'' producers Rory Albanese and Adam Lowitt; and conversations with the actor Patrick Wilson, the director Michael Moore, and Michael E. Uslan, a producer of ''The Dark Knight'' and ''The Dark Knight Rises.'' A complete lineup can be found at montclairfilmfest.org. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.
