Edward DeMarco, the regulator for Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, said it might make sense for the mortgage finance companies to write down mortgage loan principal.
A medical journal rejected the company’s request to retract a published report that found that 20 deaths were linked to failures of a heart device component made by the company.
The Marlins summoned Manager Ozzie Guillen from the road to address comments he made about Fidel Castro.
Wall Street notched its fifth consecutive decline on Tuesday fueled by concerns over the euro zone.
The electronics giant, already battered by a number of factors, doubled its projected net loss for the business year that just ended because of an additional tax expense.
Exports surged last month, helping to produce an unexpected trade surplus of $5.35 billion in March, but imports grew lethargically, a warning sign for the nation.
In a major precedent relating to conditions in an American maximum security prison, the court allowed for the extradition of the cleric Abu Hamza al-Masri and four other defendants.
President Obama renewed his call for the ‘Buffett Rule’ minimum tax on annual income over $1 million.
North Korea said on Tuesday that it had completed preparations to launch a satellite into orbit, prompting a flurry of airline rerouting from South Korea and other Asian nations.
A cease-fire plan was teetering, with the Syrian government making new demands, the opposition ridiculing them as unrealistic, and no sign that Syria’s military forces had withdrawn from cities.
Suicide bombers struck in busy areas of Herat and Helmand on Tuesday, killing as many 18 people, according to local police officials.
The Malaysian government introduced a new law in Parliament on Tuesday that would limit detentions of people suspected of terrorism or security offenses to 28 days.
The panel tasted 20 Rioja reservas, aged wines you can drink without paying a fortune or waiting them out.
Riojas, from Spain, are adaptable to many types of dishes.
Saffron lends an exotic note to this soup, and an egg in each bowl makes it a one-dish meal.
Roman egg drop soup, which can be made in any season, is brightened with freshly grated nutmeg and lemon zest.
A recipe for homemade chicken broth.
A recipe for Roman egg drop soup.
Citrus salads brighten winter days, but when it gets warmer, spring lettuce adds a fresh touch.
A recipe for pink grapefruit and radicchio salad with dates and pistachios.

The N.C.A.A. announced that one of its top executives, Greg Shaheen, would not return as the executive vice president for championships and alliances. Mark Lewis, the president of Jet Set Sports, will replace Shaheen. For about a decade, Shaheen ran the N.C.A.A.'s signature event and its biggest money maker: the men's basketball tournament. There is still a chance that Shaheen may return in a less prominent role.
McBAIN--Frances Elizabeth, beloved mother, grandmother and friend died peacefully in her longtime home in Manhattan, on March 31, 2012. We mourn her loss.

As the saying doesn't quite go but should from now on: a Lannister always gets a third season. HBO said on Tuesday that it was ordering another year of ''Game of Thrones,'' its fantasy drama about the warring clans of Starks, Lannisters, Baratheons, Greyjoys and Targaryen (among other unusual permutations of vowels and consonants) on the mythical continent of Westeros. The series, which is adapted from George R. R. Martin's best-selling ''Song of Ice and Fire'' novels and produced by David Benioff and D.B. Weiss, was a breakout hit in its first season, earning an Emmy nomination for best dramatic series and winning an Emmy and a Golden Globe for its star Peter Dinklage, who plays the manipulative Tyrion Lannister. Season 2, which began on April 1, is already off to a strong start, drawing nearly 4 million viewers for the debut broadcasts of each episode that have been shown so far. Dates for the production and premiere of Season 3 of ''Game of Thrones'' were not announced but should occur some time after Daenerys Targaryen crosses the Red Waste. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

The Stanley Cup playoffs are a second season, utterly new. Nothing that happened in the long regular season matters, and so great teams fall to poor teams, heroes stumble and the unsung become champions who lift the old silver chalice come June. Take the first round, which starts Wednesday. The top-seeded Rangers and Canucks and the second-seeded Bruins and Blues have reason to worry. Since the current playoff format was adopted 17 seasons ago, there have been 68 series matching the No. 1 seed in a conference against the No. 8 seed, and No. 2 versus No. 7. Of those 68 series, 23 have ended in victory for the underdog.

An article on Saturday about an illegal immigrant whose brother donated a kidney to him described part of the procedure incorrectly. The ureter -- not the urethra -- was connected to the patient's bladder.

Mitt Romney's aides insist that their boss is a warm, self-deprecating guy when the cameras are off. On Tuesday, a leaked video of Mr. Romney bantering in what he thought was an off-camera moment offered a glimpse of his more relaxed self. A two-and-a-half minute video leaked to the Web site Gawker shows Mr. Romney making small talk before a February interview with Fox News's Sean Hannity in Las Vegas. Though Mr. Romney seems remarkably at ease, some of the conversation -- about, for instance, the horses he owns with his wife -- may not help him combat his wealthy, out-of-touch image. The video was leaked, according to Gawker, by a disgruntled Fox News employee.
An article last Wednesday about eggs produced by backyard chicken coops quoted the price of a legbar egg in London in the wrong currency. It costs £1, not 1 euro.

An Associated Press report in the World Briefing column on Saturday about the first official Good Friday holiday in Cuba in a half-century misidentified a Roman Catholic observation on that day. It is the Passion of the Lord, not a Mass. (No Mass is said on Good Friday.)

Now that Rick Santorum has suspended his campaign, and Newt Gingrichis focusing his efforts on the convention, Mitt Romney still faces one opponent with money: Representative Ron Paul. And on Tuesday, Mr. Paul was campaigning in Texas, his home state, which votes on May 29, to show that the Republican contest was still registering a slight pulse. Mr. Paul was visiting Texas A & M University as part of a three-day swing through the state, which also included stops in Fort Worth and San Antonio. And showing how much the campaign is focused on collecting delegates in Texas, it produced a video before Mr. Santorum's suspension that employs a Texas twang to take swipes at Mr. Santorum (labeling him a ''big-spending, debt-ceiling-raising fiscal liberal''), Newt Gingrich (''the moon colony guy'') and Mitt Romney (''the moderate from Massachusetts'').
JACOBSON--Irving M. Our lifelong cherished friend...you are always in our hearts and minds for the spirit and joy you gave to us. We love you forever. Lynn and Martin Schwat

An article on Friday about the 1944 killing of David Kammerer by the Beat Generation figure Lucien Carr misspelled the given name of Carr's mother, who discovered ''desperate'' letters from Kammerer to her son, according to ''This Is the Beat Generation'' by James Campbell. She was Marion Gratz Carr, not Marian. And a correction in this space on Saturday misspelled the surname of one of the two authors of a screenplay, ''Kill Your Darlings'' that is based on the killing. He is John Krokidas, not Krokidis. (Austin Bunn is his co-writer.)

The Rangers agreed to terms with forward Chris Kreider, a first-round pick in 2009 and a key member of the Boston College team that won the N.C.A.A. championship Saturday, on a three-year contract Tuesday afternoon. Kreider, who turns 21 on April 30, will join the Rangers for practice Wednesday morning. Whether he plays for them during the playoffs is uncertain. If Kreider plays even one game in the postseason, there will be only two years left on his contract.

GER--Ralph, MD, FRCCS, FACS, died on Monday, April 9, at age 91. He was a Professor of Anatomy and Structural Biology at Albert Einstein College of Medicine, where his Anatomy course became popular for generations of medical students who admired both his erudition and his dry sense of humor. He also served as Chairman Emeritus, Dept of Surgery at Winthrop University Hospital in New York and Associate Chairman, Dept. of Surgery at Nassau County Medical Center on Long Island. In addition, he served as a founding member and officer of the American Association of Clinical Anatomists (AACA), authored a widely used anatomy textbook "Essentials of Clinical Anatomy", and developed many surgical devices and procedures. He is survived by his beloved wife Dorrit and loving children Amanda and Jerry Gitlitz, Michael and David, Kevin, grandchildren Jason, Andrew and Alexa and sister Zelda Lowenberg. Funeral services will be held on Thursday, April 12, 2012 at 11am at the Riverside-Nassau North Chapel, Great Neck, NY.

When the Mets play the Nationals on Wednesday in the final game of their three-game series, fans will not only see a marquee matchup between Johan Santana and Stephen Strasburg, but also get to see a slice of history at a bargain-basement price. Roger Craig, the starting pitcher in the Mets' first regular-season game in 1962, will throw out the first pitch Wednesday, which occurred 50 years ago on that date. The Mets lost that game to the Cardinals in St. Louis, and Craig, now 82, went on to lose 24 games in 1962 and 22 more games in 1963. But his good cheer in the face of his hard luck became emblematic of those Mets teams.

A music review on Tuesday about a recital by the Italian soprano Anna Caterina Antonacci, at Alice Tully Hall, misstated her performance history in the United States. She has performed in at least two staged operas in the United States; it is not the case that she has never performed in America.

SOLLEDER--Helena Pichel. September 10, 1922 - February 27, 2012. Born in New York. Graduate of Fordham Law School. Husband: George J. Solleder. Children: Gabrielle and George. Smart, feisty, loving and loyal. She had a zest for life and an indomitable spirit. Funeral Mass Friday, April 13, 10:30am at St. Francis Xavier Church, 46 W. 16 St. Burial at Calvary Cemetery.

''So you've been Titanic-ing,'' Susan Olsen, the staff historian at Woodlawn Cemetery in the Bronx, said when J. Joseph Edgette walked in. Indeed he had. Dr. Edgette is, among other things, an expert on where the ''Titanic people,'' as he calls them, were buried.

BEER--Cy (Seymour), on April 9, 2012. Cherished husband of Ronni. Devoted father of Larry (Cindy), Michael, Steven (Bonnie), and Jeffrey. Beloved grandfather of Jessie, Alyssa, Danielle, Allison, Alex, Adam, Max, Gabriel, and Rebecca. Dear brother of Gertrude, Kay, Daniel, the late David, son of the late Morris and Jennie. Services Thursday 11:45am at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

The Mostly Mozart Festival, in its persistent search for variety, usually finds other composers to highlight. This summer will be no different: a dozen concerts will include works by Schubert, festival officials said on Tuesday. But rarely has it invoked the animal world. The festival said the other focus would be ornithological, as in ''the influence of birdsong on composers and visual artists.'' Programs will include chirp-related works by Messiaen and several contemporary composers. The festival will sponsor bird walks in Central Park, present ''The Murder of Crows,'' an art installation by Janet Cardiff and George Bures Miller, at the Park Avenue Armory, and show the 2001 documentary ''Winged Migration.'' Visiting conductors of the festival orchestra include Yannick Nézet-Séguin, Susanna Mälkki and Osmo Vänska. Among the soloists will be Nelson Freire, Lawrence Brownlee, Joshua Bell and Martin Frost. Louis Langrée will conduct nine concerts in his 10th year asmusic director. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.
$5.75 MILLION 80 Mason Street (at Lewis Street)
JACOBS--Phoebe. From all of us who were fortunate enough to love you and to come along for part of your adventures, thank you. We will miss you. Marty and Lynn

An obituary on Monday about the television journalist Mike Wallace referred incorrectly to an interview he conducted for the CBS News program ''60 Minutes'' with the chemist Jeffrey Wigand, who said tobacco executives had lied when they testified before Congress that they believed nicotine was not addictive. While CBS did not broadcast the interview in November 1995 as originally scheduled, it did indeed broadcast it three months later; it is not the case that ''the interview was not broadcast.'' The obituary also misstated the year when ''60 Minutes'' moved to its longtime time slot, Sunday nights at 7. It was 1975, not 1970.
$4 MILLION 610 East Ninth Street (between Avenues B and C)

POISON PILL Cracker Barrel Old Country Store announced Tuesday that it had adopted a shareholder rights plan to stop Sardar Biglari, left, the investor who has been engaged in a hostile takeover attempt that has lasted months, from accumulating a controlling stake in the restaurant chain. The plan, which Cracker Barrel's board approved on Monday, would take effect once any shareholder accumulates a 20 percent stake in the company. Mr. Biglari's stake stood at 15.5 percent as of March 30. On Monday, Mr. Biglari raised his stake to 16 percent, according to a federal securities filing. KEVIN ROOSE
MELLON--Katherine "Kitty" Woodward, died on March 30, 2012 . A Memorial service will be held on Friday, April 27 at 11:00am at Calvary Church, Stonington, Connecticut.

SEDDON--Paul Edward Cadoc. Much loved son of the late Kathleen and James Seddon and brother and friend to Martin, Vincent and Barbara Seddon. Born in Maesteg, South Wales, on April 27, 1953, he died in Mount Vernon, New York on March 14, 2012. A graduate of Lehman College, he was a gifted writer of poetry, stories and essays. He was also an indefatigable walker and a passionate soccer fan. He will be greatly missed.

Yahoo finally gave employees a hint of its future strategy Tuesday. In a memo obtained by The New York Times, Scott Thompson, the company's new chief executive, told Yahoo's remaining 12,000 employees that he was restructuring the company around three core groups: ''consumer, regions and technology.''

BOKLAN--Donald H. 87, on April 9, 2012. Son of the late Stella and Murray Boklan. Beloved husband to Ruth for 62 years. Cherished father of Charles Boklan, Nancy and Steven Pollack. Adored Grandfather of Scott and Suzi Pollack, David Pollack and Rachel Pollack. Dear Brother of Kenneth and the late Hope Boklan and the late Robert Boklan. Dear brother-in-law of Olive and the late Larry Ellner. Loving Uncle to Pam Boklan and the late John Duell, Meg and James Christiano, Beth Boklan, Jane and Chris Millen, Lisa and Larry Saltzman and Joseph and Michele Ellner. Great-uncle to Robert Duell, Katie and Hannah Millen, Sarah Saltzman, Zachary, Molly and Alex Ellner. Dearest friend to Ann and Benard Fried, James and Leroy Kissam. Grateful patient of Dr. Gary Ross Friedman, MD. Don was always available to help anyone in need Be it family, friend or stranger. Most important were his exemplary qualities of character his selflessness, integrity and his love and devotion to his family and friends. This is his legacy which we shall cherish forever. Funeral service Thursday, April 12, 2012, 11:00am, at Gutterman's, 175 N. Long Beach Rd, Rockville Centre, NY. Interment to follow at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Rt. 109 and Southern State Parkway, Farmingdale, NY.

With the 50th anniversary of the founding of the Rolling Stones fast approaching, speculation about what the band might or might not do to commemorate the date continues. The guitarist Ronnie Wood offered some tantalizing hints on Monday, saying that the group would go into a recording studio later this month ''to just bat some ideas around'' and ''get the feel again.'' Mr. Wood, who joined the Stones in 1975 after the departure of Mick Taylor, spoke to reporters at a news conference in New York at the opening of an exhibition of his paintings, ''Faces, Time and Places.'' Mr. Wood is the junior member of the band, and his opinions carry less weight than those of Mick Jagger or Keith Richards, who have traditionally supplied the group's material and direction, but in the context of the Stones' complicated internal politics Mr. Wood is close to Mr. Richards and often shares his views.

GRUNEWALD--Theodore J.,Sr., 87, on April 6, Stamford CT. Brooklyn native, son of Theodore J. Grunewald and Ellen Jackman. USAAF 1943-46. NYU cum laude 1948. Pioneering ad executive/TV producer. William Esty 1948-52; Doyle Dane Bernbach 1952-3; Director of TV and Radio 1953-5, Hicks and Greist, Vice President 1953-57, bod 1957-, Principal 1958-59, Senior Vice President 1959-65. Created Jerry Lester Show. Opened ad agency, Bliss/Grunewald, Inc., 1965. Began 35-year real estate career 1972; developed, built luxury homes, Stamford; VP for exceptional properties, Wm. Raveis, Greenwich to retirement 2008. Survived by wife of 63 years, Dorothy M. Grunewald, Stamford; son, Theodore J. Grunewald Jr., NYC; daughter, Carol L. Grunewald, and son-in-law Jeremy R. Rifkin, Washington, DC. Predeceased by son, Steven P. Grunewald 1992. Lawrence Funeral Home, Darien, CT.

The 2012 Lollapalooza lineup is a veritable union of reunions, with a roster that includes reconstituted acts like the heavy-metal iron men of Black Sabbath, the alternative rockers Afghan Whigs and the rejuvenated post-hardcore band At the Drive-In, its organizers announced on Wednesday. This long-running summer music festival, founded by the Jane's Addiction front man Perry Farrell, will be held Aug. 3-5 at Grant Park in Chicago, and will also feature headliners like Red Hot Chili Peppers, the Black Keys, the Shins, Florence + the Machine and Jack White, the recently solo White Stripes singer and guitarist, who isn't reuniting with anyone on this outing as far as we know. Other acts on the bill include the Swedish DJ Avicii, Passion Pit, Sigur Ros, The Weeknd, Franz Ferdinand, J. Cole, Frank Ocean, Metric, and tUnE-yArDs, along with no fewer than 100 additional acts. A complete lineup and ticket information can be found online at lollapalooza.com. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

An obituary on Tuesday about Frank H. Strickler, a lawyer who represented two of President Richard M. Nixon's top aides, misidentified the C.I.A. position once held by E. Howard Hunt, who was convicted of helping to organize the 1972 Watergate break-in. He was a C.I.A. officer, not a C.I.A. agent. (An agent is someone who has been recruited to work on behalf of an intelligence service.)

HOROWITZ--Irma Meisel. Our beloved sister Irma died on Sunday, April 8, after a short illness. She was a wonderful sister and friend. We will miss her more than words can express. Marilynn Klein and Gabrielle Zarrow

JACOBS--Phoebe. On behalf of Jazz at Lincoln Center's board, staff and the members of the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra, past and present. All of us at Jazz at Lincoln Center loved Phoebe Jacobs. We loved her feisty outspoken spirit, we loved her New York accent and style, we loved to listen to her talk about the past and her deep friendships with Louis Armstrong and so many other jazz greats, and we loved her optimism and her bright clear gaze always fixed on the next horizon and on the future. More than anything, we loved Phoebe Jacobs because she embodied the very essence and the heart and soul of America's greatest art form, jazz. She talked jazz, she swung jazz, she ate jazz, she danced jazz, and she lived the past and future of jazz. She was her own second line and wherever she was, the language, sound, taste and smell of our music - jazz - was always there. Almost from the very beginning of Jazz at Lincoln Center she was one of our brightest guardian angels. Phoebe and the Louis Armstrong Foundation, which she chaired and vice chaired, were there to guide, fund and challenge us to do more to spread the good news about jazz and its unique position in the story of America and American culture. The millions of dollars from the Louis Armstrong Foundation were essential to our growth and recognized success but even more important was the special gift Phoebe gave to us: the gift of herself with her warm, wonderful, honest personality. Her deep devotion and belief in the importance of this music helped us create so many programs which will influence generations of children to love jazz as she did and recognize its powerful message of making the world a warmer, more democratic and soulful place. We loved Phoebe dearly and will miss her and the sparkle she radiated whenever she entered our House of Swing. We send our deepest sympathy to her children and grandchildren. Lisa Schiff, Chairman Wynton Marsalis, Artistic Director Gordon J. Davis, Founding Chairman

SILVERMAN--Karen F. Our deepest sympathies to Richard, Jared, Julia and the entire Haftel and Silverman families on this saddest of occasions. Karen will be forever in all our hearts and we will always cherish the memories of our times spent together. Love, Peter, Heather, Caroline, Pamela and Neil Boneparth

ALDRICH--Frances "Daisy" Daggett, of Providence, Rhode Island, South Dartmouth, Massachusetts and Vero Beach, Florida, died on April 2, 2012. Daisy was born on December 9, 1923, to Frances White Daggett and David Lewis Daggett of New Haven, Connecticut. On September 13, 1943, she married Richard Steere Aldrich, the son of Janet Innis Aldrich and Richard S. Aldrich of Providence, Rhode Island. Her husband, Dick, died in 1997. Daisy is survived by her four children: Frances Aldrich Llopis of Madrid, Spain; Richard S. Aldrich, Jr. of New York City; Abby Aldrich Gray of Baltimore and William Stuart Aldrich of Chicago. Daisy is also survived by eight grandchildren: Francesca Garrigues, Lavinia Llopis, Lucy A. Gray, Lydia C. Gray, Richard S. Aldrich IV, Peter T. Aldrich, Russell P. Aldrich and Caroline H. Aldrich; and three great-grandchildren: Michaela de la Mata, Chloe Moraleda and Gilda Moraleda. Daisy served as a Regent, Trustee, Regent Chair and Honorary Chair of the Capital Campaign for the George Washington Foundation, and was a member of the alumna board of Miss Porter's School. A memorial service will be held at Grace Church, 175 Mathewson Street, Providence, at 2pm on Saturday, April 14, 2012. In lieu of flowers, donations in Daisy's memory may be made to the Providence Animal Rescue League, 34 Elbow Street, Providence, RI 02903.
JACOBSON--Irving, 93, passed away on April 9, 2012. Survived by his wife, Evelyn and his children and grandchildren. He was a good man, loved by many.

An obituary on March 30 about the novelist Harry Crews described an incident from his childhood incorrectly. He fell into a cauldron of scalding water used to slough the hair -- not the skin -- off slaughtered hogs.

An editorial on Saturday about a natural gas drilling proposal in Utah said incorrectly that the energy company, Gasco of Denver, had not met with conservation groups, chiefly the Southern Utah Wilderness Alliance. The company and the wilderness alliance met numerous times last year.

KLEIN--Elaine, on April 7, 2012. A beloved and significantly contributing member of the PLAYBILL Magazine family for more than 40 years. In recent years, Elaine was an active volunteer at the Cedar Sinai Medical Center, Los Angeles. Dearest mother of Cyd Tomack, and Amy and Kevin Campion, cherished grandmother of Brooke Maduri and Taylor Tomack, great-grandmother to Katy and Tyler Maduri and Aunt to Stephen Kessler and Linda Kaplan. Services: Thursday at Riverside, 180 West 76th St. at 12:45pm.

KARPEL--Leonard, died April 9. Beloved husband of Elaine, devoted father of Anne Freilich, the late Sharon Kleiman, Jeffrey and Marcy Karpel, grandfather to Avi and Adir Freilich, Michael Tietel, Rachael and Zach Bernstein, Lewis and Cheryl Karpel. Funeral services Wednesday April 11, 11:30am Jewish Center of Kew Gardens Hills, 71-25 Main St., Flushing, NY. Contributions to honor Leonard's legacy to AICR/ Sharon Karpel Kleiman Memorial Fund 1759 R St., NW, Washington, DC 20009.

There's no shortage of jokes to be made about Brooklyn, but are there enough places in Brooklyn to make jokes? The Brooklyn Academy of Music and the IFC cable channel are working together on a new opportunity for comedians to perform their material in that borough (whether their bits are about Marty Markowitz or double-wide baby strollers). This week the two organizations are expected to announce the introduction of a free monthly comedy showcase at BAM. The showcase, ''Get It Out There: Comedy by BAM & IFC,'' which will be presented for the first time on April 25, will be held at the BAMcafé and will feature performances by Wyatt Cenac (of ''The Daily Show With Jon Stewart''), Mike Lawrence, Damien Lemon and Giulia Rozzi. The show is hosted by Jared Logan, and additional dates, with lineups to be announced, are planned for May 30, June 27, Sept. 12, Oct. 3, Nov. 7 and Dec. 5.

MARCUS--Philip. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Philip Marcus, chair of our St. Francis Hospital Health Care Professionals Committee. Through his exceptional dedication and generosity, he has benefited countless individuals in New York and around the world. We extend our condolences to Philip's wife, Rovena; his children, Mitchell, Brian, and Alyssa; his grandchildren; and the entire family. Jerry W. Levin, President Alisa R. Doctoroff, Chair of the Board, John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

OWENS--Fritzi Weitzmann, died on Friday afternoon, just before sundown on Passover. She was a true Aishet Chayil, the Biblical woman of valor. Adored wife of Herbert Owens for more than 68 years, beloved mother of Bob [Evie], Ruth, Mark [Mindy] and sister of Ilse. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother. Raised in Vienna, Austria from her birth in 1924 until the Nazi occupation in 1938, she and her immediate family fled to safety in Albania with the help of its righteous Muslim ruler, King Zog I. After a year in Tirana, Fritzi and her family arrived in New York to start her new life as an American high school student the only woman in her class at the School of Industrial Arts. After graduation, she joined her parents at Weitzmann Photo Studio which they had re-established in New York. Later, Fritzi was the first female volunteer in the Photography Department at the Metropolitan Museum of Art for 25 year. She also served as a volunteer for more than 10 years at the International Foundation of Art Research. She loved attending operas, concerts, and the theater; and spending time with her family. For the past 16 years, she had courageously fought cancer, not allowing her illnesses to slow her down. Her amazingly rich life and marriage have now come to an end. We are heartbroken to be observing Passover without her and her renowned gefilte fish. The private graveside service was held on Sunday morning. Because of the Passover holiday, Shiva will be observed on Sunday, April 15, from 2 to 5pm, at the home of Bob Owens and Evie Klein, 241 Central Park West. Contributions in her memory can be made to Hadassah NY, Sharon Chapter, at 50 West 58th Street, New York, NY 10019.

ZIER--Helen, (nee Blum), June 30, 1917 - April 9, 2012. Devoted wife to the late Herman Zier, CPA. Beloved mother of Donna Leonhart, Merri Jurasin, Dr. Bennett Zier, Jonathan Zier, and Richard Zier. Loving grandmother of twelve grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. She was an inspiration to her family and will be dearly missed by all three generations. Nous vous aimons. Au revoir.

SATERSON--Athena, (nee Galidas), 84 years old, died on April 8, 2012. Journalist for 28 years with The Ridgewood News and longtime resident of Ridgewood, NJ. As a native New Yorker, her lifelong loves included art, travel and spending time in New York. Cherished mother of Constantine, George, Kathryn, Anastasia and Chrysanthe. She is predeceased by her husband George in 2011. Beloved grandmother of Michael, Catherine and Maya.

JACOBS--Phoebe. The trustees and staff of the Louis Armstrong House Museum are saddened by the passing of Phoebe Jacobs, longtime Vice-President of the Louis Armstrong Educational Foundation, and extend their heartfelt condolences to her family and friends. Without Phoebe's vision and efforts, there would not today be a thriving Louis Armstrong House Museum in Queens. She was one-of-a-kind, a remarkable raconteuse, and will be greatly missed.

The Mostly Mozart Festival, in its persistent search for variety, usually finds other composers to highlight. This summer will be no different: a dozen concerts will include works by Schubert, festival officials said on Tuesday. But rarely has it invoked the animal world. The festival said the other focus would be ornithological, as in ''the influence of birdsong on composers and visual artists.'' Programs will include chirp-related works by Messiaen and several contemporary composers. The festival will sponsor bird walks in Central Park and show the 2001 documentary ''Winged Migration.'' ''The Murder of Crows,'' an art installation by Janet Cardiff and George Bures Miller at the Park Avenue Armory, will be presented and organized by the Armory in association with the festival. Visiting conductors of the festival orchestra include Yannick Nézet-Séguin, Susanna Mälkki and Osmo Vänska. Among the soloists will be Nelson Freire, Lawrence Brownlee, Joshua Bell and Martin Frost. Louis Langrée will conduct nine concerts in his 10th year as music director. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

A report last Wednesday in the Food Stuff column referred incorrectly to the system of plastic taps and tubing that Crown Maple Farm uses to collect sap to make its syrup. The system is used by most large maple-sugar producers; it is not a new process.

LOS ANGELES - DreamWorks Studios, the film boutique founded four years ago by Steven Spielberg and Stacey Snider, got a new lease on life, as Reliance Entertainment agreed in principle to continue financing the company. Under the arrangement, DreamWorks will make fewer movies than in the past, according to people briefed on the deal who spoke on condition of anonymity, because neither Reliance nor DreamWorks had authorized public discussion of the agreement while it was being completed. Spokesmen for both Reliance and DreamWorks declined to comment.

BORN--Esther. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Esther Born, a generous, longtime contributor. Beloved wife of the late Robert Born, Esther and her family have perpetuated a powerful legacy through their generosity and commitment. We extend our condolences to her children, Richard (Debbie) Born and Rita (Fred) Distenfeld; her brother, Harry Wittlin; and the entire family. Jerry W. Levin, President Alisa R. Doctoroff, Chair of the Board, John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

An article on Monday about Bubba Watson's victory at the Masters golf tournament referred incorrectly in some copies to the shot he hit from the woods to get onto the green on the second hole of the playoff against Louis Oosthuizen. He hooked the shot onto the green; he did not slice it. The error was repeated in a picture caption in some copies.

Most people would think that Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg of the Supreme Court would need more security than Alan R. Mulally, the chief executive of Ford Motor Company. Ford's directors don't seem to agree. The board requires that Mr. Mulally - for safety reasons - fly on a private jet whether he is going to Washington for business or Hawaii for vacation.

The pianist Cecil Taylor, a fundamental influence in the wilder currents of improvised music since the 1950s, will be the subject of a two-week series of concerts and films in Manhattan and Brooklyn in May, produced jointly by Harlem Stage and Issue Project Room. (Information and tickets for the concerts are available through their Web sites.) ''Cecil Taylor: A Celebration of the Maestro'' will include two nights of solo piano programs dedicated to Mr. Taylor by Vijay Iyer, Craig Taborn and Amina Claudine Myers, with a guest appearance by the poet Amiri Baraka, on May 8 and 9 at Harlem Stage Gatehouse; a concert by the pianist Thollem McDonas, the bass clarinetist Arrington de Dionyso and the drummer-bandleader William Hooker on May 16 at Issue Project Room; and two solo performances by Mr. Taylor, on May 17 at Harlem Stage Gatehouse and May 19 at Issue Project Room. (On May 22, Anthology Film Archives will present a slate of video footage from Mr. Taylor's past.)

The writer and director Chris Weitz is trying his hand at young-adult fiction. Mr. Weitz, who directed ''The Twilight Saga: New Moon,'' will write a trilogy of post-apocalyptic novels for Little, Brown Books for Young Readers, a division of the Hachette Book Group, his publisher announced. The first book in the series, ''The Young World,'' is expected to be released in spring 2014. ''Chris Weitz offers a premise that is completely provocative and irresistible for teens: What if we ran the world?'' Megan Tingley, the publisher of the division, said in a statement. ''We were impressed by his ability to tell a timely and compelling story that is every bit as vivid on the page as it would be on the screen.''

(NBC) LAW & ORDER: SPECIAL VICTIMS UNIT After a woman is raped in a style similar to that in a case Detective Benson (Mariska Hargitay, above left, with Kelli Giddish) solved eight years earlier, squad members are forced to re-examine old evidence, which resulted in a confession by the suspect after a tough interrogation but claims of innocence from him ever since. Now they must determine whether they are dealing with a copycat assault or wrongful imprisonment, causing friction between Haden (Harry Connick Jr.), the executive assistant district attorney, and Benson when her detective work is challenged. Mark Consuelos guest stars in this Season 13 spring premiere. 9:30 A.M. (CUNY) CITY TALK Neera Tanden, president of the Center for American Progress, discusses competing visions of the American dream, income equality and the Affordable Care Act. The show is repeated at 4:30 and 9:30 p.m.

SAMET-DAVIS--Lori Susan Blank, October 2, 1940 - April 8, 2012. Beloved wife of jazz musician Charles Davis. Sister of Karen Cohen; stepmother (four); aunt (two); grandmother (five); great-grandmother (five). Graduate of Skidmore College, 1961. Family and friends throughout the world loved her and will miss her wit, intelligence, and passion for life. Contributions can be made, in lieu of flowers, to the American Cancer Society. A memorial is being planned.

PARKE--Lois E.,born on February 6, 1930, a former resident of New York City and Cherry Grove, Fire Island, died April 10th in Boca Raton, FL, surrounded by friends and her long-time companion, Helen Turnquest. A retired Assistant Professor of Health Studies at New York City Technical College, Lois graduated from Kent State and received a Masters in Public Health from Columbia University. She was also a long time friend of Bill W and her spirit will live on in the many lives she touched. A celebration of Lois's life will be held this summer in Cherry Grove. Contributions in Lois's memory may be made to the Cherry Grove Dune Fund, Box 4115, Cherry Grove, NY 11782.

MARCUS--Dr. Philip, 65, a world renowned pulmonologist died April 9th in Paris, France. Phil was born in New York City on November 26, 1946. He was the beloved husband and best friend to Rovena Marcus for more than 42 years. Born and raised in the Lower East Side of NYC, Phil went on to accomplish greatness, as a doctor, a family man and philanthropist. He graduated from Columbia University, cum laude with a BS degree in Pharmaceutical Sciences with honors in Pharmacology. He went on to receive his medical degree from State University of New York-Downstate Medical Center, College of Medicine, graduating summa cum laude. He was the founder of Nassau Chest Physicians and served on the Board of Directors of the American Lung Association. He also served as Chief of the Division of Pulmonary Medicine at St. Francis Hospital-The Heart Center in Roslyn, NY. Phil was a consummate student and in 1999 at the Bloomberg School of Public Health-John Hopkins University where he earned the M.P.H. degree in May, 2002. A passionate student, Phil was an equally passionate teacher. He was actively involved in teaching medical students as well as residents in Internal Medicine and Pulmonary Medicine. He was a Clinical Professor of Medicine and Pharmacology and the Associate Dean for Curriculum Development at the New York College of Osteopathic Medicine. He held teaching appointments at State University of New York at Stony Brook, St. John's University, and NYU School of Medicine. Philanthropy played an important role in Phil's life. Having grown up in extremely humble conditions, those in need were never far from his mind. He generously supported myriad causes and organizations. Phil was a major fundraiser for Jewish causes including UJA, Shaare Zedek Hospital in Jerusalem as well as an advocate for accessible health care supporting the American Lung Association and RotaCare both of which he was honored by for his work. Even more, and perhaps most importantly, Phil never ignored the needs of his patients and was known to provide medical care to his neediest of patients free of charge or in exchange for some home cooked food! Phil's love of travel took him all over the world, where he could continue to soak up and learn about everything from Italian food and Jewish antiquities to Parisian art and German opera. It was these trips that he was blessed to share with Rovena and regales his family with stories upon his return. One of Phil's proudest achievements was his family who loved him immensely. Affectionately known as Pop-Phil, he spent much of his free time with his children and grandchildren, often hosting big family dinners that were filled with a lot of energy and laughter. In addition to being survived by his wife Rovena of Jericho; Phil is also survived by his in-laws and surrogate parents Morton and Harriet Shreck; sons: Mitch husband of Sarah Marcus of Forest Hills, Brian husband of Faith Marcus of New York City, a daughter Alyssa wife of Gary Klein of Harrisburg Pennsylvania; and grandchildren, Max Marcus, Luke Marcus, Julia Klein, Jake Marcus, Jenna Klein and Liam Philip Marcus.

Fritzi is survived by her husband, Herbert; her three children, Bob, Ruth, and Mark; and her sister, Ilse. We extend our condolences to the entire family. Jerry W. Levin, President Alisa R. Doctoroff, Chair of the Board, John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

MANILA -- Philippine and Chinese officials on Wednesday called for a diplomatic solution to a naval standoff in the South China Sea, while insisting that they would defend their territorial claims in the region. ''If the Philippines is challenged, we are prepared to secure our sovereignty,'' Albert F. del Rosario, the Philippine foreign secretary, said at a news conference as a Philippine frigate and two Chinese ships positioned themselves near disputed islands in the South China Sea. The Chinese Embassy in Manila issued a statement reaffirming its claim to sovereignty over the islands and said that the Philippine Navy was harassing its fishing vessels in the area.

JACOBS--Phoebe. The trustees and staff of the Louis Armstrong House Museum are saddened by the passing of Phoebe Jacobs, longtime Vice-President of the Louis Armstrong Educational Foundation, and extend their heartfelt condolences to her family and friends. Without Phoebe's vision and efforts, there would not today be a thriving Louis Armstrong House Museum in Queens. She was one-of-a-kind, a remarkable raconteuse, and will be greatly missed.

Lowepro has built a camera bag of Olympic proportions. Its Flipside 500 AW bag, the newest addition to the Flipside line, was originally built specifically for the 2010 Winter Olympics, with the capacity to carry a professional DSLR with a 500mm lens attached. But you could only have one of the limited-edition bags if you were one of 1,200 accredited photographers who were given one as a gift.

Many waterproof iPhone cases turn the sleek device into a oversized lump with all the elegance of a 1950s diving bell. Not so with the LifeProof iPhone case, which claims to be the slimmest waterproof case for the iPhone, adding just a sixteenth of an inch in thickness.
NEUFELD--S. Arthur, 90. Beloved husband of the late Dorothy R. Neufeld. Survived by his nieces Marjorie Weinreb and Barbara Wright and nephew Peter Wright.

MURPHY--Nora Sharkey, who retired as Associate Superintendent of Schools for Communications and Marketing for the Archdiocese of New York in 2006, died on April 9, 2012 at the age of 71. Mrs. Murphy was a resident of Bronxville/Eastchester. She was a member of the adjunct faculty of The Graduate School at The College of New Rochelle and the host of a weekly talk show program on WVOX-AM. The author of "A Youth Guide To Saint Patrick's Cathedral," Mrs. Murphy was a communications consultant to schools, Catholic dioceses and non-profit agencies throughout the Northeast. She was a graduate of The Fordham University School of Education and held a master's degree from Manhattan College. She was the widow of Michael G. Murphy, who died in 2003. Mrs. Murphy is survived by her son, Michael T., of Covington, WA, and three grandsons, Evan, Alexander and Aidan. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 6 to 9pm Thursday and 9 to 10:30am Friday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, on Friday, April 13, at 11am. In lieu of flowers, contributions to HOPE Community Services (50 Washington Avenue, New Rochelle) or The Marist Brothers (4200 West 115th Street, Chicago, Illinois 60655) would be appreciated.

We extend our deepest condolences to Dr. Axelrod and her family on their loss. H. Leon Pachter M.D. F.A.C.S The George David Stewart Professor and Chair Department of Surgery NYU School of Medicine

An article last Thursday about the Brooklyn Brainery, an adult-education center, misstated the surname of a student there and misstated the given name of a course instructor. The student is Kenyon Cory, not Cody, and the instructor is Michelle Jackson, not Melissa. The article also described incorrectly the work of Jonathan Soma, a founder of the Brooklyn Brainery. He is a freelance Web programmer, not an IT temp.

SOLLEDER--Helena Pichel. September 10, 1922 - February 27, 2012. Born in New York. Graduate of Fordham Law School. Husband: George J. Solleder. Children: Gabrielle and George. Smart, feisty, loving and loyal. She had a zest for life and an indomitable spirit. Funeral Mass Friday, April 13, 10:30am at St. Francis Xavier Church, 46 W. 16 St. Burial at Calvary Cemetery.

KNOPP--Kenneth M.,died on April 9 in Boynton Beach, FL. Born on November 21, 1923 in Manhattan. Loving Husband of the late Marlyse B. Knopp. Beloved Father/Father-in-law of Randy and Heidi. Proud Grandfather of Alexis, Robert and Keith. Navy Veteran of WW II. His warmth humor and exuberance will be missed by all who knew him.

BEER--Cy (Seymour), on April 9, 2012. Cherished husband of Ronni. Devoted father of Larry (Cindy), Michael, Steven (Bonnie), and Jeffrey. Beloved grandfather of Jessie, Alyssa, Danielle, Allison, Alex, Adam, Max, Gabriel, and Rebecca. Dear brother of Gertrude, Kay, Daniel, the late David, son of the late Morris and Jennie. Services Thursday 11:45am at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

With a bittersweet reference to its best-known movie franchise, Lucasfilm, the production company of George Lucas and the studio behind the ''Star Wars'' saga, said that it would not pursue plans to build a new facility in Marin County, Calif., saying that it feared alienating neighbors and wanted to work with ''communities that see us as a creative asset, not as an evil empire.'' Lucasfilm, which operates its Skywalker Ranch in Marin as well as the Letterman Digital Arts Center in northern San Francisco, had been seeking to build a new 269,000-square-foot studio called Grady Ranch in an area known as Lucas Valley (which is not named after Mr. Lucas). But the project had met with fierce resistance from other Lucas Valley residents concerned about its potential impact on the environment and their quality of living.

The band may be called One Direction, but it turns out there are two claimants to that name. As a result, the British boy band whose debut CD, ''Up All Night,'' immediately went to the top of the Billboard pop chart when it was released last month is being sued by a pop-rock quartet from California that says it has been in business under that name since 2009. In a suit filed Monday in federal court in Los Angeles, the California-based One Direction requested both $1 million in damages and an injunction to prevent the British band, which came to prominence on Simon Cowell's television talent show ''The X Factor'' in 2010, from continuing to use the name. The complaint says that the management of the British quintet knew that the California group had registered the name in the United States but chose to ignore its rights when it decided to enter the American market.

When Andy Dunn helped start Bonobos five years ago, he wanted to shake up the retail industry with a men's wear brand exclusively sold online. Now Mr. Dunn, 33, is embracing the brick-and-mortar model, striking a partnership with Nordstrom, the 111-year-old department store.

Last New Year's Eve, Eric Dompierre was at a party with his high school basketball teammates. At 12:30 a.m., he called his father, Dean Dompierre, to see if he could stay out for another hour. By 2 a.m., his father was good-naturedly dragging him home. It was a typical night in the life of a teenager in Ishpeming, Mich., a small mining town of about 7,000 people in the state's Upper Peninsula, exactly the sort of night that Dean Dompierre had always wanted for his son.

SCHOW--Howard Bernard, 84, passed away peacefully early Easter morning, April 8th, 2012 from natural causes. He was a beloved husband, father, father-in-law, grandfather, and one of the world's great stock pickers. He is survived by his wife Nan, three children and their spouses, and five grandchildren. Howard was Founder and Chairman Emeritus of PRIMECAP Management Company. Previously, he had been Chairman of Capital Research and Management in Los Angeles where he managed the AMCAP Fund until he left in 1983 to start PRIMECAP, where he was known as the lead manager for the Vanguard PRIMECAP Fund. Howard shunned the media because he believed his ideas belonged to their clients. But, his 50 year record as a portfolio manager garnered the attention and respect of the investment community as one of the very best in the mutual fund business. His stock picking ability extended across decades, investment types, company sizes, and market conditions. The one constant was his ability to outperform the market. Howard's colleagues will remember him for his competitive spirit, his utter dedication to his profession, his sense of obligation and responsibility to the client, and his eternal optimism. Howard started his philanthropy as soon as he had the means, and was partial to his alma mater, Williams College, endowing a professorship and giving the lead gift for the Nan and Howard Schow Science Library. In 2000, he funded a private family foundation to support healthcare, education, and the environment at the community level. Just as with his investments, he enjoyed meeting people and seeing results. To date, the foundation has supported 99 organizations, including the new Nan and Howard Schow Trauma Center at Huntington Memorial Hospital. A memorial service will take place at St. Edmunds Church in San Marino, California, on Saturday, April 21, at 10am. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to Huntington Memorial Hospital Office of Philanthropy (100 West California Blvd, Pasadena, California 91105) or www.huntingtonhospital.com or The Nature Conservancy - Santa Cruz Island Project (c/o The Nature Conservancy, attn: Reve Warfield, 201 Mission Street, 4th floor, San Francisco, CA 94105) in memory of Howard B. Schow.

Salman Rushdie's coming memoir about his years in hiding has a title, and it requires a little explanation. ''Joseph Anton,'' as the book is called, was Mr. Rushdie's alias during the decade when he went underground after the 1989 publication of his novel ''The Satanic Verses'' led Iran's Ayatollah Khomeini to issue a fatwa calling for his death. The order was lifted in 1998.

COOL GIRLS HAVE ALWAYS BORROWED FROM THE BOYS. That rebellious spirit is celebrated in ''Tomboy Style,'' just out from Rizzoli and filled with raffish images of Françoise Hardy, Lou Doillon and others who, in their dress, don't follow the rules. This spring, fashion inspired by men's wear -- dress shirts and shoes, suspenders, ties -- is widely accessible, in part because it is more femme than usual. With softened colors and shapes, you can slip into your boyfriend jeans without looking like your boyfriend.

An article on March 29 about the reality television show ''Mob Wives'' misidentified the location used for the show's opening scene. It is Battery Park in Manhattan overlooking the Jersey City waterfront -- not the Staten Island waterfront overlooking the Manhattan skyline.

A year ago, when word emerged that Republicans in Wisconsin were encouraging less-than-genuine candidates to run in Democratic primary elections as a strategy, some Wisconsin residents voiced shock. This was not the way politics traditionally had been done around here, they said. But as candidates in recall elections for Wisconsin governor, lieutenant governor, and four Republican-held State Senate seats filed petitions by a state deadline on Tuesday, no one seemed particularly surprised to see more of the same -- what Democrats were calling ''fake Democrats'' and Republicans were openly describing as ''protest candidates.'' After more than a year of division and tumult in the state's political doings, little seems left to surprise anyone.

Barney McKenna, whose racing, raucous and often lyrically haunting banjo playing helped propel the Irish folk band the Dubliners to fame, died on Thursday at his home in Dublin. The last of the original members of the band, he was 72. Michael Howard, a classical guitarist who was with Mr. McKenna when he died, told Irish and British newspapers that they were at the kitchen table when Mr. McKenna seemed to have ''nodded off.''

A federal appeals court has restricted the use of a national law cited in federal prosecutors' efforts to convict a former Goldman Sachs programmer accused of illegally downloading computer code from his onetime employer. In an opinion released on Wednesday, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit ruled that the former employee, Sergey Aleynikov, had not violated the Economic Espionage Act of 1996 or federal stolen property laws. The opinion elaborates on the February decision by a three-judge panel of the appeals court to overturn Mr. Aleynikov's conviction, a reversal that dealt a blow to one of the most prominent federal prosecutions of corporate espionage in recent years.

SHIRTDRESSES, crisp and tailored, are a refreshing reminder of how easy dressing can be. This spring, between the racks of crazy-salad prints, there are tweaked shirtdresses from virtually every label, each a blank canvas for dressing up. While the days are still cool, layer on a pullover and blazer, buttoning the shirt all the way to the neck. As it warms up, style simply with a wide white belt and black ankle-strap pumps, as on Céline's spring runway. By summer, think rolled-up sleeves and a straw hat. The options are limitless. Clockwise from top right: Sacai shirtdress with knit vest, $1,455 at Barneys New York, barneys.com; Miu Miu checked shirtdress, $1,395 at net-a-porter.com; Proenza Schouler belted cotton shirtdress, $850 at Bergdorf Goodman, bergdorfgoodman.com; Junya Watanabe cotton shirtdress, $895 at net-a-porter.com; Boy by Band of Outsiders leather-trimmed cotton shirtdress, $725 at net-a-porter.com.

One of the most famous independent record stores in the world is opening a branch in Brooklyn. Rough Trade, which opened in London in 1976, became one of the epicenters of the punk movement. Two years later, it started a record label that helped define the sound and look of post-punk with releases by Scritti Politti, Stiff Little Fingers, the Raincoats and the Television Personalities. Later, the label found its biggest claim to fame when it signed the Smiths (and, later still, another coup with the Strokes).

Alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City from Thursday to Saturday because of Passover, Orthodox Holy Thursday and Orthodox Good Friday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

An article on March 31 about the drugging and killing of nine Afghan militia members, purportedly by a colleague, misidentified the manufacturer of the Ranger pickup truck used by the fleeing suspect. It is Ford, not Toyota.

GRUNEWALD--Theodore J.,Sr., 87, on April 6, Stamford CT. Brooklyn native, son of Theodore J. Grunewald and Ellen Jackman. USAAF 1943-46. NYU cum laude 1948. Pioneering ad executive/TV producer. William Esty 1948-52; Doyle Dane Bernbach 1952-3; Director of TV and Radio 1953-5, Hicks and Greist, Vice President 1953-57, bod 1957-, Principal 1958-59, Senior Vice President 1959-65. Created Jerry Lester Show. Opened ad agency, Bliss/Grunewald, Inc., 1965. Began 35-year real estate career 1972; developed, built luxury homes, Stamford; VP for exceptional properties, Wm. Raveis, Greenwich to retirement 2008. Survived by wife of 63 years, Dorothy M. Grunewald, Stamford; son, Theodore J. Grunewald Jr., NYC; daughter, Carol L. Grunewald, and son-in-law Jeremy R. Rifkin, Washington, DC. Predeceased by son, Steven P. Grunewald 1992. Lawrence Funeral Home, Darien, CT.

TULSA, Okla. -- In the minutes after a shooting spree left three of their neighbors dead and two others wounded, several residents told the police everything they had seen and heard. But only several. Abandoned properties hold no witnesses. In the largely black neighborhoods of north Tulsa where the shootings took place, dozens of homes and businesses surrounding the four locations of the attacks are empty.

A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Wednesday about this summer's Mostly Mozart Festival, using information from the festival, referred incompletely to the art installation ''The Murder of Crows'' at the Park Avenue Armory, an offering related to the festival's bird theme. It will be presented and organized by the Armory in association with the Mostly Mozart Festival, not by the festival alone.

MARWOOD, a line of neckwear handmade in England, came into being on a blog. Becky French, who worked as a designer at Ralph Lauren and Aquascutum, began compiling an online sketchbook of bespoke English tie patterns and other inspirational images, from which her real-life line took shape. The results are beautiful little things: ties made from traditional English lace and high-quality woven silk. Ideal for men and women with an eye for detail. (Susie Lau has gushed about them on Style Bubble.) One older gentleman looking for a tie told Ms. French, ''This is something Oscar Wilde would wear.'' Marwood lace bow ties, $165 at Barneys New York; barneys.com.

Yes, this was it, the park officer said when a man with a rather bulky camera asked if he had found the right place. ''Our famous pier,'' she said. Pier 54, a few steps west and south of West 14th Street, is not much to look at these days: a rusted frame of an entrance, a partly collapsed deck, a lot of cracked pavement with weeds poking up.

Donna Murphy, a two-time Tony Award winner, will play the Witch in this summer's Shakespeare in the Park production of the Stephen Sondheim-James Lapine musical ''Into the Woods,'' the show's producers at the Public Theater announced on Wednesday. Ms. Murphy joins several previously announced cast members, including Amy Adams as the Baker's Wife, Gideon Glick as Jack and Jessie Mueller as Cinderella. Still to be cast is the role of the Baker, played on Broadway by Chip Zien and then Stephen DeRosa. ''Into the Woods'' begins its five-week engagement at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park on July 23, with opening night set for Aug. 9. Timothy Sheader will direct, with co-direction by Liam Steel.

CHOOKASIAN--Lili, a Contralto with the Metropolitan Opera from 1962 to 1986 and a Professor of Music at Yale University from 1986 to 2009, died on April 10, 2012. She was internationally renowned by conductors, fellow musicians and colleagues for her musicianship, deep, dark, velvet-like singing voice, and unique vocal qualities. She appeared with many of the world's major symphony orchestras and opera companies in a stage career that spanned five decades from the 1940s through the 1960s. In later life, she taught voice at Yale University and lived in Branford, CT. She is survived by three children, 11 grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren. Services will be held at W. S. Clancy Memorial Funeral Home, 244 North Main St., Branford on April 12, 2012 from 4 to 7pm and at St. Vartan's Armenian Cathedral in Manhattan at 11am. The family requests that donations be made, in lieu of flowers, to either Connecticut Hospice in Branford, CT or St. Vartan's Armenian Cathedral in New York City.

This week on the music charts, Nicki Minaj opens at No. 1 and Madonna earns a dubious distinction with the biggest second-week sales drop for a No. 1 album in at least 21 years. Ms. Minaj's new album, ''Pink Friday: Roman Reloaded'' (Young Money/Cash Money/Universal Republic), sold 253,000 copies last week, according to Nielsen SoundScan, easily reaching the top spot on Billboard's chart. It is the second No. 1 album by Ms. Minaj, a Queens-born rapper whose costume closet and onstage persona are possibly even more flamboyant than Lady Gaga's. Her first album, ''Pink Friday,'' opened at No. 2 in late 2010 and reached the top a few months later. (Despite the title, ''Roman Reloaded'' is not a reissue or repackaging, but a new release.)

A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Friday about items from the New York Public Library's American collections that will be digitized and made available online misstated the given name of one of the brothers for whom the library's Berg Collection of English and American Literature is named. He was Albert A. Berg, not Alfred.

Wednesday's installment of President Obama's running campaign to raise the taxes of millionaires featured a group of wealthy people who agree with him, standing at his side as he professed that the idea is popular among the gilded elite from Warren Buffett on down. ''The people who've joined me here today are extremely successful,'' Mr. Obama said during an appearance in the White House complex.

Sell-out rock shows usually mean a lot of shouting, some sweating, maybe a few drunken pass-outs. Kraftwerk inspired none of that on Tuesday night. The first of its eight consecutive sold-out performances at the Museum of Modern Art had reverence and stylistic weight; even for a New York museum crowd there was a lot of black. Artfully swept hair, uncomfortable-looking shoes, architectural glasses: check, check and check. The high-design audience was rewarded with an equally aesthetically tuned concert, with the band, a foursome in graphic black-and-white unitards, playing neon-lighted synths. Behind them a video screen offered a parade of simple 3-D images, like stick figure robots and spinning numbers, a retro future in an MS-DOS font. The show, part of a retrospective for this pioneering German electronica group, was a coveted event, with fewer than 450 tickets available to the public for each night of the run. All eight sold out within an hour when they went on sale in February. (With a face value of $25, they were going for hundreds online afterward.)

It seemed like a good idea to check in with David Simon. As a reporter whose book was the basis of the NBC series ''Homicide: Life on the Street'' and as the creator of the HBO series ''The Wire,'' he might have some pertinent things to say about his friend Richard Price's new show, ''NYC 22'' on CBS. Mr. Simon had hired Mr. Price, the author of ''Clockers'' and other novels, to write for ''The Wire,'' and we thought Mr. Simon would understand the differences involved in writing a cop show for cable and one for broadcast. But when the conversation wound back to ''The Wire,'' four years after that endlessly exalted show went off the air, a controversy was born. In the interview, for ArtsBeat, we mentioned that Mr. Price had said that though many people praise ''The Wire'' now, at the time the show was broadcast it didn't draw many viewers and almost couldn't get a Season 4, much less a Season 5.

Neil Glat, who assisted in N.F.L. expansion and stadium development during his 15 years working for the league, has joined the Jets as team president. Formerly the N.F.L.'s senior vice president for corporate development, Glat will start with the Jets in early May, overseeing the organization's business operations after the winter departures of two executive vice presidents, Matt Higgins and Thad Sheely.

Fire a cannon for another fallen entrant in ''The Hunger Games'' - not for any of its young contestants this time, but for the director Gary Ross, who said he would not return to make the sequel to that hit dystopian action-adventure, and whose involvement in the franchise has been as hotly debated as Katniss Everdeen's fiery dress. Mr. Ross said in a statement: ''Despite recent speculation in the media, and after difficult but sincere consideration, I have decided not to direct 'Catching Fire.' As a writer and a director, I simply don't have the time I need to write and prep the movie I would have wanted to make because of the fixed and tight production schedule.''

To celebrate the return of baseball ArtsBeat asked some staff members of The New York Times to recommend their favorite fiction or nonfiction books that revolve around the sport. We then asked readers to weigh in, via Twitter, on their favorites. GEORGE VECSEY, SPORTS COLUMNIST I'd like to pick two period pieces about the baseball of my youth: ''The Southpaw'' by Mark Harris, a perfect game of a novel about race, money, sex, politics and independence. And ''The Boys of Summer'' by Roger Kahn, about my Brooklyn Dodgers, with Jackie Robinson and other memorable people.
9:19 p.m. | Updated The Justice Department jumped directly into the fight over the future of digital books on Wednesday - and Amazon came out the winner.

Two weeks before the N.F.L. draft, the Giants were on the verge of a move Wednesday to strengthen their group of linebackers, the position that was perhaps the most inconsistent for them during their Super Bowl season. Cincinnati Bengals linebacker Keith Rivers, a first-round pick in 2008, is expected to join the Giants in exchange for a fifth-round pick this year, according to a team executive briefed on the trade discussions, who was not authorized to discuss the deal. The details are still being finalized, the person said.

WASHINGTON - Attention Pete Rose: Michael Weiner has your back. The executive director of the Major League Baseball Players Association said Wednesday that Rose should be in the Hall of Fame even though he gambled on baseball games. Players who took steroids should have a shot at the Hall of Fame as well, Weiner said. ''The Hall of Fame is for the best baseball players who have ever played,'' Weiner said during a question and answer session at the National Press Club. ''Pete Rose belongs in the Hall of Fame. He has more hits than anybody else.''

UNLIKE the mannish clunkers of last spring, dandyish footwear, often in white and pastel hues, feels sophisticated and chic. Imagine these shoes with a shorts suit, a pretty summer dress or even jeans. Note, too, that they are a sensible alternative to toting ballet flats in your purse. Above: Dieppa Restrepo lizard leather monk straps, $506 at Maryam Nassir Zadeh, 123 Norfolk Street; mnzstore.com. Below, from left: Haider Ackermann cutout oxfords, $1,210 at Saks Fifth Avenue, saks.com; Fratelli Rossetti perforated calfskin oxfords, $550 at Fratelli Rossetti, 625 Madison Avenue; fratellirossetti.com.

EXECUTIVE PAYThe Association of British Insurers, an industry body whose members include large institutional investors, has issued a warning to shareholders of Barclays over the pay of the British bank's chief executive, Robert E. Diamond Jr., left. The trade body questioned whether the total package was appropriate given that the company's profit declined 16 percent last year to £3 billion. The Barclays's chief received £6.3 million ($10.3 million) in compensation for last year, including £2.7 million in deferred shares. MARK SCOTT

As smartphones become more powerful, they consume more power, sending users in an endless search for a working charger. No one wants a phone to die in the middle of a call or, worse, in the middle of a Facebook update. Hoping to capitalize on the smartphone's continuous need for juice, Iomega has released SuperHero, an iPhone dock that not only charges but also backs up content.

BANGKOK -- Two powerful earthquakes struck about two hours apart off the coast of Sumatra on Wednesday afternoon, spreading panic among residents of the Indonesian island and reviving memories of the devastating 2004 earthquake and tsunami in the same area. There were no reports of casualties or significant damage, and the tsunami warnings that were widely broadcast on television, cellphones and the Internet were called off again a few hours later.

8 P.M. (TCM) STARRING LIZA MINNELLI Turner Classic Movies pays tribute to Ms. Minnelli with four films, starting with ''Arthur'' (1981), in which she plays a screwball waitress from Queens pursued by a perpetually drunk Manhattan millionaire (Dudley Moore, above with Ms. Minnelli) who must marry a debutante or lose his inheritance. In the documentary ''Private Screenings: Liza Minnelli,'' at 10, she speaks with Robert Osborne about growing up in Hollywood. The movie lineup resumes at 11 with Martin Scorsese's ''New York, New York'' (1977), in which she's a nightclub singer, with Robert De Niro as a saxophonist. And in Alan J. Pakula's ''Sterile Cuckoo'' (1969), at 2 a.m., she and Wendell Burton play misfit, mismatched college students in love; the film earned Ms. Minnelli the first of her two Oscar nominations. At 4 she also appears in the final scene of ''In the Good Old Summertime'' (1949) with her mother, Judy Garland. 3:30 P.M. (Ovation) THE TRUTH ABOUT CHARLIE (2002) Thandie Newton steps into the Audrey Hepburn role as a new wife who returns to her Paris apartment to break it off with her art-dealing husband, Charlie, only to find the place ransacked, in this remake from Jonathan Demme of the 1963 comic thriller ''Charade.'' And soon she discovers that no one, and nothing, is as is seems. Mark Wahlberg, in the role originated by Cary Grant, portrays the charming stranger eager to be of assistance; Tim Robbins is the man at the United States Embassy she turns to for help. The sensual, butter-voiced Ms. Newton is ''so good that when she's on screen, the movie works -- or at least you think it does,'' Elvis Mitchell wrote in The New York Times. ''It's a spot-specific case of alchemy.'' The film will be rebroadcast at 5:45.

MARCUS--Philip, MD. It is with great sadness that the doctors, nurses, and employees of Nassau Chest Physicians, P.C. announce the death of our Founder, Philip Marcus, MD, MPH. He was born in extremely humble conditions in New York City in 1946, Dr. Marcus rose to the pinnacle of leadership positions in multiple organizations. He graduated cum laude from Columbia University College of Pharmaceutical Sciences. He received his medical degree from the State University of New York Downstate summa cum laude in 1973. In 2002 he graduated from the Bloomberg School of Public Health, Johns Hopkins University with an MPH. Clinical training included Residency and Chief Residency at Long Island Jewish Medical Center. He was a Resident in Pulmonary Medicine at Long Island Jewish Medical Center and he was the Parker B. Francis Fellow in Pulmonary Research at Northport Veterans Hospital in Northport, NY. Dr. Marcus received certification in Internal Medicine, Pulmonary Diseases, and Critical Care Medicine. Dr. Marcus was the Director of the Division of Pulmonary Medicine at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, NY. He was the Associate Dean of Curriculum Development at New York College of Osteopathic Medicine. He also had been Chairman of the Department of Medicine at the same college. He was Adjunct Associate Professor in the Department of Pharmaceutical Sciences School of Medicine at the State University of New York at Stony Brook. His professional activities included multiple leadership positions in the American College of Chest Physicians. He rose to the Board of Regents and was chairman of multiple committees. He was on the Editorial Advisory Board of the journal, CHEST. He was on the Editorial Board of the Annals of Respiratory Medicine and a reviewer for Allergy, and Annals of Internal Medicine. He has been a panel member for over fifteen years for US Pharmacopeia and has been on Advisory Committees for the FDA. He was president of the American Lung Association of Nassau/Suffolk from 1991 to 1995. He continued to serve as a Member of the Board of Directors of the American Lung Association. He was also a major fundraiser for Jewish causes including UJA and Shaare Zedek Hospital in Jerusalem. Dr. Marcus has practiced Pulmonary Medicine on Long Island since 1978. He is the Founding Physician of Nassau Chest Physicians, P.C which has grown to eleven physicians and three nurse practitioners. Starting as one of the few Board Certified Pulmonary Physicians on Long Island, he was personally responsible for making NCP one of the premier Pulmonary Medicine groups in the area. He was a great teacher, mentor, and friend to everyone associated with him. The employees at Nassau Chest Physicians will miss him forever. Sympathies to his wife Rovena, his children, and his grandchildren. The Members of Nassau Chest Physicians, P.C.
