The blossoming cherry trees around the Tidal Basin in Washington, a gift of friendship from Japan in 1912, attract millions of ogling, photo-snapping visitors each spring. For their 100th anniversary, the fluffy pink blooms are receiving more attention than ever, featuring celebrations organized by the Japanese Embassy across this country and a special-issue 45-cent stamp. Far less celebrated, and largely forgotten, are the cherry trees - 2,500 of them, nearly as many as were sent to Washington - that Japan gave New York City a century ago.

A music review on Tuesday about a recital by the pianist Maxim Anikushin, at Carnegie Hall, misidentified a work by Samuel Barber that was one of the encores. It is ''Let's Sit It Out; I'd Rather Watch: A Walls,'' not the ''Waltz'' from ''Souvenirs.''

WALLACH--Sylvan, 98, died on April 12 at home. Loving husband of Judith, devoted father of the seven children in their blended family, joyful grandfather and great-grandfather, his warmth, intelligence, and kindness will be greatly missed. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

Goldman Sachs agreed on Thursday to pay securities regulators $22 million to settle accusations that it did not have adequate policies in place to stop stock research tips from being passed inappropriately to its biggest clients. In its complaint, the Securities and Exchange Commission said that top clients received preferential treatment through Goldman's ''trading huddles,'' in which the bank's research analysts met frequently to develop trading tips that were passed on to the firm's traders and then select clients.

If they can go fight in a war, they should be able to fight in a cage if they'd like. KEITH MINER,a mixed martial arts fighter from Texas, on amputees, some of whom are from the military, who are pursuing careers in mixed martial arts. [B10]

Scholars, along with ordinary readers in ''Da Vinci Code'' withdrawal, will soon be able to remotely access some of the collections of the Vatican Library, thanks to a digitization project to be announced on Thursday. The project, which will be undertaken in collaboration with Oxford's Bodleian Library and supported by a $3.2 million grant from the Polonsky Foundation, will make some 1.5 million digitized pages freely available online from the two institutions' collections of Greek manuscripts, 15th-century incunabula, Hebrew manuscripts (including a ninth-century manuscript believed to be the earliest surviving Hebrew codex), and early printed books.

BRODHEAD--James E.,character actor, writer, former journalist and atheist activist, died on April 6th, 2012 in Santa Barbara, California. He was 80 years old. He is survived by his wife of 49 years, Sue Hawes; their sons Will Brodhead (Dorothy R. Adams) of San Francisco, and Dan Brodhead of Los Angeles; and two sisters, Clover Brodhead Gowing, Ph.D. (Parker) of Sequim, Washington, and Heather Brodhead, also of Santa Barbara. Contributions in Mr. Brodhead's memory may be made to the Santa Barbara Symphony; the Barter Theatre Foundation of Abingdon, VA; American Atheists of Cranford, NJ; or the Freedom from Religion Foundation of Madison, WI.

OWENS--Fritzi. The Officers and Clergy of Temple Israel of the City of New York mourn the passing of congregant Fritzi Owens, beloved wife of Herbert Owens. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her bereaved family. Lief D. Rosenblatt, President David J. Gelfand, Rabbi

The Books of The Times review on Thursday, about ''Escape From Camp 14: One Man's Remarkable Odyssey From North Korea to Freedom in the West,'' by Blaine Harden, misidentified the prisoner who tried to kill himself by jumping down a coal mine shaft. It was Kim Yong, a former North Korean Army officer -- not Shin Dong-hyuk, the subject of the book.

GAVURIN--Dr. Edward Isser, 85, of Monroe Twp. died Saturday, April 7, 2012 at Princeton Medical Center in Princeton. Born in the Bronx, New York, Dr. Gavurin was raised in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn. He went on to New York University to earn his PhD in Psychology in 1957. In the early 1960's, Dr. Gavurin became a researcher and professor of Psychology at what is now Herbert H. Lehman College. Following his retirement from academia, he pursued his interests in classical music and poetry. During his retirement, he published four books of his poetry. Dr. Gavurin was predeceased by his wife of 39 years, Lillian Gavurin (nee Nobel) in 1990. He is survived by his wife Gloria Ocken, two sons, Daniel Gavurin and Stuart Gavurin and eleven grandchildren.

A HEAVY HAND Mark Zuckerberg, below, the 27-year-old chief executive and co-founder of Facebook, does not usually play the role of deal maker. But the social network's $1 billion purchase of Instagram, the popular photo-sharing service, was a Mark Zuckerberg production. The deal -- large and cobbled together quickly -- underscores his control of Facebook and how he drives the social network's pace. EVELYN M. RUSLI

WALLACE--Mike. President Mary Sue Coleman and the University of Michigan community express their deepest condolences to the family of Mike Wallace. We have lost a very dear friend who was a role model for the next generation of journalists and whose legacy will live on in Ann Arbor and throughout the world.

PARIS - The French government likes social media - so much so that the country's sovereign wealth fund has invested 10 million euros in an online network. Viadeo, a company based in Paris that bills itself as the world's second-largest social network for professionals, after LinkedIn, said Thursday that it had secured 24 million euros ($31.6 million) in new financing in what analysts described as the biggest investment ever in a European social network.

An article on Monday about Israel's decision to bar Günter Grass, one of German's best-known writers, from entering the country because of his recent poem that assailed Israel for its threats to attack Iran over its nuclear program described imprecisely Poland's relationship to Nazism. While there were Nazi sympathizers in Poland, especially among ethnic Germans, the Polish people as a whole did not support Nazi ideology nor did Nazism ''rise'' there. It was imposed by a victorious German army.

Updated, 2:52 p.m. | The suspicious package was spotted by a screener at the World Financial Center at 10:50 a.m. on Thursday. There appeared to be some kind of munition inside. The screener called 911. The building, near ground zero, where terror threats are taken particularly seriously, was evacuated. As officers from the Police Department's elite bomb squad converged on the complex, a preliminary analysis indicated that a grenade - apparently of World War II vintage - was contained in the parcel, according to one city official.

DISCH--Patricia McGrath, on April 11, 2012. Retired Administrative Assistant, Avon Products, Inc., U.S. Headquarters, New York, NY. Loving wife of George E. Reposing at Denis S. O'Connor Funeral Home, 91-05 Beach Channel Dr, Rockaway Beach, NY 11693. Visiting Saturday, from 7-9pm and Sunday, 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass, Monday, 11am at St. Thomas More Church, Breezy Point, NY. Interment: Calvary Cemetery.

9 P.M. (CBS) ACM PRESENTS: LIONEL RICHIE AND FRIENDS -- IN CONCERT In an evening of country collaborations Mr. Richie performs solo works and duets from his new greatest-hits album, ''Tuskegee,'' alongside Kenny Chesney, Tim McGraw, Jennifer Nettles, Kenny Rogers, Darius Rucker (above left, with Mr. Richie) and Rascal Flatts. Others offer renditions of Mr. Richie's signature songs, including Jason Aldean (''Say You, Say Me''), Luke Bryan (''Running With the Night''), Sara Evans and Marc Anthony (''Endless Love''), Martina McBride (''Still''), the Band Perry (''Penny Lover''), Big & Rich (''Brick House'') and Lady Antebellum (''Truly''). 11:15 A.M. (MoreMax) THE COMPANY (2003) In this ensemble drama featuring members of the Joffrey Ballet of Chicago, Robert Altman dissects the inner workings of a dance troupe through a few months of its season while focusing on Ry (Neve Campbell), a ballerina trying to make her way to the top as she keeps company with Josh (James Franco), a chef. Malcolm McDowell plays Alberto Antonelli, the company's genteel, bristling artistic director who is so self-absorbed that he has no idea of the damage he is capable of inflicting. In his review for The New York Times, Elvis Mitchell wrote that the film ''is enjoyably lithe and droll yet somehow almost water-soluble; it seems to dissolve on screen.''

Maybe it was Farah Fath, a former soap opera star, who said it best on Wednesday when ABC confirmed that it had renewed ''General Hospital'' for a landmark 50th season. Congratulating the cast and crew in a Twitter message, she wrote, ''A soap renewal in 2012 is nothing short of victorious.''

DIAMOND--Dennis, 88. It is with deepest sorrow that we acknowledge the passing of Dennis Diamond on Wednesday, April 11th. Dennis was a devoted husband of Fern for 62 years, loving father of Jeffrey (Marcia), Lori and Nancy (Lenny) and adoring grandfather of Ari (Debra), Daniel, Graig (Rachel), Leah, Jacob, Amanda and Jill. He dedicated his life to his family, especially his grandchildren who were his greatest joy. A World War II veteran, Dennis was a member of the 101st Airborne Division and a winner of the Bronze Star for bravery. A furrier for 53 years, he loved every day of his career. He was loved, respected and will be missed not only by his family but by all who knew him. Funeral services will be held this Sunday at the Riverside Memorial Chapel in Mount Vernon, NY. Rest In peace Zadie.

The trustee overseeing the liquidation of MF Global is considering whether to sue the brokerage firm's executives and directors for their role in its collapse last year and the misuse of customer money. The potential for civil lawsuits is the latest twist in the high-profile investigation.

The cast for Annie Baker's new Off Broadway adaptation of ''Uncle Vanya'' includes a country estate's worth of fan-favorite actors, including Michael Shannon (''Boardwalk Empire'') and Merritt Wever (''Nurse Jackie''), as well as stage regulars Reed Birney (''A Small Fire''), Maria Dizzia (a Tony nominee for ''In the Next Room, or the vibrator play''), and Peter Friedman (''After the Revolution''). The ensemble was announced on Wednesday by the theater company Soho Rep, which is mounting this version of the Chekhov classic June 7-July 15. Mr. Birney will play the title role of the despondent caretaker of a Russian estate, with Mr. Friedman as the arrogant, ill professor and Ms. Dizzia as his young wife, Yelena. Ms. Wever will play Sonya, Vanya's niece and the professor's daughter, and Mr. Shannon will play the doctor Astrov, who (like Vanya) becomes smitten with Yelena.

The Yankees are the most successful franchise in professional sports, having won 27 World Series championships. But the team may be tempting fate by having its home opener on Friday the 13th. Never before, in a history that dates to 1901, has the franchise opened at home or on the road on that date. Of course, the superstition attached to Friday the 13th is just that. But the uneasiness it can cause in people is real - an emotion referred to as friggatriskaidekaphobia (a combination of Frigg, the name of the Norse goddess for whom Friday was named, and triskaidekaphobia, the fear of the number 13).

BEIRUT, Lebanon -- A fragile cease-fire negotiated by the special envoy Kofi Annan prevailed in most of Syria on Thursday, the first vaguely optimistic signal in months in that nation's bloody antigovernment uprising. But some deadly clashes were reported and activists said areas that had been riven by violence remained under virtual martial law, with tank deployments, armed checkpoints and rooftop snipers. United Nations diplomats said they were encouraged by the apparent adherence to the cease-fire on its first day by President Bashar al-Assad's government and his opponents in the conflict, but emphasized that the government had yet to make good on its pledges under the plan to withdraw troops and heavy weapons from major cities.

An article on Thursday about a naval standoff between the Philippines and China in the South China Sea described incorrectly the location of the Philippine island of Luzon and Scarborough Shoal, which is claimed by both countries and is near where Philippine surveillance aircraft spotted eight Chinese fishing boats on Sunday, leading to the standoff. The shoal is 124 nautical miles west of Luzon, not east.

FORBES--Raymond C.,of Brooklyn, NY, passed away on March 30, 2012 in his 85th year. He was born on January 27, 1927 at 293 Sterling Place, Brooklyn, NY. Ray attended the Peddie School in Hightstown, NJ and as a member of their 1944 championship basketball team was inducted into the Peddie Hall of Fame. He joined Merrill Lynch after leaving Cornell in 1946, and interrupted his long association with the company to serve in the Korean War. Ray was a Governor of the American Stock Exchange. The firm of Raymond C. Forbes was established in 1975. Ray was a founding member of the NYSE Bible Study group, continuously meeting since 1977. As a lifelong member of the Downtown Athletic Club, Ray served as a Governor from 1995-1998. He was the longest NY Mets season ticket holder, dating back to 1962. Ray is survived by his wife Patricia; his five children; Christopher, Raymond, Patrick, Marie-Regina Sotos, Patricia Sarn and eleven grandchildren. Contributions in his memory can be made to the Raymond C. Forbes Foundation for Market Place Ministry in New York City, 221 Lake Terrace, Bradley Beach, NJ 07720.

An article on Thursday about the band Kraftwerk's concerts at the Museum of Modern Art misidentified the album they are scheduled to perform tonight. It is ''Trans Europe Express,'' not ''The Man-Machine.'' (A performance of that album is scheduled for Saturday night.)

SKLAR--Elsie Wiesenberg. March 1, 1917-March 14, 2012. Athlete, comedienne, and brilliant listener, Elsie brought her sunny gifts to the hundreds of kindergarten children she taught for 25 years at PS 205 in Bensonhurst and to her friends in the Three Arrows Cooperative Society and in Santa Barbara where she and beloved husband Sam, formerly detective captain with the 78th precinct, moved in 1979. She will be missed and celebrated by daughter Deidre, son Rick (Nadav), granddaughter Justine Yerushalmi, three great-granddaughters, and brothers Albert Warren and Martin Wiesenberg. Santa Barbara Memorial April 15: DSklar@DancEth.net

An editorial on Wednesday about the Florida Marlins and their manager, Ozzie Guillen, misstated attendance in the team's new stadium. There had been only one game there, which was nearly sold out. Attendance had not been as low as in the old stadium.

CHOOKASIAN--Lili. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of mezzo-soprano Lili Chookasian who sang 28 roles and 290 performances here from 1962 to 1986. A singer of remarkable versatility and a rich, dark vocal timbre, she portrayed roles both large and small with consummate artistry. We extend our sincerest condolences to her family and friends. Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Director

The blossoming cherry trees around the Tidal Basin in Washington, a gift of friendship from Japan in 1912, attract millions of ogling, photo-snapping visitors each spring. For their 100th anniversary, the fluffy pink blooms are receiving more attention than ever, featuring celebrations organized by the Japanese Embassy across this country and a special-issue 45-cent stamp. Far less celebrated, and largely forgotten, are the cherry trees - 2,500 of them, nearly as many as were sent to Washington - that Japan gave New York City a century ago.

Not to be left out from what has been a dismal week for broadcast ratings, another hit series succumbed to a downward trend on Wednesday night This time it was ABC's ''Modern Family'' that fell to season lows in total audience, at 10.3 million, and in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic, according to Nielsen. The series premiere of ''Don't Trust the B---- in Apartment 23'' followed, and managed a decent viewer sampling with 7 million. On Tuesday Season 3 of ''Justified'' on FX finished strongly with its highest-rated season finale ever in the 18-to-49-year-old set. FX expects that the episode will become the most-watched of the season once DVR-based viewing has been taken into account. Previous episodes have seen an average increase of 64 percent in overall viewership and 75 percent in the 18-to-49 category.

Reversing a decades-old rule, a federal appeals court said on Thursday that public television and radio stations could not be prohibited from broadcasting paid political advertisements. The ruling could prompt some noncommercial stations to start including ads from candidates and political action committees on their broadcasts, just as commercial stations do. Hundreds of millions of dollars are expected to be spent on advertising in the prelude to the elections this fall.

ANGELL--Carol Rogge. A legendary, widely admired, and much loved teacher of reading and learning skills at the Brearley School, she died on Tuesday at her home in Manhattan of metastatic breast cancer, at the age of seventy-three. She leaves her husband of forty-eight years, Roger Angell; a son, John Henry Angell, of Portland, Oregon; a step-daughter, Alice Angell, of Portland, Maine; a granddaughter, Clara Rose Angell; two step-granddaughters, Laura Gibbons and Lily Anna Evangelista; and a brother, Dr. Peter Rogge, of Sacramento, California. She was a spirited, light-hearted, gently ironic woman who conveyed her passionate bond to literature and writing to generations of young students, many of whom remember her as a life changer and a life model. Born in New York, she was a graduate of the Garden School, in Queens, Bucknell University, and the Columbia Graduate School of Education. Shifting careers after employment as a copy editor with American Heritage Magazine and the Bollingen Series, she came to Brearley in 1980, joining the Department of Reading and Testing (now the Department of Learning Skills), which specializes in intensive work with beginning readers. She served as chairman of the department from 1997 to 2006, but continued as a teacher there until last fall. Her responsibilities included individual tutoring of Upper School English students, which meant that an average day would find her reading "Frog and Toad Are Friends" with her first-grade group in one period and then conferring with a senior over a knotty "King Lear" paper in the next. Her informality could not quite conceal her professional brilliance, which brought her repeated awards of Brearley's "Chair of Excellence." She also established a long-term connection with the East Harlem Storefront School, where she taught during sabbatical leaves. Friends knew her as an effortless but magical cook, a cheerful wife and mother, and a serious devotee of fox terriers and Verdi and Trollope. Summers took her back to her porch in Maine, where, sitting with another open book, she would lift her eyes briefly to the sunlit adjacent waters of Eggemoggin Reach and then, of course, go right on reading.

In his first interview since ending his presidential campaign,Rick Santorum said Thursday that what pushed him out of the Republican race was his campaign's dwindling bank account. ''We repeatedly went out there - sort of a David and Goliath - and were outspent by a lot of money, but we had a lot of other things going for us,'' Mr. Santorum said during an interview with Tony Perkins, the president of the Family Research Council, a conservative Christian advocacy group.

The biggest question hanging over the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame induction ceremony this weekend has been answered: Axl Rose has said he would not attend the event, and therefore there would be no reunion of the classic lineup of Guns N' Roses. Mr. Rose delivered the news in a 1,000-word open letter sent to The Los Angeles Times, which the paper published online in its entirety on Wednesday afternoon. In the letter -- addressed to ''The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, Guns N' Roses Fans and Whom It May Concern'' -- he announces and, at elaborate length, explains his decision to decline the induction and to avoid the ceremony, which will be held in Cleveland on Saturday.

5:33 p.m. | Updated Barnes & Noble wants you to take your e-reader to bed. The latest iteration of the Nook, revealed by the book retailer on Thursday, is a black-and-white device with a softly glowing backlit screen. It is designed to solve a common problem that consumers can encounter with e-readers: They are tough to use in the dark.

Raymond Aubrac, who took that nom de guerre as a storied leader of the resistance effort in Nazi-occupied France during World War II, died on Tuesday in a military hospital in Paris. He was 97. His daughter Catherine announced the death.

When its last two studio albums have inspired a Broadway musical, what does an ambitious punk-rock band do next to keep its listeners scratching their heads? If you're Green Day you go into the studio and get cracking on three new albums to be released in the span of about four months. Following their best-selling 2004 release, ''American Idiot,'' and its 2009 followup, ''21st Century Breakdown,'' whose songs were the basis for the ''American Idiot'' stage musical, the Green Day bandmates Billie Joe Armstrong, Mike Dirnt and Tré Cool said they were back at work with the producer Rob Cavallo in their home town, Oakland, Calif., to record a trilogy of albums: ''¡Uno!,'' scheduled for release on Sept. 25; ''¡Dos!,'' on Nov. 13; and - wait for it - ''¡Tré!'' on Jan. 15 next year. Green Day said in a statement, ''We are at the most prolific and creative time in our lives,'' adding: ''Instead of making one album, we are making a three-album trilogy. Every song has the power and energy that represents Green Day on all emotional levels. We just can't help ourselves.'' The triple release by a punk band, with exclamation points, is no mean feat. Perhaps the last act to attempt it was the Clash, which issued a three-album set, ''Sandinista!,'' in 1980, and let's just say there's a reason the group is better remembered for ''London Calling.''

MURPHY--Nora Sharkey, who retired as Associate Superintendent of Schools for Communications and Marketing for the Archdiocese of New York in 2006, died on April 9, 2012 at the age of 71. Mrs. Murphy was a resident of Bronxville/Eastchester. She was a member of the adjunct faculty of The Graduate School at The College of New Rochelle and the host of a weekly talk show program on WVOX-AM. The author of "A Youth Guide To Saint Patrick's Cathedral," Mrs. Murphy was a communications consultant to schools, Catholic dioceses and non-profit agencies throughout the Northeast. She was a graduate of The Fordham University School of Education and held a master's degree from Manhattan College. She was the widow of Michael G. Murphy, who died in 2003. Mrs. Murphy is survived by her son, Michael T., of Covington, WA, and three grandsons, Evan, Alexander and Aidan. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 6 to 9pm Thursday and 9 to 10:30am Friday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, on Friday, April 13, at 11am. In lieu of flowers, contributions to HOPE Community Services (50 Washington Avenue, New Rochelle) or The Marist Brothers (4200 West 115th Street, Chicago, Illinois 60655) would be appreciated.

DIAMOND--Dennis, 88. It is with deepest sorrow that we acknowledge the passing of Dennis Diamond on Wednesday, April 11th. Dennis was a devoted husband of Fern for 62 years, loving father of Jeffrey (Marcia), Lori and Nancy (Lenny) and adoring grandfather of Ari (Debra), Daniel, Graig (Rachel), Leah, Jacob, Amanda and Jill. He dedicated his life to his family, especially his grandchildren who were his greatest joy. A World War II veteran, Dennis was a member of the 101st Airborne Division and a winner of the Bronze Star for bravery. A furrier for 53 years, he loved every day of his career. He was loved, respected and will be missed not only by his family but by all who knew him. Funeral services will be held this Sunday at the Riverside Memorial Chapel in Mount Vernon, NY. Rest In peace Zadie.

Prime Minister Yoshihiko Noda said Friday that his government would seek to restart two nuclear reactors, in what would be a first step toward ending an almost complete shutdown of the nation's nuclear power industry. Mr. Noda declared two units at the Ohi Nuclear Power Plant in western Japan to be safe based on the results of computer simulations designed to check the reactors' tolerance of a large earthquake and tsunami like those last year that knocked out cooling systems at the Fukushima Daiichi plant. But he must convince skeptical leaders and voters in Fukui Prefecture, the site of the Ohi plant, that it is safe to turn the reactors back on. Currently, only one of the nation's 54 commercial reactors is operating. The shutdowns, which have cut the nation's electricity supply by up to a third, have raised concerns about higher energy prices and power shortages.

''Depend on me is how it always turned out,'' she raps. ''Even already got my own bank account. Debit, no credit, and my checks don't bounce!''

How do you compare additional fees, like those for checked bags, to see if one is a better deal? Or, you're planning a vacation on the airline you prefer for business travel, but you're bringing family along this time. How can you easily find out how much all that extra checked luggage will cost you?

A former research analyst pleaded guilty to criminal charges in an insider-trading case that federal prosecutors have described as a ''circle of friends'' who together earned about $62 million in illegal gains in Dell stock. On Friday, Danny Kuo, a former analyst at Whittier Trust Company, a money-management firm in South Pasadena, Calif., appeared in Federal District Court in Manhattan and admitted obtaining confidential information about Dell, the computer giant, and Nvidia, a computer graphics company. He said he passed the information to his boss, who traded on the tips. His firm, Whittier, avoided $78,000 in losses, prosecutors said.

It's clear that prepaid debit cards - cards that you load with cash, spend down and then reload - are hot. In 2009, consumers loaded roughly $29 billion on such cards, which are especially popular with young adults and those considered underbanked - meaning they have little access to mainstream financial institutions like banks. But by next year, that amount is expected to reach $202 billion, according to an estimate cited in a report from an arm of the Pew Charitable Trusts. Even the budgeting guru Suze Orman is marketing a prepaid card.

A London lawyer closely involved in pursuing cases involving Rupert Murdoch's British tabloids said Friday that his firm was suing The Times of London, also part of Mr. Murdoch's News International group, over e-mail hacking for which the newspaper has apologized. The suit concerns a case in which a reporter who is no longer with the newspaper hacked into the e-mail account of a police detective who ran an award-winning blog. The claim, said the lawyer, Mark Lewis, ''is not just on misuse of information or privacy grounds, but also a claim for what lawyers would call deceit,'' based on denials the newspaper made. A spokeswoman for News International confirmed the lawsuit had been filed but declined to comment further. The blogger's true identity was not publicly known until an article in The Times of London in 2009 identified him. At a hearing in February into press ethics and practices, James Harding, the editor of The Times of London, apologized on behalf of the newspaper, reversing its earlier denials.

A map on Thursday with the Lille Journal article, about a hotel in Lille, France, that prosecutors say was the hub of an elite prostitution ring, omitted part of the name of the region where Lille is located. It is Nord Pas-de-Calais, not Pas-de-Calais.

MORGAN--Nicky N.,beloved husband and best friend for 34 years to Lynn Kasner Morgan, devoted son of Jack Morgenstern and the late Sallie Morgenstern, and son-in-law of Mickey Kasner and the late Edward Kasner. Nick passed away on April 11 while on vacation and after a brief illness. Born in 1950 in Bucharest, educated at the Technion High School in Haifa and receiving a BSEE from Polytechic Institute in New York, Nick was a talented and creative engineer, inventor and photographer. He will be sorely missed by his many friends and family. Graveside services will be held on Sunday, April 15 at King Solomon Memorial Park, Clifton, NJ. Donations in Nick's memory may be made to the American Diabetes Association or the Montclair Volunteer Ambulance Unit.

Thousands of Islamists converged on Cairo's Tahrir Square on Friday to protest the candidacy of Omar Suleiman, left, who served as President Hosni Mubarak's spy chief, saying he would halt democratic reforms. The Muslim Brotherhood's political arm, the Freedom and Justice Party, helped organize the rally, which drew an overwhelmingly Islamist crowd, including ultraconservative Salafists. Banners linked Mr. Suleiman, who says he wants to restore order and limit the Islamists' power, to the ousted Mr. Mubarak and urged Egypt's revolution to continue ''until we are done with both of them.'' One protester, Khaled el-Shafei, 38, an archaeologist who supports the Muslim Brotherhood candidate, Khairat el-Shater, said, ''I would be happy with any elected president -- an Islamist or a liberal -- as long as they are not an army officer or a remnant of the old regime.'' On Thursday, Parliament passed a law barring former high-ranking officials of Mr. Mubarak's government from running for office, but the country's ruling military council is unlikely to approve it.
No air. I just could not breathe. That's when I thought, if I don't find this woman in a few minutes, we're both going to die. MAYOR CORY A. BOOKERof Newark, on rescuing a neighbor from a fire. [A14]

KLINE--Leonard, of New York and Houston, beloved husband of Carmen, father of Linda and Alisa, grandfather of Daniel, Ethan and Willie, father-in-law of Sophia and Ken, passed away peacefully after a long illness. He will greatly missed by many people whose lives he touched with grace and humor.
With earth’s population approaching unsustainable levels, much of the growth is in sub-Saharan Africa, where trends that have lowered birthrates elsewhere have not yet caught on.
Alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Saturday because of Passover. Other regulations will remain in effect.

Jorge Posada watched his former teammate Andy Pettitte halt a one-year retirement to return to the Yankees last month. Now that Posada, the former catcher, is retired after 17 seasons with the club, he joked that he must wait a year, as Pettitte did, before he considered a return. ''So next year, you'll have to ask me that question again,'' Posada said.

POWERS--Marie Josephine (Drew), of New York City on April 13 after 93 prayerful years of grace-filled life. Dearest mother of Deacon John M. Powers, beloved wife of the late Jack Powers, and cherished daughter of the late Maria Josefa and Charles Drew. Graduate of the Nightingale-Bamford School and Vassar College. Past President of the Auxiliary of Lenox Hill Hospital, of which she was a member for half a century. A descendant of Col. James Reed, who led his troops from New Hampshire at the Battle of Bunker Hill, she was President of the Daughters of the Cincinnati during our nation's Bicentennial. For many years she was an active member of the National Society of Colonial Dames as well as the Colonial Dames of America, serving as an officer and member of their boards. In her later years she felt especially blessed in becoming a Dame of the Sovereign Military Hospitaller Order of St. John of Jerusalem of Rhodes and Malta, joyfully participating in five of the Order of Malta's annual pilgrimages to Lourdes. Funeral vigils at Frank E. Campbell (1076 Madison Avenue) on Sunday 7-9pm and Monday 2-4 and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial at Church of St. Vincent Ferrer (66th Street and Lexington Avenue) on Tuesday at 10am. In lieu of flowers, donations in Marie Powers' memory may be made to the Order of the Malta-American Association (1011 First Avenue, New York, NY 10022) or the Daughters of the Cincinnati Scholarship Fund (20 West 44th Street/Suite 508, New York, NY 10036).

A correction in this space on Friday about the band Kraftwerk's concerts at the Museum of Modern Art misidentified the day they were scheduled to perform their album ''The Man Machine.'' It was in fact performed on Friday night; it is not scheduled for tonight. (''Computer World'' is scheduled for tonight.)

An article on Friday about a cease-fire directed at halting the conflict in Syria misstated part of the name of a Syrian exile opposition group in Britain, with contacts inside Syria, that reported 11 died in scattered clashes on Thursday, the first day of the cease-fire. It is the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights, not the London Observatory for Human Rights.

Add BET to the list of channels who will be competing in late-night television. Sometime this fall the channel will start ''Don't Sleep With T.J. Holmes,'' a Monday-through-Friday series that will compete with the likes of ''The Daily Show'' on Comedy Central, ''Chelsea Lately'' on E! and ''Conan'' on TBS.

DeBEER--Dr. Roy. Cedarhurst Medical Associates sadly announces the death of our associate, Roy DeBeer. Funeral services will be held Sunday, April 15, 2-4pm, Seventh Day Advent Church, 265 Belmont Pkwy, Hempstead, NY 11550.

Frank Langella has had an accomplished stage career and a modestly successful one in films. But while his star turn on Broadway in ''Dracula'' transformed him into a matinee idol for a brief period, and he has won three Tonys and worked consistently ever since, Mr. Langella never became a major film star and never achieved the kind of immortality bestowed on many of the luminaries who glide through his terrific new memoir, amusingly titled ''Dropped Names.'' This may have been a piece of inordinate good luck, you come to feel after dipping into the book. For Mr. Langella's encounters with a glittering roster of famous names are often shot through with a haunting sense of melancholy, a sensitive awareness of the cruel exigencies of great public acclaim, which is almost always transitory.

Just as the publishing industry has finished marking the 100th anniversary of the Titanic's sinking with dozens of related books, at least one publisher is looking ahead to another anniversary: the sinking of the British ocean liner Lusitania by a German U-boat during World War I. Crown Publishers, part of Random House, said on Friday that it had acquired a nonfiction book by Erik Larson, the author of ''The Devil in the White City,'' that will ''offer a fresh take'' on the sinking. The attack, on May 7, 1915, killed nearly 1,200 people, including more than 100 Americans. It fueled anti-German sentiment in the United States, although America did not enter the war for another two years. The book, tentatively titled ''Sea of Secrets,'' will be published in 2015. Mr. Larson's latest book, ''In the Garden of Beasts,'' was released in May 2011 and has sold more than 900,000 copies.

MARKS--Malvin, 80. Beloved husband of Joan for 60 years, adored father of Janet (Alex), Andrew and the late Bradley and Poppy to Benjamin and Becky. A kind and gentle man who will be remembered by everyone who met him. "The Riverside," Sunday, 11:45am.

BRAUNSCHWEIG--Robert, 82. Attorney and senior partner, Wachtell, Manheim & Grouf. Missed by his loving children Julius, Diana and Marc; grandchildren Leo and Scarlett; and many friends. Memorial gifts: Perlman Music Program on Shelter Island. Please visit: perlmanmusicprogram.org.

9 P.M. (Starz) MONEYBALL (2011) Brad Pitt, above -- giving what Manohla Dargis, writing in The New York Times, called ''the quintessential Brad Pitt performance'' -- earned an Oscar nomination for his portrayal of Billy Beane, the real-life general manager of the Oakland Athletics who transformed the team, one of the poorest in baseball, into a serious competitor against wealthier franchises by essentially ignoring everything he'd been taught about the game. Jonah Hill, also nominated, plays Peter Brand, a computer whiz with an economics degree from Yale, and a disciple of Bill James, a statistician who, starting in 1977, devised a radical way of understanding baseball data. And Philip Seymour Hoffman is the team's manager, Art Howe, who isn't about to buy into the newfangled approach that his boss and his protégé insist will create a winner. The director Bennett Miller, ''largely shaking off the official art-house pretensions of his breakout feature, 'Capote,' takes all this seemingly dry, dusty, inside-baseball stuff and turns it into the kind of all-too-rare pleasurable Hollywood diversion that gives you a contact high,'' Ms. Dargis said of this fictionalized adaptation of the book by Michael Lewis. ''Moneyball'' also received nominations for best screenplay for Steven Zaillian and Aaron Sorkin, who wrote the script, and Stan Chervin, who provided the story, as well as for best film. 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Lillian Daniel and Martin Copenhaver, pastors with the United Church of Christ and the authors of ''This Odd and Wondrous Calling,'' talk with Bob Abernethy about what it is really like to be a minister. Kim Lawton explores the social, emotional and spiritual challenges facing those caring for elderly parents.

Everybody knows it's not uncommon for fans of Leonard Cohen's to become fixated on him and his romantic if sinister music. But a jury has decided that a former business manager of that Canadian singer-songwriter harassed him by sending him hundreds of e-mails and voicemail messages that at times left him feeling threatened, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Cohen stopped working with the former manager, Kelley Lynch, in 2004, and had obtained a court order for her to stop contacting him. The case against Ms. Lynch, decided Thursday in a Los Angeles court, centered on messages that she sent the singer between February 2011 and January of this year, which prosecutors said made Mr. Cohen's life ''a complete and utter living hell,'' according to The A.P.

A picture on Friday with the City Room column, about the 100th anniversary of a gift of cherry trees to New York City from Japan, was published in error. It showed crab apple trees, not cherry blossoms in Riverside Park north of 90th Street in Manhattan. (There are cherry trees in that vicinity.)

The Drawing Center will reopen on Sept. 13 after a yearlong expansion, Brett Littman, the executive director announced on Friday. The $9.6 million renovation adds 50 percent more exhibition and public space above and below the storefront center at 35 Wooster Street in SoHo, which specializes in drawing exhibitions. The project includes a pair of ground-floor galleries, an education center and offices.

SACKS--Nellie A. Survived by her loving husband Judge Lester Sacks, son Robert Ancona, his wife Edit Ancona, Bradley Sacks, Jeffrey Sacks, Stephanie O'Brien, grandchildren Sam Ancona and Emily Schmitz, and great-grandchildren Rebecca and Andrew Schmitz. Services will be held tomorrow at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expy., Fresh Meadows. Interment to follow at Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale.

In the battle of the boroughs, it's Queens, 15; Manhattan, 14; and Brooklyn, the Bronx and Staten Island with zero; at least when it comes to Scrabble. Friday was National Scrabble Day, celebrated annually on the birthday of Alfred Mosher Butts, the out-of-work architect who created the game in the 1930s in his Jackson Heights home. A missing sign commemorating the achievement was recently restored at the corner of 81st Street and 35th Avenue.

In the center of a messy, bowl-shaped pile of branches, twine, plastic bags and pizza plates, two baby hawks lifted their wobbly white pompom heads Friday morning to snap at red chunks of rat flesh dangling from their mother's beak. Steadying the rodent corpse with a talon, she tore stringy entrails and delicately fed them to her offspring, bit by bit. Mealtime on a 12th-floor ledge at New York University, where a pair of red-tailed hawks have set up a nursery overlooking Washington Square Park, comes every few hours now, since the babies, known as eyases, hatched on Monday and Tuesday. When they are not eating, they sleep beneath their mother -- sometimes in a postprandial digestive coma -- or play-fight like an avian Two Stooges.

A cloistered garden at the historic Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston will be redesigned by the landscape architect Michael Van Valkenburgh, the museum announced on Friday. Known as the Monks Garden, the green space is connected to the exterior gardens that surround the museum's new wing, designed by Renzo Piano.

ANGELL--Carol Rogge. A legendary, widely admired, and much loved teacher of reading and learning skills at the Brearley School, she died on Tuesday at her home in Manhattan of metastatic breast cancer, at the age of seventy-three. She leaves her husband of forty-eight years, Roger Angell; a son, John Henry Angell, of Portland, Oregon; a step-daughter, Alice Angell, of Portland, Maine; a granddaughter, Clara Rose Angell; two step-granddaughters, Laura Gibbons and Lily Anna Evangelista; and a brother, Dr. Peter Rogge, of Sacramento, California. She was a spirited, light-hearted, gently ironic woman who conveyed her passionate bond to literature and writing to generations of young students, many of whom remember her as a life changer and a life model. Born in New York, she was a graduate of the Garden School, in Queens, Bucknell University, and the Columbia Graduate School of Education. Shifting careers after employment as a copy editor with American Heritage Magazine and the Bollingen Series, she came to Brearley in 1980, joining the Department of Reading and Testing (now the Department of Learning Skills), which specializes in intensive work with beginning readers. She served as chairman of the department from 1997 to 2006, but continued as a teacher there until last fall. Her responsibilities included individual tutoring of Upper School English students, which meant that an average day would find her reading "Frog and Toad Are Friends" with her first-grade group in one period and then conferring with a senior over a knotty "King Lear" paper in the next. Her informality could not quite conceal her professional brilliance, which brought her repeated awards of Brearley's "Chair of Excellence." She also established a long-term connection with the East Harlem Storefront School, where she taught during sabbatical leaves. Friends knew her as an effortless but magical cook, a cheerful wife and mother, and a serious devotee of fox terriers and Verdi and Trollope. Summers took her back to her porch in Maine, where, sitting with another open book, she would lift her eyes briefly to the sunlit adjacent waters of Eggemoggin Reach and then, of course, go right on reading.

A full slate of repeats on CBS allowed the other broadcast networks to gain some ground in the ratings on Thursday. Fox was by far the No. 1 network for the night, according to Nielsen data, as both ''American Idol'' and ''Touch'' received a bump in viewership from last week. They finished with 15.3 million total viewers and 8.2 million, respectively. ABC also benefited from the lack of competition. Not only did ''Grey's Anatomy'' bounce back from season lows, but the political drama ''Scandal'' also posted higher numbers, including 7.5 million total viewers, in its second week than its premiere. It's a rare feat for a new program.

BLACK--Mary Ethel Agan. Died March 20 at the Hebrew Home Riverdale, NY. Born in Savannah, GA. October 7, 1941. Writer, editor. Daughter of the late Maj. Gen. Arthur C. Agan, USAF, and Louise Agan. Mother of Joshua Cheuse, Grandmother of Minalu Cheuse. Sister to Maggie Alexander and Todd Cowart. Memorial service, May 27, 6pm, Adler Library, Ethical Culture Society, 2 West 64th Street, NYC 10023.

Compensation for the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, Lloyd C. Blankfein, fell roughly 35 percent to $12 million in 2011, in a year when the company's stock tumbled 46.2 percent. Mr. Blankfein, whose pay package was disclosed on Friday in a regulatory filing, received a base salary of $2 million, a cash bonus of $3 million and restricted stock valued at $7 million. In 2010, Mr. Blankfein received nearly $19 million, which included a $5.4 million cash bonus and stock currently valued $7 million.

ROME -- After London, Barcelona and Paris, Woody Allen's newest tribute to a European capital, ''To Rome With Love,'' had its premiere here on Friday. But the amorous sentiment may not be requited judging by the grumblings of some Italian journalists and film critics at a crowded post-screening news conference. ''Your Italy is superficial, full of escorts, where Italians come across as nonexistent people,'' said one seemingly peeved female journalist who suggested that Mr. Allen might have been influenced by the widely reported antics of former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, who is embroiled in a sex scandal. The journalist later gushed, ''But I loved the film.'' (Mr. Allen retorted that he had ''no insight into Italian politics, or culture,'' adding, ''I just wanted to make a film set in Rome that would be entertaining to see.'')

President Obama's campaign has left no doubt about how it intends to run against Mitt Romney, portraying him as a bazillionaire elitist and conviction-free flip-flopper who has allied himself with the Republican Party's most extreme positions. -After a year in which he was excoriated on an almost-daily basis by Mr. Romney and the others seeking the Republican nomination, Mr. Obama is now letting loose his competitive, street-ball side, mocking his opponent's vocabulary and suggesting a Republican victory would lead to social Darwinism. The comments by a Democratic strategist Wednesday night about Ann Romney's work history were condemned by Mr. Obama and his inner circle but only reinforced the sense that a lot Democrats are primed to play rough in 2012.
A film review on Friday about ''Monsieur Lazhar'' referred incorrectly to the movie. It is the fourth feature by the director, Philippe Falardeau, not his first.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Touchy Day at Augusta National Men's Club,'' April 5: Virginia M. Rometty, the chief executive of I.B.M., has ascended the corporate ladder without the assistance of Augusta National Golf Club. It appears the club has more to gain from her membership than does Rometty. She should not accept an official invitation to join Augusta National until the chairman issues a televised apology for the club's colossal lapse in judgment. Kevin Palmer

One of the things that make baseball fun is the frequency of statistical oddities. The first full week of this season was replete with them, with Denver as a backdrop. On Monday, the Giants' Barry Zito beat the Rockies, 7-0, becoming the second visitor to throw a shutout at Coors Field in the last 13 seasons. (Roy Oswalt was the other, in 2008.) It was also Zito's first shutout since 2003, after 274 starts without one. That span between shutouts is the longest in major league history.

THE new season requires a new scent, and this spring's sporty-robust fragrances for men deliver it. The latest in the Eau de Lacoste series, called Red, features a stimulating combination of ginger, black pepper and cardamom, all meant to energize. Made up of exotic notes like Indonesian nutmeg and bergamot, Issey Miyake L'Eau d'Issey Pour Homme Sport has a finish that's as cool as the bottle design. And from Viktor & Rolf, Spicebomb is the male counterpart to the brand's popular Flowerbomb perfume for women. Notes of vetiver and wood suggest ruggedness, and (aggressive grenade-like packaging aside) the scent's manliness won't blow up in your face. EDWARD BARSAMIAN

If there's anything perennial in fashion, it's a pair of black boots, and Robert Clergerie's are as enduring as any out there. Roland Mouret, the French-born, London-based designer known for his sculptural clothes, is now the creative director of the comfort-meetsbourgeois- chic brand. In addition to statuesque heels and brogues, he's done several variations on the boot theme: Parisian motorcyclists, sinuous thigh-highs, sturdy jodhpurs (above; $795 at Robert Clergerie's New York and Los Angeles stores, and at barneys.com). ''Women like Catherine Deneuve knew how to wear a really sexy yet practical shoe,'' Mouret says. ''And I think today's women are ready for that again.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

A three-story Park Avenue town housenever publicly listed for sale haschanged hands for $13 million, making itthe most expensive transaction of the week, accordingto city records.The sale of the building, at 1108 Park, between89th and 90th Streets in Carnegie Hill, comesjust two weeks after the sale of its neighbor, 1110 Park Avenue, for $16.5 million. Both werebought anonymously by the same limited liabilitycorporation, but papers filed with the city indicatethat the buyer was the residential developerToll Brothers of Horsham, Pa.The company declined to comment.The 25-foot-wide town houses, dating to 1856,are among the oldest buildings on the avenue.No. 1108 was sold by the estate of Joseph Bogen,a longtime resident who died last year. No. 1110was once owned by the Abstract painter andphilanthropist Judith Rothschild.Both houses predate the construction of thelarge luxury apartment buildings that startedsprouting up at the turn of the last century andnow dominate the avenue.Although Toll Brothers has not officially acknowledgedbuying the properties, and noplans for redevelopment have been made public,some local residents said they were bracingfor a fight. The two houses fall just outside theCarnegie Hill Historic District; neither is protectedby landmark status, and they come withsubstantial air rights. In other words: an ideallocation for a developer with big ambitions.Big Ticket includes closed sales from the previousweek, ending Wednesday.

EVANS--Corbett Lee, 86, of Lebanon, Missouri died on March 12, 2012. Private graveside services were held at the Stoutland, Missouri Cemetery on March 18th. Corbett graduated from Drury College in 1943, then taught at Muskingum College. He completed a Master's Educational Degree at Columbia Teacher's College and then taught at Horace Mann School. From 1958 to 1969 he taught music and was Executive Officer of Julliard School, Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts. In the 1970's he traveled behind the Iron Curtain to meet Composer Udo Zimmerman whose work was then introduced to the United States. Corbett's legacy of helping deserving students of the arts continues in the form of a scholarship fund he has designated for Kenyon College. He is survived by one brother, W. O. Evans and family.

Jane Taylor, the founding bassoonist of the Dorian Wind Quintet, one of the premier ensembles to involve that uneasy alliance of flute, oboe, clarinet, French horn and bassoon, died on Sunday in Manhattan. She was 79. The cause was a heart attack, said her sister, Beatrice Asken.

There may be no better barometer of a designer's commercial success than retailers and consumers clamoring for those interim collections known as resort and prefall. So after four seasons of challenging pieces like patterned pajama sets and over-the-top quilted coats, the Northern Irish designer J. W. Anderson (left) has come down to earth - at least a little - for his first prefall collection. Alongside straight-leg pants, pleated skirts and jewel-tone turtlenecks (including one in blue with bright green sleeves), Anderson still offers plenty of quilting: a white A-line skirt, a red-and-white checkerboard print jacket and two puffy bombers, one in black patent leather and another in brown with white sleeves and a shearling collar. ''I like the idea of storytelling, and for me this collection was the prequel to my fall collection,'' the designer says. ''Both collections are for the same woman and for me all the pieces work together, but I definitely aimed to design clothes that were easier and more relatable.'' That doesn't mean Anderson has lost touch with the avant-garde. For fall expect vinyl suiting, pillow-top apron skirts and a curious take on the deerstalker cap. Jerome Williams will start for the Los Angeles Angels on Sunday night at Yankee Stadium. He has never pitched in the Bronx, never faced the Yankees and never worn No. 42, which all players will do as baseball honors Jackie Robinson. Williams has a tie to Brooklyn, where Robinson broke baseball's color barrier in 1947, but it is through basketball. His father, Glenn, grew up in Bedford-Stuyvesant and played with Bernard King, the Brooklyn legend and future N.B.A. star. Glenn Williams wanted his son to play basketball, but Jerome preferred pitching.

Laughter is more subdued at Introverts United meetings, where members discuss ''the common challenges of being introverted in a culture that values extroversion,'' as Michael Barrett, a Rollins junior and club president, would explain only in an e-mail (an ''introvert thing''). Actually, introversion is ''in'' these days. In ''Quiet: The Power of Introverts in a World That Can't Stop Talking,'' published in January, Susan Cain writes that introversion is not a flaw -- one of the club's meeting topics. ''Being introverted does not mean being shy or antisocial,'' Mr. Barrett said. ''We are simply differently social. We tend to prefer more meaningful discussions with fewer people.''

MARCUS--Philip, M.D.,M.P.H. The administration, trustees, and staff of St. Francis Hospital, The Heart Center in Roslyn, New York, mourn the untimely death of Philip Marcus, M.D., M.P.H., dedicated physician leader, educator, and beloved friend. Dr. Marcus was the Director of the Division of Pulmonary Medicine at St. Francis Hospital, where he was also the Medical Director of the Respiratory Intensive Care Unit, Director of the Pulmonary Function Laboratory and Pulmonary Rehabilitation Program, and Medical Director of Respiratory Therapy. Dr. Marcus joined the Hospital in 1977. Dr. Marcus was also Clinical Professor of Medicine and Pharmacology at the New York College of Osteopathic Medicine and served as Associate Dean of Curriculum Development. He conducted clinical trials and lectured nationally and internationally on asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. He was active in the American College of Chest Physicians and has served on the editorial advisory board of their journal, Chest. He is the founding physician of Nassau Chest Physicians, P.C., and is a past president of the American Lung Association of Nassau-Suffolk. Throughout his entire tenure at St. Francis Hospital, Dr. Marcus always demonstrated a boundless commitment to the welfare of the Hospital, its patients, and employees. Dr. Marcus's clinical acumen, leadership, generosity, and spirit of community service will be sorely missed. Our thoughts and prayers are with the entire Marcus family during this sad time.

An obituary last Sunday about the Chinese dissident Fang Lizhi misidentified the university where he had been vice president. It is the University of Science and Technology of China, whose main campus is in Anhui Province; it is not Anhui University of Science and Technology or ''Anhui's branch of the University of Science and Technology of China.''

GOTBAUM--Mark. beloved husband, father, friend, died unexpectedly on March 29. He was a devoted artist and teacher, an award-winning political illustrator, a jazz enthusiast, and former varsity basketball player (CCNY '65). He is survived by his wife, Dr. Julie Marcus; his daughter, Madeleine Gotbaum; and their dog, Chewy. Contributions can be made to WBGO.

This summer, the seaside has a new version of the little black dress: swimwear by the French label Thapelo Paris. The 33-year-old Australian designer behind the line, Wil Ariyamethe, creates glamorous suits with throwback appeal like sleek but not skimpy bikinis, a Marilyn Monroe-inspired number (above; $400 at nancymeyer.com) and a one-piece that recalls Grace Kelly in ''High Society.'' Ariyamethe says she takes cues from ''vintage European swimsuits from the '50s, '60s and '70s,'' adding that ''a woman doesn't need to show everything to have sex appeal. Old World charm and elegance is sexy.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

BELFORD--Ralph Jeffers "Jeff" II, 77, passed away April 7, 2012 in Princeton, New Jersey. Born October 21, 1934 to Dr. Ralph Belford and Ruth Pine Belford, Jeff grew up in Princeton and spent summers in Buck Hill Falls, PA. He attended Phillips Exeter Academy and then Princeton University, graduating in 1956. He married Ann Sexton Kennedy April 30, 1960, and together they had five children. Jeff later married Sarah Cirrincione December 9, 2004, and formed strong bonds with her children. He was a fine soccer player and singer in his school years, and loved golf throughout his life. Jeff's career was spent as a marketing executive for pharmaceutical firms, later as a career counselor, and then several years at the Gallup Organization. Jeff is survived by his wife Sarah, his sister Ann Belford Ulanov, his five children: Jeb, Morgan, Lincoln, Benjamin and Tiffany; as well as five grandchildren. He is also survived by Sarah's three children: Gabrielle, Frank and Stephen. A memorial service will be held at the Princeton University Chapel on Friday, May 4, 2012 at 10:00am.

FOR decades, period architecture and pristine cobblestone streets have kept Old Montreal well trodden by tourists. But this gracious waterfront area, dating back centuries, is regaining cachet with locals, and high-end retail has followed. A western stretch of narrow Rue St. Paul, where souvenir shops once hawked Québécois kitsch, has become an unlikely hub for high fashion. Huge picture windows in restored stone buildings now showcase of-the-moment looks to rival the hippest that New York or Paris have to offer -- all with an insouciant Montreal twist.MICHAEL KAMINER

LORD--George deForest. Former Yale Professor died March 31 at Connecticut Hospice in Branford at the age of 92. George Lord, son of Hazen Symington Lord and George deForest Lord (a principal in the law firm Lord, Day and Lord), grew up in Manhattan and in Syosset, Long Island. He attended Groton School and Yale University, graduating in 1942. He fought in World War II in the South Pacific as a B-25 pilot with the Marines, flying 44 combat missions and receiving the Distinguished Flying Cross and the Air Medal with four Gold Stars. He obtained a PhD at Yale and joined its English Department, attaining the rank of full professor in 1966 and publishing numerous scholarly works. His major focuses included Andrew Marvell, English satirical poetry, and the heroic epic and mock heroic epic. In 1988 he was appointed the George M. Bodman Professor of English Literature. Lord was predeceased by his wife Marcia Babbidge Lord, siblings Edith Meyer and Edward Crary Lord, and his infant daughter Edith. Surviving him are previous wives Ruth duPont Lord and Louise Hendricks Lord, his children Pauline Lord of East Lyme CT, George Lord, Jr., D.C., of Athens GA, and Henry Lord of New Haven, five stepchildren, five grandchildren and three great- grandchildren. A memorial service will be held in August.

Professional tennis is, at its core, a selfish pursuit, but Ivan Ljubicic, who is about to play his last tournament, has done his part to make it less so. A war refugee who became a champion, he had major moments on his own: winning 10 tournaments and reaching No. 3 in the world rankings in 2006, the only year he ever truly felt he had a chance to win a singles title in the Grand Slam tournaments that have routinely thwarted him. That high-water year, he reached the quarterfinals of the Australian Open, made the semifinals of the French Open and qualified for the elite, eight-man tour championship for the second season in a row.

BROWN--Joan Bernice Rosenfeld, on April 13, 2012. Beloved wife of Mitchell for over 40 years; loving mother of Robyn, Peter and Jill; adoring grandmother of Alexis and Justin. Born in 1947 to the late Abraham and Gertrude Rosenfeld; predeceased by her brother, Paul. Demonstrated incredible courage in the face of adversity. Will be remembered for her love of family and friends, her sense of humor and her laugh. Sunday night dinners in Chinatown will not be the same. Her regular visits and daily phone calls will be missed tremendously. She had a unique ability to make everyone feel special. Funeral Sunday, April 15 at 2pm; Temple Israel of NYC; 112 East 75th Street, New York, NY 10021.
BROWN--Joan. My dear friend you will be missed. You have touched so many people with your caring, love and kindness. Special people like you are a rarity. Rest in peace. Maurice and Valerie

MCDONALD--Elizabeth Ann (nee Johnson), 73, beloved wife for 51 years of Joseph F. McDonald and beloved mother of Alex McDonald, Devin McDonald Vinson, and Molly McDonald. Born in Brooklyn and a long-time resident of Cobble Hill and Brooklyn Heights, Betty McDonald was a gifted and devoted teacher at Grace Church School who passionately believed in the importance of early childhood education and nurtured the development of so many children in her community. Betty graduated from Mount Holyoke College and earned her masters degree in education from Bank Street. An extraordinary mother, she rejoiced in being a loving and devoted grandmother to Ames, Milo, Mac, Otis, and her brand new Annabel. Betty is also survived by her sister, Joyce Diwan, and her cousin, Lillian Blaschke. Betty was a truly beautiful person in every sense. Her loving and caring nature, her openness and unfailing integrity, and her common-sense intelligence inspired her family, friends, and students. She will be deeply missed. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Friends of Grace Church School [254 Hicks Street, Brooklyn, NY 11201] for a scholarship fund being set up in her name would be greatly appreciated.

Economic conditions alter the outcomes of presidential elections, but economic conditions during certain time periods matter much more than others. Economic voters are shortsighted, it turns out, and their myopia makes American electoral accountability surprisingly haphazard. Sixty years of political history suggest that income growth in the months leading up to Election Day has a strong, consistent impact on the incumbent party's re-election prospects -- what happens in the rest of a president's term is mostly irrelevant. If the last 15 presidential elections are a reliable guide, income growth between now and Nov. 6 will matter more to voters than how the economy has fared through President Obama's first 39 months in the White House.

THE swift pace of spring openings on Broadway continues as the April 26 deadline for Tony Award eligibility looms, but there is a hot ticket farther south, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, where the Maly Drama Theater of St. Petersburg, Russia, is coming to town for a short run of Chekhov's ''THREE SISTERS.'' There are surely great American productions of Chekhov -- ''The Cherry Orchard,'' this season at Classic Stage Company comes to mind -- but here's a chance to see classical Russian theater by a respected Russian company. Lev Dodin, the artistic director at Maly, has been directing Chekhov for decades, and at the Brooklyn Academy in 2010 he brought over a widely admired (and sold out) production of ''Uncle Vanya.''

Through my own experiences working as a filmmaker and cameraman in Iraq and Afghanistan over the past nine years, I've seen many young soldiers turn into troubled veterans. Specialist Ryan Yurchison served in Iraq in 2006, and three years after returning home, he overdosed on a fatal cocktail of drugs. His family now believes his death was a suicide.

William H. Macy In ''High Off the Hog'' (Page 40), the Oscar-nominated actor William H. Macy recounts a motorcycle trip up the Pacific Coast with his ''Shameless'' co-stars Justin Chatwin and Steve Howey. Macy, who owns two bikes, including the Softail Classic Harley he received after filming ''Wild Hogs,'' is no stranger to writing. He has penned film scripts with the director Steven Schachter, as well as an episode of his Showtime series in which his character's mother turns up on leave from jail and in search of a former meth cook who owes her money. Macy, who was just inducted into the Hollywood Walk of Fame with his wife, the actress Felicity Huffman, will next appear as a priest in the Sundance festival hit ''The Surrogate.''

ANGELL--Carol R.,The Brearley Community mourns the loss of our beloved colleague, friend, mentor, advisor and teacher. The Tate galleries often display art from around the world. Now, the arts institution is hoping to take its visitors on the road, as part of Tate Travels, a series of 14 trips related to the arts organized in partnership with the Ultimate Travel Company. The first journey, in May, is a four-day trip to St. Ives, where the tour offers a private viewing of the summer exhibition at the Tate gallery there. (£895, $1,420 at $1.59 to the pound per person.) Among other trips: a visit to Paris and Champagne in September, accompanied by Tate's wine buyer and a Tate Modern curator, and a five-night stay next year in Berlin, where visits include various galleries and the Brandenburg Gate, above.

I have a confession to make. It isn't necessarily pretty, but it can be pretty sexy. I frequently sleep with an inappropriate partner - my makeup. Just like tously bedhead can increase a woman's hot factor, so can last night's makeup. Not only because of the way it looks, but also for the narrative it implies. (Provided you're not too puffy from last night's martini, of course.) I love the way loose pigment from M.A.C. or Make Up For Ever melts into the creases of my lids and creeps down the corners of my eyes while I sleep, and how Lip Tar from Obsessive Compulsive Cosmetics leaves a telling stain on my lips. A slightly smudgy cat eye in the morning reminds me of the sex kitten I was the night before. Mascara should be a strictly cumulative affair, if you ask me; it's so much better after two or three days' worth of top coats. I'm not the only one to embrace this beauty taboo. Lady Gaga has said she hits the hay in full makeup seven nights a week. The Warhol Factory superstar Edie Sedgwick reportedly never removed her fake lashes; she just kept adding more. And try telling me Carine Roitfeld doesn't leave on that liner sometimes. Heck, this morning at the gym, the woman next to me revealed she was doing her lunges with a full face from the night before. And it stayed perfectly put!

Population is key. If you don't take care of population, schools can't cope, hospitals can't cope, there's not enough housing -- there's nothing you can do to have economic development.PETER OGUNJUYIGBE,a demographer in Nigeria, where women have an average of more than five children. [10]

GLASGOW--Lloyd, devoted husband to the late Dorothy, loving father to Jenny and Donna, adoring grandfather to Byron, and irreplaceable friend to many died peacefully at his home on April 7 at the age of 91. A veteran of World War II, he served as a Lieutenant in the U.S. Coast Guard. He earned two battle stars and was awarded three medals for distinguished service in the Atlantic Theater antisubmarine patrol. As President and Chairman of Jacques Jugeat, Inc. (Lalique North America), he modeled integrity, honesty and loyalty to two generations of retailer buyers and wholesale sales representatives in the luxury giftware and tabletop industry. Generous to a fault, beloved for his loyalty, admired for his consistency, solicited for his wisdom, celebrated for his wit and charm, and loved for so much more, he is greatly missed. In lieu of flowers, donations to Doctors Without Borders in his memory would be welcomed.

''You need to see a doctor,'' the woman told her 27-year-old daughter. ''Really,'' she insisted. ''I'm worried.'' Her daughter, who lived several states away, was visiting, and when the mother happened to see her go up the stairs, she was struck by how odd this simple, everyday action looked. Her daughter's slender hips rocked from side to side as she moved up the steps. It was as if she had to lift her entire body to bring up each leg. Her mother was certain that something was wrong. 1. SLOW CHANGES

THE MATA FESTIVAL, an annual springtime explosion of new music, offers a bracing overview of the styles that young composers and performers are exploring right now. This year's prospectus is dominated by indie classical works -- hybrids in which classical, avant-garde, pop and world music elements are combined to yield results that are not quite in any of those languages. An opening-night performance and party at the Paula Cooper Gallery includes performances by the inventive loadbang ensemble, as well as electronic remixes of works from festival concerts by the electronica virtuoso Preshish Moments. The main concerts, at Roulette, start Wednesday with a battle of the bands, of sorts: the JACK Quartet and the Quartet New Generation -- a new-music recorder consort, of all things -- will play works by Huck Hodge and Qin Yi. Thursday is devoted to composer-performers, with Cecilia Lopez, Matt Marks, Mellissa Hughes and Kate Soper presiding over their own works. And Friday, Signal, the superb orchestra led by Brad Lubman, will play an international program that includes music by Francesco Filidei, Eric Wubbels, David Coll, Alex Freeman and Ivan Orozco. 6:30 p.m. Tuesday, 534 West 21st Street, Chelsea, $50; Wednesday to -Friday, 509 Atlantic Avenue, at Third Avenue, Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, (917) 267-0363, roulette.org; $20 to $25.

''Mary Tyler Moore'' is a sitcom. That is not my latest contribution to the literature of graffiti. That is a fact. A sitcom, as the trade pros would have it, is a situation comedy, one of the most fragile, abused and perishable of television formats.

DETROIT - People who own a hybrid car are unlikely to get another one the next time they buy a new vehicle, according to a study released Monday by the consulting firm R.L. Polk. Nearly two thirds of hybrid owners -- 65 percent -- who bought a new car last year chose a gasoline-powered model instead, Polk found by analyzing registration data for 75,000 vehicles. Excluding the top-selling model, the Toyota Prius, fewer than one quarter of hybrid owners bought a new hybrid.

IT seemed slightly improbable when, five years ago, the American Ballet Theater principal Ángel Corella started his own company in the Spanish province of Segovia. Spain has never been known for its classical dance troupes, nor did Mr. Corella have major benefactors or initial state support. But his boldness and determination to give Spain its own ballet troupe seems to have paid off. His company, which opens a short New York season at City Center on Tuesday, has 65 dancers and has found a new home in Barcelona. For the BARCELONA BALLET'S New York run Mr. Corella will dance with his company in ''Pálpito,'' a new piece by Ángel Rojas and Carlos Rodríguez, set to an original score by Héctor González. Since Mr. Rojas and Mr. Rodríguez are the directors of the flamenco troupe Nuevo Ballet Español, a ballet-flamenco fusion seems likely. But there's also plenty of ballet-ballet, in the form of Clark Tippet's ''Bruch Violin Concerto,'' with its multiple impassioned pas de deux, and Christopher Wheeldon's little-seen ''For 4,'' set to Schubert's ''Death and the Maiden.'' 7:30 p.m. Tuesday and Wednesday, 8 p.m. Thursday and Friday, 131 West 55th Street, Manhattan, (212) 581-1212, nycitycenter.org; tickets start at $25.

Cookbook, a green grocery store in the Echo Park neighborhood of Los Angeles run by the master gardener and chef Marta Teegen, is a monument to the principle of quality over quantity: inside the modest 500-square-foot space is nearly everything a cook with a penchant for natural ingredients could possibly want. The best organic produce, yes. But also Dr. Bob's ice cream, fresh-cut flowers, pasture-raised meats, Mast Brothers chocolate, Creminelli salami, Café Fanny granola and an ever-changing menu of prepared foods, derived each week from a different cookbook of Teegen's choosing. Mediterranean sources, like ''Moro East'' by Sam and Sam Clark, are in heavy rotation. ''We are interested in looking at what new things people are doing with food,'' Teegen says, ''but we also like to go back to the classics.'' More... This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

It started as an innocent collaboration with a throwaway name: the Californian KC Underwood, then 26, taught guitar to the 16-year-old Briton Alice Costelloe, a rock singer since she was 13, and they called themselves Big Deal because surely they'd never be one. Three years and an album later (''Lights Out''), the sound they thought wouldn't make waves outside his London flat - synchronized vocals and two electric guitars - has Britain enthralled (now the States, too: the band is fresh off a splashy debut at South by Southwest). And that moniker? ''The joke's not so funny now that we're stuck with a bad name,'' Underwood says. At least it's better than their first one: Hard Cheese. Music Video: ''Chair'' by Big Deal, from their album, ''Lights Out'' -

IN the aftermath of the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, there were plenty of stories of loss and heartache and heroism. And there was one story that was just plain bizarre: that of a woman using the name Tania Head, who for six years told an elaborate tale of having been rescued from the World Trade Center that was eventually revealed to have been fabricated. ''THE WOMAN WHO WASN'T THERE,'' a documentary being shown Tuesday night at 8 on Investigation Discovery, reconstructs Ms. Head's deception through film clips and interviews with some of the real survivors whom she convinced. Ms. Head became prominent in a survivor group and turned up at commemorative events, telling her story. She was, she said, seriously burned in the south tower even as her fictional fiancé was dying in the north tower.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''In Miami, Winning Clearly Isn't the Only Thing,'' April 11: We all know that Ozzie Guillen makes a much better baseball strategist than a candidate for the diplomatic service. However, I believe that he has the right to publicly express his opinion, no matter how controversial it may be.

Kingsley--Donald E. of Bristol, RI and Harwich, MA died on Monday April 9 after a long illness. He attended URI until he enlisted in the Army Air Force. He served as a fighter pilot and instructor of formation flying with the rank of First Lieutenant. Mr. Kingsley started in the investment industry in 1955 with Waddell and Reed, Inc. He became General Manager of Mutual Funds with Hayden Stone in 1959, and was later associated with Lehman Brothers, Stone and Webster, and Loeb Rhodes among others. By 1965 he was an Assistant Vice President at Harris Upham and Co., became National Mutual Funds Manager, was made Vice President in 1967, and when the firm merged with Smith Barney, became First Vice President and Director of National Sales. He was a Senior Vice President, Partner, and Managing Director on the Board until his retirement in 1987. Mr. Kingsley was a resident of Armonk, New York when he retired to Cape Cod. He is survived by his wife, Carmelita, daughter Lisa Baroni of Armonk, NY, and daughter Lauren Kingsley of Dexter, MI; also, grandchildren Roland Baroni III and Melissa Baroni, both of Boston, MA.

You know Chagall's canvases, but what of his cottons? ''Artists' Textiles'' (Antique Collectors' Club, $50) amasses works on fabric by 20th-century greats like Braque, Matisse, Calder and Warhol. The book begins in the 1910s with pathbreaking swatches by the British artist Roger Fry, who helped erase what he called ''the erroneous distinction between fine and applied art.'' Eventually, these art textiles were turned into commercial clothing: a Joan Miró dress, a Salvador Dalí tie. By the 1960s, Picasso was allowing his pictures to be printed on almost any fabric, save upholstery. The sofa was a line he wouldn't cross, the book notes: ''Picassos may be leaned against, not sat on.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

One of the West Coast's best-kept beauty secrets, the body ''contourier'' Megan Simon uses endermologie, sunless airbrush tanning, electrical currents, pet products and plain old good advice to make her celebrity clientele look slim, trim and cellulite-free. Trade secrets Besides attacking clients' cellulite with her endermologie machine, Simon makes their bodies look lithe by spraying an extra layer of sunless tan on thighs, sides of the waist and backs of the arms. An extra application around the jawline helps mask a double chin. Another useful illusion: Scott Barnes's Body Bling in Original applied all over, with the Platinum shade on the fronts of the legs to streamline. She swipes Nars Illuminator in Copacabana on the bridge of the nose and across the forehead to create the look of a perfect nose. For sunless touch-ups, she recommends SunFx White Out. Find her at beautifulyoumc.com.

We all know that comic books informed the Pop Art of Roy Lichtenstein, but less noted is that he also influenced the comics themselves. For a few months in 1965 Marvel touted its 12-cent comic books as Marvel Pop Art Productions. Something to chew on as we wait for the Lichtenstein retrospective to open May 16 at the Art Institute of Chicago. Above, ''Hot Dog With Mustard,'' 1963 (artic.edu).

Starwood Hotels & Resorts (starwoodhotels.com) has introduced a slate of rewards for foodies who are members of its loyalty program.
