DELANO--Georgia. An elegant lady who lived life to the fullest and enjoyed every minute. Inspired by the Preservation Youth Project at St. Mark's Church, she and her family moved to East 10th Street in the 1970s becoming an active element in the community fabric. She was a Founder, President Emerita, and a Trustee of the Citizens to Save St. Mark's, now the St. Mark's Historic Landmark Fund, because of the people, the place and the programs it nurtures. The Landmark Fund mourns her passing and celebrates her leadership, her spirit, her sense of joy and fairness, and her contributions throughout the City. She led by example and inspired us all to be better than ourselves. Georgia will be in our hearts forever.

Utilizing a well-located port in Boardman, Ore., could allow the state to transport coal mined in Wyoming and Montana to Asia, where the appetite for coal is still strong.
A young heroine and her two sidekicks set off on adventure in “Giants Beware!”
A Chinese government expert warned that geologic instability could force the relocation of 100,000 more residents of the area around the Three Gorges Dam.
The predicted reduction in lending is a major reason Europe is expected to have a mild recession this year and barely grow in 2013, the International Monetary Fund said.
An officer who was caught on videotape hitting a Danish activist in the face with a rifle in the West Bank will be dismissed “on moral grounds,” Israeli military said.
A day after Wall Street’s best gains in a month, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.63 percent as I.B.M. missed its revenue forecast and Intel’s results didn’t impress investors.
The police inquiry into phone hacking at Rupert Murdoch’s tabloid newspapers moved a step closer to possible criminal prosecutions on Wednesday.
Both Iranians and foreigners were arrested in connection with what was described as a plot to assassinate one of the country’s “specialists,” Iran’s state media reported.
Photographs published by The Los Angeles Times of soldiers with the hands and legs of Taliban fighters add to a list of cases that have cast American soldiers in the harshest possible light.
The Great Mosque in Djenné, Mali, a revered religious monument constructed almost entirely from sun-dried mud bricks coated with clay, is undergoing a restoration that has created local conflicts.
Issues that dogged heart device makers seven years ago are resurfacing over a problem with a defibrillator wire made by St. Jude Medical.
Anders Behring Breivik was questioned about trips to Liberia and London during which he said he met a Serbian war criminal and founded his anti-Islamic militant group.
After 24 years of steely determination to remain in Myanmar despite offers to leave, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi will make her first foreign trip since 1988, visiting Norway and Britain.
Republican voters in Arizona on Tuesday chose Jesse Kelly to face off against Ron Barber in the special election to fill the congressional seat vacated by Gabrielle Giffords.
Stuart Leslie, an industrial designer, shopped for accessories that look good enough to put on display.
Joseph Altuzarra’s seven-piece collection for J. Crew includes mariner stripes as dresses and long-sleeve tops; a classic gingham sundress or tie-front shirt; and espadrilles in red or apricot.
Some people opt for cosmetic surgery to make themselves look better on Skype or FaceTime.
Haute Hippie is not as oxymoronic a venture as it might sound, with Talitha Getty, the dusky beauty and wife of John Paul Getty Jr., as much a patron saint of the movement as Wavy Gravy is.

BOSTON - Senator Scott P. Brown has been playing up his devotion to the Boston Red Sox, releasing two radio advertisements that celebrate the team and its ballpark and a video of himself and his wife in matching Sox jackets as they greeted fans on Opening Day. But on Wednesday, Mr. Brown woke up to a headline on the front of The Boston Herald proclaiming, ''Scott Brown Taps Evil Empire.'' Mr. Brown, the newspaper reported, had received a $2,500 contribution for his re-election campaign last month from Randy Levine, the president of the dreaded New York Yankees.

LUXNER--Harriette (Heidi) Sterns, died on April 17, 2012, in Bennington, Vermont, at the age of 71. Born in Peoria, Illinois, and the daughter of Cis and William Sterns Jr., Heidi grew-up in Summit, New Jersey, where she attended The Kent Place School. A 1962 graduate of Smith College, Heidi pursued an active career in the publishing industry and was an early pioneer for women in executive management in corporate America. She worked with The New York Times, helped found Working Woman magazine, and rose to Senior Vice President at Institutional Investor. She retired to Dorset, Vermont, in the late 1990s, where she was active with the Manchester Music Festival, Southern Vermont Art Center and Dorset Congregational Church. She is survived by her husband, David Luxner; her two children, Reed Merrill and Sara Merrill Shafer; three grandchildren, Rebecca Lala Merrill, Alexander Reed Shafer and Katherine Riley Shafer; her brother, William Sterns III; and her faithful feline, Tarzan Jr. A memorial service will be held at the Dorset Congregational Church on June 13, 2012. In lieu of flowers, please consider making a contribution to the Manchester Music Festival.

LONDON -- The Canadian convenience store operator Alimentation Couche-Tard agreed on Wednesday to buy Statoil Fuel & Retail of Norway for $2.8 billion, part of a strategy by the Canadian company to expand into the Scandinavian and Eastern European markets. Under the terms of the deal, Couche-Tard, based in Laval, Quebec, will offer the shareholders of Statoil Fuel & Retail 53 Norwegian kroner, or $9.22, for each of their shares in the company, which operates convenience and gas stations across Scandinavia and Eastern Europe.

LONDON EXACTLY a year ago, Hampton Court Palace, on the outskirts of this city, hid yet another secret in its long history. A team of dressmakers worked on the royal wedding behind closed doors and shuttered blinds.

Maybe Apple's plastic iPhone stand doesn't seem a substantial enough vessel for your beloved 4S. Don't worry, Element Case has you covered. The case maker has built the Vapor Dock for the iPhone, a dense half-pound of machined aluminum anodized in silver or black.

FREILICHER--Frances, 92, on April 16 in Lantana, FL. Devoted wife of the late Jack. Beloved by her sons Melvyn, (Joseph Keenan), Bruce (Nancy), and David and her grandchildren Emily and Luc. Frances was always learning and giving from a most generous heart. Funeral: Sunday, 11am, Plaza Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave, New York, NY. Contributions can be made to Hebrew Home at Riverdale.

You can't see Quiara Alegría Hudes's ''Water by the Spoonful'' right now, even though it just won the Pulitzer Prize for drama. The play, the second part of a trilogy, ran for less than a month in its world premiere at Hartford Stage in late 2011. The other two finalists, Jon Robin Baitz's ''Other Desert Cities'' and Stephen Karam's ''Sons of the Prophet,'' were far better known, having enjoyed prominent and well-received New York productions; ''Other Desert Cities'' is playing on Broadway and is a likely contender for the Tony Award for best play, to be announced in June. This is not the first time the Pulitzer has gone to a play on the strength of the script as opposed to a production. (None of the five jurors saw ''Water'' in Hartford.) That's completely permissible according to the prize rules, but it tends to ruffle feathers; the last time this happened -- when Nilo Cruz's ''Anna in the Tropics'' won sight unseen in 2003 -- the theater critic John Lahr of The New Yorker sniffed that it was ''as absurd as giving a restaurant four stars on the basis of its menu.''

A report in the Observatory column on April 10 about the effects of social stress on immunity in rhesus macaques described researchers' findings incorrectly at one point. As the report correctly noted elsewhere, scientists who examined the monkeys' white blood cells linked social stress to differences in the expression of nearly 1,000 genes -- not to differences in the genes themselves.

FINLETTER--Eileen, died on April 18th at the Hebrew Home in Riverdale, NY at age 91. She was the widow of Thomas Finletter and the mother of the late Rachel Geist Rubel and of Stephen Geist, who survives her along with eight grandchildren. Eileen will be fondly remembered for her quick wit, great intellectual curiosity and her devotion to her many friends. There will be a private burial.

Five guitars stolen last week from Tom Petty and his band have been recovered, and one person is under arrest in connection with the theft, The Associated Press reported on Tuesday. Lt. Ron Iizuka of the Culver City, Calif., police department declined to provide details, though he confirmed the guitars stolen last Thursday from a rehearsal studio had been found. The instruments went missing from the Culver Studios, a complex of sound stages west of downtown Los Angeles where Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers had been rehearsing for a tour, which starts Wednesday in Colorado. They included Mr. Petty's 1967 maple 12-string Rickenbacker electric and his Gibson SGTV Junior electric. Also missing were Mike Campbell's blue custom-made Duesenberg guitar, Ron Blair's Fender Broadcaster guitar and Scott Thurston's 1967 Epiphone Sheridan guitar.

He is probably the luckiest unlucky man you could ever have.JOSHUA BEDERSON, head of neurosurgery at Mount Sinai Medical Center, on Officer Eder Loor, a policeman who is expected to recover fully after being stabbed in the head. [A1]

Because of an editing error, the Giglio Journal article on Wednesday, about the effect the capsized cruise ship Costa Concordia may have on the Italian island's tourism, misstated the length of the ship, which has lain on its side just off Giglio since it hit a submerged rock on Jan. 13. The Costa Concordia is 951 feet, not 591.

THE naturalist and philosopher Henry David Thoreau coined a wonderful word for an imagined instrument in his 1854 book, ''Walden'': the ''realometer.'' Thoreau's realometer would allow an inquiring person to measure the reality of his perceptions, to push past the ''mud and slush of opinion, and prejudice, and tradition, and delusion, and appearance ... to a hard bottom.'' Thoreau has provided us with this very tool in his extensive journals. Starting in 1851, he began recording the progress of the seasons in Concord, Mass., by noting the first flowers, leaves and migratory birds of spring. All told, he kept records for more than 300 species.

LIMITED CHOICES Citigroup, which received a public rebuke when shareholders voted to reject the bank's executive compensation plan, now has two options. It can choose to ignore this advisory vote, or it can try to revise management's pay either retroactively or for this year. If Citigroup ignores the vote, the bank could face a number of pressures that may subsequently force the financial firm to adjust the compensation of its chief, Vikram S. Pandit, above, and other executives anyway.

HELD--Huyler. The Board of the Society for the Relief of Women and Children deeply mourns the death of our advisor Huyler C. Held, who for many years provided wise counsel to our Society and supported us in our efforts to relieve poverty and homelessness amongst the women of New York City. We will miss his wisdom and friendship. Mrs. Adrian H. Jones,President

A literary partnership between Charles Dickens and J. R. R. Tolkien would have been downright impossible, if not undesirable. (A tale of hungry workhouse hobbits who want more gruel? An evil, all-seeing eye visited by foreboding spirits on Christmas?) But a London publisher has nonetheless found a way to get their names onto the same project, in the form of a collaboration between descendants of Tolkien and Dickens, BBC News reported. The publisher Thames River Press said it would release two fantasy novels written by Michael Tolkien, aimed at younger readers and based on stories told to him by his grandfather, the ''Lord of the Rings'' author J. R. R. Tolkien. Gerald Dickens, a great-great grandson of Dickens, will narrate the audiobook releases. BBC News said the first book, called ''Wish,'' was inspired by the Florence Bone story ''The Rose-Colored Wish'' and chronicles two children who come into possession of an evil sorcerer's enchanted artifact; the second book, ''Rainbow,'' takes its inspiration from another work by Ms. Bone called ''The Other Side of the Rainbow.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Lisa Schiff is stepping down as the chairwoman of Jazz at Lincoln Center after leading the organization through a tumultuous decade of growth. Ms. Schiff was expected to announce at the institution's annual gala on Wednesday night that her successor would be Robert J. Appel, a financier and philanthropist who joined the Jazz at Lincoln Center board in 2008. Her decision to hand the chairman's duties over to Mr. Appel comes just four months after Adrian Ellis, the executive director she brought in to oversee the move to Columbus Circle, announced that he was leaving for the private sector. Together Ms. Schiff and Mr. Ellis had shored up the institution's finances, reduced its debt and expanded its presence abroad.

8:30 P.M. (13) RODELINDA The soprano Renée Fleming (above) reprises the title role in Handel's opera about the love of a queen for her exiled husband, Bertarido, the king of Milan, sung by the German countertenor Andreas Scholl, in this revival of the 2004 Metropolitan Opera production created as a showcase for its star. The mezzo-soprano Stephanie Blythe plays Eduige, Bertarido's sister, and the British countertenor Iestyn Davies makes his Met debut as Bertarido's faithful friend Unulfo. ''The specialist Mr. Scholl, apart from his splendid lyrical gifts, gave an occasional lesson in what is now thought to be an appropriate use of vibrato in Baroque music, starting with straight tone and gradually warming it with vibration,'' James R. Oestreich wrote in The New York Times about this production, directed by Stephen Wadsworth, conducted by the Baroque specialist Harry Bicket and presented here by ''Great Performances at the Met.'' ''Ms. Fleming painted her coloratura in broad strokes,'' he added. ''But it was enough that she threw herself and her voice wholeheartedly into the considerable drama.'' 3 P.M. (Fox Business Network) COUNTDOWN TO THE CLOSING BELL Liz Claman celebrates her 1,000th episode, live from the floor of the New York Stock Exchange.

SOLOW--Renee. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Renee Solow, beloved sister of Sheldon Solow. Over the years, the Solow family's unparalleled philanthropic giving has changed the course of countless lives. Renee expressed her deep concern for the Jewish community and all New Yorkers through her support of UJA-Federation. She was especially interested in helping to resettle struggling Jews from the former Soviet Union. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Jerry W. Levin, President Alisa R. Doctoroff, Chair of the Board, John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

KRISTIN REITER, half of the popular fashion blog BleachBlack.com (written with her friend Valerie Killeen), has designed a silvery new iPhone case. Made with a chrome-coated metal frame and LCD mirror screen protectors, the case also serves as a compact mirror, just the thing for those of us who check for lipstick smudges on the phone camera. ''I am constantly in need of a mirror,'' said Ms. Reiter, who is also a global design director at Nike. ''Compacts aren't something people really carry around anymore.'' Find the clever case, $150, at kristinreiter.com/shop.php.

WHEN the young Belgian designer Alexandra Verschueren won the prestigious Hyères Fashion Festival in 2010, she did so with a collection that was inspired in part by origami, and she hand-pleated every piece. Humberto Leon of Opening Ceremony was the first to express interest in her work, and her new collection, called Shift, has now arrived at the shop. For the second collection, Ms. Verschueren, who still works from a studio in her parents' Antwerp home, found a company in Japan to do her intricate pleating, a painstaking process in which fabric is pressed in a handmade paper mold, then steamed so the pleats will last. The resulting pieces include airy separates (far left). Other looks, like these shifts, one with translucent cutouts and the other in a pretty vegetable-dyed tangerine with scallop detail, are both dainty and strong. Alexandra Verschueren designs, $250 to $1,010 at Opening Ceremony, 35 Howard Street; openingceremony.us.
GREEN--Corey, died April 16th, 2012 after a short illness. Memorial services will be held Friday April 20th, 2pm in The Parish Hall at St. Marks Of The Bowery, 131 East 10th St., New York 10003.

Goldman Sachs is said to be in negotiations to sell one of its most notable portfolios, Petershill, which has suffered some major setbacks in its hedge fund investments. Asset Management Finance, a firm that takes stakes in money managers, is considering buying Petershill, a five-year-old Goldman portfolio that owns pieces of established hedge funds, according to people with knowledge of the discussions. The people cautioned that the talks with Asset Management Finance, which is majority-owned by Credit Suisse, could still fall apart.

If you admire those moody, sparsely lit portraits where the subject's face is surrounded by darkness, you may despair that you will never get that shot without a studio and black backdrop. It turns out you don't need either. You can fake a black backdrop even on a sunny day outdoors with just a camera and separate flash.

The path to gaming the Volcker Rule has always been clear: Banks will shut down anything with the word ''proprietary'' on the door and simply move the activities down the hall. To look as if they were ready to comply with the Volcker Rule, the part of the Dodd-Frank Act that aims to prevent banks from gambling on their own account with money that taxpayers insure, financial firms quickly spun off or shut down their hedge funds, private equity firms and proprietary trading desks.

Known for its unstoppable bunny and the batteries that keep him going, Energizer recently introduced a line of well-designed household lighting products, including flameless candles and accent lamps. The sleek Glas Collection includes a task lamp with an energy-efficient LED light source that produces 42 lumens per watt, more than a typical incandescent bulb. More lumens per watt means more light for less money.

House Republicans are finding that their embrace of Roman Catholic bishops can have a political downside. Ever since the Obama administration ran afoul of the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops over mandated contraception coverage, Republican lawmakers have used Catholic leaders as a cudgel in their efforts to paint the Obama administration as waging a war on religious freedom. But the group recently sent letters to chairmen of two House committees lambasting Republican efforts to cut government spending.
Q. Where did the Menu bar go in Internet Explorer 9?

If your once-zippy Android phone has noticeably slowed down or certain apps have started to behave erratically, clearing cache files may help. Cache files -- temporary files that apps store on your phone -- can hog space and cause other problems like Twitter timelines not updating properly. Several apps like Easy Cache Cleaner and App Cache Cleaner are available on Google Play (the successor to the Android Market) offer to easily clear cached files, but you can also do it yourself. In Android 2.2 and later, press the Menu key on the phone and tap Settings. On the Settings screen, tap Applications and then Manage Applications.

SHREDDED denim, which last made a splash with those $2,000 Balmain jeans, has turned up again, deliberately dissolute but styled up this time around. The fashion blogger Peony Lim (bottom right) wears her torn jeans with a tweed coat, Miu Miu pumps and a classic Chanel bag. Amanda Brooks (top right) tops her tattered pair with a smart peacoat. And we'd bet that the shredded Acne jacket that the stylist Kate Lanphear (above), she of the signature black, is wearing has lent impetus to the trend. Rihanna and Hanneli Mustaparta, the photographer-blogger, have also been out and about in the jacket, called Fever Torn, which at this point is out of stock. If you are moved to break out your beaten-up Levi's this spring, think about adding an anorak and multistrap Mary Janes rather than the predictable, albeit always cool, leather jacket and Chucks. Then tear up the town.

On the shelf where my parents kept the LPs when I was a child was an album with a picture of a woman who had nothing on but a towel. She was sitting on the edge of a bathtub, talking on the telephone. The album was ''Oh, Rosalinda,'' the movie soundtrack of the Johann Strauss II operetta ''Die Fledermaus.'' Somehow, maybe from an LP with a less racy, less memorable cover, or maybe from a song on the radio, I became aware of another famous operetta, ''The Merry Widow.''

To win over Instagram, Facebook was forced to show its hand. Facebook bought the photo-sharing service for $1 billion in early April, agreeing to pay roughly 30 percent in cash and 70 percent in stock, according to people briefed on the negotiations who did not want to be identified because the discussions were private. At that level, Facebook is pegging its own stock price at roughly $30 a share. Based on those numbers, the giant social network is valued at north of $75 billion.

HELD--Huyler C. The Partners, Associates and Staff of McLaughlin & Stern LLP record with great sorrow the passing of our Partner, mentor and friend Huyler C. Held. Until his final day he was a wonderfully unique and compelling force in the legal and philanthropic circles of New York, and we shall miss him greatly.

GREENE--James B.,84, died peacefully at home in New York, NY on April 17th surrounded by family. Beloved husband of the late Diana, loving father to Edward and Robin, he was a garment industry importer and designer. The funeral will be on April 19th at Plaza Jewish Chapel at 630 Amsterdam Ave. at 11:00am. The family will be sitting Shiva through Monday.

The Up Close column last Thursday, about Veronica Vasicka, the founder of the Brooklyn music label Minimal Wave, misspelled the first name of a musician whom she photographed. He is Jon Spencer, not John.

Illumina succeeded in battling a $6.2 billion hostile takeover bid from Roche Holding, as the provider of genetic analysis services claimed victory in a fight over control of its board. On Wednesday, shareholders voted to re-elect all of Illumina's directors at the company's annual meeting by a large margin, defeating an effort by Roche to gain control of the board. Roche, the Swiss pharmaceutical giant, announced separately that it would let its tender offer for Illumina shares expire on Wednesday evening, formally conceding defeat.

GOTTSEGEN--Matthew C.,61, died suddenly after a brief illness. Funeral services were held on Thursday, April 5th, 2012 in Kingston, NY. He is survived by his wife Alice and daughters Sarah and Frances. Kindly send donations to: newdestinyhousing.org, an organization which Matthew passionately supported.

HELD--Huyler C. of New York City and Oyster Bay, NY. Died on April 16, 2012 peacefully at home at age 87. Survived by nephews and nieces, Russell and Linda Landon, Brad, Charles, Ann (Ellis) and Jane (Rotondi) Woodworth, and by many cousins. Graduate of Lawrenceville School, Princeton University (Class of 1947) and Columbia Law School. Served in USNR 1943-46. Board member of The Cathedral of St. John The Divine, Fountain House, Inc. (Past President), Society for the Preservation of Long Island Antiquities (Past President), The Nature Conservancy of NYS, The New York Botanical Garden, Preservation League of NYS, St. James' Church, NYS Archives Partnership Trust, The John Merck Fund, Eppley Foundation for Research, Friends of Upper East Side Historic District, and other philanthropic institutions. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts to either Fountain House, Inc. 425 W 47th Street, New York, NY 10036, or SPLIA, PO Box 148 Cold Spring Harbor, NY 11724, would be appreciated.

The Mexico City Journal article on April 10, about a towering vertical garden, one of three eco-sculptures installed across the city to be both art and oxygenator, misstated the role of carbon dioxide in urban pollution. Ground-level ozone forms from the interaction, in the presence of sunlight, of nitrogen oxides and volatile organic compounds; it does not form from carbon dioxide.

Sony has won European regulators' approval for its $2.2 billion takeover of EMI Music Publishing, which would create the largest catalog of songs in the world, according to a person briefed on the process. The European Commission is scheduled to make an announcement on Thursday, the self-imposed deadline for its investigation, that it approved the deal with as much as $35 million in concessions, said that person, who requested anonymity because the information had not been made public. The commission's approval was first reported by The Financial Times.

Six mannequin torsos -- three wearing Chicago Bulls jerseys and three with Boston Celtics jerseys -- sat on tables in front of N.B.A. owners in a meeting room at the St. Regis hotel in Manhattan. The jerseys were unlike any that the Bulls and the Celtics wear. All had a corporate name or logo -- and were sartorial harbingers of the N.B.A.'s future.

The Personal Health column on Tuesday, about the risks posed by the large number of medications that many elderly Americans take, misstated the condition that Travatan eye drops are used to treat. It is glaucoma, not wet macular degeneration.

BlackRock, the giant money manager, said it would have no choice but to shift some of its business away from certain Wall Street firms if Moody's Investors Service went ahead with its threat to downgrade some of the country's biggest banks. ''I think this has serious implications,'' Laurence D. Fink, the firm's chairman and chief executive, said in an interview on Wednesday following the release of BlackRock's first quarter earnings. ''If Moody's does indeed downgrade these institutions, we may have a need to move some business around to higher-rated institutions.''

An article on Saturday about a low-voltage model of a subway train that took passengers to Yankee Stadium for the team's home opener referred incorrectly to the time period in which such models, known as Lo-V's, have made runs to the stadium. The models were decommissioned in 1969 and did not run again until 2004, when they began to be used occasionally for ceremonial purposes. It is not the case that ''a Lo-V has made a run to the stadium every year since 1917.'' (In any case, Yankee Stadium did not come along until 1923.)

An article on Monday about students being tutored for this week's state standardized tests misstated the number of third and fourth graders enrolled in Manhattan branches of the Kumon tutoring chain. There are 642 enrolled -- not roughly 3,000, which is the total enrollment in those branches.

SPENCER--Mary Kathleen, 63, flew to heaven on Sunday April 15, 2012. The daughter of the late George Spencer and Mary Dooley Spencer is survived by six brothers and sisters, George Spencer, Suzanne Spencer, Sally Walsh, Michael Spencer, Jeanmarie Skelly, and Donna Meehan. In addition, Mary will be remembered by thirteen loving nieces and nephews and nineteen grandnieces and grandnephews. A graduate of Hunter College with a Masters degree in Education, Mary served as a New York City Public School teacher for more than 30 years, retiring from PS 16X in 2003. Mary's unselfish good works touched all who knew her. Following cremation, a memorial mass will be held at Visitation Church 160 Van Cortlandt Park South Bronx, NY on Friday April 20th at 10:15am. Immediately following will be a luncheon at Xavier's on the Hudson. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Memorial Sloane Kettering Cancer Center for Melanoma Research or Calvary Hospital in her memory.

Axl Rose was always a rock star with a colorful vocabulary, but until now few of his fans realized it included the word sorry. In a post published Tuesday on the Web site of his band, Guns N' Roses, Mr. Rose offered his apologies to his fans and to the people of Cleveland for snubbing last Saturday's induction ceremony at the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum, writing that he ''seriously didn't plan on or expect the overwhelmingly positive response and public support for my decision.'' Last week the mercurial Mr. Rose announced in an open letter that he would not attend the induction ceremony honoring Guns N' Roses (as well as acts like Red Hot Chili Peppers and Beastie Boys) and asked that he not be inducted in absentia, citing a grab bag of personal and professional issues that included the ''endless amount of revisionism'' of his band's history and ''the greed of this industry and the ever present seemingly limitless supply of wannabes and unscrupulous, irresponsible media types.''

The Tribeca Film Festival returned to New York on Wednesday with more than 90 features in tow and a variety of events that expand beyond the movie screen. Started as a project to help revitalize downtown neighborhoods after Sept. 11, the festival has evolved in several ways over the past decade. And making choices about the kinds of films the festival will show has always been an important factor in its growth. This year a new team is making those choices. The artistic director, Frédéric Boyer (above right), was artistic director and chief programmer of the Directors' Fortnight at Cannes. Genna Terranova (right), who comes from an acquisitions background and was the festival's senior programmer, has been promoted to director of programming. And Geoffrey Gilmore (below right), who was the longtime director of the Sundance Film Festival before taking over as chief creative officer at Tribeca in 2009, has expanded his programming role.

LISA PERRY, whose bright A-line shifts would slip seamlessly into Megan Draper's mod wardrobe, has teamed up with Jeff Koons for her latest art-inspired apparel collection, her first with a living artist. (Andy Warhol and Roy Lichtenstein were the focus of earlier collaborations.) Apart from those time-traveling shift dresses, the new collection has an expanded selection of accessories, which incorporate some of Mr. Koons's iconic works. There are Lucite clutches printed with ''Monkey Train (Birds),'' $995; a vinyl tote featuring ''Green Diamond,'' $325; and these playful ''Loopy'' cuffs, $295. Available Thursday at Lisa Perry, 988 Madison Avenue; lisaperrystyle.com.
A selection of recent comments from readers of the Home section, drawn from letters and postings at nytimes.com. On Executive Mansions

3:07 p.m. | Updated SXC Health Solutions agreed on Wednesday to buy Catalyst Health Solutions for about $4.4 billion in cash and stock, creating one of the biggest independent drug benefits management companies in the country.

New York City Opera, which last year announced a plan to take opera to the people with performances around the city, said on Wednesday that it had established agreements to perform in two places: the Brooklyn Academy of Music and New York City Center, its original home. In releasing its plans for next season, the company said it would perform Thomas Adès's ''Powder Her Face,'' directed by Jay Scheib, and Benjamin Britten's ''Turn of the Screw,'' directed by Sam Buntrock, at BAM; and Rossini's ''Moses in Egypt,'' directed by Michael Counts, and Offenbach's ''Périchole,'' directed by Christopher Alden, at City Center.

COHEN--Rabbi Jack. The Board and all those associated with The Mordecai M. Kaplan Center for Jewish Peoplehood mourn the passing of our beloved Honorary Chairman, Rabbi Dr. Jack J. Cohen of Jerusalem, who died there on April 16 at the age of 93. The Jewish people have lost a giant of a teacher and a role model. One of Mordecai Kaplan's greatest and most devoted disciples, Jack was the foremost advocate in Israel for the Reconstructionist approach to Judaism for more than 50 years. Among many other accomplishments, Jack was a founder of Congregation Mevakshei Derech in Jerusalem and the creator of its Kaplan Center. A man of enormous talents and erudition, Jack also exemplified true humility and treated all human beings with respect and kindness. His tireless passion for continuing the work of his teacher Mordecai Kaplan was an inspiration to all of us. We will miss both Jack's intellectual leadership and the gentleness of his soul. Jack's memory will forever be a blessing. Eric Caplan Daniel Cedarbaum Mel Scult Jack Wolofsky

An article on Wednesday about Rick Santorum's political plans paraphrased incorrectly from comments by a strategist for Mr. Santorum about the former senator's plans to endorse Mitt Romney. The strategist, John Brabender, said that he expected Mr. Santorum to meet with Mr. Romney in the next two or three weeks to discuss a possible endorsement -- not that he expected an endorsement to take place in that time period.

9:34 a.m. | Updated News Corporation said Wednesday it would suspend half of the voting rights of its non-American shareholders in order to comply with United States government regulations on foreign ownership. The Federal Communications Act limits the ownership and voting power of foreign investors in broadcast stations to no more than 25 percent. In a breach of government rules, News Corporation's foreign investors owned 36 percent of the company's class B voting shares. The company's board said it approved an immediate suspension of 50 percent of foreign shareholders' voting rights.

The Broadway-bound production of ''Rodgers & Hammerstein's Cinderella'' has found a leading lady who fits the glass slipper - as well as the actor to play her prince. Laura Osnes, who starred as the outlaw Bonnie Parker in the Broadway musical ''Bonnie & Clyde'' last year, will play a re-invented Cinderella in the production aiming to open during the 2012-13 theater season, while Santino Fontana (''Sons of the Prophet,'' ''Billy Elliot'') will play the prince, the show's producers said on Wednesday. The Rodgers and Hammerstein version of ''Cinderella'' began as a television musical in 1957, and has been performed in theaters and opera houses but never on Broadway. The new production features a freshly written book by Douglas Carter Beane (''Lysistrata Jones,'' ''The Little Dog Laughed''), who has added some modern-minded twists to the classic story; this time around, for instance, it is Cinderella who rescues the prince.

DANY--Lisa Joy Cohn, left us far too soon on April 16th after a courageous struggle. She was a shining light in so many lives beloved wife of Sean, adored mother of Ryan and Sloane, cherished daughter of Joan Cohn and James Cohn, loving sister to Robyn Cohn Deutsch and brother-in-law Jon, and amazing aunt to Ruby and Nate. Lisa's beauty, grace and elegance lit up a room. Her devotion to family, friends, and the community is her legacy. Her generous spirit will always endure. Services to be held at Westchester Reform Temple Thursday at 12:30pm. In lieu of flowers, please consider making a donation to Cycle for Survival in memory of Lisa. Donations can be made at www.cycleforsurvival.org or sent to Cycle for Survival at 633 Third Avenue 28th Floor, New York, NY 10017.

The lineup for the Midsummer Night Swing series of concerts this year includes a European boogie-woogie combo with Charlie Watts on drums and a concert by masters of forró music from northeastern Brazil, some of whom have rarely appeared outside their homeland, Lincoln Center announced on Tuesday. Now in its 24th year, the dance concerts will be held from June 26 to July 14 at the band shell in Damrosch Park on West 62nd Street, and dance lessons are available for those in need of help with the steps. The series begins with the Nelson Riddle Orchestra doing a tribute to Frank Sinatra and Ella Fitzgerald and ends with the Harlem Renaissance Orchestra playing an evening of classic big-band swing. In between are concerts devoted to all manner of social dance: salsa, charanga, cumbia, boogaloo, cha-cha, forró, tango, foxtrot, Lindy Hop, swing and jitterbug.

Retail sales in the United States rose a surprisingly strong 0.8 percent in March. Over all, retail sales were 5 percent higher in the past 12 months than they were in the 12 months through July 2008, when sales peaked as the credit crisis and recession began to hit. The charts show the change in sales from the peak for overall retail sales and for 10 categories of retailers. The biggest gains have come from Internet retailers, while neither auto dealers nor retailers catering to homeowners have made a complete recovery.

MUMBAI, India - In 2010, when the Indian government sold 10 percent of the shares of Coal India, one of the world's largest coal mine operators, the transaction was a way to raise money to help reduce its budget deficit. It did not anticipate that some of the shares would end up in the hands of activist hedge fund managers who would demand that the behemoth company, which employs more than 372,000 people, be managed differently.

GER--Ralph, M.D. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University is deeply saddened by the passing of our professor of anatomy and structural biology and of surgery. An Einstein faculty for more than 40 years, Dr. Ger was a pioneer in myocutaneous flap and laparoscopic hernia surgery. He was better known by generations of Einstein students for his anatomy course, where his erudition and dry sense of humor made it a most memorable course. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to the entire Ger family. Allen M. Spiegel, M.D., Dean Ruth L. Gottesman, Ed.D. Chair, Board of Overseers Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University

ACIERNO--Joseph Nicholas. It is with great sadness that the Acierno family wishes to announce the passing of its gentle patriarch Joseph Nicholas Acierno. Joseph, affectionately known as Chuck by his family and friends, died peacefully on April 18, 2012 after battling illnesses for many years. The beloved husband of Rosemarie for 58 years, devoted father to Lynne, John, and Mark, and grandfather to eight, he carried himself with understated elegance. Joseph was a graduate of Tulane University and Fordham Law School and served in the armed forces. For decades, he was an Icon in the New York transportation industry, was president of the Metropolitan Taxicab Board of Trade and was known for his deep sense of integrity and unflappable even tempered nature. He and his brother John transformed their taxi business into what was to become the largest black car and limousine business in the New York metropolitan area. The business is now carried on by the fourth generation of Aciernos. Although now gone, his spirit and family values will live on with those he touched. His family will receive friends at Burroughs, Kohr and Dangler Funeral Home, 309 Springfield Ave., Summit, NJ on Friday April 20, between the hours of 2-4 and 7-9pm. The Funeral Mass will be celebrated Saturday, April 21, 10:00am at St. Rose of Lima R.C. Church, 50 Short Hills Ave., Short Hills, NJ. Private entombment will follow. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation, or the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society would be deeply appreciated.

Business for private equity firms may be improving, but it was not enough to lift the Blackstone Group's first-quarter profit. CLARK--Richard W. "Dick". The entire Syracuse University family mourns the loss of its dedicated and esteemed alumnus Richard "Dick" W. Clark (Whitman School of Management, '51). In 1995, Syracuse University honored him with the Arents Pioneer Medal for his contributions to the entertainment industry. We remember him most fondly for the warmth and generosity with which he helped guide generations of SU students as they embarked on careers in the entertainment industry. Our heartfelt sympathies to Kari and the entire family. We will miss Dick greatly. Richard L. Thompson, Chairman of the Board of Trustees Nancy Cantor, Chancellor and President

WASHINGTON -- President Obama is finding himself increasingly boxed in on the Keystone pipeline fight as more Congressional Democrats are joining Republicans in backing the project, which has strong labor support and could generate significant numbers of jobs in economically hard-hit states. On Wednesday, the House passed a short-term transportation bill that included a provision that would pave the way for the construction of the next stage of the oil pipeline, a measure that Mr. Obama has said he would veto. The bill passed 293 to 127, with 69 Democrats supporting it.

Judy Kuhn will play Fosca opposite Melissa Errico as Clara in the Classic Stage Company's coming revival of Stephen Sondheim and James Lapine's musical drama ''Passion,'' the theater announced on Thursday. The show, directed by John Doyle, is to begin performances in February 2013. Additional casting, including the role of the soldier Giorgio, is still to be announced. Set in 19th-century Italy, ''Passion'' is an unconventional beauty-and-the-beast tale about Giorgio, an army officer who unexpectedly falls in love with Fosca, an ugly older woman near death. Although Clara, Giorgio's mistress, is more beautiful, Fosca's unconditional longing for Giorgio makes him question what it means to be in love. The darkly romantic score includes the songs ''Happiness,'' ''I Wish I Could Forget You'' and ''Loving You.''

MUMBAI, India - In 2010, when the Indian government sold 10 percent of the shares of Coal India, one of the world's largest coal mine operators, the transaction was a way to raise money to help reduce its budget deficit. It did not anticipate that some of the shares would end up in the hands of activist hedge fund managers who would demand that the behemoth company, which employs more than 372,000 people, be managed differently.

In the latest rebuke of eye-popping pay packages on Wall Street, a major institutional investor is taking the rare step to oppose the re-election of a Goldman Sachs board member who approves compensation for many of the bank's top executives. The managers of Sequoia Fund announced plans this week to vote against James A. Johnson, a longtime Goldman director and a former chief executive of Fannie Mae, and urged other shareholders to follow suit. The push comes days after Citigroup shareholders rejected the bank's $15 million payout to its chief executive, Vikram S. Pandit.

It may be a tiny Chinese educational company worth a little over $200 million. But the ChinaCast Education Corporation has found itself embroiled in a battle worthy of a John Grisham novel. Its ousted chief executive, Ron Chan, has been accused of aiding in the disappearance of ChinaCast's chops - ornate corporate seals that are needed to approve everything from paychecks to contracts.
International RUSSIA TRIES TO STEM PANIC

David Cronenberg, Lee Daniels, Walter Salles, Ken Loach and Michael Haneke will be among the directors vying for the Palme d'Or at this year's Cannes Film Festival, its organizers announced on Thursday. The slate of 22 features that will be shown in competition at the festival, which runs from May 16 through 27 and will open with Wes Anderson's latest film, ''Moonrise Kingdom,'' also includes ''The Paperboy,'' a drama directed by Mr. Daniels (''Precious''), adapted from the Pete Dexter novel and starring Nicole Kidman, Matthew McConaughey, Zac Efron and John Cusack; a film version of Jack Kerouac's ''On the Road,'' directed by Mr. Salles (''Dark Water''); ''Amour,'' a new work by Mr. Haneke, a previous Palme d'Or winner for ''The White Ribbon''; and ''The Angels' Share,'' a comic caper from Mr. Loach, who received that award for ''The Wind That Shakes the Barley.'' Mr. Cronenberg's adaptation of the Don DeLillo novel ''Cosmopolis,'' featuring the ''Twilight'' star Robert Pattinson, will also be in competition, while ''Antiviral,'' the debut film by his son, Brandon Cronenberg, will be among the features shown in the festival's Un Certain Regard lineup. Other much anticipated works by filmmakers like Paul Thomas Anderson and Terrence Malick were not completed in time for the festival's deadlines, Cannes director Thierry Frémaux said. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

FEINBERG--Sidney March 3, 1940 April 20, 2007 He was born with a gift of laughter and a sense that the world was mad. Rafael Sabatini We still mourn the loss of our beloved friend Sidney a superb lawyer, consummate teacher, witty raconteur, and generous and loyal friend. Angela and Kathy

A TEMPORARY PASS Regulators on Thursday announced a clarification that Wall Street need not immediately comply with a new rule banning banks from trading with their own money, sending sighs of relief across the financial industry. The guidance, delivered by the Federal Reserve and other agencies, explained that under the Dodd-Frank Act, banks have two years to fully comply with the Volcker Rule. While the law called for a two-year compliance period until 2014, the fine print left some room for interpretation. Banks were jittery about what would happen come July 21, Day One for the rule, fearing that they would have to scramble to comply before a final rule spelled out the nitty-gritty of their obligations. BEN PROTESS

Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about investor concerns arising from the French presidential election described incorrectly an economic proposal by the Socialist candidate, François Hollande. While he has proposed hiring 60,000 civil servants and teachers, he would do so by filling slots left open by retiring public employees; it would not be an expansion of the work force.

The case of the missing network viewers continued Wednesday night as more shows, including some of the biggest hits on television, recorded their lowest ratings of the year. That happened to ABC's ''Modern Family,'' considered the strongest comedy on television, which sank to a season-low 4 rating in the 18-to-49-year-old audience that drives most ad sales. The pattern continued with other ABC shows on the night. The comedy ''Suburgatory'' hit a low for that series, a 2 rating, and the much-talked about drama ''Revenge'' returned from a seven-week hiatus with its own season low, a 2.3 rating.

Beloved wife of Robert for 43 years, loving mother of Carrie Kurzon Schreckinger (Stephen), and Wendy Kurzon Cherwin (Matthew). Devoted grandmother of Milo, Oliver, Piper and Sawyer. Sister to Bruce Fischberg. Service private. Donations in her memory may be made to:https:// donations.melanoma.org.

9:13 p.m. | Updated Even with its reduced footprint on Main Street, Bank of America on Thursday reported better-than-expected operating results for the first quarter, helped by a revival on Wall Street and lower credit losses among consumers.

A play about a young, lost, broken-hearted antihero, with a knack for empathy but a little clueless about life's problems? Paging Jake Gyllenhaal! Mr. Gyllenhaal, who became a movie star for poignant performances in ''Donnie Darko'' and ''Brokeback Mountain,'' will make his American stage debut this summer in the Roundabout Theater Company production of ''If There Is I Haven't Found It Yet,'' a British play that turns on an overweight teenager's relationship to her drifter uncle (Mr. Gyllenhaal). Roundabout announced on Thursday that the play, written by Nick Payne (''Constellations'') and directed by Michael Longhurst, would begin performances Off Broadway on Aug. 24 at the Laura Pels Theater and run through Nov. 25. ''If There Is I Haven't Found It Yet'' had an acclaimed run at the Bush Theater in London in 2009; Mr. Payne and Mr. Longhurst, meanwhile, worked together this winter on Royal Court's production of ''Constellations.''

An article on Wednesday about the reluctant role of the United States in the corruption and murder scandal that has engulfed the Chinese government, misstated, in some editions, the name of the Beijing ministry from which an official had gone to an American consulate to collect another official who had knowledge of the scandal and had unsuccessfully sought asylum at the consulate. It is the Ministry of State Security, not public safety. The article also misstated, in some editions, the status of Gu Kailai, a principal in the scandal who has been tied to the murder of a British businessman, Neil Heywood. Ms. Gu is under investigation in Mr. Heywood's murder; she has not been charged.

JAVITCH--Lee. The Officers and Members of Old Oaks Country Club mourn the passing of dear friend and fellow member, Lee Javitch. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to his wife, Rona and his entire family. Geoffry Handler, President

Federal prosecutors in California are investigating whether a Goldman Sachs executive leaked confidential information about two publicly traded companies to Raj Rajaratnam, the convicted hedge fund manager. The previously undisclosed criminal inquiry emerged during a pretrial hearing on Thursday in the case of Rajat K. Gupta, the former Goldman director. Mr. Gupta is accused of telling Mr. Rajaratnam about secret boardroom discussions at Goldman and Procter & Gamble, where he also served on the board.

The field for the Democratic nomination in the newly redrawn Sixth Congressional District in Queens just became a little narrower. Jeffrey Gottlieb, a clerk for the city's Board of Elections and a longtime, if understated, behind-the-scenes fixture in Queens Democratic political circles, has withdrawn from the race, according to a person involved in the campaign who had not been authorized to speak about it publicly. The move came days after Mr. Gottlieb filed the signatures he had collected with the city to get on the ballot (a minimum of 938 valid signatures were required).

While the struggling starter Phil Hughes's role remained as vexing as ever for the Yankees, it was Curtis Granderson who ended up commanding the most attention Thursday night, smashing three home runs in a 7-6 victory over the Minnesota Twins. ''A lot of work went into today before we stepped on the field,'' said Granderson, who has struggled with his timing. ''I was struggling to get myself in a good position to be able to do things when I wanted to do it. That's what we worked on today.''

Even with a widening network of bike lanes, the city's streets can still be intimidating for children and other New Yorkers trying to bicycle for a wobbly first time. The cars are close and the trucks seem even closer, and other cyclists' hurrying to work can make tottering around the lane on training wheels feel like an imposition.

Elizabeth A. Sackler, the art collector and philanthropist, announced a major donation to the Brooklyn Museum at its Brooklyn Ball gala benefit on Wednesday evening, where she was an honoree. Ms. Sackler, whose gift created the Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art five years ago at the museum, announced a seven-figure donation to support the establishment of a permanent curator of feminist art for the institution. The gift, which comes from members of the Sackler family, will endow the salary and activities of the curator of the Sackler Center for Feminist Art indefinitely, a spokesman for the museum said. (The exact amount was not disclosed.) The position is currently held by Catherine J. Morris.

Cardozo School of Law are saddened by the passing of Renee Solow, M.D. a highly respected member of the Jewish community who practiced medicine as a specialist in radiology and mammography in private practice for several decades in Manhattan and had a passion for history and compassion for those who needed help. She was the beloved sister of Sheldon H. Solow, a Cardozo School of Law Board of Overseers member, who with his wife, Mia, is a Yeshiva University Benefactor, and cherished sister of Rosalie Wolff. May the entire Solow family be comforted. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor

Federal prosecutors in Manhattan asked a judge on Thursday to sentence former State Senator Carl Kruger of Brooklyn to at least nine years in prison for his conviction on corruption charges, saying he had ''systematically and wantonly betrayed the public trust by soliciting hundreds of thousands of dollars of bribes.'' Mr. Kruger, 62, resigned from the Senate in December and pleaded guilty to conspiracy to commit fraud and to commit bribery. He is to be sentenced next Thursday.

Gov. Mitch Daniels of Indiana endorsed Mitt Romney for president on Wednesday - then criticized him a day later in an interview with The Indianapolis Star. Mr. Daniels, a fiscal conservative who many Republicans had hoped would seek the presidency himself, seemed to chide Mr. Romney for not offering a more positive message to voters. (Mr. Romney has spent a lot of time on the campaign trail attacking President Obama, and his ''super PAC,'' Restore Our Future, has used its considerable resources to demolish primary rival after primary rival with negative ads.)

Survived by his wife of 50 years Barbara (Bobbie) Beck and his son Jedd Bellman. A tireless and conscientious attorney and fighter for civil rights. Worked for the US Commission on Civil Rights, NAACP legal staff and various other civil rights organizations. The funeral will be on April 20th at Plaza Jewish Chapel at 630 Amsterdam Ave., at 1pm. Contributions can be made to LatinoJustice PRLDEF, 99 Hudson St. 14th Floor, New York, NY 10013.

JAVITCH--Lee H. Born in 1931 in Carlisle, PA. Admired and loved by all that knew him. Dedicated husband and best friend for 38 years to Rona Javitch, proud father of Jonathan (Miriam), Lisa (Louis Benjamin), and David (Rikki), and loving grandfather of Sam, Shoshana, Yona and Jake. Former President and Chairman of Giant Food Stores, which he built to over 30 locations after it was founded by his father David as the Carlisle Meat Market in 1923. He served on the Boards of Trustees of the Pennsylvania Real Estate Investment Trust, the Board of Directors of Dauphin Deposit Bank and Allfirst Bank. A man of immeasurable generosity to many loyal friends, and a dedicated philanthropist for the community, he served on the Board of Directors of The Jewish Theological Seminary of America, and for the Boards of MAZON: A Jewish Response for Hunger, and Clal - The National Jewish Center for Learning and Leadership, for which he also served as Chair. Funeral service will be held today, April 20th at 11:30am at the Jewish Community Center of Harrison in Harrison, NY, with internment to follow at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY. Contributions may be made to MAZON or UJA to honor the memory of a man we will always cherish and never forget.

Contrary to the expectations of nearly every preseason prognosticator, the Phoenix Suns are battling for the final spot in the Western Conference playoffs. As usual, the Suns' ageless point guard, 38-year-old Steve Nash, is leading the way. Phoenix selected Nash with the 15th pick in the 1996 N.B.A. draft. But after only two seasons with the Suns, he was traded to the Dallas Mavericks, where he teamed with Dirk Nowitzki and Michael Finley to help turn the Mavericks franchise around.

A painting looted by the Nazis from its Jewish owner more than 70 years ago was returned to his heirs on Wednesday after being loaned to a Florida museum, Reuters reported. The painting, ''Christ Carrying the Cross Dragged by a Rogue,'' by the 16th-century Italian painter Girolamo Romano, was part of an exhibition on Baroque art that the Pinacoteca di Brera in Milan, Italy, had loaned to the Mary Brogan Museum of Art and Science in Tallahassee last fall.

In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts to either Fountain House, Inc. 425 W 47th Street, New York, NY 10036, or SPLIA, PO Box 148 Cold Spring Harbor, NY 11724, would be appreciated.

An obituary on Dec. 25, 2011, about the bandleader Pupi Campo misspelled the given name of one of his three daughters who survive him. She is Cathi Muckle, not Cathy. The error was pointed out in an e-mail from a reader on Wednesday.

Dartmouth College has selected Tod Williams Billie Tsien Architects to design a major expansion and renovation of its Hood Museum of Art, the college announced on Wednesday. The Hood's collection has increased to more than 70,000 works and the project, which will increase gallery space at the museum's 1985 building and add classrooms, new entrance areas and amenities, is part of Dartmouth's new Arts District. The district includes the Hopkins Center for the Arts and the new Black Family Visual Arts Center The financier Leon Black, an alumnus, and his wife, Debra, last month contributed $48 million for the center, which is scheduled to open in September. Dartmouth is also planning a renovation and expansion of the Hopkins Center and will select an architect in the coming year.

The City Room column on Monday, about high school students' participating in meditation sessions at the Brooklyn Zen Center, described the operation of the Awake Youth Project incorrectly and also misstated the way in which a student became involved with the center. The Awake Youth Project is a collaboration between the center and the Brooklyn College Community Partnership; it is not the Zen Center's program. And a student, La-keeyatta Steward, became affiliated with the center through an internship paid by the Brooklyn College Community Partnership; she was not assigned community service work there by a teacher at her high school.

Morgan Stanley's rebuilding efforts are starting to take hold, as it posted one of its strongest quarters since the financial crisis. The bank showed healthy gains in core areas like wealth management and equity sales. Bond trading - the great profit machine on Wall Street - also kicked into high gear. In all, first-quarter profit surged 27 percent to $1.4 billion, excluding one-time accounting charges.

TYNAN--William Francis III, born on January 25, 1934, died in peace on April 2, 2012 at home in Tequesta, FL, with his loving wife of 53 years, Judith Lynch, by his side. Bill graduated from Chaminade High School in 1951 and Georgetown University, Class of 1955, and attended Georgetown Law School. Upon graduation, he served his country honorably in the US Army during the Korean War. He joined his father's company, William F. Tynan Jr., Inc., in Garden City, NY, as an associate broker, becoming President after his father's death. Bill is mourned by his family and five children, and will be remembered as a devoted family man who possessed a sense of humor, dignity, and an abiding Roman Catholic faith. There will be a memorial Mass celebrated on April 25 at St. Joseph's Church in Garden City at 11:15am.

The story of a stuttering monarch called on to deliver a crucial announcement to his subjects at the onset of World War II would seem to be as dramatic as they come. And apparently selling a stage production of that tale to British theatergoers is no picnic either. The producers of a theatrical version of ''The King's Speech,'' which dramatizes the story of King George VI and his speech therapist, Lionel Logue, that transferred to London's West End last month announced that it would close early because of poor ticket sales, The Telegraph reported. As a film, ''The King's Speech'' was a regal success, winning four Academy Awards last year, including one for best picture; one for best actor to Colin Firth, who portrayed George VI; and one for its original screenplay by David Seidler. As a play, also written by Mr. Seidler and directed by Adrian Noble, it opened in February at the Yvonne Arnaud Theater in Guilford and transferred in March to the Wyndham's Theater in the West End. It received some respectable reviews there - Time Out London said that the actor Charles Edwards made an even better George VI, ''bringing a subtlety, understated wit and mercurial flair'' that Mr. Firth lacked - and was slated to run through July 21. But producers said it will now close May 12.

JAVITCH--Lee H. The Jewish Theological Seminary mourns the loss of Lee H. Javitch, prominent business executive and philanthropist, and a distinguished member of the JTS Board of Trustees from 1991 to 2009. Mr. Javitch's exuberance for life made him a generous and dedicated supporter of Conservative Judaism, community building, education, youth, and the arts. He had extensive experience in Jewish organizational life, and sat on the boards of numerous nonprofits. Mr. Javitch leaves a legacy at JTS that will be felt for decades to come. May his wife, Rona, three children, four grandchildren, and extended family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Arnold Eisen, Chancellor Abby Joseph Cohen, Board Chair

Over the last several decades, Martin J. Bienenstock has established himself as one of America's most prominent bankruptcy lawyers, advising General Motors and Enron. Now, he faces perhaps the most challenging assignment of his career: the restructuring of his own law firm. Mr. Bienenstock is one of the leaders of Dewey & LeBoeuf, the embattled law firm struggling to survive. A heavy debt load and a wave of lawyer defections - more than 20 percent of its partners have left this year - have imperiled the 1,000-lawyer firm.

An article on Friday about President Obama's opposition to the Keystone pipeline referred incorrectly to a new route through Nebraska that Trans Canada has proposed. Nebraska environmental officials say no final decision has been made on the route and whether it will cross the environmentally sensitive Ogallala Aquifer. It is not the case that a new route through the state will indeed avoid the aquifer.

Bob Dylan called his former collaborator Levon Helm ''one of the last true great spirits of my or any other generation'' in a note he posted online. Mr. Helm, former drummer and vocalist with the Band, which backed up Mr. Dylan in the 1960s, died of complications of cancer on Thursday at age 71. Of Mr. Helm, Mr. Dylan wrote: ''He was my bosom buddy friend to the end, one of the last true great spirits of my or any other generation. This is just so sad to talk about. I still can remember the first day I met him and the last day I saw him. We go back pretty far and had been through some trials together. I'm going to miss him, as I'm sure a whole lot of others will too.''
An Op-Ed article on April 12 about trees and the environment referred incorrectly to one of the greenhouse gases that are warming the planet. It is carbon dioxide, not carbon.

HARGRAVES--Gordon S. "Skip," died on April 19, 2012, peacefully at the age of 80. Survived by his deeply loved wife Margaret Magavern and their children Gordon S. Hargraves, Jr., Samuel M. Hargraves, Elizabeth Hargraves Mandy, Anna Hargaves Hall and six grandchildren. Attended Haverford School, Graduated from Exeter Academy ('49), Princeton University ('53) and Harvard Business School ('57). He served in the US Navy as an officer on a Destroyer from 1953-1955. His multifaceted career began in advertising, and after two decades with Manufacturers Hanover Trust, he joined The Cold Spring Harbor Biological Laboratory as Director of Planned Giving. A generous man full of warm spirit and great adventure, a wonderful sense of humor, and devoted to his family, he was also an active and dedicated member of the community, serving diligently on the Boards of St. John's Church, Huntington Hospital, St. Johnland Nursing Center, The Caumsett Foundation, The Whaling Museum, East Woods School, and The Masters School. As was noted when he was honored for Special Services to St. John's Church on the occasion of its 175th Anniversary in 2010, "He is someone who we deeply love and who also loves us." A memorial service will be held at the Cold Spring Harbor Beach Club at noon on Saturday, April 28th. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to St. John's Church in Cold Spring Harbor, The Caumsett Foundation, St. Johnlands Nursing Center, The Cold Spring Harbor Biological Laboratory, or The Maine Coast Heritage Trust (for the Black Island Preserve).

An article in some editions on Friday about the Yankees' 7-6 victory over the Minnesota Twins, in which Curtis Granderson hit three home runs, misstated, in some copies, the history of home-run feats by other Yankees players. Lou Gehrig hit four home runs in a game against the Philadelphia Athletics on June 3, 1932, at Shibe Park; it is not the case that no Yankee had ever hit four home runs in a game.

The lows and woes continued for network series on Thursday night, extending what has been a week filled with record-setting depths for a raft of shows. ''American Idol,'' the perennial ratings leader, matched what has been its worst-ever rating - for its results show - among the 18-to-49-year-old viewers who account for most of the show's ad sales. ''Idol'' dropped to a 3.9 rating, which still ranks as easily the best on the night - it's just the worst ''Idol'' has ever done.

Roughly one of every five Americans used their mobile phone for some sort of banking activity last year, and about the same proportion say they will probably use mobile banking in the future, a recent survey from the Federal Reserve found. But many consumers still don't see the need for mobile banking, and many also are skeptical of the level of security around banking with their phone, the survey found. Among users of mobile phones who haven't yet adopted mobile banking, about half said they were ''concerned'' about security, the survey found.

An obituary on Thursday about the television host and producer Dick Clark, using information from a spokesman, misstated the number of grandchildren who survive him. It is three, not two. The obituary also misstated Mr. Clark's role in the first New Year's Eve telecast he produced. He was the producer only, not the producer and host. And it misstated, in some editions, the year of that telecast. It was 1972, not 1973.

LONDON - The West End area is getting a new theater, its first in 30 years. London's local government granted permission late Thursday for the construction of a 34,000-square-foot theater, which is to feature a glass facade and seat about 350 people. The building is being designed by the architectural firm Allford Hall Monaghan Morris, which also worked on the design of the Saatchi Gallery and the Barbican in London.

An article on Friday about the decision by Jeffrey Gottlieb, a clerk for the New York City Board of Elections, to drop out of the race for the Democratic nomination for the newly redrawn Sixth Congressional District in Queens misidentified, in some editions, the political office currently held by Grace Meng, who is running for the seat. She is a state assemblywoman, not a city councilwoman.

Consumer advocates are urging the federal government to crack down on so-called ''yo-yo'' automobile financing. That's when a buyer is allowed to leave the sales lot with a car even though the sale isn't technically final, only to be called back to the dealership days later and pressured to sign a new financing agreement with less favorable terms. This type of financing abuse was described in testimony submitted to the Federal Trade Commission in February by the Center for Responsible Lending, a nonprofit group, and several other consumer groups. The F.T.C. has held a series of public roundtables called ''The Road Ahead,'' to gather information on auto financing practices.

Even audiences familiar with Yasmina Reza's comedy ''God of Carnage,'' and the way it reduces its four adult characters to squabbling children over the course of roughly 90 minutes, might raise an eyebrow at a production of the play that will open in Boston next month. When this ''God of Carnage'' is performed at the Bulger Performing Arts Center by the Boston Teen Acting Troupe, it will star four teenagers, whose only real-life experience with parental discipline comes from being on the receiving end of it.

A report in the ''Arts, Briefly,'' column on Friday about casting for the Classic Stage Company's planned revival of ''Passion,'' by Stephen Sondheim and James Lapine, referred incorrectly to the production. Dicapo Opera presented the musical in New York in 2003; the Classic Stage Company's production will not be the first full revival in the city since the show won the 1994 Tony Award for best musical.

10 P.M. (Cinemax) THE TREE OF LIFE (2011) Jack O'Brien (Sean Penn), a middle-aged architect haunted by the death of his younger brother many years earlier in 1950s Texas, tries to reconcile his complicated relationship with his father (Brad Pitt, above, with Laramie Eppler) while contemplating human existence -- the origin of the universe, the development of life on earth, the end of time -- in this drama from Terrence Malick. Jessica Chastain plays Jack's mother, whose grief, and that of her husband's, over the loss of their son casts a shadow of tragedy on everything that will follow. And Hunter McCracken, a first-time actor, is Jack as a boy. ''The sheer beauty of this film is almost overwhelming,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times, ''but as with other works of religiously minded art, its aesthetic glories are tethered to a humble and exalted purpose, which is to shine the light of the sacred on secular reality.'' The movie, which won the Palme d'Or at the Cannes Film Festival, received Oscar nominations for best picture, best director and best cinematography, for Emmanuel Lubezki. 10:30 A.M. The sentencing of an ex-business manager who was convicted last week of harassing Leonard Cohen brought no cries of hallelujah from the singer-songwriter, who said he hoped the ''one-time friend'' would devote herself ''to the lowly practices of self-reform,'' The Guardian reported. Kelley Lynch, a former manager whom Mr. Cohen cut ties with in 2004, was convicted in a Los Angeles court of two counts of leaving or sending harassing or obscene messages and five counts of violating a restraining order. In recent years Ms. Lynch had sent Mr. Cohen hundreds of e-mails and voice messages, including some that made threats against the singer's family and said he ''needed to be taken down and shot.'' She was sentenced to 18 months in prison. Earlier, in 2006, a court ruled that she must pay back $9.5 million she stole from Mr. Cohen.

HARGRAVES--Gordon S. The Board of Directors of St. Johnland Nursing Center mourns the death of Gordon Hargraves. Skip came on the Board in 2000 and served on many committees. In 2005 he joined the Executive Committee as Vice President and served as President since 2006. His outstanding leadership during a period of institutional growth and challenging economic times will be long remembered. His uplifting spirit and positive attitude were an inspiration to us all.

GLASS--Walter H. Walter H. Glass, 91, died peacefully April 15, 2012, in Sleepy Hollow, NY. Born Vienna, Austria on February 13, 1921. Fled Nazis to US in 1939, encouraged in Austria by the Society of Friends (Quakers). B.A. Economics, University of Texas at Austin, summa cum laude, Phi Beta Kappa '42. Trained in intelligence, Camp Ritchie. Served Europe, Army Supreme Headquarters Allied Expeditionary Force. Harvard Law, JD '47; hired by Securities and Exchange Commission. Married Ann Murkland '49. Coal reorganization of post-war Germany with State Department (HICOG) until joining General Electric in 1953 where he specialized in international contracts and traveled the world (with stint at Raytheon '59-'63) until retirement 1986. Active in Stamford-Greenwich Friends Meeting, and at Kendal on Hudson. Said his life's lessons were two principles: work hard, and be nice to people. He lived it and he passed it on. Survived by wife, Ann Glass, 87, of Sleepy Hollow, NY; children Martha Sullivan of New York, NY; Elizabeth Poyet of Larchmont, NY; Adam Glass of Washington, DC; Daniel Glass of Fairfield, CT, and eight grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at Kendal on Hudson in Sleepy Hollow, New York at 2:00pm, Saturday, April 28, 2012. In lieu of flowers, gifts in memory may be made to the Walter H. Glass Endowment, Harvard University, Attn: Anne Funderburk, 124 Mt. Auburn St. Cambridge, MA 02138, checks payable to President and Fellows of Harvard College. It was Walter's wish to aid immigrant students facing financial hardship, inspired by the help he received.

The St. Louis Cardinals would not have won last year's World Series without Chris Carpenter, who beat Texas in Games 1 and 7. So when the team president, Bill DeWitt III, worked with Jostens to design the championship rings, he made sure to consult Carpenter on his most unorthodox idea. ''I asked Carp, 'What do you think about putting the squirrel on the ring?' '' DeWitt said. ''He was like, 'I don't know, yes, no,' - he was wavering. And I said, 'What if it's subtle, and you can't see it unless you look really hard?' He said that was a good idea. So I got his approval, which was comforting.''

The Swedish photographer Christer Stromholm was concerned with freedom in all of its permutations. That concern led him in the 1960s to Paris, where he photographed young transgender men trying to live as women. And the result was ''Les Amies de Place Blanche,'' opening May 18 at the International Center of Photography. Above, ''Pepita, 1963'' (icp.org).

WUNDER--Frances Parsons, passed away peacefully on April 20, 2012 at the age of 98, predeceased in 1999 by George William Wunder, her beloved husband of 60 years. Fran was born in Salt Lake City, Utah, and was an independent woman from the start. She attended Stanford University before returning home to assist her family during the Great Depression and graduated Phi Beta Kappa from the University of Utah in 1935. Fran was a long-time member of the Junior League in Cincinnati, Ohio and Port Washington, New York. She co-founded the Children's Theater associated with the North Shore Junior League. Fran was also a member and past president of the Manhasset Chapter of PEO. She was a dedicated member of St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in Port Washington, New York and served on its altar guild for many years. Frances possessed a pioneering spirit and a zest for life that will be greatly missed and fondly remembered by all who knew her. Frances is survived by her three children and their families including four grandchildren and four-great grandchildren. A memorial visitation will be held Wednesday 7-9pm at Austin F. Knowles, Inc Funeral Home, 128 Main Street, Port Washington, New York 11050. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory to St. Stephen's Episcopal Church, 9 Carlton Avenue, Port Washington, NY 11050 would be greatly appreciated.

GERNERT--Herbert E.,86, of Basking Ridge, formerly of New Vernon, NJ, died on April 16 after a brief illness. He was a son of the late Herbert and Judith Cattell Gernert and the brother of the late Archibald Gernert. A World War II veteran, he was a meteorologist who served on the USS Grand Rapids in the North Atlantic. Herb attended Wesleyan, graduated from Princeton, and received his MBA from NYU. He had a long career as an investment manager at Brown Brothers Harriman, Cyrus J. Lawrence, Inc. and Vilas-Fischer Associates prior to founding his own management and consulting firm. In his later years, he chaired the investment committees of several charitable organizations. Herb was also an adjunct professor at Fairleigh Dickinson University and a lecturer for the American Management Association. Hewas a former president of the Harding Township Board of Education and served both asa deacon and an elder of The First Presbyterian Church of New Vernon. He is survived by his wife of nearly 60 years, Sally, his daughter, Lynn, his son, David, his daughters-in-law, Susan and Nancy, and his grandchildren, Annalie, Jack, Luke, Eli and Hope. Donations to The Seeing Eye, PO Box 375, Morristown, NJ 07963 (www.seeing eye.org) would be welcomed.

HARGRAVES--Gordon S. The Board of The Caumsett Foundation mourns the passing of our highly valued friend, advisor and Vice President Gordon S. (Skip) Hargraves. He loved the Foundation Board, contributed powerfully in many ways, and never let his illness reduce his commitment or involvement. We will never forget the joy that Skip brought to the faces of the young (and not so young) year after year as Mr. Bunny. He was a wonderful man with a big heart. We will remember him with fondness and respect for all he accomplished, and we will miss him. Thomas J. Calabrese, Chairman Henry D. Babcock, President
