FLYNN--James K. (Jim), passed away of cardiac arrest, at home at the age of 63. Jim was born on September 16, 1948 and was welcomed into heaven by his parents, Daniel and Catherine Flynn on April 20, 2012. Jim supported and was an active alumni of Manhattan College. His serviced with the U.S. army which shorten as a result of injuries. As a disabled Veteran, Jim was co-owner of the popular Pinewood Bar and took over the family business, The FergusII Catering after the death of his father, both long standing establishments in Riverdale. After a long career in the Financial community which included positions with Bankers Trust, O'Neill & Feldman, LFRothschild & Company and finally Ameriprise. Jim then retired to his beach home at the Jersey Shore which was a "home away from home" for many of his friends and family. He will be deeply missed by his loving siblings Maureen Harrington, Donald Flynn (Alanna) Joan Nevin (Thomas), Kathleen Kelleher-Sheridan (Paul), and his Twin brother John (Christine). He will also be greatly missed by his 13 nieces, nephews and their families. Jim was a great history buff, loved the beauty of the New Jersey Shore, helping others and most of all his friends and family. Visiting hours will be held at the Riverdale-on-Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Avenue, Bronx, New York on Tuesday, April 24, 7:00 to 9:00pm; Wednesday, April 25, 2:00-5:00pm and 7:00-9:00pm. A mass of Christian burial will take place on Thursday, April 26 at 9:45am at Saint Margaret of Cortona in Bronx, NY followed by interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. In lieu of floral remembrances, donations can be made to the KIND Foundation, 4880 Donald Ross Road, Suite 110, Palm Beach Gardens, Florida 33418. This charity assists children with learning disabilities and is already being supported by our families.

HELD--Huyler C. We mourn the passing of long-time Fountain House Board Member, Huyler C. Held. Mr. Held was elected to the Board in 1960 and, until his death, faithfully served in many capacities, including as President of the Board. He was a tireless advocate for those living with mental illness and a wise and caring Trustee of our organization. With the growth of the Fountain House community throughout his tenure as Trustee, he provided guidance and leadership in addressing the challenges confronting the Board and the needs of the Fountain House members. His commitment and clarity of vision were matched by his considerable wit, grace, and warmth. The Fountain House community will miss him greatly, but his immeasurable contributions will be a lasting gift to us all. Lorna Hyde Graev Board Chair, Fountain House Kenneth Dudek President, Fountain House

Jon Dore:Obtuse jokes shot through with wry menace. ''Orphans have more time to practice driving, because they're not being loved by anyone.'' Dave Attell: Material so funny you suspect it can magically heal minor cuts and burns. ''I don't have a girlfriend, but sometimes I like to pretend I do. I just stand in my apartment screaming, 'No, that's not what I said!' ''

THE Broadway season, in a sense, screeches to a halt this week, as the deadline for Tony consideration arrives. (Nominations will be announced May 1.) The end has come unusually early, causing a dizzying pileup of seven opening nights in a single week. The roster gives an accurate if not always inspiring snapshot of the current state of commercial theater. From the Broadway Screening Room category come two new musicals: ''GHOST,'' a London import based on the 1990 hit movie, and ''LEAP OF FAITH,'' after the (nonhit) Steve Martin movie about an evangelist, with Raúl Esparza in the lead. ''THE LYONS,'' a Nicky Silver play starring Linda Lavin, represents the Questionable Off Broadway Transfer. From the High-Concept Revival department comes ''STREETCAR NAMED DESIRE,'' starring Blair Underwood, which features a multi-ethnic cast with an emphasis on black actors. The Nostalgia Repackaged entry is a pseudo new musical, ''NICE WORK IF YOU CAN GET IT,'' featuring Matthew Broderick and Kelli O'Hara singing Gershwin tunes. ''DON'T DRESS FOR DINNER,'' a farce by Marc Camoletti (''Boeing-Boeing''), is an example of the If-It-Worked-Once approach to producing.

A picture credit last Sunday with an article about Damian Lopez Alfonso, the Cuban bicycle racer who lost both arms in a childhood accident and who will compete in the 2012 Paralympic Games, misspelled the surname of the photographer. Pat Benson (not Banson) took the picture of Mr. Alfonso.

ARONSON--Bernard, passed away on April 9, 2012 at the age of 97. He died at his home in Boca Raton, Florida, surrounded by his wife, Mitzi, and his children Judith and Stephen. Berni and Mitzi had been married for 70 years. The family held a very touching bedside service with some loving friends. Berni had been one of the oldest surviving Huntington residents and WWII Veterans, having served four years in England from 1941 through 1945. He was a Huntington High School Graduate, playing quarterback on the football team, "The Blue Devils" before graduating in 1932, and attended CW Post. He was a loving husband and father, grandfather, great-grandfather and uncle to the entire Aronson family. Mr. Aronson was the last surviving sibling of the family and was part of the backbone of the Huntington community in the early part of the 1900's. The Aronson nieces and nephews and their children also survive him.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''N.H.L. Suspends Rangers' Hagelin Three Games for Elbowing Alfredsson,'' April 16: The N.H.L.'s decision to suspend Carl Hagelin highlights the inconsistencies in the league's disciplinary decisions.

EMOUS--Nancy Smith, of Monteagle, TN passed away April 20th after a brief illness. She was 81. She grew up in Riverside and Greenwich, CT. She worked for years at J. Walter Thompson in New York City. She married Bram Emous. She later divorced and moved back to Greenwich where she ran a successful home based business until retirement. After a stroke she moved to the Chattanooga area near her son. Nancy is preceded in death by her mother Virginia Francis Cutter Cooke. She is survived by brother Charles C. Smith and son Jan Derek Emous.

HERZOG--Dorothy, died peacefully on April 21st in Pompano Beach, Florida. Born in Brooklyn, New York, she was the daughter of Louis and Fanny Katz. She is predeceased by her daughter Laura, and her husband Seymour Herzog. Dorothy was a vivacious magnetic personality who enjoyed her retail career in New York. Her memory will always be cherished by her family. She is survived by son Arthur Rubinstein and partner Tom Condon, son David Rubinstein and wife Pegeen, grandson Eric Rubinstein and wife Lauren Brinkley-Rubinstein, grandson Matthew Rubinstein, and great-grandson Xavier Rubinstein. Burial will be private.

An article last Sunday about steep population growth in Nigeria and elsewhere in sub-Saharan Africa described Nigeria's geographical size incorrectly in comparing it to a less densely populated area of the United States. Nigeria, measuring about 357,00 square miles, is about 35 percent larger than Arizona and New Mexico combined, not ''roughly the size of'' the states combined.

GOODMAN--Georgine Rake, 87, died April 7 in her home in New York City after an extended illness. She was the widow of the late Maurice Goodman, Jr. Born in Toledo, Ohio on November 16, 1924, she was the beloved daughter of Henry and Myrtle (Alecksen) Rake, and the sister of Gloria Rake Karstaedt. After attending the University of Wisconsin and the Kenneth Sawyer Goodman School of the Theater in Chicago, she moved to New York City to pursue a career in theater and fashion. She was an Associate Fashion Editor at Glamour Magazine, and then Editor of the Children's Fashion Section of the New York Times Sunday Supplement. On June 7, 1952, she married Maurice Goodman, Jr.; they shared fifty-six years of marriage. The couple was an enthusiastic and dedicated patron of the theatre and ballet over their lifetime. Always personally involved in the arts, Mrs. Goodman served as a docent at the Metropolitan Museum of Art for 12 years, and her photographs and watercolors won numerous awards. She was the loving mother of Prudence G. Meyer, Susannah E. Rake, and John R. Goodman, and the grandmother of Laura A. Simson, Georgina. E. Simson, and Annabelle R. Butash. A memorial service to celebrate her life will be held later in the year. Contributions in her honor to Planned Parenthood and the Alzheimer's Association will be most appreciated.

LAX--Philip. The Ellis Island Restoration Commission mourns the passing of our President Philip Lax and extend sympathy to his family. Norman Liss, Chairman of Development Hon. Jacqueline A. Beusse, VP Dr. August Bolino, VP Hon. Set Charles Momjian, VP Hon. Howard Slotnick, Treasurer

A 13-room Park Avenue co-op that sold for $12.6 millionwas the biggest sale of theweek, according to cityrecords.The transaction at 941Park is a reminder of thecontinuing allure of OldWorld properties at classicaddresses, even asflashier new condominiumsdowntown and on theWest Side hit recordprices week after week.At the time 941 Park Avenuewas built, in 1928, itrepresented the height ofopulence. In terms ofspace and details, it canhold its own against manyof the newer offeringsaround the city.''A private elevatorvestibule opens to astately 28-foot-long foyerleading to a magnificentlyproportioned livingroom with a wood-burning fireplace,'' the listingread. ''Currently, the master bedroom suite iscombined with the adjacent bedroom and isused as a custom-fitted dressing room.''The owners of the apartment, Morad Ghadamian,a carpet importer, and his wife, Sima,sought $12.9 million when they listed their fivebedroomhome, a duplex on the seventh andeighth floors.The buyers were Lance Rosen, a hedge fundmanager, and his wife, Diane, according to cityrecords.Dolly Lenz, a top broker at Prudential DouglasElliman, handled the sale. She said theRosens had considered good karma an important element in the sale.Sellers and buyers met andliked each other, whichhelped to seal the deal.''They saw the happinessin the family that was selling,''Ms. Lenz said. ''Andthey only wanted to buysomething where therewas not a negative story attached,like a divorce orsomething.''In the past, 941 Park hasattracted some of the city'swealthiest and most influentialpeople, including theNBC News anchor TomBrokaw and the GoldmanSachs chief executiveLloyd C. Blankfein, both ofwhom recently sold theirhomes in the building.Meanwhile, althoughthe $12.6 million deal wasthe week's largest sale ofan apartment to a newowner, another transactiontopped it.Clementina S. Flaherty, an author, who recentlywent through a high-profile divorce fromWilliam Flaherty, a zinc magnate, secured controlof the couple's duplex apartment at 1040Fifth Avenue for $13 million.Considering that the two, when still togetherin 2008, had briefly listed the 10-room apartmentin the Rosario Candela building for $43million, it seems that Ms. Flaherty's $13 millioninvestment could be worth her while, shouldshe decide to move on.Big Deal includes closed sales from the previousweek, ending Wednesday.MARC SANTORA

Jed Hoyer won two World Series, each with a very different meaning, as an assistant under Theo Epstein for the Boston Red Sox. The 2004 title signified the completion of a job that started before they arrived. The 2007 title fulfilled a new vision. Now Hoyer is trying again as the general manager of the Chicago Cubs, with Epstein as the team president and Jason McLeod, the former Boston scouting director, as a top assistant. If they win a championship, it will very likely have more in common with the 2007 Red Sox than the 2004 version. These Cubs have few long-term answers in place.

March 14, Cucao Beach, Island of Chiloé, Chile For me, traveling is a social experience of exploring untouched natural places. It's a way to enrich the spirit. After a drive bordering the immense and beautiful Huillinco Lake, we arrived at the isolated beach of Cucao on the Pacific. With the strong sound of breaking waves, I felt the power of nature. I felt free and at the same time, insignificant, in the vast and endless beach. After a while, my husband, son and I walked to one another, took hold of one another's hands and silently walked to the horizon. My sister was there and at that precise moment shot the picture. With its year-round green landscape and hills and strong folklore, it was the perfect destination to show my American husband the south of Chile, my native country. ISABEL MARGARITA LONG, Arlington, Va.

HARGRAVES--Gordon S. "Skip," died on April 19, 2012, peacefully at the age of 80. Survived by his deeply loved wife Margaret Magavern and their children Gordon S. Hargraves, Jr., Samuel M. Hargraves, Elizabeth Hargraves Mandy, Anna Hargaves Hall and six grandchildren. Attended Haverford School, Graduated from Exeter Academy ('49), Princeton University ('53) and Harvard Business School ('57). He served in the US Navy as an officer on a Destroyer from 1953-1955. His multifaceted career began in advertising, and after two decades with Manufacturers Hanover Trust, he joined The Cold Spring Harbor Biological Laboratory as Director of Planned Giving. A generous man full of warm spirit and great adventure, a wonderful sense of humor, and devoted to his family, he was also an active and dedicated member of the community, serving diligently on the Boards of St. John's Church, Huntington Hospital, St. Johnland Nursing Center, The Caumsett Foundation, The Whaling Museum, East Woods School, and The Masters School. As was noted when he was honored for Special Services to St. John's Church on the occasion of its 175th Anniversary in 2010, "He is someone who we deeply love and who also loves us." A memorial service will be held at the Cold Spring Harbor Beach Club at noon on Saturday, April 28th. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to St. John's Church in Cold Spring Harbor, The Caumsett Foundation, St. Johnlands Nursing Center, The Cold Spring Harbor Biological Laboratory, or The Maine Coast Heritage Trust (for the Black Island Preserve).

HELD in abandoned lofts and obscure malls in Chinatown, fought by male models and veteran Marines, publicized through spur-of-the-moment phone calls and digital word of mouth, the illegal boxing matches that Devin Yalkin has photographed for more than a year are unsanctioned underground events. ''One of them took place in this weird Chinese restaurant,'' Mr. Yalkin, 30, recalled. ''They got rid of all the chairs and tables, and just before the fight started, totally impromptu, that's when they tied the knots in the ropes to make a ring.''

CURKIN--Alvin, of Boca Raton, FL formerly of Tenafly and Fort Lee, NJ on April 18, 2012. Beloved husband of Deborah (nee Leibson) Father of Charlie and Stephen Curkin, Ronald Bernstein (Robyn), Francine Farber (Richard) and Barry Bernstein (Helen). Dear Brother of Faith Posin. Loving grandfather of Zephen, Xenia, Carly, Kyle, Brandon and Jake. Alvin was a Navy veteran of WWII and Korea. He ran the Galler 7-Up Bottling Co. in Hackensack, NJ for many years before retiring and also served as Board Chairman of the Y.M.H.A. in Hackensack, NJ and was Board Chairman of Hackensack University Medical Center 1980-83. Services will be held at Gutterman and Musicant Jewish Funeral Directors, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ on Sunday, April 22, 2012 at Noon. Should Friends desire, contributions may be made to Hackensack University Medical Center.

FINK--Hank. The Board of Governors and members of Rockrimmon Country Club are profoundly saddened by the passing of their long-time beloved friend and esteemed member. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. Jimmy Koplik, Vice President

When a pitcher throws 10 shutout innings, as the Phillies' Cliff Lee did on Wednesday in San Francisco, it evokes memories of Jack Morris, who did it for Minnesota in Game 7 of the 1991 World Series. To illustrate how much the game has changed, consider that in the 21 seasons since Morris's gem, only eight pitchers have thrown 10 shutout innings in a game. In the 21 seasons before Morris's game, it happened 138 times - including six by the Hall of Famer Bert Blyleven.

Because of an editing error, a picture caption last Sunday with an article about an agreement between Iran and six world powers to hold a new round of talks in Baghdad next month on Tehran's disputed nuclear program reversed the names of the two men shown in the foreground of a group of officials. Ahmet Davutoglu, the Turkish foreign minister, is at the right and Saeed Jalili, Iran's chief negotiator, is second from right.

An analysis of how Vallejo is received by the Chilean media and her supporters, including a discussion of her looks, could be relevant and quite interesting. Using a headline, however, that called her the ''World's Most Glamorous Revolutionary'' and peppering the article with anecdotes about how people are ''always debating who is more beautiful'' (Vallejo or a Communist Youth leader) and how she was seen ''languorously kissing her boyfriend'' obscures Francisco Goldman's point -- which is presumably to cover the movement and Vallejo's role in it -- and is also just straight-up sexist.

THE latest must-have item from Cartier comes from the company's new Juste un Clou (''Just a Nail'') collection. A reinterpretation of a bracelet that Aldo Cipullo designed for the house in 1971, the 18-karat yellow gold bangle makes its debut in connection with the opening of ''Cartier & Aldo Cipullo, New York City in the '70s,'' an exhibition of archival images at the company's Fifth Avenue flagship (through May 8). Featuring a discreet center hinge, the bracelet isn't the only bent-nail piece in the collection -- items come in white and rose gold, with and without diamond embellishments, too -- but it is the heftiest, which is always a plus when shopping for things like hardware -- and gold. Hit it! It is $34,650 at select Cartier boutiques; (212) 753-0111. EDWARD BARSAMIAN
The Leadership in Mexico Directing the Investigation

An article on Page 56 this weekend about the use of psychedelic drugs as part of the treatment for patients with terminal diseases misspells, in two instances, the surname of a cancer patient who was given one of them, psylocybin. As the article correctly notes elsewhere, she was Pam Sakuda, not Saduka.

MERCURIO--Peter Lombard, Passed away surrounded by his partner of 35 years, Stephan Hermann Worobel, family, and loved ones, on April, 12, 2012 in Connecticut. Generous Peter shared his passion for dance, music, entertaining, and literature with a wonderful circle of close friends. We all will miss his elegance, humor, kindness, and keen intelligence. For twenty-five years, owning his shop, Peter Hermann Leather Goods in SoHo, afforded him the opportunity to travel often to his favorite cities, Paris and Milan. He will be remembered by many loyal customers for his unique merchandising style and his welcoming smile. Originally from Rochester, NY, Peter has a loving extended family there. He and Stephan have homes in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn and Washington, CT, where they loved to cycle through the countryside. In lieu of flowers, Peter wished that donations be sent to the American Ballet Theater in New York City.

ELIZABETH MORRIS, frontwoman of the indie-pop band ALLO DARLIN', is capable of an exquisite melancholy. That's clear from ''Tallulah,'' the most striking song from this band's just-released second album, ''Europe'' (Slumberland). With a ukulele providing most of the spare backdrop, she details a love both tender and evanescent. ''I'm wondering if I've already heard/all the songs that'll mean something,'' she exhales, ''and I'm wondering if I've already met/all the people that'll mean something.'' That's not to say that all of ''Europe'' strikes such aching notes, but even the most animated songs on this album have a wistfulness coursing through them, whether they're talking about singers of riot grrrl bands, wearing your grandparents' clothes, or the mundanities of falling for someone else. Most of this is balanced with chipper arrangements, and as a result Allo Darlin' shows can be high-spirited affairs. But when the band plays its album release show at the Mercury Lounge this week, listen for the wounds between the cheers. 10:30 p.m. Tuesday, 217 East Houston Street, at Ludlow Street, Lower East Side, (212) 260-4700, mercuryloungenyc.com; $10 advance, $12 day of show.
A report last Sunday about the marriage of Elizabeth Chuck and Lucien Noel Jr. misstated the bride's age. She is 29, not 28.

To the Sports Editor, ''Pacers Thriving on Court, Not at Gate'' (April 15) states that the reason that the Indiana Pacers are struggling with attendance is that they lack a superstar. Actually, it is great that they do not have a superstar to be the face of the team. This gives everyone an opportunity to play and contribute. Watching players work effectively together is better than watching one superstar carry the team on his back.

CONDON--Joseph H. Ph. D, An experimental physicist, engineer, and computer scientist, died on January 2, 2012 at the age of 76. He, in partnership with Ken Thompson, created Belle, a pioneering combination of computer and special hardware that played championship-quality chess. Joseph was born in Princeton, NJ on February 15, 1935, to Emilie Honzik Condon and the noted theoretical physicist, Edward Uhler (E. U.) Condon, and was named after the 19th century American physicist, Joseph Henry. Joe earned a B.S. in physics from Johns Hopkins University and a Ph.D. in physics from Northwestern University. He and his wife of 51 years, Carol (nee Merklinger) Condon, Ph.D., have resided in Summit, NJ since 1963, when Joseph joined AT&T Bell Laboratories at Murray Hill, NJ. Joseph started his research career at Bell Labs in low temperature solid-state physics. His initial research centered on developing an ultra-sensitive torsion balance to study the electronic band structure of metals. His seminal research on the low temperature behavior of pure metals showed that, under certain conditions, magnetic domains can form in nonmagnetic metals such as beryllium. He developed a theory of such domains and obtained experimental verification of his theory. He had wide ranging interests, and it was difficult to remain focused on low temperature solid-state physics when a digital revolution was in progress. In 1968 he contributed to the emerging technologies of digital switching and produced many patents in that area. By 1975 Joe had joined the Computer Research Center at Bell Labs where, around the same time, the C programming language and the Unix operating system were created. Joe collaborated with Sandy Fraser to automate the laborious and error-prone task of manually converting a circuit drawing into a circuit board by designing the Unix Circuit Design System (UCDS). This system launched an era of rapid prototype construction for research and product development. The purpose of another of Joe's projects was to convince AT&T's development organizations to adopt the C programming language for their switching system control programs. To this end, it was decided that C should be used to reprogram an existing switch. Joe made the necessary hardware changes and Ken Thompson wrote the necessary software programs so that the re-write in C was a success and hastened the adoption of C for all switching system's software within AT&T. Another major collaboration between Joe and Ken Thompson was the creation of the chess-playing machine named Belle. Joe designed custom hardware while Ken designed the software. The hardware evaluated board position, did piece move generation, and used a cache memory for previously evaluated board positions. Belle's hardware could evaluate millions of board positions and generate all legal chess moves every second. The control software kept track of how many moves ahead the hardware was evaluating and selected the best current move. Belle achieved a master rating. It won the World Computer Chess Championship in 1980 and the ACM North American Computer Chess Championships in 1978, 1980, 1981, 1982, and 1986. Joseph was a physicist and engineer noted for his insight and intuition into physical systems and for talented digital system design. His designs were parsimonious and supremely effective, yet his collaborations were generous and never compromised by ego. Joe had a delightful sense of humor and unlimited curiosity. He loved to travel with Carol in their recreational vehicle and loved American Indian crafts, classical music, and the theatre. He was very active in The Religious Society of Friends (Quakers) and was a frequent volunteer in the FISH Hospitality Program. In addition to his beloved wife, Carol, Dr. Condon is survived by a brother, Paul Edward Condon, Ph.D., of Lafayette, CO, and was predeceased by a sister, Marie Condon Thornton of Berkeley, CA. Other survivors include a sister-in-law and husband, many nieces, nephews, great-nieces, and great-nephews. A memorial service will be held at 2pm on Saturday, April 28 at the Plainfield Meeting House of The Religious Society of Friends, 225 Watchung Ave., Plainfield, NJ 07060. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions in memory of Joseph to the above-listed Meeting, or to the FISH Hospitality Program, Inc., P.O. Box 170, Dunellen, NJ 08812, or to a charity of your choice.

CONNELL--Robert A. "Bob": 72, died on April 17. Bob was an avid sailor who participated in five America's Cup trials. He was the devoted husband of Pamela; father of Brooke and Tacy; stepfather of David Dunn and the late Bradford Dunn; and brother to Andy Connell and Susan Murphy. Donations in Bob's memory can be made to US Sailing: 15 Maritime Drive, Portsmouth, RI 02871.

HELD--Huyler C. The Partners, Associates and Staff of McLaughlin & Stern LLP record with great sorrow the passing of our Partner, mentor and friend Huyler C. Held. Until his final day he was a wonderfully unique and compelling force in the legal and philanthropic circles of New York, and we shall miss him greatly.

What's Hot: Skin brighteners like Clinique's Even Better Clinical Dark Spot Corrector. Where to Get It: The beauty department at Bloomingdale's.

Last week, cherry blossoms were falling all over the city, and children chased them in the same way they chase snowflakes. The most spectacular drifts of this pink snow were to be seen along Park Avenue, where cherry trees line the center island, and speeding cars cause the petals to swirl and dance. On the fashion scene, there's a new interest in the carryall bag. Various versions have been around for a decade, bottom left, but now some of the most sought-after are from the Paris house Céline, right. Devoid of hardware, they rely on the simplicity of design and craftsmanship. Another status carryall, left, is marked with a Y for Yves Saint Laurent. The large bag dripping in fringe, below, is back; this time, it has nothing to do with the hippie era.

ROSENTHAL--Jerome, 89, of Rockville Centre died April 19. Proudly served in "bloomin" Navy in WWII. Married to Hobart College sweetheart Bernice for 63 wonderful, love-filled years. Active Hofstra PEIR participant for the last 20 years. Besides devoted wife, leaves children Cindy and Randy Heller, Margie Rosenthal and Seth Hanft, and grandchildren Marissa, Tyler, Noah. Jerry loved his family and life and was the happiest man around. Services: Gutterman's, 175 N. Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre, on April 22, 1pm. Donation suggestions: Congregation B'nai Sholom, Rockville Centre or American Cancer Society.

JUSSARA LEE recently opened a boutique in the West Village that carries a small inventory of custom-made staples: suits for both men and women, cotton button-downs, sheath dresses and even bridalwear. ''It's our clothing's proportions that differentiate us,'' said Ms. Lee, who is known as a fashion purist with a knack for structured, clean, sharp lines. She also offers off-the-rack items like Welsh knitted cashmere sweaters ($900), Victorian French lace blousons ($500), cummerbund-inspired miniskirts ($750) and ladylike handbags by Holly Caldwell ($795). One can rely on a sprinkling of new desirables every couple of weeks. But for the utmost in personalized treatment, Ms. Lee suggested making an appointment. ''If Michelle Obama calls, I could make an exception and do a home call,'' she said with a laugh. ''I would be on the first Acela train to D.C.'' For the rest of us, Jussara Lee's shop is worth the trip on the A, C or E lines. 60 Bedford Street (Morton Street); (212) 242-4128.

The closest that many travelers get to a luxury hotel is by looking at an ad in a glossy magazine, but several new properties offer posh living for the midrange budget. One of them, the Monastero Santa Rosa (above), a 20-room hotel on the Amalfi Coast of Italy overlooking the Bay of Salerno, is scheduled to open in mid-May. It has two packages for travel between May 17 and June 7: guests can stay five nights for the cost of three, or three nights for the cost of two. That translates to rates starting at 330 euros (about $423 at $1.28 to the euro) per night, including breakfast.

The Who Made That column on April 8, about mini- golf, referred incorrectly to the authorship of the book ''Miniature Golf.'' It was written by Nina Garfinkel and Maria Reidelbach -- not by John Margolies, who was the book's photographer.

As I was walking through the gym the other day, I caught a glimpse of an overweight woman across the room. But then I did a double take, and then another. The woman was me -- I had seen my own reflection in a distant mirror and, for a split second, hadn't recognized myself. This moment of mistaken identity was disconcerting, but it wasn't all that unusual. Many of us are surprised by our size when reflected in the mirror or a store window -- it's like thinking that a recording of your own voice sounds off. And while psychologists have worried for years that media images of superslim starlets would put the nation's collective self-esteem at risk, it turns out that something altogether different has happened. As the population becomes fatter, study after study shows that instead of feeling bad about ourselves, we have entered a collective state of denial about how big we're actually getting.

AMIRA AHMED, left, a breakout model, is more than just a beautiful face framed by a short haircut. For this half-Somali, half-Filipino woman who surfs the West Coast -- ''I love waiting for that special wave'' -- and hits Tignes in the French Alps to snowboard between fashion seasons -- ''Simply a must!'' -- modeling is as much about traveling and maintaining the routineless life she knows so well as it is a job. Born in Stockholm, this 22-year-old grew up on her stepfather's boat where, she said, ''the sea became my playground.'' Upon coming ashore, she attended boarding school in Prague, then college in London, where she studied international relations. ''It's natural that I would find work that I could do everywhere,'' she said. Now calling Brooklyn home, the rising star recently landed campaigns for Gap, AllSaints and Levi's. Just don't expect her to start nesting anytime soon. KATHRYN BRANCH

A few weeks ago we announced an essay contest on a very meaty issue. We invited readers to make the best ethical case for their meat-eating ways, because despite the apparent popularity of the practice, omnivores had yet to answer the powerful ethical critiques laid down by vegetarians and vegans. Our panel of esteemed judges are right now making their way through the essays in search of the winner. Their verdict will appear in this space on May 6. Before that, dear readers, it's your chance to vote. Go to nytimes.com/magazine to read the finalists and judge them for yourselves. Everyone is welcome to vote, whether you live for bacon or die for tofu, whether you submitted an essay yourself or are now hearing of the contest for the first time. Just go, read the essays, consider their arguments and mark your ballots. The results of your voting will be published online, accompanied by fanfare and a side of fries.

NEW YORK'S conservatories have provided plenty of noteworthy options for opera lovers recently, with talented young singers and thoughtful stagings. Juilliard presents Mozart's ''DON GIOVANNI'' with a cast that includes the bass-baritone Ryan Speedo Green, who recently won the Metropolitan Opera's National Council Auditions, as the Commendatore, and the baritone Alexander Hajek as Leporello. Stephen Wadsworth directs, Gary Thor Wedow conducts. 8 p.m. Wednesday and Friday, 2 p.m. Sunday, Peter Jay Sharp Theater, 155 West 65th Street, Lincoln Center, (212) 769-7406, Juilliard.edu; $30. Uptown at the Manhattan School of Music Steven Osgood conducts John Corigliano's two-act ''GHOSTS OF VERSAILLES,'' which recounts the afterlife of the Court of Louis XVI and has been described by the composer as ''grand opera buffa.'' Commissioned by the Metropolitan Opera and given its premiere there in 1991, the work will be presented here using a new performing edition designed for smaller houses. (The Met original featured almost 300 singers.) Jay Lesenger directs. 7:30 p.m. Wednesday and Friday, 2:30 p.m. Sunday, Borden Auditorium, 120 Claremont Avenue, Morningside Heights, (917) 493-4428, msmnyc.edu; $20.

The Prototype column last Sunday, about stores and services for breast-feeding mothers, misstated the title of Cheryl Petran at the Pump Station and Nurtury. She is chief executive, not chief operating officer.

THE once gritty 14th Street corridor between P and U Streets in Washington is reinventing itself and morphing into an upscale residential district. Between old warehouses in the midst of becoming trendy lofts and cranes in vacant lots pulling up high-end glass condos are growing pockets of refined taste and class. Lower rents have enabled a host of independent shopkeepers to let loose creative spirits. And on weekends 14th Street comes alive with pedestrians, along with their dogs and strollers, ambling wide streets, and cyclists pedaling along the neighborhood's bike lanes. AUDREY HOFFER

The 1960 Democratic National Convention in Los Angeles was crammed with the political superstars of the day -- John F. Kennedy, Adlai Stevenson -- as well as key staff members like Andrew Hatcher. Garry Winogrand took pictures of all of them, but his primary interest was elsewhere. ''He photographed the life, the back corners, the audience,'' says Leo Rubinfien, a photographer who is curating a retrospective of Winogrand's work opening at SFMOMA next year. ''The people watching the parade, not the parade -- that was how he worked.'' The prolific Winogrand, who died in 1984 at 56 in Mexico, where he went for cancer treatment, left behind thousands of unseen pictures. Among them are these photographs, discovered last year in his archive at the Center for Creative Photography in Tucson. Only one from the convention is known to have been published: the picture of Kennedy at left, accepting the nomination and asking the party for ''your help and your hand and your voice.'' Total rolls shot by Winogrand in his lifetime: approx. 25,000

The Field Notes column last Sunday, about diets being tried by brides-to-be before their weddings, misstated the name of the town in Pennsylvania where one bride, Casey Crisefi, lives. It is Havertown, not Hagerstown.

An article last Sunday about uranium mining in Texas misstated the number of uranium mining facilities in the United States. There are six uranium production facilities in the country, not six uranium mines. The article also misstated the location of one of the facilities. It is in Utah, not New Mexico.

Beloved wife of the late Arthur, an esteemed CPA, devoted mother of Karen and Steven Bachmann, Janet and Edward Greenberg, and the late Stephen. Loving and loved nanny of Seth and Lisa Kain, Jill and Larry Karp, Jennifer and Larry Sweetwood, Michael and Sarin Bachmann, Amy-Beth And Gregory Katz, and Jonathan Greenberg. Adored great-grandmother of Alex, Daniel, Sydney, Max, Ryan, Jack, Abigail, Vanessa, And Marissa. We miss her already. McMANUS--Shirley Anne (nee Whelan), died April 13, 2012, in Westerly, RI, after a brief illness. Shirley was born in Providence, RI, on July 5, 1928, the daughter of David Everett Whelan and Alice (Corrigan) Whelan. She attended Classical High School, and graduated magna cum laude in 1945. She went on to Manhattanville College in New York City, earning a nursing degree in 1949, and practicing nursing until her marriage to James Edward McManus, M.D., in 1950. After living in East Norwich, NY, and Douglaston, NY, they settled in Katonah, NY, where they lived for 40 years, raising seven children. Shirley was active in the League of Women Voters, and served on the town's Democratic Committee. She was captain of the Katonah Memorial Park women's tennis team, and also gave tennis lessons to youngsters and adults. She was a voracious reader of literature, and a whiz at crossword puzzles. She loved gardening, cooking, and music, especially sacred music and folk music of heartland America. She and her husband relocated to Kingston, RI, in 2005, where they have been parishioners at Christ the King Church, North Kingston. Shirley is survived by her devoted husband and seven loving children, Susan Anne McManus, M.D., James Edward McManus, Jr., John Patrick McManus, Thomas Michael McManus, Paul Emmett McManus, M.D., David Whelan McManus, and Kevin Richard McManus. She is also survived by son-in-law Robert Pickoff, M.D., and daughters-in-law Suzanne McManus, Marsha Kallich, M.D., Kaori McManus, Elizabeth McManus, Susan Smiga-McManus, M.D., and Renee McManus; 16 grandchildren, Dylan, Kate, James, Michael, Conor, Ryan, Margaret, Padraic, Kenneth, Liam, Zac, Erika, Jack, Kiely, Reilly, and Lucie; and two brothers, David William Whelan, Captain U.S.N. Retired, and Richard Joseph Whelan D.D.S. She was pre-deceased by her parents, and a third brother, John Everett Whelan. A Mass of Christian Burial was said at Christ the King Church., and was followed by burial at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. Donations in her name may be made to Manhattanville College, Purchase, NY, or to Christ the King Church.

BIGFOOT hunters aren't the only ones out there searching for the unknown. Here are a few other ''hunts'' that travelers can join. The Atlantic Paranormal Society (413-478-3642; idealeventmanage.com). Perhaps the ghosting equivalent of the Bigfoot organization, this group organizes excursions to paranormal hot spots (its founders, Jason Hawes and Grant Wilson, are regulars on the Syfy series ''Ghost Hunters''). On April 28, the group heads to the Menard House in Galveston, Tex. $150, reservations recommended.

The cover article last Sunday, ''Portent or Blip?'' (April 15), reported on signs of a recovery in the Manhattan real estate market. Following are edited excerpts from nytimes.com: All you New Yorkers might be interested to know that you don't have a monopoly on a lively market. Much of the greater Boston area is experiencing the same phenomenon. I had buyers (not investors, not ''off-shore'' buyers, just a young couple looking for a home) offer $20,000 above asking on a modest, nondescript condo in Brookline (whose neighbor had closed below asking not three weeks before) -- there were five offers and they did not get the unit. ... ''Too many eager buyers, not enough inventory'' is not only the story in New York but also around Boston. Ellen F

THE director and designers of ''Ghost the Musical,'' the Broadway show opening Monday, based on the 1990 film, wanted aspects of the staging to feel like a live music video, complementing the pop and rock score. The result is a mix of old-fashioned stagecraft and high-tech solutions from the rock concert playbook. Video projections and arena-style lighting transport the characters from a loft apartment to a moving subway car. Several scenes feature illusions that would be at home in a Las Vegas magic show. In one, the title figure, Sam (Richard Fleeshman, center), appears to reach through a door. Here members of the creative team describe how the elements come together during ''I Had a Life,'' the Act I closing number, in which the audience discovers that Sam's best friend, Carl (Bryce Pinkham, far right), has betrayed him and is a threat to Molly (Caissie Levy, near right), his still-grieving girlfriend. ERIK PIEPENBURG

Dozens of hotels have notable art collections, but a few are focusing specifically on photography, with shows that wouldn't be out of place at a gallery. W Hotels, for example, will introduce its first Instagram photo exhibition on May 1 at the Living Room in its Times Square property. The hotel is in partnership with the photo-sharing company to curate a display of pictures from New York-based Instagrammers who capture architecture, design and street art in the city (one is seen above). The exhibition will be on display through June. Sofitel Luxury Hotels has a traveling photo show focusing on the French actress Brigitte Bardot called ''BB Forever: Brigitte Bardot, the Legend.'' The exhibition, which has 30 never-seen pictures that showcase Ms. Bardot's rise to fame, opened during Oscar Week at the Sofitel in Los Angeles and will travel to Sofitel properties in the United States throughout the rest of the year.

THESE days a lot of photographs seen in galleries and museums offer prearranged images of people, places or things. Sometimes the long tradition of street photography -- of capturing strangers as they move past the lens -- seems slightly lost in the shuffle of staged portraits, jaw-dropping panoramas of natural or urban vistas, or the latest permutations of postmodern setup. Some balance may be restored by ''I SPY: PHOTOGRAPHY AND THE THEATER OF THE STREET, 1938-2010,'' a multigenerational examination of the work of six photographers that opens Sunday at the National Gallery of Art in Washington. Contrasting different approaches and fluctuating ratios of control and randomness, it starts with Walker Evans, who used a hidden camera to photograph New York subway riders in 1938. It will include images from the 1950s that Harry Callahan made in Chicago, using a telephoto lens to snap pedestrians, and that Robert Frank took from buses of people on the sidewalks of New York. Bruce Davidson, revisiting the city's subways in the early 1980s, asked permission to take people's pictures. In the late '90s and 2000s Beat Streuli and Philip-Lorca diCorcia both set up stationary cameras on New York's streets, orchestrating memorable images of fluid choreographies and dark theatrics. Through Aug. 5, (202) 737-4215, nga.gov.

In last Sunday's Big City column, Ginia Bellafante wrote about the tragedy of Henry Wachtel, 19, who is charged with killing his mother in the aftermath of an epileptic seizure. Mr. Wachtel had been in a short film -- based in part on his own experiences -- about New York teenagers living in a world of meager opportunities and absent parents. Readers wrote in to criticize the column's portrayal of Mr. Wachtel's mother, Karyn Kay. I was a very close friend of Karyn's for over 35 years. Karyn had a deeply loving relationship with her son and was utterly devoted to him. Most of my recent visits with Karyn were centered around discussions concerning Henry's health, and his schooling.

NESTLED in London's West End is the 143-year-old jewelry house S. J. Phillips. Little has changed for this purveyor of rare and exceptional pieces -- some dating to the 1600s -- and that's part of its charm. But every now and then a client comes along who is as distinctive as the gems. ''For years I loved admiring the beautiful Pre-Raphaelite-like enamel pansy brooches in the store's showcases,'' said Eliane Fattal, a photographer and art historian by diploma, an S. J. Phillips shopper by choice and now a jewelry designer by trade. ''As artful and dreamy as their pansy pins were, I also felt sad at the fact that they were particularly difficult to wear in this era.''

Tim Wakefield retired at 45 in February after a 19-year pitching career that included 200 wins, 186 of them with the Boston Red Sox, and 2,156 strikeouts. But Wakefield's elusive pitch is fluttering again in the big-screen documentary ''Knuckleball.'' The film had its premiere Saturday as part of the Tribeca Film Festival in New York. The movie chronicles the careers of Wakefield and R.A. Dickey of the Mets. Q.

BIRDSALL--Charles K. (Ned) Professor Emeritus at the University of California, Berkeley, died March 6, 2012. He was 86. Born in 1925 in Manhattan, Ned Birdsall graduated from the University of Michigan with bachelor's and masters degrees in electrical engineering, and received his PhD in electrical engineering from Stanford University in 1951. His early work on microwave tubes led to 27 patents and election to Fellow of Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) at the age of 36. In 1959 Ned joined the Electrical Engineering Department at UC Berkeley. During his long academic career Ned became known as a pioneering inventor and educator whose contributions to plasma science have made lasting impacts on communications and other technologies. Among numerous awards, Ned was selected as the inaugural recipient for the IEEE Marie Sklodowska-Curie Award in 2011. At UC Berkeley Ned helped create two groups: the Plasma Theory and Simulation Group, and the Energy and Resources Group. Ned was awarded the Berkeley Citation in 1991. Outside his professional life, Ned was known for his love of hiking, skiing and long-distance running. Ned is survived by Ginger, his wife of 30 years, daughter Barbara Hagen of Bend, OR, son Tom Birdsall of San Francisco, son John Birdsall of Yountville, CA; Ginger's daughter Michele Proffitt of Modesto, CA; son Andrew Pletcher of Capitola, CA and daughter Sandra Glendinning of Alameda, CA; along with eight grandchildren and one great- grandchild. He was preceded in death by daughters Anne and Beth. A celebration of Ned's life is planned for April 29 at 1pm at the Faculty Club at UC Berkeley. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be sent to: The Charles K. (Ned) Birdsall Graduate Research Fund at University Relations, 2080 Addison Street, Berkeley, CA, 94720. Checks should be made payable to U.C. Berkeley Foundation.

For travelers who want to use digital applications abroad but would like to avoid the outrageous post-vacation data charges, Lonely Planet has a solution. The company recently introduced a series of travel-guide apps for several countries that can be used offline. ''We found out early on that for leisure travelers, roaming is a really scary thing,'' said Jeremy Kreitler, Lonely Planet's vice president for Wireless Services. ''Everybody has a friend with a bad phone bill from traveling abroad.'' Apps for Italy, Ireland, Australia, France, Spain and Costa Rica can be downloaded to an iPhone, iPad or iPod Touch, from either the App Store or through the Lonely Planet Travel Guides app. Each guide is $9.99 and provides suggested itineraries, as well as practical and historical information about the country. Detailed maps allow you to find points anywhere in the country, using your device's GPS.
GROSS--Bela. 10/10/1921-4/26/201. We have you in our hearts and minds with each passing day, since you've been gone. Martha, Robin & Anita

THE friendship of RALPH LEMON and Walter Carter must surely be counted as one of the great artistic collaborations of the early 21st century. Anyone who has encountered one of Mr. Lemon's layered artistic projects -- choreographic, visual or written -- is likely to be familiar with Mr. Carter (1907-2010), the Mississippi native who began showing up in Mr. Lemon's work in 2002 doing all sorts of strange, task-based activities (sometimes with his wife, Edna, and other relatives and neighbors). He was like a kind of marvelously inscrutable found object, one with as many schemes and designs in his head as Mr. Lemon had in his. Now, in ''1856 Cessna Road,'' Mr. Lemon delves into this eight-year relationship, in a solo show featuring large-scale color photographs, a video installation and 30 drawings made into video animation. It is Mr. Lemon's first exhibition at the Studio Museum in Harlem, and the first time this collection of works is being shown in New York. It is not to be missed. Through May 27, 144 West 125th Street, (212) 864-4500, studiomuseum.org; $7 suggested donation.

In the afterword to his latest novel, ''11/22/63,'' about John F. Kennedy's assassination, Stephen King calls Jack Finney ''one of America's great fantasists,'' and his book, ''Time and Again,'' ''the great time travel story.'' Thus, we would seem to have sufficient reason to make ''Time and Again'' our next book. Written in 1970, the novel revolves around the advertising artist Si Morley, who is recruited by the government to join a secretive operation committed to exploring the possibility of time travel. The project lands him in the New York of 1892, where, as a sidebar to his adventures, he has reason to trace the mystery of a half-destroyed letter for a friend. Join us for the live online conversation on May 16 from 7 to 10 p.m.

TO spur the sales of hybrid, electric, diesel and biofuel-powered vehicles listed on its pages, eBay officially started Green Driving on Thursday, a site-within-a-site dedicated to high-efficiency cars, trucks and motorcycles. The idea came from eBay's sustainability group, led by Annie Lescroart, which was behind company initiatives to get sellers to recycle their old mobile phones and to reuse shipping boxes. But like those programs, Green Driving isn't merely a do-gooder project intended to burnish eBay's image, but an opportunity to reach more shoppers.

WE know from a rare personal admission that Mitt Romney experienced a faint whiff of alcohol, a long, long time ago. ''I tasted a beer and tried a cigarette once as a wayward teenager,'' he said last November, ''and never tried it again.'' No doubt, Romney has friends who own multinational breweries. But he would fail the presidential beer test -- that is, whom would you most like to sip suds with -- simply because his Mormon faith prohibits drinking alcohol. But then, he would also fail the presidential cookie test, as he showed in another awkward appearance with real people last week.

REED--Genevieve Funston, of Greenwich, CT, age 99, died on April 16, 2012. She is survived by her daughter Susan Logan Whitman and her son-in-law Dr. Hendricks Hallett Whitman, twin grandsons Keith and Reed Whitman and their wives Kelly Leo and Sarah Coughlin Whitman and greatgrandson Charles Elliott Whitman. Memorial Service and Burial will be private.

IN ''My Week With Marilyn'' Eddie Redmayne -- freckled and plush lipped, with an undercurrent of naughty English schoolboy -- wore his infatuation on his sleeve as Colin Clark, a filmmaker recounting an intimate interlude with Marilyn Monroe in 1956. In ''BIRDSONG,'' the latest entry in the ''Masterpiece Classic'' oeuvre, Mr. Redmayne goes full-throttle romantic as Stephen Wraysford, a lieutenant in the British Army who, on the Allied front in 1916, barely seems to register the surrounding destruction as he remembers the summer of 1910 and his singular love, Isabelle Azaire (the clear-eyed Clémence Poésy). ''Birdsong'' is adapted from the 1993 novel by Sebastian Faulks, which, according to a recent BBC survey, ranks 13th -- between ''Wuthering Heights'' and ''Rebecca'' -- on a list of Britain's best-loved books. Shown on PBS this Sunday and next at 9 p.m. (check local listings), the two-part dramatization cuts between the ochre-hued trenches of World War I and the sun-dappled woods of northern France as it chronicles the relationship of Stephen and Isabelle, the wife of a textile factory owner, from its fledgling stages, when the unintentional touching of feet reverberates with passion, to its startling demise.
WEISER--Herbert, of the Bronx passed away Friday, April 20, 2012. He was 91 years old. A 11:00am graveside service will be held on Monday in the Cedar Park Cemetery Paramus, NJ.

PAVANE--Lawrence, 87, family patriarch, beloved husband, father, grandfather, uncle, and friend, died on April 20th. To all who knew him he was loving, generous, vibrant, inquisitive, confident, and selfless. A graduate of The City College of New York, Larry served in the Merchant Marine in World War II, after which he embarked on a successful career as an engineer, eventually forming Pavane Associates where he was a principal and owner. Throughout his productive life he led by example, both by his professionalism and unwavering integrity, and he will be sorely missed by all who had the good fortune to know him. He is survived by Roslyn, his wife of 66 years, his sons, Howard and Martin, and their wives, Susan and Merrill, and four wonderful grandchildren, Erin, Brian, Jennifer and Liana, and Jennifer's husband Doron, and he lives on through all of them. Services will be held at Gutterman's, 175 N. Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, New York on April 22nd at 1:45pm. Donations in his honor may be made to The City College of New York's Grove School of Engineering.

IT'S been quite a year in movies for cults and the charismatic leaders who control them. Elizabeth Olsen played a damaged refugee from a group in ''Martha Marcy May Marlene,'' and the barely seen ''God's Land'' depicted a Texas commune waiting for a spaceship to deliver it to the promised, er, dimension. ''SOUND OF MY VOICE,'' perhaps the best of all, opens Friday in New York. A hot offering at the Sundance and South by Southwest festivals, the film, the debut feature of the director Zal Batmanglij, presents two journalists going undercover to investigate a mysterious order whose priestess, Maggie, claims to be from the future and requires blood transfusions from her disciples. Playing Maggie is the emerging multi-hyphenate Brit Marling, who, with Mr. Batmanglij, wrote the film and produced it. (She also starred in -- and helped write and produce -- ''Another Earth,'' an underseen indie from last summer.) Given the buzz, it's probably safe to expect Ms. Marling to command a devoted following of her own soon. Landmark's Sunshine Cinemas, 143 East Houston Street, East Village; (212) 260-7289, landmarktheatres.com.

COHEN--Rabbi Jack. The Board and all those associated with The Mordecai M. Kaplan Center for Jewish Peoplehood mourn the passing of our beloved Honorary Chairman, Rabbi Dr. Jack J. Cohen of Jerusalem, who died there on April 16 at the age of 93. The Jewish people have lost a giant of a teacher and a role model. One of Mordecai Kaplan's greatest and most devoted disciples, Jack was the foremost advocate in Israel for the Reconstructionist approach to Judaism for more than 50 years. Among many other accomplishments, Jack was a founder of Congregation Mevakshei Derech in Jerusalem and the creator of its Kaplan Center. A man of enormous talents and erudition, Jack also exemplified true humility and treated all human beings with respect and kindness. His tireless passion for continuing the work of his teacher Mordecai Kaplan was an inspiration to all of us. We will miss both Jack's intellectual leadership and the gentleness of his soul. Jack's memory will forever be a blessing. Eric Caplan Daniel Cedarbaum Mel Scult Jack Wolofsky

Leave it to the N.F.L. to turn the announcement of its regular-season schedule into a midweek celebration of events that will not occur for five months. The league somehow generates drama out of repackaging information that is available months in advance: every team faces each division opponent twice, after all, and out-of-division opponents can be determined by a simple formula as soon as the previous season ends. The league's schedule broadcast should start with a truth-in-advertising tagline, ''All the things you knew were going to happen, but in an exciting new order!''

DEUTSCH--Henry, (88), died peacefully, April 18, 2012. Beloved husband of Marion; loving father to Robin, Jill, Aimee; adoring grandfather of Wendy, Jodie, Alissa, Jesse, Evan, Dayna; proud great-grandfather to Gavin and Parker; brother of Daniel. An Armed Forces veteran, graduate of Cornell University and Cornell School of Veterinary Medicine. Owner of a private veterinary practice, president of both the Long Island Veterinary Society and Nassau County Emergency Clinic, and an active member of Shelter Rock Tennis Club for 47 years. He touched the hearts of all who knew him.

CRAIG--Lois. Former Associate Dean at the MIT School of Architecture and Planning from 1980 until 1995, died on March 23 at her apartment in Chicago. She was 82. She was known for her research and writing in the fields of architecture and urban design. In 1972 she was appointed Director of the Federal Architecture Project at the National Endowment for the Arts. As director, she co-authored The Federal Presence: Architecture, Politics, and National Design(MIT Press 1978), the first comprehensive study of federal government architecture. At MIT she became well known for her research on American suburbs. She received a NEA Design Achievement Award in 1988 and became an Honorary Member of the American Institute of Architects in 1989. Her husband, Stephen Prokopoff, was a museum director and curator in Philadelphia, Chicago, Boston, Champaign, IL, and Iowa City. She is survived by her sister Marion Dodd; her children Stephen, Carolyn and Jennifer Craig; by Stephen's wife Sharon Kiddon, and by her granddaughter Corrina Craig. She is also survived by two stepsons, Alexander (Sasha) and Ilya Prokopoff.

WHEN Ursula Andress, clad in a silver bikini, lifts her stiletto shoe after a killing scene in the 1965 film ''The 10th Victim,'' the thought flashed through my mind -- as I am sure it would a designer's -- that the style would look fabulous today. It's safe to assume that many in fashion have scrutinized this film, set in the future and directed by Elio Petri and also starring Marcello Mastroianni. On the blog Irenebrination, Anna Battista dug out the movie's stylish facts, and noted a link to a fashion spread two years later in the Italian girlie magazine Playmen. You would swear the images are stills from the movie. She also supplied background on the costumes, designed by Giulio Coltellacci, writing, ''The tailor-made creations sported by Marcello are tempered by a sartorial and conceptual softness, making him look like a bored futuristic dandy.'' As it happens, Bruno Piattelli made his clothes, and those for the Playmen shoot.

2:30 P.M. (HBO2) SEPARATE LIES (2005) In this directorial debut from Julian Fellowes (''Downton Abbey''), who adapted the screenplay from Nigel Balchin's novel ''A Way Through the Wood,'' Tom Wilkinson portrays James Manning, a London lawyer who spares no one his imperious authority, not even his wife, Anne (Emily Watson, above with Mr. Wilkinson). When the husband of their cleaning woman is killed in a hit-and-run accident, James suspects that Bill Bule (Rupert Everett), a family acquaintance who attended a party at the Mannings' home that evening, was driving the car. Then Anne confesses that she and Bill are having an affair -- and that she was behind the wheel. But instead of allowing her to go to the police, James constructs an alibi. ''This powerful performance, equal in stature to Mr. Wilkinson's grieving father in 'In the Bedroom,' pushes 'Separate Lies' halfway toward the rarefied class of that 2001 film,'' Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. ''But that's not nearly far enough to begin to lift this intriguing but chilly moral puzzle to anything close to greatness.'' 9 A.M. (CUNY) REVISITING THE GREAT SOCIETY: THE ROLE OF GOVERNMENT FROM F.D.R. AND L.B.J. TO TODAY The roots and legacy of President Lyndon B. Johnson are explored by Robert A. Caro, his Pulitzer Prize-winning biographer; former Vice Present Walter F. Mondale; former Senator George S. McGovern; and the journalist Bill Moyers in this two-hour report, culled from a symposium presented last month by the Roosevelt House Public Policy Institute at Hunter College. Highlights include a panel discussion moderated by Bob Schieffer of CBS News as well as archival photographs and audio recordings of Johnson in conversation with the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and presenting a speech in 1965 before a joint session of Congress. The program will be repeated a 3 and 9 p.m.

POLLIS--Mary Elizabeth, 49, passed away Friday, April 20, 2012 at her home in Rhinebeck. Mary was born September 6, 1962 in Rhinebeck. Mary chose to live her entire life in Rhinebeck, raising her family in the community she loved. She attended Rhinebeck High school where she was a field hockey player and cheerleader. Mary attended St. Lawrence University where she earned her degree in English and psychology and was a member of Kappa Kappa Gamma. Mary was a proud alumni and very happy that her children, Carolina and Andrew, also attend St. Lawrence University. Mary is extremely proud of her children and dedicated her life to their activities. She served on parent committees at St. Lawrence and Trinity Pawling School, and was very involved at the Kildonan School for Dyslexia. Mary recently returned from a trip to Ireland with her youngest son Daniel; they visited her oldest son Jack, a student at Champlain College studying abroad in Dublin for a semester. Dan and Mary extended the trip to London where they went to the theatre and toured the city on foot. In addition to her home in Rhinebeck, Mary and her family have lived every summer since 1986 at their home in West Falmouth, MA. Mary was very involved in the community and served on the Tournament Committee at the Harbor Head Tennis Club. Mary especially loved sailing and the family maintained several sailboats on Cape Cod and the Caribbean. During the winters she and John taught their four children to ski at Bromley Mountain in Vermont. Mary enjoyed many things in life and shared her love and humor with everyone she knew. She was an avid reader and traveler. Mary is survived by her husband John P. Pollis whom she married in 1986 at the Good Shepherd Church in Rhinebeck. She is also survived by her four cherished children, Carolina, Andrew, Jack and Daniel; her parents Robert and Joan (Fitzpatrick) Marvin; ten siblings, Jody Ceglarski, Ann Marie Swann, Eileen Hosbein, Maureen Carroll, Barbara Nozaki, Bob, Paul, Billy, Jimmy and John Marvin; aunt and uncle Dr. Robert and Marilyn Fitzpatrick, and many cousins, nieces and nephews. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated Tuesday, 10:30am, at the Good Shepherd Church, 92 East Market St., Rhinebeck, NY. Calling hours will begin immediately following the Mass and continue until 2pm at the Dapson-Chestney Funeral Home, 51 W. Market St., Rhinebeck. A time for sharing memories will take place at 2:00pm. Following calling hours family and friends are invited to return to Mary's Home, 122 Morton, Rd., Rhinebeck for continued fellowship and refreshment into the evening. The family requests that memorial donations be made in Mary's memory to the The Kildonan School for Dyslexia, 425 Morse Hill Road, Amenia, New York 12501. Services are under the direction of the Dapson-Chestney Funeral Home, 51 W. Market St., Rhinebeck. To sign the online register please visit dapsonchestney.com

Through May 12 the Metropolitan Opera is mounting three complete cycles of the four operas that make up Richard Wagner's ''Ring des Nibelungen.'' After performances of the individual works over the last two seasons, the director, Robert Lepage, has made changes throughout.

GOODMAN--Georgine Rake, 87, died April 7 in her home in New York City after an extended illness. She was the widow of the late Maurice Goodman, Jr. Born in Toledo, Ohio on November 16, 1924, she was the beloved daughter of Henry and Myrtle (Alecksen) Rake, and the sister of Gloria Rake Karstaedt. After attending the University of Wisconsin and the Kenneth Sawyer Goodman School of the Theater in Chicago, she moved to New York City to pursue a career in theater and fashion. She was an Associate Fashion Editor at Glamour Magazine, and then Editor of the Children's Fashion Section of the New York Times Sunday Supplement. On June 7, 1952, she married Maurice Goodman, Jr.; they shared fifty-six years of marriage. The couple was an enthusiastic and dedicated patron of the theatre and ballet over their lifetime. Always personally involved in the arts, Mrs. Goodman served as a docent at the Metropolitan Museum of Art for 12 years, and her photographs and watercolors won numerous awards. She was the loving mother of Prudence G. Meyer, Susannah E. Rake, and John R. Goodman, and the grandmother of Laura A. Simson, Georgina. E. Simson, and Annabelle R. Butash. A memorial service to celebrate her life will be held later in the year. Contributions in her honor to Planned Parenthood and the Alzheimer's Association will be most appreciated.

The United States Olympic program might not have picked its basketball team yet, but the team already has a full lineup of sponsors. USA Basketball, the nonprofit governing body for basketball in the United States and organizer of the Olympic basketball team, will announce Jeep as its newest sponsor and the Jeep Wrangler the ''official vehicle partner of USA Basketball.''

WASHINGTON -- Just before Air Force One begins its descent, a group of agents huddle in a cabin near the back to study a map, a diagram and a step-by-step itinerary detailing the president's every move once he steps off the plane. It is an old ritual, this last operational run-through for the special agents of the presidential protective division, the most elite of the Secret Service agents and the last barrier between the commander in chief and a host of threats. This ritual is a big reason President Obama has been so reluctant to criticize the Secret Service, as the agency reels from a scandal over suspected misconduct involving prostitutes during a trip to Cartagena, Colombia.

MEHLICH--Yusha, on April 20, loving wife of the late Peter Mehlich. Beloved friend of Annette Risso and Kasia Karska. Came from Europe after WWII, she was a muse to many artist, a social light in her day. Avid animal lover. She will be missed by many. A memorial gathering Monday at Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel" Madison Ave. at 81st St. from 6-7pm. At 7:15pm a memorial service will be held. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the ASPCA.
INTERNATIONAL U.N. MONITORS TOUR REBEL-HELD SYRIAN TOWN

SPIER--Beatrice, May 22, 1922. Died April 20, 2012. Lover of good coffee, The NY Times, great writing, opera, and justice. Funeral services Tuesday, April 24, at 1:45pm at Plaza Jewish, 630 Amsterdam Avenue. Donations may be made to DoctorsWithoutBorders.org.

WEINBROM--Barry. Loving husband, father, son, brother, uncle and friend passed away surrounded by loved ones on April 20, 2012. He lived life to the fullest, and then some. He will live forever in the hearts of everyone he touched.

Because of an editing error, a report in the ArtsBeat column on Thursday about the play ''Water by the Spoonful'' by Quiara Alegría Hudes, which won the Pulitzer Prize for drama on Monday, misspelled the surname of the writer of ''Sons of the Prophet,'' one of the two other finalists for the prize. He is Stephen Karam, not Karan.

It took 56 bids, but a check endorsed by the creators of Superman that conceded the ownership rights to the character went for $160,000 at auction at Comicconnect.com. The check was issued by Detective Comics Inc. and was for $420, which included $130 for the rights to Superman, $210 for stories in Detective Comics, and two $36 payments for stories in More Fun and Adventure Comics. It was made out - incorrectly - to Seigel and Schuster, misspellings of the surnames of Jerome Siegel and Joe Shuster, the writer and artist team who created Superman. The back of the check is endorsed by each man twice - first with their names spelled incorrectly and then accurately. The auction began on March 26.

The Headlong Theater Company in London has announced that the world premiere of the musical adaptation of ''American Psycho,'' based on the 1991 novel by Bret Easton Ellis, will be part of its 2012-13 season. Hywel John (''Pieces'') will portray Patrick Bateman, a Wall Street executive who moonlights as a serial killer in the story. Rupert Goold (''Enron'') will direct the production, which has music and lyrics by Duncan Sheik (''Spring Awakening'') and a book by Roberto Aguirre-Sacasa (''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark''). An opening date has not been set.

MURASKIN--Roslyn Phd.,71, died April 21, 2012 after a two-year battle with ovarian cancer. She is survived by her husband of 47 years, Matthew; her three children and their spouses, Seth and Stacy, Craig and Savet and Tracy and Ted Birkhahn and six grandchildren, Lindsay, Nickia, Benjamin, Zachary, Sloane and Sydney; mother, Alice and brother, Richard. Funeral services Tuesday, April 24, 11:00am at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho tpke. Woodbury, New York.

An article on March 31 about MTV's plans to revive ''Art Breaks,'' a 1985 series of TV spots created by a vanguard of downtown New York artists, erroneously included two artists among those involved in ''Art Breaks.'' While Keith Haring and Kenny Scharf appeared on other MTV programming, ''Art Breaks'' did not include their work.

Unusually, Google is putting its mouth where its money is. Company representatives appeared at a computer networking conference in Santa Clara, Calif., on Tuesday and Wednesday to discuss some of Google's data center network workings. It has disclosed that its data centers have moved over to an advanced system dominated by software, instead of traditional hardware of custom switches and routers. The industry calls it a software defined network or S.D.N.

The thorny privacy issues of tomorrow were on display Thursday morning, when AT&T showed off a batch of technologies under development at AT&T Labs, the company's research arm. Researchers showed off door handles that unlock when you tap your phone against them, or even when the device is still in your pocket, sending vibrations through your body and into your fingertips. There was a steering wheel that communicates with a GPS device and vibrates to tell you which way to turn, and an app that works with sensors in your personal possessions to tell you when you have left something behind.

Google and Facebook, young and successful companies that they are, risk being left behind as technology shifts from PCs and Web browsers to mobile devices. This month, when Google showcased a new design for Google Plus, the company's social network, it was as if mobile phones and tablets were still a glimmer in some future inventor's eye. The made-over Web site was beautifully designed, but the smartphone app and mobile site were completely ignored. During the site's redesign, a Google spokeswoman told me, ''Today, the mobile experience will not change.''
HOLLENDER--Selma. 4/18/94. We love you forever. Alex, Jane, Beth, Wendy, Herb and Jeanette

Small businesses are known for making low-budget television advertisements. Now YouTube is encouraging those same mom-and-pop shops to take their homegrown commercials - and ad dollars - to its platform. On Monday, YouTube plans to announce a program it hopes will position the company as a major player in the market for small-business video advertising.

An obituary on Friday about Stanley R. Resor, who as secretary of the Army from 1965 to 1971 oversaw the troop buildup in Vietnam, misstated the number of United States Army troops there in both 1966 and 1968. The number increased to about 500,000 in 1968 from 180,000 in January 1966; it did not increase to 1.5 million from 961,000.

IMARISIO--Aili T. (Leppanen), Chicago, IL - age 96, of Chicago, IL passed away peacefully on Thursday evening, April 19, at The Breakers at Edgewater, an independent living community where she resided since May of 2007. Born June 7, 1916, in Palmer, MI, daughter of Eva and Kalle Leppanen, Aili spent many of her formative years in Upper Peninsula. She is a graduate of Northern Michigan University, Marquette, MI, a teachers college at the time. Aili taught school in the Chicago area. Aili then had a career with the American Red Cross Overseas group serving in Japan during the 1940s, and subsequently serving in Germany and New York. While in New York she met the love of her life, Dr. John Imarisio. They were married in 1955. Survivors include her husband, Dr. John Imarisio, her sister Martha Leppanen of Marquette, MI; her nephew Kenneth (Deanna) Hair of Ann Arbor, MI; three nieces Kristen (Justin) Hair Kaiser of Highland Park, IL; Kimberly Hair of Lincoln Park, IL; Jennifer Hair of Canton, MI, many cousins, extended family and her primary caregiver of five years, Devina Enad. Aili was preceded in death by her sisters, Ida and Anne. There will be a celebration of Aili's life from 5:00pm to 7:00pm on Tuesday, April 24, at the Nelson Funeral Home located at 5149 North Ashland Avenue, Chicago, IL 60640 (773-561-5147). Burial will be at the Arlington National Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, a memorial may be directed to the Children's Memorial Hospital, Department 4589, Carol Stream, IL 60122.

TEBBEL--John, 60, died at home Tuesday after a short illness. Beloved husband of Martha Thomases; dear father of Arthur Tebbel. He is also survived by his mother, Ellen Tebbel, his father, Robert Tebbel, and his sister, Cyndi Tebbel. John wrote passionately about animation, art, and all aspects of pop culture. He was past president of the Bedford-Downing Block Association. A memorial will be held on Tuesday, April 24, from 6pm-8pm at the Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker Street. Donations in his memory may be made to the War Resisters League, 339 Lafayette Street, New York, NY 10012.

Yahoo reported last week a small increase in revenue for the first quarter of 2012, and it is regrouping after it cut 14 percent of its work force this month. Yahoo's 18-year-old Web site is an Internet powerhouse in e-mail and news of all kinds. Visits to Yahoo Mail in the week ending April 14, at 490.8 million, beat the next two competitors combined -- Gmail (229.5 million) and Windows Live Mail (148.1). Yahoo also led in the news and sports categories. Users turned to Yahoo 245.2 million times to search, which placed it third behind Google, with 1.5 billion visits, and Bing, with 248.9. SHELLY FREIERMAN

In a sweaty, packed back room at Public Assembly in Williamsburg on Friday night, an M.C. pumped up the crowd with profanity-laced announcements, burlesque dancers and an accordionist vied for the crowd's attention, and a dance-off was in the offing. And none of that was even the main attraction.

The supercomputer game has traditionally been the playground of giants -- government agencies and a handful of major corporations. But cloud computing is leveling even this elite realm of technology, a development underlined by an announcement at a conference on Thursday. A 20-person company, Cycle Computing, a leader in supercomputer software, recently lashed together a massive supercomputing cluster, with 50,000 processors, on Amazon Web Services to do drug compound simulations. Its software was essentially the operating system, tapping resources from several Amazon data centers.

Amylin Pharmaceuticals is seeking a potential buyer, after it rebuffed an unsolicited $3.5 billion takeover offer from Bristol-Myers Squibb earlier this year, a person briefed on the matter said Sunday. Amylin, the maker of diabetes drugs, is working with Credit Suisse, Goldman Sachs and the law firm Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, this person said, adding that no sale was imminent.

The Republican presidential nominating contest is effectively over, but the voting continues. On Tuesday, voters in five states - Connecticut, Delaware, New York, Pennsylvania and Rhode Island - will choose from the remaining three candidates in primaries that not long ago seemed as though they could be pivotal. Now, turnout is expected to be light.

WASHINGTON -- One Saturday last fall, President Obama interrupted a White House strategy meeting to raise an issue not on the agenda. He declared, aides recalled, that the administration needed to more aggressively use executive power to govern in the face of Congressional obstructionism. ''We had been attempting to highlight the inability of Congress to do anything,'' recalled William M. Daley, who was the White House chief of staff at the time. ''The president expressed frustration, saying we have got to scour everything and push the envelope in finding things we can do on our own.''

The No. 1 movie in North America over the weekend, and by a long shot (sorry, Zac Efron), came as a shock to the movie industry: ''Think Like a Man,'' a low-budget ensemble comedy aimed at African-American audiences, took in an estimated $33 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office data. Sony spent less than $13 million to make this film, which is based on Steve Harvey's book ''Act Like a Lady, Think Like a Man'' and features the comedian Kevin Hart. A vehicle for Mr. Efron, ''The Lucky One'' (Warner Brothers), was second with about $22.8 million in ticket sales. Mr. Efron has been struggling to transition from ''High School Musical'' heartthrob to grown-up movie star, and ''The Lucky One,'' based on a Nicholas Sparks novel, was seen as an easy way for him to score. While the film missed No. 1, it had a bigger opening weekend than some industry analysts had predicted. It cost about $25 million to make, and Mr. Sparks's weepy dramas (this is the seventh to make it to the big screen) tend to have box-office staying power.

ANDERSON--Joan Uttal. Died April 19, 2012, aged 89, at home in Manhattan. Actress; casting director; voiceover coach; co-producer until her death of "Midtown Jazz at Midday" at St. Peter's Church, 619 Lexington Ave., where a memorial concert will be scheduled. Survived by sister Charlene Meissner; sons Bro and Lynn Uttal; step-children Wendy Swindell, Linda A. Rost, Wesson S. Anderson; and seven grandchildren.

An article on Friday about an inquiry into suspected misconduct by Secret Service agents in Colombia misidentified the hotel where Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton stayed during an international meeting there last week. It was the Hotel Santa Teresa -- not the Hilton Cartagena, the hotel where President Obama stayed.

The situation is so catastrophic that whoever wins it won't make much difference. The French want change but only on the condition that it doesn't change anything for them. MARIE-CLAUDE NOËL, 72, who said she voted for France's president, Nicolas Sarkozy, in the first round of presidential elections. [A1]
BHATTACHARJI--Arati, On April 14, 2012, aged 84. Beloved mother of Sandip, wife of the late Pares and daughter of the late Shyama Prasad Mookerji. Retired librarian. Her son will miss his tigress.
