SAN FRANCISCO - Marc Andreessen, the Netscape co-founder who went on to use his considerable wealth to finance scores of Silicon Valley start-ups, is regarded as one of the smartest technology investors. His victories have been spectacular: Skype, LinkedIn, and, one day Twitter, if all goes well.

An Associated Press report in the Sports Briefing column on April 13 about the withdrawal of Kurt Angle, a 1996 Olympic wrestling gold medalist, from the United States Olympic trials included an outdated reference to his professional affiliation. He works for Total Nonstop Action Wrestling; he is no longer with World Wrestling Entertainment. The error was repeated in the headline.

KAHN--Melvin S.,died peacefully on April 21, 2012. Beloved husband of Evelyn, father of Stephen, Joel, and predeceased by his son Leonard. Loving grandfather of Ethan, Abigail, and Dustin. WW II Navy veteran, retired business executive. He will be missed dearly. Memorial service on April 24, 2012 at 1:00pm at Gutterman and Musicant, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ.

SEATTLE - A plan by Facebook to acquire a broad range of patents through a deal with Microsoft is on its surface yet another twist in the battles over intellectual property engulfing the tech business. But the subtext of the deal is a different story, showing how two of technology's most powerful players are teaming up to create a greater balance of power on the Internet - a market that has been tilted decisively in favor of one company, Google, for years. ''This is almost certainly a move against Google,'' said Rebecca Lieb, an analyst at Altimeter Group, a research firm. The agreement between Microsoft and Facebook, announced on Monday, came less than two weeks after Microsoft agreed to pay more than $1 billion for 925 patents held by AOL. In a second deal, Microsoft said it had turned around and sold 70 percent of those same patents - about 650 in all - to Facebook for $550 million in cash, along with rights to 275 AOL patents Microsoft plans to retain. While Facebook and Microsoft have not yet determined precisely how they are going to divvy up the patents, it is expected that Facebook will end up with a range of patents involving mobile, Web and instant messaging technologies. Microsoft is likely to keep AOL patents involving search, among other things. The arrangement will help Facebook bulk up its intellectual property portfolio before its ini tial public offering, which is expected next month, and it is a further sign of the growing importance of stockpiling patents in the arsenal of any big technology company. ''This is another significant step in our ongoing process of building an intellectual property portfolio to protect Facebook's interests over the long term,'' Ted Ullyot, general counsel of Facebook, said in a statement. The deal could also give Facebook additional ammunition in its escalating patent feud with Yahoo. Yahoo sued Facebook earlier this year, claiming violations of Yahoo patents, many related to online advertising. Facebook subsequently countersued Yahoo, in a pattern that is playing out again and again in different parts of the technology business, especially the mobile phone market. But in large part the deal is evidence of how Microsoft and Facebook have gravitated ever closer to each other in part because of a common enemy, Google. Google has menaced Microsoft's business on a number of fronts, including with free online Google applications that compete with Microsoft Office and with Android, a mobile operating system that competes with Microsoft's Windows Phone software. As Facebook has evolved into a Web behemoth, with 900 million active monthly users, Google has become increasingly focused on tamping down the challenge to its business from the social network, introducing Google Plus, a rival social service. Google's big concern is that the bounty of data Facebook has about its users, including their tastes and friend connections, will turn it into a serious rival for online advertising dollars. There is also wide speculation that Facebook will start its own Internet search engine to rival Google. ''Microsoft is simply less concerned about the threat of social to its business than Google is,'' said Michael Gartenberg, an analyst at Gartner, a research firm, explaining why Microsoft is not concerned about competition with Facebook. ''This may be a case of the enemy of my enemy is my friend,'' he added. Jim Prosser, a Google spokesman, declined to comment. Microsoft has spent the last several years forging deeper connections with Facebook at every turn. Long stymied in its efforts to create an Internet search engine that effectively competed against Google, Microsoft two years ago struck a deal with Facebook to use data from the social network in Microsoft's Bing search engine to create more relevant search results. But the arrangement has not helped dislodge Google from its position of supremacy in Internet search. Years before that, Microsoft tried to acquire Facebook, but the social network's chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, rebuffed the offer. Those conversations subsequently led to Microsoft's taking a small stake in Facebook, from which it stands to profit handsomely after the company goes public. In March, Google accounted for 66.4 percent of Internet searches in the United States, unchanged from the same month a year earlier, while Microsoft was in second place with 15.3 percent of the market, according to comScore. Microsoft's Bing search engine also supplies search results for Yahoo, which accounted for 13.7 percent of the search market during March. Microsoft has continued to lose money on Bing, including more than $2.6 billion in operating losses for its online division during its last fiscal year. Some executives within Microsoft have advocated selling Bing to another company, with the idea that a company better focused on the Internet market could pose a more credible challenge to Google, according to severalpeople with knowledge of the discussions who didn't want to be identified talking about internal deliberations.Over a year ago, Microsoft executives sent out feelers to Facebook to see if the company would be interested in acquiring Bing, though the overture was not officially sanctioned by Steven A. Ballmer, chief executive of Microsoft, one of these people said. Mr. Zuckerberg declined, saying Facebook had too much else to concentrate on. Dawn Beauparlant, a spokeswoman for Microsoft, declined to comment, as did Ashley Zandy, a spokeswoman for Facebook. In its original patent deal with AOL, Microsoft either bought or won the ability to assign about 925 patents and patent applications, along with a license to several hundred other patents AOL did not sell as part of an auction of its intellectual property. If the deal announced Monday clears regulatory scrutiny, Microsoft would still own about 275 AOL patents and retain a license to the 650 patents that Facebook will own. In addition, Microsoft is granting Facebook a license to the 275 AOL patents that it is keeping. Yahoo's legal attack on Facebook came at a sensitive time, as the company nears an expected initial public offering. In a statement, Yahoo said the deal with Microsoft will not deter its lawsuit against Facebook. ''Nothing about today's action changes the fact that Facebook continues to infringe our patents,'' Yahoo said in the statement. ''Companies who purchase patents are often working from a position of weakness and take these actions to strengthen their portfolio. We see today's announcement as a validation of our case against Facebook.'' The deal with Facebook puts Microsoft in an awkward position since it could help strengthen one close partner at the expense of another, Yahoo. ''We are very sensitive to the importance of our relationship with both Facebook and Yahoo,'' Brad Smith, Microsoft's general counsel said in an interview. ''We have enormous respect for the value of the Yahoo patent portfolio. Yahoo has been an important innovator in the Internet space.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

The 23rd Glaad Media Awards honored Chaz Bono, the transgender activist and author; the actor Josh Hutcherson; and others on Saturday in Los Angeles. The film ''Becoming Chaz'' was chosen as outstanding documentary, and Mr. Bono received the Stephen F. Kolzak Award, which was presented by his mother, Cher, and stepmother, Mary Bono Mack, for his work in fighting homophobia. Mr. Hutcherson was recognized for his efforts with the antibullying campaign Straight but Not Narrow. Other honorees included ABC's ''Modern Family,'' which was named outstanding comedy series, and Mike Mills, the writer and director of ''Beginners,'' who accepted the award for outstanding film. The Glaad Media Awards, presented by the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation, have been broken into separate events; more awards are to be presented on June 2 in San Francisco.

BOSTON - In a new television ad, Elizabeth Warren compares her climb from modest roots, to the struggles of college students today, who she says, drown in debt while ''big corporations like G.E. pay nothing -- zero -- in taxes.'' The 30-second spot, released on Monday, opens with family photos from Ms. Warren's childhood when, she says, her family was ''hanging on by our fingertips to a place in the middle class.''

GOLDMAN--Robert, 87, after a long illness on April 22nd. Journalist, publisher, author, advertising executive, documentary film maker and avid tennis player and fan. Bob was a graduate of The University of Michigan and an editor of The Michigan Daily and a writer for The Detroit Free Press, Reader's Digest and The Saturday Evening Post. Bob was a founder of Surgical Care Publications and directed over 300 films/videos for the pharmaceutical industry. He is predeceased by his wife, Phyllis. Bob is survived by his sons, Josh (Karen) of Westport and Matt (Renee) of New York and two grandsons, Jack and Rhyus. Services Wednesday 11:15am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue with interment and reception to follow in Westport. Shiva at Bob's home will be Thursday 4-9pm and Sunday 11am-4pm.

STOCK SURGE Shares in the bookseller Barnes & Noble soared more than 18 percent on Monday after the hedge fund Jana Partners bought a 12 percent stake in the company. Jana Partners, a hedge fund known for taking an activist role at other companies, disclosed late Friday that it had bought nearly seven million shares in Barnes & Noble and had an option to buy 250,000 more at $13 a share. Shares of Barnes & Noble, maker of the Nook e-book reader, above, closed at $13.41 on Monday, up $2.07. AZAM AHMED

Over the years, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority board has had among its members its share of lawyers, failed mayoral candidates, union leaders - even the wife of a former Beatle. So while it may be hard to top the star power of Nancy Shevell, who left the board this year after she married Paul McCartney, the board did make history on Monday by appointing a former governor as her replacement: David A. Paterson.

WILLIAMSON--Benjamin Robert, Jr.,a resident of Manhattan, died in an automobile accident at Figure Eight Island, NC on April 22. Born September 18, 1956, in Raleigh NC, Robert is survived by his mother, Blanche Bacon, and father, Robert, both of Raleigh, and by his wife of 24 years, Caroline Crook Williamson and their three children: Caroline Costner, age 20; Benjamin Robert III, 18, and Wyndham Josephine, 13. Robert had an abiding interest in people of all ages and stations, loved to probe questions both big and small, and was gifted with a sunny magnetism that attracted many friends. He had a soft spot for his family. To be a close friend meant steady bombardment with e-mails about his children, usually with a selection of the photographs and videos he was always taking on family trips, at sports events and at class plays. From childhood, Robert had a keen interest in business and started many enterprises, most famously, in his preteen years, a rabbit farm. Robert graduated from the Ravenscroft School in Raleigh, where he was the 2008 distinguished alumnus and a member of its sports hall of fame, and in 1979 from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Following graduation, he worked for Sonoco, a paper products company in Hartsville, SC, before going to Wake Forest School of Business and receiving an MBA with honors in 1983. Later that year, he joined Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette in Manhattan as a stockbroker. In 1998 he joined Tiger Management, a New York City fund. In 2000 he co-founded his own hedge fund, Williamson McAree Investments, and, in January of 2011, joined Chilton Investment Co. where at his death he was a managing director. As a New Yorker, Robert maintained his ties to the South, hosting a Christmas party with Caroline where Southern accents predominated, and attending the annual ball of the North Carolina Society of New York, where he served a term as president. Robert played junior varsity basketball for Carolina, and he remained an avid Tar Heel fan. He gave time and money to many New York charities, including New Life of New York City, a faith-based youth outreach organization, where he was chairman of the board at his death, and Inwood House, where Caroline plays a leadership role. He was a longtime member of the Church of the Heavenly Rest, and at the time of his death was chairing the search for a new pastor. In addition to the family members mentioned above, Robert is survived by his sister Blanche Spencer Williamson of Southampton NY; brother Julian Robertson Williamson of Raleigh, wife Elizabeth and their three daughters; stepfather Zack Bacon; stepbrothers, Zack Bacon, Louis Bacon, and Bart Bacon; stepmother, Eve Williamson; stepbrothers Bill Blades and Rob Blades and stepsister Helen Dixon; mother- and father-in-law Betty and C.B. Crook of Albemarle, NC; brother-in-law Charles Crook of Marina del Rey, CA; uncle, Julian Robertson of New York City; aunt, Wyndham Robertson of Chapel Hill, and many beloved first cousins with whom he was in regular contact. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, April 25th at 5:00pm at Christ Episcopal Church in Raleigh. The funeral will be held on Monday, April 30th, at 4:00pm at the Church of the Heavenly Rest at 90th Street and Fifth Avenue. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, a contribution be made to New Life of New York City, 66 Clinton Street, New York City, 10002, to the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 2 E. 90th Street, New York City, 10128, or to the charity of one's choice.

The On Baseball column on Wednesday, about Red Sox Manager Bobby Valentine's criticism of third baseman Kevin Youkilis in an interview, misidentified the city where the television station that broadcast the interview is located. WHDH is in Boston, not Hartford.

HONG KONG - China's banks are among the biggest and most profitable financial institutions in the world. But the state-backed banks are also starved for capital, after an aggressive lending spree that was encouraged by the government.

When David M. Poppe sat down a little over a week ago to write a letter to his investors, he knew he was taking an unusual step. Mr. Poppe, who manages money for the Sequoia Fund, one of the most well-respected institutional investment firms in the country, made his letter public last Thursday, setting off a debate within the upper echelons of corporate boardrooms.

COATZINTLA, Mexico -- For seven decades, Pemex, Mexico's state-owned oil monopoly and a mainstay of the government's revenue, regulated itself -- which is a polite way of saying it could do pretty much as it pleased. No authority challenged the wisdom of investments like the billions it has spent here in the Chicontepec oil field to extract just a trickle of petroleum even as private companies have pulled torrents from similar shale rock in Texas and North Dakota.

Valeri Vasiliev, the top defenseman with the great Soviet hockey teams of the 1970s and '80s, died on Thursday in Moscow. He was 62. The cause was heart failure, kidney failure and pneumonia, his wife, Tatania, told the Russian daily Sovetsky Sport. Vasiliev was a mainstay of the Soviet national team when it won Olympic gold medals in 1972 and '76 and eight International Ice Hockey Federation World Championships between 1970 and '82.

9 P.M. (13, 49) MONEY, POWER AND WALL STREET In the summer of 1994, in a luxury hotel in Boca Raton, Fla., a team of JP Morgan bankers in their 20's devised an insurance product for loans called a credit default swap, and in the process fueled a golden era of profits for the banking industry. But what was originally intended to stabilize the financial system eventually brought it to its knees, inciting protests, above. ''It was quite clear to me that a number of really quite large financial systems had not had the kind of management information systems which allowed them even to know what all their risks were,'' Daniel K. Tarullo, a Federal Reserve governor, said later. In this two-episode ''Frontline'' presentation, Martin Smith and Michael Kirk investigate the efforts in Washington and on Wall Street to rescue the economy and explore how certain decisions, missed opportunities and the uneasy partnership between government leaders and the titans of finance have affected fortunes worldwide. Part 2 will be shown next Tuesday. 3:05 P.M. (Sundance) PICASSO AND BRAQUE GO TO THE MOVIES (2010) Picasso attended the 1900 World's Fair in Paris, where he was mesmerized by the American dancer Loie Fuller, who wore billowing veils onto which colored light was projected. Those images found their way into his 1907 painting ''Les Demoiselles d'Avignon.'' This documentary from Arne Glimcher argues that films, starting with the early experiments of Thomas Edison and the Lumière brothers, were a formative influence on Modern painting, especially Cubism, which was founded by Picasso and Braque in 1907. Martin Scorsese, who helped produce the film, narrates; the artists Julian Schnabel, Chuck Close, Eric Fischl, Lucas Samaras and Robert Whitman weigh in.

My 11-year-old grandsons, Stefan and Tomas, weigh about 80 pounds each. On the 20-minute walk to their middle school and the uphill walk home, they carry backpacks that weigh about 12 pounds each, or 15 percent of their body weight. When extra books or clothing, a musical instrument or other equipment are added, the weight they carry can reach 20 pounds. But whatever the figure, those packs are simply too heavy for their still-forming bones and muscles.
An obituary on Friday about the actor Jonathan Frid, using information from a colleague, misstated the date of his death. It was April 14, not April 13.

It took 14 speakers and an 11-page news release on Monday to spread the news that city officials had struck a deal for New York University to create a school of applied science in Downtown Brooklyn. The agreement, which has been in the works for months, would end years of debate about what to do with the old headquarters of the city's transit authority at 370 Jay Street. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority had largely abandoned the 61-year-old building, transferring many of its occupants to other offices in Manhattan.

Bernard Rapoport, the founder of an insurance company who became a linchpin of the beleaguered community of Texas liberals, died on April 5 in Waco, Tex. He was 94. His death was confirmed by his granddaughter Abby Rapoport.

An article on Wednesday about a poll indicating that more Americans are inclined to link recent weather extremes to global warming referred imprecisely to the name of a group that is trying to draw attention to that link. The name, 350.org, refers to what the group considers a safe upper limit for carbon dioxide in the atmosphere (350 parts per million), not an ideal level. (The level in March was 394 parts per million.)

The Mount Vernon Journal on Saturday, about the city where Dick Clark grew up, misstated the year that Mount Vernon High School opened. It was 1963, not the early 1950s. The article also misstated the size of the city. It is 4.4 square miles, not 6.

An article on Saturday about a New York City program under which people live rent-free in historic homes in return for serving as caretakers misidentified the location of the Edgar Allan Poe Cottage. It is in the West Bronx, not the South Bronx.

Police think that a stolen white minivan may have been used in a theft earlier this month of precious works of art from China worth nearly $29 million from the Fitzwilliam Museum at the University of Cambridge in England, the BBC reported. ''These works are a highly important part of our collection and their loss is a great blow,'' a museum spokesman said of the 18 pieces, most of them made of jade.

An article in some editions on April 15 about the Rangers' 3-2 overtime loss to Ottawa in Game 2 of their playoff series misidentified one of the fighters Senators Coach Paul MacLean put in the starting lineup. He is Matt Cark-ner -- not Terry Carkner, who is a cousin of Matt's and played in the N.H.L. from 1986 to 1999.

With Congress and privacy watchdogs breathing down its neck, Google is stepping up its lobbying presence inside the Beltway - spending more than Apple, Facebook, Amazon and Microsoft combined in the first three months of the year. Google spent $5.03 million on lobbying from January through March of this year, a record for the Internet giant, and a 240 percent increase from the $1.48 million it spent on lobbyists in the same quarter a year ago, according to disclosures filed Friday with the clerk of the House.

A report in the ''Arts, Briefly,'' column on Monday about a forthcoming musical adaptation of ''American Psycho'' erroneously included the casting of a starring role. While the actor Hywel John has appeared in a promotional trailer, neither he nor any other actors have been cast.

The managing agent for four airlines that run Terminal 1 at John F. Kennedy Airport had a plan: remove and destroy a two-story-tall sculpture that they commissioned 14 years ago and bring in more food stands. Lawyers for the artist went to court on Monday saying, in effect, no way. And a federal judge told the management unit for the airlines at the terminal, not so fast.

Netflix said on Monday that it finished the first quarter with nearly three million more streaming subscribers than it had started with, showing continued interest from Internet users despite the company's missteps last year. But the company's prediction of slower subscriber growth in the second quarter rattled investors Monday afternoon. In after-hours trading, Netflix stock slumped more than 16 percent.

BUCHALTER--Stephen, 69, died peacefully at home on April 21, 2012. Loving husband to Janet Rosdil; stepson Joshua, son of Ross and Rosalind (deceased); brother of Ronni (Michael Lux) and Joel. Grandfather of Kyrin and Holden and uncle of Erin Botsford. Retired attorney. Lover of ideas, books, history. Defender of justice. Avid fanatic of the Mets, Giants and Knicks. Defying the predictions of his doctors, Robin Gibb, the Bee Gees singer, has emerged from a coma after more than a week, but he remains in intensive care and is battling advanced colorectal cancer, his physician said on Sunday. In a statement, Dr. Andrew Thillainayagam said Mr. Gibb, 62, had caught pneumonia and lapsed into the coma last week after he was weakened by two surgeries and chemotherapy to combat tumors, The Associated Press and the BBC reported. Dr. Thillainayagam, a gastroenterologist, said Mr. Gibb was lucid and able to speak on Sunday, though he was being fed intravenously and was breathing with the help of an oxygen mask. He remains ''exhausted, extremely weak and malnourished,'' the doctor said.

Last spring, Katie Dickman of Dunkirk, Md., was at the playground with her 18-month-old toddler, Hannah, when the little girl asked to ride down a twisting slide. Ms. Dickman accompanied her daughter, carefully keeping the child on her lap as they coasted to the bottom. But without warning, Hannah's sneaker caught on the side of the slide. Although Ms. Dickman grabbed the leg and unstuck her daughter's foot, by the time they reached the ground, the girl was whimpering and could not walk. A doctor's visit later revealed a fractured tibia.

Because of an editing error, a report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Saturday about Bob Dylan's recollections of collaborating with Levon Helm, the drummer and singer who died last week at 71, erroneously included Mr. Helm among the musicians pictured at a 1974 performance. Another drummer, who was not identified, was shown with the group; Mr. Helm was not pictured.

When Augie Hong awoke with severe abdominal pain nearly two years ago, he went to the hospital emergency room closest to his home in San Francisco. The diagnosis was acute appendicitis, and doctors removed his inflamed appendix. Mr. Hong had health insurance, so he wasn't too worried about paying. Then the bills started to arrive.

HONG KONG--The Securities and Exchange Commission has sued another China-based company and two of its executives, charging them with lying to investors about the value of the company's assets and how it used $120 million in proceeds from its initial public offering on the Nasdaq. In a complaint filed Monday in a federal court in Louisiana, the S.E.C. also alleged that the chairman of the company, SinoTech Energy, secretly siphoned $40 million last summer from the company's account at the Agricultural Bank of China.

The British love their period costume dramas, except when they don't. In a familiar tale of a teacher being surpassed by its student (which, come to think of it, would make a pretty good British period costume drama), the BBC said it would not order another season of its revival of ''Upstairs, Downstairs,'' a revival that came on the heels of ''Downton Abbey,'' which in turn owes a creative debt to the original ''Upstairs, Downstairs.'' In a statement reported by BBC News, the BBC said that 2012 ''has been a great year for Original British Drama on BBC1 but at this stage there are no plans for 'Upstairs Downstairs' to return.''

The family minivan idles at the intersection of 59th and York in Midtown Manhattan. My boyfriend swabs my midriff with alcohol as he steadies the needle. My parents look on from the front seat, quietly studying their 22-year-old daughter and the young man they've known for only a month. The needle is filled with gonadotropin, a hormone that stimulates the ovaries to produce eggs. I'm late for my checkup at the fertility clinic. How in the world did I get here?

It was a life well lived; a man well loved. SCHEMAN--Blanche (Kirsch), 94, died April 22nd in Minnesota. A life-long fighter for social justice, she was the first woman student council president of Brooklyn College and President of the Mid-Atlantic region of the National Student Federation, lunching twice at the White House with Eleanor Roosevelt. She was a reading specialist in the Cold Spring Harbor Schools. She married Paul Scheman in 1941. They lived in Freeport, then Huntington until Paul's death in 1987. She later moved to Sarasota and in 2004 to Minnesota, near daughter Naomi, who survives her, along with daughters Carol (David Korn) and Judith (Robert Baumann), Carol's daughters, Rebecca and Joanna Fiduccia, and Judith's daughter, Ingrid. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Blanche's memory to Learning Ally, Attn: Donations, 20 Roszel Rd., Princeton NJ 08540. Memorial gathering in New York City on May 5th; for details call the family or email blanchememorial@gmail.com.

But Ms. Lohan will soon have a chance to convince audiences otherwise in a made-for-television movie that casts her as Ms. Taylor.

GOLDMAN--Robert, 87, after a long illness on April 22nd. Journalist, publisher, author, advertising executive, documentary film maker and avid tennis player and fan. Bob was a graduate of The University of Michigan and an editor of The Michigan Daily and a writer for The Detroit Free Press, Reader's Digest and The Saturday Evening Post. Bob was a founder of Surgical Care Publications and directed over 300 films/videos for the pharmaceutical industry. He is predeceased by his wife, Phyllis. Bob is survived by his sons, Josh (Karen) of Westport and Matt (Renee) of New York and two grandsons, Jack and Rhyus. Services Wednesday 11:15am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue with interment and reception to follow in Westport. Shiva at Bob's home will be Thursday 4-9pm and Sunday 11am-4pm.

CLYMAN--Evelyn G. The members and staff of Eugene M. Grant & Co., LLC note with deepest sorrow the passing of Evelyn G. Clyman, beloved sister of Eugene M. Grant. Evelyn was admired and appreciated for her wisdom and warmth and for the special relationships that she maintained with the individuals in our office. She will be greatly missed. Richard E. Kobrin, Member

LEDERMAN--Mark T.,of New York and Palm Beach passed away on Monday April 23rd at home surrounded by his family after a valiant battle with ocular melanoma. He was involved with various Jewish and other philanthropic organizations including the Interdisciplinary Center of Herzliya, Park East Synagogue, Palm Beach Synagogue, Congregation Orach Chaim, New York Presbyterian Hospital and Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. He was also an active member of the Palm Beach Country Club, The Atlantic Golf Club and the Harmonie Club. He lived his life to the fullest with vigor and enthusiasm. Golfing, running marathons, riding Harley Davidson motorcycles and racing cars were just a few of his passions. His greatest "job" over the past two years was overseeing the renovation of his beloved PBCC golf course. He is survived by his loving wife of forty-three years, Carol, his siblings Frank and Ellen Lederman, his children Amy and Jeffrey Verschleiser and Judy and Ken Kloner. At the center of his life were his seven grandchildren Joshua, Madison, Brooke and Hope Verschleiser and Daniel, Jacqueline and Tobias Kloner. Services will be held at Park East Synagogue, 163 East 67th Street, at 9am on Wednesday April 25th. Donations can be sent to the Melanoma Immunotherapy Fund c/o Dr Jedd Wolchok, Memorial Sloan Kettering or The Interdisciplinary Center of Herzliya.
LEDERMAN--Mark. To Marco: You will be missed, but never forgotten. Alan and Steven

Rotival--Alexander Holt "Sandy", 80, born in Paris, France, passed away on April 22. As a resident of Woodstock, CT, Sandy had a deep personal love for the community and it's history. Throughout his international career, he was a key actor in the emergence of post-colonial West Africa and the social and economic development of the region. He served as Resident Representative of the United Nations in a number of West African countries and established a close rapport with heads of state and their ministerial staffs. Upon his return home, he made significant contributions to the community and to philanthropic organizations such as Celebrating Agriculture, Planning & Zoning and Performing Arts New England. He is survived by his children and their spouses Valerie and Jean-Paul, Laurent and Amy, Constance and Philippe, his grandchildren Chloe, Celine, Alexandre, Julie, Sophie, Isabelle, Theophile, Matthieu, and Edouard, his sister, Denise Huffman, nephew and niece, his cousins, Hamilton Holt, John Holt, Miranda Smith, Coleman Holt, Tappan Holt and Joseph Chadborne, and their spouses and family members. A ceremony in celebration of his life will be held on Saturday, April 28th at the Woodstock Hill Congregational Church at 1100. In lieu of flowers, please consider making a donation to The Connecticut Farmland Trust. If you would like to contact the family, they can be reached at famille.rotival@gmail.com

LEDERMAN--Mark. The greatest father, grandfather and friend. From tennis tournaments, gymnastics, skiing, weddings, births, hockey and soccer games, cooking, go-cart racing and the beach, life was always more fun when you were around. Kurt Sutter, the creator of the on-road mayhem in the hit FX biker drama ''Sons of Anarchy,'' will be taking the action off-script in a new show called ''Outlaw Empires,'' which will profile real-life crime organizations like the Crips, the Irish mob and the Aryan Brotherhood as well as an rogue biker gang, Entertainment Weekly reported on Tuesday. The series, scheduled to begin on the Discovery Channel on May 14, ''will make 'Sons of Anarchy' look like 'Sesame Street,' '' Mr. Sutter told the magazine's Inside TV blog, adding that the show will differ from similar fare by emphasizing the criminal's point of view rather than that of law enforcement.

LUDDEN--Bennet R.,97, music librarian, died peacefully on April 16 in Washington, DC. He was Head Librarian at The Juilliard School from 1957-1979. Born in Salem, OR, he attended DePauw University from 1938, receiving his Master's in 1943. As an Exchange Fellow, he studied in Budapest from 1938-1940. He earned a Master's in Library Science from Columbia University in 1957. He taught at Willamette, Columbia and Kent State University. On retirement, he became a student, then teacher, of studio ceramics. A collector of antique ceramics, he donated his collection to the Hallie Ford Museum at Willamette. Traveling extensively, he wrote a monograph on architecture of the Cycladic Islands. Mr. Ludden is survived by his sister Russellen Hale, of Phoenix, AZ, four nieces, six great-nieces and nephews, and numerous colleagues and friends. Services will be private.

Representative Paul D. Ryan, the Republican chairman of the House Budget Committee, has been excoriated by some Roman Catholic leaders ever since he claimed this month that his budget plan, which slashes antipoverty programs, was inspired by the moral teachings of his Catholic faith. The latest criticism comes in a letter released Tuesday and signed by nearly 90 faculty members and priests at Georgetown, the Jesuit university in Washington, in advance of Mr. Ryan's visit there on Thursday. Mr. Ryan is to deliver the prestigious Whittington Lecture, named for an associate dean who was killed on the airplane that crashed into the Pentagon on Sept. 11, 2001.

CHENAULT--Anne N. Mrs. Anne N. Chenault, 98, passed away quietly in her sleep on April 23 at home in Hempstead, New York. Anne (nee Anne Naomi Quick) was born February 23, 1914 to Oscar and Louise Quick in Anderson, South Carolina, the second of ten siblings. The family moved to Brooklyn, where Anne attended public schools. She went on to graduate first in her class from the School of Dental Hygiene at Howard University in 1938, serving as class speaker. At Howard, Anne met her future husband, Hortenius Chenault, a student at the Dental School. They married in 1942 and later moved to Long Island, establishing a successful dental practice in Hempstead. Anne also worked as a dental hygienist for the Department of Health of the City of New York. Anne was a long-time member of the South Hempstead Congregational Church. She served her church selflessly, teaching Sunday school, serving as Vice President of the Women's Fellowship, and in later years taking care of flowers for the altar. She also served as secretary of the Friends of the Hempstead Library, volunteered with a youth organization for women in Long Island, and was an active member of the Links and the NAACP. Anne is survived by her children: Patricia, Arthur, Kenneth and Stephan; her daughters-in-law, Stephanie and Kathryn; and her grandchildren, Byron, Jillian, Kenneth, Jr., and Kevin. A wake will be held Friday, April 27th, from 5:00 - 9:00pm at the Carl Burnett Funeral Home, 456 South Franklin Street in Hempstead, New York (516-489-4492). The Home Going Service will be held Saturday at 11:00am at the Congregational Church of South Hempstead, 416 Woodland Drive, South Hempstead (516-489-3610). Burial will follow the service at Greenfield Cemetery in Hempstead and there will be a repast at the Church after the interment at 3:00 pm. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions to:The Anne Chenault Scholarship Fund, Howard University College of Dentistry, The Dental Hygiene Program, 2225 Georgia Ave., NW Suite 901, Washington, DC, 20059, Attention: Mr. Haki Halisi.

More people are watching the Stanley Cup playoffs in the United States this year, partly because four national networks are covering them, up from two in recent seasons. Through 21 broadcasts, the NBC Sports Network is averaging 691,000 viewers a game, up 17 percent from last year when the channel was called Versus. In important advertiser demographics, the viewership for men from 18 to 49 is up 22 percent and for men 25 to 54, it has increased 16 percent. NBC's four games have averaged 2.6 million viewers, up 33 percent from last year, with last weekend's games not yet in the calculation.

An article on Monday about a case before the Supreme Court challenging an Arizona immigration law, and the possible effect a ruling might have on a similar law in Georgia, described imprecisely the timing of discussions between the Georgia Agribusiness Council and Gov. Nathan Deal on legislation there. While the business council expressed its concern to Governor Deal, it did so before the law was enacted, not after. ( It was to federal officials that the council complained after the law took effect.)

Free full-scale performances by the Metropolitan Opera in New York City's parks increasingly look like a thing of the past. For the fifth summer in a row, the Met will present recitals instead of complete opera performances. The Met, in announcing the summer season on Monday, said that the singers Danielle de Niese, Dimitri Pittas and John Del Carlo, accompanied by the pianist Dan Saunders, would perform at SummerStage in Central Park on July 25 and at Brooklyn Bridge Park in Brooklyn on July 27. Deanna Breiwick, Alexander Lewis and Edward Parks, with the pianist Vlad Iftinca, will give recitals in Crotona Park in the Bronx (July 31), Clove Lakes Park in Staten Island (Aug. 2), Jackie Robinson Park in Manhattan (Aug. 7) and Socrates Sculpture Park in Queens (Aug. 9).

The Fox network said Monday evening that Ryan Seacrest had agreed to continue hosting the nation's most popular reality television show, ''American Idol.'' With the new contract, Mr. Seacrest will remain on the broadcast for two more seasons, taking him through the spring of 2014, according to a person with direct knowledge of the deal who insisted on anonymity because the terms were not being made public. The new contract is valued at $15 million a season.

Mr. Scott stepped down from the Goldman Sachs board last year; he is not currently a director there.

You might think that if you bought shares of a Chinese company that was listed on an American stock market, you would actually own a piece of that company. Unfortunately, it is not that simple. The recent cases of the ChinaCast Education Corporation and the Sino-Forest Corporation show that in many instances, foreign investors in Chinese companies might have bought shares that don't really represent much. It's a problem that has the potential to extend to even the soundest Chinese company listed in the United States.

Updated, 5:55 p.m. | A family was torn apart by violence early Tuesday morning as a son turned a gun on his own mother, killed his 13-year-old half-sister, and engaged police in a lengthy predawn shootout in Washington Heights, the police said. The violence erupted around 3:30 a.m., when police officers responded to a 911 call of a woman shot inside an apartment at 2971 Frederick Douglass Boulevard, near 155th Street, at the Polo Grounds Towers public housing complex, the police said. Once inside, officers found Christine Fryar, 44, with multiple gunshot wounds and her daughter, Annie, 13, with a gunshot wound to the head. The woman told the police that the shooter was her son, the police said.

In combat zones, National Guard units generally take their orders from active duty commanders. Not so in Washington. For two months, the Air National Guard, with the help of governors from every state, has been battling the active duty Air Force over proposed budget cuts that would have trimmed the Guard's force by more than 5,000 people and more than 200 aircraft.

Sinead O'Connor says she is canceling her 2012 tour because she has bipolar disorder, the latest in a series of erratic pronouncements by the Irish songwriter suggesting she is deeply troubled. Ms. O'Connor, 45, made the announcement on Monday on her Web site, saying her doctors had told her to avoid touring after a ''very serious breakdown between December and March,'' The Associated Press reported. Her Web site was later taken down, though a fan site preserved her comments.

Many men 75 years and older, who are far more likely to be harmed than helped by prostate cancer screening, continue to be tested for the disease, despite federal guidelines strongly advising against the practice. The debate about screening older men for prostate cancer was reignited last week after reports that the billionaire investor Warren Buffett, who is 81, said he received a diagnosis of early-stage prostate cancer after a routine blood test for prostate specific antigen, or P.S.A.

An article on April 14 about the Hall of Fame horse trainer Bob Baffert's return to Oaklawn Park after a heart attack misstated his record at that track entering the Arkansas Derby. He had won 15 of 24 career starts there, not 14 of 23 or 15 of 25. The article also misstated, in some editions, his number of children. He has five, not four. (Baffert's winning record improved to 16 after his horse Bodemeister won at Oaklawn.)

An obituary on Friday about Stanley R. Resor, who as secretary of the Army from 1965 to 1971 oversaw the troop buildup in Vietnam, misstated the number of United States Army troops there in both 1966 and 1968, and a correction in this space on Monday also gave incorrect figures. The number of Army troops increased to about 360,000 in 1968 from about 117,000 in January 1966, not to 1.5 million from 961,000, as the article initially stated, or to 500,000 from 180,000, as the earlier correction said. (The 1.5 million represented Army troops everywhere during those years and the 500,000 represented all troops in Vietnam at those times, not just Army troops.)

D'URSO--Florence B. Calvary Hospital and Calvary Fund mourn with great sadness the passing of our munificent benefactor and Calvary Fund Board Trustee Emerita, Florence B. D'Urso. Florence was a devout daughter of the Church, and an extraordinary philanthropist. She joined the Calvary Fund Board in 1986, and through the years remained a tireless advocate for the Hospital's patients, families, caregivers, and leadership. She and her late husband, Camillo, were devoted to Calvary, and the Hospital's Florence and Camillo D'Urso Patient Activities Center, where hundreds of patients and families enjoy concerts and holiday celebrations every year, honors their outstanding generosity. In recognition of the D'Ursos' concern for the dignity of human life and service to humanity, in 1987 Calvary presented the Calvary Medal, the Hospital's highest tribute, to Florence and, posthumously, to Camillo. Florence commissioned the Compatior sculpture in 1999, in observance of Calvary's centennial, and in memory of her son, David Francis, and brother, Father Francis Joseph Perkosky, SS, both lost to cancer. Today, the Compatior is the essential symbol of Calvary's compassionate and comprehensive care. Florence will be remembered for her love and knowledge of architecture and art, her life of grace in the face of sorrow, and her deep and abiding faith. We extend our sincere condolences to her daughters Donna and Lisa, her son, Mark, her daughter-in-law, Michelle, her treasured and beloved granddaughter, Michaela Frances, and the entire D'Urso family. Thomas J. Fahey, Jr., MD, Chairman, Calvary Hospital Steven J. Golub, Chairman, Calvary Fund Frank A. Calamari, President and CEO, Calvary Hospital Michael J. Brescia, MD, Executive Medical Director, Calvary Hospital Vincent J. Spinelli, Executive Vice President, Calvary Fund

Louis Langrée, the French conductor who has been a mainstay of the Mostly Mozart Festival as its music director for a decade, will also become music director of the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra. Mr. Langrée, 51, will start his four-year contract the season after next, the Cincinnati Symphony announced on Tuesday, but he will conduct two programs with the orchestra in November. He will immediately put a Francophone stamp on his new job, leading works by Franck, Messiaen and Saint-Saëns in the first set of concerts that month. Mr. Langrée also directs the Camerata Salzburg and conducts around Europe as a guest, with a specialty in period-instrument ensembles. He has considerable experience in opera, too, having served as music director of the Opéra National de Lyon and the Glyndebourne Touring Opera and having led numerous individual opera productions at major houses, including the Metropolitan Opera. Lincoln Center, which presents Mostly Mozart, says Mr. Langrée's contract there runs through the summer of 2014.

A former seniorBloomberg administration official has been fined $22,000 by the New York City Conflicts of Interest Board, primarily for using a city computer account to send e-mails related to her paid service as a board member of a real estate company. Martha E. Stark, a former Finance Department commissioner who resigned in 2009, acknowledged that she sent roughly 300 e-mails from her city account, over a four-year period, related to the Tarragon Corporation. Ms. Stark also acknowledged that she asked a former first deputy commissioner, as well as an executive assistant, to work on administrative tasks related to Tarragon.

''Una Noche,'' or ''One Night,'' a film showing at the Tribeca Film Festival, tells the story of three young Cubans who decide to defect to the United States, and last week the three main actors were scheduled to join the film's director, Lucy Mulloy, at the New York premiere. But a funny thing happened when the plane landed in Miami last Wednesday: two of the actors promptly disappeared. Six days later, the whereabouts of Javier Núñez Florián and Anailín de la Rúa de la Torre remain unknown. They missed the film's opening on Thursday night, and the Spanish-language press in Miami, sensing another opportunity to score points at the expense of the dictatorship that has ruled Cuba for more than 50 years, is now crowing that the pair, imitating the characters they played, have defected - though, in contrast to the film, without having to risk their lives by traveling by sea.

O. Scott wrote in The New York Times.

ROSENBERG--Lawrence Charles.,M.D. Lawrence Charles Rosenberg, M.D., 83, peacefully passed away at his home in Bronxville, NY on April 21, 2012, surrounded by loving and caring family. Born November 23, 1928 in Alexandria, VA, he was the son of Abraham and Cecelia Rosenberg. He graduated Georgetown University in 1948 and earned his medical degree from the Medical College of Virginia in 1953. He completed his internship and residency in Internal Medicine in 1955 at Bellevue Hospital in New York City, after which he was a submarine medical officer with the U.S. Navy in Key West, FL. He began a general surgery residency in 1958 at the Bronx Municipal Hospital Center in New York followed by specialty training in orthopedic surgery, which he completed in 1962. He went on to become Associate Professor of Orthopedic Surgery at New York University School of Medicine where he was actively involved in surgery, education, and research. He was a member of the Alpha Omega Alpha and Sigma Zeta Honorary Scientific Societies and received the Kappa Delta Award for outstanding basic research related to orthopedic surgery in 1970. Academic medicine and research became his primary interests and, in 1976, he was appointed Professor of Orthopedic Surgery at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine and Director of the Orthopedic Research Laboratories at Montefiore Medical Center. He became president of the Orthopedic Research Society in 1981 and received several awards for outstanding achievement in orthopedic research during his lifetime. His field of interest was the structure of cartilage and proteoglycans and he led a distinguished career during which he collaborated with fellow scientists across the country and around the world, and contributed over 100 articles to the scientific literature. Following his retirement from Albert Einstein College of Medicine, he remained active on the editorial boards of various medical journals and, from 1983 to 2003, served as Deputy Editor for the Board of Consulting Editors for Research at the Journal of Bone and Joint Surgery. He met the love of his life, Nancy Sherman, in Woods Hole, MA and they wed in 1951. Their extraordinary, intellectually stimulating, playful, and romantic union lasted thirty-eight years. Larry filled the home with humor, a passion for excellence, and his fierce emotional intelligence. He loved classical music, playing the piano, and delighted his family with brunches and fine dinners, which he would prepare on weekends. He was a highly articulate man of few, carefully chosen words, great charm, gentleness, patience, manners, wisdom, compassion, integrity, and also mystery. He was an exemplary human being, a devoted husband and father, a mentor, and moral compass to family, friends, and colleagues. Larry illuminated our lives with his passion, his playfulness and his eternally young spirit. He had a profound need to share the things that moved him and did so eagerly and generously throughout his life. Beloved husband of the late Nancy Sherman Rosenberg, adored son-in-law of the late Monroe and Gertrude Sherman and brother-in-law of Susan Sherman, devoted father of Eric Rosenberg, Constance Hochman and son-in-law Mark Hochman, Mark Rosenberg, M.D. and daughter-in-law Andrea Needleman, M.D., and Elizabeth Zimmerman; loving grandfather of Amelia and Sarah Hochman, Julian, Jenna, and Meris Rosenberg, and Natalie and Sophia Zimmerman.

The Tennessee Supreme Court has upheld a lower court decision allowing Fisk University to sell a 50 percent stake in a 101-piece art collection donated by Georgia O'Keeffe, The Associated Press reported on Monday. The $30 million sale, to the Crystal Bridges Museum in Bentonville, Ark., had been contested by the Tennessee attorney general, who argued that the sale would inhibit future donations by overriding O'Keeffe's stipulations that the collection never be sold or broken up.

The 144-year-old New York Athletic Club is known for its nurturing role in the history of American amateur sports, the hundreds of Olympic medals its members have won, and its fancy headquarters on Central Park South featuring squash courts, guest rooms, a library and a strict dress code. It has no wish, apparently, to be known for an unscheduled fisticuffs session: a knock-down, drag-out, coed brawl that unfolded at the club's Tap Room in the wee hours of April 13 and ended with two people sent to the hospital and three men under arrest.

3:16 p.m. | Updated BOSTON - Senator Scott P. Brown, Republican of Massachusetts, said on Tuesday that he would release his personal tax returns from the last six years and challenged Elizabeth Warren, his presumed Democratic opponent, to do the same. The candidates have been sparring over tax policy, with Ms. Warren saying that the nation's wealthiest households should be taxed at higher rates, and Mr. Brown countering that raising taxes only increases government spending. Last week, amid the back and forth, The Boston Globe asked both to release six years' worth of tax returns.

LEDERMAN--Mark. We have lost more than a friend; we have lost a unique human spirit, who filled our lives with joy and laughter. Mark sought to capture happiness regardless of the circumstance. What others might have found unattainable, Mark grasped with ease. He treated every individual with equal respect, whether they were the caddies at his golf club or the CEO of a major company. In return, he was loved and special to everyone that had ever known him. They don't make Zionist, patriotic, friendly, down to earth, generous individuals like Mark anymore. He was one of a kind. I will never forget him taking the Israeli Ethiopian students in carts through the Palm Beach Country Club, as if they owned the place, and the caddies and the hired help could not figure out who these VIP's were. He took on challenges of personal best. He loved to run in the New York City marathon. He won golf tournaments, and even with impaired vision, he became an accomplished race car driver. When the doctor told him about the ocular melanoma, Mark said, "I have more to live for than to die for". This was his mantra. A triumph of the human spirit! For Mark, "there were only good days and not such good days". We shall miss his essence. The true caring and love we both had for him will endure forever. This incredible man and his magnificent love of life, and solid allegiance to friendship are irreplaceable. Bonnie and Steven Stern

SCHLESINGER--Edward S. The Rockefeller University deeply mourns the loss of Edward S. Schlesinger, a beloved friend, trusted advisor, and generous benefactor. Ed served as a member of the University's Committee on Trust and Estate Gift Plans for thirty-five years, and was a passionate advocate for the University and its mission to improve human health through scientific research and education. His incisive wit and keen intelligence will be missed by all in the Rockefeller community who had the privilege to know Ed. Over many decades, his tireless efforts and visionary philanthropy helped to advance numerous programs at Rockefeller, including research related to cancer, autism, and vaccine development. Ed was also the devoted father of distinguished Rockefeller faculty member Dr. Sarah "Sally" Schlesinger. We extend heartfelt condolences to Sally and the entire Schlesinger family. Russell Carson, Chairman David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Marc Tessier-Lavigne, President Barry S. Coller, Physician-in-Chief James I. Black, Chair, Committee on Trust and Estate Gift Plans Marnie Imhoff, Vice President

WILLIAMSON--Benjamin Robert, Jr. Inwood House mourns the loss of our dear friend Robert Williamson. Robert saw the potential in each person and situation, and gladly gave of himself by connecting friends, providing sound advice, and generously supporting efforts to help those less fortunate. With his wife Caroline, he was a role model for the parents and citizens we hope all of our young people will become. Our hearts are full for Caroline, our cherished trustee emeritus, and their children and we extend our sympathy to Robert's many family members and friends. Words cannot express our sorrow for Robert's loss, or our gratitude for his profound legacy of hope.

PACAUD--Simonne. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Simonne Pacaud, mother of Annie Cohen and mother-in-law of Robert Cohen. A resident of Toulouse, France, Simonne instilled in her family a rich tradition of philanthropic giving. We extend our deepest condolences to her children, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren. Jerry W. Levin, President Alisa R. Doctoroff, Chair of the Board, John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

SPIELBERGER--Dr. Greta Spanierman. With heartfelt sorrow we announce that Dr. Greta Spanierman Spielberger passed away on April 23, 2012. Greta came to the U.S. after the end of World War II. She had been incarcerated during the War at various concentration camps in Germany including Auschwitz. In 1956, she married Dr. Lawrence Spielberger who practiced anesthesiology at NYU and taught at Bellevue Hospital until his retirement. Greta was an ophthalmologist who saw patients into her early nineties. She will be missed by her cousin Henry Salzberg and his family, her boyfriend Dr. Robson Grier, her nieces by marriage, Dr. Eva J. Allen and Agnes Tombor, nephews by marriage, Dr. Nicholas H. Allen and Gabor Szanto, as well as distant relatives in her native Vienna. Services Friday, April 27th, 12 noon at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Ave at 65th Street. Interment will follow in Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, New York. In lieu of flowers, please contribute to the Cancer Society.

The Philadelphia Orchestra said on Tuesday that it had settled a dispute with its musicians' national pension fund, calling the agreement a ''critical step'' in its effort to emerge from bankruptcy court. The orchestra agreed to pay $1.75 million to the American Federation of Musicians and Employers' Pension Fund, it said, in exchange for the fund's dropping its claims against the orchestra. The orchestra had withdrawn from the fund, prompting the fund to say that it was owed $35 million as a consequence. That was one of the demands dropped under the agreement, the orchestra said. The orchestra filed for bankruptcy protection a year ago, in part to reduce its pension burden. The Philadelphia Orchestra's withdrawal from the national pension caused concern among other orchestras, who felt the move could weaken the fund. The fund challenged the terms of some donations to the orchestra, arguing that orchestra management could have used them for pension obligations but claimed it could not. The orchestra said on Tuesday that the agreement also solved that problem.

STAFFORD--Dr. Inge Paul. Dr. Inge Paul Stafford, 76, of Essex Fells, NJ, died peacefully at home surrounded by her loving family on Monday, April 23, 2012. A funeral service will be held on Friday, April 27, 2012, at 11am in the First Presbyterian Church at Caldwell, NJ. Interment will be private. Born in Frankfurt, Germany, Dr. Stafford lived in North Caldwell before moving to Essex Fells in 1976. A psychologist, Dr. Stafford had a private practice in Montclair for 18 years. Before practicing Dr. Stafford was a teacher in the Verona and West Essex School Systems. A Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Dickinson College of Carlisle, PA, she received a Masters of Teaching from Harvard University School of Education, a Masters in Counseling from Montclair State University, and an EdD in Psychology from Rutgers University in New Brunswick, NJ. She also received an Honorary Doctorate from Dickinson College. Inge served on the Board of Trustees of Dickinson College for 22 years and retired as a Trustee Emeritus, having served as Vice Chairman for several years. She was an ordained elder at the First Presbyterian Church at Caldwell. In addition to the great joy Inge took in spending time with her family, she was an avid gardener, with particular pride in her roses. She enjoyed boating with her husband, Jack, cruising the Atlantic seaboard from Maine to Florida, as well as traveling the world and reading. Surviving are her beloved husband of 52 years, Jack; devoted daughters, Carolyn Stein and her husband, Dr. Eric, Jennifer Farrow and her husband, John, Christina Chapin and her husband, Jason, and Charlotte Stafford; a brother, George Paul; 12 cherished grandchildren, and four adored great-grandchildren; also sisters-in-law Barbara Stafford, Susan Paul and Nancy Stafford and brother-in-law Gordon Stafford. In lieu of flowers, donations to the First Presbyterian Church at Caldwell, 326 Bloomfield Ave., Caldwell, NJ 07006 would be appreciated.

SCHLESINGER--Edward S. The Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion family mourns the passing of Edward S. Schlesinger. His profound commitment to education and the arts inspired the creation of the Irma L. and Abram S. Croll Center for Jewish Learning and Culture, an enduring legacy of his vision that offers enrichment to the larger community, and the Dr. Paul M. and Trudy Steinberg Distinguished Professorship in Human Relations and Counseling, both on our New York Campus. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. May they find comfort together with all those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi David Ellenson, President Irwin Engelman, Chairman Board of Governors

Rotival--Alexander Holt "Sandy", 80, born in Paris, France, passed away on April 22. As a resident of Woodstock, CT, Sandy had a deep personal love for the community and it's history. Throughout his international career, he was a key actor in the emergence of post-colonial West Africa and the social and economic development of the region. He served as Resident Representative of the United Nations in a number of West African countries and established a close rapport with heads of state and their ministerial staffs. Upon his return home, he made significant contributions to the community and to philanthropic organizations such as Celebrating Agriculture, Planning & Zoning and Performing Arts New England. He is survived by his children and their spouses Valerie and Jean-Paul, Laurent and Amy, Constance and Philippe, his grandchildren Chloe, Celine, Alexandre, Julie, Sophie, Isabelle, Theophile, Matthieu, and Edouard, his sister, Denise Huffman, nephew and niece, his cousins, Hamilton Holt, John Holt, Miranda Smith, Coleman Holt, Tappan Holt and Joseph Chadborne, and their spouses and family members. A ceremony in celebration of his life will be held on Saturday, April 28th at the Woodstock Hill Congregational Church at 1100. In lieu of flowers, please consider making a donation to The Connecticut Farmland Trust. If you would like to contact the family, they can be reached at famille.rotival@gmail.com

NARVA--Gale. We at Congregation B'nai Yisrael mourn the death of our friend Gale. We share our sadness with her husband Ken and children Jennifer, Rachel and Carly. We will miss her vibrant love. Lawrence C. Fox, President Rabbi Douglas E. Krantz Rabbi Seth M. Limmer Cantor Hayley Kobilinsky

George Cowan, a chemist who helped build the first atomic bomb, detect the first Soviet nuclear explosion and test the first hydrogen bomb, died on Friday at his home in Los Alamos, N.M. He was 92. The Santa Fe Institute, a scientific research center that Dr. Cowan headed and helped found, announced the death.

CLYMAN--Evelyn nee Greenberg, died peacefully in her home on April 23, 2012 in New York City. She was the widow of the late Dr. Martin J. Clyman and dear mother of Jeffrey (Jacky) Clyman and Sandy (Jonathan) Merrill. Cherished grandmother of Scott Clyman, Mark (Liz) Clyman, Marti Beth Lilien and Dr. Eve Merrill and great-grandmother of Samantha Clyman. Born in New York City on August 27, 1920. She was the beloved daughter of the late Pauline (Gach) and Samuel Greenberg. She is survived by her brother and sister-in-law Eugene and Emily Grant, sister-in-law Vivian (Clyman) Davis and many loving nieces, nephews and grand-nieces and grandnephews. She attended Adelphi College and graduated from New York University with a B.A. in 1940. During WWII she was a Red Cross volunteer in New York. She was also an accomplished interior designer and throughout much of her life was active in many philanthropic institutions in support of the arts, social needs, and medical research. These included: The Jewish Museum, UJA-Federation, Mount Sinai Medical Center and The American Airpower Museum. She served for many years as the President of The Board of the Jewish Repertory Theatre. Her love and knowledge of animals and flowers were boundless and she thoroughly enjoyed both in her country home, year after year. Funeral services, Thursday, April 26, 11:15am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th Street.

RIFKIN--Betty C. 1928-2012. Beloved wife of Abe Rifkin; mother of Marsha, Noah, Laura; grandmother of Marissa, Jack; mother-in-law of Marilyn and Chris. Teacher, Leader, Visionary Alumni, Brooklyn College, Teacher's College, Columbia University.
CLYMAN--Evelyn. We wish to extend our condolences to the family of Evelyn Clyman on the passing of our neighbor and fellow cooperator. The Board of Directors 975 Park Avenue Corp.

The invasion of apps on toys continues with this weeks release of Foam Fighters Pacific from WowWee ($9.99), a set of three-inch styrofoam gliders that you can suction cup under your iPhone's outside camera. Align the wings with an on-screen template and the app's augmented reality features superimpose a WWII dogfight over your living room. Here's how it works. After the free app is installed, you can try a sample training battle with no plane required. But that's not how WowWee gets paid. The fun stuff, like taking out that battleship floating by your lamp, or trying to dive bomb a bunker, requires scanning the wing of a plane. This unlocks one of six the missions, each based loosely on historical WWII battles. Besides being fun and addicting, it's a great way to get very dizzy. During the demo at this year's Toy Fair, up to eight other players could join the fight over your local Wi-Fi connection, a feature that was not working in the version I tried.

VOGEL--Amos, child of Freud's Vienna, survivor, Jew, disenchanted Zionist, Trotskyite, life-long anarchist, loving husband and father, sweet man, champion of freedom of imagination, founder with Marcia of Cinema 16 and co-founder of the NY Film Festival, teacher, sensualist throughout, writer, mentor to many, a man for whom there was no taboo. Hitler failed, Amos is survived by his two loving sons, Steven and Loring, and his four magnificent grandchildren.

WITH the arrival of unconventional new retail ventures like these three, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, already popular as a weekend destination for food and flea, is fast becoming the spot to shop for jewelry and gifts. At Caitlin Mociun's new gallerylike shop, just a stone's throw from Smorgasburg, you'll find her fine gold and sterling silver jewelry surrounded by ceramic bowls and metallic leather Baggu bags. Ms. Mociun's new gemstone pieces, including a tourmaline and diamond cluster necklace for $1,104, are lovely as special-occasion gifts. Down the street at Beautiful Dreamers, a boho haven for charmingly offbeat clothes and trinkets, you'll find Alyssa Norton braided silk bracelets with vintage rhinestones, Adina Mills large crystal quartz rings ($155) and Anndra Neen cage chokers. And at A Thousand Picnics, a rustic jewelry shop and general store from the designers behind the Species by the Thousands and Cold Picnic lines, brass unisex animal necklaces and nature-inspired bangles ($225) are displayed alongside summery macramé plant holders and blankets with leather harnesses.

A picture caption last Thursday with the On Location column, about a house in High Falls, N.Y., owned by Zoe Bissell and Bryan Buryk, misstated the source and cost for a wool and jute ottoman. It is from High Falls Mercantile and cost $375; it was not custom made for $1,500.

9:30 P.M. (NBC) PARKS AND RECREATION Amy Poehler wrote and directed this episode, in which her character, Leslie, finally goes against Bobby Newport (the guest star Paul Rudd, above, with Ms. Poehler), her chief campaign rival, in a televised debate. The Thursday night comedy lineup begins with ''Community,'' at 8, in which the study group, after discovering that its yam experiment has been sabotaged in the science lab, goes in search of the perpetrator for a mock trial presided over by Professor Kane (Michael K. Williams). In a live broadcast of ''30 Rock,'' at 8:30, Kenneth (Jack McBrayer) tries to convince his Kabletown bosses, as well as Liz (Tina Fey) and Jack (Alec Baldwin), that ''TGS'' should remain a live show. And in ''The Office,'' at 9, an unemployed Andy (Ed Helms) crashes a fund-raiser for Senator Lipton (Jack Coleman) and ends up adopting 12 disabled dogs. 11:15 A.M. (Sundance) BLUE BLOOD (2007) Stevan Riley follows the boxers who made the 2005 Oxford University Amateur Boxing Club varsity squad as they fight their peers at Cambridge, a rivalry that has existed for more than 100 years.

NIMS--Nancy Chloe Keyes, 86, formerly of Washington, DC, died on April 24, 2012 in Westwood, MA. Survived by husband of 62 years Hon. Arthur L. Nims, III, daughters Dr. Chloe Nims and Lucy Nims Lafleche, son-in-law Paul Lafleche, and grandsons Sam and David Lafleche. A pianist and graduate of Smith College and the Juilliard School, she lived for music, her friends and her family. Family service in Woods Hole, MA April 28 2pm at the Church of the Messiah. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the music programs of the Washington National Cathedral or of Smith College.

DOTY--George. The Board of Directors of the American Federation for Aging Research is deeply saddened by the passing of Founding Board member George Doty. Mr. Doty and his wife Marie, through their extraordinary generosity and vision helped to lay AFAR's foundation and shaped its mission. He will be sorely missed

NEIDERMAN--Laurie. The Medical Staff of Maimonides Medical Center is deeply saddened by the death of Laurie Neiderman. Laurie was one of the most kind and warmest people you would ever want to know. Together again. Former Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates, after a detour through the Obama administration, announced Wednesday that he was joining former Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and Stephen J. Hadley, a former national security adviser, in their strategic consulting firm. The move reunites the Bush-era foreign policy team. The firm, RiceHadley, will now be known as RiceHadleyGates and will continue to advise companies about doing business in emerging markets like the Middle East, China, Brazil, India and Turkey.

An obituary on Monday and in some editions on Sunday about Charles W. Colson, the aide to President Richard M. Nixon who later became an evangelical leader, misstated the date that the former C.I.A. officer E. Howard Hunt, who had been hired by Mr. Colson to spy on the president's opponents, was arrested in connection with the break-in at the Watergate office complex in Washington. Mr. Hunt was arrested in September 1972 -- not in June 1972, shortly after the break-in, when five other suspects were arrested.

Ever since AT&T first demonstrated its Picturephone video telephone at the 1964 New York World's Fair, the public has been fascinated - at least in theory - with the idea of combining video and voice. But the promise of video calling has never matched its lackluster market acceptance. As users of Google Voice, Skype and other Internet-based video calling products know, unless you're willing to pony up large sums of money for professional videoconferencing gear, picture quality can range from decent to crummy, depending on the speed of the connection. That's true whether you're sitting in front of your computer, or using a webcam with a Skype-compatible HDTV.

The Scouting column last Thursday referred incorrectly to the Dolce Vita store at 255 Elizabeth Street in SoHo. It is the company's newest New York store, not its first. The column also misidentified the department store that sells Dolce Vita shoes. It is Bloomingdale's, not Barneys. And because of an editing error, the column gave an incomplete address for the Treasure & Bond store. It is at 350 West Broadway, not at 350 Broadway.

CHENAULT--Anne N. Mrs. Anne N. Chenault, 98, passed away quietly in her sleep on April 23 at home in Hempstead, New York. Anne (nee Anne Naomi Quick) was born February 23, 1914 to Oscar and Louise Quick in Anderson, South Carolina, the second of ten siblings. The family moved to Brooklyn, where Anne attended public schools. She went on to graduate first in her class from the School of Dental Hygiene at Howard University in 1938, serving as class speaker. At Howard, Anne met her future husband, Hortenius Chenault, a student at the Dental School. They married in 1942 and later moved to Long Island, establishing a successful dental practice in Hempstead. Anne also worked as a dental hygienist for the Department of Health of the City of New York. Anne was a long-time member of the South Hempstead Congregational Church. She served her church selflessly, teaching Sunday school, serving as Vice President of the Women's Fellowship, and in later years taking care of flowers for the altar. She also served as secretary of the Friends of the Hempstead Library, volunteered with a youth organization for women in Long Island, and was an active member of the Links and the NAACP. Anne is survived by her children: Patricia, Arthur, Kenneth and Stephan; her daughters-in-law, Stephanie and Kathryn; her sister Mildred Miller; and her grandchildren, Byron, Jillian, Kenneth, Jr., and Kevin. A wake will be held Friday, April 27th, from 5:00 - 9:00pm at the Carl Burnett Funeral Home, 456 South Franklin Street in Hempstead, New York (516-489-4492). The Home Going Service will be held Saturday at 11:00am at the Congregational Church of South Hempstead, 416 Woodland Drive, South Hempstead (516-489-3610). Burial will follow the service at Greenfield Cemetery in Hempstead and there will be a repast at the Church after the interment at 1:30pm. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions to:The Anne Chenault Scholarship Fund, Howard University College of Dentistry, The Dental Hygiene Program, 2225 Georgia Ave., NW Suite 901, Washington, DC, 20059, Attention: Mr. Haki Halisi.

WILLIAMSON--Robert, Jr. It is with great sadness that the Board and staff of The New York Botanical Garden offer their condolences to Caroline Williamson, a member of the Board of Advisors of the Botanical Garden, on the tragic death of her husband Robert. Caroline is an active member of the Garden's family, chairing benefit events and participating in many other ways, and we extend our deepest sympathies to her and the other members of Robert's family. Maureen K. Chilton, Chairman Gregory Long, President

BARON--Jack, 95, of Pompano Beach, FL, formerly of New York City and Great Neck, Long Island, died at home, surrounded by his loving family on April 25, 2012. He leaves behind his devoted wife of 69 years, Goldie (nee Shapiro) Baron, his beloved children Arthur (Naomi), Judy and Barbara (Clive Miskin), loving grandchildren Joshua, Jessica, Joanna, Alex, Sally and their families, 8 adored great-grandchildren, many nieces, nephews and close friends. Jack was a founding partner of Admiral Photo Offset, a printing firm in lower Manhattan where he worked for 32 years before he retired in 1983. An avid art collector and world traveler, he loved golf, bird-watching, opera and classical music. He was a longtime member of Muttontown Country Club on Long Island and Palm Aire country club in Pompano Beach, FL. Services will be held at Star of David Memorial Garden, at 7701 Bailey Rd., North Lauderdale, FL 33068 on Friday, April 27, 2012 at 1:45pm.

NOLAN--Ellen, formerly of Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, NY, died April 23, 2012, in Port Jefferson, NY. A retired executive assistant to the managing director of McKinsey & Co., NY, she was predeceased by her sister, Annette M. Nolan. She is survived by her brother Richard T. Nolan and wife Barbara, and seven nieces and nephews. Reposing Sunday, April 29, 2012, 2-4pm - 7-9pm at Bryant Funeral Home, 411 Old Town Rd., Setauket, NY. Funeral mass Monday 10am at Infant Jesus Church, Port Jefferson, NY. Interment - St. John's Cemetery, Queens, NY.

The trustees of Jazz at Lincoln Center have reached into the ranks of business leaders in the digital media sector for a new executive director, hiring Greg Scholl, a former NBC Universal executive with a background in digital music distribution, to manage the nonprofit arts institution. Mr. Scholl, 42, will on June 1 replace Adrian Ellis, who resigned in January after steering the organization through a turbulent period of growth. Mr. Scholl's appointment is part of a reorganization being carried out by Wynton Marsalis, the jazz trumpeter and artistic director for Jazz at Lincoln Center, often referred to by the initials J.A.L.C.
TISHMAN--Marcia. Mom, your love and compassion continue to inspire us. We miss you so much. Kisses to Dad. Love, Steven, Andy, Michael and Robert

BASEBALL caps are trending for the ladies this spring. The caps caught our attention on last fall's Miu Miu runway, worn slightly askew, and they popped up again for spring, in leather at Victoria Beckham, in sunny prints at Karen Walker (above). But it was on the street, during the last round of fashion shows, when several women to watch, like Leaf Greener of Elle China (top right) and the blogger Hedvig Opshaug (top left, in Miu Miu), were snapped in the caps, that the look gained legs. ''I don't think it necessarily has anything to do with the athletic 'sporty' trend,'' said Michelle Reneau, the market director at Nylon, who wore a Bill Blass ball cap emblazoned with a gold anchor. ''It's a new way to play down something overly femme.'' For spring, she suggests wearing one with a serious piece, like a pencil skirt, to make the look more playful. Karen Walker cap, $40 at shopkarenwalker.com.
