The crisis confronting the law firm Dewey & LeBoeuf has stunned the legal profession. About 70 of Dewey's 300 partners have left since January after their salaries were slashed because of the firm's weak financial performance. Dewey's woes hardly surprise Michael H. Trotter, a partner at Taylor English Duma in Atlanta who, in addition to a five-decade career as a corporate lawyer, has written two books about the economics and management of law firms.

Upgrading to a new version of Microsoft Office -- and then figuring out where all your favorite commands, menus and tools are in the new version -- is something many users face every few years. To help ease Office workers into the latest edition, Microsoft provides several tutorials for the Mac OS X and Windows versions of the programs in the suite, which includes Word, Excel and PowerPoint. For those feeling their way around Mac Office 2011, Microsoft has free training videos and guides. The training materials can also be downloaded for offline use.

SHEDDING A UNIT The Royal Bank of Scotland, the nationalized British bank run by Stephen Hester, below, will spin off its mergers and acquisitions business by early next year, as the bank cuts back on its investment banking unit, according to people with knowledge of the matter. Under the proposal, 45 bankers will form a new advisory boutique business out of the new unit, said one of the people, who spoke on condition of anonymity. John McIntyre, the bank's head of corporate finance, is expected to run the new operation. MARK SCOTT

One of Morgan Stanley's former real estate executives in China pleaded guilty on Wednesday to violating federal anticorruption laws as the American government continues to crack down on citizens who commit fraud and bribery abroad. The executive, Garth R. Peterson, who once ran the Shanghai office of Morgan Stanley's global real estate business, was charged with secretly acquiring millions of dollars' worth of property investments for himself and a Chinese government official. The official, in turn, steered business to Morgan Stanley's funds, the government said.

In a signal that NBC and the show's producers may believe the future of ''Smash'' lies more in its soap opera elements than its inside look at the creation of a Broadway musical, the new guiding creative hand on the series is going to be Joshua Safran, an executive producer of the glossy CW soap ''Gossip Girl.'' NBC confirmed Wednesday that Mr. Safran is the choice to replace Theresa Rebeck as the hands-on executive producer - also known as show runner - of the second season of ''Smash.'' Because the deal to secure Mr. Safran has not closed, NBC is offering no comment about the direction the network may have in mind for ''Smash,'' which has bounced from critical favorite to something of a critical punching bag in its first season. NBC, which still believes strongly in the potential for the series, announced last month that it was renewing ''Smash'' for a second season, and followed that up almost immediately with the news that Ms. Rebeck, a playwright (her ''Seminar'' is still on Broadway), was departing as the show runner on the series.

WALTERS--Travis Hachy, passed away on April 24, 2012. Just 21 years old, Travis was an accomplished film, TV, and Broadway actor, statewide gymnastics champion, writer, world traveler, treasured friend, and loving nephew, cousin and beloved son of Clyde and Wendy Walters. The funeral is Friday April 27 at 2pm at St. Vartan's Cathedral, 630 Second Ave. and 34th St., with reception afterwards. Donations can be made on www.walkmsnyc.org as Travis would have walked that walk himself.

LAS VEGAS - If the pressure is on Pixar to prove that its creative spark remains intact after the critical crash that was ''Cars 2,'' then the Disney-owned animation studio appears to be rising to the challenge. In a presentation to theater owners here on Monday, John Lasseter, Pixar's chief creative officer (and the director of ''Cars 2''), said the studio has added a movie about the Mexican holiday Día de los Muertos to its slate. The film, which does not yet have a title or a release date, will be directed by Lee Unkrich, who won an Oscar for ''Toy Story 3.'' Mr. Lasseter gave no additional details, but did show a colorful (early) logo with skulls and Mexican marigolds. Pixar likes to keep details of its upcoming movies close to its vest, partly because of competitive concerns; a typical Pixar film takes four years to complete. But Mr. Lasseter did dole out a few more morsels: a previously announced movie pondering what would happen if dinosaurs never became extinct got a title -- ''The Good Dinosaur'' -- and a release date of May 2014; and the next (still untitled) film from Pete Docter (''Up'') will debut in June 2015 and will still take audiences on a journey inside the human mind as previously disclosed. A prequel to ''Monsters Inc.,'' called ''Monsters University,'' is slated for 2013.

The Yale School of Drama and Yale Repertory Theater announced on Wednesday that they had received an $18 million gift - the largest in their history - to finance the creation of new plays and musicals through commissions to writers, developmental workshops and productions at both Yale Rep and other theaters that stage the work. The hub of this playwriting activity will be the newly re-named Binger Center for New Theater (formerly the Yale Center for New Theater), named after the businessman and theater owner James H. Binger, whose philanthropic organization, the Robina Foundation, made the gift of $3 million in operating funds and $15 million for endowment. The Robina Foundation had previously given $3.8 million to establish the theater center at Yale, which since 2008 has financed commissions to more than 30 writers as well as the world premieres and subsequent productions of 12 new plays and musicals - including the critically acclaimed ''Belleville'' by Amy Herzog and ''Good Goods'' by Christina Anderson at Yale Rep this season; Will Eno's play ''The Realistic Joneses,'' also developed at the center, is now running there.

In November, the last time we checked in with David Hallberg, he was emerging from the most celebrated -- and scrutinized -- performance of his life. The ballet world was watching with rapt attention as he made his debut on the historic stage of the Bolshoi Theater in Moscow. Had Sergei Filin risked too much by breaking tradition and hiring an American principal dancer for the Bolshoi Ballet? Had Mr. Hallberg, still a principal at American Ballet Theater, made the right choice, splitting his time between Moscow and Manhattan? And would he recover from the shocking departure of the ballerina Natalia Osipova -- a favorite partner -- for a lesser-known theater in St. Petersburg, financed by a billionaire known as the Banana King?

The N.F.L. draft can be a turning point in a team's history. It can also reaffirm the status quo, for better or worse. The three-day event, which begins Thursday night at Radio City Music Hall, is an opportunity for teams to fill immediate needs, add developmental players or, in a few cases, kick-start franchise-wide paradigm shifts. The Colts have stated that they will take Stanford quarterback Andrew Luck No. 1 over all; the Redskins are enamored of Baylor quarterback Robert Griffin III and will certainly take him second. After that, anything is possible. Here, in alphabetical order, is a peek at the likely shopping lists for all 32 teams. ARIZONA CARDINALS

On the pop charts this week, Lionel Richie holds at No. 1, Maroon 5 has a fast-selling download, and two One Directions compete. Mr. Richie's ''Tuskegee'' (Mercury Nashville), his new album with country-style versions of his old hits like ''Easy'' and ''Hello,'' is No. 1 for a second week in a row, with 114,000 copies sold in the United States, according to Nielsen SoundScan. In its four weeks of release, the album has sold 537,000 copies. Jason Mraz is No. 2 with ''Love Is a Four Letter Word'' (Atlantic), which sold 102,000 in its first week, and another new mellow rock album, Train's ''California 37'' (Columbia), opened at No. 4 with 75,000.

LICHTENSTEIN--Phyllis. BAM mourns true friend and dear wife of former President Harvey Lichtenstein. She personified class & sophistication. Our hearts go out to Harvey, Saul, and John. Karen Brooks Hopkins Joseph V. Melillo Alan Fishman

LEDERMAN--Mark. The Palm Beach Country Club expresses its profound sorrow at the passing of it's esteemed member, Mark T. Lederman, and extends sincere sympathy to his wife, children, grandchildren and other members of his family. William L. Mack, President; Alan Curtis, Secretary

WENGER--Harold Samuel, M.D.,of Wellesley, MA, entered into rest on April 25, 2012. Complete notice will appear in the Friday edition. Services entrusted to the John Everett & Sons Funeral Home of Natick, MA www.everettfuneral.com

Recasting shows can be a challenge for Broadway producers when stars leave once their contracts are up -- even causing some shows to close, as ''Promises, Promises'' did in 2011 when producers saw little upside in replacing Sean Hayes and Kristin Chenoweth. But one Broadway musical has been having a good run with its new leading lady. ''Sister Act'' has been performing far better at the box office since the former child star Raven-Symoné took over the lead role of Deloris Van Cartier on March 27. Now 13 months into its Broadway run, ''Sister Act'' had modest ticket sales at points last fall and then some dreadful winter weeks. No one was blaming its star at the time, Patina Miller, who received a Tony nomination as best actress in a musical last year, and it is too soon to say if Raven, as she is known, has stabilized ticket sales for the long haul.

The Obama administration on Wednesday fired back at an adviser to Mitt Romney who had asserted that the president's economic plans would mean a huge tax increase for all Americans. R. Glenn Hubbard, chairman of the White House Council of Economic Advisers under President George W. Bush and now an adviser to Mr. Romney, wrote in The Wall Street Journal that the spending Mr. Obama proposes for the next decade would require an 11 percent tax increase for Americans who make under $200,000 a year. That would be on top of tax increases Mr. Obama has proposed for higher-income Americans.

Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about a rally in Moscow in response to Patriarch Kirill I's call for the Russian Orthodox Church to defend itself against what he has called a campaign of blasphemy misstated the number of times Vladimir V. Putin has been elected Russia's president. It is three, not two.
GOODMAN--James. To a wonderful man who has been our good friend for many years. We love you and you'll be sorely missed. Marilyn and Richard Davimos

IN the late 1960s, the Dutch designer Marijke Koger, considered the first lady of psychedelic fashion, created costumes for the Beatles and Cream through her art collective the Fool. She also designed clothes for the Beatles' Apple boutique in London. Today, seeing her silk-screened prints, like this look modeled by Raquel Welch, you'd swear you saw their reflection in recent collections of Jonathan Saunders or Christopher Kane. Now, in ''Electrical Banana: Masters of Psychedelic Art'' (Damiani, $39.95 at artbook.com), a book of previously unpublished photos, as well as essays and interviews, Ms. Koger and other artists who defined the look of the '60s get their due. '' 'Hippie' has a bit of a bad name now,'' said Norman Hathaway, an art director who designed for Paul McCartney, and who wrote the book with Dan Nadel. ''People now think about granola and that 'Portlandia' vibe. The stuff in this book is far from that.'' The book also features Mati Klarwein, who painted the cover art for the Miles Davis album ''Bitches Brew,'' and Heinz Edelmann, who created the hallucinogenic landscape of ''Yellow Submarine.'' And there's a foreword interview with Sir Paul.

You can travel the 82 miles from Grand Central Terminal to the remote, pastoral station in Wassaic, N.Y., with no more human engagement than the time it takes a conductor to punch your ticket and walk on. Or you can wind up on Timothy P. Curley's train.

O'KEEFFE--Norrisa (nee Thompson). Norrisa passed peaceful on Sunday April 22, 2012 at the age of 93. She was preceded in death by her loving husband Frank W. O'Keeffe, her father Stanley Thompson and mother Leila Butterfield Carton Thompson. She was a direct decedent of John Butterfield the founder of the American Express Company and General Daniel Butterfield who composed Taps. She is survived by her nieces, Marilise Huyot Flusser, Suzanne Huyot Matthau, and Nicole Huyot Stevenson and nephew Martin Keating. She was raised in Denver Co., Utica NY and New York City. She graduated from Marymount School, Manhattanville College and Columbia University. She enjoyed a long career as a Furniture and Jewelry Appraiser having worked for Tiffany, Sotheby's and O'Reilly Appraisals. Norrisa became a volunteer with the future Cardinal Cooke at Casita Maria in 1938. She was Chairman Emeritus at the time of her death of the Casita Maria Center. Norrisa was a lifelong member of the Ladies of Charity and the Order of the Holy Sepulcher of Jerusalem and Kennedy Child Study Center. Mass of Resurrection at St. Vincent Ferrer R.C. Church on Wednesday, May 9, 2012 at 10:30am. Donations in lieu of flowers to Casita Maria Center, 928 Simpson Street, Bronx, NY 10459. 718-589-2230. scalderon@casitamaria.org

Last Friday the Culture Desk blog of The New Yorker announced a contest asking readers to nominate the word that most urgently needs to be eliminated from the English language. And the results are in: For the next week, no one who speaks English -- or at least writes it on the magazine's Web site -- will be allowed to describe someone else as wearing ''slacks.'' While the word will not be formally banned from the print magazine, Ben Greenman, the contest's organizer, wrote on Monday, there will also be a dead-tree version of the prize: A member of the magazine's esteemed copy department will write the word on a piece of paper, crumple it up and toss it in the garbage.

The About New York column on Friday, about Peter Bulow, a psychiatrist and sculptor who copies the heads of fellow passengers in clay while he rides the subway, misspelled part of the name of the University of Illinois campus where he earned a medical degree and a master of fine arts. It is the campus at Urbana-Champaign (not Champagne).
LEDERMAN--Mark T. Loved family, loved friends, loved Israel, loved golf, loved racing and loved life. We love you and will forever. Margie & Steve Fiverson Nancy & Harold Oelbaum

You don't have to share the Cartwright family's spirit of frontier justice to appreciate the return of a plaque honoring the ''Bonanza'' star Michael Landon to a park in Collingswood, N.J., where the actor grew up, months after it was removed under unclear circumstances. In January, a local weekly newspaper, The Retrospect, said that a reader had come to its offices bearing the marker honoring Landon, who died in 1991, and who lived in Collingswood before going on to find fame on television shows like ''Little House on the Prairie'' and ''Highway to Heaven'' (not to mention films like ''I Was a Teenage Werewolf''). The Retrospect said that the plaque, which was displayed at a small playground whose equipment had been financed by Landon's widow, Cindy, had been found in a ''dump.'' But Jim Maley, the mayor of Collingswood, said the plaque had been removed in November during a cleanup of the park and was being kept temporarily in a ''public works facility.''

An article on April 14 about Wal-Mart Stores' tapping of expertise from environmental groups to further its sustainability efforts referred incompletely to the relationship of one such group, the Environmental Defense Fund, to the company, which is controlled by the Walton family. While the Environmental Defense Fund receives no direct corporate funding from Wal-Mart, it has received grants from the Walton Family Foundation and a member of the Walton family serves on its board of trustees.

Q. I use iPhoto '11 to upload pictures directly to a shared Flickr page. I just opened my own Flickr account, but the iPhoto Share menu only shows the shared original account. I don't see any options for adding the new one on that menu. Does the program work with only one account?

An article on Wednesday about the identification of a case of so-called mad cow disease in a California dairy cow paraphrased erroneously from comments by the United States Department of Agriculture's chief veterinary officer, Dr. John Clifford. It has not been disclosed what prompted a rendering plant to test the animal for the disease, bovine spongiform encephalopathy; Dr. Clifford did not say that the plant noticed symptoms of B.S.E.

LONDON -- Britain has fallen into its first double-dip recession since the 1970s, according to official figures released Wednesday, a development that raised more questions about whether government belt-tightening in Europe has gone too far. The report of an unexpected 0.2 percent decline in economic output during the first quarter of 2012 provoked an outcry in Britain and came on the same day that Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, shifted his rhetoric on the debt crisis to put more emphasis on growth.

Evelyn was admired and appreciated for her wisdom and warmth and for the special relationships that she maintained with the individuals in our office. She will be greatly missed. Richard E. Kobrin, Member

MUZUNGU SISTERS, an online shopping site that promotes the local artisans discovered by Tatiana Santo Domingo and Dana Alikhani on their travels, has collaborated with Missoni and C.B. Made in Italy on a limited-edition collection of slipper-style loafers. C.B. Made in Italy is the creation of a young Milanese woman, Cecilia Bringheli, whose luxurious hand-sewn little slippers are favored by the fashion set. The new shoes are covered in ''upcycled'' Missoni fabrics (materials that would otherwise be waste), and the sales will aid the Small Steps Project, an organization that provides shoes for impoverished children. Available April 30 at muzungusisters.com, $525, with 10 percent of sales donated to smallstepsproject.org.

D'URSO--Florence B. The Board of Trustees, Friends and staff of Inner-City Scholarship Fund mourn the loss of our dear friend and trustee Florence B. D'Urso. Florence meant so much to the ICSF family and touched countless young lives through her support of our mission to make a Catholic school education possible for so many underserved children in New York City. Her spirit will live on through the young people who play the pianos in our schools that she so kindly donated. We offer our deepest condolences to her wonderful children, Mark, Lisa, Donna, her dear granddaughter Michaela and her daughter-in law Michelle. We will miss Florence's loving heart.

LONDON -- Credit Suisse said on Wednesday that its profit fell 96 percent in the first quarter, as the big Swiss bank continued to contend with the dual headwinds of a new regulatory environment and an economic slump. Credit Suisse further reduced its risky assets and said its cost-cutting plan was on track. But some analysts voiced concern about whether the bank could keep up the pace of the reorganization without hurting earnings amid a more difficult market environment.

GOODMAN--James M. The Palm Beach Country Club expresses its profound sorrow at the passing of it's long-time member, James M. Goodman, and extends sincere sympathy to his beloved wife, children, grandchildren and other members of his family. William L. Mack, President; Alan Curtis, Secretary

Has a grandparent mocked your parenting today? Noted that you survived childhood without a five-point car-seat harness, a bike helmet or mandatory fences around every pool? The current generation of parents is used to such things, having been dubbed ''helicopters'' and accused of nearly every kind of overparenting. But safety concerns are well founded. Those helmets, car seats and pool guards? They're working.

An article on April 12 about clothing rescued from the Titantic wreckage referred incorrectly to an honor received by Deborah Nadoolman Landis, the curator of an exhibition on the role of costume design in cinema history. She was an Oscar nominee for best costume design; she did not win the award.

DOTY--Sr. George Espy 94, Wall St. Legend, retired Partner of Goldman Sachs & Co., former Partner of Lybrand, Ross Brothers and Montgomery, veteran of World War II, leading Catholic philanthropist, humanitarian, mentor, cancer survivor, heart attack survivor, miracle worker, longest living Doty of his lineage, devoted husband of the late Marie Doty, beloved father, grandfather, great grandfather, brother and uncle, of Rye, NY, Naples, FL and formerly of Smith's Parish, Bermuda died peacefully at home surrounded by his family on April 24, 2012 after a long illness. He was an inspiration to all who knew him. Born in Manhattan, George was the 4th of 6 children of Dr. George E. Doty and Lillian Gertrude (Bergen). He graduated from Collegiate School in 1934, received a B.S. from Fordham University in 1938 and an M.S. from Columbia University in 1939. He began his career in 1936 working nights as a clerk for the City of New York Department of Sanitation. After graduating from Columbia, he joined Price Waterhouse. His career continued at General Motors before he enlisted to serve in the Navy in 1942. Upon his return from the War, he joined Richards & Ganley before eventually joining Lybrand. He became a senior partner there before joining a client firm, Goldman Sachs in November 1964 as a general partner. He retired and became a "Limited Partner" in November of 1984. He had an extraordinary professional career filled with accomplishment, but he was most proud of his philanthropy, largely inspired by the example of his mentor Gustave Levy, whom he often said was the most generous man he knew. His loyalty and generosity to his family, business partners and friends was unmatched. He served as a trustee of Fordham University from 1971-1980, as Chairman from 1977-1980 and was honored to be considered their most consistent donor. He was the President of the Collegiate School Board Of Trustees from 1972-1977. He was a Director of Foundations & Donors Interested in Catholic Activities (FADICA). He was a former Chairman of the Board of St. Vincent's Hospital. He was a founding member of the American Federation for Aging Research (AFAR) and served as Chairman from 1987-1993. George, a descendant of Edward Doty who came to the United States on the Mayflower, served as Governor of the Society of Mayflower Descendants in the State of New York and as President of the Sons of the Revolution in the State of New York (1967-69). He served as Lieutenant of the Equestrian Order of the Holy Sepulchre of Jerusalem Eastern Lieutenancy. He was a Knight of the Order of Malta. He received an Honorary Doctorate (Doctor of Laws) from Fordham University in 1981 and from Adamson University (Doctor of Humane Letters) in 1994. He will be best remembered for his 63-year marriage to Marie Doty (Ward) who died in 2008. He was a doting and loving husband providing exemplary care particularly during the later stages of her life. He is survived by all of his adoring children, Anne Marie (C. Lawrence) Paine of Fairfield, CT, Barbara Doty of Sag Harbor, NY, Virginia Doty of NYC, George (Le-ellen Spelman) Doty, Jr. of NYC and William (Jana Hale) Doty of Harrison, NY, 16 grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren with another due in July. He is also survived by his loving sister, Joan (Peter) O'Rourke, Palm Springs, CA and 17 nieces and nephews. The family will receive friends on Sunday, April 29th from 12-6 PM at Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Rd., Rye, NY. A Mass of Christian Burial will be offered at the Church of the Resurrection, 910 Boston Post Rd., Rye, NY on Monday, April 30th at 11am. In lieu of flowers, friends are strongly encouraged to make donations in his memory to either Asian Relief, Inc., 180 Admiral Cochrane Blvd., Suite 240, Annapolis, MD 21401 or Catholic Near East Welfare Association, 1011 First Ave., New York, NY 10022.

RETRO geometric prints, sleeveless shifts, false eyelashes: Walk into a dress shop or drugstore these days, and you might think you've been teleported back to 1965. With celebrities like Adele showing off vintage looks, and ''Mad Men'' inspiring makeup by Estée Lauder and clothes by Banana Republic, is it any wonder many women are trying to tease their hair? To achieve volume and sex appeal with this method without resembling an extra from ''Hairspray,'' one need only look to the ultimate 1960s siren, Brigitte Bardot.

Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about Egypt's cancellation of deliveries of natural gas to Israel in a payment dispute referred imprecisely to Israel's relationship to Gaza, which is one of the causes of popular Egyptian anger at Israel. While Gaza's borders are controlled by Israel, and the territory is subject to an embargo Israel imposed in 2007, Gaza is no longer occupied by Israel, which unilaterally withdrew its military forces in 2005. (As the article correctly noted, there is continued occupation of the West Bank by Israel.)

ECKER--Allan B. The partners, counsel, associates and staff of the firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison LLP express profound sorrow of the death on Tuesday, April 24 of our former partner and friend, Allan B. Ecker. We express our deepest sympathies to all members of the family.

DOTY--George E. Fordham University and the Board of Trustees mourn the loss of our alumnus, colleague and great friend, George E. Doty. A graduate of Fordham College, he was a valued member of the Fordham Board of Trustees for many years and later served as Trustee Emeritus until his recent death. From 1977 to 1980 he led the Board as its Chair with great distinction. Fordham was proud to honor Mr. Doty with an honorary Doctorate of Laws degree in 1981 in recognition of his deep commitment and exemplary service to his alma mater. Our thoughts and prayers are with his children, Anne Marie, Barbara, Virginia, George, and William; his sister, Joan; and their families John N. Tognino Chair of the Board of Trustees Joseph M. McShane, S.J. President

An article on April 18 about Coursera, a start-up that seeks to distribute interactive online courses, erroneously included one university on a list of its academic partners. While Princeton, Stanford, the University of Michigan and the University of Pennsylvania are partners with Coursera, the University of California, Berkeley, is not. (It has been experimenting with Coursera's platform but has no formal partnership.)

MARTIN--Robert F.,Somers, NY, resident died at home on April 23, 2012, aged 81. US Army veteran, Iona College alumnus, distinguished teacher of English who served the Yonkers NY public schools for 35 years. Survived by his loving wife of 50 years, Ursula, their two children Robert C. and Lynda, and grandchildren Andrea, Robert "Paddy", Fiona, and Eleri. Services through Clark Associates FH in Katonah, NY.

Walt Disney Pictures has hired the rock singer, guitarist and producer Jack White to write, produce and perform the score for the upcoming ''Lone Ranger,'' the company announced Monday at the CinemaCon theater owners convention in Las Vegas. The film, directed by Gore Verbinski (''Pirates of the Caribbean,'' ''Rango''), stars Johnny Depp as Tonto and Armie Hammer as John Reid and is set for release on May 31, 2013. The score will mark the first time Mr. White, known for his arch and minimalist garage rock, will do an entire score, though he and Alicia Keys wrote and performed the theme song for the 2008 James Bond movie ''Quantum of Solace.'' He also sang several traditional songs, including ''Wayfaring Stranger,'' for the score to ''Cold Mountain.'' It remained unclear how Mr. White would treat the classical theme that has always been associated with the Lone Ranger. ''We're going to have a little rock 'n' roll score, and I can't wait to hear his rendition of the 'William Tell Overture,''' the producer, Jerry Bruckheimer, said at CinemaCon.

A major difference between the recovery from the 2007-9 recession and previous recoveries is that residential construction, usually a major contributor to recovery, has contributed very little. In part, that is because the homebuilding industry was a victim of past recessions but a major cause of the most recent one. Overbuilding, brought on by easy credit, left the economy vulnerable. Now, there are some signs that the overbuilding has been worked off.

Game 7 lived up to its billing Thursday night at a raucous Madison Square Garden. The Ottawa Senators desperately pressed for an equalizing goal in the third period. The Rangers frantically defended their goal, diving to block each shot. Henrik Lundqvist scrambled from post to post to make acrobatic saves. Each loose puck sparked pitched battles along the boards and behind the nets. Even the unflappable Lundqvist was nervous. He called the constant pressure ''nerve-racking.''

An article on Monday about an announcement by Egypt's state-owned natural gas company that it was ending a deal to ship gas to Israel because of a payment dispute misstated the year the two countries signed the Camp David peace accords. It was 1978, not 1979. (The Camp David peace treaty was signed in 1979.) The error was repeated in some copies on Tuesday in a report about Egypt in the World Briefing column and again in later editions when that report was expanded to an article.

BOERI--Dr. Umberto, was born on September 15, 1931 in San Remo, Italy. He passed away on April 16, 2012 in Moorestown, New Jersey. He got his Medical degree at the University of Modena in Italy; he came to the U.S in the early 60's and practiced for over 40 years in both Brooklyn and Manhattan, with H.I.P. and the Board of Education. He was loved by his patients, staff and colleagues. The essence of Dr. Boeri's angelic nature was evidenced by his generosity such that he would often be referred to as Santa Clause by the children around him. Although he was a Pediatrician, Boeri was also a patron to the Arts. As a member of the Metropolitan Opera Guild, he was often a guest of many of the artists such as world famous singers Mirella Freni and Luciano Pavarotti, whom he met in Modena, Italy during the infant stages of their careers. He had a particular love for Opera and for his own enjoyment he would study the voices of famous singers and "not so famous" and discuss their techniques with his circle of friends. Boeri's love for this Art form was deepened by his close relationships to the singers who graced the Operatic stages from the 1950's until the 2000's. The world of Opera and the singers loved him back. Dr. Boeri was a special spirit in this world, he was able to see beauty in everything and his legacy will live on... in the world's beauty. Dr. Umberto Boeri will be laid to rest on Saturday, April 28, 2012 at 12:00pm at the Trinity Church Cemetery on Riverside Drive and 153rd Street, New York City. Condolences may be sent to: Ulises and Celina Espaillat, 10 Kirkbridge Court, Marlton New Jersey, 08053. We ask that any donation in his memory be made to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation: http://www.pdf.org/en/fund/ memdon

LONDON - European banks can't shake the region's debt crisis. On Thursday, Deutsche Bank, the largest bank in Germany, said its profit fell 34 percent to 1.4 billion euros ($1.85 billion) in the first quarter, with the economic malaise depressing trading and investment banking activities. A Spanish rival, Banco Santander, reported that its net profit dropped 24 percent to 1.6 billion euros over the same period, as the bank experienced a sharp rise in troubled loans.

Ann Romney had ''a little bit of a scare'' involving her multiple sclerosis before Super Tuesday, she told ''Entertainment Tonight'' in an interview set to be broadcast Thursday evening. Mrs. Romney, the wife of Mitt Romney, received a diagnosis of multiple sclerosis in 1998, and has learned to largely control her disease through a combination of diet, exercise and horse therapy. But she told Nancy O'Dell of ''Entertainment Tonight'' that in the days leading up to Super Tuesday -- a day in early March when 10 states held votes -- she ''was quite fatigued.''

One of the original owners of Hulu, Providence Equity Partners, is selling its stake, people with knowledge of the impending sale said on Thursday. Providence, a private equity firm, invested about $100 million in Hulu, an online video Web site, when it was formed five years ago. The firm joined the NBC owner NBCUniversal and the Fox owner News Corporation in the joint venture, which has become a profitable business with tens of millions of users and two million paying subscribers.

An interview on the DealBook page on Thursday with Michael H. Trotter, an author of two books about the economics and management of law firms, omitted two words in an answer by Mr. Trotter to a question about a practice of recruiting lawyers by offering them guaranteed contracts. Mr. Trotter said: ''That's a very risky strategy. For one thing, people don't always produce what they promise; often not all the clients that they currently have move with them, so to give anyone a guaranteed contract based on their past success is basically a mistake.'' (The words ''not all'' were omitted.)

Cissy Houston, the gospel singer and mother of Whitney Houston, met with publishers in New York this week to shop a book about her daughter, several people who were in the meetings said. Affectionately calling her daughter ''Nippy,'' her childhood nickname, and appearing emotionally and physically drained, Ms. Houston met with publishers in a suite at the St. Regis Hotel, said the people, who declined to be identified because the negotiations were still going on.

CLYMAN--Evelyn nee Greenberg, died peacefully in her home on April 23, 2012 in New York City. She was the widow of the late Dr. Martin J. Clyman and dear mother of Jeffrey (Jacky) Clyman and Sandy (Jonathan) Merrill. Cherished grandmother of Scott Clyman, Mark (Liz) Clyman, Marti Beth Lilien and Dr. Eve Merrill and great-grandmother of Samantha Clyman. Born in New York City on August 27, 1920. She was the beloved daughter of the late Pauline (Gach) and Samuel Greenberg. She is survived by her brother and sister-in-law Eugene and Emily Grant, sister-in-law Vivian (Clyman) Davis and many loving nieces, nephews and grand-nieces and grandnephews. She attended Adelphi College and graduated from New York University with a B.A. in 1940. During WWII she was a Red Cross volunteer in New York. She was also an accomplished interior designer and throughout much of her life was active in many philanthropic institutions in support of the arts, social needs, and medical research. These included: The Jewish Museum, UJA-Federation, Mount Sinai Medical Center and The American Airpower Museum. She served for many years as the President of The Board of the Jewish Repertory Theatre. Her love and knowledge of animals and flowers were boundless and she thoroughly enjoyed both in her country home, year after year. Funeral services were held on Thursday, April 26.

Virginia Commonwealth University has long been one of the leading public university graduate arts and design programs in the country. Now it also wants to be a cultural destination for audiences and performers. The university on Wednesday unveiled the design for a new $32 million Institute for Contemporary Art, designed by Steven Holl and Chris McVoy of Steven Holl Architects. Calling the 38,000-square-foot building ''part exhibition and performance space, part lab and incubator,'' the university said the institute will feature a series of flexible programming spaces for visual art, theater, music, dance and film.There will be an auditorium with more than 240 seats, a sculpture garden, classrooms and a cafe. The project is scheduled to open in 2015; $14 million has been raised so far. A search for a director is underway, and the university hopes to break ground in 2013. Mr. Holl also designed the Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art in Kansas City; the School of Art & Art History at the University of Iowa; and an expansion for the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston. His design will be presented in an exhibition opening April 26 at the Meulensteen gallery in New York.

CHENAULT--Anne N. Mrs. Anne N. Chenault, 98, passed away quietly in her sleep on April 23 at home in Hempstead, New York. Anne (nee Anne Naomi Quick) was born February 23, 1914 to Oscar and Louise Quick in Anderson, South Carolina, the second of ten siblings. The family moved to Brooklyn, where Anne attended public schools. She went on to graduate first in her class from the School of Dental Hygiene at Howard University in 1938, serving as class speaker. At Howard, Anne met her future husband, Hortenius Chenault, a student at the Dental School. They married in 1942 and later moved to Long Island, establishing a successful dental practice in Hempstead. Anne also worked as a dental hygienist for the Department of Health of the City of New York. Anne was a long-time member of the South Hempstead Congregational Church. She served her church selflessly, teaching Sunday school, serving as Vice President of the Women's Fellowship, and in later years taking care of flowers for the altar. She also served as secretary of the Friends of the Hempstead Library, volunteered with a youth organization for women in Long Island, and was an active member of the Links and the NAACP. Anne is survived by her children: Patricia, Arthur, Kenneth and Stephan; her daughters-in-law, Stephanie and Kathryn; her sister Mildred Miller; and her grandchildren, Byron, Jillian, Kenneth, Jr., and Kevin. A wake will be held Friday, April 27th, from 5:00 - 9:00pm at the Carl Burnett Funeral Home, 456 South Franklin Street in Hempstead, New York (516-489-4492). The Home Going Service will be held Saturday at 11:00am at the Congregational Church of South Hempstead, 416 Woodland Drive, South Hempstead (516-489-3610). Burial will follow the service at Greenfield Cemetery in Hempstead and there will be a repast at the Church after the interment at 1:30pm. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions to:The Anne Chenault Scholarship Fund, Howard University College of Dentistry, The Dental Hygiene Program, 2225 Georgia Ave., NW Suite 901, Washington, DC, 20059, Attention: Mr. Haki Halisi.

Early in Raymond De Felitta's documentary of the 1960s-era South, ''Booker's Place: A Mississippi Story,'' a couple of tales are quickly told about black men who were shot or beaten for their transgressions against whites: one for inadvertently brushing his mop against a woman's foot, another for touching someone's car. The anecdotes lay down the law as it stood shortly before the time Booker Wright, a black waiter, made the fateful decision to explain to a documentary crew for NBC News not only what he served white customers but also how he felt about their varied treatment of him. He was beaten for his brave, conscientious honesty, and his own business (the Booker's Place of the title) was torched. Mr. De Felitta's moody, well-rounded film (which is also playing in the Tribeca Film Festival) is a kind of excavation and investigation of Mr. Wright's actions as a piece of civil rights history.

An article on Wednesday about an effort to bring food from the region's midsize farms to the Hunts Point wholesale produce market in the South Bronx misstated the number of states from which produce is brought to the market. The produce comes from New York, New Jersey and 47 other states -- not from New York, New Jersey and 49 states, as stated in some editions, or from 47 states, as noted in other editions.

BOSTIAN--Barry, retired educational publishing executive, died of lung cancer Monday, April 22, at his home in Orlando, FL. He was 71. He is survived by his wife of 51 years, Donaline Jordan Bostian of Orlando; two children, daughter Beth Bostian of Richmond, VA, and son Matthew Adam Bostian of Orlando; and sister Betty Boliek of Augusta, GA. Born in Concord, NC, on August 27, 1940, Barry was the son of Herman C. and Helen O. Bostian of nearby Kannapolis, NC. He graduated from A.L. Brown High School in Kannapolis in 1958 and from what is now Lenoir-Rhyne University in Hickory, NC, in 1961. That same year he married Donaline Jordan of Kannapolis. He began his career in 1961 teaching English at Concord High School. After completing his master's degree at the University of North Carolina, he continued teaching at what is now Pfeiffer University in Misenheimer, NC. His special literary interest was the American novel, and his favorite authors were Mark Twain, John Steinbeck, Ernest Hemingway, and others who wrote to communicate rather than obfuscate. His favorite novel was Twain's Huckleberry Finn, which he felt was, for those who read between the lines, the most powerful argument against slavery and racial prejudice ever written. In 1967, he joined publisher Harcourt Brace & World, which was about to launch a highly innovative grammar textbook series for elementary and junior high schools. He remained at Harcourt for 36 years, serving in various management and administrative capacities. In the early 1980s, just as computer technology was beginning to impact schools, he was named Vice President and Director of Technology Marketing. He retired from Harcourt in 2003 and worked as a part-time representative for the Command Group of Printing Companies, based in Secaucus, NJ. He was an avid golfer and author of The Fairly Official NESH Guide To Great Golf Games, a privately published book distributed to friends and members of the Noble and Exalted Society of Hackers, a golf club he co-founded. He was interested in birds and indulged his passion for plants by fastidiously caring for a collection of orchids amassed over three decades. A celebration of his life will be held at the family home in Orlando on May 4, 2012. In lieu of flowers, please consider planting a tree or shrub with Barry in mind or making a donation to the Orange Audubon Society at www.orangeaudubonfl.org.

The Blue Note Jazz Festival, which had its inaugural run last June, will return this year, June 10 through 30. Presented by the Blue Note Entertainment Group, which operates the Blue Note jazz club, the Highline Ballroom and B.B. King Blues Club, the festival chiefly involves those three rooms, with a few exceptions. There are fewer shows this year than last, but the festival covers much of the same ground. Among the repeat bookings are the Manhattan Transfer; the funk bassists Bootsy Collins and George Porter Jr.; the veteran jazz pianist McCoy Tyner; the bassist and vocalist Meshell Ndegeocello; and the tap dancer Savion Glover, whose weeklong run will feature Mr. Tyner followed by the master drummers Jack DeJohnette and Roy Haynes.

Rotival--Alexander Holt "Sandy", 80, born in Paris, France, passed away on April 22. As a resident of Woodstock, CT, Sandy had a deep personal love for the community and it's history. Throughout his international career, he was a key actor in the emergence of post-colonial West Africa and the social and economic development of the region. He served as Resident Representative of the United Nations in a number of West African countries and established a close rapport with heads of state and their ministerial staffs. Upon his return home, he made significant contributions to the community and to philanthropic organizations such as Celebrating Agriculture, Planning & Zoning and Performing Arts New England. He is survived by his children and their spouses Valerie and Jean-Paul, Laurent and Amy, Constance and Philippe, his grandchildren Chloe, Celine, Alexandre, Julie, Sophie, Isabelle, Theophile, Matthieu, and Edouard, his sister, Denise Huffman, nephew and niece, his cousins, Hamilton Holt, John Holt, Miranda Smith, Coleman Holt, Tappan Holt and Joseph Chadborne, and their spouses and family members. A ceremony in celebration of his life will be held on Saturday, April 28th at the Woodstock Hill Congregational Church at 1100. In lieu of flowers, please consider making a donation to The Connecticut Farmland Trust. If you would like to contact the family, they can be reached at famille.rotival@gmail.com

Paola Morsiani, the curator of contemporary art at the Cleveland Museum of Art, has been appointed the director of the Neuberger Museum of Art of the State University of New York at Purchase, Thomas J. Schwartz, the president of the college, announced Wednesday. Ms. Morsiani, 50, will become the seventh director of the nation's 10th largest university art museum, which has a collection of over 8,000 works in all media. Ms. Morsiani is replacing Thomas Collins, who led the institution for five years before leaving in 2010 to become director of the Miami Art Museum.

While a roundup of all the different cuts of ''Blade Runner'' would be able to fill its own retrospective, the Film Society of Lincoln Center is taking a broader approach to a coming tribute to the director Ridley Scott, whose movies have visited the far-flung future, outer space, ancient Rome, not-so-merry olde England and points in between. On Thursday, the Film Society said that between May 25 and June 3 it would present a retrospective of the films of Mr. Scott (whose latest sci-fi adventure, ''Prometheus,'' is planned for a June 8 release), with a lineup of 19 features including mainstream breakthroughs like ''Alien'' and ''Blade Runner,'' hits like ''Gladiator'' and ''Thelma & Louise'' and lesser-known works from the director's career.

WENGER--Harold "Doc", 61, passed away Wednesday, April 25, 2012 at his home in Wellesley, MA. Harold was born in Germany on December 12, 1950, and came to the United States with his parents Fay and Jack Wenger, refugees of the Holocaust. Harold was a graduate of Rutgers University and Cornell Medical School where he received his medical degree. Harold completed his medical residency at Michael Reese Hospital in Chicago, IL and his surgical residency at Boston Medical Center. In 1984, Harold founded Baystate Medical and Surgical, an independent physician staffing company in Massachusetts. Aside from medicine, Harold was a "Jack of all trades", best known for his sharp tongue, big heart, and unique sense of fashion. Harold leaves his wife, Katherine Wenger of Wayland, MA; daughter Julia Wenger of Framingham, MA; son, Alexander Wenger of Northampton, MA; and sister, Sylvia Rogowski, of Merrick, NY. The Wenger family will receive visitors in the John Everett & Sons Funeral Home, 4 Park St. (at Natick Common) Natick, MA on Sunday, April 29, 2012 from 1-4pm. Burial will be private in Beit Olam - East Cemetery, Wayland, MA. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations to be made by check payable to Eastern Middlesex Alcoholism Services, c/o Tim McCarthy, 12 Cedar St., Malden, MA 02148. For online guestbook please visit www.everettfuneral.com.

SMITH--David Shiverick, 94 years old, of West Palm Beach, FL passed away peacefully at his home on Friday, April 13, 2012. Born on January 25, 1918 in Omaha, NE, he was educated in Omaha and attended the Sorbonne in Paris. He graduated magna cum laude from Dartmouth College where he was a Phi Beta Kappa and graduated from Columbia University Law School. A four year veteran of WW II, he served as a lieutenant in the U.S. Navy in the South Pacific where he received the Purple Heart. He practiced law in New York City and Washington, D.C. He was a Dean of Columbia's Graduate School of International Affairs and served as U.S. Ambassador to Sweden during the Ford Administration. He is survived by his wife of 40 years, Mary Edson Smith; his three children, Edward John Noble Smith (Maribeth), David Shiverick Smith, Jr. (Jordan) and Jeremy Tinkham Smith and six grandchildren: Zeb, Sarah, Jay, Tate, Niva and Eleanor. He was predeceased by his son Bradford Delano Smith in 2008. A Memorial Service will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, those who wish may make a contribution in his memory to the charity of their choice.

Michelle Obama's summer vacation to Spain in 2010 cost taxpayers more than $467,000 in transportation and security expenses, according to a watchdog group that obtained federal records. The disclosure came at a time when Republicans were already pressing President Obama about billing trips to the government that seem campaign-oriented. Speaker John A. Boehner, Republican of Ohio, called on the president Thursday to reimburse taxpayers for this week's trip to three battleground states.

LONDON - Britain's securities regulator once had a reputation for taking a light-touch approach to regulation. No longer. FERRARA--Dr. Marianne F. Schwob of Highland Village, Texas passed away on April 20, 2012 surrounded by her family after a struggle with cancer. A mass will be held at 5pm on Monday, April 30 at St. Philip the Apostle Catholic Church, 1897 W. Main St. Lewisville 75067, with a reception to follow.

Signature Theater on Thursday announced world premiere productions of plays by Sam Shepard (''True West'') and David Henry Hwang (''Chinglish'') during the next 18 months, while another respected Off Broadway stalwart, the Atlantic Theater Company, announced its own world premieres by John Guare (''The House of Blue Leaves'') and Melissa James Gibson (''This'') for its 2012-13 season. Signature, which moved into its new $66 million complex of three theaters this winter, will produce three plays by Mr. Hwang as part of its mission to present several works consecutively by a single playwright. In fall 2013 the director Leigh Silverman, who staged ''Chinglish'' on Broadway last fall, will mount Mr. Hwang's new play ''Kung Fu,'' inspired by the life of Bruce Lee, about a young martial artist who comes to America from Hong Kong in the 1960s dreaming to be a movie star.

PLEA FOR TIGHTER REGULATION The lawmakers who sponsored an effort to rein in risky trading on Wall Street are urging regulators to complete a forceful version of the Volcker Rule by the summer. In a letter authored by Democratic Senators Carl Levin of Michigan, left, and Jeff Merkley of Oregon, a group of 22 senators called for regulators to adopt a final rule free from loopholes and concessions to Wall Street. BEN PROTESS

10 P.M. (NBC) DATELINE NBC In 2004 4-year-old Sean Goldman was taken from New Jersey to Brazil by his mother, Bruna Bianchi, for what was supposed to be a two-week vacation to her native country. Instead she cut off ties with Sean's biological father, David Goldman (above, with Sean), divorced him and married a lawyer from a prominent family while keeping her son in Brazil. When Sean was 8, Ms. Bianchi died after childbirth, and his stepfather moved to adopt him. This forced Mr. Goldman to fight for Sean's return and set off an international case that lasted until father and son were reunited on Christmas Eve 2009. Sean, now 11, speaks here with Meredith Vieira in his first interview. 8 A.M. (IFC) THE DIVING BELL AND THE BUTTERFLY (2007) In 1995 Jean-Dominique Bauby, a 43-year-old French fashion magazine editor and something of a playboy, had a stroke that left him with a condition called locked-in syndrome, in which he retained vision, hearing and a perfectly functioning mind but was left almost completely paralyzed. He told his story in a book that he dictated to an assistant by blinking. In this third feature film from the artist Julian Schnabel, Bauby is played by Mathieu Amalric; Emmanuelle Seigner is Céline, the longtime partner he has recently left and the mother of his three children; and Marie-Josée Croze is the speech therapist who teaches him to use his left eyelid to communicate. ''The phrase 'triumph of the human spirit' hovers over 'The Diving Bell and the Butterfly,' along with a swarm of other empty, uplifting clichés,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. Still, he added, Mr. Schnabel ''demonstrates his own imaginative freedom in every frame and sequence, dispensing with narrative and expository conventions in favor of a wild, intuitive honesty.''

MacLEAN--John L. April 24, 2012. Died at Calvary Hospital after a long battle with cancer. Survived by wife Nina, beloved children Monika, Rose, Ryan, William and countless wonderful friends. Predeceased by son Sean. John's love of life will be remembered by many. Funeral Mass at later date. In lieu of flowers, please donate to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center or Calvary Hospital.

An obituary on Thursday about the chemist George Cowan, who helped build the first atomic bomb, misstated the name of the university from which he received a doctorate after World War II. It was the Carnegie Institute of Technology -- not Carnegie Mellon University, which was established in 1967 when the Carnegie Institute of Technology merged with the Mellon Institute.

Why let a little thing like death get in the way of a lucrative reunion? The two surviving members the girl group TLC are planning a reunion tour that will use video projections of Lisa Lopes, who died in a car crash a decade ago, according to the celebrity-watch Web site TMZ. A representative for the group told TMZ that Tionne Watkins, known as T-Boz, and Rozonda Thomas, called Chilli, were planning a North American tour to start later this year and that they had already reserved performance spaces in five major cities. It remains unlikely that the group will use the same technology Dr. Dre and Snoop Dogg used recently to make a ghostly image of Tupac Shakur, who died in 1996, during a performance at the Coachella music festival. But Ms. Watkins and Ms. Thomas do plan to project images of Ms. Lopes, known as Left Eye, onto a screen. They will then harmonize with recordings of her vocal tracks.

DOTY--Sr. George Espy 94, Wall St. Legend, retired Partner of Goldman Sachs & Co., former Partner of Lybrand, Ross Brothers and Montgomery, veteran of World War II, leading Catholic philanthropist, humanitarian, mentor, cancer survivor, heart attack survivor, miracle worker, longest living Doty of his lineage, devoted husband of the late Marie Doty, beloved father, grandfather, great grandfather, brother and uncle, of Rye, NY, Naples, FL and formerly of Smith's Parish, Bermuda died peacefully at home surrounded by his family on April 24, 2012 after a long illness. He was an inspiration to all who knew him. Born in Manhattan, George was the 4th of 6 children of Dr. George E. Doty and Lillian Gertrude (Bergen). He graduated from Collegiate School in 1934, received a B.S. from Fordham University in 1938 and an M.S. from Columbia University in 1939. He began his career in 1936 working nights as a clerk for the City of New York Department of Sanitation. After graduating from Columbia, he joined Price Waterhouse. His career continued at General Motors before he enlisted to serve in the Navy in 1942. Upon his return from the War, he joined Richards & Ganley before eventually joining Lybrand. He became a senior partner there before joining a client firm, Goldman Sachs in November 1964 as a general partner. He retired and became a "Limited Partner" in November of 1984. He had an extraordinary professional career filled with accomplishment, but he was most proud of his philanthropy, largely inspired by the example of his mentor Gustave Levy, whom he often said was the most generous man he knew. His loyalty and generosity to his family, business partners and friends was unmatched. He served as a trustee of Fordham University from 1971-1980, as Chairman from 1977-1980 and was honored to be considered their most consistent donor. He was the President of the Collegiate School Board Of Trustees from 1972-1977. He was a Director of Foundations & Donors Interested in Catholic Activities (FADICA). He was a former Chairman of the Board of St. Vincent's Hospital. He was a founding member of the American Federation for Aging Research (AFAR) and served as Chairman from 1987-1993. George, a descendant of Edward Doty who came to the United States on the Mayflower, served as Governor of the Society of Mayflower Descendants in the State of New York and as President of the Sons of the Revolution in the State of New York (1967-69). He served as Lieutenant of the Equestrian Order of the Holy Sepulchre of Jerusalem Eastern Lieutenancy. He was a Knight of the Order of Malta. He received an Honorary Doctorate (Doctor of Laws) from Fordham University in 1981 and from Adamson University (Doctor of Humane Letters) in 1994. He will be best remembered for his 63-year marriage to Marie Doty (Ward) who died in 2008. He was a doting and loving husband providing exemplary care particularly during the later stages of her life. He is survived by all of his adoring children, Anne Marie (C. Lawrence) Paine of Fairfield, CT, Barbara Doty of Sag Harbor, NY, Virginia Doty of NYC, George (Le-ellen Spelman) Doty, Jr. of NYC and William (Jana Hale) Doty of Harrison, NY, 16 grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren with another due in July. He is also survived by his loving sister, Joan (Peter) O'Rourke, Palm Springs, CA and 17 nieces and nephews. The family will receive friends on Sunday, April 29th from 12-6 PM at Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Rd., Rye, NY. A Mass of Christian Burial will be offered at the Church of the Resurrection, 910 Boston Post Rd., Rye, NY on Monday, April 30th at 11am. In lieu of flowers, friends are strongly encouraged to make donations in his memory to either Asian Relief, Inc., 180 Admiral Cochrane Blvd., Suite 240, Annapolis, MD 21401 or Catholic Near East Welfare Association, 1011 First Ave., New York, NY 10022.

-This one's for the birds. The New York Times reported on Monday that standing water - in a puddle or even a birdbath - can subject the offending property owner to a fine of up to $2,000. It's a violation of the New York City health code aimed at combating mosquitoes that carry West Nile virus. So when a reader who lives in the neighborhood pointed out that there's a forlorn birdbath next to City Hall in Lower Manhattan, we just had to investigate.

Honda and Acura top the list of car brands that best retain their value over time, according to an annual ranking from the automotive site Edmunds.com. Honda ranked highest in the nonluxury category, with a projected retained value of about 48 percent, on average, after five years, Edmunds found. Acura was first in the luxury category, with an average retained value for its models of about 45 percent.

More than a dozen prominent pop singers and rock bands have joined a campaign aimed at forcing The Village Voice to stop running ads on Backpage.com for escorts, strip-clubs and other ''adult services,'' a publicist for the campaign said. The list of bands who have signed a petition against the ads includes the former members of R.E.M and the members of the Roots, Alabama Shakes, the Civil Wars and Drive-By Truckers. Among the singers who have lent their support are Alicia Keys, Rosanne Cash and Talib Kweli. -Village Voice Media, whose 13 weeklies include The Village Voice, Westword and Phoenix New Times, has been under fire for eight months for continuing to run the ads, which critics say lead to the exploitation of minors. Last August the country's 51 attorneys general sent a letter demanding that the company close down the adults section on its Backpage.com, much of it related to the sex trade.

Just as they do every year, the famous officials, journalists and Hollywood stars will gather Saturday night at the White House Correspondents' Association dinner for an odd mix of celebrity and wonkdom. And just as it is every year, it will probably not be the highlight of the president's week.

An article in Thursday's paper tracks the growing interest among major banks in offering prepaid debit cards, check cashing and wire transfers. Reading it together with a Bucks post from a few months back about the rise of payday-loan-like cash advance services from major financial institutions, you begin to understand just how seriously the banks take the idea of competing with old-fashioned currency exchanges and other storefront money centers that are known for their high fees and exorbitant interest rates. Whether you like these types of products and services or not, millions of people need them (or have come to rely on them, at least). So are banks better positioned to treat the customers who need these offerings fairly?

The Pied-A-Terre hostel in Washington Heights advertised Wi-Fi, breakfast and access to barbecue equipment at bargain prices. The Loftstel in Brooklyn offered dorm-style beds for $25 a night, and three-bedrooms for just $195. In a city where a hotel room often costs a week's pay, they seemed attractive options. But there was one big problem: these arrangements, city officials said, were illegal.

LICHTENSTEIN--Phyllis Ann Holbrook. Phyllis died on April 22, 2012 after a brave battle against cascading complications following a kidney transplant. She was just days short of her 70th birthday. Phyllis was a warm, beautiful, intelligent, generous, and gracious lady, and she will be sorely missed by all who knew her. The only daughter of the late John and Alice Holbrook, she leaves behind her husband, Harvey Lichtenstein, former President of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, their son John, her stepson Saul, and her three brothers John, David, and Peter Holbrook. There will be a memorial service on Friday, May 11, 11am at Calvary Church, 277 Park Avenue South in New York. A lunch reception will follow at the National Arts Club from 12:00 to 2:30. All relatives and friends will be welcome. In lieu of flowers, please donate something to your favorite charity in memory of Phyllis.

Nearly 50 years after he sounded ''Chimes of Freedom'' on one of his earliest folk-rock albums, Bob Dylan, the mercurial pop troubadour, will be rewarded with a Presidential Medal of Freedom, the highest civilian honor given by the United States, alongside such noteworthy figures as Toni Morrison, Madeleine Albright, John Glenn and John Paul Stevens. The White House said in a statement that President Obama had named 13 recipients of the medal, which is granted to ''individuals who have made especially meritorious contributions to the security or national interests of the United States, to world peace, or to cultural or other significant public or private endeavors.''

The Manhattan district attorney's office is investigating accusations of wrongdoing at the troubled law firm Dewey & LeBoeuf, the firm said on Friday. Dewey acknowledged the investigation in an internal memorandum sent to its partners. The firm said that state prosecutors were focused on misconduct by Steven H. Davis, its former chairman, who helped drive the 2007 merger that formed the firm. The memorandum also said that the firm had asked two of its own lawyers to conduct an internal investigation into the accusations.

Mitt Romney effectively wrapped up the Republican presidential nomination. Newt Gingrich said he would drop out. President Obama stumped through key swing states. But there's a case to be made that the developments this week with the greatest long-term meaning for American politics took place across the Atlantic, not in Washington or New Hampshire or Iowa. In Britain, the economy lapsed into a double-dip recession, a result in part of a strict fiscal austerity plan imposed by the conservative government. And political tremors swept across the Continent as the European Union engaged in a fierce battle over whether Germany is demanding excessively deep budget cuts in the effort to keep debtor countries from financial collapse.

The conductor Kurt Masur, 84, is said to be in good condition in a Paris hospital after having fallen off the podium and into the audience last night while leading the Orchestre National de France at the Théâtre des Champs-Élysées. The fall occurred during the second and final work on the program, Tchaikovsky's Symphony No. 6 (''Pathétique''), in the midst of the third movement, ''Allegro molto vivace.'' Mr. Masur's assistant, Stefana Atlas, said that the fall resulted from an accident rather than his increasingly frail physical condition, which has led him to cancel some performances in recent months. ''Even though he has a railing at the back of the podium,'' Ms. Atlas said in a telephone interview, ''he didn't realize his left foot was close to the left edge and he fell behind into the audience, hitting his shoulder.'' Ms. Atlas said that Mr. Masur remained conscious and was taken to the hospital, where X-rays and other scans showed no major injuries or broken bones. She said that he would probably be released after another day or two of observation. Mr. Masur, who was the music director of the New York Philharmonic from 1991 to 2002 and is the honorary music director of the Orchestre National de France, is next scheduled to conduct the Dresden Philharmonic in Beethoven's Eighth and Ninth Symphonies on May 5 and 6. Ms. Atlas said that no decision had yet been made about whether Mr. Masur would be able to keep that engagement.

BIRCKHEAD--Oliver. Oliver Birckhead, of Cincinnati, Ohio was born June 20, 1922 in Brooklyn and graduated from Trinity-Pawling School, Pawling, New York, Nichols College, Dudley, Massachusetts in 1942 and Stonier Graduate School of Banking, Rutgers University. He passed away on April 27, 2012. Mr. Birckhead, who was honored as a Great Living Cincinnatian in 2003, was President and CEO of The Central Bancorporation which later merged into PNC Bank where he became Vice Chairman and Director until he retired in 1989. Mr. Birckhead is survived by his wife Jane, two sons, Dr. Oliver Birckhead, III, Randall Birckhead, daughters-in-law Leslie Birckhead, Deborah Birckhead and grandchildren Oliver IV, Laura, Sarah, Rebecca and Elizabeth.

8 P.M. (HBO) LARRY CROWNE (2011) Tom Hanks directed and stars in this romantic comedy about a divorced former Navy cook turned overzealous chain store worker who finds his employee-of-the-month run squelched when his bosses inform him that they're letting him go because he doesn't have a college degree. Julia Roberts, above with Mr. Hanks, is the community college speech teacher with a morning margarita problem who gives him the opportunity to quote the wise words of George Bernard Shaw. Naturally an extracurricular relationship ensues with a little help from Larry's scooter and a tough-girl classmate (Gugu Mbatha-Raw), who invites him to join her motorbike ''gang.'' ''The reliable if slowly fading charms of its stars lend 'Larry Crowne' a gloss of likability,'' Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. ''But by the time it ends, we have long ago left Earth to settle on Planet Schmaltz with a syrupy pile of French toast.'' NOON (13) RICHARD HEFFNER'S OPEN MIND Dr. Peter B. Bach, director of the Center for Health Policy and Outcomes at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, discusses the traditional doctor-patient relationship and a new medical specialist he calls the hospitalist.

The Federal Communications Commission on Friday approved a proposal to have local broadcasters publish information about political advertising sales on the Web in a government database. Supporters of the proposal said it would give the public more information about the millions of dollars that are spent on ads to influence elections. It had been expected to pass despite deep opposition by the owners of some television and radio stations.

ARONI--Frances, Hedyah. On April 25, 2012 Frances Hedvah Aroni took her last breath in this world the same way she lived her life on her own terms. This beautiful, gentle woman lived an extraordinary life and in her final days was lovingly cared for by her devoted family and friends. In the 1940's, Frances was an underground feminist who believed in the Power of women to Change the World. She devoted time to the newly emerging ADL in the 50s; and helped found Brandeis University in 1948 with Dr. Abram L. Sachar. Although she worked for many causes her most proud accomplishment was her work to help rescue and relocate displaced persons to Philadelphia from the concentration camps in Europe. Her legacy will live on in the many lives she touched. She was the wife of an internationally known cantor, Zvee Aroni and for 35 years they formed a true partnership based on love and respect. Frances will be remembered by her daughter, Vivian Serota and her son, Benjamin Roth. Grandchildren: Daniel and Cherie Serota, Deborah and Kenneth Carbone. Great-grandchildren: Michael and James Carbon and Stephen, Jonathan and Chase Serota.

The traditionally stronger conference may lack the star power of the East, but it more than makes up for it in overall quality. No. 1 San Antonio Spurs vs. No. 8 Utah Jazz

Because of an editing error, the Advertising column on April 18, about marketers' rapid embrace of the image-sharing Web site Pinterest, misstated the number of Twitter posts that could be made of a thousand words. The number would vary according to word length, but would almost certainly be more than ''about seven posts.'' (Twitter posts are limited to 140 characters, not 140 words. While that number of characters could yield a thousand words in about seven posts, they would have to be single-letter words like ''a'' and ''I.'' This would result in a post not much worth retweeting.)

The thought going into the 2011-12 season was that the lockout-shortened schedule would benefit younger, deeper teams. The Indiana Pacers seemed to prove the theory correct, jumping all the way to the No. 3 playoff spot in the Eastern Conference behind a no-name roster, but the San Antonio Spurs showed that even a veteran team could adjust to the strange circumstances, tying for the best record in the N.B.A. No longer the Leastern Conference, the East produced eight teams with winning records for the first time since 2004-5. The Western Conference still has the overall lead in quality, but the star power of the East can no longer be ignored.

Because of an editing error, an article on April 20 about the halting of fraternity pledging at Binghamton University because of hazing complaints overstated what is known about the cause of death of a student at Cornell University in 2011. While the student, who was not named in the article, died after drinking at a fraternity kidnapping ritual, the cause of his death is the subject of current criminal and civil cases. It has not been determined that forced drinking indeed killed him.

CHENAULT--Anne N. Mrs. Anne N. Chenault, 98, passed away quietly in her sleep on April 23 at home in Hempstead, New York. Anne (nee Anne Naomi Quick) was born February 23, 1914 to Oscar and Louise Quick in Anderson, South Carolina, the second of ten siblings. The family moved to Brooklyn, where Anne attended public schools. She went on to graduate first in her class from the School of Dental Hygiene at Howard University in 1938, serving as class speaker. At Howard, Anne met her future husband, Hortenius Chenault, a student at the Dental School. They married in 1942 and later moved to Long Island, establishing a successful dental practice in Hempstead. Anne also worked as a dental hygienist for the Department of Health of the City of New York. Anne was a long-time member of the South Hempstead Congregational Church. She served her church selflessly, teaching Sunday school, serving as Vice President of the Women's Fellowship, and in later years taking care of flowers for the altar. She also served as secretary of the Friends of the Hempstead Library, volunteered with a youth organization for women in Long Island, and was an active member of the Links and the NAACP. Anne is survived by her children: Patricia, Arthur, Kenneth and Stephan; her daughters-in-law, Stephanie and Kathryn; her sister Mildred Miller; and her grandchildren, Byron, Jillian, Kenneth, Jr., and Kevin. A wake will be held Friday, April 27th, from 5:00 - 9:00pm at the Carl Burnett Funeral Home, 456 South Franklin Street in Hempstead, New York (516-489-4492). The Home Going Service will be held Saturday at 11:00am at the Congregational Church of South Hempstead, 416 Woodland Drive, South Hempstead (516-489-3610). Burial will follow the service at Greenfield Cemetery in Hempstead and there will be a repast at the Church after the interment at 1:30pm. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions to:The Anne Chenault Scholarship Fund, Howard University College of Dentistry, The Dental Hygiene Program, 2225 Georgia Ave., NW Suite 901, Washington, DC, 20059, Attention: Mr. Haki Halisi.

Shiva Condolence Calls will be held at the home of Joseph Gerofsky on Sunday then Monday-Friday Shiva Condolence Calls will be at the home of Daniel and Iris Gerofsky.

For the first time, a space shuttle landed in New York City. Not under its own power, though, because it never had any power of its own. The shuttle that arrived at Kennedy International Airport on Friday after swanning over the metropolitan area for about an hour was the Enterprise, which was the prototype for the shuttles that rocketed into space.

Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about the Rangers' 2-1 victory over the Ottawa Senators in Game 7 of their playoff series described incorrectly in some copies the shots the Senators took in the final 7 minutes 40 seconds. Standard & Poor's downgraded Nokia's bonds on Friday to junk status, noting that the company's first-quarter revenue fell below its expectations, particularly because sales of its phones that include the older Symbian software had fallen so drastically.

Eleven-year-old actress Lilla Crawford will star as musical theater's most famous orphan in this fall's Broadway revival of ''Annie,'' the producers said on Friday. Ms. Crawford, a Los Angeles native, made her Broadway debut last year playing Debbie in the cast of ''Billy Elliot'' before it closed this winter. She was selected to play Annie after a nine-month star search that included 5,000 auditions across the United States and via online video. In a statement, Ms. Crawford said her first comment when she heard about the casting was, ''Oh, my gosh, it happened! My heart just stopped.'' One of the lead producers of the show, Arielle Tepper Madover, said in her own statement about Ms. Crawford: ''When she is in the room you can't take your eyes off her. She has a gorgeous voice, is a terrific actress, wonderful dancer and a sweet girl.''

To the Sports Editor: Re ''In Comfortable Retirement, and Getting Tired of It,'' April 22: Trevor Pryce is certainly a lucky man to be retired and healthy at such a young age. But if he's looking for meaningful ways to fill his time, there are numerous community centers, sports leagues and youth programs that could put his talent, knowledge and experience to very good use.Gary Axelbank

It has long been pointed out that middle- and working-class voters are influenced by politicians pushing social issues to vote against their economic interests. Some progressives now seem to be elevating a social issue -- gay marriage -- over issues of economic justice. As important an issue as gay marriage may be, it is distressing to see the vote for gay marriage by Senator Mark Grisanti of New York, who is described as ''a budding star by most Conservative measures,'' viewed as a basis to assist his re-election. Whatever good was accomplished by his vote for gay marriage will be outweighed by his giving the Republicans control of the Senate, thereby advancing their agenda on issues like minimum wage, income tax, health care, public education and fracking. PAUL S.,

FLUMENBAUM--Libby (nee Luba Tenenbaum), of Coconut Creek, FL. Formerly of the Bronx. Two months shy of her 90th birthday. Predeceased by husband, Leon Flumenbaum. Proud and beloved mother of Martin and Rochelle. Loving mother-in-law of Ruth Hochberger and Paul Estenson. Adored and adoring grandmother of Martha, David and Judy Flumenbaum, and Sam, Lilly and Abe Estenson. Born in Lodz, Poland, a survivor of the Holocaust, she came to the United States in 1950, where she built a new life with her husband and children. Devoted to her family, her friends and her Judaism. A deeply good, strong, and loving woman.

PRESSER--Yvonne, one of the most accomplished fashion models of the '60s, died on April 20 of Alzheimer's Disease. Yvonne was a regular in New York designer collection showings and a house model for Norman Norell, the first American to compete with European couturiers. She showed Norell's clothes around the world and in Vogue, Harpers Bazaar, Town & Country, Life and The New York Times. Women's Wear Daily called her the pioneer of the "Boy Style" haircut and "Van Dongen" eye makeup. Yvonne retired in 1970. She lived in Bellevue, WA, and is survived by her husband Robert, son Brian, daughter-in-law Christine, and granddaughter Mia.

ROLAND--Steve. July 16, 1928, died April 26, 2012. A Broadway veteran, he appeared in the original productions of such shows as "South Pacific" and "Bells Are Ringing" and thousands of television and radio commercials. Loving husband to Lispet and father to Richard and Kristina. No funeral, and in lieu of flowers or cards, please send donations to The Actors Fund.

ALTHOUGH Ms. Sherman already has a considerable fan base, her blockbuster retrospective on view at the Museum of Modern Art through June 11 has enhanced her popularity. This season works by Ms. Sherman from various years and series are for sale at Sotheby's, Christie's and Phillips de Pury. This 1981 image is from her famous ''Centerfold Series,'' a group of portraits inspired by photographs in Playboy but with the women in clothes and conveying a complicated mix of emotions.

Spring's blossoms have reached a peak with the wisteria. At the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, the pergolas of Japanese wisteria, some 30 inches in length, range from deep mauve to nearly white. On some, the tiny blossoms look like roses; others have the more typical pod shape. There are four topiaries around the Worth Monument near Madison Square Park. Wisteria also can be found at Rockefeller Center and a community garden on the West Side. The cascading blossoms remind me of what I saw in Paris last month: the elongated look of women in stripes.

Because of an editing error, a report last Sunday about the marriage of Whitney Frick and Andrew Bernstein misstated the surname of the bride's father, Ford C. Frick II, in a subsequent reference. He is Mr. Frick, of course, not Mr. Ford.

MIAMI - Jeremy Lin played one-on-one Saturday afternoon, an indication that he is ahead of schedule in his recovery from knee surgery. But his availability for the Knicks' first-round playoff series against the Miami Heat remains uncertain. Lin was running, cutting and moving laterally on the American Airlines Arena court three hours before Game 1. He also played one-on-one against the assistant coach Kenny Atkinson. Lin had surgery on April 2 to repair a small meniscal tear in his left knee. Until recently, he had been limited to jogging in a straight line.

REICH--Murray. Many in the New York art community mourn the loss of a beloved colleague in Murray: artist, teacher, provocateur, friend. Our love to Elizabeth, Zeke and Michelle.
