An article on Friday about Carletta Sue Kay, the singing alter ego of Randy Walker, a veteran of the San Francisco music scene for the last several years, rendered the title of the singer's debut album incorrectly. It is ''Incongruent,'' not ''Incongruous.'' It also misspelled the given name of a musician in the group Magnetic Fields, with whom Mr. Walker worked on an album. He is Stephin Merritt, not Stephen.

See a larger version of the forest from this week. Compare with the enlarged version of last week's image. In a week, our site has been utterly transformed by the emergence of leaves. Green pennants now fly on witch hazels, sweet gums, white oaks, and other trees and shrubs. They enliven the air and brighten the forest's dull grays and browns with their vibrant hues.

I don't believe that the technical difficulty involved in making matzo is a barrier to entry. Big companies feast on technical difficulty; it may be what they do best. Beer is very complicated, and Budweiser makes pretty good lager in staggering quantity with amazing consistency. The real barrier to entry is the size and nature of the market. Even if Sara Lee wanted to spend $100 million to build a slow-growing $15 million matzo business, which it doesn't, there's a good chance they would fail because of loyalty to the traditional Jewish brands. THOMAS BOYER,

PETROU--Dimitris, 99, of Volos, Greece, died peacefully in his sleep on April 20th in New York City. Cherished husband to the late Lillian Barth Kimball, he arrived in America after WWII and built a career as a stock broker, retiring from Smith Barney in 2006. He is survived by cousins Alexandros and Anita Liaskas, in Greece, and their daughter, Artemis LIaskas, in Sweden.

The cover article last Sunday, ''City of Sky-High Rent,'' reported on how Manhattan renters were dealing with escalating costs. Following are edited excerpts from nytimes.com: As an ex-New Yorker who left over 35 years ago, advice is: Leave the place. NY is not the be-all, end-all. There are lots of affordable and beautiful places to live across the country without the noise and grit. It takes a little work to find them, but then NY'rs are used to working all kinds of hours slaving away on Wall Street or in some other corporate arena. Use that kind of work ethic to find a better quality of life somewhere else. Life is very short, so make the most of it while you can. Been there, done that. Sharon, Chico, CA

LICHTENSTEIN--Phyllis Ann Holbrook. Phyllis died on April 22, 2012 after a brave battle against cascading complications following a kidney transplant. She was just days short of her 70th birthday. Phyllis was a warm, beautiful, intelligent, generous, and gracious lady, and she will be sorely missed by all who knew her. The only daughter of the late John and Alice Holbrook, she leaves behind her husband, Harvey Lichtenstein, former President of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, their son John, her stepson Saul, and her three brothers John, David, and Peter Holbrook. There will be a memorial service on Friday, May 11, 11am at Calvary Church, 277 Park Avenue South in New York. A lunch reception will follow at the National Arts Club from 12:00 to 2:30. All relatives and friends will be welcome. In lieu of flowers, please donate something to your favorite charity in memory of Phyllis.

IF today's book publishers were interested in critical takes on the theater, I would propose someone write a consideration of the modern genre of plays about teachers and students. It's a vast, fertile field. Consider the diversity in this incomplete list: ''The History Boys,'' ''Seminar,'' ''Comedians,'' ''The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie,'' ''Oleanna'' and ''Miss Margarida's Way.'' These are often bruising plays about power, race and gender that are distinctly talky. That has long been one of the main criticisms of Athol Fugard's ''MY CHILDREN! MY AFRICA!,'' being revived at the Signature Theater. The 1989 drama, set in apartheid-era South Africa, centers on an argument about the best way to dissent. The idealistic teacher and his more radical student trade monologues in this passionate play of ideas. In his New York Times review Frank Rich described the prose as ''pedagogical.'' At the same time the play is self-consciously about the power of words, and the right production can fill in the emotional core of these verbose characters. The director of this new production, Ruben Santiago-Hudson, has staged August Wilson plays, so his experience with long monologues may come in handy. Tuesday through June 10, 480 West 42nd Street, Clinton; (212) 244-7529, signaturetheatre.org.
BOERUM HILL HOUSE $1,295,000

Imagine a being capable of processing, remembering and sharing information -- a being with potentialities proper to it and inhabiting a world of its own. Given this brief description, most of us will think of a human person, some will associate it with an animal, and virtually no one's imagination will conjure up a plant. Since Nov. 2, however, one possible answer to the riddle is Pisumsativum, a species colloquially known as the common pea. On that day, a team of scientists from the Blaustein Institute for Desert Research at Ben-Gurion University in Israel published the results of its peer-reviewed research, revealing that a pea plant subjected to drought conditions communicated its stress to other such plants, with which it shared its soil. In other words, through the roots, it relayed to its neighbors the biochemical message about the onset of drought, prompting them to react as though they, too, were in a similar predicament.

A brief article in some editions last Sunday about the selection of the Jack Finney novel ''Time and Again'' for the Big City Book Club, on nytimes.com, misstated the year to which the protagonist of the book is transported back in time. It is 1882, not 1892.

SCHNELL--Lloyd Jay, 69, of Weston, Florida, formerly of Pomona, New York, passed away on April 25, 2012. He is survived by his beloved wife of 47 years, Ellie Shapiro Schnell; loving children: Ronnie (Staci) Schnell, Amy (Steven) Raisman, cherished grandchildren: Jeremy and Mallory Schnell, Naomi and Noah Raisman; devoted mother: Bernice (pre-deceased father: Nathan) Schnell. Lloyd was a man of amazing courage, wit and intellect. His legacy will live on through his family and the many lives he touched and enriched.

Heathrow Airport in London (heathrowairport.com) operates at 99 percent capacity daily, with 13,070 takeoffs and landings. Since it can't add capacity to ease demand during the Olympic Games in July and August, the airport authority is aiming to boost organization on the ground. It is building a temporary terminal for the 10,500 Olympic athletes and their delegations, but spectators using Heathrow can find shortcuts as well. Travelers with children should look for family-designated security areas equipped with wider, stroller-friendly lanes indicated by child-oriented signage like a rainbow over the metal detector.

BALTER--Stanley A. He is survived by his wife of 64 years, Jean Levy, his sons Richard and Robert, daughter-in-laws Karen and Carmen, grandchildren Allison and Anthony and sister Lynn Kimelman. Stanley was born February 25, 1924 in the Bronx, NY. Lived in Woodcliff Lake, NJ for 35 years before moving to Boca Raton. A veteran who served as Lieutenant in the Signal Corps during WWII. A graduate of Columbia University with highest honors with Master's degrees in Engineering and Finance. He was a Chartered Financial Analyst. He was member of Tau Beta Pi Engineering Fraternity. He worked on the space program for Singer Corporation before becoming President of Balter Research Associates, security analysts whose clients were money fund managers. Stan was an expert in the history of American Folk Music, with an extensive library of this music, much of it not available anywhere else. Stan and his music will be missed by all of us.

TAYLOR--J. Gary, PhD, died at 76 on April 21. Born September 17, 1935, he leaves his second wife, Patricia, of 30 years, his sons, Geoffrey, Joshua and Adam (predeceased by Luke Taylor), step daughters, Wendy Moore, Janet Solomon and Peggy Rambach, his sister, Hadley Fisk, thirteen grandchildren and his constant helper, Mercedes Rodney. Contributions may be made to University Glee Club of NYC, c/o D. Doran, 91 Summit Ave, Jersey City, NJ 07304.

ON Wednesday 1stdibs.com, the marketplace for all things vintage, will unveil a selection of rare Elsa Schiaparelli jewelry, timed to a museum show that connects her work to that of another influential Italian designer, Miuccia Prada. The items for sale were made between the 1930s and 1950s. They range in price from $350, for a pair of japanned metal ear clips, to more than $50,000, for a makeup compact shaped like a rotary telephone dial, which Schiaparelli designed with Salvador Dalí around 1935.

DURING the Victorian Era, the leather industry boomed in Bermondsey, a London neighborhood on the south bank of the Thames, and over time, it evolved into an antiquing destination. But, despite its central location, neglect set in during the late 1900s. ''I never felt very safe, and Bermondsey Street was particularly rough,'' said Tamasin Hopkins, a personal assistant and area resident, referring to her early years in the neighborhood, where she moved in 2000. Now, she said, ''I would describe it as really vibrant, and I feel very plugged in to London living here.'' The Spanish chef José Pizarro, formerly of Brindisa restaurant in Borough Market, has clearly taken notice: He opened José, a tapas and sherry bar, there last summer and the more upscale Pizarro a few doors down in December. Bermondsey also sits in the shadow of the Shard (below right), a 95-story skyscraper with an unveiling planned for 2013, which promises to attract still more attention to the neighborhood. JOSEY MILLER

BUSCHMANN--Wilbur J.,died peacefully in his home on April 21st at the age of 91 years. He is survived by his beloved wife of 68 years, Ruth, and mourned by his daughters Joan (and her husband Robert Cox), Gail, and his son, William as well as by his four loving grandchildren and five great-grand children. It was a life well lived; a man well loved. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be directed to the Winthrop Home Care Agency c/o Winthrop-University Hospital, Office of Development 290 Old Country Road, Suite 22, Mineola, New York 11501.

SULLIVAN--Jeffrey. Born February 20, 1970, Died April 7, 2012. Jeffrey worked in New York in the Intellectual Property departments of Fried Frank and then Baker Botts, LLP. He enjoyed the intellectual challenge of his work, as well as the many travel opportunities his work afforded him, the frequent and close client contact he was able to maintain, and the colleagues and clients who became friends to him. He loved working in New York (and living in Hoboken) and had many friends in the area who will miss him and with whom he enjoyed spending time. He is survived by his friends in New York, Texas, Japan, and other locales, and by his loving family in Florida, who miss him terribly. Jeffrey will be greatly missed by all; he was a unique person whose insight, sensitivity, generosity, quick wit, command of language, and soft heart can never be replicated. A Memorial Mass is scheduled for May 19, 2012, at 1pm at the Church of Our Saviour, 59 Park Avenue at 38th Street.

GEROFSKY--Joseph, passed away on April 25, 2012. Third day of Iyar in the year 5772. Born November 9, 1923 in Brooklyn, NY. Loving son of Herman and Anne. Devoted husband of the late Doris. Loving father to Daniel (Iris). Beloved grandfather to Brianna and Deborah. Devoted brother to the late David. Loving uncle to Anne, Vicki, Beth, Robin, Michael, Robert and Sandy. He was co-owner along with brother David, of Gerofsky Bros. Textile Waste, established in 1890. Former National Secretary of American Jewish Congress. Helped to form Interracial Council for Business Opportunity. Member of the Masonic Order. He was a very caring, generous and charitable man, who always wanted the best for his family and friends. He will be sorely missed. Services will be held at Washington Cemetery (Bay Parkway and McDonald Avenue) Brooklyn, NY on Sunday, April 29 at 10:30am. Shiva Condolence Calls will be held at the home of Joseph Gerofsky on Sunday then Monday-Friday Shiva Condolence Calls will be at the home of Daniel and Iris Gerofsky.

OVER the last half-decade the name Dessner, as in the twin brothers Bryce and Aaron of the National, has become a stamp of wide-angle indie-rock high-mindedness. When you see it and the word ''curated'' together, you know you are in the general area of a taste-shifting experiment: the bridging of conservatory training and trebly electric guitars; string quartets and post-Velvet Underground eighth-note stomps. On the basis of that aesthetic Bryce founded the MusicNOW festival in Cincinnati in 2006 and helped program the Big Ears festival in Knoxville, Tenn., in 2010. Now we have the first CROSSING BROOKLYN FERRY, Thursday to Saturday, a music and film festival produced by the Brooklyn Academy of Music and listing both Dessners as curators. It includes Coachella-festival indie types like the Walkmen Beirut and St. Vincent; modernist ensembles good at playing Cage and Xenakis, like the JACK Quartet and So Percussion; and the great in-between, including the guitarist-composer Tyondai Braxton, the one-man project Hubble (a k a Ben Greenberg) and the analog-synth-obsessed reappropriation maestro Oneohtrix Point Never (a k a Daniel Lopatin). 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, Fort Greene, (718) 636.4100,crossingbrooklynferry.com; $45 per day.

FOR a driver in New York State, it was a good week to put away the cellphone. That's the objective behind Operation Hang Up, a statewide enforcement campaign against distracted drivers that began Monday and was to continue through Sunday. At a news conference on Tuesday, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo outlined the campaign, which was intended to cite motorists who use their cellphones and other electronic devices while driving. ''Operation Hang Up is designed to send a strong message to motorists across New York State that driving and using a handheld device simply do not mix,'' he said in a statement.

KARCHMER--Max, on April 28th, at the age of 98. Beloved husband of Beatrice and devoted father of Marion Giardina and Michael Kane; cherished grandfather of Victor Kane and Katie and Sasha Giardina. Funeral Services Monday, 12 Noon at the Heritage Funeral Home, Putnam Valley, NY. Interment King David Cemetery. For further information: 1-800-924-7454.
THE BIG PROFILE

8 P.M. (Fox) THE SIMPSONS Bart persuades his family to go on a cruise, above, and even wrangles a luxury suite. Now if he can only figure out how to make the vacation last longer than a week. Treat Williams and Steve Coogan guest star. The soundtrack features an original song by Robert Lopez, a creator of ''The Book of Mormon.'' 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH CANDY CROWLEY John O. Brennan, the chief counterterrorism adviser to President Obama, discusses the war on terror a year after the killing of Osama bin Laden. Mr. Brennan moves over to ''Fox News Sunday,'' at 10, and ''This Week With George Stephanopoulos,'' also at 10, on ABC.

COMFORT--Barbara. Barbara Comfort, 95, died peacefully on April 22. Known to all as Bobby, she was the sister of Carol Comfort Felker of Mountain Lake, Florida, and the late Walter Rockefeller Comfort III of Tampa, and beloved Auntie Mame to nieces and nephews John Comfort of New York City, Jane F. Matz and Charles J. Felker of Washington, DC, and Stephen C. Felker of Chicago. Bobby lived in New York City, Landgrove, VT, and North Branford, CT. She was born in Nyack, NY, grew up in Engelwood, NJ, and studied painting at the National Academy of Design and at the Ecole des Beaux-Arts at Fountainebleau in Paris. A landscape and portrait painter, Bobby also engaged in many other enterprises: during WWII, she ran a welding factory for Electrons, Inc. that made electronic tubes for the Navy; in the 70's, having started a lucite design company, she invented the first Cuisinart blade holder; in the 80's she became a mystery writer, creating a series of murder mysteries based in Vermont that are still sold throughout the state. Bobby built the first modern house in Landgrove, which was on the cover of American Home in 1949. A bon vivant and world traveler, she would occasionally burst into French songs after dinner. She will be missed greatly by her family and many friends.

WALKER--T. Barry, died at his home in Los Angeles April 17 after a fall. He was 67. Born in New York City, Barry received his art-history degree from Hamilton College and went on to become Associate Curator of Prints and Drawings at the Brooklyn Museum. He joined the Museum of Fine Arts Houston in 1991 as the first Curator of Prints and Drawings. In 2002, he became the Curator of Modern and Contemporary Art. He retired in 2011 and was widely regarded as a specialist in 20th century art. At the MFAH, Walker spearheaded the most important acquisition of 20th century prints in the history of the Museum, the archive from Peter Blum Edition. His focus on acquiring important works by Jasper Johns, Jackson Pollock, Pablo Picasso and Arshile Gorky helped build the Museum's international reputation. He is survived by his sister, Kerry Walsh, a niece, Cathleen Sowinski (Arthur), and a nephew, Devon Walsh (Heather) and their children Jack, Katie and Tommy. A Memorial Service will be held on May 23rd, 2pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, Madison Avenue at 81st Street, New York, NY. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to MFAH, 1001 Bissonnett, Houston, TX 77005 attention Amy Purvis.

JACOBI--Tanya, died peacefully on April 19, 2012, at age 90. Beloved mother of Jeffrey E. Jacobi, grandmother of Michael and mother-in-law of Rosemary. Emigrated to the U.S. from Latvia at age 13 to reunite with her mother and study at the Detroit Institute of Musical Arts. At 17, ventured out on her own to New York. Possessing a wide array of talents, she performed as a featured pianist in premiere hotels and clubs along the East Coast, sang with the New York City Opera chorus, and later sold her artwork at B. Altman & Co. and New York City galleries. For over 40 years, her Upper West Side apartment included the vocal studio of her husband, the late Henry Jacobi, who coached prominent Broadway and film actors. Her unique blend of humor, compassion, generosity and that special "Tanya flair" will always be remembered.

For five years, Jiri Makovec, 35, a Czech photographer, stranded himself on an island. ''For me, New York City is like an island apart from the rest of the U.S.,'' he said. ''Anytime I've been somewhere else in this country, I felt it was very different from New York.''

An article last Sunday about Alan Z. Feuer, a New Yorker who reinvented himself and was often seen at society balls, included a quotation in which one of Mr. Feuer's society friends misattributed an aphorism. While Henry David Thoreau is often credited with variations of the aphorism ''Most men lead lives of quiet desperation and die with their song still inside them,'' that is not what he wrote in ''Walden.'' He merely said, ''The mass of men lead lives of quiet desperation.'' (Or to quote another Thoreau aphorism: ''You must work very long to write short sentences.'')

Our next selection is Jack Finney's novel ''Time and Again,'' which Stephen King has called ''the great time-travel story.'' Published in 1970, the novel revolves around the advertising artist Si Morley, who is recruited by the government to join a secretive operation. The project takes him back in time to the New York of 1882. Join us for a live online conversation on May 16 from 7 to 10 p.m. To join the Book Club and receive updates about chats, send an e-mail with the subject line ''Join'' to bigcity@nytimes.com.

To the Sports Editor: ''Bobcats Are Fighting a Losing Battle'' (April 22) referred to the 1947-48 Providence Steam Rollers, who won six games in the Basketball Association of America, a precursor to the N.B.A. I was in attendance when Carl Braun set a league scoring record for a game with 47 points. Unfortunately, he scored them for the opposing team, the Knicks.George Monteiro
GOODMAN--James. We've shared so many happy occasions. We will miss you, and never forget you. Love, Reva and Jesse

''Working on the investigation will be a great challenge. I don't underestimate Google.'' Beth A. Wilkinson, an outside litigator hired by the Federal Trade Commission, as it escalates its antitrust investigation of Google's search technology. The move sends a strong signal that the government is prepared to take Google to court.

Hugo Fiorato, a former child prodigy who became the conductor of the New York City Ballet and one of its most enduring influences, died on Monday in Boston. He was 97. His death was confirmed by his stepson Jonathan Scott.

A FULL-FLOOR penthouse at 100 11th Avenue that sold for $19,397,662.50 was the biggest sale of the week, according to city records. The penthouse, which has a 4,500- square-foot terrace, was also the last sponsor unit to sell in the building, which was designed by Jean Nouvel. Holly Parker, a managing director at Prudential Douglas Elliman who oversaw sales at 100 11th Avenue, on the Hudson River, said the actual sale price for the apartment was $19.75 million. She did not know why city records showed a lower number.

For decades, the premier positions for excellence through the decades were center field for the Yankees and left field for the Boston Red Sox. Maybe we should consider another: first base for the Chicago White Sox. Paul Konerko bashed his 400th career home run Wednesday, with all but seven for the White Sox. Konerko came to Chicago from Cincinnati before the 1999 season in a trade for Mike Cameron, and his arrival cemented Frank Thomas as the designated hitter.

THE relationship between celebrities and the news media is never more symbiotic than during the arrival of a new baby. Magazines get a boost to their newsstand sales, reality TV shows get a new plotline and the expectant parents often get lucrative paydays. JACOB BERNSTEIN AUGUST 1991 When Demi Moore, then seven months pregnant, appeared naked on Vanity Fair's cover in an Annie Leibovitz photo, chains like Safeway refused to sell it. Since then, Jessica Simpson, Claudia Schiffer, Cindy Crawford and Britney Spears have all struck a similar pose.

CHRISTIAN--W. Ramsey, born February 20, 1922, died March 23, 2012, at 90 years. Proud of his Manx heritage, Ramsey was named for his father "Jack's" childhood home in Ramsey, Isle of Man. After earning a PhD in Chemistry at McGill University, Montreal, in 1946, Ramsey worked at Colgate-Palmolive research. He then worked in industrial chemical production, commuting from New York City to Newark. Ramsey's favorite activities were designing and building houses with great views. In 1952, he completed 14 Old Farm Road on 5 acres in Bedminster, NJ, then, an addition. In the 1960s he built 3 Sandpiper Walk, Davis Park, Fire Island, then a second "upside down" house overlooking a valley in the Catskills of Margaretville, NY. Ramsey also loved to Australian crawl in the ocean, downhill ski, listen to classical music while "conducting" and garden, using plants' scientific names. Ramsey is survived by Jane Harrison and her daughter Troy Harrison of Accord, NY, her daughter Paige Harrison of Bangalore, India, his son John Ramsey Christian of Mount Laurel, NJ, and his daughter Dana Christian Wegman of Ossining, NY. May he find peace.

THE market hasn't seen a record-breaking price for Bacon since the Russian billionaire Roman Abramovich bought his 1976 ''Triptych'' for $86.3 million at Sotheby's in May 2008. Since then prices have not come anywhere near that sum, but neither have the offerings. Now, on May 9, Sotheby's is selling a 1976 canvas depicting a male figure who is thought to be the artist's lover, George Dyer, who committed suicide in 1971. The painting was the star of a 1977 exhibition of Bacon's work at the Galerie Claude Bernard in Paris. It was the cover image of the show's catalog and hung alongside the record-breaking ''Triptych.'' ''It was such a popular show they had to close off the street,'' said Mr. Meyer, who added that this painting is creating considerable buzz. One reason is that it has not been on the market for 35 years. Another is the painting itself, with the hypnotic reflections of the man in the mirror and on the floor.

An article about Bay Area teams' tapping into the tech corridors of Silicon Valley to transform baseball contained several errors. It misspelled the name of a company that developed a dynamic pricing system for Giants tickets. It is Qcue, not cQue. It also misquoted Barry Kahn, chief executive of Qcue. He said, ''We're seeing a 30 percent uptick on individual ticket revenues,'' not ''We're seeing a 30 percent uptick on the Giants' individual ticket revenues.'' Finally, Qcue's use of algorithms on tickets was misstated. The company is not adding promotional codes to tickets that allow fans to upgrade their seats or receive discounts, although that may be possible in the future.

ROSENBERG--Lawrence Charles.,M.D. Lawrence Charles Rosenberg, M.D., 83, peacefully passed away at his home in Bronxville, NY on April 21, 2012, surrounded by loving and caring family. Born November 23, 1928 in Alexandria, VA, he was the son of Abraham and Cecelia Rosenberg. He graduated Georgetown University in 1948 and earned his medical degree from the Medical College of Virginia in 1953. He completed his internship and residency in Internal Medicine in 1955 at Bellevue Hospital in New York City, after which he was a submarine medical officer with the U.S. Navy in Key West, FL. He began a general surgery residency in 1958 at the Bronx Municipal Hospital Center in New York followed by specialty training in orthopedic surgery, which he completed in 1962. He went on to become Associate Professor of Orthopedic Surgery at New York University School of Medicine where he was actively involved in surgery, education, and research. He was a member of the Alpha Omega Alpha and Sigma Zeta Honorary Scientific Societies and received the Kappa Delta Award for outstanding basic research related to orthopedic surgery in 1970. Academic medicine and research became his primary interests and, in 1976, he was appointed Professor of Orthopedic Surgery at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine and Director of the Orthopedic Research Laboratories at Montefiore Medical Center. He became president of the Orthopedic Research Society in 1981 and received several awards for outstanding achievement in orthopedic research during his lifetime. His field of interest was the structure of cartilage and proteoglycans and he led a distinguished career during which he collaborated with fellow scientists across the country and around the world, and contributed over 100 articles to the scientific literature. Following his retirement from Albert Einstein College of Medicine, he remained active on the editorial boards of various medical journals and, from 1983 to 2003, served as Deputy Editor for the Board of Consulting Editors for Research at the Journal of Bone and Joint Surgery. He met the love of his life, Nancy Sherman, in Woods Hole, MA and they wed in 1951. Their extraordinary, intellectually stimulating, playful, and romantic union lasted thirty-eight years. Larry filled the home with humor, a passion for excellence, and his fierce emotional intelligence. He loved classical music, playing the piano, and delighted his family with brunches and fine dinners, which he would prepare on weekends. He was a highly articulate man of few, carefully chosen words, great charm, gentleness, patience, manners, wisdom, compassion, integrity, and also mystery. He was an exemplary human being, a devoted husband and father, a mentor, and moral compass to family, friends, and colleagues. Larry illuminated our lives with his passion, his playfulness and his eternally young spirit. He had a profound need to share the things that moved him and did so eagerly and generously throughout his life. Beloved husband of the late Nancy Sherman Rosenberg, adored son-in-law of the late Monroe and Gertrude Sherman and brother-in-law of Susan Sherman, devoted father of Eric Rosenberg, Constance Hochman and son-in-law Mark Hochman, Mark Rosenberg, M.D. and daughter-in-law Andrea Needleman, M.D., and Elizabeth Zimmerman; loving grandfather of Amelia and Sarah Hochman, Julian, Jenna, and Meris Rosenberg, and Natalie and Sophia Zimmerman.
BRODSKY--Judith (Lil), 99, formerly of 415 East 85th St., New York City, died March 28, 2012 in Albany, OR after a long, slow decline in her health.

BERSANI--Dr. Henry A. "Hank," Jr. Professor of Special Education at Western Oregon University in Monmouth, OR died Saturday, March 31 as a result of injuries sustained in an accident while riding his bike. Born February 10, 1951 in Syracuse, NY; he received a B.A. from St. Michael's College in Winooski, VT, and M.S. and Ph.D. from Syracuse University. Prior to joining Western Oregon University, Hank served at Oregon Health Sciences University. Dr. Bersani was a leader in his field, and a world-renowned speaker on the topic of special education and developmental disabilities. A committed advocate for persons with disabilities, his work reached across the globe and touched the lives of thousands. He shared his expertise with the Forgotten People Foundation, assisting special needs children and adults in Vietnam. Dr. Bersani received many awards, received a Fellowship with the Joseph P. Kennedy, Jr. Foundation in Washington, D.C., and was a Fellow and member of the American Association on Mental Retardation for over 30 years. Bersani served as President during the year that organization changed its name to the American Association on Intellectual and Developmental Disabilities (AAIDD) and was instrumental in this name change. Hank was an avid cyclist and rode over 3000 miles last year. He is survived by his wife, Lynda (Brown); children, Lisa and Alexander; his parents Henry A. Bersani, Sr. and Mathilde C. Bersani; of Syracuse; and his sister, Maribeth Bersani. Contributions to The Hank Bersani Student Scholarship Fund, the Forgotten People Foundation or AAIDD may be sent c/o Dallas Mortuary Tribute Center, 287 SW Washington St., Dallas, OR 97338.

BIRCKHEAD--Oliver. Oliver Birckhead, of Cincinnati, Ohio was born June 20, 1922 in Brooklyn and graduated from Trinity-Pawling School, Pawling, New York, Nichols College, Dudley, Massachusetts in 1942 and Stonier Graduate School of Banking, Rutgers University. He passed away on April 27, 2012. Mr. Birckhead, who was honored as a Great Living Cincinnatian in 2003, was President and CEO of The Central Bancorporation which later merged into PNC Bank where he became Vice Chairman and Director until he retired in 1989. Mr. Birckhead is survived by his wife Jane, two sons, Dr. Oliver Birckhead, III, Randall Birckhead, daughters-in-law Leslie Birckhead, Deborah Birckhead and grandchildren Oliver IV, Laura, Sarah, Rebecca and Elizabeth.

FOR nearly six decades this watercolor, depicting Paulin Paulet, a gardener on Cézanne's family estate near Aix-en-Provence, France, was familiar to scholars only as a black-and-white photograph. No one knew if the actual work, a study for Cézanne's celebrated Card Players paintings, still existed and if it did, who owned it. But it recently resurfaced, and the Dallas collector who had it in his home is selling it on Tuesday. Cézanne's images of workers on his farm -- pipe-smoking men sitting around a table, their expressions dour, absorbed in a game of cards -- are among his most recognizable work. Executed from 1890 to 1896, they were the artist's take on genre paintings made famous by 17th-century Dutch masters. Although not as instantly recognizable as ''The Scream,'' the watercolor is considered an art historical landmark, but one that will most likely appeal to the connoisseur collector rather than a speculator or a trophy hunter.

ELLIOTT--Lee K. Harpswell, ME--Lee K. Elliott, 86, passed away peacefully on April 26th, at her home in Cundy's Harbor, Maine, with Bob, her husband of fifty-nine years and their children at her bedside. She was born in Parkersburg, West Virginia, on February 1, 1926, the daughter of Gail G. Peppers and Virginia (Echols) Peppers. She attended school in Parkersburg and Charleston, where she graduated from high school. She was awarded a writing scholarship at Northwestern University, which she completed before moving to New York City to pursue a modeling career. In that capacity she worked at the Grace Downs Agency and for the Richard Hudnut and Elizabeth Arden Salons. As Lee Pepper, she was runner-up to Bess Meyerson in the "Miss New York City" Contest in 1945. Her first marriage was to the writer/comedian, Raymond Knight, (producer of one of radio's original comedy hours). They had two daughters, Colony and Shannon, before Knight's untimely death in 1953. Lee eventually joined NBC as an assistant TV director, working with Jim Elson and Dwight Hemion, among others. In 1954 she married Radio/TV personality, Bob Elliott, ("Bob and Ray"). Together they had three children: Amy, Bob Jr., and Chris. "Nanny" also leaves 10 grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Her warm smile and razor-sharp sense of humor will be dearly missed. "To the Queen!" A family memorial will take place later this summer. Grateful appreciation is extended to Chans Hospice Care, 60 Baribeau Dr., Brunswick, ME 04011, to which contributions in Lee's memory may be addressed. Services are under the direction and care of Brackett Funeral Home, Brunswick, ME.
FRIEDLER--John. Wonderful brother-in-law, loving uncle, kind and devoted friend. Joan, Philip and Suze Leshin

LEDERMAN--Mark. IDC Herzliya mourns the passing of our dear friend Mark. He was a great supporter of Israel and his generosity paved the way for many Ethiopian Israelis to earn their BA degrees at IDC. His warmth and kindness will be deeply missed. Our condolences go out to his beloved wife Carol, and his children Amy and Jeff. Prof. Uriel Reichman Mr. Jonathan Davis Mrs. Felicia Zarai

The San Francisco Giants drafted Brian Wilson in the 24th round in 2003, knowing his elbow was damaged. They suggested Wilson recover from reconstructive elbow surgery under their supervision, rather than return to Louisiana State, and he agreed. Their partnership has been a rousing success, with 171 saves and a World Series title, but the rebuilt elbow finally gave out this month. Wilson had a second Tommy John operation, ending his season and leaving the Giants with Santiago Casilla as their closer.

KEAN--Luz Maria (Beba) Silverio, 87, of New York, NY, on April 3 after a full, adventurous, loving life at the core of her family. She made an indelible impression on all she met, and we will never forget her generous spirit and incandescent charm. Survivors, along with their respective families, include her sister Ana Maria; brothers Joaquin and Nicasio; sons Robert, Peter, Alexander, Nicholas and Christopher; eight grandchildren, eight great-grandchildren, and many dear friends. Memorial, May 19 at 4pm, St. Thomas More, 65 E. 89th St.

THE diverting drama of sports had never collided with the drama of real life quite the way it did in 1936, when Jesse Owens ran and jumped his way to Olympic glory in the heart of Nazi Germany. That achievement of course receives plenty of attention in ''JESSE OWENS,'' the ''American Experience'' episode being broadcast on PBS on Tuesday night. (Check local listings.) A black man winning four gold medals was certainly not in Hitler's plans when he agreed to let his deputies make an international showcase out of the Summer Olympics, which had been assigned to Berlin before Hitler came to power. He expected Aryan domination. With his victories Owens grabbed international attention. The program, though, is at its most compelling when it explores how quickly he lost it. After clashing with the Amateur Athletic Union, Owens was soon reduced to racing against horses to make a buck. Then, as now, fame could be cruelly fleeting, even for those whose accomplishments made a statement heard round the world.

D'URSO--Florence B. Calvary Hospital and Calvary Fund mourn with great sadness the passing of our munificent benefactor and Calvary Fund Board Trustee Emerita, Florence B. D'Urso. Florence was a devout daughter of the Church, and an extraordinary philanthropist. She joined the Calvary Fund Board in 1986, and through the years remained a tireless advocate for the Hospital's patients, families, caregivers, and leadership. She and her late husband, Camillo, were devoted to Calvary, and the Hospital's Florence and Camillo D'Urso Patient Activities Center, where hundreds of patients and families enjoy concerts and holiday celebrations every year, honors their outstanding generosity. In recognition of the D'Ursos' concern for the dignity of human life and service to humanity, in 1987 Calvary presented the Calvary Medal, the Hospital's highest tribute, to Florence and, posthumously, to Camillo. Florence commissioned the Compatior sculpture in 1999, in observance of Calvary's centennial, and in memory of her son, David Francis, and brother, Father Francis Joseph Perkosky, SS, both lost to cancer. Today, the Compatior is the essential symbol of Calvary's compassionate and comprehensive care. Florence will be remembered for her love and knowledge of architecture and art, her life of grace in the face of sorrow, and her deep and abiding faith. We extend our sincere condolences to her daughters Donna and Lisa, her son, Mark, her daughter-in-law, Michelle, her treasured and beloved granddaughter, Michaela Frances, and the entire D'Urso family. Thomas J. Fahey, Jr., MD, Chairman, Calvary Hospital Steven J. Golub, Chairman, Calvary Fund Frank A. Calamari, President and CEO, Calvary Hospital Michael J. Brescia, MD, Executive Medical Director, Calvary Hospital Vincent J. Spinelli, Executive Vice President, Calvary Fund

Podcast Scheduled to appear this week: Nell Freudenberger on her new novel, ''The Newlyweds''; Julie Bosman with notes from the field; and Gregory Cowles with best-/seller news. Sam Tanenhaus, the editor of the Book Review, is the host. By the BookAn interview with Madeleine Albright, the former secretary of state and author of a new memoir, ''Prague Winter.''

There was a phase I went through -- I was 6 or 7 -- when I would get home from school, race upstairs and close my door. I'd don one of my dad's jackets -- I preferred a gray pinstripe -- balance his glasses on my snub nose and shuffle around in his wingtips. Then I would organize piles of papers on my desk. When the mood struck, I'd pretend to read The Wall Street Journal. If my mother came up to check on me, I'd shout, ''Not now, Mom! I'm working!'' Even better than playing ''Office'' was the real thing. My dad was a mutual fund manager, and his office felt like Cheers: a place where everyone knew my name. The traders would high-five me and teach me the occasional curse word. Dad's secretary, Louise, let me sit at her desk. Sometimes, I would color in stock charts. (''This makes it easier for me to read,'' Dad would say, approvingly.)

INFUSO--Joseph. We note with sadness the passing of Joe Infuso, our friend and colleague of many years. From its inception in 1932, few employees of Queens Litho/ Queens Group made as pivotal a contribution. Joe was one of a nucleus of dedicated long term employees whose commitment, professionalism and personal initiative helped turn a small letterpress shop in a loft into a nationwide packaging business with a stellar reputation. His charm, infectious laugh and smile, and personal integrity, combined with decades of hands-on print experience, made him the company's ambassador in the Los Angeles entertainment market. His wife Jay, his children Joe, Louis, Glen and Rosalie, eight grandchildren, and nine great-grandchildren survive him. We extend our sincere thanks and condolences to his entire family. Leonard Hecht, Eric Kaltman, Richard Roth, Gerald Sanders, and Leonard Verebay

ESTATE property is especially desirable in part because it has generally been off the market for years and comes with reasonable estimates. This canvas, from 1941, is one of 17 works being sold on Wednesday from the estate of Theodore J. Forstmann, the New York financier who died in November. Painted in the early years of World War II, the distorted figure of Dora Maar, Picasso's muse and lover, posed in a chair is one of scores of seated women whom he depicted. ''The anguish of the war and his relationship with Dora, which was deteriorating, is reflected in these paintings,'' said John Richardson, the Picasso biographer. ''He painted Dora in such an angular way, she almost looks like a pair of scissors.'' The painting was made the same year as Picasso's ''Dora Maar With Cat,'' a far more dramatic canvas with a black cat perched on Maar's shoulder that sold for $95.2 million at Sotheby's in 2006.
METUCHEN RANCH $649,900

A report in the One-Page Magazine on April 15 about flight attendants' using soft voices on Virgin Atlantic flights misstated a measurement of sound. The attendants will be trained to speak in a volume of 20 to 30 decibels, not a pitch.

WENIG--Dr. Harold G.,was a graduate of City College and Yale University, with a Ph.D. from NYU in Mechanical Engineering, President of Wright Industries, Fellow of New York Academy of Sciences. Beloved husband of Shirley. Loving father of Arlene (Dr. Lawrence A. Seigel) and Nadine (Dr. Larry Isaacs). Dear brother of Jack. Cherished grandfather of Jason, Ariana, Gregory and Eric. Services Sunday, 10:15am at "Sinai Chapels" 16205 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

THE Turkish director Nuri Bilge Ceylan, whose ''Once Upon a Time in Anatolia'' shared the 2011 grand prize at Cannes, has become an auteur hero. But beyond Mr. Ceylan most American moviegoers probably have little experience with Turkish movies. That makes the 29-film series ''THE SPACE BETWEEN: A PANORAMA OF CINEMA IN TURKEY'' -- presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center with the Moon and Stars Project of the American Turkish Society -- all the more valuable. With movies from the late 1950s to the present, the series concentrates on socially engaged works rather than on the country's commercial cinema. Mr. Ceylan's work, represented here by the measured, melancholy ''Climates'' (2006), feels familiar in an art-house way. A movie like Yilmaz Guney's ''Elegy'' (1971) seems more like a window into another world. A story of smugglers, it plays at times like a western, with shootouts on a rocky hillside, where tumbling boulders present as much of a threat as bullets. But it also takes time to show a lovely female doctor teaching villagers about safe water. Through May 10, Walter Reade Theater and Elinor Bunin Munroe Film Center, Lincoln Center, filmlinc .com.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Changes to Postseason Inevitable, but Format Is Far From Certain,'' April 25: This article did not mention the word education; university presidents were mentioned only in passing. Obviously, universities participating in Division I football are now being run by television commitments and the Bowl Championship Series.

ARONI--Frances Hedvah. To Granny, You took us on magical trips to Disney World but at dinner time, when you took out your umbrella, standing on a chair - ready to take flight - you became Mary Poppins and made eating healthy food and taking our vitamins - seem like a great adventure. You will be a part of our hearts forever. With love, Daniel Serota and Deborah Carbone

FRIEDLER--John P.,born March 11, 1933 in Amsterdam to Nelly and Frans Friedler, died peacefully at his home in Bedford, NY on April 27, 2012. The family fled Europe in 1939 and settled in Mexico, where John grew up. He graduated from Westminster School and Hamilton College. He is survived by his wife, Carole ("Cookie"), his children Mark (Anna), Nicole (Michael), and Elizabeth, and his sister, Monique Kunewalder. Uncle to Nick and Suze, and Grandpo to Matthew and Adriel. Avid sailor, MG enthusiast, and biker/hiker with his beloved poodle, Blackberry. An elegant, dapper gentleman with flashing blue eyes and a bow-tie. Services private. The family will be at home Monday-Wednesday, 5-8:30pm.

A review on April 15 about ''The Great Animal Orchestra,'' by Bernie Krause, misstated the history of the author's stint with the folk music quartet the Weavers. While he took over the position in the group once held by Pete Seeger, he did not ''replace'' Seeger -- Seeger was replaced by Erik Darling, who was himself succeeded by Frank Hamilton; Krause replaced Hamilton.

The Q&A column last Sunday, in which Soraya Darabi, a founder of the Foodspotting Web site and app, names some of her favorite travel apps and Web sites, misstated part of her professional experience. She worked in the communications department at Condé Nast Digital on products like epicurious.com; she was not helping to develop products like epicurious.com for the company. And she advises digital start-ups, which usually entails an equity stake; she is not a paid consultant.

ARONI--Frances, Hedyah. On April 25, 2012 Frances Hedvah Aroni took her last breath in this world the same way she lived her life on her own terms. This beautiful, gentle woman lived an extraordinary life and in her final days was lovingly cared for by her devoted family and friends. In the 1940's, Frances was an underground feminist who believed in the Power of women to Change the World. She devoted time to the newly emerging ADL in the 50s; and helped found Brandeis University in 1948 with Dr. Abram L. Sachar. Although she worked for many causes her most proud accomplishment was her work to help rescue and relocate displaced persons to Philadelphia from the concentration camps in Europe. Her legacy will live on in the many lives she touched. She was the wife of an internationally known cantor, Zvee Aroni and for 35 years they formed a true partnership based on love and respect. Frances will be remembered by her daughter, Vivian Serota and her son, Benjamin Roth. Grandchildren: Daniel and Cherie Serota, Deborah and Kenneth Carbone. Great-grandchildren: Michael and James Carbon and Stephen, Jonathan and Chase Serota.
SCHWARTZMAN--Nathan. We will always remember your kindness and sweetness. You will be greatly missed. Love, Reva and Jesse
SCHABERG--Jane, Feminist Biblical Scholar. Memorial service at Christ Church, 960 East Jefferson Ave., Detroit, MI 48207, May 19th at 1:00pm.

FIN de siècle Paris may have been a hotbed of debauchery, but the most compelling painter of that time, ÉDOUARD VUILLARD (1868-1940), stayed home and painted his mother and sisters in their modest rooms pursuing ordinary domestic activities. Compact, flattened and densely patterned, yet mysteriously atmospheric, those works gained early success for the young Vuillard and remain among the most beloved paintings of the Post-Impressionist era. Conventional wisdom has it that Vuillard failed to live up to his early promise. Unlike his coevals Matisse and Bonnard, after 1900 Vuillard took a traditionalist turn to realistic portraiture and decorative wall painting. Viewers may judge for themselves whether his critics have been unkind this week when ''Édouard Vuillard: A Painter and His Muses, 1890-1940'' opens Friday at the Jewish Museum. The first major museum show in New York to focus on Vuillard in 20 years, the exhibition will present more than 50 paintings as well as prints and photographs. It also will examine the influence of friends, supporters, critics and benefactors -- many of whom were Jewish -- on the artist's life and work. Through Sept. 23, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92nd Street; (212) 423-3200, thejewishmuseum.org.

I see no reason why anyone who drinks responsibly at any hour of the day should find it ''subversive.'' A nip of port is excellent with a large steak-and-eggs breakfast, as is a chardonnay over ice before lunch on occasion, and a hot afternoon working in the garden begs for a clean scotch and water. I suspect that societal rules regarding alcohol consumption fuel binge drinking. Why postpone relaxation (over a drink or in any other manner) for happy hour or the weekend, when a modest serving of alcohol midday would be more healthful and soothing? PUMA BEARCLAN,

Nothing enters the Steinway factory in Astoria, Queens, looking anything like a piano. The wood, for example, is just lumber, before it is shaped into the rim of the instrument. Assembling the pianos takes months, with a lot of waiting between steps so that the wood can be conditioned properly. Near the end of the process, each piano is wheeled into the ''pounding room,'' where 88 rubber fingers play the instrument for hours, breaking in the piano and exposing any problems or weaknesses. After being tuned several times, each piano has a final inspection. The last hands that touch every piano belong to Wally Boot, who has worked at the factory for almost 50 years and checks every key to ensure an even tone. Anthony Gilroy, a Steinway spokesman, says, ''There are still some things that are better done by hand.'' Pianos produced per year at the Queens factory: 1,500

A theater entry in last Sunday's Week Ahead column described incorrectly the racial makeup of a new Broadway production of ''A Streetcar Named Desire.'' The play features a multiracial cast that has an emphasis on black actors, but it is not an all-black production.

A FEW years ago, on a visit to the McQueen studios in London, I poked my head into a room of interns beavering away at rows of desks. They could have been accountants, I thought, poring over their Victorian ledgers. That scene could be duplicated across the fashion world, as new design-school graduates take their place in studios and hope for the best. It's exciting to land a job -- a bonus if it's with a halfway decent name -- but hardly glamorous. The other night I attended the senior fashion show at Pratt Institute. Seventeen students, from a class of 38, presented their work to an overflowing crowd in Chelsea that included a number of designers and editors like Hamish Bowles of Vogue. Before the show started, Calvin Klein presented a lifetime achievement award to Fern Mallis, for her role in centralizing the New York shows and generally making them run at a more professional clip. And Ms. Mallis, now a consultant (and an occasional actress), thanked Mr. Klein for helping her when she needed it. From the podium, wearing a long, bright red dress, she told him, ''You are the cherry on the sundae, which, I swear, I will stop eating.''
LUNE--Marvin, of Huntington, NY. Funeral Services Monday 11am at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Tpke., Woodbury, LI. Interment at Huntington Rural Cemetery.

MARKOE--Frank, Jr.,beloved father of Andree Markoe Caldwell and Ritchie Markoe Scribner, died peacefully at home on Jupiter Island, Florida, on April 25. He was born September 5, 1923 in Baltimore, Maryland. After serving in the U.S. Army Air Force from 1942 to 1945, he graduated from Washington and Lee University in 1947 and from the University of Maryland Law School in 1950. A partner in the Baltimore firm of Cable & McDaniel, he practiced law from 1950 to 1955. From 1955 to 1958 he served as general counsel and director of the Emerson Drug Company in Baltimore. After overseeing its merger into the Warner-Lambert Company, he was recruited by its chairman Elmer Bobst to be general counsel to the pharmaceutical conglomerate, where he later became executive vice-president and vice chairman of the board. Having moved with his two young daughters to Far Hills, he was active in New Jersey civic life and politics and served as president of the New Jersey Ballet. In 1977 President Carter appointed him to the Board of International Broadcasting (Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty). Upon retiring from Warner-Lambert, in 1981 he embarked on a second career in hospital administration and was named executive director and vice chairman of the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, where he oversaw its development and building campaigns during the 1980s. In 1990 he retired and moved to Jupiter Island, Florida, where he devoted his final years to his family, friends, and golf, and scored two holes-in-one. In addition to his two daughters, he is survived by three grandsons, Charles Scribner IV, William McCormack Caldwell, and Christopher Markoe Scribner, and a recent great-granddaughter, Elizabeth Blair Scribner. Memorial service at St. James' Church, Madison Avenue at 71st Street, New York City, on Friday, June 1st at eleven a.m.

TIMING is everything in the auction business. So it's no accident that this Surrealist canvas -- once owned by Elsa Schiaparelli, a Paris couturier closely associated with the Surrealist movement and who collaborated with Dalí on designs -- is being offered for sale just days before the opening of the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Costume Institute exhibition ''Schiaparelli and Prada: Impossible Conversations.'' From 1936, ''Printemps Nécrophilique'' is an eerie dreamscape with two figures that is also coming up for sale as the interest in Surrealism continues to escalate. ''It's one of the last great isms of art history to be fully appreciated,'' said Simon Shaw, who runs Sotheby's Impressionist and modern art department in New York. ''The roots of more recent art can be found in some of these Surrealist paintings, so it crosses over successfully, appealing to contemporary collectors too.''

DREW--Anne. The documentary filmmaker died April 12 at her home, of lung cancer. A central partner for more than four decades in Drew Associates, Anne edited and produced award-winning cinema verite films on ballet, war, Duke Ellington, Indira Gandhi, and President John F. Kennedy, among others. Anne is survived by her husband and filmmaking partner of 42 years, Robert Drew; her brother, Peter Gilbert; her sister, Dorothy Gilbert Goldstone; and her stepchildren, Thatcher Drew, Lisa Drew, and Derek Drew. There will be a gathering and short service at the Harvard Club on May 6, from 4-7pm. Donations to the Anne Drew Film Preservation Fund, PO Box 1134, Sharon, CT 06069.
ROST--Henry A.,Hotelier January 22, 1884 - April 29 1954

WALKER--Derek. When a bomb destroyed their home in England during World War II, young Derek Walker survived by huddling with his family under the kitchen table. What could have seemed harrowing was, to Derek, "a fascinating adventure." His life continued as a fascinating adventure until cancer brought it to an end at the age of 80 on April 19. After his boyhood war experience, the irony was not lost on Dr. Walker when his first job involved research on British atomic weapons. Wanting to pursue "more humane employment," he moved to the pharmaceutical industry where he led the development of chemical processes to improve quality and safety. His work earned numerous patents and industry accolades until his retirement from Schering Plough Research Institute in 1996. In retirement, Dr. Walker published a book on chemical processes and traveled the world with Paddy, his wife. He was drawn to remote regions, where he indulged his love of photography. Dr. Walker had a passion for writing verse, describing himself as "not even a minor poet, but a micro poet," and published a collection of his writings, "Curious and Quirky Verse: 1941-2011." Characteristic of his altruism, he designated the proceeds to Adam's Camp for special-needs children in Colorado. The importance of education was an enduring theme of Dr. Walker's life. A generous scholarship, secured through the determination of his mother, enabled him to earn a PhD in chemistry from Leeds University. He affirmed his commitment to higher learning by founding a scholarship in his mother's name to help students in need attend university to study the sciences. Those wishing to pay tribute to the remarkable life of Derek Walker can donate to the Elizabeth F. Walker Foundation, c/o Arbroath Capital, 10955 Westmoor Dr., #

WENGER--Harold "Doc", 61, passed away Wednesday, April 25, 2012 at his home in Wellesley, MA. Harold was born in Germany on December 12, 1950, and came to the United States with his parents Fay and Jack Wenger, refugees of the Holocaust. Harold was a graduate of Rutgers University and Cornell Medical School where he received his medical degree. Harold completed his medical residency at Michael Reese Hospital in Chicago, IL and his surgical residency at Boston Medical Center. In 1984, Harold founded Baystate Medical and Surgical, an independent physician staffing company in Massachusetts. Aside from medicine, Harold was a "Jack of all trades", best known for his sharp tongue, big heart, and unique sense of fashion. Harold leaves his wife, Katherine Wenger of Wayland, MA; daughter Julia Wenger of Framingham, MA; son, Alexander Wenger of Northampton, MA; and sister, Sylvia Rogowski, of Merrick, NY. The Wenger family will receive visitors in the John Everett & Sons Funeral Home, 4 Park St. (at Natick Common) Natick, MA on Sunday, April 29, 2012 from 1-4pm. Burial will be private in Beit Olam - East Cemetery, Wayland, MA. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations to be made by check payable to Eastern Middlesex Alcoholism Services, c/o Tim McCarthy, 12 Cedar St., Malden, MA 02148. For online guestbook please visit www.everettfuneral.com.

TALISMAN--Arthur B.,died peacefully at home on April 25 at age 84. His son, Mitchell Talisman, was by his side. He was predeceased by son Irving and wife Gloria. Arthur founded Talisman and Sherman, an accounting firm; he attended NYU and served in the military.

GOLDSMITH--Dolores. May 2, 2009. I Am Not There. Do not stand at my grave and weep, I am not there I do not sleep, I am a thousand winds that blow, I am the diamond glints on snow, I am the sunlight on ripened grain, I am the gentle autumn's rain, When you awaken in the morning's hush, I am the swift uplifting rush of quiet birds in circled flight, I am the soft stars that shine at night, Do not stand at my grave and cry, I am not there, I did not die.

The Frugal Traveler column last Sunday, about a $100 weekend in Melbourne, misstated the conversion from Australian dollars to United States dollars in the totals given for the writer's expenses for Saturday. The Saturday total, 58.35 Australian dollars, was about $60, not $56.02. The column also misstated the conversion for the amount remaining, to be spent Sunday. It was 47.65 Australian dollars, or about $49, not $43.98.

In honor of the London Olympic and Paralympic Games, British Airways will be serving up special in-flight meals concocted by Michelin-starred chefs from July through September. The special Olympic menu pays homage to traditional British cuisine and is inspired by the airline's 1948 London Olympics in-flight meals. The owner of Dinner (see Page 10) and the Fat Duck, Heston Blumenthal (above), who is famous for creating holistic dining experiences by combining taste and sound, created the onboard meals along with Simon Hulstone, owner of the Elephant in Torquay (southwest England), who will be overseeing the onboard kitchens during the summer.

David Wells was in Detroit last Saturday, preparing for a broadcast the next day, when he watched the final inning of Philip Humber's perfect game on television. As Humber wobbled against the leadoff man in the ninth inning, Wells rooted him on. ''I said a prayer for him when he went to 3-0,'' Wells said. ''I started yelling at the gods, 'C'mon, let this guy in!' ''

DILLON--Thomas Hardin. Thomas Hardin Dillon, age 59, died peacefully on April 26th after a brave battle with cancer, surrounded by his family. A life-long resident of Oldwick, NJ, Tom was active in business, philanthropy, and sporting circles. Tom was born December 16, 1952 in Morristown, NJ to the late Dorothy Hardin Dillon and Sidney G. Dillon of Gladstone, NJ. He graduated from The Hill School (1973) and Clark University (1977). He was a partner with Advance Capital Partners, LLC a diversified real estate investment and development entity headquartered in Bedminster, NJ. In addition, Dillon served as President of both the Hills Development Company and Environmental Disposal Corporation. Prior to his affiliation with Advance Capital Partners, Dillon was President of Gale, Wentworth & Dillon, LLC a residential development company headquartered in Florham Park, NJ. Before joining Gale, Wentworth & Dillon in 1991, Dillon was a Vice President of MPW Companies, headquartered in New Jersey. Prior to MPW, he was an officer with Midlantic Mortgage Corporation the real estate finance subsidiary of Midlantic National Bank. In addition to his business affiliations, Dillon was a Paul Harris Fellow in Rotary International. He served on the Board of The Boys and Girls Clubs of Newark where he was Board President. He served on the Boards of the Tewksbury Land Trust, Far Hills Country Day School, the Watchung Area Boy Scouts Council and Bates Manufacturing Company. He served as President of the Somerset Hills Lake and Game Club for many years. He was on the Board of the Siasconset Casino, Nantucket Island, MA. He was a member of Raritan Associates. Tom was an avid sportsman, excelling in paddle tennis, tennis, golf, hockey, and hunting. But his real passion was fishing, which led him to all the major rivers in the western U.S., South America, and eastern Canada. Tom leaves his wife Patty of Oldwick, NJ; sons Tom, Jr., of Hoboken, NJ, Henry of New York City, and daughter Sarah of New York City; his father Sidney G. Dillon of Gladstone, NJ; and siblings Molly Raymond of Potomac, MD, Lucy Dillon of Nantucket, MA, Mary Bird of Bethesda, MD, and Charles Dillon of Oldwick, NJ, as well as numerous cousins, nieces, and nephews. A celebration of Tom's life will be held at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Gladstone, NJ, on Thursday, May 3rd at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Tom's memory can be made to The Boys and Girls Club of Newark, NJ, or to the Carol G. Simon Cancer Center at the Morristown Memorial Hospital, Morristown, NJ.

LEVY--Ruth (Rivka) (nee Wallach), June 23, 1922 - April 22, 2011. Devoted wife to George, of blessed memory. Loving mother to Dr. Miriam, Dr. Daniel, David, and Rabbi Naomi Levy (spouses Paul, Susan, Etti, and Robert). Proud grandmother (Bubby) to Jared, Ethan, Lily, Rebecca, Sam, Emily, Naamah, Lior, Ophir, Adin, and Noa. Born in Poland, raised in Boro Park; attended Hashomer Hatzair, Camp Kindervelt, New Utrecht High, Brooklyn College and Columbia University. A devoted friend, teacher, and mentor to many from Brooklyn to Brookline, including the Shulamith School, the Flatbush Jewish Center, Kehillat Israel, and the Hebrew Rehab. She was a woman of wisdom, courage, strength, kindness and love. Her life has ended, but her light continues to shine upon us and illuminates our way.

THE Dutch company INTRODANS will reintroduce itself this week. When New York audiences caught their first glimpse of this group in 2005, in the form of the Introdans Youth Ensemble, they applauded its vitality. Now, seven years later, the main company is making its American debut. The performers promise to be just as lively as the youth ensemble in ''Heavenly,'' a program of three ballets by three choreographers, all on transcendental themes as expressed by the immediacy of beautiful dancing bodies. Two are by Dutch choreographers: Ed Wubbe's ''Messiah,'' to excerpts from Handel, juxtaposes swirling ensembles with intimate duets, and Nils Christe's ''Fünf Gedichte'' employs Wagner's ''Wesendonck Lieder'' to suggest the transition from life to death. In contrast ''Paradise?'' by the Brazilian choreographer Gisela Rocha combines hip-hop and tap with sexy moves and urban cool set to music by Michael Sauter. Viewers will have to decide for themselves what that question mark in the title may mean. 7:30 p.m. Tuesday and Wednesday, 8 p.m. Thursday through Saturday, 2 p.m. Sunday, Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-0800, joyce.org; $10 to $49.

ROHATYN--Jeannette S. Died Easter Sunday, April 8, 2012, after a long illness. She is mourned and missed by her sons, grandchildren, nieces and nephews, and by all those whose lives she touched. She was born Jeanne Emma Streit in Paris, France, on December 26, 1924. Her father, Clarence K. Streit of Missoula, Mont., was a poet, New York Times correspondent and anti-fascist polemicist, whose book "Union Now", published on the eve of World War II, advanced the idea of federating the world's democracies, anticipating NATO and the European Union by decades. It was an idea to which he devoted the rest of his life. He was nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize in 1950. Her mother and namesake, Jeanne Defrance, of Lille, France, and later Paris, was herself the niece of a significant figure in French jurisprudence, Fernand Payen, who, as former Chief Barrister of the Paris Bar Association, was assigned the unenviable task of defending Marechal Petain in his trial for treason in the months following the Liberation. Her beloved grandmother Marguerite was an editor at La Vie Heureuse. Jeannette's parents met at a bus stop at the Place de L'Opera in 1920 and remained inseparable for the rest of their lives. Her mother lived to be 101. Jeannette's early years would be defined by her father's intellectual and political journey. The family moved from Paris to Vienna and then Geneva, where Jeannette attended the Ecole Internationale; and then to Missoula, Montana, and Washington, DC, where she attended high school. It was as a teenager in Montana that Jeannette must first have become aware of her difference, and of the uncommon breadth of her worldview. It was a difference and apartness that she celebrated for the rest of her life. She attended Swarthmore College, majoring in art history, and graduated Magna Cum Laude in 1946. An active alumnus who served on the Board of Trustees from 1977 to 1980, she went on to established the Clarence K. Streit Scholarship and the Baudelaire Award in French Studies. After college, she went to work at the United Nations in the then novel field of simultaneous interpreting, covering the French/Spanish/English section from 1947 until her retirement in 1963. As a member of the first generation of United Nations staff, she joined a remarkable and in many ways glamorous group, international in character and far-flung as a matter of fact, in a job that provided a front-row seat to events shaping the post-War and Cold War years. In 1956 she married Felix Rohatyn, then a salaried investment banker at Lazard Freres. Soon thereafter, the couple bought a large, sunny apartment on Park Avenue for the price of a luxury German sedan today; he became Partner in the firm, and she left the UN to raise their children. In 1958 they greeted the first of three boys, Pierre, with Nicolas and Michael following soon after. Though the marriage ended in divorce, recent years saw a renewal of friendship, with holidays spent together in the company of their children and grandchildren, and concern for each other discreetly communicated and well understood. After retirement, Jeannette's energies found further outlet in the service of her lifelong passion opera. An indefatigable volunteer with the Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions, she oversaw the Eastern Region for many years, assisting such voices through the program's ranks as Susan Graham, Renee Fleming, Dawn Upshaw, Hei-Kyung Hong and Samuel Ramey. A Jeannette Rohatyn Prize she called it the "Great Promise Award" was established by her sons in 2005 to honor one of her pet concerns: the runner-up. It aptly reflects her nature, of keeping faith with all of her beloved singers, especially those who might need encouragement the most. Jeannette's other passions were wordplay, languages, trees, unstructured time for children, perfectly ripe cherries and, as anyone who knew her can attest, The Right Way of Doing Things. She was exacting, loyal, charming, an astute critic and an overly stern self-critic, and a person for whom being cultivated was neither aspirational nor a privilege, but an innate, human virtue. She is survived by her sons Pierre, of St. Alexandre, France, and Nicolas and Michael of New York City; her nieces Valerie Schroth of Westport, CT, and Lisa Devon Kirkley of Alexandria, VA; and nephews Eric Perret of Milford, CT and Andrew Perret of Brooklyn, NY; and her beloved grandchildren Alexander, Coco, Clara, Nicholas and Ida. "La mer, la mer, toujours recommencee..." -Paul Valery

NEW YORK'S musical offerings are so abundant in some periods that it is possible to design your own micro-festival. This week offers an opportunity to do so with Bartok orchestral works. Two of his greatest and most crowd-pleasing big pieces, filled with virtuosic solo displays in the various orchestra sections, are on offer -- and at pleasing prices. On Sunday at 4 p.m. the AMERICAN SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA presents his Concerto for Orchestra as part of its Classics Declassified series. The music director, Leon Botstein, will give a talk about the work before the performance, which will be followed by a question-and-answer session. Peter Jay Sharp Theater at Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, (212) 864-5400, symphonyspace.org; $25. Then, in a free performance on Thursday at 8 p.m. the JUILLIARD ORCHESTRA plays the ''Miraculous Mandarin'' Suite, under the baton of Robert Spano, along with Sibelius's Symphony No. 7 and two works by the great Canadian composer Claude Vivier, who was murdered in 1983 at the age of 34. Alice Tully Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 769-7406, juilliard.edu; free tickets at the Juilliard box office.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''All Too Often, a Sorry State of Affairs,'' April 23: Although the Nets did not provide many wonderful moments for their fans, they actually provided us with a lifetime of memories.

Feb. 2, Oxford, England I came across the Godstow Nunnery while on a shoot near Oxford at the end of a bitterly cold day of rain and wind. The light was drawing in, but it had an unusually luminous quality to it, and it was the play of that light on the side of the building and in the windows that drew me to making this shot. There were some geese nesting nearby, and a group of males set off through the frame. Others followed at a more leisurely pace, and it was at that point that I took the picture. Just to my left, out of the frame, runs the River Thames, and while I was there, I got to chatting with a guy living on a houseboat that he had moored next to the nunnery. He told me that the large, semi-mobile houseboat community that lives in and around Oxford were subject to new restrictions and mooring charges in an effort to move them from the view of tourists and the upwardly mobile and vowed there would be a fight back. The mixture of the elements of light, the ancient setting and the talk of resistance made it, in my mind, a quintessentially English scene. ANDREW TESTA, freelance photographer, London

THE Massachusetts Transportation Department announced last week that it would make special license plates available for purely electric, plug-in hybrid and regular hybrid vehicles, becoming the second state, after Hawaii, to do so. The optional plates, which cost $20 with no annual fee, feature the letters EV, or EC for commercial vehicles, and a graphic of a car with a plug. Last year, after reports of fires involving the batteries of the Chevrolet Volt plug-in hybrid that had been subjected to crash tests, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration urged automakers to develop postcrash procedures for their E.V.'s.
INTERNATIONAL IN TURKEY, FEARS OF RETREAT
